column2: A group of home builders has purchased eighty-three acres of land on Ocean Avenue in Northport, L. I., which will be developed with about 100 dwellings. The site overlooks Northport Harbor and has beach frontage on Northport Bay.
TELEVISION experienced one of its finer half-hours yesterday with a one-woman performance of "Everyman," the fifteenth-century morality play that became a transitional form of drama.
As a footnote to Saturday evening's rained-out concert at Lewisohn Stadium, it might be mentioned that at intermission Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer made a speech.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Stock Exchange business was affected last week by imminence of the August bank holiday -- which begins what amounts to a national holiday period -- but the markets gave another demonstration of their inherent strength.

The forthcoming Anglican Congress, commencing Wednesday in Minneapolis, was hailed yesterday as a "landmark in the history of the Anglican Communion" by Archbishop Arthur William Barton of Dubin, Church of Ireland (Anglican).

NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Mayor Leo P. Carlin and a group of aides and officials sat for an hour tonight on a private lawn here listening carefully for low-flying planes. All they heard was deep -- and, to many of them, disturbing -- silence.

Lives will be saved and injuries will be avoided if serious consideration is given to the point made by the president of the Columbia University Optometry Alumni Association in his letter published on July 19.

In World War II Ronald Seth was "hanged" as a spy, but he has lived to describe his experiences at the hands of the Germans in "A Spy Has No Friends." He began his espionage activities for the British in Estonia. After his capture and hanging he persuaded his captors to groom him for espionage work among the Allies and thus returned to his country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- President Rhee, speaking earlier from the puipit of the Methodist Church he had joined almost half a century ago, declared the righteousness of his cause and said he was not afraid to drive the Communists from his country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Major foods will be in larger supply for the grocers' shelves and prices to the housewife will drop slightly during the rest of 1954, the Africulture Department predicted today.

All is not yet sweetness and light in the controversial efforts of the National Sugar Refining Company to erect an illuminated advertising sign across the East River from the United Nations. Although the Board of Standards and Appeals by a 3-to-1 vote approved the company's application to put the sign up, the Citizens Union now has made known its intention to question in court the board's right to take action.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Joseph J. (Specs) O'Keefe, once named a prime suspect in the $1,219,000 Brink's robbery, refused today to discuss the June gangland shooting in which the police said he evidently suffered wounds over the heart and on the wrist.

UPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Stone Webster Engineering Corporation will plan and construct the building and supporting facilities for the 25,000,000,000-electron-volt proton synchrotron to be built at the Brookhaven National Laboratory site here.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 1 (UP) -- The top-seeded entry in the boys' singles and the second-seeded player in the junior singles won the national junior and boys' tennis championships today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $81,509,113,652. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. called on the public yesterday to help combat the malicious false alarm evil. Two firemen whose ladder truck was returning from a false alarm were killed in a collision Saturday night in Queens.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- The Soviet Union opened its biggest country fair today on a sixty-six-acre site in northern Moscow.
Thanks for your "Warning on Colonialism" on the editorial page of July 29, and for Prof. Felix Oppenheim's letter about our attitude toward President Rhee.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that New York was "on the verge of becoming a community of violence and crime" because its police force was undermanned and underpaid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- William F. Knowland, the Senate Majority Leader, said tonight that debate on the motion to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, would "not be allowed to drag on."

MEXICO CITY, July 20 -- Of course it is possible to find Mexican food in Mexico, just as you can find some good English restaurants in London if you look hard enough. But for the most part, the best restaurants of Mexico City are cosmopolitan and prepared to hold their own against the offerings of any other capital.
The policeman who arrested an errant soldier and the magistrate who sentenced him vied for the honor of paying his fine yesterday. The magistrate won, and the soldier was spared a day in jail.
A feeble cold front passing through the city from the north yesterday morning brought a slight break in the summer's longest hot spell.

Among its other effects, the violent discussion over the link between cigarette smoking and health caused advertising costs for such smokes to go up in 1953 a little more than 26 per cent over the 1952 figure.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 1 -- Dutch and Belgian economies are gradually drawing closer to each other.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period July 25 through July 31:

Now that the omnibus revenue bill has passed both Houses, we may expect that the Administration will again press for action on another important piece of fiscal legislation -- one that the first session of the Eighty-third Congress left behind as unfinished business when it adjourned just a year ago tomorrow.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 1 -- A crowd of Vietnamese demonstrators officially estimated at 1,000 to 2,000 was dispersed here today following a half-hour "peace" parade. The parade ended when Vietnamese police fired warning shots into the air and arrested 130 marchers.

PARIS, Aug. 1 (UP) -- This was a sad day for those Paris motorists who drive by the horn and let the fenders and pedestrians fall where they may. Their bad driving manners became a thing of the past, by municipal decree if not in actual fact.
City Councilman Edward A. Cunningham urged yesterday that the Democratic platform include a plank calling for a referendum on the question of legalizing bingo, lotteries and off-track betting.

Arrangements for American marketing of handicrafts and other goods produced by modest enterprises in underdeveloped and needy areas of the world were announced over the week-end by a new subsidiary of CARE, the international welfare organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The American Medical Association denied here today that it was engaged in an "anti-veteran crusade," as charged in New York yesterday by Arthur J. Connell, national commander of the American Legion.

The Maritime Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced yesterday that it was pressing its protest to the State Department against a "tough" policy of Vietnamese customs officials with American merchant seamen.

The total of gifts and bequests for philanthropy announced for the first six months of this year indicated an increase over 1953 in ten large urban areas, according to the John Price Jones Company, Inc.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- Two hundred delegates from the United States and Canada are expected to be present for the opening session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the American Newspaper Guild tomorrow.

A new $45,000,000 state mental hospital is to be built in the East Bronx on a 124-acre tract near the intersection of the Hutchinson River Parkway with the Bronx and Pelham Parkways. The 4,000-bed institution will be the first entirely new structure of its kind erected in the state since the end of the Second World War, and it will mark the beginning of a $200,000,000 construction program by the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., the supermarket chain that extends from New York to Florida, rang up record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended May 1. Earnings rose 28 per cent on a 19 per cent gain in sales.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower told a newspaper group a few weeks ago that his belief in the freedom of the press needed no defense, that he paid tribute to a free press every Wednesday morning -- meaning his weekly news conference.
The Rev. Dr. Edwin A. Bell declared yesterday that the experience of Christian faith in Europe was helping to alleviate the historic differences between the French and German peoples.

SEVEN ISLANDS, Quebec, Aug. 1 -- One of the greatest capital enterprises in the history of mining moved from the realm of high adventure to the level of workaday commerce yesterday when ore began to move south from here to the steel mills of America.

One of the most efficient deep-sea terminals in the country is taking shape on the long-neglected Hoboken waterfront, and American Export Lines has signed a long-term lease as the sole tenant. It is a massive project involving two new piers of extreme width and capacity and a renovated existing pier of standard finger design.
THURMONT, Md., Aug. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower decided today to prolong his stay in the cool Catoctin Mountains until tomorrow morning.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 1 The Thames River adjacent to Burr's Dock wore a gay, busy yachting look today when most of the contestants for the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise had made their moorings.
Man's surrender to the loving Fatherhood of God was urged yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. McManus in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick' Cathedral. He is a member of the cathedral clergy.

Manhattan Island has been the scene of an amazing variety of magnificent dreams and great aspirations during its three hundred years as a busy community. Many have been realized far beyond the wildest expectations of those who first conceived them; others have faded and vanished away, forgotten and often unrecorded.
Five new films will arrive at first-run theatres this week. The program follows:

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Strong support for the United Nations technical aid program, whose fate is before the United States Senate, came today from a group of prominent United State business men, labor leaders, educators and diplomats.

Riverdale Shopping Center, Inc., headed by Milton Barkin, has arranged a lease with the Food Fair Stores on a supermarket in the Riverdale Shopping Center to be erected on West 235th Street, between Oxford and Johnson Avenues, in Riverdale, the Bronx, Ernest Ramon, broker, negotiated the lease.
ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- Governor Dewey today ordered a "fresh look" at the state's income tax law, with an eye toward relief for working mothers and the aged, sick or infirm.
The police arrested twenty persons last night in the third nightly round-up of undesirables in the Times Square area.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Wally Ulrich of Rochester, Minn., won his first major golf tourney today, carding a final-round 66 for a seventy-two-hole meet record score of 268 in the $20,000 Kansas City open tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The nation's railroads, losing money on passenger traffic, are asking state agencies all across the country to let them abandon unprofitable passenger services.

City officials have come to the conclusion that the Manhattan Bridge, built in 1909 for a less populated and more leisurely era, is so heavily burdened that it should be rehabilitated. A little more than a year ago the Public Works Department discovered that rapid transit trains, heavily loaded and using predominantly the north side of the bridge, were causing a twisting effect that was straining the span.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The International Congress of the American Church Union, an unofficial group of the Episcopal Church, opened tonight at the Chicago Stadium with solemn evensong services attended by 10,000 persons.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Record-breaking performances set the pattern yesterday for the greatest opening-day efforts in the 24-year history of the British Empire Games.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Marlon Brando agreed today to lift his voice in song as Sky Masterson in "Guys and Dolls."

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton posted a straight-set victory over Billy Talbert, United States Davis Cup captain from New York City, to win the sixty-fifth annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today.

The job of directing "Cindy and Sam," a musical with a tongue-in-cheek attitude toward the Cinderella legend, has been offered to an eminent Savoyard, Martyn Green. He admitted receiving the bid and was mulling it over. Up to now, Mr. Green's directorial experience embraces the staging of "Charley's Aunt" in India and Gilbert and Sullivan.
Competing airlines enjoyed a bonanza of extra passengers yesterday as the strike of 1,200 pilots continued against American Airlines.

PARIS, Aug. 1--Government experts stressed today that the plan for "reconversion" of the French economy, for which Premier Pierre Mendes-France on Thursday obtained Cabinet approval, aims to readapt French industries and manpower uses in the future.
The monthly business letter of the National City Bank of New York, published today, says that in both consumer and in defense goods lines business appears to be picking up.

The United Parents Associations announced yesterday that its president, Mrs. Lillian Asche, had asked Arthur Levitt, president of the city's Board of Education, to hold public hearings in the board's study of a single salary schedule for teachers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 12 to 1, for his fifteenth triumph of the year, after the White Sox had taken the first game of a double-header, 6 and 5, today.

Gross income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries set a new high for any half-year period in the company's history with a total of $499,072,164 for the six motnhs ended June 30. Net income climbed 20 per cent to $36,515,125 from $30,279,126 in the corresponding period a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- Representatives of India, Canada and Poland, the three nations constituting the armistice supervisory commission for Indochina, decided today to send an advance team there for on-the-spot study.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee released a staff report today charging that United States military aid was helping the British develop commercial jet planes to compete with American airliners.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The Saratoga Association for the Improvement of the Breed of Horses will open its eighty-sixth mid-summer race meet here on the morrow.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 -- A 2-1 victory in the nightcap, in which Eddie Lopat was called upon to be a relief pitcher for the first time this season, gave the Yankees a sweep of today's double-header with the Baltimore Orioles.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 1 -- German research into the theory of rocketry will be resumed officially this year in Stuttgart, where an institute is being organized by Dr. Eugen Sanger, a former German rocket expert. Until recently he was employed by the French at the Arsenal Astronautique near Paris.

Despite depressed market conditions in the world's tanker industry, the United States flag fleet of such carriers continues to be the largest under any national flag, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

Now that Guatemala is no longer front-page news some reconsideration of our role there, and its unanticipated consequences, may be remarked. The situation from the American viewpoint is indeed anomalous.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Dave Cole of the Cubs pitched hitless ball until one man was out in the eighth inning to beat Pittsburgh, 12 -- 2, on two hits in the second game of a double-header. Dick Littlefield blanked Chicago, 2--0, on three hits in the opener.
Parents of mentally handicapped children may be interested in the following booklet published recently:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Communist powers are now attempting to lull the free world into a false sense of security by reducing their "more obvious expansionist pressures," Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, said today.

VIENNA, Aug. 1 (UP) -- The Warsaw radio said today that the Communist Polish Government in a note to the United States charged that two American fighter planes had attacked two Polish ships off Hainan Island in the South China Sea.

The men's clothing industry operated at 73 per cent of capacity during the first half of 1954, compared with 87 per cent a year earlier and 68 per cent in the corresponding 1952 months, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

At a moment when the questions of restoring Germany's sovereignty, rearming her and bringing her into the Western community of nations are driving toward decision, note must be taken of certain elements within Germany which appear bent on compromising her position and reviving doubts as to German adherence to the West and Western standards.
ALICE, Tex., Aug. 1 -- Citizens of Texas' lush Lower Rio Grande Valley are waging a war of nerves against the Federal Government's round-up of Mexican "wetbacks."

BERLIN, July 21 -- West German illustrated magazines with far more readers than any other news media, delve so extensively into the Nazi period and into World War II that they are a cause of uneasiness to the Western Allies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- Representatives of twenty national groups will press for prompt Federal aid for school construction at a meeting tomorrow with Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, Federal education commissioner, it was announced today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1 -- The shortage of electric power has been recognized now as probably the biggest single impediment to Brazil's industrial development.
She might easily be taken for one of her own models. She is blond and on the petite side, and wears bouffant skirts that stress the smallness of her waist. She is Madelein Fauth.

Labor-management relations in the Italian shipping industry are stable and labor prospects are steadily improving, according to Admiral Raffaele De Courten, president of Lloyd Triestino, one of the four leading Italian ship lines.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Angry French colonists demanded a quick death today to Premier Pierre Mendes-France's offer of internal autonomy to Tunisia. In near-by Morocco, where nationalists also want freedom from French rule, six persons were killed in a new wave of incidents.
Little volume and low rates characterized the charter market last week.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The sixteenth program of the Berkshire Festival, given this afternoon by the Boston Symphony Orchestra conducted by Richard Burgin, was the most symphonic program of this season.

PREDICTING a record performance in advance of a race usually is the surest way to apply the brakes to the fastest runners. Nevertheless, the feeling persists in this corner that Saturday's duel between Roger Bannister of England and John Landy of Australia in the British Empire Games at Vancouver, B. C., holds exceptionally bright prospects for a further reduction of the world record for the mile run.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Air National Guardsmen of the New York metropolitan area converged on Hancock Field by plane and automobile today for two weeks of training in gunnery and low-level bombing.

Persisting drought conditions tended to keep cotton futures prices firm in the week just ended, with contracts for the active months closing on the New York Cotton Exchange at from 25 to 85 cents a bale above the week before. All contracts except distant December touched new highs.

Walter W. and George W. Naumburg offered their third free concert of the summer to the people of New York Saturday night in Central Park. The evening was the anniversary of the death of their father, Elkan Naumburg, who donated the bandshell in which the fifty-piece symphony orchestra played.

Charles W. Halloran, Fire Commissioner of Buffalo, who is being advanced for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic state ticket by a group of union leaders within the American Federation of Labor, said yesterday that he was receptive to the proposal.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 -- Israel has accepted three proposals for preventive measures to improve the situation along the border with Jordan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today. The steps were suggested recently by Britain, the United States and France.

It is hard to understand why President Eisenhower should have yielded to the protectionist demands of a few watch manufacturers by stiffly raising the tariff on Swiss watch movements. No good can come from this measure which violates American economic tradition as well as the principles widely proclaimed by the Administration itself.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 1 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan has proposed a defensive pact embracing the western Indian Ocean area and has suggested a military guarantee should be given by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers to South Africa.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 1 -- A grudging, no-quarter fight for the Republican gubernatorial nomination and for control of the Kansas G. O. P. organization will reach its climax Tuesday in the state primaries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Supreme Court will sit in judgment during its October term upon a device that the Government has used effectively to catch taxpayers for more than a decade.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 2 -- An executive committee of rocket experts at the International Astronautical Federation meeting here has been trying to frame a program midway between what has been aptly described as "Utopia and reality."

A generally lower trend prevailed on the local commodity exchanges yesterday in moderately active trading. Losses were registered by sugar, coffee, rubber, tin, zinc, cottonseed oil and potato futures, while wool tops, cocoa and silk bucked the down trend.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Eisenhower nominated C. Canby Balderston of Pennsylvania today to be a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Marlon Brando, dressed in full regalia for his role of Emperor Napoleon, whistled his own accompaniment as he did a competent time-step today on the set of Twentieth Century - Fox's "Desiree."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Eisenhower approved the Housing Act of 1954 today. Although it fell somewhat short of his requests, he called it "a major advance toward meeting America's housing needs."

In the story reporting action in the House of Representatives on the Foreign Aid Bill one fact stood out sharply: The largest vote recorded on the bill or any proposed amendment to it was 71 to 100, with other votes quoted: 63 to 98, 14 to 86, 34 to 100.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union asserted today that Dr. Otto John, former West German intelligence chief, had had "no access to secret matter, the revelation of which would endanger the security of the Federal Republic."

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Aaron Copland has been making changes in his opera, "The Tender Land." At least two of these revisions were in the work as it was performed here tonight at Tanglewood by the Opera Department of the Berkshire Music Center, and while they do not alter the musical profile of the piece, they do make a difference to the story.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 2 -- "Liberation" forces marched yesterday at the Army parade grounds, where many received decorations for valor in the recent revolution.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The United States and Britain have reached full agreement about the role of the Royal Air Force in the event of war.
New York City has 42 per cent more policemen in proportion to its population than has the United States as a whole. There is one police employes for each 380 persons in the city.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metals Company, faced with a strike of 2,500 workers and a threatened walkout of 7,500 more, said today it had resumed contract talks with the United Steelworkers Union, C. I. O.

With stock price averages at their best level in a generation, John Q. Public is showing increased interest in the stock market. As a result, the Big Board commission houses are doing better than they have in some time. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange is running about 35 per cent ahead of that in 1953, and the 2,500,000 to 3,000,000 share day seems to be in vogue again.

ON the grounds of the Augusta National Golf Club last April the Masters tournament was in progress. Bob Jones, the club's illustrious president, was seated in his cottage close to the tenth fairway. Suddenly he heard a roar that shook the photographs on the wall. "I'm willing to bet," said Jones with a smile, "that Billy Joe Patton has done something unusual."

An American edition of Frans G. Bengtsson's "The Long Ships: A Saga of the Viking Age" will be issued Sept. 13 by Knopf. The story is about the Vikings of the tenth centry and in particular the son of a famous pirate. It has been translated from the Swedish by Michael Meyer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The debate in the Senate on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has proved one thing: that the Wisconsinite is still a very influential man in the United States Senate.

When President Eisenhower refrained from reappointing Gordon Clapp to be Chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority it was understood that he and Mr. Clapp did not wholly agree in their opinions about public power. It seemed that Mr. Clapp was more enthusiastic about developing and extending T. V. A. than Mr. Eisenhower was, even though the President explicitly stated that he intended to sustain T. V. A. as it was and is.
Lower taxes enabled the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries to lift their net income to $152,150,633 in the first half of this year from $114,758,444 in the 1953 period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- One hundred ninety-two contract bridge pairs today played the final qualifying session of the 1954 life masters pair championship, most important pair event in the American Contract Bridge League's annual national chamships.

Twelve hundred and forty-two persons -- 80 per cent of them women -- took a written test yesterday for jobs as school crossing guards in the Bronx. The examination was held at Taft High School, 230 East 172d Street, the Bronx.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- British exporters were told here last week that in many respects the psychology of the United States customer was more foreign to the British than that of the western European or Commonwealth buyer.

CENTEREACH, L. I., Aug. 2 -- The school houses in this Suffolk County town next fall may really be houses, if the Board of Education is able to work out its plan for dealing with the zooming school enrollment.

The summer weekend should by all logic be the creme de la creme of vacation freedom, the whipped cream in the iced coffee of luxurious idleness. When, however, Saturdays and Sundays are bounded on each side by working days rather than by carefree holidays, the summer week-end sometimes turns out to be little more than a tantalizing glimpse of an earthly paradise operated primarily for the benefit of other people.

In other parts of the civilized world the bicycle is a recognized and accepted thing, like a human being or a flying saucer. But New York, it seems, does not want bicycles, human beings or flying saucers. It is a city built for catering to the automobile, offering far better facilities to the cars within its gates than to its citizens.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 2 -- Prime Minister Sir John Kotelawala proposed today that the Colombo powers confer soon on a policy toward a British invitation to take part in a Southeast Asia defense organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the third day of Senate debate today on the resolution of Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Tuesday, Aug. 3 -- The State Police dispatched patrols to four Middlesex County towns early today after numerous residents had telephoned that they had been awakened by a mysterious explosion.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Considerable heaviness was in evidence in the entire grain list on the Chicago Board of Trade today, with soybeans weakest, followed by corn.
The United Fruit Company will resume its passenger service from New Orleans to Guatemala on Aug. 12. Kenneth H. Redmond, president of the company, announced yesterday in Boston.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 2 -- Tahar Ben Amar, a moderate Nationalist, became Premier today of the first Tunisian regime empowered to negotiate with France for self-government.
MALONE, N. Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Three of four white men who the St. Regis Indians say are "intruders" today were ordered by the Franklin County Court to leave the tribe's reservation at Hogansburg.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 2 (AP) ---Officials of the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers at the Studebaker CorpOration announced today that members would vote this week on a wage adjustment proposal that would lower their basic.pay by 20 per cent.
The possibility that the pilots strike that has grounded American Airlines since Saturday might spread to United Airlines was indicated yesterday.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 2 -- Disgruntled Guatemalan Army regulars rushed to the aid of brawling military cadets with mortars and tanks today and forced Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, Provisional President, to disband his revolutionary "Liberation Army" in a day-long revolt.
Textron, Inc., giant textile company, yesterday purchased about 42 per cent of the common stock of Robbins Mills, Inc., representing working control of that company, from J. P. Stevens Co.

The conflicts and duplications of the 1,800 separate agencies which raise money from New Yorkers for charitable causes, and the confusions of those faced with this criss-cross fire of appeals, urgently call for thorough study and further concerted efforts toward their mitigation -- as recent articles in this newspaper have convincingly shown.

In the July 29 dispatch from London it is stated that the British Government intends to give Cyprus a new Constitution in the pattern of Britain's African and Asian colonies and that the Minister of State in the Colonial Office, Henry L. Hopkinson, as well as the outgoing Colonial Secretary, Oliver Lyttelton, declared, in reference to the island's future, that certain Commonwealth territories "never expected to be fully independent."

IN the 1954 edition of the British "Who's Who," Group Capt. Douglas Robert Stewart Bader lists his recreation as golf and his handicap as six. Although a handicap as low as six is beyond the skill of ninety-nine out of 100 golfers, most men would not mention it in a reference book. But Captain Bader has good reason to.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to consider disciplinary action against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy before the summer adjournment, expected in about two weeks.

With the bases filled and one out in the thirteenth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, Billy Cox, a ninth-inning substitute, hit a sacrifice fly that gave the Dodgers a 2-1 victory and snapped the Milwaukee Braves' winning streak at ten games.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The sharp cleavage in the British labor unions over the proposal to rearm West Germany was highlighted today with the publication of the agenda for the eighty-sixth annual session of the Trades Union Congress to be held in Brighton Sept. 6 to 10.
Domestic steel-making activity was expected to pick up slightly this week in the wake of last week's decline.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 2 -- The biggest question mark hovering over the Iranian oil settlement today is its effect on other Middle East oil-producing states.

Prices of industrial shares, as measured by The New York Times price index of twenty-five representative issues, reached yesterday their best level since Oct. 25, 1929, the day before "Black Tuesday."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board received a recommendation today that the Labor Youth League be declared a Communist front.
Thirty-five thousand unionized hotel workers in New York will receive wage rises totaling $4,500,000 a year under an arbitration award yesterday.

Floyd Patterson, Brooklyn light heavyweight, scored a technical knockout over Tommy Harrison of Los Angeles in 1:29 of the first round of the main event listed for eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the Iberia Airlines of Spain be authorized to operate between Madrid and New York City.
Arnold Constable started off yesterday the parade of back-to-college showings that will take place during the next two weeks. A full roster of the season's most endorsed trends was presented.
The Ohio Oil Company reported yesterday a net income of $19,493,031 for the first half, or $2.97 a common share. This compares with $20,399,931, or $3.11 a share, in the first half of 1953.
About $400,000,000 of bank money was drained out of the New York market yesterday as an end result of Treasury, Commodity Credit Corporation and Federal Reserve operations.
Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight champion, and Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati will meet again for the title in a listed fifteen-rounder at the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night, Sept. 15.

HARWICH, England, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The owners of a little French fishing trawler argued today with the owners of the sea-going British tug Turmoil over the salvage rights of a smoldering Norwegian freighter, abandoned by her crew in the North Sea yesterday.

Manufacturers of nationally advertised branded items still have a long way to go after an advertisement is written and placed. This observation was made by several speakers and roundly seconded yesterday at a soft goods packaging and merchandising clinic put on by McCall's Magazine at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- London's police force, with headquarters at Scotland Yard, is below strength and worrying about it, but crime figures do not show any appreciable deterioration in public safety.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- A former Painters Union official told House investigators today it had been "common-practice" for contractors to pay bribes to union officials in the Washington area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- While farm food prices have fallen 20 per cent since 1951, consumers have benefited very little in the retail market, the Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives reported today.

It was on to Cleveland and three shots at the league-leading Indians for the Yankees last night. Casey Stengel and his defending champions, trailing the Tribe by two and a half lengths, rode the rails to Ohio after they had spent yesterday resting here.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Tahar Ben Amar was born in Tunis in November, 1885, the son of a middle-class family. After studying at the Carnot School he turned to agriculture and was among the leaders in the use of modern equipment in that area.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 -- Friedrich Gulda, the Austrian concert pianist, had to share his interpretation of Beethoven's "Emperor" concerto last night with a piano tuner.

Philip O. Grant has been elected vice president in charge of sales and customer relations of the Fred. Gretsch Manufacturing Company, manufacturers and wholesalers of musical instruments. He previously was general sales manager.

The Uniformed Firemen's Association and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association have jointly offered a $500 reward for the arrest and conviction of the person responsible for the false alarm that brought death to two firemen and injury to nine others Saturday night in Queens.
The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical revival, "Carousel," will end its engagement at the City Center on Sunday night. By that time, it will have completed a ten-week engagement.

Business in New York City's department stores in July was 1 per cent less than in the same month a year ago, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times. This comparison was of the sales of eleven stores, and excludes figures of one store which has gone out of business since last year.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., prepared today to tighten its policy in regard to Communists, but it also reiterated the belief that news writers should be allowed publicly to espouse controversial views.

Dr. Ralph Barton Perry, professer Emeritus of Philosophy at Harvard, denied yesterday a charge by Louis Budenz, former managing editor of The Daily Worker, that he had been a member of the Communist party.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2 -- Of the twenty states represented in the annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation starting at the Roosevelt Hotel here tonight New York has entered fourteen players, including Nicolas Rossolimo, former champion of France.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 2 -- A report published today in The Yale Law Journal asserted that the American Medical Association had excessive authority over the practice of medicine. It charged the association with failure to use this authority as an "instrument of progress"
Mayor Wagner backed Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams yesterday in his urgent plea for an enlarged police force.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 2 (UP) -- Jon Hendricks and Lorraine Crapp, two of Australia's brightest swimming stars, won the men's and women's 110-yard freestyle races today to lead their country in the British Empire Games swimming competition.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Brig. Gen. Herbert Davis Vogel, an engineering expert on water problems, was chosen today to be the chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
George H. Stevenson has been named general sales manager for Utica-Mohawk Cotton Mills of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy presented to the Senate today a letter he said was written by a former Secretary of War. Harry O. Woodring, in which the latter bitterly castigated General of the Army George C. Marshall.
ROME, Aug. 2 -- An Italian-Yugoslav agreement on Trieste was believed to be near today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The White House said today that the National Security Council had not reached a final decision on a new military manpower plan.
Trading in cotton futures was slow on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices declined 5 to 11 points.

No one who appreciates high adventure in the struggle of man against nature can help but be stirred by the Ungava saga, whose first chapter has now been triumphantly concluded. For a half century men had known that some of the world's richest deposits of iron ore were located in the wild, frozen and desolate Ungava region of northern Quebec.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Bob Turley limited the Philadelphia Athletics to five hits tonight for his eighth victory of the season, 10 -- 2, as the Baltimore Orioles took the first of a three-game series.

NEWARK, Aug. 2 -- Meyer C. Ellenstein, a former Mayor who was instrumental in the creation of the Newark Airport, said today that he would initiate action tomorrow to have the huge air field closed permanently.
RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- The 20-year-old granddaughter of Thomas N. McCarter, public utility magnate and founder of the Public Service Corporation, ended her life early today by drinking weed killer.
Two large manufacturers of chemicals, the General Aniline and Film Corporation and the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, announced plans yesterday for expanding production facilities.

Persons active in behalf of the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children have taken over the performance of the new production of "On Your Toes" on the night of Oct. 19 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre to raise funds for the organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A strange turn in the Senate debate on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today brought a statement by Senator Wayne Morse that President Truman had permitted him to use a "top secret" document in the 1952 Presidential campaign. This document, dated Sept. 26, 1947, set forth the recommendation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, of which General Eisenhower was a member, that American troops be withdrawn from South Korea.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 -- The number of West German workers campaigning for a new wage scale and a reasonable share in the country's prosperity swelled to approximately 4,000,000 during the week-end.

TANGIER, Aug. 2 -- With the gradual hardening of most of the European currencies, Tangier's free foreign exchange market has fallen into a slump. Only large operators, who can do business on a very small margin of profit, are attracted by the rates being quoted here.
The free world has lost a real friend in the death of Nguyen Huu Tri, former Governor of North Vietnam, Indochina.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Following is the text of a declaration adopted here today by the American Assembly:

The President's recent action in raising the tariff on imported watches and watch movements must be counted as one of those measures which are not only a net loss to the general welfare but also an unnecessary loss.
The grand jury is a more adequate tool of justice than a legislative investigating committee, a conference on law enforcement at New York University was told yesterday.

The Charles P. Daly Medal of the American Geographical Society has been awarded to Dr. John Kirtland Wright, geographer and historian, for his contributions to science. The announcement of the honor was made yesterday by Dr. Charles B. Hitchcock, director of the society.

An excellent ingredient in many summer sandwiches is that dark, sour-flavored bread known by its German name of pumpernickel. The Germans use the loaf, as do the Danes, in inviting trays of open-style sandwiches, thin pieces of pumpernickel spread with good butter and topped with cheese, smoked salmon, sausage or pate.

TRENTON, Aug. 2 -- Any possibility of increasing New Jersey's admittedly inadequate supply of potable water in the near future appeared doomed tonight. The State Legislature failed to reach an agreement on a bill calling for a bond issue to finance the construction of new reservoirs, and then adjourned until Nov. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Eisenhower designated 102 counties in Missouri and Oklahoma today as drought disaster areas and announced details of a special feed grain program to aid farmers in these areas.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- For the Saratoga Association, which dates back to 1864, and for Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who dates back to '74, this was a fine day of horse-racing at a spot where racing has an extra-special charm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Following is the 75-12 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight referred to a select committee the resolution by Senator Ralph E. Flanders and all amendments to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

There's more than one way to beat the heat, even when one does not have an air conditioner. Color, for example, is more than just an eye pleaser. It is also one of nature's air-conditioning gifts, according to recent findings of the Color Research Laboratory of the Sun Chemical Corporation.

A recent marked decline in the price of green peppers, which brought them from a city-wide average of 25 cents a pound to 15 cents, suggests their frequent use in family meals. One unusual way to prepare the vegetable is to braise it with onions in olive oil. Directions follow:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars today denounced the Federal Government and Congress for what it termed their "growing and cynical disregard" for the welfare of veterans and their families.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Boston has an official population of 801,444 and a total metropolitan population of 2,369,986. Thousands more enter the city limits daily for work, shopping and amusements.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 2 -- There were more boats than for any other New York Yacht Club cruise in memory and there was abundance of enthusiasm among the competitors, but one essential ingredient for any sailing race was lacking today. There was no wind. So the opening contest from New London to Dering Harbor here was canceled.

The American Safety Razor Corporation said yesterday that "apparent sabotage," threats of violence and slowdowns by organized employes might force it to move this month from Brooklyn to Virginia rather than next spring, as planned.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 2 -- John Snedeker's North Star of the Bellport Bay fleet managed to drift across the finish line under the required three and one-half hour time limit today to take the Star Class honors in the opening day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's race week.
Three of the five shelters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were hampered yesterday by a strike of employes seeking union recognition.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 2 -- Art Larsen, the highest seeded player here, created an hour-long stir at the opening of the Eastern grass court tennis championships today by threatening to withdraw from the tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club and from other tourneys in the East.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Profits of the nation's manufacturing corporations were lower in the first quarter of this year than in the corresponding period of 1953.

" This Is Cinerama," the wide-screen production that has been running successfully in major cities throughout the country, will have its first overseas showing in September as part of the official United States representation at the International Trade Fair to be held in Damascus, Syria.
Honor and praise were heaped yesterday by the city on President Syngman Rhee of Korea.

DENVER, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Joseph D. Neff, United States Commissioner, set bond at $100,000 each early today for four top Communists seized together last night one block from the Colorado Capitol building by F.B.I. agents.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Frankie Fernandez, Honolulu welterweight, made his debut in a New York ring last night and won a split decision over Livio Minelli of the Bronx in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 2 -- The World Presbyterian Alliance approved here tonight a statement declaring that the sacrament of holy communion surmounted all man-made barriers, whether they were political, geographic or racial.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 2 -- Morris Wolf, General Council of the Foreign Operations Administration, said today that the United States was prepared to give more economic aid to South Vietnam if it can be used "profitably and advantageously."
STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 2 -- Eight well-prepared Girl Scouts shouldered hefty rucksacks at Fox Gap in the Kittatinny Mountains today and started their part of the biggest hike in Scout history.

BRUSSELS, July 28 -- As an American journeys through Europe in this summer of general economic recovery one impression increases in direct ratio to the number of informed persons with whom the discussion is of United States foreign policies and the relations of these countries with our own.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Wheels were put in motion by Westchester officials today for a referendum in November on a pollution reduction program for the Hudson River to cost $12,000,000 to $15,000,000.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Roy Sievers blasted his eighteenth and nineteenth home runs of the season tonight, driving in five runs for the Washington Senators in an 11-to-6 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 13,117 fans at Briggs Stadium.

A block of 233,974 shares of common stock of Northern Illinois Gas Company, former subsidiary of Commonwealth Edison Company, will be placed on the market today by a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today the arrest of two additional alleged Communist party leaders in Colorado, making a total of seven taken into custody in the West in the last twenty-four hours.

A five-story loft and store building on plot 60 by 100 feet at 199-201 Franklin Street, corner of Washington Street, in the heart of the downtown wholesale produce area, has been resold by Edward Schwartz, operator, to an investing client of Marcy Fink, attorney.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- A new emergency regulation in Kenya's campaign against the anti-white Mau-Mau terrorists will go into effect tomorrow. It empowers the Government to impose complete evacuation of any area it deems necessary for the public safety and order.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Administration's drive for stronger laws to combat subversion gained ground in Congress today.

The Sheraton Corporation of America enjoyed a record gross and net in the fiscal year ended April 30. Ernest Henderson, president of the nation-wide hotel chain, predicted "another good year" in fiscal 1955.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -- Prime Minister Nehru is understood to have informed British Foreign Secretary Eden that efforts to form the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization would only "increase international tension."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) -- For the second time Dick Haymes, the singer, was ordered deported in an order today by Ralph Farb, special hearing officer of the Immigration Service. The Board of Immigration Appeals in Washington had ordered the case re-opened.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The United States will vote for Prince Wan Waithayakon, Thai Foreign Minister, for president of the United Nations General Assembly next fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The International Association of Machinists announced today that a simultaneous strike against six major airlines had been voted by almost 20,000 members of the union by a margin of more than nine to one.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- The police of this city report a sharp rise in crimes this year compared with 1953. The most notable increase was in crimes of violence, which are traditionally few in number in Japan.

James H. Carmine, formerly executive vice president, has been elected president of the Philco Corporation, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of 1,200 of the company's distributors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He succeeds William Balderston, who becomes chairman of the board, a post to which James T. Buckley declined re-election.

NEWARK, Aug. 2 -- The arrival of twenty-five paintings by Scottish youngsters at the Newark Museum has revealed an interesting difference in approach and emphasis between their methods and ours, Robert Reid, Junior Museum supervisor said this week.
FAIRBANKS; Alaska, July 27 -- Six years ago most of the housing in Alaska was substandard. There was a preponderance of tar paper shacks and lean-tos.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- A rise of almost 50 per cent in the number of burglaries committed in this city during the first six months of 1954, as compared with the corresponding period last year, highlights Chicago's crime picture.
CAIRO, Aug. 2 -- The conditions under which the United States will grant military and economic aid to Egypt were under study today by the Government here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The State Department denied today a charge by the Polish Government that United States aircraft had strafed two Polish merchant ships off Hainan on July 26.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee was reported tonight to be ready to back the allocation of $9,958,000 to the United Nations technical assistance program. This would be sufficient to meet United States commitments through Dec. 31.

It is thirty years ago today that Dr. Sun Yat-sen, influenced by the writing of an American, Dr. Maurice William, made his formal break with the theory and practice of communism and turned the eyes of China toward the free rather than the slave world. In those thirty years the Communist conspiracy has been the enemy of a free China and the enemy of freedom everywhere.
Japan's first passenger ship, built since the war, the Brazil Maru, will arrive in Los Angeles next week on her maiden voyage on the way to South America.
Plastic protective helmets, such as the one that saved Milwaukee's Joe Adcock from serious injury, are worn by a large majority of major league batsmen, according to The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had declined for the first time in seven weeks.

Five foreign-flag steamship lines, operating both passenger and cargo ships out of this port, eventually will be dispossessed as tenant of Piers 1 and 3, Hoboken. The Port of New York Authority last week signed a fifteen-year lease for a modern, three-pier $15,000,000 marine terminal with American Export Lines.

Collectivization of Communist China's 100,000,000 peasant families is to be essentially completed in less than a decade, a Pravda article maintains. Although only 2 per cent of Chinese peasants now belong to collective farms, Mao Tse-tung's regime plans to have 35 per cent collectivized by 1957.

The issues involved in the total immobilization of the vast transport network of American Airlines are of critical importance in an industry that has made fabulous progress in recent decades. Basically, the issues are simple; yet it is difficult for the outsider to weigh the respective positions of the operators and the striking airline pilots and come to a clear decision.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Bunny Chief won the $10,091.42 Ohio Breeders' 2-year-old filly pace as a four-day Grand Circuit meeting opened at the Good Time Oval today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The curtailment of military production was reflected today in a reduction of fourth-quarter steel and copper allocations by nearly half from the military take in the April-June quarter.

CAPT. DICK SCHOLZ' charter boat, the Lillian S II, is a spic-and-span boat, clean as a whistle. Scholz is a big bronzed Joseph Conrad character. He knows the sea and he loves it. And he knows a thing or two about catching big fish.
The cease-fire in Indochina, contrary to many impressions and much comment, does not mean that there are no limited "hot wars" in other areas as part of the "cold war."
PASSAU, Germany, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A West German shepherd dog, trapped in the Danube River floods, seems to have piloted its doghouse through the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Midwest contract bridge pair of David C. Carter of St. Louis and John Hubbell of Kansas City this afternoon forged ahead of a 112-pair finalist field in the 1954 life masters' pair championship.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- Jefferson Medical College and Hospital will receive more than $5,000,000 for blood research under the will of Thomas Drake Martinez Cardeza, Philadelphia art collector, explorer and banker.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- A group of residents of the Berkshire area have joined to establish a fitting memorial to Serge Koussevitzky.

A record net income of $5,509,692 for the first half was reported yesterday by the General American Transportation Corporation. This compares with $3,778,563 earned in the corresponding six months of 1953.

The Rockland Light and Power Company, Nyack, N. Y., reported yesterday that net income for the first five months of this year had amounted to $925,070, representing an increase of 38 per cent over the earnings in the same period of 1953.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- A strike against the three major television networks was called off today by Television Writers of America, an independent union, which had ordered the walkout on July 21.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A woman whose foot was blown off by a land mine as she fled from behind the Iron Curtain with her family was wheeled into President Eisenhower's office today.

In his annual budget message, transmitted last Jan. 21, President Eisenhower renewed a request he had made just before the adjournment of the first session of the Eighty-third Congress a year ago this week. The national debt was then "close to the legal limit of $275 billions."

Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion, and Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati signed formal contracts yesterday for their return title fight, booked for fifteen rounds at Yankee Stadium on Sept. 15.

FOR the last twenty-five years intelligent readers of newspaper headlines have realized that the troubles of a distraught world are not specific and ephemeral, that they are all part of a general crisis of civilization. Fascism, communism, hot and cold wars, tottering democracies, astronomical sums spent on armaments and that mushroom-shaped cloud all are symptoms of a cancerous illness.

H. Daroff Sons, Philadelphia men's clothing manufacturer, has acquired the stock interest of Bankers Securities Corporation in Botany Mills, Inc., of Passaic, it was announced yesterday. Michael Daroff, president of the clothing concern, made the announcement at a meeting of the board of directors of Botany in Passaic.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug 3 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Fred Hall and former United States Attorney George Templar, were almost matching vote for vote today in primary returns for the Republican governorship nomination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Eisenhower signed today the Vocational Rehabilitation Act, which lays a foundation for increasing from 60,000 to 200,000 by 1959 the number of disabled persons rehabilitated each year.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug 3 (AP) -- In less than one hour of trading today, the value of Australian oil stocks tumbled nearly $63,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, behind the six-hit pitching of Warren Spahn, rolled to their eleventh victory in twelve games tonight with a 3 -- 1 conquest of the Philadelphia Phillies.
The Coast Guard marks today two milestones in its history -- the 164th anniversary of its founding and the completion of forty years jurisdiction over the International Ice Patrol.

One of summer's gastronomical treats is the fresh swordfish that is coming to town from waters off Nova Scotia. This 400 to 500-pound giant of the deep, which is harpooned as it comes up to laze near the surface of the water, is cut into thick steaks. These have no bones and a meaty texture and taste.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Arnold Johnson, a Chicago real estate man, said today he had made a "fair and full offer" to buy the Philadelphia Athletics from the Mack family and planned to move the American League team to Kansas City next season.
TOKYO, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- New flags, almost idtentical with those of the defunct Imperial Japanese Navy, were presented today to ships of the new Japanese Navy, called the Maritime Defense Force.
Many troubles in prisons arise because society cannot make up its mind whether it wants to rehabilitate its criminals or punish them, a New York City official declared yesterday.
Old Crow, a National Distillers straight Kentucky bourbon, made this news yesterday:

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Frederick O. Hammer, 46 years old, was convicted today of carrying concealed deadly weapons on the day he shot his heiress wife, from whom he is estranged, at Delaware Park Race Track.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, inspected the United Nations buildings hastily today and then sat down to discuss in more leisurely fashion the major objectives of the organization.
Two new films will open at first-run theatres today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today killed a proposed constitutional amendment that would fix the size of the Supreme Court at nine members and require the justices to retire at the age of 75. The vote was 11 to 8.
Your article on my testimony before the Jenner subcommittee printed in the July 28 edition contains a number of very unfair distortions and several outright misstatements of fact.

Broadway, which hasn't got enough houses to satisfy the demands of the new season, will regain a former legitimate theatre in the fall. The house is the old Guild Theatre, which first opened its doors in 1925 at 245 West Fifty-second Street, and for a time bore the name ANTA Playhouse.

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- An important timetable for negotiations among the principal non-Communist countries on fundamental issues of trade and monetary policy was completed at a strenuous ten-day meeting that was concluded today.

About all that can be said concerning the Senate's action Monday night in the case of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin is that the junior Senator won a tactical victory on one flank and lost on the other flank. Under the direction of Majority Leader William F. Knowland of California the subject of disciplinary action was referred to a committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The United States has sent another protest to Communist China against the attack by Peiping's fighter aircraft on a British airliner over the South China Sea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A "Task Force" composed of four attorneys from the staff of the Federal Trade Commission has been assigned to check up on compliance by business with F. T. C. orders, stipulations and trade practice rules relating to advertising.

As board chairman of the League of Mutual Taxi Owners, with a membership of 2,200 owner-drivers of New York taxicabs, I want to comment on a letter which appeared in The New York Times July 28, signed by Emil A. Dannemann, president of the National Transportation Company.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 3 -- The Massachusetts Federation of Labor adopted today a resolution questioning the "sincerity" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on the basis of his voting record.

Federal aeronautics authorities have warned pilots against making low and hazardous flights over Long Island state parks, according to an announcement yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission.

TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The southbound roadway of the Garden State Parkway will be opened from Woodbridge to Eatontown at noon tomorrow. This will give southbound travelers an unbroken road for eighty miles from Irvington in Essex County to Manahawkin in Ocean County.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 3 (UP) -- England's Chris Chataway, who paced two men to four-minute miles, today captured the three-mile race at the British Empire games and set an Empire record in the process.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3 -- General Burns, who is Canadian Deputy Minister of Veterans Affairs, has been given leave of absence by the Government. He will go to New York next week for consultations with United Nations officials.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- The East German Ministry of the Interior reported tonight the arrest of many agents who it said were employed by the United States and West German intelligence organizations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- June sales of wholesalers showed a gain of $193,000,000 compared with May, the Department of Commerce reported today. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations.

Police Commissioner Adams complains about the shortage of police personnel to combat New York City's growing crime wave. At the same time thousands of his men, highly trained in criminology, are relegated to the positions of mere clerks or timekeepers checking overtime parking.

The Boeing Airplane Company lifted sales by 19 per cent and earnings 90 per cent over a year ago, setting new records for any first half year in the history of the company. The company declared a special dividend of 50 cents along with the regular quarterly distribution, both payable Sept. 10.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today that the military reserve situation would be "a scandal" in the event of war right now.

New York has been having the great pleasure of paying tribute to a great man, a stanch fiend and a most welcome visitor. Korea's President Syngman Rhee and his gracious wife have said repeatedly that they have felt overcome by the warmth of the greeting that has been extended to them.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- The fifty-fifth national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars here reached its high point this afternoon with a colorful parade.
TOKYO, Aug. 3 -- Chinese Communist authorities, diverted for a time by the Indochina truce, are returning their attention to Korean problems.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Aug. 4 -- Scattered, but state - wide returns from yesterday's primaries indicated the nomination of Donald S. Leonard as Republican candidate for Governor of Michigan and of Philip A. Hart as the Democratic candidate for the Lieutenant. Those were the only two state-wide contests.

The wardrobe needs of the suburban housewife, the career girl and the college student were taken into consideration yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue's showing at the Savoy Plaza Hotel. Planned not just for one group but for all fashion-minded women, the presentation made great sense.

Nine of every ten companies whose common stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange paid their owners a dividend in the first half of this year. And these payments, added up to a record $2,966,388,750, according to The Exchange, the Big Board's monthly magazine

PRESTON CITY, Conn., Aug. 3 -- A four-engine trans-Atlantic Air France plane crashed ten feet from a farm house here in heavy rain at 9:56 A. M. today. Even though it ex ploded and burst into flames, all twenty-nine passengers and eight crew members survived. Six passengers and three crewmen were hospitalized.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Montgomery County citizens battled all night to save 4,000 oxygen-starved fish in a private lake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Senate voted today, 45 to 41, to cut the authorization for foreign aid by $500,000,000, but failed to define how the cut should be applied and thus left the final money amount of the bill in doubt.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The top players won't be competing at Tam O'Shanter until the all-American golf tourney starts Thursday, but an unheralded pro posted a 6-under-par 66 to pace today's opening qualifying round.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 6 points lower than on Monday.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, capitalizing on five Baltimore errors, beat the Orioles, 6 -- 2, tonight.
BUFFALO, Aug. 3 -- The sale of the Statler stock also was announced here today by Edwin F. Jaeckle, lawyer for the Statler family. The chain was founded here in 1905.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Still further ground was lost in soybean futures during the session today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Closing time found the market for 5 7/8 to 7 1/8 cents net lower for the session and much nearer the day's bottoms than its tops.

Sales and earnings of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., for the quarter and six months ended on June 30 were less than those of the periods a year ago. Leon Lowenstein, hoard chairman of the textile company, in the report to stockholders yesterday, said unit prices are at the lowest point in many years and profit margins have been squeezed.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- Conrad Hilton announced today that his hotel company had contracted to buy for $37,650,000 a controlling interest in the Statler Hotel chain. It is believed to be the biggest such transaction in hotel history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- The House voted today to slash prices of Government-owned feed grains to aid livestock producers whose feed sources have been dried up by the drought.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- France is expected to quit her two remaining enclaves in India "within the next few days," according to a French foreign affairs official.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Belgium and the United States are working on an agreement under which this country will be able to supply Belgium with technical data for peacetime development of atomic energy after Congress acts on a pending revision of the atomic energy, law of 1946.
Joseph D. Nunan, former United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue, was sentenced yesterday to a five-year penitentiary term and fined $15,000 for income tax evasion.

Politics and religion are the subjects of the only two books published today. "Logical Nonsense" is an informal treatise on politics by Reginald Vowles, and Vantage Press is issuing it at $2. "Windows of Heaven," by Glenn Clark, contains daily meditations for twelve weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I railroads at $224,000,000 for the first six months of 1954, off 46 per cent from the $418,000,000 reported in the first half of 1953.
LOWER forms of life thrive in Times Square than have been caught in police nets in the last few days, but so. far they have slipped through the meshes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Robert E. Minte, a paint contractor here, told a Labor subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that he had paid $1,000 to two union officials because "I felt pretty bad about bawling them out."

KITIMAT, B. C., Aug. 3 -- Another step was taken toward man's conquest of the mountain fastness of western Canada when the first ingot was poured at the new smelter of the Aluminum Company of Canada here today.

Forty-five civic organizations have joined the Citizens Budget commission, a volunteer group, in its request for an "objective study" of the upper Hudson River as an auxiliary source of water supply for the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate tonight tackled one of the biggest supplemental money bills in peacetime history. Democrats charged the Administration with "negligence" and "hokum" for having failed to include several of the items in regular appropriation bills already passed.
A new and simplified tube system of adding colorants to paint was demonstrated yesterday in the Astor Hotel by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.
The second annual Ball of the Roses for the benefit of Roosevelt Hospital will be held on Jan. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
The going was slippery at the Polo Grounds last night and the air heavy. But this in no way slowed the front-running Giants.

TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. said today that George A. Kress, treasurer of the South Amboy Trust Company, had told state investigators he had handled a $300,000 deposit of state disability benefits funds in 1949 on instructions from the late Harold G. Hoffman.

People living in and around the Grant's Tomb neighborhood are asking themselves if a miracle has happened. For years we had been plagued with horrible litter, dirt, rubbish, garbage lying around on the once-beautiful lawns, and with crowds of boys tossing hard balls in every direction, so that mothers did not dare sit with their babies, and children dared not play there.
Margie, a lovely, golden female from the steaming jungles of the Amazon, has left her husband. And this apparent act of marital infidelity has thrown a section of the East Side into a minor uproar.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Billy Hoeft kept the Detroit Tigers in the American League's first division today with a five-hit, 2-to-0 victory over the Washington Senators before 3,682 fans at Briggs Stadium.

The Subversive Activities Control Board's hearings to determine whether the National Council of American Soviet Friendship should be required to register as a Communist front were recessed unexpectedly yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Operators of heavy trucks will be required to buy new state mileage tax plates and permits at $2 a set next January.

A new issue of $18,527,000 of revenue bonds of Public Utility District 1 of Snohomish County, Wash., is being offered to investors today by a banking syndicate headed by A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc.

IT takes all sorts, shapes and sizes of baseball equipment to mold a pennant-winning ball club. Casey Stengel has been proving this for the past five years. Leo Durocher and his Giants are giving a very fine demonstration of it this season as they continue to run the National League ragged trying to keep up with them.

Staying home for the summer has its advantages for parents and children alike when opportunities are available for sharing activities of mutual enjoyment. Such opportunities are provided by the Young Women's Christian Association of Brooklyn in its "stay-at-home" day camp program for girls 10 to 15 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., was asked today to investigate alleged violations of human rights, including the non-employment of Negroes, among the nation's top three wire services.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 3 -- Tahar ben Amar, the Premier-designate of Tunisia, began the task today of forming a Cabinet to regain the internal sovereignty that has been in French hands for seventy-two years.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The stock market here started the week buoyantly today after yesterday's bank holiday. Good gains were recorded in most sections with leading industrial equities, South African gold mining issues and Government securities in solid demand.

The American Assembly, a kind of private Congress founded by President Eisenhower when he was president of Columbia University, and now composed of some sixty representative Americans from many walks of life, has surveyed the American foreign policy and has found it, on the whole, good.
Prices of most commodity futures on the local markets moved irregularly yesterday in moderately active trading. Weakness was shown by tin and zinc, while cocoa futures continued in demand.

OTTAWA, Aug, 3 (Canadian Press) -- Canada considers that any United States tariff increase on hardboard or other wallboards would be a violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), trade officials said today.
St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it had borrowed $73,000,000 from nine insurance companies on twenty- five-year 3 5/3 per cent debentures.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- House of Representatives and Senate conferees worked out today a compromise on the controversial issue of the Federal Government's role in commercial atomic power development.
ALBANY, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A total of 180 new cases of polio has been reported upstate for the first seven months of this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson denied today that purchases of British and other military equipment overseas had been "a flop."
The candy business is dandy, if activity at the National Candy Wholesalers Association show at the Commodore Hotel is any measure.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 3 (UP) -- Mrs. Barbara (Bobo) Rockefeller, who was born a coal miner's daughter, won a $5,500,000 settlement and a Reno divorce today from Winthrop Rockefeller.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Twenty-two Manhattan-bound trains of the Long Island Rail Road were delayed during the morning rush hour yesterday by a short circuit and fire in an express train at the Woodside, Queens, station.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Continuing the production push it began last April, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has confidently announced that the studio would make a minimum of twenty-seven motion pictures during the next twelve months.
INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 3 -- Most of the freakish effects of interplanetary space can now be studied within the atmosphere of the earth.
Michael Wayne, the 30-year-old owner of an eighty-six-year-old restaurant, the Old Homestead, at 56 Ninth Avenue, gave us some ideas yesterday on buying beef and serving steak.
Old fashioned, hand-drawn pumps and hose carriers used long ago by the city's volunteer firemen, were exhibited yesterday at a band concert in Battery Park.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Brookmeade Stable's Tritium has been paying for her oats and hay, and providing a bit extra for carrots and sugar, but she hadn't won since October, 1952, when she went to the post in today's feature at Saratoga.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 3 -- The Vietnamese Government announced tonight that it had established two special courts to deal with cases threatening Vietnam's "national independence" and "public security," particularly with acts aimed at overthrowing the national government.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Robert Moses, as president of the Long Island State Park Commission, denounced today as "land speculators" and "fly-by-night builders" the real estate operators seeking to erect commercial establishments along the Jericho Turnpike in Nassau County.

The United States Committee of the Inter-American Association for Democracy and Freedom and the Post War World Council sent a joint telegram yesterday to John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, protesting against the alleged attempt of President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua to invade Costa Rica.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The White Motor Company today reported earnings of $2,343,706, equal to $2.58 a share, for the first half of 1954. The company earned $1,965,143, or $2.52 a share, in the first half of last year. Sales were $79,461,061, against $77,194,214.

Cargo rates on routes between Japan and the United States will be increased by the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company this week in a new attempt to stabilize the long-depressed Pacific steamship freight business.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Dave Gundy, 13-year-old representative of the defending American Yacht Club, won the first two qualifying races in the Scovill Cup series for the midget sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- The legal question whether Harry Bridges ever was a member of the Communist party was debated again today in Federal District Court.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Nationalist opposition to the "Tunisian independence policy" of Premier Pierre Mendes-France developed today in political party meetings here as it was announced that Tahar ben Amar, moderate leader of the Neo-Destour party had submitted to the Bey of Tunis a new government largely in them hands of that militant party.

Yesterday was the second busiest day Wall Street commission houses have had this year. But while prices on the average moved to their best level for the movement, it was no one-way street for the investing public.
Following are the names of the persons who were aboard the Air France Constellation that crashed at Preston City, Conn.:

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams has suggested to Mayor Wagner that the quickest possible move toward strengthening the police force would be to put his men on paid overtime. The Commissioner's proposal was made in the wake of his hard-hitting report Sunday that the police were undermanned and underpaid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Influential Republican and Democratic members are determined to keep the Senate in session until it passes final judgment on the conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The preliminary reactions at City Hall to Police Commissioner Adams' appeal for a greatly enlarged police force appear to have been moderately favorable but, if we read them correctly, somewhat disappointing, nevertheless. Mayor Wagner is going to look into the matter, and he pledges an increase to exceed the authorized quota of 20,878.
