PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs snapped a four-game losing streak tonight, collecting twelve hits to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 -- 2. Joe Nuxhall had a shutout Until the ninth, when the Pirates pushed across both of their runs.
Three alleged members of an East Harlem narcotics ring were arrested yesterday by Federal agents. Narcotics said to be worth $500,000 at retail in the illicit market were seized.
TWO of the most coveted records in deep sea rod-and-reel fishing now belong to the Marron family (Lou and Eugenie) of New York and Brielle, N. J.

I read with interest the letter from our Canadian friend, P. R. W. Webb, in The New York Times of July 26. His presentation of the argument for recognition of Communist China helps clarify the crux of our differences in viewpoints.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 3 -- New Jersey's Democratic and Republican candidates for the United States Senate publicly discussed labor legislation today. They agreed that the Taft-Hartley Law ought to be amended but differed as to how and when.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 3 -- The Dutch Government is strongly opposed to a United States Senate bill that would authorize the return of seized property to its former German owners. The view here is that the proposal, if carried out, would be a repudiation by the United States of an agreement it had made with its allies.

The Air France pilot who crash-landed his plane in Connecticut yesterday first tried to land at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and then left the metropolitan area while considering another attempt.

VIEWERS who find themselves impatient with television's summer doldrums might try a spot of radio. It won't always be rewarding, but there is an interesting difference in the way the two mediums pace their programs -- radio being much more leisurely.
American Airlines, grounded since Saturday by a strike of 1,200 pilots, filed a $1,250,000 damage suit yesterday against the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France has now entered his second race against the clock. He has begun a study of the European Defense Community treaty, which, like the quest of a truce in Indochina, has a time limit.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 3 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas announced tonight that defiant army units at the near-by Aurora military base had surrendered to an ultimatum by the ruling junta.

I should like to call your attention and that of your readers to a disturbing trend which has developed in many suburban communities and which I believe to be short-sighted, selfish and fundamentally opposed to public policy.
Back in form after his lapse against Milwaukee, Carl Erskine pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 2-1 victory over the Cardinals before 12,073 spectators at Ebbets Field last night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 3 -- A possible Chilean Government sales monopoly of all copper produced by two Anaconda subsidiaries, the Chile Exploration Company and Andes Mining Company, and Kennecott's subsidiary, Braden Copper Company, moved a step forward today.

NEWARK, Aug. 3 -- A civil suit demanding a halt to low-flying airplanes was filed in Federal District Court here today by Newark and the four neighboring communities of Elizabeth, Linden, Union and Hillside.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 3 A. H. Fuller's Bermuda race winner of 1946, Gesture, was the victor among the large sloops and yawls, DeCoursey Fales' famous schooner Nina won in her division and Henry Sears' sloop Actaea scored in Class B in the opening competition of the New York Yacht Club cruise today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today that President Eisenhower had under consideration a directive to the White House staff to double-check action by department heads on Federal Bureau of Investigation security inquiries on Government employes.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 3 -Leslie T. Fossell, 38 years old, who was administrative assistant to Justice Raymond E. Baldwin of the Connecticut Supreme Court when Mr. Baldwin served in the United States Senate, was found dead last night in his home on North Avenue here. His death was listed as a suicide.

WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 3 -- An Air Force jet fighter-bomber crashed and exploded in a street of a thickly populated residential section here at noon today. The pilot was killed, and a man working in front of his home near the crash was critically injured.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein will ask the executive committee of the National Association of Attorneys General to overrule its president, Eugene Cook of Georgia, unless he drops his refusal to ask Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, to address the association's annual convention in December.
The election of Alfred E. Kadell as senior vice president of the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, subsidiary of National Steel Corporation, was announced yesterday.
An inch of rain early yesterday, more than fell in all of July, brought badly needed relief to parched lawns, gardens and farm crops.
The National Sugar Refining Company abandoned yesterday its plan to erect a large illuminated advertising sign across the East River from the United Nations headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The country's loosely knit defenses against air attack will be welded into a single command with the Air Force in charge, probably about Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- State Department policy-makers hope to turn to the advantage of the free world the French defeat in Indochina and the impending British withdrawal from Suez.

CAIRO, Aug. 3 -- The Moslem Brotherhood, fanatical and sometimes terrorist, religious organization, proclaimed today its opposition to all aspects of the recently concluded British-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal zone.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Antoni Klimowicz, 24-year-old Polish refugee who was removed from a Polish vessel here Saturday, has received permission to remain in Britain until Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary, rules on his permanent status.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein will ask the executive committee of the National Association of Attorneys General to overrule its president, Eugene Cook of Georgia, unless he drops his refusal to ask Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, to address the association's annual convention in December.
The election of Alfred E. Kadell as senior vice president of the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, subsidiary of National Steel Corporation, was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Aug. 3 -- The Moslem Brotherhood, fanatical and sometimes terrorist, religious organization, proclaimed today its opposition to all aspects of the recently concluded British-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal zone.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Antoni Klimowicz, 24-year-old Polish refugee who was removed from a Polish vessel here Saturday, has received permission to remain in Britain until Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, Home Secretary, rules on his permanent status.

The New York Philharmonic- Symphony's 113th opening night at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 7 will be transmitted to theatres in other cities by closed-circuit television, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 -- A juvenile court judge here has tapped a new source of advice for solving the juvenile delinquency problem -- the teen-agers themselves.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- To have or not to have a bosom seems to be the fashion question of the hour.

Vacations are usually discussed in terms of places. The travel pages of the newspapers carry advertisements and articles designed to direct one's attention to mountain resorts or seashore resorts; or they point out places of interest on a proposed motor tour, or ports-of-call on a vacation steamer.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 -- Irv Noren singled, Mickey Mantle doubled and Yogi Berra drove both home with a single through the right side. All this happened with none out in the third inning before 60,643 fans at Municipal Stadium tonight and sufriced to give the Yankees a 2-1 victory over the league-leading Cleveland Indians.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 3 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada today was named to replace Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike of Denmark as head of the United Nations truce staff in Palestine.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3 -- Seven New Yorkers, competing among 110 entrants in the fifty-fifth tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, were among the victors in the opening round, concluded today in the University Room at the Roosevelt Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- American President Lines, which five days ago completed arrangements with the Federal Government for a $65,800,000 ship - acquisition program, disclosed today it had purchased controlling interest in the American Mail Line, with headquarters in Seattle.
The sharp decline in unemployment insurance benefit claims in the state continued last week, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday.
PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 3 -- The Christian church must never identify itself with any particular social, economic or political system, the World Presbyterian Alliance declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A security pact linking the United States with Japan, South Korea and Nationalist China has been considered here as a way to strengthen further the defenses of the Far East.

Betty Grable, Harry James and Mario Lanza will be the stars of the first of a series of monthly hour-long musical shows to be sponsored by the Chrysler Corporation over C. B. S. television. The show will be televised in color from Hollywood on Thursday, Sept. 30, from 8:30 to 9:30 P. M.
A smoky fire burned out a ninth-floor room and drove 500 persons from their quarters in the thirty-one-story Park Sheraton Hotel early yesterday. The blaze was attributed to a cigarette smoker.
Officers and crew members of the aircraft carrier Bennington donated 150 pints of blood yesterday in a Red Cross bloodmobile hoisted aboard the vessel in the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Lefty Jack Harshman struck out seven batters and gave five hits tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 6-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 30,062 fans.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Heavy rains drenched Good Time Park today and caused a postponement of the Grand Circuit racing as sixteen speedy 3-year-old trotters awaited the $106,830 Hambletonian classic scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

The Port of New York Authority has completed Portuguese and Spanish-language versions of its film "Via Port of New York," with which it plans to impress on Latin-American shippers the advantages of using this port's vast shipping facilities.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Matthew M. Neely, a Democratic power in West Virginia for more than forty years, rolled on to certain victory early today in his bid for renomination to the United States Senate.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 4 (UP) -- Records were smashed in the British Empire Games swimming competition today while upsets featured the finals of the rowing events with the Duke of Edinburgh looking on from a royal box.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., both were forced to extra sets today before they scored quarter-final victories in men's singles in the international German tennis championships.

Improved lighting is largely responsible for a 41 per cent reduction in traffic accidents on the Avenue of the Americas between Thirty - second and Fifty-ninth Streets in the first six months of the year, Millard Henlein, executive secretary of the Avenue of the Americas Association, declared yesterday.

Gen. Benjamin Franklin Butler (1818-93) is the subject of a biography by Robert S. Holzman, Professor of Taxation at New York University and a charter member of the Civil War Round Table of New York. Macmillan will issue it Sept. 7 under the title "Stormy Ben Butler."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The 1954 life masters pair championship today went to the Midwestern contract bridge pair of David C. Carter of St. Louis, and John Hubbell of Kansas City.

A great deal of enthusiasm, unorthodox tools, colorful scraps of fabric and many willing little hands are the ingredients that make up a summer project for children at the Aguilar branch of the New York Public Library, 174 East 110th Street. A group of youngsters there is being supervised by staff members, headed by Miss Mary...
Chase National Bank is competing aggressively for loans to small business both here and within the service area of out-of-town correspondent banks.

National advertising in the first half of this year, measured in terms of dollars, was 9 per cent greater than in 1953, Printers' Ink reported yesterday. The publication, a weekly magazine of advertising, management and sales, said its general index of advertising set a new high for the year of 173 in June. This compares with the 1935-39 average of 35 and the 1953 average of 158. The 1946 average was 80.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The chief of Britain's projected commercial television network said today that its programs would be produced by two or three big commercial companies working under relaxed official supervision.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. forecast yesterday a shake-up in the top ranks of the Fire Department. He said he wanted to bring about greater efficiency and put men with superior qualifications in supervisory posts.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Nuri al-Said, pro-British leader of the Constitutional Union party, formed a new Cabinet today to succeed the caretaker Government of Arshad al-Umari.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Fifteen thousand public service workers in Hamburg struck this morning for higher wages. It was the first strike of its kind in Hamburg in more than fifty years.
Four persons were under arrest yesterday on a charge of trying to slip a $200,000 collection of diamonds through customs without paying duty.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Aug. 4 (AP) -- State investigators reopened a four-year-old night club slaying today and filed a murder charge against a gambling figure already arrested twice in Phenix City's vice clean-up.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter, aiming to become the first to regain the world light-weight crown twice, advanced on that path tonight with a convincing ten-round decision over Glen Flanagan in a nationally televised bout at the Chicago Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 -- Herbert Hoover, "feeling fine" and looking unusually well for a man of his years, is ending a month's "vacation" on the West Coast and preparing to celebrate his eightieth birthday anniversary next Tuesday at West Branch, Iowa, his birthplace.
The plea for political asylum in this country of Maria Krizanova, 38 - year - old Czechoslovak, has been approved by the Assistant Commissioner of Immigration in Washington.
Retailers can look forward to better business as a result of the recent fashion showings in Paris, according to one of New York City's leading merchants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- The Army announced today that a "corporal" guided missiles battalion would be added to the growing atomic weapons arsenal in Europe to aid in the "defense of the free world."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 -- Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi called on the nation tonight to bar "destructive personal prejudices" in political life and follow the principles of democracy and Iran's Constitution, "which are the only guarantees of progress."

Administrative and technical personnel are still needed by companies throughout the country, according to a study by the American Management Association, released yesterday. This is the reverse of the situation in the top management and middle management job markets, disclosed by earlier studies of such positions.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 4 -- The Pakistan Review, national monthly partly subsidized by the Government, has questioned the advantage of the three-month-old mutual defense assistance agreement under which Pakistan will begin receiving United States military aid in October.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Administration continued today its coolness to a $250,000,000 emergency Federal school construction program.
Confusion in regard to negotiations for a new contract for shipyard workers became compounded yesterday as the union denied the existence of a new agreement with the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

A strong Reserve force is the answer to the swelling economic burden of national defense and the continued threat of "brush fire" wars, Maj. Gen. Roger J. Browne, commandant of the First Air Force, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhowers news conference today. The President's remarks are in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules, except portions authorized for direct quotation by the White House.

PEAPACK, N. J., Aug. 4 -- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Republican of Somerset County, said today that Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, had accepted an invitation to appear on a television program Sunday night to debate with the Senator the merits of a $200,000 appropriation requested by Mr. Meyner.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- According to information here tonight, a hitch in the formation of the Tunisian Government has occurred because of disagreement within the Neo-Destour party.
TOKYO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Japan Rowing Association advised the Cambridge Blues today to stop seeing red because their "old school tie" was being used here. It's all a mistake.
LABOR and capital are organizing in -- of all things -- lawn tennis. At Southampton last week the Tennis players League met in closed session and came up with recommendations for corrective action.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Michigan Republicans yesterday surprisingly picked a professional policeman to oppose Gov. G. Mennen Williams, Democrat, in the November elections.

The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that its new $150,000,000 refinery at Aden on the Arabian peninsula had gone into production four months ahead of schedule. Capable of processing 120,000 barrels of crude oil daily, this new plant brings the company's refining capacity to nearly 600,000 barrels a day.

In a display of what seems to be a combination of good citizenship and enlightened self-interest the National Sugar Refining Company has bowed to public objections and abandoned its intention to erect a large illuminated advertising sign across the East River from United Nations Headquarters.

One of the most important interim tasks left behind by the New York Legislature is the making, in Governor Dewey's words, of "an historic reappraisal of New York State's system of financing public eduation." The Temporary State Commission on Educational Finance, which is to report not later than Feb. 1, while the 1955 Legislature is in session, has a difficult, sweepingly broad assignment.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The stock markets here were active and cheerful again today. Prices rose in virtually every section.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Ray Boone drove home three runs with a double and a single and Wayne Belardi batted in two more with a home run today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 6-to-2 victory over the Washington Senators. Ned Garver went the distance to earn his ninth victory.
Today's new film is "Adventures of Robinson Crusoe," a Mexican-made, English-language version of the Daniel Defoe story, featuring Dan O'Herlihy in the title role, at the Trans-Lux Normandie Theatre.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Elda Earl Webb, 38-year-old apartment house superintendent, was booked on a charge of murder after Dr. Harry M. Ajamian, 48, died this morning at the Jersey City Medical Center. Webb previously had been held on a charge of assault with intent to kill.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Basile Mostras, Greek Ambassador to Britain, delivered a strong protest to the Foreign Office today over the words used by Oliver Lyttelton, former Colonial Secretary, in Parliament last week.

Visitors to this city are often heard to comment that New York is devoid of such qualities as community spirit or civic pride. It is understandable how visitors might gain this impression of our city, for manifestations of community spirit are not so easy to discern here as they are in smaller municipalities.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y. Aug. 4 -- Back on the job after a seven-week rest, C. V. Whitney's 3-year-old Fisherman outran eleven older horses and won first money of $8,975 in the American Legion Handicap today. The game little colt took up 122 pounds and gave weight to all the others.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4 -- Anglican church leaders from every quarter of the earth opened a ten-day Congress here tonight in a vivid demonstration of their common faith and heritage.
Chemical compounds sold in New York State that contain hazardous substances must bear warning labels after Aug. 27.
Record half-year earnings have been attained by the United Aircraft Corporation. Net income of $13,266,584 was reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30.
For about thirty minutes before noon yesterday, Wall Street's bears were in the driver's seat.

The twenty - ninth annual music memory contest of the Goldman Band in Central Park last evening ended in a three-way tie for first place, which will be settled by the toss of a coin at tonight's concert.
Former Magistrate Morris Ploscowe recommended yesterday an experiment in selecting judges by civil service, at least in the lower courts.

For some time now, the New York Stock Exchange and the National Federation of Financial Analysts Societies have been trying to get more corporations to publish quarterly sales figures. They contend that such data are important for the protection of investors.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 -- All thoughts of a sweep over the league-leading Cleveland Indians by the pursuing Yankees melted in the dampness of Municipal Stadium tonight. The Tribe hammered Allie Reynolds for all its runs in the third and fourth innings and squared the series with a 5-2 victory that dropped the Bombers back to two-and-half games behind the pace-setters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Louis M. Bell, a Chicago paint contractor, said today he paid a Washington area leader of the American Federation of Labor painters union $500 in 1951. Mr. Bell said, "it was the Christmas season" and he was trying to get a job finished fast at the Army's near-by Fort Belvoir, Va.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today threw out a long-standing rule prohibiting employers from questioning their workers about their union affiliation or activities.

Three shipping associations representing the bulk of the American merchant marine appealed yesterday to President Eisenhower and other Government leaders in behalf of legislation to aid the nation's maritime industry.

A three-man fact-finding panel has recommended that 600 junior pressmen receive 70 per cent of the $3.75 "package" increase that brought an end to last year's newspaper strike. The ruling followed hearings involving twelve New York newspapers and Local 2 of the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The nation's electric utilities produced a record 453,520,531,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity in the year ended June 30, the Federal Power Commission has reported. The output exceeded the old record set in the year ended May 31 and was 7.6 per cent above production in the year ended June 30, 1953.

A decline last week of 442,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 158,402,000 barrels, compared with 158,844,000 a week earlier and 141,575,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited his son, Maj. John S. Eisenhower, and sixteen other guests to a White House stag dinner tonight. The major is serving temporarily as his father's aide before taking over a new assignment at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. The others invited:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday, closing 3 points higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph L. Hromadka, Czech clergyman attending the World Presbyterian Alliance meeting here, declared today that "so-called Christian civilization finds itself in disintegration."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug 4 (AP) -- Bond issues totaling $57,000,000 for a vast program of civic improvements were approved overwhelmingly by Kansas City voters yesterday.
GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Harold Halsted, competing for the Commodore Corry Trophy, sailed his Chuckle V to victory today in the second race of the Star Class series.
A Queens truck driver confessed to the police early today that he had turned in the false alarm last Saturday night that resulted in the death of two firemen.

Colette, the French writer, author of the novel from which the recent Broadway play "Gigi" was made, died in Paris this week. She was once described by a countryman as "the historian and poet of the instincts." From a Frenchman this is rare praise. Colette had an odd training for the accolade.

EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 1 -- The phenomenal prosperity that oil and natural gas have brought to Alberta has created serious financial problems for its rapidly growing cities.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Of all the many-faceted activities that fill the air with music at Tanglewood, none is more deserving of support than the chamber music series. And the remarkable thing is that it gets fine public turnouts, better turnouts, in fact, than some similar events in the big cities.
The National City Bank of New York is planning to increase its capital by about $130,000,000 through the sale of 2,500,000 new shares of capital stock.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Alec Guinness will have a change of pace when he plays the devil in "Madam, Will You Walk," Columbia Pictures disclosed today.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Newport Dream, from the Newport Stock Farm of Plainfield, N. J., trotted off with the $106,830 Hambletonian Stake in straight heats today at Good Time Park.
FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 5 (UP) -- The good earth of the forty-eight states and Alaska and Hawaii will cradle a memorial pine tree late this month outside President Eisenhower's Gettysburg, Pa., farm.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The bread and the coarse grains parted company to some extent on the Chicago Board of Trade today. Wheat and rye closed higher and corn and oats lost ground, as did soybeans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Long Island Rail Road moved today to have the City of New York barred from participating in its reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A $250,000 "bookkeeping" operation that Ian Woodner, New York builder, said "was done for the purpose of making ourselves acceptable sponsors" of Federal Housing Administration-insured housing projects drew the attention of Senate investigators today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., considered today a policy change under which Communists could be excluded from its membership.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Eisenhower Administration will ask Congress tomorrow for a $10,000,000,000 increase in the $275,000,000,000 ceiling on the national debt.

The 1459 University Avenue Corporation, controlled by J. O. Pederson, has sold the building containing forty-three apartments at 1459-61 University Avenue in the Bronx to the Brander Realty Corporation for investment. The property is assessed at $165,000 and was sold for cash above mortgages totaling $154,000. Sidney Rodwin, lawyer, represented the buyer. Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., were the brokers.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The Foreign Office announced today the appointment of Sir Frank Roberts, Deputy Under Secretary of State at the Foreign Office, as Ambassador to Yugoslavia. He succeeds Sir Ivo Mallet, who has been named Ambassador to Spain.

The Associates Investment Company, a major automobile and commercial finance company, had a consolidated net income of $7,971,765 in the first half of this year, a gain of 17.2 per cent over the $6,801,535 earned in the 1953 period.
The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation announced yesterday that it would place on the market a color television set to retail at $695.
Holding that the funds it expended went for research in broad areas of learning, the General Education Board denied yesterday that it sought to "propagandize a particular philosophy of education."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- By a vote of 293 to 55, the House of Representatives passed today a bill to compel defiant witnesses to testify in cases involving the national security. With a voice vote after little debate it also approved expedition in the prosecution of witnesses held to be in contempt of Congress.
The Police Department started yesterday a program to promote safety in the use of its motor vehicles.

How television might be used in warfare to give commanders an intimate view of frontline operations will be demonstrated from Fort Meade, Md., next Wednesday at 11 A. M., when the N. B. C.-TV network carries a special program in color from the post.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The London drama critics took kindly to "Sabrina Fair," which opened tonight at the Palace Theatre.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4 -- A forty-one-year-old New York Fifty converted to schooner rig showed what was left in her aging heels today by spotting modern craft five minutes at the start and beating them boat for boat.
Henry Thompson and Don Liddle kept the Giants on the winning trail yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Jerry Lynch's two-run homer with two out in the ninth lifted the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Dutch opposition to a bill in the United States Senate to return to Germans assets seized as alien property during World War II focused attention today on the differences in the Eisenhower Administration on the question.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Robin Roberts fanned nine and held Milwaukee to five hits in pitching his sixteenth victory tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies downed the Braves, 2 -- 1. Bob Morgan's bases-empty homer in the third was the deciding blow.
A new branch of the New York Public Library system will be dedicated today at 3 P.M., at 285 East 205th Street, the Bronx. The $450,000 building is a departure in design from other libraries here.
Several measures that will impair service morale, esprit, discipline and combat effectiveness have been approved by Congress and the armed services in recent weeks.

Your editorial of Aug. 3 entitled "Ungava Saga" properly credits the daring and skill of the men who have unlocked the ore storehouses of Canada, but apparently confuses the Labrador-Quebec development at Knob Lake with other developments in the Ungava Bay area.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- All the high-ranking players from the United States and Australia easily won their second-round matches in the Eastern grass court championships today. Therefore, Edward Moylan of Trenton, who has no national status, attracted much attention as he skillfully went about defeating Luis Ayala, Chile's champion, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- The Army suspended Mrs. Annie Lee Moss from her Pentagon job for the second time today pending final settlement of her security case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Harsh words marked the opening today of Senate debate on a farm bill.
PEKIN, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Sixty-eight thousand barrels of whisky blew up tonight in an atomic-like explosion at the American Distilling Company plant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth P. Farrington was sworn in today to succeed her late husband, Joseph R. Farrington, as Delegate to Congress from the Territory of Hawaii.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Britain's first truly supersonic jet fighter, the English Electric P-1, made its maiden flight today. Government officials hailed the occasion as Britain's entry into a new phase of aviation in which aircraft will sustain level flight at supersonic speeds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A solution to the perplexing question of whether atomic patents for peacetime use should be open to all applicants continued to elude Senate and House conferees today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Three professionals today shot 6-under-par 66's at the Tam O'Shanter Country Club to bring about a four-way tie for the top place in the field of 300 seeking to qualify for tomorrow's All-American tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The White House today authorized direct quotation of President Eisenhower's news conference remarks in praise of General of the Army George C. Marshall as follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A Senate-House compromise on a $3,054,568,000 foreign-aid authorization was reached today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United States demanded again today that Communist China make compensation for the death and injury of Americans who were aboard a British airliner shot down by Chinese Communist aircraft. The attack took place near Hainan Island over the South China Sea July 23.

The Times' editorial of July 23 opposing outlawry of the Communist party was sound, as far as it went, but it did not go far enough. In discussing the legal obstacles to outlawry you mentioned a doctrine embodied in the Bill of Rights. Guilt is personal and no one becomes guilty through mere association -- with that argument of yours no good lawyer can disagree.

PARIS, July 30 -- On a window-seat in the offices of Ambassador John C. Hughes, permanent chief of the United States delegation to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, it is not surprising to find a chart. But this is a very superior product to most of those which, in growing thousands, have baffled their makers and viewers since the chart became the favorite illustration of reports of the complicated enterprises of a swelling world bureaucracy.

With the foreign aid authorization bill in conference and the appropriation bill still to be completed, this country's international economic program had yesterday reached a critical stage. To the President, speaking at his press conference, the action of the Senate in lopping half a billion more off the sum requested seemed niggardly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 28:

The constructive efforts of the new Guatemalan Government to eradicate communism and restore law and order have been interrupted by armed clashes between rival Government forces, which bring new tension to the country and imperil the gains of the first successful anti-Communist revolution staged anywhere since the last war.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The first New York suburban branch of Saks Fifth Avenue was opened here today without ceremony.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Harvey C. Fruehauf's Precious Stone won the $23,050 Clang Handicap in a terrific four-horse finish today as Washington Park opened its thirty-day racing season. Just a little more than a length separated the 10-to-1 winner from Baybrook, who was fourth in the field of twelve.

Paul A. Pfeffer, who was sentenced to twenty years to life imprisonment on a second degree murder conviction early in the year, went free yesterday in $10,000 bail that was put up by an anonymous benefactor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at this news conference today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Personal income in the United States was running at an annual rate of $286,500,000,000 at the end of June, about the same as a month earlier, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The report of Police Commissioner Adams on crime in this city is shocking. Each day over 300 serious crimes are committed in New York City. Innocent citizens are being terrorized by hoodlums. The crime rate is rising-rising rapidly enough to cause Commissioner Adams to say that New York is "on the verge of becoming a community of violence and crime."

WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 4 -- The residents of Denver and Roxbury Roads went today about the task of clearing debris and patching the holes ripped into their homes by pieces of the Air Force jet plane that crashed and exploded here at noon yesterday.
A woman from Santa Fe visited the rug department of B. Altman recently. She showed great interest in the large collection of Indian rugs on display and asked to be introduced to the buyer.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- A silt-laden French destroyer was hauled from her muddy grave in the Clyde River off this port today in the first stage of what the Admiralty described as "one of the heaviest tidal lifts in the history of salvage."

The sale of the apartment house at 290 Potter Place in Weehawken, N. J., to the Sanfree Realty Company, Inc., was reported by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker in the deal. The structure contains thirty-one apartments and was sold by the Investment Realty Company.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Aug. 4 -- An 11-year-old fighter of polio was admitted to Memorial Hospital here last night with the disease she had been doing her very best to curb.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Charles C. Finucane of Spokane, Wash., and Frank H. Higgins of White Plains, N. Y., as Assistant Secretaries of the Army. The two would fill new posts created by legislation which the President signed yesterday.

Federal investigators began yesterday to interrogate crew members of the Air France Super Constellation that crashed at Preston City, Conn., Tuesday, with thirty-seven persons aboard, all of whom survived.
New Jersey and New York have become big automobile manufacturing states. They are now in fourth and sixth places, respectively, in the country's output of passenger cars.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 4 -- Larry Evans, William Lombardy, Nicolas Rossolimo and Abe Turner of New York City and Prof. Erich W. Marchand of Rochester scored their second victories in the second round of the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, completed today at the Roosevelt Hotel.

SOUTH NYACK, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Village Clerk Hilliard Ross today asked New York Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran whether new land deposited here by the Hudson River during the last generation or so was properly within this village.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 4 -- The Nassau County Health Department's second and final beach report for 1954 lists sixty-one beaches under permit, three application denials continued and one permit revoked.

The Aluminum Company of America plans to raise the price of aluminum pig by 1/2-cent a pound today to 20 1/2 cents to help cover the cost of wage increases recently granted employes. Aluminum ingot will be advanced 0.7 of a cent a pound to 22.2 cents.
In an attempt to prove that crime can be reduced here merely by increasing the police force, a plan has been worked out to establish a model precinct in East Harlem.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- From the morn through the midnight scene dark rich tweeds parade through Madeleine de Rauch's collection.

During the summer salad season, interest in every kind of dressing is strong. Homemade mayonnaise has its special place -- complementing a cold salmon for a buffet supper, for example, or enhancing a chicken salad for Sunday lunch. Its virtue is that it permits the choice of ingredients. In it one can use a good olive oil and a delicate wine or herb vinegar and prepare a superb product that adds much to epicurean enjoyment.
ROME, Aug. 4 -- After a climactic free-for-all fight between Government and Left-Wing deputies, the Chamber of Deputies recessed for the summer this evening. The Senate recessed last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower delivered a dramatic two-minute eulogy of General of the Army George C. Marshall today in response to new slurs on the character of the wartime Chief of Staff.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The United States offered today specific principles for strengthening the United Nations to cope effectively with future aggressors. The plan was outlined to the Collective Measures Committee of the General Assembly.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves fell $4,000,000 during July to $3,013,000,000, the Treasury announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Supersonic Sabre jets will take part in the gala welcome planned for tomorrow's arrival of the freighter Hawaiian with the first shipment of iron ore from the vast Quebec-Labrador deposits.

Speaking of our local museum of architecture, attention is invited to the latest accession -- to use the collector's term -- proposed for the display in Park Avenue, and represented in the architects' preview as a thirty-story tower of glass and metal rising from a massive pedestal of marble and bronze, itself four stories high.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 4 -- Reinforced French troops today carried forward a campaign to seal up the ultra-nationalist irregulars in the central mountains near Kasserine. They moved as Tunisia awaited the investiture of a Cabinet to negotiate autonomy in the protectorate.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, second largest domestic producer of copper, showed a sharp drop in sales in the first half of this year. Earnings, however, bettered those of a year earlier as a result of lower taxes.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics combined fourteen hits, stout pitching by Alex Kellner and a Baltimore error to beat the Orioles, 6 to 4, before 7,637 fans tonight. The victory enabled the Macks to climb into seventh place, a game ahead of Baltimore in the American League standings.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 4 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, made a strong plea here tonight for a firm foreign policy based on strength. Only thus, he said, can world peace be assured.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Delegates to the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars demanded today that Congress outlaw immediately the Communist party and its affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower acknowledged today his duty as the Republican leader to avoid party splits. However, he was not disposed at this point to interfere in the Senate controversy over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

Apartment house residents in parts of the upper East and West Sides cooperated with the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday by cutting down the use of electricity by 25 per cent after a partial failure of power.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- Over the strenuous opposition of the United States, France and Britain, the United Nations Economic and Social Council voted today to establish a permanent consultative commission on international trade in commodities.
A sharp admonition against possible Congressional attempts to regulate or control educational foundations was made public yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower said again today that Communist China was not fit to sit in the United Nations. But he added he was talking about present conditions, not the indefinite future since conceivably that Government might reform.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 4 -- The possibilities of a relatively light spaceship embodying solar-electric beams of propulsion have attracted special attention among the many designs, fantastic and otherwise, submitted by amateur and professional rocketeers at the International Congress of Astronautics here.

Recent news dispatches indicating the imminence of United States civilian jet aircraft transportation, coupled with those of accelerated jet procurement by the Air Force, testify anew to the importance of jet propulsion in our national future.

THE New York Athletic Club Anglers, who won the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament in 1951 and 1952, were "skunked" last year when the title went to the Brielle (N. J.) Marlin and Tuna Club for the third time. Brielle had scored previously in 1939 and 1949.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Moscow proposed today that the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France meet within two months.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The Polish Government has protested to Britain against removal of Antoni Klimowicz, 24-year-old stowaway, from the Polish vessel Jaroslaw Dabrowski here Saturday night. The Poles also demanded compensation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower won a major battle today in his new campaign to minimize the Communist gains in Southeast Asia.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, utilized the disarray caused in West Germany by the defection of Dr. Otto John to launch today another political offensive against the Federal Republic and its United States supporters.
One of two men involved in the $1-robbery-slaying July 5 of a Brooklyn fisherman on a Manhattan Beach pier was indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury for murder in the first degree.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Matt Batts singled in the tenth inning today after a relief hurler, Ellis Kinder, had filled the bases with walks and the Chicago White Sox gained their sixth straight victory, 6 to 5, over the Boston Red Sox.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- If fish can be grateful there are several thousand very appreciative bass and bluegills in a pond near here today.

Local gardens are yielding excellent, tender cucumbers in such quantities that prices have declined appreciably. One large group of stores is selling the vegetable, which is so appropriate in hot weather, at 5 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The new Soviet note was delivered to John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, this afternoon by Georgi N. Zaroubin, Soviet Ambassador to the United States.
A $4,068,967 tax lien against Hyman Harvey Klein, former Baltimore liquor dealer, was filed yesterday by the Government in Federal Court.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, President of the three-man Junta, moved swiftly today to consolidate his authority after overcoming opposing Regular Army units in two days of fighting and jockeying for position.
MADRID, Aug. 4 -- The Falange party said today that Spain would "never join in any manner or form any coalition" that included Britain so long as Gibraltar remained a British colony.

Jackie Robinson walloped a two-run homer into the upper left-field stand in the ninth inning last night and with that mighty blow transformed the gloom of the Dodgers and the 16,857 Ebbets Field fans into joy.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The way was cleared today for this water-short city to tap the Mianus River.

A flurry of trading in realty on and near Third Avenue was reported yesterday, the deals reflecting increased investment interest in property that may be expected to benefit from the proposed early demolition of the elevated structure there.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 4 (AP) -- The widow of Dr. Herman Baruch, former Ambassador to Portugal and the Netherlands, lost today a court move that would have given her a larger share of his estate.

The Rockefeller Foundation made public yesterday twenty-two pages of "comments upon certain specific grants" that enlarged on its answer to charges made before the House Committee to Investigate Tax Exempt Foundations.
Until they grow up to pursue the little boy look, little girls will be little girls.
The often-discussed three-way merger of American Woolen Company, Textron Inc. and Robbins Mills is one step away from accomplishment.

Prices of most commodity futures on the local exchanges held generally firm yesterday with the exception of coffee, rubber and wool futures: Zinc, copper, cocoa and hide options were in fair demand during the day. Potato futures moved forward in response to heavy demand from trade sources.

WELLFLEET, Mass., Aug. 4 (UP) -- Joseph N. Welch, unruffled by a reported plot on his life, said today he believed the man who wanted to kill him was the husband of a woman who figured in a divorce case the attorney handled fifteen years ago.
Maxwel Anderson's latest plays, "The Masque of Queens" and "The Bad Seed," will be staged this season by Ralph Levy, a theatrical newcomer who never before has directed a Broadway attraction.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Earle Mack, revealing that the Kansas City offer of Arnold Johnson for the Athletics was $4,500,000, tonight hinted a probable sale because "there isn't a chance of keeping the team in Philadelphia as far as finances are concerned."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Radio and television broadcasters urged today that they be given equal rights to cover Congressional hearings.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 4 -- Indonesia, re-emphasizing her neutralist foreign policy, has rejected participation in the proposed Southeast Asian treaty organization aimed at checking Communist expansion.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 5 -- Manned and unmanned rockets will circle the earth in intersecting orbits at many altitudes ranging from 150 to 40,000 miles, according to an interplanetary traffic system described here today at the final session of the International Astronautical Federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower ordered today tighter and faster reporting on the results of security risk investigations.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 5 -- Iran and eight international oil companies initialed today an agreement ending the long dispute over Iran's oil.

The C. I. T. Financial Corporation had a record net income from operations of $17,649,278, equal to $1.89 a share of common stock, the report for the six months ended with June disclosed yesterday. In the initial half of 1953 the net was $16,391,130 or $1.70 a share.
The repayment of loans related to Commodity Credit Corporation operations has caused another decline in New York banks' business loans.
Here is a business man making a speech:

Magistrates J. Irwin Shapiro of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Charles E. Ramsgate of Brooklyn were reported yesterday to be scheduled for appointment by Mayor Wagner as justices of the Domestic Relations Court. Both are Democrats.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A shortage of funds is troubling Democratic party leaders on the eve of their big effort to capture control of Congress in the November elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today its formula for distributing new securities of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company under the reorganization plan which the I. C. C. approved last week.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 5 -- Sewell L. Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co. and one of industry's most controversial figures, has been ousted from the presidency of the Cadillac-Sault Lumber Company here, it was learned today. His successor is W. R. Murphy, 30-year-old son of a man whom Mr. Avery removed from an executive post with the company six years ago.

Peck Peck has a wonderful way with tweeds. Long before tweeds became the season's No. 1 fabric, this store was working out its own colors and blends and doing a comprehensive job of coordinating them with sweaters and blouses.
When the Cardinals said good-by at Ebbets Field yesterday, they left many of the 16,226 Flat-bush fans jeering their erstwhile Dodger heroes.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 (AP) --Governor Dewey today gave top priority today to plans to build a four-lane high'way bypassing the village of Liberty, vThere a runaway tank truck killed three persons July 24.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- Two policemen were injured today in Bremerhaven in a scuffle with landowners and dockworkers who sought to halt construction work on a new United States Army housing development.
The text of Mayor Wagner's statement on steps he has taken to increase the city's police force follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A move was under way today to try a short cut in formal routine to get through Congress a bill that would require defiant witnesses to testify in cases involving the national security.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A Hackensack, N. J., lawyer-builder was denounced face to face by Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, today as a man who victimized apartment hunters in a conscienceless "1,000 per cent rack t."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen today branded as "most inaccurate" a Congressional charge that Britain was taking advantage of United States military aid to steal the lead in jet transport plane development.
An architect who had been working on plans for remodeling a vacant house at 233 East Forty- eighth Street was found dead on the top floor there yesterday. Death was attributed to natural causes.

NEWARK, Aug. 5 -- The police rang down the curtain today for eight Newark boys and their mysterious treasure hoard. For two days the eight, aged 11 to 13, had confounded their friends with a seemingly inexhaustible supply of silver quarters and dimes. All told, the police estimate, the boys spent $400.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 5 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali reaffirmed today the unanimous Cabinet decision that Pakistan retire from seven-year-old canal waters dispute with India.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate entrusted to a carefully selected six-man committee today the responsibility of considering disciplinary action against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ford Konno of Honolulu and Ohio State University, and Carolyn Green, 20-year-old University of Miami (Fla.) co-ed, smashed their own A. A. U. records for the 1,500-meter free style today in opening events of the national swimming and diving championships at Broad Ripple pool.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A report that Annie Lee Moss was given a Communist party membership book for 1943 resulted in her suspension for a second time from her job with the Army Signal Corps.

The answer of the Rockefeller Foundation and the General Education Board to the attacks on them, and foundations in general, by the ineffable Reece committee is an eloquent and convincing supplement to the replies already made by the Carnegie Corporation, the Ford Foundation, the Fund for the Republic and the Council of Learned Societies.
CALVERTON, L. I., Aug. 5 -- A new Navy jet fighter, designed for carrier warfare and capable of supersonic speeds at level flight, took to the skies for its first public demonstration today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Wendell W. Anderson, Detroit industrialist, has been named successor to Tracy S. Voorhees as special representative of the Defense Department in Europe and defense adviser to Ambassador John C. Hughes, United States permanent representative on the North Atlantic Treaty Council.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., was preparing a declaration of policy tonight to bar Communists from membership in the union.

An alleged purse-snatcher was fatally shot by a patrolman at Park Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street late last night after a brief car-and-foot chase. The man, tentatively identified by the police as August J. Harvey, about 25 years old, of 409 East 117th Street, was felled at 11:20 P. M.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 5 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies declared today that Australia would become a contributing party to the projected Southeast Asian defense alliance and would accept military obligations in support of her membership.

The Pennsylvania Railroad said yesterday that it would drop its request for a 25 per cent rise in Long Island Rail Road commutation fares as soon as the 20 per cent increase called for in the redevelopment plan for the road became effective.

That shrimp are of great gastronomical interest to New Yorkers is evidenced by the fact that this city sells more of the shellfish than any other city in the country. New York is America's largest shrimp market, which probably means it is the largest in the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Senate- House conferees eliminated a cut-off date for military assistance abroad as they completed action tonight on a $3,054,568,000 foreign aid authorization.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Lewis Hoad, with his overpowering service, led Australia's contingent of four players into the quarter-finals of the Eastern grass court tennis championships today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Some members of the bipartisan farm bloc conceded today they still were short of votes to beat the Administration's drive for a flexible farm-support system.
The Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third largest automobile producer, yesterday slashed its quarterly dividend to 75 cents from the $1.50 paid quarterly for the last two years.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The British Home Office declared today there was no truth in the "serious slanders against the conduct of the Metropolitan Police" in a note from the Polish Government protesting removal of a stowaway from a Polish ship last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Federal mediators gave up today in their effort to avert a new strike at key atomic plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.

The formation of a domestic research and manufacturing division known as the Farnsworth Electronics Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., was announced yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Farnsworth will take over and expand the activities in industrial and defense electronics formerly carried on by I. T. T.'s Capehart-Farnsworth Company division, including television set manufacturing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- An A. F. L. Painters Union organizer wept today as he denied to House investigators that he ever had received pay-offs from contractors using union labor.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday he would urge a law amendment to stiffen the penalty for sending in a false fire alarm.
Fire Capt. Philip Weinstein contended yesterday that the air-conditioning services he performed complied with the law and that he was not guilty of the charges against him.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 5 -- The Netherlands and West Germany have agreed to submit their long-standing Rhine shipping dispute to a conference of shippers plus Government observers, the Ministry of Transport and Waterways announced here today. The session will be held next month.

Jack Dempsey, the fighter of the half-century in an Associated Press poll in 1950; Joe Louis, and Henry Armstrong, a former triple champion, led the modern pugilists into Boxing's Hall of Fame yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Robert W. Sparks, first vice president and treasurer of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York, has resigned as chairman of the U. S. savings bonds advisory committee for the state of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The 1954 contract bridge national championships continued here this afternoon with a record-shattering entry of 256 men pairs and 218 women pairs playing the first of three scheduled sessions in their respective championship.
G. Joseph Minetti, a Brooklyn lawyer and long-time figure in municipal affairs, was nominated yesterday by President Eisenhower to a vacancy on the three- man Federal Maritime Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The United States Government has had very little to cheer about in the field of foreign affairs recently, but it is distinctly set up about the improvement in the political situation in the Mediterranean and the Middle East.

The chancery office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that Cardinal Spellman had received information from his "brother bishops in Vietnam of the massed flight of civilans from North to South Vietnam to escape from the Communist-led Vietminh.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 -- It's an old Yankee custom. When another fall might have led to the flop of the year, the champions roared to a 5-2 victory over the pacesetting Cleveland Indians today, capturing the odd game in the set and moving to within a length and a half of the Tribe.
GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Skippers participating in the annual regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association experienced one of the roughest sailing days of the season this afternoon.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower hailed the Anglican Congress, in session here, as an "inspiring demonstration of a world-wide yearning for peace and understanding among the peoples of many nations."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A bill to admit 385 Basque sheepherders to this country under special visas, despite rigid immigation restrictions, was approved by the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ilya Ehrenburg, Soviet writer arrived with his wife today to attend the fiftieth birthday celebration of Pablo Neruda, Chilean Communist poet, and immediately got into a dispute with customs officials.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering a new issue of $3,650,000 of first mortgage sinking fund bonds of the Lakefront Dock and Railroad Terminal Company, a jointly owned Great Lakes undertaking of the New York Central Railroad and The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. The borrower will use funds raised by the sale to pay off advances from New York Central and the B. O.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- A best-ball score of 64 by Chet Birch and Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow set the pace for the qualifiers in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament today. A field of 102 teams, including some of the top amateurs in the East, competed at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

The $425,000,000 National Dairy Products Corporation, leader of the dairy products industry, is splitting its stock two-for-one. The company also increased its third-quarter dividend by 5 cents to 80 cents a share. Simultaneously, it also reported earnings of $18,960,490 for the first six months, which set a record for any half-year in the company's history.
Cotton was moderately active, and stronger yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Active futures rose 15 to 28 points.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's production of shorn wool at 229,371,000 pounds, or about 1,000,000 pounds less than last year.

A volume about one facet of the Civil War is planned for Sept. 13 publication by Knopf. It is entitled "Bohemian Brigade." The author is Louis M. Starr, a member of Columbia University's Oral History Project. He describes how the war was viewed through the press and how the conflict led to a "revolution" in journalism, changing the American newspaper from an organ primarily of editorial opinion into the "ancestor of the modern metropolitan daily."
Sales of taxpayers in the Dyckman and Washington Heights sections featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.
Teamsters and major truckers in the metropolitan area announced yesterday that they would try to negotiate a master union contract covering 30,000 drivers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission authorized television stations today to set up "satellite" outlets on ultra high frequency (U. H. F.) channels that would be able to relay their telecasts over a wider area.

A small collection of Yemenese handicraft was shown yesterday at the Consulate General of Israel, 11 East Seventieth Street, by Mrs. Ruth Dayan, wife of the Chief of Staff of the Israel Army of Defense.
YSTRADGYNLAIS, Wales, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- A village school-master won today a coveted bardic chair at the National Eisteddfod here with a 350-line ode about the flooding of a Welsh village.

Today's new film is "Human Desire," a Columbia drama, at the Palace. Glenn Ford, Gloria Grahame and Broderick Crawford are starred with Edgar Buchanan and Kathleen Case heading the supporting cast. Alfred Hayes wrote the screen play from the novel, "The Human Beast," by Emile Zola. Fritz Lang directed and Lewis J. Rachmil produced.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Tom Ewell, a logical choice to play the summer bachelor, will recreate his role of Richard Sherman when Twentieth Century-Fox films "The Seven Year Itch."

JOE A. MUNANG, a Dusun tribesman from British North Borneo, runs a little barber shop in Amsterdam Avenue opposite St. John's Cathedral. He shaves vicars and prebendaries and, except in summer, has good trade from college undergraduates and faculty.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 5 -- The difficulties of self-government have already appeared in this French Protectorate, which had been promised internal autonomy by France when it could form a Cabinet to negotiate an agreement with the French Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- It is almost certain that the Senate will adopt whatever recommendation -- indictment or no -- is brought in by the high Senate grand jury now chosen to investigate Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

An upward flurry in over-the-counter bids for Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company's stock took place in the market yesterday in the wake of the National City Bank's proposal to increase its capitalization by one-third. Together, these developments touched off talk about the possibility of a revival of the merger of National City and Corn Exchange which was projected twenty-five years ago but came to naught.
Practical furnishings, lustrous silks and bright colors are artfully blended in the interiors of a model house now open to public inspection in Shore Crest Estates on Landing Road in Glen Cove, L. I.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Phil Cavarretta's two-run double in the first inning was all the punch the Chicago White Sox needed today to beat the Boston Red Sox, 5 to 1, and stretch their winning streak to seven games before a ladies' day crowd of 21,490.
Realty trading reported in Brooklyn yesterday was confined largely to purchases of apartment properities by investors.

Seen from a window high above the city streets the fabric-covered people move in broad organic masses. Painted iron vehicles creep and spurt and stop by turns like obsessively competitive insects. Through the heavy hanging air the sun breaks over the stone and flesh and iron, making flat shadows everywhere.
Whoever buys the clothes in the New York family seems to be more cautious in spending for the males than for the females.

Much has been learned since the first attack on Everest a generation ago as to the best way to climb the higher peaks of the Himalayas. The devoted souls who go into those inhospitable wildernesses now wear improved types of clothing and eat improved types of food.

Efforts are being made by Courtney Burr and John Byram to clear the rights to the unpublished tunes of the late Vincent Youmans, a popular composer. The melodies are to be interpolated into "Shangri La," derived from James Hilton's novel, "Lost Horizon," which Mr. Burr and Mr. Byram expect to bring to the stage.
The police have begun a drive against gangs that have been breaking open parking meters and stealing the coins placed in them.

WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 5 -- The Air Force sent two investigating boards and two teams of specialists into this village today to unravel the physical and legal tangles left by the crash and explosion of a jet plane last Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Members of Presbyterian and Reformed churches on both sides of the Iron Curtain were told today to "be loyal to the Government of the nation in which you live," but to make decisions in obedience to God, not man.

Most commodity futures on the local markets moved into lower territory yesterday. Cocoa futures, however, continued in demand for the fourth straight trading session, and firmness was evident in the silk futures market.
Additional shipping charges planned by motor carriers and railroads would be a "serious threat to the economic well-being of our city," Corporation Counsel Adrian P. Burke declared yesterday.

Unless we have fallen victim to "fear itself" why should Dr. Rhee's address to Congress be termed "unfortunate"? Such absolute honesty and articulate realism are so extraordinarily rare in statesmen that Syngman Rhee stands alone. The words "fiery" and "peppery" are unworthy to describe the forceful, authoritative qualities which make him a true leader.
New York lived up once again to its fabled leputation as a tourist mecca this week, and nine happy Strobels of Tacoma, Wash., will head for home today pleased that that is so.
A 63-year-old man drowned and two others were hurt when a twenty-six-foot speed boat exploded in Gravesend Bay, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Large and medium Grade A eggs, currently a "good property for consumers," according to a spokesman for the trade, have declined 4 cents a dozen in the last week. The city Department of Markets, in its regular weekly check of retail food prices, found that the large eggs were 67 cents a dozen, the medium 55 cents.

SOME interesting questions are being raised by hearings in Washington on whether television and radio should have access to Congressional inquiries publicly conducted. The only thing conclusive so far is that the hearings are not being televised.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- One of the pleasures of racetrack life at Saratoga in August is watching the promising 2-year-olds that are just starting their silk-flying careers. Tom Fool did his first racing here. Native Dancer won four stakes here at 2. Many other good horses gained their first fame at the old park.

Premier Mendes-France is nothing if not bold. In many ways the boldest move he has made in his sensational few weeks in office is the frontal attack he is seeking authority to launch on the crippling rigidities of the French economy.

In the summer the theatregoer is given a fair choice. He can obey the sign that advises: "When you're blue and feeling low, take the subway, see a show," or he can remove his car from the $5 or $15 ticket side of the street and drive to the country to see a show.

It struck this reader as strange that the leader of an allied nation would have the audacity to enter this country as a visitor and a guest, accept the hospitality of the United States' Congress by being allowed to address a joint session of that body, and then while still a guest in this country to remark for publication that "The Americans have not got common guts enough to face the problem."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Austria will join the twelve other countries cooperating with the United States in preventing the reshipment of strategic American goods to Iron Curtain countries, the Commerce Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended on Saturday were 1 per cent above those in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Stock market prices advanced again on a broad front here today. Persistent buying in the face of rapidly dwindling supply of floating stocks led to gains higher than those recorded previously this week. British Government stocks, particularly long dated issues, which improved 1 per cent, and leading industrials were in greatest demand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A temporary increase of $6,000,000,000 in the national debt ceiling, now set by law at $275,000,000,000, was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee. The vote was 9 to 6.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The results of a Latin-American caucus convinced United Nations diplomats today that the vote on the presidency of the General Assembly this fall would be close.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's first-half exports fell $144,000,000 from those of the first six months of 1953 to a three-year low of $1,875,700,000. Her sales were down in all major foreign markets.

The Giants had to take their joy from the scoreboard report of the Dodger defeat by the Cardinals yesterday. The New Yorkers lost their game with the Cubs, 6 -- 4, on successive eighth-inning homers by Ernie Banks and Eddie Miksis. The setback snapped a six-game Giant winning streak.

Following are the texts, as supplied by The Associated Press, of a joint statement in Teheran by the Iranian Government and the consortium of oil companies that will operate Iran's oil industry; of a statement by the British Government on the Iranian oil agreement and of a message from British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Iranian Foreign Minister Abdullah Entezam:

The management of Society Brand Clothing plans to diversify operations under a new name if the sale of its name and goodwill to Hart Schaffner Marx is approved by stockholders. The stockholders will meet on Aug. 23 to vote on this and other proposals.

Stock prices moved narrowly and irregularly yesterday, but the trading pace continued fast. Most of the interest centered in aviation issues -- both aircrafts and air transports -- and a selected list of so-called secondary or lower-priced issues. Better known names and gilt-edged securities encountered profit taking.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Though elsewhere skirts are short, waistlines drop and bosoms flatten, Mme. Gres, unconcerned, continues her drapery, bias cut, swaying godets and asymmetry. Here are clothes always individual, sometimes theatrical, sometimes very beautiful.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 -- Nine of the field of 110 competitors are tied for the lead with a 3-0 score after three completed rounds in the United States Chess Federation open championship at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Firing two more verbal broadsides in their "cold war" campaign to divide and disarm the free world for further Communist conquests, the Soviets have dispatched a new note to the Western Powers on German unification and European security and have issued a new declaration on President Eisenhower's proposed atomic pool for peaceful purposes.

The American Airlines notified 1,243 striking pilots yesterday that they had been suspended as of July 31. The company warned them that it reserved the right to discharge them if they continued to refuse to fly.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, told former President Harry S. Truman today the Korean people would be everlastingly grateful to the man who sent United States troops to help them fight the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended with last Saturday totaled 683,569 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Simon W. Gerson of Brooklyn, onetime Communist candidate for the New York City Council refused to answer any questions about alleged communism today on grounds that the nation had become "McCarthyized."
FLORIDA commissioners have set the dates and the conditions for both firearms and archery big-game hunting in the state this fall.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The state of Kansas today lost its suit to recover $110,000 it paid for a hospital building in a deal arranged by C. Wesley Roberts, former Republican National Committee chairman.

Iranian oil, on which an agreement was announced yesterday, has been a source of international tension virtually since William K. D'Arcy, an Englishman, obtained a concession from the Iranian Government in 1901. The concession covered all of Iran except the five northern provinces, around the Caspian Sea.
Sales of new shares of the Broad Street Investing Corporation set a record of $1,463,000 in July, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

The "Slow Down and Live" campaign has had remarkable success, a traffic expert said yesterday. He added that those who deny that speed is an all-important factor in accidents were weakening the safety program.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 (AP) ---TheState Thruway Authority took iai $275,790 during its first full month of toll operations on a 11Smile stretch of the superhighway.
PEKIN, Ill., Aug. 5 (UP) -- A distillery fire raged through its second day today, leaving six dead and destroying nearly 5,000,000 gallons of whisky with losses estimated at up to $7,000,000.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Both the Foreign Office and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company professed today to be satisfied with the agreement signed in Teheran, although there is likely to be criticism in the country at the small sum arrived at for compensation to the company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An unheralded pro who took to Tam o'Shanter's sunny wind-swept course shortly after dawn and posted a five-under-par 67 today captured the first-round lead in the $25,000 All-American golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the National Labor Relations Board might go ahead with an investigation into the truth or falsity of non-Communist affidavits filed by a union official.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- For an hour today, the House of Representatives debated whether "un-American" trout should be so identified on restaurant menus across the country.
An assistant bacteriologist in a Health Department clinic won awards totaling $600 yesterday for suggesting a short cut in detecting cervical cancer.

RIO DE JANEIR0, Aug. 5 -- An "electoral manifesto" of the outlawed Communist party of Brazil published today indicates the Communists aim to get their candidates in the October Congressional elections despite all bans.

Ray L. Hamilton has been elected vice president of Bechtel Corporation, San Franscisco, Calif., construction company. Since 1953 he has been a vice president of Bechtel International Corporation and of Canadian Bechtel, Ltd.
The Transit Authority appointed yesterday a new director of its labor relations bureau with expanded responsibility for all personnel matters.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The world's two greatest milers let their rivals lead the way to the wire today in the preliminaries of the British Empire Games mile run, John Landy of Australia and Roger Bannister of England being content to qualify for tomorrow's final.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Bob Porterfield tamed the Detroit Tigers on six hits today as he pitched the Washington Senators to a 4-to-1 triumph before 3,802 fans at Briggs Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- It should now be evident to Senator McCarthy that the controversy of which he is the central figure will inflict political damage on his party at the November elections. That is implicit in the action taken by the Senate growing out of the two Flanders resolutions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Prospects for developing a major source of newsprint from native hardwood trees were described as "highly encouraging" in a Government report submitted to Congress today.

There is good news indeed in the announcement of an agreement between Iran and a consortium of foreign oil companies to start up again the flow of Iranian oil into world markets after the long interruption following nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian oil properties in 1951.

It is good news to learn from Robert Moses that construction of the $30,000,000 coliseum at Columbus Circle is on schedule and that the cornerstone of the much-needed vast exhibit hall will be laid about Oct. 1. After many lawsuits and delays, the coliseum seems to be indeed "on its way."
A 60-year-old commander in the Naval Reserve killed himself yesterday because of inability to find employment.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Twenty Vietnamese were shot dead in demonstrations following the official cease-fire Sunday in Central Vietnam, the French High Command said today.
