The old International Longshoremen's Association has begun organizing drives in fields far removed from the docks.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss declared here today that the United States hoped to maintain "an overwhelming superiority" in atomic weapons "until all nations agree to workable international control."

All over the state at the outskirts of every city and town are to be seen great billboards saying "In the event of enemy attack this highway will be closed." LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5 -- One of the country's fine jazz pianists has been studying sonata form at Tanglewood as an enrolled, paying student this summer.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The freighter Hawaiian, laden with the first shipment of iron ore from Canada's fabulous Quebec-Labrador mining development, received a gala greeting upon her arrival today.
MADRID, Aug. 5 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has chosen Jose Maria Areilza y Martinez Rodes as the new Spanish Ambassador to the United States, diplomatic circles said today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Red China has sent back a United States note protesting against a death-dealing attack on a British airliner off Hainan July 23, it was disclosed tonight. For the second time the Chinese Communists refused even to consider such a protest.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Dr. Albert E. Heustis, State Health Commissioner, said today that Michigan State Health Laboratories had developed what he described as the first known cure for typhoid fever.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union reiterated today its "complete readiness" to negotiate with the west on peaceable use of atomic energy provided an agreement were reached on banning all weapons of mass extermination.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 5 -- There was a touch of royalty to the competition of the New York Yacht Club cruise today when a sovereign of the seas gained the cup put up by Queen Elizabeth in dusty going off Brenton Reef Lightship.
Mayor Wagner, re-emphasizing the urgent nature of the city's crime problem, announced yesterday that he had taken emergency measures to increase the police force.
R. L. Huffines Jr., president of Textron, Inc., was elected chairman of the board and president of Robbins Mills, Inc., yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Directors of American National Bank and
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The Air Force has ordered America's first jet transport plane into production as a flying tanker for jet bombers, Secretary Harold E. Talbott announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower wrote the Shah of Iran today that he was confident the Iranian oil agreement marked the beginning of "a new era of economic progress and stability for your country."

GUATEMALA, Aug. 5 -- Out of the confusion, bloodletting and political struggle of the last few days, one fact emerges clearly: Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas' strength and prestige have considerably increased.
WASHINGTON, Aug 5 -- Following are close - ups of the members of the special Senate committee named to inquire into the question of censuring Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- Carlos Lacerda, a popular crusading editor, was shot in the foot here early today in an assassination attempt in which his companion was accidentally killed.
TRENTON, Aug. 5 -- New Jersey will take action soon to recover from the South Amboy Trust Company $300,000 in missing state disability benefit funds.

Chicago Aug. 5 -- There was a still further parting of the ways today between the bread grain and the coarse grains on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat gained some ground and corn lost considerably more than wheat gained.

AT 221 Fourth Avenue in New York is a somber office building whose tenants include several firms in the woolen business. It is also America's foremost dog house. On the twelfth floor and part of the thirteenth is an organization whose business is pure-bred dogs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- In the week ended Aug. 4, member bank reserves decreased $403,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
In your editorial of July 31 "Teachers Needed" you have once again performed an important public service in calling attention to the serious shortage of teachers in our schools.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Friday, Aug. 6 -- Senator Estes Kefauver swept to an easy victory last night in his bid for renomination to a second term in the Democratic primary election.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Hog receipts fell below expectations today and prices moved quite sharply higher. Butchers jumped 25 to 75 cents and sows 25 to 50 cents in very active trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- New polio cases throughout the nation increased about 28 per cent last week but the rise was "normal for this time of year," the United States Public Health Service reported today.

The Times in its editorial of July 27 treats the subject of the recent murders committed by Chinese Communist fighting planes on passengers of an English international commercial aircraft in a rather restrained and mild vein. The editorial treats this shocking incident as if it were a minor occurrence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A seasonal rise in building activity carried July construction totals to a monthly peak of $3,500,000,000, a joint report by the Commerce and Labor Departments disclosed today. The total for July was 5 per cent above June's figure and 6 per cent higher than that for July of last year.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Representatives of the Western Big Three met in London today to begin drafting a reply to the Soviet proposal for an East-West conference on European security. The Kremlin's bid is getting a cool reception.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that organizations that object to being listed by the Attorney General as subversive must submit to administrative procedures before taking their cases to court.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Agnes Andrews, wife of a Garden City dentist, who admitted being drunk last March 16 when her car jumped a curb and seriously injured two small boys on the sidewalk, was named in a $470,000 damage suit filed in Supreme Court here this week by the boys' fathers.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Sixty cadet-midshipmen received Bachelor of Science degrees, licenses as third officers in the merchant marine, and commissions as ensigns in the Naval Reserve at outdoor commencement exercises today at the United States Merchant Marine Academy here.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals reported yesterday that 2,000 dead animals had accumulated at four of its shelters because of a strike of employes that began last Monday.
Secret Service agents broke into a midtown hotel room yesterday and arrested a 41-year-old ex-convict who had planned to re-enter the counterfeiting field.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 6 -- The Chilean Government has taken a firm stand against an Opposition proposal for an official monopoly of sales of copper produced by American companies in this country. As a result, the Chamber of Deputies is more likely to defeat the measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 point to 109.8 in the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Sales of Motorola, Inc in the second quarter of 1954 were $44,458,415, nearly equaling the $44,673,101 record for the quarter set a year earlier, Paul V. Galvin, president, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate unanimously agreed today to limit debate and vote Monday on the key issue of rigid versus flexible farm price supports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of Foreign Operations, once refused information to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations because some of Mr. McCarthy's investigators had not been cleared for secret information.

Fifty years ago a youngish man whose family had been manufacturing woolens in Europe came to the United States to set up a mill. His name was Julius Forstmann. Today, Forstmann woolens are a hallmark in American fashion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A former Army sergeant accused Senator William E. Jenner of having been "drunk and disorderly'' as a captain during World War II. The Indiana Senator retorted: "You know you are lying.''

Tax liens totaling $29,586,160 were filed yesterday by the Government in Federal Court against three Canadian men. They were indicted with six others last May in a $16,000,000 income tax evasion case, said to be the largest such case in the history of the Internal Revenue service.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Bert Kohlmann, left-handed golfing star and his teammate, Stanley Harte of Inwood, accounted for the day's principal upset in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- It appeared that Australians would be completely in possession of the field in the eastern grass court championship today, but Arthur Larsen salvaged victory in the last of the quarter-finals at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies took advantage of the wildness of Howie Pollet to score three runs in the first inning tonight as they defeated, the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 4. behind Curt Simmons, who hurled his tenth victory.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 6 -- The Netherlands has taken diplomatic steps to express her disappointment with the United States decision to back Prince Wan Waithayakon, Thailand's Foreign Minister, for the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly next fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission's broadcast bureau said today it had information alleging that Edward O. Lamb of Toledo, a publisher and broadcaster, "knowingly associated" with Communist party officials there from 1934 to 1940.

Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was elected President of Colombia this week. The news did not obtrude because there was no violence, and in fact there were only ninety-six voters, members of the National Constituent Assembly.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 -- Journeyman craft labor is commanding basic wages as high as $4.32 an hour in Alaska this summer. There is a lessening opportunity, however, for the great amount of overtime work, at time-and-one-half and double-time pay, that has characterized the Territory's construction boom of the last several years.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -- The representatives of India, Canada and Poland, constituting the Truce Supervisory Commission in Indochina, wound up sessions here today with an agreement on organizational and procedural matters.

Police riding in a miniature plastic car soon will patrol the Holland Tunnel. They will operate on the catwalk, the elevated strip at the side of the tunnel where foot policemen are now stationed. WATERTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- More than 9,000 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists from New Jersey are leaving Camp Drum today and tomorrow for their home stations, after two weeks summer training.
The second assembly of the World Council of Churches will be held at Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., Aug. 15 to 31. The first was convened in 1948 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations finished its eighteenth session here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Representative Edwin E. Willis launched a move today to mobilize Congressional strength in a fight to eradicate the water hyacinth -- a plant pest that is choking streams in many southern states with heavy resultant loss.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- The Communist Government of the Soviet zone has accepted President Eisenhower's offer to supply free food to the victims of the recent floods in central Germany.

A bill providing for twenty- four-hour inspection of ships in quarantine, already approved by the House of Representatives, is scheduled to come up for consideration by the Senate today. All proponents of the measure are optimistic over the chances for an affirmative vote.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which conducted the hearings in the Army-McCarthy dispute, announced today that it hoped to file its final report by the end of next week.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Ted Williams, striving to win the American League home run title even though he was sidelined for nearly five weeks at the start of the season, teed off for his twentieth homer with one on in the tenth inning tonight to lead the Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Orioles. WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Burbank, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of incorporating a streetful of people into a motion picture without their knowledge.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued strong yesterday and active months rose 2 to 7 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States denied today as "completely untrue" a charge by Communist Poland that American aircraft had fired on two Polish ships near the island of Hainan in the South China Sea on July 26.
Steps to increase the police patrol force were taken yesterday by two members of Mayor Wagner's cabinet in charge of civil service and the city budget.

F. C. Tucker has been appointed manager of eastern sales for the plastics department in Pittsfield, Mass., of the General Electric Company. Maurice H. Mayo has been named manager of finance for the company's general purpose component motor department in Fort Wayne,Ind.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 6 -- The United States coal industry has been squeezed out of an important European market, partly as a result of an understanding between the Netherlands and Belgium, it was reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Merton B. Tice, an attorney of Mitchell, S. D,, was elected commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at today's closing session of the organization's fifty-fifth national encampment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a bill to require the Secretary of State to send to the Senate all Executive agreements made with other nations.

TRENTON, Aug. 6 -- High state officials expressed annoyance here today on learning that the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission was now operating on an annual budget of $2,021,560. One described it as "exorbitant," another as "seemingly excessive."

THE folkways of the intellectuals interest David Riesman enormously. He studies them with the shrewd insight of a merry eye. He collects their talismans and passwords. He could probably shut off a whole week-ends conversation merely by forbidding any intellectual present to say "hysteria," or "Kafka," or "adjusted," or "Dostoevsky," or "ambivalent," or "Eliot," or "dichotomy," or "Freudian," or "conventional" or "formulation" -- to take just ten from the current recognition signals of the tribe.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Officials of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., told the Studebaker Corporation today its members would not go along with the union's suggestion that their pay be cut 15 per cent to help sell more cars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -A six-man group headed by Roger Steffan of New York left by air for Formosa today to make an economic survey at the request of the Nationalist Chinese Government.
A midtown jewelry concern was robbed yesterday of $10,000 in gems and $800 in cash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Spadework for what promises to develop into a full-scale investigation of the television and radio networks will be started by a Senate committee staff around Sept. 1, according to word on Capitol Hill.
Jolly Cholly Grimm and his Braves are on the warpath again.

The New York State Power Authority and the Ontario Hydro-Electric Commission of Canada have agreed on equal division of the cost of rehabilitating 6,000 persons in Canadian areas to be flooded by the $600,000,000 St. Lawrence power development.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 6(UP) -President Victor Paz Estenssoro said today that nationalization of tin mines and agrarian reform, two major points in his National Revolutionary Government program, had been accomplished successfully.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The stock market ended a buoyant week on a rising note today. Despite profit-taking sales, most of the main sections finished better.

An electrical engineer at one of the three Fort Monmouth Signal Corps laboratories has been cleared of security charges by the Department of the Army and informed that he may come back to work. The engineer will also be entitled to take up the question of back pay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration gained some ground in its fight for what it considers adequate foreign aid funds today. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a bill providing $2,990,824,816 in new cash to carry forward the Mutual Security Program.

Your recent editorial "New Piers" and the voicing of your wishes for a long period of labor peace on the waterfront deserve special consideration and action on the part of all concerned with the waterfront situation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) The Joint Congressional Economic Committee criticized Congress today for economizing on economic statistics.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Capt. Lauren S. McCready, head of the engineering department at the United States Merchant Marine Academy here, is a man who practices what he teaches.
With Russ Meyer supplying quality pitching, too little of which has been on display at Ebbets Field this season, the Dodgers romped to an 8-1 triumph over the Redlegs last night.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Mike Garcia pitched his first victory in almost a month tonight when the Cleveland Indians beat the Philadelphia Athletics, 7 to 3.
BRIELLE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Looking out the wide picture windows of the Brielle Yacht Club as dawn breaks over the Manasquan River you see the charter boat crews making ready for the day's fishing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that thirty Army officers, including five generals, had taken an "active part in the promotion and honorable discharge of Maj. Irving Peress, Army dentist.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 6 -- port-tack reach in a fair breeze from Brenton Reef Lightship to West Chop off this harbor was just right for the smaller sloops and yawls in Class A on the New York Yacht Club cruise today.
TORONTO, Aug. 6 -- Emilie Dionne, shyest and most silent of the Dionne quintuplets, died today of a stroke. She was 20 years old.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 6 -- The staggered cease-fire timetable fixed at Geneva brought peace today to the 1,500,000 inhabitants of the valleys, mountains and jungles of Laos.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Rudy Horvath of Windsor, Ont., took the lead in the $25,000 All-American golf tournament today, but the incomparable Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias stole the show at Tam O'Shanter with a record-smashing performance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Railroad "piggy-back" transportation of truck trailers on railroad flat cars won final approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission today. The commission ruled 5-to-2 to permit the service, with four members taking no part in the decision.
Stockholders of the Hotels Statler Company approved yesterday the passing of control of their property to the Hilton Hotels Corporation.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6 -- Four of the 110 players in the United States Chess Federation open championship were tied for the lead, with scores of 4 -- 0, at the completion of play in the fourth round today.

New York, with its rising juvenile delinquency problem, might take note of a little experiment that is being tried in Louisville, Ky. There a Juvenile Court judge has attempted to tap a new source of advice in pondering the wayward youth problem -- the 'teen-agers themselves.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- Business under the International Wheat Agreement during the crop year which ended last Saturday was disappointing. Virtually complete figures available today show that sales were less than two-fifths of those in the previous year, when Britain was still a member.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Mozart and Pergolesi, the latter as seen through the twentieth-century eyes of Stravinsky, provided the material for tonight's program in the Theatre-Concert Hall at Tanglewood. Lukas Foss was the conductor, and he had the cooperation of a sizable segment of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, a Berkshire Music Center chorus and a number of vocal soloists drawn from the center's opera department.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 6 -- The tug between the militantly nationalistic Neo-Destour party of Tunisia and the French Government, that is hampering the first steps toward self-government in this protectorate, continued today without apparent gain for either side.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives approved an atomic energy bill today but disagreement over patent provisions may touch off another bitter Senate floor fight.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- A New York labor union trying to organize an-electronics plant here in a test case today found the door slammed in its face. The company discharged its twenty employes, locked its doors and said it would liquidate.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- Critics of Gil McDougald's peculiar batting stance should have been at Briggs Stadium tonight when, with one swing in the eighth inning, he delivered all the runs that gave the Yankees a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

MEXICO CITY, July 21 -- Mexico has a wide variety of dishes, changing from region to region according to the foods most easily available and the demands of the climate. Chili peppers and beans are two great staples, though contrary to views of the national cookery prevailing north of the border, they are not the only things Mexicans eat.
A rush of orders to sell Chrysler, which halved its dividend rate after the market closed on Wednesday, caused stock prices to slip badly in Wall Street yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- British defense circles said today that the Second Battalion of the Suffolk Regiment had been long due for transfer from Trieste and that its dependent personnel had been moved some time ago via Austria to Germany.

With activity in the public market for new capital subsiding seasonally at midsummer, the underwriting community is centering its interest on the proposal of the National City Bank of New York to increase its capital by one-third.

Although generals, colonels and majors were among the 2,000 men who began gathering yesterday at the Astor Hotel for the seventh annual reunion of the First Marine Division Association, the center of attraction was a mild-mannered staff sergeant with a set of bagpipes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 -- The official emblem of the world-wide Anglican Communion, a familiar sight here these days, was designed by a well known New York churchman, the Rev. Canon Edward N. West of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower nominated today the five members of the Advisory Board of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 6 -- Former President Truman advised Democratic party leaders today that they could capture control of Congress in November if they raised enough money for a fighting campaign. Mr. Truman gave this advice to Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Presidential nominee, and Stephen A. Mitchell, the Democratic National Chairman, when they visited him on the screened-in back porch of his home at nearby Independence, Mo.

Enactment of legislation to make possible another year of American military and economic assistance to our friends moved another important step forward yesterday. The Senate Appropriations Committee's action in approving almost $3,000,000,000 of new funds, as well as the expenditure of over $2,500,000,000 previously appropriated, represents a more generous, and also more far-sighted, approach than was shown in the House of Representatives.
The Public Service Commission denied yesterday a petition by the New York Telephone Company to increase the monthly rates for telephone service in the state.
Establishment of a Cargo Inspection Bureau at New Orleans has been announced by James A. Dennean, chairman of the Far East Conference.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Cutting a huge cake amid 250 friends on his eightieth birthday at his summer home here today, Dr. James T. Shotwell soberly estimated the chances for a durable world peace as "not so bad, in a way."
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The mixed up 3-year-old filly division may be straightened out somewhat tomorrow when fifteen race in the $50,000 added Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Democratic hopes for the November Congressional elections rose so high today as to worry some party members about overconfidence.

An aged couple's yearly sentimental trip to Coney Island yesterday turned into several terrifying hours of separation for them, and, finally, into one of the most touching reunions ever seen in Pennsylvania Station. In between it gave Travelers Aid workers a major mystery to solve.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Ray Milland will take on the added responsibilities of director in a new Western drama to be made for Republic.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed tonight to West Germans and the Governments of the Western alliance in an effort to arrest the crisis provoked by the flight of Dr. Otto John.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The International Council of Christian Churches today urged President Eisenhower to reconsider his decision to speak at a meeting of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., Aug. 19.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower expressed gratification today that the Government of East Germany had accepted an offer of emergency food supplies.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., plans to exclude Communists from its ranks starting a year from now.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- About 9,000 paintings and drawings by children of ninety-three countries, including a few behind the Iron Curtain but not Russia, were on display today in Independence Square.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored five runs in the eighth inning tonight to beat the Washington Senators, 10 to 5, and equal their longest winning streak of the season, eight games, before 25,454 fans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- A resolution condemning the Girl Scouts of America for permitting its organization to be used for United Nations propaganda was approved overwhelmingly here today at the annual convention of the Illinois department of the American Legion.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- There were some charming mutuels at the Saratoga track today, and among them was the $32.50 that was flashed on the pay-off board after the Bee Gee Farms' Petal had won the $5,000 added filly-and-mare handicap that was run in the feature spot.

Radio station WNYC will broadcast the discussion sessions at the twenty-third annual Couchiching Conference from Geneva Park, Lake Couchiching, ninety miles north of Toronto. Leading Canadian American and English educators will discuss Canadian economic and social problems in their international setting beginning tonight and continuing through Friday.

The quiet countryside, contrary to the bards, is not always quiet nor always peaceful. In fact, Connecticut's pastoral regions encompassing the Clinton Playhouse last week re-echoed with sounds of the turmoil involving John Barrymore Jr. and Charlotte and Lewis Harmon, silo entrepreneurs.

The reported progress by John L. Lewis' District 50 in the local tugboat field was confirmed yesterday by a switch of Local 933-5 of the independent International Longshoremen's Association to the United Marine Workers Division of the "catch-all" district of the United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- John Jacob Astor of New York took his third bride today. He was married to Miss Dolores Margaret Fullman of Miami Beach, Fla., at the capital's near-by Gretna Green in Arlington, Va.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. (AP) -- Adios Boy, a 3-year-old colt owned by J. S. Turner of Nassa-wadox, Va., and driven by Howard Camden, established a world record of 1:36 for thirteen-sixteenths of a mile tonight in winning the $15,000 Westward Ho Pace by three lengths from Bonny Brook Dean.
Sharp declines in coffee and cocoa featured trading on the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Other commodities were steady to slightly lower in comparatively light dealings.
Net income of the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation, operator of a major Midwest gas pipeline, rose to $3,003,610 in the first half of 1954 from $1,566,721 in the corresponding period a year ago.

Your editorials of July 23 entitled "No Time for Horseplay" and July 27 entitled "After the Filibuster Ends" reveal a lack of understanding of the issues which were debated by the Senate recently in connection with a revision of the Atomic Energy Act of 1946.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- With the exception of deferred deliveries in oats and corn, all of the grain and soybean futures gained varying amounts during today's trading session. At the close, wheat was 1/4 to 3/4 cent higher; corn 1 1/4 off to 1 cent up; oats unchanged to 3/8 cent lower; rye 1 1/4 to 2 cents up, and soybeans 5/8 to 2 1/2 cents higher.

In a letter published in the July 18 edition of The Times Melvin Schrier takes us to task for minimizing the importance of vision as a safety factor in driving. We believe Dr. Schrier misinterpreted our meaning of the two points we brought out. They were definitely not intended to be listed in order of importance.

SEA BRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Two underwater swimming experts wearing oxygen masks and rubber foot fins joined volunteers today in a search of the Shrewsbury River here for 3-year-old George Betz Jr. The boy disappeared at 11 A. M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board threw out today a number of proposals by airlines operating into foreign countries. The airlines sought to cut their liability to passengers and otherwise limit their responsibilities.

Plans for altering the building at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue andNinety-first Street were announced yesterday by IKyraan t3ettigole, attorney, who said his client, the Security Operating Corporation, had purchased the property measurinff 45 by 100 feet.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Fears over the accelerated spread of communism in Italy were expressed today by Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, co-chairman of the Conference of Christians and Jews and pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.
CALLANDER, Ont., Aug. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Emilie Dionne will be buried Monday in a tiny cemetery in the near-by rural parish of Corbeil.
Despite gains in both passenger traffic and gross revenues, earnings of Eastern Air Lines declined in the first six months of this year.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Reynolds Metals Company, one of the three major American aluminum producers, is preparing to enter an agreement to take part of the electric power from a proposed Canadian project on the Yukon River, an Anchorage Times correspondent reported from Washington today.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Roger Bannister, John Landy and six others will run tomorrow in the "miracle mile" of the British Empire Games and for about 4 minutes the athletic world will be tuned to Vancouver with eyes, ears and heart.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The United States and Britain have made headway in the last few days on plans for a multi-nation conference on Southeast Asian defense, to be held during the first half of September.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The last-place Pittsburgh Pirates beat the St. Louis Cardinals twice tonight, 7 -- 3 and 6 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States has strongly protested to the Soviet Union against the detention of two members of the staff of the United States Embassy in Moscow.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Labor party headquarters announced today that the party delegation headed by Clement R. Attlee, which is to leave here Monday for a visit to Communist China, would stop over in Moscow for several days.

The editorial "A Dangerous Breed" in your issue of Aug. 2 refers to an article by Walter Sullivan in your issue of July 31 describing the renascence of dueling in the German universities. A fine article, no doubt. It is nearly identical and almost as good as the story which Mark Twain told in reference to the same subject about seventy years ago in, if I remember correctly, "A Tramp Abroad."

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- A lack of public awareness of eye hygiene in underdeveloped regions is a leading factor in blindness throughout those areas, delegates to the general assembly of the World Council for the Welfare of the Blind were told today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Government statisticians have found that the rates of economic expansion in Canada and the United States have been remarkably close in post-war years.

One doesn't have to put in two years before the mast to discover that the sea is mysterious and sometimes frightening. The recent invasion of dead and dying mossbunkers along the Rockaway shores and the premature visitation of jellyfish in the same waters brings to mind some of the terrible terrors that can make it so for ocean bathers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States has expressed to South Korea its concern over recent acts of violence and demonstrations against neutral nations truce inspection teams. The teams were appointed to inspect the cease-fire in the war between North and South Korea.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The committee named to consider censure charges against Senator McCarthy was urged today to reconsider its ban on television and radio coverage.
NEOPIT, Wis., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Authorities have resurrected a Federal law to prevent a $5,000,000, windfall from turning the Menominee Indian reservation into a salesmen's mecca.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Canadian contract bridge pair of Douglas Drury of Toronto and Eric R. Murray of Hamilton, Ont., led a field of 256 pairs in the men's pair championship this afternoon with a two-session qualifying score of 409 points.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States, Denmark, Norway and Sweden agreed today to establish a new transpolar air route between Scandinavia and the United States by way of Greenland.

Australia anticipates a great expansion of consumer demand for all types of merchandise. And many American companies, to take advantage of the prospective increase, are beginning to manufacture and distribute their products there.
INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 6 -- Showers of streamlined cosmic particles called primary rays are viewed as a hazard for the first men to leave the earth on a space flight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Capitol police confessed astonishment today at an order to empty the office of Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, at 9 o'clock every night, by force if necessary.

We welcome the steps ordered by Mayor Wagner to increase the size of the police force. The city's new Personnel Director will speed the promulgation of a new civil service list and appointments from it; the Budget Director will cooperate with a certificate of appointment and will begin a search for funds that can be shifted from other purposes to the Police Department.

The makers of Guinness Stout, a rich dark Irish brew used by itself or mixed half-and-half with lighter beers, have given up their attempt to make the product in the United States. They will revert after next week to the system of importing the stout from Ireland, as had been the practice up to 1949.

The city's new Personnel Director will speed the promulgation of a new civil service list and appointments from it; the Budget Director will cooperate with a certificate of appointment and will begin a search for funds that can be shifted from other purposes to the Police Department.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla took the oath of office today as President for the next four-year period.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)--The Government said today it was carrying out as rapidly as possible most of the airport safety recommendations of the Doolittle Commission of 1952.

ADD the name of Electro Sonic to the phonograph cartridge field. Electro Sonic claims to have developed a new type of moving coil pickup with the smallest inertia ever achieved, and with an effective weight at the stylus of three- thousandths of a gram. The frequency response is given as 20-20,000 cycles.

FOR many years now the legendary qualities of T. E. Lawrence have bemused us. What kind of man was this young Prince of Mecca with the golden dagger at the waistband, who wrote magnificently about his exploits in Arabia, then wearied of all the accidents surrounding his name and disappeared into the anonymity of an aircraft repair shop?

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 7 -- This California coastal city of 50,000 stands prepared to entertain three times its number for the thirtieth annual fiesta, Old Spanish Days in Santa Barbara, from Wednesday through next Saturday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7 -- Bill Woolsey finally caught his fellow-Hawaiian, Ford Konno, in an American championship defense today at a prolonged session of the national A. A. U. swimming and diving championships which produced two American records and four A. A. U. marks.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 7 -- The Rev. William R. Ricker assumed the pastorate of the East Baptist Church here in 1937, when he retired as an electrical department foreman at the Bayway Refinery of the Esso Standard Oil Company. Now, at the age of 82, he plans to quit the pulpit because he feels the church needs a younger cleric.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 7--The tall doctor from England, Roger Bannister, whipped John Landy and the clock to win the British Empire Games "mile of the century" today in 3 minutes 58.8 seconds.

The acute problem of policing a big city has been brought into sharp focus by the disturbing charge of Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams that this city is "on the verge of becoming a community of crime and violence" because its force is undermanned and underpaid.

AMONG the specialists who give advice on child development there are still a few who tell parents to follow their suggestions to the letter. They imply that there is only one right way of rearing children which, if not followed, will result in trouble and parental "guilt." Today this extremist with all the answers seems to be matched by an extremist of another kind.

DUBLIN, Aug. 7 (UP) -- H. G. Winkler of Germany, riding Halla, a brown gelding, won today's second international jumping competition at the Dublin Horse Show in a field of 36 entries from six nations.

It is a revealing irony that more people were killed during an Army uprising in Guatemala last week than fell during any single engagement of the fortnight's insurgent campaign in June that made Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas the Provisional President.

The Soviet propaganda apparatus has been putting great stress this summer upon convincing the world that all major Kremlin figures are now of equal rank and a truly "collective leadership" now rules the Soviet Union.

PORT-LYAUTEY, French Morocco, Aug. 7-- Eleven persons were killed and more than thirty injured in a riot here today when Moroccans demonstrated against the French-appointed Sultan and attacked security forces and European civilians.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- More than 1,300 persons made a pilgrimage to New Paltz yesterday as five of the original houses in old Huguenot Village were opened to the public.
One of New York's attractions for both residents and out-of-town visitors, the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, has been having a boom in summer attendance.
DENVER, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Maps should look just like the earth would appear to a man in space, Elrey B. Jeppesen decided years ago.

The inland waterways are playing an increasingly important role in the movement of the nation's commerce. Held in the background for nearly a century because of the shift of preference to the much faster railroads, inland waterway transport has gained momentum in the last few years and now is among the industries showing the greatest expansion.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7 -- Anglican Church leaders from every part of the world put aside their theological discussions this afternoon to make a pilgrimage to the first cathedral of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country.

The greatest audience in the history of track and field yesterday saw or heard descriptions of the "miracle mile" at Vancouver, B. C., thanks to a cross-continent hook-up of radio and television stations.

LICQ-ATHEREY, France, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- A prominent cave explorer, Norbert Casteret, dangled from a steel cable for three hours today as he was lowered into the icy blackness of the Pierre Saint Martin Cavern.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Stan Ogilvy's Flame completed a successful series today, gaining her fourth first in five starts this week to capture the Corry Trophy, a star-class feature of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's week-long competition.
TORONTO, Aug. 7--Emilie Dionne died following a series of epileptic seizures, according to the findings of two Montreal physicians who performed an autopsy today.
BRIDGETON, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- A diver for sunken treasure believes he has located the hulk of a British warship sunk in the Mullica River by Colonials during the Revolutionary War.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 7 -- Rear Admiral Walter Frederick Boone, who bears the surname of Daniel Boone, the famous Kentucky hunter and frontiersman, will assume the superintendency of the United States Naval Academy Thursday.

AS a group, the thirty landscapes by members of the Hudson River School now on loan to the Hudson River Museum at Yonkers are not particularly distinguished. But the essential character of this school, and its steady turning away from romanticism to realism during the fifty years of its existence, 1851-65, are sufficiently established.

BANFF, Alta. -- Appearances are deceiving in the Canadian Rockies. This is a realm where mountains, like people, are not always what they seem to be. That noble peak across the wooded valley, which looks so formidable to climb, may offer an easy but hidden route to the summit, presenting no more challenge than a bridle path in Central Park.
MILPITAS, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP) -- This little hamlet of 800 population near the south end of San Francisco Bay awoke with a peck of troubles one February morning in 1953.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 7 (AP) -- E. H. Louw, Economic Minister, expressed amazement last night at an announcement that the Ford Foundation of New York had granted $120,000 to the South African Institute of Race Relations.
HAVANA, Aug. 7 -- President Fulgencio Batista today continued to appoint ministers to renew the Cabinet, all of whose members resigned to seek election Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Peter Thomson, the 24-year-old British open champion from Australia, posted a four-under-par 68 today to take first place in the $25,000 All-American tournament with a 54-hole total of 206.
AS Casey Stengel drives his Yankees in a desperate bid to win that sixth flag in a row we are reminded of a conversation we had with Gar Wood, famous speed boat operator, some twenty years ago.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Although the Victorian gas lamps have gone, older London theatre-goers will find enough to satisfy them at the Savoy Theatre in the fall when the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company returns to its home ground with a full program of Gilbert and Sullivan.

THE completed program of the sixty-third annual convention and trade show of the Photographers Association of America, to be held Aug. 30 through Sept. 3 at the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago, has just been released.

A Vox disk by the Barchet Quartet containing the Quartets K. 80, K. 155, K. 156 and K. 157 makes a logical starting point. Not only are these the first four string quartets Mozart wrote, but this is the first time they are present on one disk.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- While some countries view with dismay any prospect of an increase in rabbits, Ecuador has embarked on an intensive series of experiments in breeding them bigger and more numerous.

WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover and 50,000 guests are expected here Tuesday for a gigantic eightieth birthday party in his honor. This town, the birthplace of the nation's only living Republican ex-President, has a normal population of 719.

A RECENT symposium, in which a group consisting mostly of professional photographers attempted to reach an estimate of the 35mm camera's place in contemporary photography, is reported in September U. S. Camera, a special 35mm issue, published this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- In these closing days of an election-year session, Congress is rapidly completing its record on President Eisenhower's program.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- Brotherly love has rolled up its sleeves and five clergymen, with ladders, paint and brushes, are covering smears that vandals splashed on homes of Negro families on the East side.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France submitted to the National Assembly this week a broad outline of what may almost be called an economic revolution. With it, he proposed a bill, on which a vote will be taken Tuesday, to grant the Government broad powers to start bringing the economy up to date.

SUCH has been the spate of books coming out of South Africa in recent years, it must by now be common knowledge that the population of that tragic land is divided loosely into three groups: White, Colored and Black (or Native). Peter Abrahams, the poet and author of several novels, is colored.
Dr. Roger Bannister of England won from John Landy of Australia by five yards in their "Mile of the Century" match at the British Empire Games at Vancouver, B. C., yesterday.
SOUTHFIELDS, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- More than a score of milk trucks bound for New York City were halted here tonight in what appeared to be a wildcat strike by drivers.

JERUSALEM, July 26 -- Israelis generally have little knowledge of life of the Jewish community in the United States, according to Dr. Moshe Davis, provost of the Jewish Theological Seminary. He is now lecturing here in behalf of the American Jewish Tercentenary Committee and the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

IT is the opinion of Dai H. Lewis, a director of the New York State Automobile Association, that as a matter of justice to motorists, a flat registration fee of $15 should be levied on all passenger cars in the state. New York's present license-fee system is based on the weights of automobiles, 50 cents being charged for every hundred pounds up to 3,500 pounds, and 75 cents for each additional hundred pounds.

COMMUNICATIONS engineers never have shared the layman's enthusiasm for the northern lights, that spectacular pageant nature stages in Arctic skies summer after summer. It seems the electrical particles responsible for the phenomenon of aurora borealis also account for the magnetic storms that scramble radio, telephone and teletype communications.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 7 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the United States' international esteem had hit its lowest point in years because of the "bewildering" policies, of the Republican Administration.
The newest and boldest use of color in a public housing project here is on view at Cypress Hills Houses in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

THROUGHOUT the nations of the world, perhaps billions of coins pass through hands from day to day. And on many of these coins are designs that have some part of a plant in their motif. Almost since the first days of coinage, flowers, fruits and trees have been represented on them.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System and Dr. Frank C. Baxter have set a heartening precedent. By presenting a simple but stimulating literary program, they are putting forth a fine example of the tremendous good that can flow from cooperative efforts of commercial television and educational interests.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- The Indian Government appears to resent deeply the representations made by Britain and Brazil to exercise moderation in the settlement of the future of Portuguese possessions in India.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas backed up today a declaration that the Government was in complete military and political control of the country by announcing the lifting of the restriction of constitutional guarantees.
year's Congressional election battle.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 -- Test borings are being made for this city's $155,000,000 harbor tunnel, described as the biggest single public works project in the history of Maryland. The tube has been in the discussion stage for more than 30 years.

Frederic O. Hess, president of Selas Corporation of America, is an engineer who can do more with a precisely directed gas flame than some people can do with a floor full of machine tools, alloys and additives.

The University of Notre Dame has introduced a new liberal arts curriculum, to become effective with the freshman class this fall. The new plan of studies for the Bachelor of Arts degree constitutes the first major curriculum change in the university's College of Arts and Letters in more than thirty years.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 7 -- The Southwest is booming, its cities and towns are growing and the future is bright. That is the way things look to the normally observant mind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Air Force today announced decorations for six officers and men who rescued nine survivors of the British airliner that was shot down by Chinese Communist planes near Hainan Island on July 23.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Irving Gushen's Soldier Son today won the $5,000 Old Stone Handicap before 23,823 fans at Narragansett Park.

DO books reflect an immediate interest? Somehow, in some way, we think they do. We are, of course, talking about non-fiction books. Fiction is something else, and properly reflects a lasting concern or belief that transcends or lurks beneath the belly of the news.

Not even the tidings that the Giants had lost to Milwaukee could spur the Dodgers to a triumph over the Redlegs yesterday. After being out in front by two runs, the Brooks bowed, 5 -- 4, to a Cincinnati club that had won only two of its previous ten games on this Eastern trip.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 7 -- The $400,000 boardwalk fire that damaged the front of the world-famous Steel Pier here recently recalls the important part amusement piers have played in entertaining more than 100,000,000 visitors to this resort in the last seventy-two years.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Rival Republican groups battled today for control of the California state party organization. The long shadow of the 1956 Presidential campaign was discernible over the harsh political contest.

I am distressed to find that your Summer Festival layout, "Where Culture Is Cooler" (July 25), shows a picture of Pearl Lang in the "Song of Deborah" at Jacob's Pillow, Mass. (assisted by Joan Skinner), without mention of her name.

A QUARTER of a century has passed since William Morton Wheeler revised his classic "Ants, Their Structure, Development and Behavior." At that time his bibliography ran to sixty pages and more than 2,300 entries. Today it would be far longer.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Premier Y. T. Pyun said yesterday South Korea would "avoid resorting to any forcible means" in the campaign to get the Communist members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission out of the country.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 7 -- Rocket enthusiasts at the International Astronautical Congress were told today that space flight programs were now almost entirely dominated by considerations of military security.

NASSAU, BAHAMAS -- The first new major hotel in many years will open here next Saturday in time to take advantage of the best summer season this British colony has ever enjoyed. Business at the resort's present "big three" hotels is running 30 per cent ahead of last year's record summer as the Emerald Beach Hotel, Nassau's version of the modern resorts opened throughout the Caribbean since the war, prepares for its first guests.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- Next Monday the Government will begin to apply a new law providing very severe penalties for anyone who produces or sells adulterated wine. The chief purpose of the measure is to defend the good name of Italian wines, some of which are world famous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A new weapon against subversion was being hammered into shape this week in a bill to compel testimony of witnesses before Congress or its committees by granting them immunity from criminal prosecution.

IN the tumult of French politics, the most easily overlooked person is the French politician. Except for the ephemeral fame accorded to him when as Deputy he is considered for the Premiership, few are known outside their own districts. This is an unfortunate oversight; the French multi-party system being what it is, a few Deputies can make or break governments almost at will.

Announcement was made by Harvard University last week that a new course leading to a master's degree in data processing will be started this fall. Processing of industrial, scientific and business data by machine, according to the Harvard announcement, has become so important that the new course, the first offering such a degree in an American university, has been established.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The thriving city of Singapore seems to be getting more prosperous all the time and it is wide open to foreign investors.

Archie Moore, 37-year-old light heavyweight champion of the world, will put his title on the line for the third time Wednesday night when he meets Harold Johnson, 26-year-old Philadelphian, in a scheduled 15-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Neither showers nor downpours overcome the effect of several dry seasons on shade trees. Big old trees as well as those set out during the last year require watering once a week until the ground freezes. Sprinkling is no help. Let water seep slowly through the hose for several hours. AND IF THERE IS TIME: Weeds are easily removed after a rain.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The United States adopted a hands-off attitude today toward the dispute aroused when German householders refused to move from their homes to make way for a United States Army housing project.

THE life and times of Abraham Lincoln will be the theme of the 1954 National Postage Stamp Show, sixth annual exhibition-bourse sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers Association. The show will be held Nov. 19-21 at the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, serving incidentally as a wind-up for National Stamp Collecting Week.

HAVANA, Aug. 3 -- President Fulgencio Batista's order for the removal of Communists from the Government payroll is meeting with resistance from special interests and complete indifference on the part of the Cuban people, Ernesto de la Fe, Minister Without Portfolio, says.

Representative Clifford Hope, Republican chairman of the Agriculture Committee of the House and arch foe of the Administration's program of flexible farm price supports, has just released a summary of a report of the committee's staff on the relation between food prices on the farm and at the retail level.

PARIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Premier Pierre Mendes - France today promised Frenchmen a rebuilt, more prosperous nation.

Twelve years ago today, Edward S. Davis, then a 20-year-old Navy midshipman, was fished out of the South Pacific. Thirteen days later he was fished out again. This double baptism has left him with a respect for the number 13 that is rare in a modern mariner.

Two thousand members of the First Marine Division Association attended yesterday a memorial service for the division's dead. The service was held in the Astor Hotel, where the association is meeting for its seventh annual reunion.

The International Astronautical Federation met in Innsbruck, Austria, this week, but the eyes of the astronauts were not on the Alps towering over the Inn River Valley. They were on the moon and on Mars and Venus in the skies overhead.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Ken Wood of England and two other English runners beat Fred Dwyer of Philadelphia in the mile race at an international track and field meet today before a crowd of 30,000 at Ibrox Stadium.

THE latest novel by John Tebbel is a well-paced story about the birth and growth of The Guardian, a newspaper founded in Little Old New York in 1835 and continuing through the Civil War draft riots. Scrupulously documented and generously spiced with those bits and pieces of fact which ease the conscience of the historical novelist and reassure the readers, "A Voice in the Streets" makes good and, at times, titillating reading.

DALLAS, Aug. 7 -- Construction work is on a midsummer boom in the Southwest and July contract awards, for the first month this year, topped the corresponding month of 1953. Awards for the month totaled nearly $86,000,000, compared with about $80,000,000 in July a year ago.

ROBERT BOWEN'S third novel, less openly savage than his first two books, "The Weight of the Cross" and "Bamboo," is a devastating insight into the modus operandi of a particularly nasty type of middle-class woman.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 7 -- Three times a day a big silver baloon rises from Fort Custer, near here. Swinging under it is a plastic box containing instruments that collect and transmit to a ground station information on metereological conditions at 1,000 feet to 80,000 feet.

The campaign to build the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy at Stratford, Conn., will be stepped up by an outdoor benefit performance Aug. 29 at the Stamford (Conn.) High School Stadium. Called "Celebrity Night," the variety program will be produced by Jean Dalrymple and stage by Charles Bowden.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Rilma's Widower, a 7-year-old brown gelding owned by Philo Hammond of Stockton, Kan., and driven by Del Cronk, scored an upset victory in 2:12 2/5 in the Riverhead Pace over the mile and one-sixteenth distance tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

VINCENNES, Ind. -- When a cross - country motorist gets about two days west of New York City it is a good idea to break the monotony of highway travel with an interesting stop-over, if the right place can be found. Ideal for this purpose is historic Vincennes, Ind.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Aug. 7 -- The widow of a Los Alamos scientist who lost his life during a Pacific atomic bomb test received the Army's thanks this week for his contributions toward the development of such weapons.

Maj. Gen. Charles I. Carpenter, Chief of Air Force Chaplains, will head a group of Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish religious leaders on a visit to Air Force bases in Europe and North Africa. They will leave Tuesday and are expected to return around Sept. 5.

The new Norwegian cargo ship Hardanger will sail from West Coast ports this week on her maiden voyage in the Westfal-Larsen Line's service around South America.

Hasler, an assistant naval attache, as a result of their photo-snapping activity is the second formal complaint of this nature made by the Americans to the Soviet Foreign Office this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Several weeks before Nov. 2, when the voters go to the polls to decide which party will control the organization of the Eighty-fourth Congress, the Senate will return from a recess to render judgment on the proposal that Joseph R. McCarthy, its junior member from Wisconsin, be censured for certain of his legislative and personal activities as unbecoming a Senator of the United States.

WASHINGTON -- The Moslem call to prayer may soon be a familiar sound in Washington, for the finishing touches are being put on the first mosque to be built in the nation's capital. The North American continent has a new bird, the cattle egret (Bubulcus ibis). This handsome member of the heron family looks something like the white domestic goose, according to the current issue of the National Geographic Magazine. The cattle egret is believed to be the first bird to leave the Old World and travel to the Western Hemisphere without human aid.

THE network, the sponsors, the producers, the talent and others concerned with N. B. C. television's series of ninety minute color shows, to start in the fall, are agreed that the telecasts should be carried "live" from coast to coast.
Two Bronx 16-year-olds who spent thousands of dollars of the girl's parents' money returned home yesterday, declaring they had been married during a run-away trip that took them to Washington.

The American Association of University Women has announced 1954-55 fellowship awards of $70,500, an increase of 11 per cent over the assistance last year to women scholars for advanced research. The awards have been made to thirty-five women who showy promise in creative, scholally work and whose projects will make a definite contribution to knowledge.

Malan's racialism.

HAVANA, Aug. 7 -- The Cuban Government has hung out the welcome sign to oil prospectors.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 -- Not even a palpably bad decision by the umpires could save the Yankees from a costly 3-1 defeat by the Detroit Tigers today at Briggs Stadium. While George Zuverink stopped the champions with sidearm sinkers, the Bengals damaged New York's pennant hopes with long-range drives, including homers by Ray Boone and Wayne Belardi. Tom Morgan was the loser.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 7 -- Retail stores sales racked up modest to good gains in most lines last week as clearance sales of summer goods were well patronized. Offerings of fall merchandise met good response. Price tags, for the most part, are lower than a year ago on staples.
