Stores that stocked up for summer selling benefited by the hot weather and did good business in July, resident buying offices report. Others, who were forced to shop the market for quick-delivery goods, found such merchandise hard to obtain, and their business suffered as a result.

AN idle August afternoon or, a quiet summer evening, suggests the Horticultural Society of New York, is an ideal time to curl up with a good garden book. It is also a fine time to get a head start on reading for those fall courses that will soon be in the offing.

Under Secretary of State Gen. Walter B. Smith pointed out that the U. S. S. R. would now like to allay the feeling of alarm that caused the free nations to draw together. Everyone will welcome the fact that the Soviet Union adopts, for the time being, a less aggressive policy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Senate today confirmed a nine-member United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly headed by former Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Bob Brownell and Ralph Bogart, golfing partners and business associates from Bethesda, Md., moved into the final of the John G. Anderson memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Club today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- Troops quartered in the Rio de Janeiro district were kept on the alert through last night because of tension arising from the attack early Thursday on Carlos Lacerda, a newspaper editor, in which an air force major was shot dead.
DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 7 (AP) -Lewis Castle, the stocky banker who will direct the giant St. Lawrence Seaway project doesn't force work from his people -- he leads them in getting the job done.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Trainer Jack Creevy put a pair of blinkers on Mrs. George D. Widener's Evening Out today for the first time in her career, sent the 3-year-old filly to the post in the $63,000 Monmouth Oaks with his blessings and then awaited developments. The move paid off.

ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The "art" of getting information from interviews and observation is being studied in Cornell University's Social Science Research Center, where an experimental course in social science field methods has been completed.
OFTENTIMES similarity in flower form can be confusing. In some cases it leads to plants being known incorrectly by the name of the flower they resemble, rather than their own official name.

Washington worked quietly behind the scenes last week to build up a new rampart against communism in the form of a Southeast Asian Treaty Organization. But at the week-end SEATO was still a dream and the only announced enthusiasm for the project came from Australia, a non-Asian country which feels itself threatened by Asian communism.

THE rotation of the earth helped bring about the nationwide pilots' strike against American Airlines. The rotation causes prevailing westerly winds over the United States; the winds slow down westbound airplanes; the fact that American's westbound non-stop flights to the Coast take more than eight hours caused the strike.

ALTHOUGH this summer's drought -- broken only partly in the East this past week -- has seemingly dimmed the prospects for autumn bloom, certain fall-blossoming bulbs may be planted in August to provide spots of good color from September through much of November.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A report by the Federal Office of Education shows that 497,216 public school children were enrolled in special classes during the school year 1952-53.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Precautionary measures to guard against further slides on the American side of Niagara Falls were decided upon this week by State park officials and engineers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A group of Michigan Republicans, including their candidates for the Senate, the Governorship and two House seats, called on President Eisenhower today and had group and individual campaign photographs taken in his office.
A dream of nearly fifty years, that of harnessing the power in the International Rapids Section of the St. Lawrence River, will begin the transition to reality Tuesday.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France asked the National Assembly today for a vote of confidence on the bill to grant him special powers to institute his program for French economic and financial "recon version."

THE most ambitious project ever entrusted to a string quartet goes rolling along. With the release of Haydn's six Russian Quartets, Op. 33 on three Haydn Society disks, the Schneider String Quartet is well over the halfway mark in the marathon that will encompass all of the composer's eighty-odd works in the form. Nice, resonant recorded sound here, and meticulous performances.
In the "cold war" against communism we are engaged in a world struggle for the minds of men. Events have shown that we are losing that struggle.

IT was high time someone brought out a new recorded version of Rigoletto, and the Italian firm of Cetra has done it. The new version of the opera, made under the direction of Angelo Questa by the symphony orchestra of Radiotelevisione Italiana and the Cetra Chorus, presents Giuseppe Taddei in the title role, Ferruccio Tagliavini as the Duke of Mantua and Lina Pagliughi as Gilda. (Capitol, three disks).

THE fires of ancient Troy burn brightly these nights against the Roman skyline, and we went out the other evening to watch the conflagration. The fires, man-made and reasonably under control, are sponsored by Warner Brothers and are viewable, upon invitation, on the back lot of Cinecitta Studios, a few miles outside this city.

THE sign said something about "beware of deer and children," so we knew we had arrived. The bear which had loped ahead of us for the last quarter of a mile had really been on the road, not, as we had begun to think, leading us up his own private trail.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- What is the so-called "Lustron deal" that has risen from his past to haunt Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin?

NATCHEZ, Miss., Aug. 7 -- Despite the possible consequences of an open defiance of the Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision, school authorities here have decided to maintain segregation as long as possible.

CORTEZ, Colo., Aug. 5 -- Four rural electrification cooperatives in the heart of this uranium country have begun a campaign to obtain the first atomic reactor for use in small electrical generating plants.
AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 7 -- Liberal and conservative Texas Democrats are locked in their tightest and bitterest battle of many years in the run-off primary campaign for Governor.

THE idea of travel on credit, which has recently prompted several airlines to start selling tickets and tours on various kinds of installment plans, has been taken up on a large scale by one of the important travel agencies, the American Express Company.
Steamship, rail and bus travelers as well as air passengers may now travel on the installment plan under a credit arrangement announced last week by the American Express Company.
The glass container business, despite the inroads made in recent years by containers fabricated from other materials, is doing well.
Francis William Holbrook Adams, twenty - fourth Police Commissioner of New York since 1898 when consolidation produced "the greatest city," believes in fundamentals.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State at the Foreign Office and Acting Foreign Secretary in Anthony Eden's absence on a holiday in Austria, cited today the "new pattern of relations" that the British Government was seeking to develop in its relations with the Middle East states.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Howard Seymour's Mutiny was the winner by a wide margin in the International Class tonight as a fleet of 121 sloops engaged in a drifting match on the first day of the American Yacht Club's regatta week-end on Long Island Sound.
BUDD BOETTICHER, who at the tender age of eighteen served time as a torero below the Rio Bravo, is about to make what may well be the definitive bullfight picture of all time.

Now that sectional, regional and divisional regattas and other small-fry events on the speedboat racing circuits have led into the season's home stretch, the time has arrived for the big doings of the summer. The Northwest had the Gold Cup yesterday at Seattle.

HARTFORD, Aug. 7 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford, Democratic nominee for Governor, promised eastern Connecticut residents this week that he would conduct a "personal" campaign to bring new industry into the area if he were elected in November.

Ragwort still shows its rather dusty yellow flowers at the roadside, and soapwort makes a display of pink in the waste places. They are only two of the dozens of worts that thrive and bloom without particular notice or acclaim, since the old-time gatherers of wild herbs have largely vanished.
CRAPE MYRTLE is to the South in summer what the lilac is to the North and the East in spring. And, like the lilac, it has become the shrub of the people.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- For the first time in any month, building contracts reached $142,000,000 in Pennsylvania in June. The Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University also noted that postal receipts, telephones and bank debits established new highs for June.

When the excess profits tax expired last Dec. 31, to the hurrahs of some 50,000 or so corporations affected, concern was expressed in some quarters that the termination might have painful side effects.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 7 -- Although the Indochina war is over, the political battle in partioned Vietnam is far from finished.

THE conquered place of Robert Shafer's first novel is Europe, Asia, Africa and the eastern half of North America. The conquerors are the Russians. The defeated forces of the United States and its allies, with 20 million men in their armies west of the Mississippi and south of the Rio Grande, are readying a counter-attack. Part of the plan calls for the rescue of a uniquely gifted scientist from Russian-held Center City, Ohio.

ALBERT E. Plesman, the former president-director of KLM, the Royal Dutch Airlines, who died last December at the age of 64, will be pictured on a 10c + 4c gray blue stamp which the Netherlands will issue on Aug. 23. The stamp is one of a set of two semipostals, inscribed "Youth and Aviation," intended to raise money for the Dutch National Aviation Fund.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- A team of scientists is on the way to the Middle East to investigate the dawn of civilization.
HONG KONG, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Three United States priests, released by the Chinese Communists as a result of the Geneva conference, reached Hong Kong tonight from Yuanling, Hunan Province.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 2 -- A thoughtful young Frenchman who lives at the press camp in Hanoi came to Saigon today for a short leave and was good enough to bring down the mail. It included a July 30 notice addressed to this correspondent by the Vietnamese Controller of Telegraph in Hanoi.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- The East German Government announced today that the Soviet High Commission in Germany had returned the office buildings and residences occupied by Soviet authorities since 1945 in the Berlin suburb of Karlshorst.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Westchester is embarking on a new tax-supported mental health program for county residents who need brief or prolonged psychiatric care.
WHEN Herbert Clark Hoover attains his eightieth birthday this Tuesday he will be the first ex-President in more than a century to reach that age. The last was John Quincy Adams, who died in 1848.

Governor Dewey clashed yesterday with Mayor Wagner over the city's proposal to solve its crime problem with additional funds from the state. The Governor made public figures to show that New York had all the money it needed to hire extra policemen without appealing to Albany for more money.

THE story of the ill-fated Japanese geisha, Cio-Cio San, internationally renowned as depicted in Puccini's opera, "Madame Butterfly," is at long last slated to go before the cameras. Excerpts from this favorite already have turned up in films from Hollywood and Europe, and one Paramount drama in 1932 featured the libretto along with Sylvia Sidney and Cary Grant, her Lieutenant Pinkerton, minus a single Puccini note.

One of the major problems facing Mayor Robert F. Wagner when he took office last January was "New York's finest." The Police Department was far under strength. The police were bitter over their pay scale. They were also demoralized over the loss of public confidence as a result of the "cops and gamblers" scandals of 1951-52.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is seeking and may obtain the right to cross-examine witnesses before the special Senate committee created to study censure charges against him.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Herman L. Bishop, a building contractor of this village, has announced his intention to oppose Adrian Mason of Patchogue for the chairmanship of the Suffolk County Democratic committee. Mr. Mason has held the post since May 3, 1952, when he was elected to succeed Supervisor Joseph V. Kelly of Riverhead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Senate worked through a fourth day of speeches on the farm issue with some signs today that it might settle for the flexible farm price support level voted by the House of Representatives.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Industries in the Chicago area continued to provide for increased production facilities during July. The Association of Commerce and Industry reported that investments in in dustrial plants announced during the month totaled $16,453,000, compared with $12,348,000 in the same period last year.

AS usual, this writer guessed wrongly in picking a vacation month this year. What look like the two best pictures of the summer popped up in July, which was just the month we figured would be the least replete with high- grade films.

LADYSMITH, Wis., -- The roaring excitement of white water and the relaxation of long, still stretches through virgin forests await the traveler who runs Wisconsin's Flambeau River in a canoe or small boat. It offers nearly fifty miles of paddling, through all types of water and past some of the wildest woods left in the state.
Two thousand boys and girls have so far entered the fifth annual junior fishing contest to be conducted by the Parks Department a week from tomorrow.

IT is now at least three weeks since readers of this column, and of daily bridge reports in The New York Times, have heard about much except the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament in Washington, D. C., which is now in its final rounds.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- The West German Government offered a reward of 500,000 Deutsche marks ($119,000) today for information that would clear up the strange disappearance of its former security chief, Dr. Otto John.

" SHOW me a hero" Scott Fitzgerald once wrote, "and I will write you a tragedy." In this novel of the Korean War Melvin Voorhees* shows us several men cast in the heroic mold. But he has failed to write us anything remotely approximating a tragedy.

SO many books have been written about the Eskimos that one thought they were pretty well known. Now comes a Norwegian scientist with a book about some unknown people. They are Eskimos; they speak the language in use along the Alaskan coast and way over to Greenland; yet they only go down to the sea for short trading visits.
SEATTLE, Aug. 7 -- Slo-Mo-Shun IV dropped her Gold Cup crown on Lake Washington today but her Seattle sister, Slo-Mo-Shun V roared to victory in all three heats to pick it up.

THE poor condition of many spruce trees this summer is due either to mite infestations, the long drought or a twig blight fungus called cytospora. In some cases, according to Dr. Rush P. Marshall, director of the Bartlett Tree Research Laboratories, old established spruces as well as newly planted ones are suffering from a combination of all three.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Ten Seeing-Eye Dogs trained to lead blind persons died today and sixteen others were in poor condition after someone threw poisoned wieners into the La Salle Kennels at Oak Knoll.
NETCONG, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Herbert B. Pontery, 59 years old, of Jersey City was shot fatally today by his estranged wife Ida in her summer home here, the police reported.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug 7 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the host club and Lionel Coloby, Stockbridge (Mass.) businessman, reached the semi-final round of the Garden State Golf Association's first mixed scotch foursome tournament at the Montclair Club today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Strong finishes by Dogoon in the $18,000 George Woolf Memorial and Hasseyampa in the $27,600 Sheridan Handicap paid off today in Washington Park's double-header stakes program.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 -- While two New Yorkers, Larry Evans and Abe Turner, with scores of 4 -- 0 each, adjourned their fifth-round match in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation today, four other contestants moved closer to first place with scores of 4 1/2 -- 1/2.
PRINCETON, N. J., Aug,. 7 -- A two-man recording team from Princeton University's undergraduate radio station is collecting material for a fall radio series that will picture European thought.
ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- The New York State Board of Regents chartered thirty-seven new educational, cultural and historical organizations during the school year that ended June 30.
There still was no stopping the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday although the Giants again made it close.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Jim Fridley's bases-loaded single in the third inning gave a 2-to-1 victory to the Baltimore Orioles over the Boston Red Sox today behind the two-hit pitching of Bob Turley.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Passengers returning to Southampton today from a luxury cruise aboard the Orient liner Orcades had to unload their own luggage because 1,900 dockers staged a lightning unofficial protest strike against Saturday afternoon work.

AARON COPLAND should be able to write a good opera, perhaps a first-rate one. It is to be hoped that he will try again soon. Opera in America needs operas by Americans, and Mr. Copland could be the composer to create the first work by an American to win a secure place in the repertories of the major companies.

While national figures show that only 50 per cent of high school students receive diplomas, New York City's Cooperative Education Program graduates 99 per cent. The secret seems to be a palatable mixture of work and study.

LONDON -- Famous restaurants and hotels here have been taking full advantage of the termination of Britain's food-rationing program, and as a result tourists this summer are eating better than they have since the end of the war.
ILFRACOMBE, England, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- The tiny granite church on the Isle of Lundy, where income tax and licensing laws are unknown, had its seventh recorded wedding today.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Aug. 7 -- Former United States Senator Glen H. Taylor, who threw in with the Progressives as Henry A. Wallace's 1948 running-mate, is the big question mark in Tuesday's crowded primaries.

THREE shows by one photographer are currently on view in local galleries this month and part of next. They are the work of Cyrus Townsend Brady Jr., a retired business man living at the Prince George Hotel, whose hobby is the use of the camera as a means of recording objects, scenes and people he has seeen on his frequent travels to various parts of the world:

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 7 -- With agreement in principle reached on the critical oil question, Iran will shortly be confronted with a choice between maintaining strict neutrality or joining a regional defense arrangement, such as the Turkish-Pakistani pact.
The Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Me., is marking its twenty-fifth anniversary this year.
Four passenger steamship companies announced last week a series of special cruises for the fall and winter seasons.

THESE four little volumes belong to a British series edited by Erich Heller, and published simultaneously in this country and in England. The editor's hand has been firm. He must have enjoined his authors to write 23,000 words, give or take a few hundred and to avoid using many long or difficult ones.
The restrictive trade winds from Washington have brought gloom and uncertainty to the importing field.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The 1954 men's pair championship was captured this afternoon by the Canadian pair of Eric R. Murray of Hamilton, Ont., and Douglas Drury of Toronto.

FAIR HAVEN, N. J., Aug. 7 -- In the same kind of flat water and sunny weather that has blessed the cruiser navigators all summer, a skipper of the Northern New Jersey Power Squadron, Austin P. Winters of Summit, N. J., today won the ocean predicted-log race of the Shrewsbury River Yacht Club.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- Larry Doby's three-run homer and four-hit pitching by Bob Feller powered the Cleveland Indians today to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics.

Arnold Toynbee's "The Revolution We Are Living Through" (July 25) faced only half the problem he presented. Summed up, his thesis is that the "present upheaval is a double revolt -- against the West's ascendancy over the rest of the world and against the Western middle class ascendancy over the Western industrial workers."

LIKE all Gaul, the Brooklyn-Dodgers can be divided into three parts -- the Larry MacPhail, Branch Rickey and Walter O'Malley eras. That's the way "The Rhubarb Patch" (Simon Schuster, $1.50), a memory book with words by Red Barber and pictures by Barney Stein, tells the story of the modern Brooklyn Dodgers.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Of the 12,335 elementary school children in Suffolk County who underwent the Salk test in the polio vaccine experiment of last spring and thus became "polio pioneers" none has contracted the disease, the Suffolk County Department of Health reported today.

SEWARD, Alaska -- After a late spring that held up necessary seasonal repairs, the Alaska Highway and connecting roads in Alaska and Canada are now in their peak post-war condition. The 1954 motorist finds the wilderness as appealing as ever, but less appalling than seven years ago reporter wrote, "It cash, courage and a good set of tools to travel the Alcan Highway."

The men of the Bennington who struggled to save their ship and the lives of their shipmates after an explosion last May 26 were honored here yesterday. Commanding Officer's Awards were presented to 107 officers and men on the carrier's flight deck.

BRIELLE, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Commodore Vic Till of the Brielle Yacht Club is close to seven feet in height and down here on the Jersey Shore they call him a "moon-fixer." That's a better name than they realize, for all his life Vic has been reaching for the moon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- There is a new sound in Washington. The Government has lowered its voice. After the thunder-like percussion of its statements on Indochina, it seems to have decided after all that the only realistic alternatives in this unsatisfactory era are either coexistence with the Communists or no existence.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 7 -- Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia approved today the final text of the Balkan military pact, which will weld together a potential of ninety-five divisions.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Not until the running of the $28,500 Saratoga Handicap was a favorite able to make the grade in the horse-park activities at sunny Saratoga today. Then Cold Command, at a bit over 2 to 1, did the job.

A FELLOW who goes by the nickname of "Doodles" has been picked to be father of the United States Air Force Academy. The nickname, suggesting an addiction to a "wacky" type of drawing, does not portray the man, nor his talent and love for serious sketching, nor his approach to his job.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Martin W. Oettershagen, Chicago port manager who was confirmed by the Senate today to be deputy administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation, asserts that he would have "no right" to decline the appointment.

President Eisenhower struck the right note at his latest press conference when he said we Americans should make less of the idea of our international "leadership" and more of the idea of our "partnership." Some phases of the leadership are inevitable.

WHEN is it time for turkey? A decade ago we thought of the native American bird in terms of Thanksgiving and winter holidays, coupling it with chestnut or oyster stuffing, giblet gravy, cranberry sauce and boiled onions.

ARRANGEMENTS were completed last week for an airlift in two laps that will transport the Old Vic production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" from Britain for its opening at the Metropolitan Opera House here on Sept. 21.

Congressional action is being mobilized by Representative Edwin E. Willis of Louisiana to fight a serious plant pest in several Southern states. What has been called for is literally a war of extermination on a beautiful flower, the water hyacinth.

History is still being made on the site of ancient Carthage, where so much history lies buried in the rubble. Last Sunday's report from Tunis told how Premier Mendes-France, arriving by plane from Paris, drove over to the site of ancient Carthage, where Bey Sidi Mohammed el-Amin has his summer palace, and there made the offer of internal autonomy for the French protectorate.

Education in the United States has created the world's greatest scientists, engineers, teachers and industrialists. Unfortunately, it has failed to prevent the creation of a great mass of "uneducated" educated. That is why we are confronted from time to time with the unexplained spectacle of a world-famous scientist falling prey to subversive movements.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Some of the best racing skippers of the eastern seaboard devoted an hour and three-quarters today to finding out that the wind was smarter than anybody.

THE psychological book market has been flooded with detailed studies and with careful attempts to formulate new concepts, but which do not offer the reader a well-rounded picture of the science. One can imagine the pleasure of the reviewer upon receiving into his hands three powerful and well-balanced books instead of further tentative approximations.

LAST week the annual season for state fairs got under way with Montana's exposition at Great Falls. Between now and mid-November practically all of the forty-eight states will hold their big exhibitions of farm produce, animal husbandry and the products of local kitchens.

BEAUFORT WEST, South Africa, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- Eric Louw, economic affairs minister, has challenged an Anglican bishop's statement in Minneapolis that the church did not practice racial segregation "in theory" in South Africa.

THIS little book consists of five lectures delivered at Hollins College in 1953. Hollins' President John R. Everett, troubled by the students' "extremely shaky foundation for judgment about some of the most serious questions of our day," wanted a lecturer who could give the college "a sane and firm platform of fact and theory" about international affairs.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Antoni Klimowicz, 24, the Polish stowaway who was taken off the Polish freighter Jaroslaw Dabrowski by British police a week ago, began his new life today a free man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- An appeal to state Governors to organize local committees and thus stimulate the resettlement of 190,000 victims of Communist persecution was sent to forty-seven states today by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- In the background of almost every major foreign policy decision made these days by the Eisenhower Administration there is the figure of a man who may well be called America's "master spy."

SON of the late film czar, a screenwriter in his own right, and at present a teacher of English at Wabash College, Indiana, Will H. Hays Jr. has set this long and complicated first novel in the glandularly active town of Harrisville, a semi-rural coal-mining, community.

In Washington last week the Eighty-third Congress moved toward an extraordinary climax. The familiar session's end rush to wrap up the loose ends of law-making was on. The great and dramatic difference came in the Senate. There the lines were drawn for yet another controversy over the Junior Senator from Wisconsin.

A spokesman for the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission said yesterday that the agency would welcome suggestions on how to pare its budget. But he acknowledged that under present policy the budget was not available for public inspection and criticism before its submission to the Governors of the two states.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Bobby Morgan hit two home runs and Rookie Danny Schell hit another today as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 2.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The British Labor party is divided on many issues but on none more sharply than on the question of West German rearmament.

" Lie detector" is a bad name for what technicians call a "polygraph." No machine can detect a lie. What the polygraph does is to record in wavy lines emotional states as blood pressure rises and falls, breathing varies, and the resistance of the skin to feeble electric current changes.

The demand for electric power is rising rapidly in Britain and the other principal industrial countries of free Europe, two engineering executives reported last week. And it will increase an average of 10 per cent annually for the next ten years, they predicted.

A group profile of some of the nation's top executives, published this month in the Harvard Business Review, appears to answer to a certain degree the perennial question: "What are the essential ingredients of success?" The answer is intended primarily to help management select its executives but also will be of particular interest to aspiring bosses still in school.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Yugoslav authorities hope to solve soon the riddle of whether Byzantine ruins at Caricin Grad, in southern Serbia, are the remains of the city of Justiniana Prima founded by Justinian, ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire.

GARDENERS in California and England, so many thousands of miles apart, are as close as a whisker in their admiration for and devoted cultivation of the genus ceanothus. Varying with species, varieties and geographic location, this native North American shrub or small tree, a member of the buckthorn family, has an amazing blooming season -- February to late June.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals ended Pittsburgh's longest winning streak of the season at three games today with an 8-6 victory. The Pirates committeed five errors, including three on one play.

It would seem unwise, and could be tragic, to believe and act on the case made by Sumner Slichter in "The Danger of Severe Recession Seems Over" (July 18), in which he concludes that the economy is approaching real stability.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The offer of rapid tax amortization has helped to induce companies to invest $132,541,990 in defense facilities in chronic surplus labor areas.

An almost instinctive rivalry exists in New York between pedestrian and motorist. This traditional antagonism is demonstrated most sharply on crowded downtown street corners, where the pedestrian tries eagerly to maneuver his way to the opposite curb on red light or green, and the motorist swerves in and out of precarious turns; both lawful and unlawful.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France spent this week-end studying the European Defense Community treaty, which will come up for ratification in the National Assembly Aug. 24. Rarely has a political decision involved such a mosaic of domestic and foreign issues.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates captured their second double-header in three days from the St. Louis Cardinals, winning 12 -- 4 and 5 -- 3 today.

Margarine, the rare golden jungle bird that deserted her mate a week ago, has been found -- and all is forgiven. A two-state search for the valuable bird ended at 11:48 o'clock last night when the errant wife, looking mighty bedraggled, was brought to the apartment of her owner, Harry Zelenko, at 450 East Sixty-third Street. Margie's spouse, Oleo, didn't have a word to say.
Failure by the Federal Government to deal adequately with the narcotic problem in New York is a major factor in the city's crime wave, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh declared yesterday.

The shortest distance between Gansevoort Street, Manhattan, and the Sixth Street pier, Hoboken, is about five-eighths of a mile of steely blue Hudson River water. Three New York teenagers swam it yesterday easy as pie.

One aspect of the constantly changing scene in New York that is most heartening is the evidence of awakened recognition of the need for promoting the city. This recognition can be noted on a broad front. The Department of Commerce and Public Events, headed by Commissioner Patterson, is stirring with ideas and fact-finding plans.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- A welcome southwest breeze that ran about 12 knots provided a rousing finish for a fleet of 128 boats in the concluding day of the American Yacht Club's regatta week-end on Long Island Sound today.

The opening in May of the reconstructed Brooklyn Bridge, with its traffic lanes increased from two to three in each direction, made it imperative that provision be made for the expected increase in traffic at the bridge's Manhattan Plaza. This busy area, which includes City Hall and the Municipal Building, cannot be permitted to become clogged with vehicular congestion.

On gross operatingrevenues of :$88,548,673, the Curtis Publishing [Company and its consolidated subI sidiaries made a net profit of $3,728,241 in the first six months this year. Earnings for the 1953 period were $2,750,173 on gross operating revenues of $87,568,296.

A $500,000 study of blood samples from children who took part in the polio vaccine trials has been started by eighteen laboratories, Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday.

WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Residents of this community paid tribute today to the Air Force pilot who stayed with his disabled jet fighter-bomber to crash it into an almost deserted street at noon last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The special committee created to study the conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy probably will not begin hearings until at least a week after Congress finishes its legislative business.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Jack Harshman shut out Washington, 3 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header today after the Senators had taken the opener from the Chicago White Sox, 7 -- 6, on Roy Sievers' ninth-inning home run.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey FrancisI Fisher Archbishop of CanterburyI :and Primate of All England de-I scribed British-American friendship here today as a "union" of free peoples pledged to "defend freedom in a sorely distressed world."

Henceforth, all fresh fruit products of the Florida Citrus Exchange will be marketed in the North by Scald-Sweet Sales, Inc., a new sales and promotion subsidiary. In addition to placing greater stress on quality at the packing house level, Seald-Sweet will embark on a heavy advertising campaign aimed at stimulating fresh fruit sales.

CHICAGO, Aug 8 (AP) -- Jerry Barber, who has to remove his glasses to line up short putts, conquered Tam O'Shanter's tricky, rain-dampened greens today for a closing 69 to win the All-American golf title with a 72-hole score of 277 -- eleven under par.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The White House has taken alarm at the economic plight of Japan.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Tonight a national speedboat championship is looking for another water course because plans for the 44-cubic inch title event had to be abandoned here this afternoon. Rough water was the reason.

The British Empire Games committee left little room for error in clocking the "mile of the century" Saturday in which Dr. Roger Bannister defeated John Landy with a 3:58.8 effort. The committee had $8,000 worth of timing devices checking the race.
CORBEIL, Ont., Aug. 8 -- Thousands of men, women and children lined up in the rain today for a last look at Emilie Dionne.

The Phoenix Hosiery Company had an operating loss of $156,770 and a net loss of $1,264,998 for the six months ended on June 30, Frazier D. MacIver, president, announced yesterday after a meeting of the board.

It was a brief dispatch, dated Aug. 9 and with a picture of the man beside it, that ten years ago today confirmed his loss. "Antoine de Saint-Exupery, 44 years of age, French pilot and author," this newspaper said, "is missing after a mission over southern France. * * *"
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The United States pledged today its help in evacuating 100,000 Vietnamese refugees. It will help them get a new start in life south of the line of Communist domination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Leslie Caron will go Bohemian in her next picture, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today. The French star has been assigned a starring role in "Latin Quarter," a fin-de-siecle musical extravaganza.

Minority groups must share an active interest in the political, public and civic affairs of their community if they would share the rights and privileges of all the people, Hulan E. Jack said yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- At the beginning of September the French Government will repay to Britain $25,000,000 on the loan obtained just after the liberation. This payment will bring to $170,000,000 the loan disbursements made by France since the beginning of July.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Following is the text of the introduction of the report of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to the ninth session of the General Assembly:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Representative B. Carroll Reece said today that the special House committee he headed was curious about the tax-exempt status of small foundations as well as of large ones.

A picture of Africa as still a dark continent religiously but not without hope, was painted here yesterday by the Rev. C. B. Brink of the Dutch Reform Church of Johannesburg, Union of South Africa.
Two French girls who took a trip across this country to find the "real America" have returned with heart-warming memories of friendliness, kindness and hospitality.

As is usual in midsummer, business books are running heavily to second, third and sixth editions of successful college texts. WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A Federal agency concerned with airport safety rules reports it is trying to put into effect recommendations of a study group that was set up after three plane crashes in Elizabeth, N. J., during the winter of 1951-52 had taken 119 lives.

Commissioner Cavanagh of the Fire Department has raised an issue that concerns not only his department but also the police -- and the general public as well. He says he wants to "take the Fire Department out of the business of inspecting fuel-oil-burning equipment" to make more firemen available for fighting fires.
UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold appealed today to the major powers not to sell the United Nations short.

" This house is so serene," commented a recent visitor to the Japanese house on view in the garden at the Museum of Modern Art. "You could really concentrate on one particular thing at a time, living here without being distracted by seeing a lot of other things around."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Lewis Hoad of Australia retained the Eastern grass court tennis championship today and, of the moment, stands as the man to beat in the national tournament at Forest Hills.

Contract awards for the second section of Baruch Houses, Manhattan's largest low-rent public housing project, have been approved, Herman D. Hillman, field office director of the Public Housing Administration, announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Reports of new demands for wage increases continued to reach here today. WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -Representative Lester Holtzman, Democrat of Queens, said today the Army had backed up his contention that he had nothing to do with keeping former Maj. Irving Peress from serving overseas while an Army dentist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Members of the House of Representatives are amused at a group of New York Republican colleagues who join prominently in the chorus demanding that Governor Dewey seek another term at Albany.

Women alarmed over reports that Paris designers are seeking to flatten the female silhouette are worrying needlessly, according to Evelyn Dawson, New York designer. Arriving yesterday at International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Paris, she reported that both women and designers were for the "high-busted look."

The bandstand in Central Park Mall, which normally shelters such hefty organizations as the Goldman Band and the Naumburg Symphony, played host Saturday evening to a handful of musicians who looked awfully lonely on the big stage.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 8 -- Swiss authorities focused their attention last week on possible counter-measures to take in consequence of the 50 per cent tariff increase on Swiss watches imported into the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The United States, Britain and France have formally decided to reject the Soviet proposal of Aug. 4 for a Big Four meeting on European affairs.

Shipowner strategy of playing hard to get seemed to be paying off in some areas last week as rates advanced somewhat in certain instances and remained steady in most.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- When Native Dancer was beaten in the Kentucky Derby last year, after having won eleven races in succession, many persons took pen in hand to say how sorry they were that the gray colt's streak had ended. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, owner of the Dancer, estimated that 500 messages were received.

Fred H. Hill, operator, who recently assembled a plot measuring 125 by 102.2 feet on East Seventy-fourth Street, between First and Second Avenues, has resold the property to builders planning a new apartment house.

Softness in the British pound sterling and continued strength in the Canadian dollar highlighted the movements in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted, though fairly active at times, was only moderate in volume.

Seventy-five per cent of a housewife's walking, bending and lifting are avoidable, according to recent time-motion studies made by the Home Economics Department of Wayne University.

Frank Havens of Vienna, Va., rowing for the Washington Canoe Club, won the National senior 1,000-meter single blade canoe race on the Harlem River yesterday. He beat six other oarsmen to the finish in 4 minutes 18.2 seconds.
Warning against the danger of "too great familiarity with God," the Rev. Francis X. Duffy yesterday counseled "fear of the Lord," and reflection on "hell and the punishment of God."

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Tanglewood had its biggest week-end of the season thus far, thanks to good weather. There were 10,600 persons in the Music Shed and on the lawns last night for a Berlioz program, and this afternoon 12,700 turned out to hear Gluck, Beethoven and Brahms.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 -- The inventory situation in steel-using plants appears to hold the key to fall steel business. Correction of excess inventories during the first half of this year cut steelmaking operations below the level of steel consuming operations. The reverse could happen this fall.

Reynolds Jr., president, noted in the mid-year report, issued yesterday, that the business outlook for the second half of the year was considerably better than it was in the first half.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Buffalo Street was driven to victory by Bill Haughton in the $3,500 Port Jefferson Mile Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The winner covered the muddy oval in 2:07 2/5 and finished two lengths in front of Bobby King.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Touhy's attorney, Robert B. WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The bill to admit wiretapped evidence in Federal courts in cases involving national security or kidnapping appeared to be dead tonight.

BRIDLINGTON, England, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Unidentified jet planes swooped in from the North Sea today and sent a burst of cannon fire into this Yorkshire town. Two houses were damaged, but no one was hurt.

" Rear Window," Alfred Hitchcock's suspense drama, which opened last Wednesday at the Rivoli Theatre, grossed in excess of $45,000 during the first four days of the engagement, the management reports. WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A committee of the House of Representatives today urged President Eisenhower to call a conference of all Free World nations looking to a complete diplomatic and trade break with Communist countries.

Problems of adjustment among teen-agers from broken homes and those from homes with both parents present do not differ as much as might be expected, findings of researchers at the State College of Washington indicate.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Frank J. Snyder, 32-year-old insurance company employe who was burned by blazing fuel when a disabled Air Force jet plane crashed and exploded in front of his Wantagh home last Tuesday, died here today at 3:40 P. M. in Meadowbrook Hospital.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 9 -- The strongest entry of the American tennis season to date will begin play tomorrow in the Newport invitation tournament at the Casino. An all-day rain forced cancellation of today's scheduled opening.

LIMA Peru, Aug. 9 (UP) -- President Manuel Odria reshuffled his Cabinet today and assigned the Premiership to former Navy Minister Vice Admiral Roque Saldias. The previous Cabinet was headed by Brig. Gen Zenon Noriega, War Minister.

Mayor Wagner complains that Governor Dewey and state Controller McGovern have injected politics into the city's police problem. He sees a "shocking display of irresponsibility" in the state's suggestion that the city has resources available to enlarge the force. Unfortunately, the record1 and the timetable refute the Mayor's argument as to who fired first:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Every admiral on the premises had a bet on the 2-year-old filly Two Stars in the $13,775 Schuylerville Stakes at Saratoga today. She won easily. Not much was wagered on her. She was the eighth choice in a ten betting-unit line-up, and she paid $61.70 for each $2.
PARIS, Aug. 9 (UP) -- A Skidmore College senior told tonight how she and her friends had enjoyed a tour of a French chateau with the President and First Lady of France as their guides.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Adoption of a universal manual of Braille music has been proposed here at a conference dealing with problems of the blind. However, publication of the manual is not expected for two years.

VICTORIA, B. C., Aug. 9 (AP) -- The strong, choppy currents of the frigid Juan de Fuca Strait defeated Florence Chadwick today after the famed channel swimmer had gone just four and one-half of the intended eighteen and three-tenth miles separating Canada and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Eighty-third Congress neared final approval today of the last foreign policy bill in the Eisenhower Administration's legislative program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The defending champions, William Rosen and Milton Ellenby, both of Chicago, Cliff Bishop of Detroit, and Lew Mathe and John Moran, both of Los Angeles, this afternoon took the lead in the eight-team contest for the 1954 contract bridge master team of four championship.

UPTON, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Scientists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission here have succeeded in prolonging the storage time of potatoes by exposing them to nuclear radiation.
Arnold Bernstein, shipping executive, was unable to testify because of illness yesterday in the Federal Court trial of his $11,000,000 suit against the Holland America Line.
Ninety-three local housing authorities, receiving assistance from the Public Housing Administration, plan to sell $158,964,000 of temporary notes on Aug. 17.
The Red Cross expressed gratitude yesterday for having received 372 pints of blood on Friday and 214 on Saturday for a total of 586 pints from donors in the metropolitan area.

Yesterday's downpour turned New Yorkers' attention from listening to air-raid sirens to seeking shelter from the rain. However, police precincts in the five boroughs received forty-nine phone calls from citizens who wanted to know why the sirens were blowing.
One hundred and eighty foreign aviation cadets, winding up a three-week stay in the United States with a visit to this city, were greeted yesterday in City Hall.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- India accused Portugal today of making warlike preparations in her three Indian settlements of Goa, Damao and Diu to resist the nationalist movement to merge the west coast territories with the Indian Union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A retired admiral told a conference on Africa today that permanent loss of the Suez base would be a "political-strategic debacle of stunning proportions."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- New Jersey's troubled Republican politics were spread on the White House luncheon table today.

The "look of knowledge" will serve as a promotional tie-in for the knowledge-full appearance of young scholars and the clothing they wear. The joint effort is planned by the Grolier Society, Inc., for its Book of Knowledge, and William Schwartz Co., manufacturer of the Chips 'n' Twigs line of boys' clothing.

Two new fast and shining escalators were put into operation yesterday at the Grand Central station of the I. R. T. Flushing line in time to speed subway riders on their homeward journey to Flushing, Queens, and intermediate points. The swift-moving approaches connect the mezzanine of the station with the mezzanine above the north-south Lexington Avenue line.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill giving postal workers a 7 per cent pay rise:

The New York City Opera Company will open its fall season at the New York City Center of Music and Drama on Wednesday evening, Sept. 29. This has been announced by Joseph Rosenstock, general director of the company.

ROME, July 24 -- The Italian fashion market excels in sportswear. The word boutique is heard in Rome and Florence as frequently as in Paris and most of the important Italian designers have a special little shop in which they sell separates -slacks, shirts, sweaters, scarfs, jewelry and enchanting footwear.

Permit me to raise one small voice on behalf of the much-lampooned men and women working for the city known as corporation inspectors. True enough, their work is easy and may not be necessary in the long run.

The stock market declined again yesterday for the fourth consecutive session. It was not a day of big losses, however. While there were weak spots all over the list, few were especially notable. Aircrafts, moreover, continued their independent upward trend.
Former Representative Vito Marcantonio, the tireless, controversial and resilient leftist political boss of East Harlem, died of heart disease on lower Broadway at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

The unexpected death yesterday of Vito Marcantonio removed the reasons for the major party coalition in the Eighteenth Congressional District, which was formed in 1950 to prevent Mr. Marcantonio's return to the House of Representatives.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss a perjury indictment against Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States.

Batting power, with the emphasis on the home run, has been associated with the Yankees in the baseball public's mind for more than a generation. Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Bob Meusel, Tony Lazzeri and Joe DiMaggio, of glorious memory, and such present heroes as Yogi Berra and Mickey Mantle hit the ball a mile.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 -- Foreman Clark, a chain of twelve clothing stores, most of them on the Pacific Coast, may be sold to Howard Stores Corporation of Brooklyn, operator of some seventy stores east of the Mississippi.
The American Federation of Labor refused to accept yesterday the Government's view that the national economy had been stabilized.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 9 -- Chinese Nationalist warships sank eight Chinese Communist gunboats in a brief but furious battle in Formosa Strait early today, the Defense Ministry of President Chiang Kai-shek announced.
The Radio Corporation of America cut the price of its color television receiver by half yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Children should not be allowed to leave their homeland for any other country unless it is in their best interests, it was contended today.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Temporary State Commission on Educational Finances was completed today with the appointment by Governor Dewey of fourteen members.

HARRISON, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Nine hundred production workers at the Crucible Steel Company of America plant here went on strike today over a management proposal to rotate work shifts and working days for sixteen employes in the tempering department.
A major reorganization of the Soviet school curriculum aimed at emphasizing scientific education at the expense of the humanities will go into effect this year, a Pravda editorial reveals.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Roger (The Terrible) Touhy, who rivaled the late "Scarface" Al Capone as one of Chicago's most notorious gansters, was freed after twenty years in prison today. A judge decided he had been wrongly convicted of kidnapping and threw out sentences totaling 298 years.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The use of nuclear weapons was condemned as contrary to international law on four counts by a speaker at the opening of the International Law Association's conference in Edinburgh today.

Progress continues to be made toward Tunisian autonomy. A Cabinet has now been formed to undertake, with France, the delineation of the new relationships. Only one person in that Cabinet is a Frenchman. He will serve as the Foreign Minister, since under the proposed terms of autonomy foreign relations will continue to be handled for the Tunisians by France.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 -- The executive committee of the United States Chess Federation decided today not to enter a team in the biennial international tournament, which was switched on short notice from Buenos Aires to Amsterdam.
MASSENA, N. Y., Aug. 9 (AP) -- At the touch of a button tomorrow, dirt will begin to fly in the project to put the St. Lawrence River's might at the call nine states and Canada.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Aug. 9 -- A group of old guard Republicans calling themselves the Committee for a Stronger New Jersey Republican Party has sent a telegram to President Eisenhower and Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey asking them to persuade Clifford Case of Rahway to withdraw from the Senatorial race.

TAIPEI, Aug. 9 -- A disastrous atomic war between the Western world and the Communist bloc could be avoided, Chen Cheng, Vice President of Nationalist China, said in an address before the Chinese Editors Association today.
SPRINGDALE, Conn., Aug. 9 -- Heavy rain today washed out the qualifying round in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's twenty-ninth championship tournament.
TERCEIRA ISLAND, Azores, Aug. 9 -- A Colombian airliner hit a mountain peak and burst into flames on this island in the Atlantic early today, killing all thirty persons aboard.
Libby Holman, whose throaty, sad songs attracted large and receptive audiences back in the Thirties, will return to Broadway this fall as star of her own show, "Blues, Ballads and Sin-Songs."
Virtually the last vestige on Fifth Avenue of the Mauve Decade will yield soon to pressures of the business world.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Baseball's greatest honor, a niche in the Hall of Fame, was accorded today to nine former diamond "greats."
The heaviest rain in nine months fell over the New York area yesterday, bringing new hope to farmers caught in the grip of the worst drought on record.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 -- Political tension rose to a new high today because of the failure of authorities to capture the gunman who killed an Air Force major Thursday during an attempt to assassinate an anti-administration editor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- The Middle West is leading the country in all phases of construction, including commercial, residential, industrial and public, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reported today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Max, a ten-month-old miniature fox terrier, was returned to his home at 8 River Road here today after having been lost from the deck of a cabin cruiser in the middle of Long Island Sound.

Fall plans for "The Halls of Ivy" have been completed. The filmed situation comedy program, co-starring Ronald Colman and his wife, Benita Hume, will be televised over the C. B. S. network on Tuesdays from 8:30 to 9 P. M., beginning Oct. 19.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Balkan treaty signed today in Bled by the foreign ministers of Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, as distributed by Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news agency:
CHICAGO, July 9 -- The wheat market reversed its uptrend of Friday today. With buying restricted and no news to stimulate support, sharp declines were registered.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A former seat cushion salesman at the ball park hopes to open negotiations tomorrow that will bring his 16-plus group control of the Philadelphia Athletics.

IT is nineteen years since the death of T. E. Lawrence in a motorcycle accident. His fame, which once echoed around the world, has shrunk with each passing year so that a whole generation has grown up ignorant of his deeds and unaware of the fascination of his enigmatic and paradoxical personality. Although he wrote much about himself, and others wrote more, the puzzle of Lawrence's personality remains unsolved.

ALONG with the announcement in Washington yesterday of basic regulations for the hunting of wild ducks and geese in the 1954-55 season, comes a report from Ducks Unlimited in Winnipeg on current production in the prairie regions of western Canada.

The city should be grateful to The Times for publishing so extensively the facts relating to the proposed "Jack Frost" sugar sign in Queens. Existence of other large advertising signs on buildings along the East River, survivals of earlier and less careful days, was not an adequate excuse for the addition of another huge electric sign.
A Wall Street brokerage house figured out a plan yesterday that may enable some of its clients to pick up eighteen shares of Big Board stock for 89 cents.

The Soviet Union is an enormous and complex land. Some new glimpses of its variety are afforded us by the two pages of pictures of different Soviet scenes printed in this newspaper yesterday. Some of the scenes along the Volga River caught by our correspondent, Harrison Salisbury, would have looked familiar to Mark Twain or others acquainted with the Mississippi.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 9 -- Portugal has suggested that she and India permit observers from six neutral nations to inspect the Portuguese enclaves and Indian territory surrounding them.

The city's foremost traffic scofflaw turned up in court yesterday -- a weeping mother who had collected and scorned seventy-three tickets in the last six months. In Traffic Court, 26 - year - old Mrs. Margarita Jaume of 22 West Ninety-first Street admitted softly to her record. Her haul included sixty-five tickets for parking in restricted areas, four for parking at bus stops, three for double parking and one for driving with defective lights.
Plans for a new information service to keep business posted on proposed sales of surplus property were announced yesterday by Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks.

Yugoslavia has completed the first year of her ten-year program to build at home fifty-four ships of 300,000 tons. The program is expected to rejuvenate and modernize the nation's small and aging merchant fleet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Two letters written Dr. Otto John, West German security chief, after his disappearance July 20 have strengthened the belief of officials here that he was "lured" by Communist agents behind the Iron Curtain.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, after an active session yesterday, closed at about the lows of the day, 23 to 40 points lower than last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The House of Representatives overrode its Republican leadership today and voted, 351 -- 29, for a temporary 7 per cent postal pay rise. The increase would give 500,000 postal officials and employes an estimated $200,000,000 more annually.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Brig. Gen. Herbert D. Vogel, President Eisenhower's nominee for the Tennessee Valley Authority board of directors, pledged today "to do my best for the valley and the nation." He said he would not describe the development project as an example of "creeping socialism" -- a phrase used by General Eisenhower -- and added that there were areas in which Government economic activity was desirable.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Turnover was heavy again on the stock market here today, with Anglo-Iranian Oil shares in the greatest demand.

Anti-religious propaganda and campaigns, however, have been a normal feature of the Soviet scene virtually since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, though the emphasis on this propaganda and its violence have varied from time to time.

A generally lower trend prevailed on the local commodity exchanges yesterday in quiet trading. Losses were registered by rubber, zinc, potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil futures. Coffee, sugar, cocoa and wool closed mixed. Hides, silk and burlap were higher.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The special Senate committee that will consider the resolution to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy unanimously decided today to hold public hearings, beginning Aug. 30.

The activation of the Temporary State Commission on Educational Finances under as distinguished a head as Dr. Henry Townley Heald does a great deal to lessen the apprehension of many thinking people lest an antiquated school-aid formula be ultimately responsible for economically segregated communities in the suburbs of our larger cities.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- A propaganda attack on religious beliefs is in progress from one end of the Soviet Union to the other. The extent of the Communist party's propaganda drive is revealed by a survey of the provincial as well as the central Moscow press.

The Board of Estimate will do well to give serious thought to a proposal by City Administrator Gulick in a report recommending that the Sanitation Department make its collection and disposal services available at cost to commercial establishments that request them.

MADRID, Aug. 9 -- A growing understanding of the United States woman's reference for simplicity in daytime dresses and suits marked the fall and winter collections of Pedro Rodriquez and Pertegaz shown here today to international buyers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today announced that the Government will get back $98,000 in a settlement of claims against the Federal Bank of America stemming from a West Coast housing insurance scandal in 1952.

In no area, perhaps, have the policies pursued and the appointments made by President Eisenhower over the past year and a half been of a higher order than in the area of fiscal and monetary affairs. Now he has made two more sound nominations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Columbia Pictures, now busy filming "My Sister Eileen" as a musical, has decided to add melody to James Hilton's "Lost Horizon," which the studio released in 1937, and will remake it as a musical.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 9 -- Officers of Studebaker Local No. 5, United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today adopted a wait-and-see policy on the Studebaker Corporation's contract termination move, which could cost 11,000 employes their jobs.
The light of learning shines brightly, especially to someone living in a world of darkness.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 9 -- John Nicholas Brown's Bolero, William Ziegler Jr.'s Bounding Home, E. S. Kelley's Departure and S. T. Bourne's Rusta IV were the winners today in the Nantucket-to-Edgartown run of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

Walter Cartier of Greenwich Village and Ted Olla of Milwaukee, the Wisconsin State middleweight champion, fought to a draw in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Each boxer weighed 162 pounds.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 9 -- A sloppy track, close quarters and a determined effort by the Clearwater Stable's Royal Coinage helped bring about the first defeat for the Wilton Stable's highly-touted Royal Note today.

The recent statement by Police Commissioner Adams that the police force as presently constituted is unable to cope with the present crime rate is as forthright and commendable as any statement ever issued by a political appointee.
Domestic steel production decreased slightly last week and the decline was expected to continue this week.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), one of the largest factors in the domestic oil business, yesterday reported a consolidated net profit of $53,042,928 for the first half of this year. In the corresponding six months of 1953 the net was $54,742,446.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 9 -- Tunisia turned the Moslem feast of Aid el Kebir today into a patriotic celebration because France has promised to give this protectorate internal sovereignty.
ABADAN, Iran, Aug. 9 -- Preparations are going forward to rouse the huge Abadan refinery from its long slumber and restore it as the largest producer in the Eastern Hemisphere.
PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The first Cabinet discussion of the European Defense Community treaty under the present Government will take place tomorrow night.
Wendell B. Barnes, Small Business Administrator, painted an optimistic picture for the jewelry trade yesterday.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 9 -- South Africa is less unpopular abroad than she used to be, a report of the State Information Office, issued here today, states.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9 -- A twenty-year pact pledging immediate military aid to each other was signed today by Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Herbert A. Bradley, president of the 120,000-member International Chemical Workers Union, A. F. L., was accused today at the union's annual convention of being a "tyrant."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's cotton crop at 12,680,000 bales, a reduction of 23 per cent from last year under a rigid crop control program designed to prevent surplus production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Treasury reported today that $7,300,000,000 of maturing certificates of indebtedness had been exchanged thus far for new offerings carrying lower interest rates.

During the summer, when fresh artichokes are unobtainable, fanciers of this thistle-like vegetable must rely on the canned hearts and bottoms. The hearts consist of the bottoms of very small artichokes, plus some of the tender inner leaves.

In the wake of all the to-do about whether or not cigarette smoking is related to a number of ills human flesh is heir to the people who make pipes are rubbing their hands and looking hopefully toward a spurt in trade.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Internal Revenue Service appealed today to taxpayers to be patient in awaiting its official interpretations of provisions contained in the revised Federal tax law.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Ned Garver cooled off the front-running Cleveland Indians on five hits tonight as he pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-to-0 victory before 53,778 fans, the largest crowd in two years at Briggs Stadium.

BOISE, Idaho, Wednesday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senator Henry C. Dworshak took a commanding early lead for the Republican nomination in the Idaho primary early today, as the Democratic contests developed into a close race between former Senator Glen Taylor and State Representative Claude Burtenshaw.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The House adopted today a resolution expressing opposition to payment of $179,420 in damages to eleven dismissed American employes of the United Nations.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Lord Chamberlain, Britain's stage censor, has ordered a song lampooning Anthony Eden cut from a revue at the King's Theatre.

The news that in one part of the wild blue yonder -- an Air Force base in Enid, Okla. -- KP is being abolished comes as a shock to old-time kitchen police who, looking back on it from the sentimental hills of civilian life, recall that some of their lightest military moments were spent over a stove, kitchen, hot, M-1.

Archie Moore, 37-year-old world light heavyweight champion, will undertake the third defense of his title tonight when he trades punches with Harold Johnson, 26-year-old Philadelphian, in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 10 -- Mme. Frances A. Crane, former wife of the late Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak patriot, and her housekeeper companion, Mrs. Juliet Wells, were in a head-on motor car collision at about 1:30 A. M. today.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Commercial Credit Company reported today it set new records by earning $11,948,881 in the six-month period and $24,315,057 in the year ended on June 30.

The closing days of a legislative session provide hardly the proper atmosphere for considered debate on anything, least of all on such controversial matters as those affecting constitutional rights and civil liberties. That is why an extra word of caution is appropriate now against hasty enactment of laws in this delicate field.

THE decision by the Radio Corporation of America to cut the price of its fifteen-inch color TV receiver from $1,000 to $495 comes at a time when networks and stations are planning their first major effort in color programming on a quantity basis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Administration rode rough shod over the powerful bipartisan farm bloc tonight as the Senate gave President Eisenhower virtually everything he wanted in a farm program.

An offering of 1,000,000 common shares of United Funds Canada, Ltd., a new investment company, will be placed on the market today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Francis I. duPont Co. The stock is priced at $12.50 a share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Potential investors may get earlier information on new securities under a bill signed into law by President Eisenhower today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- A horseman said last week of the C. V. Whitney Stable, "bet on 'em all; that barn is full of runners." The horseman knew what he was talking about. As of this writing, the stable has won eleven of the nineteen Saratoga races in which it had starters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Fredric March will return to Paramount, where he recently worked in "The Bridges at Toko-Ri," for a co-starring role in William Wyler's production of "The Desperate Hours."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower signed two bills today to modernize the tanker fleet flying the United States flag.

The New York Mercantile Exchange, world's biggest butter trading center, is happy that the Senate stuck by flexible supports for dairy products. Otherwise, says Lewellyn Watts Jr., the exchange president, the nation's warehouses would have been swamped with surplus butter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Following are the key roll-call votes in the Senate today on the farm bill, including the 62-to-28 victory for final passage:
Headquarters Building 125 on Governors Island was renamed Pershing Hall yesterday in honor of the late General of the Armies John J. Pershing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- American twosomes won three of the four matches in today's opening round of the international golf competition at Tam o' Shanter. The event is serving as a tune-up for the $165,000 "world" tournament starting Thursday.
The two national associations in the retail jewelry business are looking ahead to a merger.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Japanese Government and business circles read with guarded optimism today reports from Washington that the Eisenhower Administration was gravely concerned with Japan's economic plight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower's departure for a vacation in Denver, where he expects to work and play for a few weeks, has been pushed back because of the delayed adjournment of Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The general secretary of the American Council of Christian Churches said today "It is my personal conviction" that "at least 7,000 ministers in the United States are aiding the Communist cause either directly or indirectly."

BONN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has summoned his coalition leaders to a conference in his summer retreat near Baden-Baden. He acted as reports from strikebound Bavaria and Hamburg indicated that tension was rising.

While other companies bemoan the absence of contemporary works worth producing, Punch Opera seems to find them with ease. As its second production of the season at the Cherry Lane Theatre last night, it presented Albert Roussel's comic opera "Aunt Caroline's Will," which has not been done in this country before.

Fears over the accelerated growth of communism in Italy expressed in London by Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, co-chairman of the Conference of Christians and Jews and pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, and reported in your issue of Aug. 6, are unjustified.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Chicago's Frank Baumholtz hit the first pitch off Corky Valentine for a home run, but the Cincinnati Redleg pitcher throttled the Cubs the rest of the route tonight and won, 2--1. Valentine, a 24-year-old Rookie right-hander, permitted the Cubs only four other hits.
A large aircraft producer is making its mechanical roust-abouts as efficien as their human counterparts in the circus and far less noisy.
Directors of the National City Bank of New York yesterday proposed to increase the bank's capitalization by a third and raised the annual dividend rate from $2.20 to $2.40 a share.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 -- The East German Communist Government today disclosed that it was ready to make the long-awaited move to exploit the case of the former West German intelligence chief, Dr. Otto John, who defected July 20, for its long-range purpose of undermining the West German Federal Republic.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- J. W. Rodgers' Duc de Fer drove to a head victory in the $15,000 added Pageant Handicap before a crowd of 19,255 today as the Atlantic City race course opened its fall meeting.

An easy-to-use adhesive plastic fabric is the latest addition in the growing do-it-yourself field. The new product, Con-Tact, developed by Comark Plastic Division of Cohn-Hall-Marx Company in conjunction with Monsanto Chemical Company, is available in two tones of wood grain, three shades of marble, stripes, solids and kitchen and nursery prints.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower does not approve of any pending legislation restoring to Germany or its nationals assets in the United States that were seized at the outbreak of World War II.
WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 10 -- Following is the text of former President Hoover's speech at the celebration of his eightieth birthday here today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Passport Office of the State Department today threatened to upset a plan to take a deposition from the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, in the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles made the following main points at his news conference today:

Under continued selling pressure from trade sources and commission houses, cocoa futures declined 86 to 100 points in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Sales totaled 322 contracts. Closing at 62.85 cents a pound, the. nearby September option was down 100 points, or 1 cent a pound.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- In two elections, a total of 105 outstanding players and coaches have been named to the college football Hall of Fame, but it will be harder from now on to make the grade.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 -- The cruzeiro has taken several falls in the last four days. The quotation today is 66 cruzeiros 50 centavos to the dollar, or a jump of 1 1/2 cruzeiros since last Friday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 10 -- France's Deputy Commissioner General in Indochina said today that nearly 200,000 actual and prospective refugees were waiting in the Hanoi and Haiphong areas for transport to evacuate them south of Vietnam's partition line near the Seventeenth Parallel.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Pitcher Jim Wilson didn't need all the help, but the pennant-hungry Milwaukee Braves shot extra-base blows, including four home runs, around Busch Stadium with ease tonight, to back up their hurler's three-hit pitching for an 11-to-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Sherritt Gordon Mines, Ltd., announced yesterday that its new Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, refinery now was producing pure nickel powder and by-product ammonium sulfate "in commercial quantities," using an entirely new chemical process.
Designating petitions filed yesterday with the Board of Elections for the Sept. 14 primary election indicated thirty-six contests for 125 major party nominations.

Capt. John H. Morrill, a hero of the retreat from the Philippines in World War II, will become Chief of Staff at Atlantic Reserve Fleet Headquarters, 90 Church Street, on Aug. 20, it was announced yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 10 (UP) -- Tipped off by a woman who recognized a "wanted" picture, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today seized George Patrick McKinney for the year-old $190,319 robbery of a bank in Floral Park, L. I., the biggest haul ever made by a single robber.
