Excited over their trip and their mission, ninety-six British teachers arrived here yesterday on the liner Queen Mary. For most of them it was the first Atlantic crossing.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 10 -- Authoritative sources said today that if the Netherlands participated in the proposed Southeast Asian treaty organization, Indonesia would not remain "passive" on this question. But the sources failed to amplify the remark evoked by reports that the Dutch might enter the alliance in view of their control over Western New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration lowered down payments and extended loan repayment periods on Government-insured houses today to carry out President Eisenhower's "better homes" program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today the Senate should pay for his lawyer in the forthcoming censure proceedings against him -- otherwise he will represent himself. The chairman of the select committee that will study the pending censure resolution, Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, announced the committee was studying the question raised by the Wisconsin Republican.
Jazz is about to take its place for the first time among the musical presentations of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Demand for South African gold mining shares and oil shares was a feature of the generally firm stock market here today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- A television broadcast from Leningrad was received for ninety minutes in the West German city of Osnabrueck, according to reports reaching here. The air distance between these cities roughly equals that between New York and Denver, or about 1,600 miles.

WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 10 -- Former President Hoover said today that a "grievous list" of Presidential agreements during twenty years of Democratic rule had reduced human freedom throughout the world.

JUNIOR hunters -- those from 14 to 21 -- who expect to go into the woods of New York State this fall must obtain safety certificates before the opening day of the season. That means they have only two months in which to take the four-hour course designed to teach the fundamentals of safe firearms handling.

REGINA, Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Rapid development of the rust menace through much of Saskatchewan's crop area was reported today by the Saskatchewan Wheat Pool and the Provincial Department of Agriculture.

Is there no end to this Administration's no-trade, no-aid program? Is there no country whose friendship and respect is worth keeping? We have now gone from the unkind to the ridiculous in raising the tariff on Swiss watch movements.

The anticipated meeting yesterday between representatives of Walt Disney and the Motion Picture Division of the New York State Censor Board, to discuss that group's proposed deletion from "The Vanishing Prairie," did not take place.
APPOMATTOX, Va., Aug. 10 -- A national union became a factory owner and manufacturer's landlord here today for what union officials believe is the first time.

Lower taxes enabled the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries, world's largest papermaking organization, to lift its half-year net profit to $30,422,315 from $28,586,166 earned in the first six months a year ago. Sales, however, declined.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The defending champions today continued to lead a finalist field of eight contract bridge teams in the round-robin contest for 1954 master team-of-four-championship.
The New York City water supply did not benefit, except in its Croton system, from the 2.08 inches of rain that fell here Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that he had no question about the loyalty of Edward Lamb, radio executive and newspaper publisher.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- As the Soviet Union sees it, Western mountaineers in the Himalayas are peeking into the mysteries of Communist Tibet, Pravda, Communist party newspaper, said today.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Sir Gordon Richards, Britain's champion jockey, has retired. At the age of 50 he intends to start a career as a trainer.

A survey of world conditions by Adlai E. Stevenson will be issued Aug. 25 by Harper. It will be titled "Call to Greatness." The author discusses the difficulties confronting the free world and the part America must play in the fight against totalitarianism. The book is based on the Godkin Lectures that Mr. Stevenson gave at Harvard University in March under the title "A Troubled World."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A committee of the Governors' Conference said today it was in perfect accord with President Eisenhower on his approval for a vast new road-building program.
Thousands of his one-time constituents filed before the bier of former Representative Vito Marcantonio yesterday to pay their last respects.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday on a rally from the day's lows, 1 point higher to 5 lower than on Monday on a much smaller turnover.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Three former champions scored with ease in opening matches of the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's twenty- ninth title tournament at the Woodway Country Club today.
Dr. Willem Drees, Prime Minister of the Netherlands, yesterday sent the American Jewish community the best wishes of his country on the occasion of the American Jewish Tercentenary.
Stock prices rebounded yesterday after four days of losses, Pushing ahead from a wobbly start, they more than recovered the ground lost on Monday.
SOME of the town's oldest gentlewomen were dismayed yesterday by the news that the old Fifth Avenue Bank at the northwest corner of Forty-fourth Street is to be torn down.
NYACK, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Local merchants favor a tunnel route through South Mountain as a possible connecting link between the New Jersey Turnpike and the Thruway's Hudson River crossing.

As a new member of the board of managers of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, 38 Bleecker Street, New York City, I spent two days recently inspecting the society's summer camps at Elko Lake, Parksville, N. Y.

Ragweed usually starts pollinating about Aug. 10, bringing in the worst season of the year for hay fever sufferers. By Aug. 10, 1954, which was yesterday, the city had wiped out more than 2,000 acres of the offensive growth in this year's spraying campaign.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 10 -- A rugged night of wind and rain, dragging anchors and some damage was followed today by a postponement of the Astor Cup race, one of the main events of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

SPEAKING of managers -- which most everyone seems to be doing in these days of endless managerial eccentricities -- a curious observation comes to mind. How come the Dodgers, through accident or design have had three exceptionally fine managers the past eight campaigns, while certain other clubs have had difficulty finding one?

Bob Grim, their prize rookie right-hander, pitched the Yankees to a 5-2 triumph over the Athltics last night as the Bombers, backed to the wall in defense of their world championship, opened a seven-game home stand against second-division opposition.

Two groups yesterday asked the Senate special committee investigating charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to reconsider its ban on television, radio and newsreel coverage of the hearings.

The merger of four companies in the dyestuffs and chemicals field was announced yesterday. The concerns are the Alliance Color and Chemical Company of Newark, N. J., and its affiliate, the Alliance Chemical Corporation, and the Blackman-Uhler Company of Spartanburg, S. C., and its affiliated Blackman-Uhler Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Japan wants a "Marshall Plan" program of direct aid or a large loan from the United States to put her economic house in order. This was disclosed today by Ambassador Sadao Iguchi in an interview.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 -- Robert Frost departed momentarily from his own field of poetry today to give a thumbnail sketch of his views on world affairs that delighted a Brazilian press conference.

Two alert Port Patrol officers, who last February prevented the smuggling of twenty-one ounces of heroin into the country, received yesterday salary increases and letters of commendation from the Treasury Department.

A new department established by the Moore-McCormack Lines to coordinate the planning of two proposed passenger liners will be headed by Fred A. Heess Jr., naval archiect and engineer, it was announced yesterday by William T. Moore, company president.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- The Senate vote favorable to the flexible price support plan was responsible for a sell-off in grain and soybean futures in the initial trade here today. But there was a quick rebound and the market held firm until past midday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover Jr., son of the former President, is reported to have turned down an opportunity to become Under Secretary of State.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Lou Kretlow and his relief, Bob Chakales, gave the Chicago White Sox only five hits tonight as the Baltimore Orioles scored a 3-to-1 victory before 25,654 fans.

In the absence of Mayor Wagner from the city Abe Stark, President of the City Council, yesterday gave the public his views on how to deal with crime and juvenile delinquency. His statement suggests apprehension lest Police Commissioner Adams' recent address on conditions may have created "public panic which could do irreparable harm to the greatest city in the world and the capital of the United Nations."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 --Following is the text of President Eisenhower's birthday greetings to former President Hoover today:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A business men's syndicate today made a "very generous offer" to keep the American League's Athletics in Philadelphia where they have been for fifty-four years.
The American Federation of Labor looked yesterday at the record of the Eighty-third Congress and found it wanting.

Taking a hand in the controversy over the disposition of German and Japanese properties seized during the war President Eisenhower has turned thumbs down on all bills for a return of these properties now before Congress. At the same time he asks Congress to find a "fair, equitable and satisfactory" solution for what he calls the "complex of problems" involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, a leader of American troops from Europe to Asia, told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that the United States should break diplomatic relations with Soviet Russia and its satellites.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France obtained tonight postponement to Aug. 27 of a full-dress debate on the situations in Morocco and Tunisia by a vote he had told the Assembly would be taken as approval of his policy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 10 -- Belgium, which has banned importation of coal from the United States, imposed the embargo unilaterally and not by arrangement with the Netherlands, a fellow member of the European Coal and Steel Community.
Evansville, Ind., awarded $4,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., yesterday.

Persons who send in false alarms of fire would be subjected to penalties of a $1,000 fine, a year's imprisonment, or both, under a bill introduced in the City Council yesterday by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat.

Previous letters to the editor, because of their extreme partisanship, have given the impression that a solution to the British-Cyprus problem is impossible. Since this is a matter of present controversy and threatens to become a source of friction within the Western family, as evidenced by a dispatch of The Times, London, some attempt to anticipate the problem should be made before Greece brings it to the United Nations in late September.

Domestic steel production dropped last month to the lowest level since the widespread steel-workers' strike in the summer of 1952. The decline reflected reduced demand as manufacturers worked down their steel inventories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -The House of Representatives today approved a Senate-House compromise authorizing $25,000,000 for the repair, modernization and conversion of merchant-type of vessels in the reserve fleet.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 10 -- The first business session of the Nordic Council of parliamentarians, which is discussing cooperation, was marked today by two speeches that were more anti-British than pro-Nordic. Norway, Denmark, Sweden and Iceland are participating in the talks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Reducing advertising is one of the best ways to "commit business suicide," Orville W. Johler, vice president in charge of advertising for the 6,000 stores in the Independent Grocers Alliance, said today.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Betty Rosenquest Pratt of Jamaica and Ann Shilcock of England, second-seeded domestic and foreign entries respectively, today advanced to the second round in the rain-delayed Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON -- Following are the texts of letters between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany and President Eisenhower on the question of German property seized by the United States in World War II:
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 10 -- Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi asked the Iranian Parliament today "not to waste a minute" in ratifying the recently initiated oil agreement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- By a vote of 11 to 1, the Senate Public Works Committee today approved the nomination of Brig. Gen. Herbert D. Vogel to be a member of the Tennessee Valley Authority's Board of Directors.

UNION CITY, N. J., Wednesday, Aug. 11 -- Three-year-old Sharon Yacko, missing since last Saturday morning from a North Bergen orphanage, was found late last night, unharmed except for a case of measles.

Mrs. Aminda Wilkins, who has been in charge of the Welfare Department's program for tubercular relief clients for the last three years, was sworn in yesterday by Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy as secretary of the department.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 10 -- Indonesia and the Netherlands, after more than four years of uneasy partnership, signed agreements tonight to dissolve their union.
a weekly newspaper publisher, ran 7,291 votes ahead of the incumbent, Gov. Francis Cherry, on the basis of incomplete and unofficial returns early today in Arkansas' heated contest for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, predicted today that the United States would step up military aid to Japan and other Far Eastern countries to head off further Communist aggression.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 10 -- A grave warning that the "apartheid'' (racial segregation) policies of the South African Government might end in "bloodshed and violence" was voiced here today by the Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Senate approval of a new farm bill placing farm price supports on a flexible basis ranging from 82.5 to 90 per cent of parity was hailed today by farm leaders as a step away from Government control of agriculture.

TRENTON, Aug. 10 -- Republican and Democratic leaders in New Jersey expressed serious concern today over the extent to which the McCarthy issue has become a divisive factor within their respective parties.
Inge Sand, principal dancer of the Royal Danish Ballet, will make her American debut next week in four performances at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass.

MASSENA, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Governor Dewey just before noon today pressed a buzzer that marked the start of the long-dreamed-of international project to harness the power hidden in the chilly waters of the St. Lawrence River.

While rejoicing over the heartening strides taken by our city and state on the mental hygiene front -- more psychiatric services in the courts and a projected 4,000-bed state institute in the East Bronx -- we must take note of the tremendous lag in assistance for the pre-delinquent and the disturbed, but not yet diseased, member of our community.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Lord Russell resigned from his job as legal adviser to the British armed forces today after being threatened with dismissal for defying a Government order to suppress a 259-page book he wrote about German World War II atrocities.

An investment banking syndicate headed by the Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis will place on the market today, at $50 a share, 30,000 shares of new 4.72 per cent preferred stock of the Southern Colorado Power Company.

Two boys and a girl from the Midwest arrived here yesterday from a month's trip to Europe still filled with the wonder of real talks with a queen and a prince, wine at every meal and exotic souvenirs.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- The Giants played a fill-in date tonight for their last appearance of the year in Pittsburgh and turned it to good profit. They vanquished the Pirates 2 to 1, but they also let out a tremendous sigh of relief as they hustled off Forbes Field.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 10 (AP) -- John Landy admitted today that he ran against Dr. Roger Bannister Saturday with a deep cut in his foot.
In an effort to make police service here more attractive, Mayor Wagner proposed yesterday a grant of $125 for uniforms to each of the 19,000 members of the Police Department for this fiscal year.

DARTMOUTH, N. S., Aug. 10 (UP) -- Marlene Stewart of Fonthill, Ont., remained the favorite today to take her second Canadian open golf championship by winning her first-round match from Mrs. Davis Collision, 10 and 8.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Lord Beveridge told the annual conference of the International Law Association in Edinburgh today that attempts to work for peace and international law outside the United Nations should be made only as a last alternative.

SALTAIRE, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Mass gamma globulin inoculations will be administered at a community clinic set up in this small Fire Island resort village tomorrow in an effort to quell a mushrooming polio scare.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -President Eisenhower gave White House endorsement today to a project through which an American Museum of Immigration would be constructed at the base of the Statue of Liberty.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Margaret Poser, 52 years old, of New York, squeezed through the porthole of her cabin aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth and committed suicide, a Transport Ministry hearing was told here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would reopen the matter of the competitive relationships ok the North Atlantic ports in the handling of imported iron ore.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis made public yesterday its $32,600,000 unpaid bill for the 1954 anti-polio program. This deficit has prompted the Emergency March of Dimes campaign for $20,000,000 beginning Monday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- With the season's record crowd of 31,421 at Connie Mack Stadium jeering them, the Dodgers tonight were beaten by the Phils, 6 -- 3.

When the Senate voted, 49-44, on Monday night to substitute a system of flexible priee supports for the rigid 90 per cent supports obtaining on five of the nation's so-called "basic" farm commodities it recorded a victory for the Administration in one of the most difficult and most important struggles of its entire legislative program to date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- In a second appeal to the Federal Tariff Commission, domestic growers and producers of tung oil, asked that agency today to recommend the imposition of a quota up to 50 per cent on imports of tung oil, mainly from Argentina.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Considerable progress has been made toward formation of a Southeast Asia security treaty. The situation may be summarized as follows:...
GUATEMALA, Aug. 10 -- The ruling junta granted exit permits today to eighty-eight of the nearly 800 persons in refuge in foreign embassies here.

The Philco Corporation suffered a loss in the second quarter and a sharp drop in earnings for the first six months this year, reflecting the effects of the strike that stopped all television, radio and Government production in its Philadelphia and Sandusky, Ohio, plants for almost seven weeks.

The luscious blackberry is in season this month and next. Locally pints of the cultivated fruit sell for 29 to 39 cents. But suburbanites may gather the wild variety with the only cost possibly a few scratches from these prickly berry bushes that flourish in northeastern fields and woods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Searing July temperatures and drought in major farming areas sliced an estimated 15 per cent off this year's corn crop and reduced the aggregate volume of all crops 5 per cent below prospects of a month earlier, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

A group of sixteen first-class musicians brought chamber music of the highest quality to Greenwich Village last night, and an audience of 4,000 city-pent New Yorkers crowded the western half of Washington Square to hear them play.
Having uncovered a bonanza in "The Pajama Game," the three sponsors of that musical -- Frederick Brisson, Robert E. Griffith and Harold S. Prince -- already have another show up their sleeve.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- American retailers had total sales of $14,300,000,000 last month, the Department of Commerce reported today. The figure, after being adjusted for seasonal variations, number of trading days and other pertinent influences, was found to be about 1 per cent below the June level of trade and 2 per cent below that of July, 1953.
A public hearing in a deportation proceeding against Cedric Belfrage, editor of The National Guardian, a weekly, began yesterday at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Britain maintained silence today concerning India's statement accusing this country of acting on "one-sided information" in intervening in the dispute about Portuguese India.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov gave a country dinner party tonight for Clement R. Attlee, former British Laborite Prime Minister; Aneurin Bevan, leader of the left wing of the Labor party, and a group of other Laborites who stopped off in Moscow en route to Peiping.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France obtained the overwhelming approval of the National Assembly today for two of his major policies. One was what he called an "economic revolution" in France and the other his plans to grant internal autonomy to Tunisians and to conciliate Moroccans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- A system of radio-controlled traffic lights will be put into operation in Chicago by Jan. 1, Major Martin H. Kennelly announced today. He said the system would be the first of its kind in the world.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mel Parnell, making his sixth appearance since he was injured in a game with the Senators on April 24, pitched a brilliant four-hitter tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated Washington, 4 -- 0.

Alexander P. Maran, who pleaded guilty to charges of embezzling funds from Manhattan State Hospital, where he was a cashier, was committed to State Prison yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to serve two consecutive terms of five to ten years.

Today's new film is "Her Twelve Men," a Metro comedy romance in Ansco color with Greer Garson, Robert Ryan, Barry Sullivan and Richard Haydn, at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux. John Houseman produced and Robert Z. Leonard directed from a screen play by William Roberts and Laura Z. Hobson.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 10 -- National scholarships to Princeton University for the coming academic year have been awarded to sixteen outstanding secondary school graduates. The grants were announced today by W. Bradford Craig, secretary of the university's Committee on Scholarships.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 -- India has accepted Portugal's proposal for immediate appointment of neutral observers to study the fast deteriorating situation in Goa, Damao and Diu, the three Portuguese enclaves on India's west coast.

BEVERLY, Mass., Aug. 10 -- A general alarm fire declared to be of suspicious origin burned out the Beverly National Bank building shortly before 4 A. M. today. Twenty-four firemen were injured or overcome by smoke. Damage to the property was estimated at $1,000,000.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The eye is drawn irresistibly to the necklines of Nina Ricci's suits and coats and held there fascinated by the cape collars of flat fur, draped cravat-collars, gaping, flower-like collars of fox, one more becoming than the other.

The deadlock between the Stude-baker Corporation and the United Automobile Workers in the South Bend plant is far more important than the number of workers involved. At issue is a plea by the company for a cut of 10 to 15 per cent in wages. But even then wages and working conditions would be better than in the big Detroit automobile plants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union to give a final yes or no answer to President Eisenhower's 8-month-old proposal for international development of atomic power for peaceful purposes.

The role played by a major league baseball team in the life of its parent city varies from team to team, from town to town, and, indeed, from season to season. In Milwaukee, for example, the 1953 Braves were honored with parades and banquets; every victory on the playing field was applauded with fervor, while each setback became an issue of grave civic concern.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 -- Opposition member of the Brazilian Congress are pressing President Getulio Vargas to resign as a means of ending the state of tension provoked by the killing of an Air Force major Thursday.
Despite a 6 per cent drop in production of crude oil, the Pure Oil Company realized a 24 per cent increase in earnings in the first half of this year over the same period of 1953.
The liveliest showings of college designs to be presented here this season took place yesterday at Best's and Russeks. Both were a delight in their fresh, hitherto unseen merchandise.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- With a score of 66, Herman Barron of Fenway set the firstround pace in the Westchester open golf championship today.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 -- On turf heavy from the rain that forced the cancellation of play Monday, the Newport invitation tennis tournament started today at the Casino. Despite the slippery footing and the difficulty the players experienced with their timing, a full round was completed without a single reversal of any consequence.

OMAHA, Wednesday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Representative Carl T. Curtis, bidding for the Republican full-term Senatorial nomination, today was leading his chief challenger, Gov. Robert Crosby, after returns from 262 precincts out of Nebraska's 2,110 in yesterday's primary election.

Walter A. Cutter, in his letter in your issue of July 31, is very persuasive in strengthening one's opinion as to the important place that speed occupies in causing automobile accidents. His identifying an automobile as a projectile is very appropriate.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 10 -- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, United States champion, and Nicolas Rossolimo, former French champion, won their games today in the seventh round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Roosevelt Hotel and are tied for the lead with scores of 6 -- 1 each.

The drop-off in advertising linage in New York City newspapers from 1953 was narrowed and all but wiped out in July. Linage for the seven major dailies for the 1954 month was 87,158,386, against 87,233,842 a year before. This was a loss of only 0.09 per cent.

EDINBURG, Tex., Aug. 11 (UP) -- Since the first of the year thirty bodies have been washed ashore near here along the muddy Rio Grande. They never have been identified. They are buried in unmarked graves.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- The Canadian Cabinet held an emergency meeting today and decided to intervene in the hope of averting a general railroad tie-up resulting from a strike of non-operating railroad workers.
