THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 11 -- The Foreign Ministers of Indonesia and the Netherlands today assumed a tone of moderation in the dispute over West New Guinea (Irian).

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- London police were looking today for a tall American with a ten gallon hat as the man who piloted a small airplane through storied Tower Bridge and under London Bridge at high noon today.

TODAY at 2:30 P. M.: "The Shoemaker and the Elves," a production of the Department of Parks Marionette Theatre, will start its tour of Staten Island parks and playgrounds with a performance at Westerleigh Park, Maine and Neal Dow Avenues, Westerleigh.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Crop forecasts more bullish than expected resulted in limit advances today in all soybean deliveries and in March and May corn, with sharp rises in other grains. The upturns were met by a flood of profit taking sales, however, and there were substantial recessions from the early tops in all pits.
Hope for favorable Senate action on a tax treaty with West Germany that would stimulate private dollar investment in that country was expressed yesterday by foreign trade sources.
ST. LOUIS, Thursday, Aug. 12 (U P) -- Joe Adcock's seventh-inning single brought home Danny O'Connell with the deciding run last night as the Milwaukee Braves edged the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 5.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- American golfers edged the foreign team, 6 1/2 points to 5 1/2, in the first international matches at Tam O'Shanter today.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- The United Nations Command announced today it is ready to turn over to the Republic of Korea administrative control of about 2,300 square miles of territory north of Parallel 38.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The Commission of Assembly of the Free Church of Scotland voiced its "deep concern" today at the actions of Queen Elizabeth II, Queen Mother Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh in "permitting'' publicity for their contributions to rebuilding the war-bombed Roman Catholic cathedral at Southwark.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 518 pints of blood Tuesday. Employes of the J. C. Penney Company, 330 West Thirty-fourth Street, gave 206 pints. At the Consolidated Edison Company, 4 Irving Place, ninety-seven pints were donated.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 --The International Labor Organization has concluded from a study of trends in consumer prices that the world is enjoying an interval of "remarkable stability."

The creation of the Continental Air Defense Command, which will be activated Sept. 1, emphasizes the importance of defense of the continental United States, simplifies planning for it, but adds no strength to the present Air Defense Command.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 11 -- Eighty-five Mayors and Municipal Councilors of this island colony of Britain met today and voted to reject any British-sponsored constitution that failed to make provision for an ultimate union of Cyprus with Greece.

The peaceful purposes of the United States were emphasized again when President Eisenhower at his latest press conference categorically repudiated any idea of a "preventive war" and rejected any suggestion for breaking relations with the Soviet bloc or organizing the United Nations as an alliance to fight against it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Plans to merge the Hamilton National Bank into the National Bank of Washington -- making the latter the second largest bank in the city -- have been approved by directors of both institutions, it was announced today.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Bavarian employers maintained today that a back-to-work movement was cracking the strike that started Monday in southern Germany's important engineering and metalworking industries.
Motorists on the northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive are being inconvenienced these days so that subway riders may eventually have better service.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- Duke Snider returned to the line- up tonight and the Dodgers returned to their winning ways, beating the Phils, 3 -- 2, before 24,536 fans and reducing the idle Giants' first place lead to three and one-half games.
The Board of Estimate was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Martin M. Frank to grant $4,250 annually in pay rises to the seven attaches of the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Extension of United States Government guarantees covering foreign exchange transfer and currency convertibility on foreign investments to other foreign commercial risks was urged yesterday by a trade organization.
If that July dividend check did not reach you until after the first of this month, don't blame the letter carrier. It probably wasn't his fault.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Patent infringement suits naming thirteen concerns and six individuals have been filed by the Minnesota Mining Manufacturing Company of St. Paul charging illegal manufacture and sales of its plastic electrical tape.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov was guest of honor last night at a five-hour dinner party at the British Embassy.
An unlucky gunman lost a pair of handcuffs yesterday in a holdup that netted him nothing.
Private masses in Roman Catholic churches were arranged yesterday for former Representative Vito Marcantonio, who was denied Roman Catholic burial by the Archdiocesan Chancery.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- A jubilant British manufacturer announced today a "major break into the American domestic aircraft market," with an order for a total of forty four-engined turbo-propeller airliners from Capital Airlines of Washington.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- George Glass, the independent producer, has decided on a follow-up film to his "The Comedian," which he is planning for a late fall start.

WILKES BARRE, Pa., Aug. 11 -- The way was cleared today for the reopening of mines of the disbanded Lehigh Navigation Coal Company, which were shut down June 30 because of what the company called "tremendous financial losses."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Herman Barron, Fenway Country Club pro, turned in a splendid 54-hole aggregate of 206 to win the thirty-second Westchester open golf championship over the exacting Bonnie Briar Country Club course today.

Maj. Gen. Frederick A. Irving, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, who is retiring from the Army on Aug. 31 after thirty-seven years of service, was lauded at a luncheon here yesterday by 100 active and retired Army officers.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished yesterday with net gains of 17 to 26 points, at about the day's best levels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield announced today the appointment of Robert H. Schaffer, general counsel to the New York State Rent Commission, as acting postmaster of New York City.

Now that the work on the St. Lawrence River power project has been started, everybody is congratulating everybody else. It is, indeed, as President Eisenhower said in his telegram to Governor Dewey on Tuesday, a "very happy occasion."
A Chicago group has obtained control of the Four Wheel Drive Auto Company of Clintonville, Wis., manufacturer of special heavy duty trucks.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Two successive Detroit errors were turned into two runs today as Mike Garcia pitched a four-hitter for the Cleveland Indians to shut out the Tigers, 2 to 0, before 14,177 fans at Briggs Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The role of discriminating leader of the Republican party was taken today by President Eisenhower for the Congressional campaigns this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four cities, as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 4:

A sharp drop in state and municipal long-term financing occurred in July after the record-breaking totals that had been rolled up during the first six months. Last month's total of $257,902,693 was the lowest monthly figure since November, 1952.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A special committee of the American Bar Association today urged that Congress end abuses of its investigative powers that transgressed the rights of individuals.

The choice of the Children's Aid Society as the "most dependable child" of the year, Frances Cwibeker, 12 years old, of 40 Avenue D, was among fifty-four girls and boys who left New York by bus yesterday for three-week vacations at the society's camps in New Hamburg, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The President of the United States looked today like a man who's beginning to like his job. The thing that happened to Harry S. Truman midway through his first term seems to be happening to Dwight D. Eisenhower.
A serious disagreement has developed between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. -- the first since the agency and the union entered into a new contract last month.
MASON CITY, Iowa, Aug. 11 -- Mr. Hoover, appearing fresh and relaxed despite his strenuous swing through Iowa, this morning dedicated the Herbert Hoover Elementary School here.

The soft, pinkish glow of copper will be seen in many kitchens this fall. Once considered a precious metal and hard to clean, copper has been adapted to modern living and is being used in everything from can openers to garbage pails.

Will free Indochina be lost through paralysis in its governmental mechanism? On one level is the need for viable political leadership machinery; on another, administrative machinery -- a bureaucracy, which can effectively accomplish overwhelming tasks. Toward such goals as evacuation and rehabilitation, a vigorous economy, security without undemocratic repression, a public bureaucracy must make major contributions.
Although many furs shown yesterday at the Tailored Woman were luxurious enough to rate the Metropolitan's Diamond Circle, their was a definite jazz beat in the collection.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The 1954 master team-of-four bridge championship was won today by the defending champions -- Milton Ellenby and William A. Rosen of Chicago, Clifford Bishop of Detroit, John Moran of Houston and Lew Mathe of Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized New York City to intervene in the proposal of the Long Island Rail Road to issue $67,500,000 of new securities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on legislation providing that plots with appropriate markers can be set aside in national cemeteries in memory of military personnel missing in action.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 11 (AP) -- State Revenue Collector Rufus Fontenot advised oil companies operating off Louisiana shores in the Gulf of Mexico that the state intended to collect all taxes out to three leagues -- 10.35 miles -- from its coastline.

The overwhelming vote of the French Assembly in favor of Premier Mendes-France's bold program for an economic "revolution" is good news indeed -- for everyone but the Communists. As M. Mendes-France discloses the details of his plan it becomes clearer than ever that the heart of it is a prodigious effort to increase the productivity of the French economy and to increase the wages of the workers as their productivity goes up.

THE Navy crew that defeated every rival for three years had something in addition to the physical ability of a great rowing organization. It not only licked the world in twenty-nine consecutive races, but each time it made the opposition like it and won new friends for Annapolis. It had winning qualities all the way.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Gulf Oil Corporation reported today that its net crude oil production on a world-wide basis averaged 738,942 barrels a day during the first six months of this year, compared with 726,099 barrels daily in the similar 1953 period.
The Immunity bill, involving serious constitutional problems, is now before the President for signature.

MARION. Mass., Aug. 11 -- A German-built 2-year-old Concordia yawl from near-by Padanaram, Standish T. Bourne's Rusta IV, had the best corrected time of all today in hard sailing from Edgartown to this port on the next-to-last race of the New York Y. C. cruise.
WASHINGTON Aug. 11 (AP) -- The White House today authorized direct quotation as follows of President Eisenhower's news conference remarks on peace prospects:
OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 11 -- Efforts to reach an agreement on United States participation with Canada in the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway will be resumed here tomorrow.
The largest independent wholesale plywood distributor in Canada, Canadian Plywoods, Ltd., Montreal, has been acquired by the United States Plywood Corporation here.

CLINTON, N. J., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Charles R. Howell, Democratic senatorial candidate, said tonight the Republican party was indulging "in visions of the past" instead of planning for the future. He told a group of Hunterdon County Young Democrats that the nation's economy had lost ground this year under Republican leadership, which is "content to stand on a second-best prosperity."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a measure through which witnesses in Congressional investigations involving national security could be forced to testify.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 -- Two United States Internal Revenue agents questioned William O'Dwyer for nearly two hours today about his 1949 and 1950 income tax returns. Afterward, the former New York City Mayor said he was "ready to fight them all the way through."
The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, operator of the second largest network of neighborhood branch banks in New York City, is considering a merger offer by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that domestic new car sales had dropped 20 per cent in July below the forty-seventh month high set in June.

Members of the Girls Service League have taken over the performance of "Mrs. Patterson," a new play, for the night of Dec. 8 at a theatre to be announced. Mrs. Fraser M. Horn heads the benefit committee, and serving with her as vice chairman is Miss Virginia Thaw.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Army contradicted today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's testimony under oath that an Army officer had delivered to him a confidential document on Communist subversion.

Harry Byrd, who has been somewhat of a disappointment, made a doubly valuable contribution to the Yankee cause at the Stadium yesterday by defeating the Philadelphia Athletics, 3 -- 1, with a four-hitter.
CAIRO, Aug. 11 -- The first detachment of Britain's Suez garrison sailed for England yesterday, two weeks after Egypt and Britain initiated the outline of an evacuation agreement.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 11 -- Sir Eric Harrison, Minister of Defense Supply, announced tonight that the Australian - designed Jindivik pilotless target jet aircraft had entered the stage of quantity production at the Government aircraft factory in Melbourne.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 11 -- A brief, violent thunder squall overturned sixty-one sailing craft during a series of races in Marblehead harbor today but tragedy was averted through quick work by power boat operators in the area.

SEA ISLE CITY, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Two children were drowned today when the car their mother was driving swerved off the boulevard as it approached the drawbridge at the entrance to this resort, and fell into the deep channel below.
The New York City Ballet will open a season of four weeks at the City Center on Aug. 31, during which it will present two new ballets by George Balanchine, both set to music of American composers.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 11 -- The top prelate of the Church of England charged the Government of Yugoslavia today with paying "lip service" to freedom on the one hand and violating it on the other.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea, in its proposal to the Unified Command for turning over the area to President Rhee's South Korean regime, said that the transfer should be made "as soon as practicable."
The Sheraton Corporation of America, one of the nation's largest hotel chains, yesterday acquired the 500-room Blackstone Hotel in Chicago.
Capt. Jacques Leveque, a springy little officer with the biggest command in the French merchant marine, took the luxury liner Liberte out of New York yesterday for the last time.

A petition to reorganize the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company under Chapter 10 of the Bankruptcy Act was filed yesterday in Federal court by three of the road's bondholders. They sought the appointment of a trustee for the road, which operates the Hudson Tubes.

Ignatz Mezei, an alien cabinet- maker adjudged to be a deportable security risk, was released from Ellis Island on parole yesterday pending further consideration of his case. Mr. Mezei, who is 57 years old, boarded a train for Buffalo, where he has a wife and four children.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The British Parliament accepted today an invitation from the Supreme Soviet, its opposite number in the Soviet Union, to visit Moscow this fall.

Carl W. Suesser's letter published Aug. 7 about the "harmless" sport of dueling revived among student groups in Western Germany is unfortunate, all the more so as he is a German himself and should therefore know better.

New entrance regulations for the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., to permit a wider selection of applicants for the fall term were announced yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bluett Hanover, a 4-year-old mare owned by Kirby and Holloway of Harrington, Del., and driven by William Haughton, scored a two-length victory over Titanic in the Southampton mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Symbol Chance was third.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Glen Taylor, winner of the United States Senate nomination in his political comeback attempt, today branded as "unfortunate" a stratement by his opponent that "it looks like the Left Wing has taken over the Democratic party" in Idaho.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France was understood to have told the Cabinet today he would submit to it tomorrow a proposal for ratifying the European Defense Community treaty that would entail no new negotiations.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Aug. 11 -- The police of this community are checking children's clothing stores in Hudson and near-by counties in an attempt to establish the identity of the abductor of 3-year-old Sharon Yacko.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Senate approved tentatively today a bill to give 1,500,000 postal workers and other Civil Service employes a 5 per cent pay increase, and then set it aside for later action.
The decline of business in the intercoastal steamship trade continued through the first quarter of 1954, with freight revenues almost a million dollars below those in the 1953 quarter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

ROWAYTON, Conn., Aug; 11 -- Robert W. (Woody) Harris, 17- year-old representative of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, placed second in the two races at the Norwalk Y. C. today to hold a 3-point lead for the Pequot Cup, symbolic of the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- A British airliner carrying twenty-three passengers brushed wing tips with a French airliner 7,000 feet over Paris today and both planes landed safely.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Sylvester Veitch, who trains C. V. Whitney's horses, took it easy on the other trainers today. He went after only one race. He sent out Dispute and Moonsight in the $18,575 Test Stakes for 3-year-old fillies. Dispute won.

A new quick-to-cook dehydrated product at Abraham Straus this week is the Croyden House "12 Minute Rice Donner." This is a seasoned, quick-cooking rice, to which canned soup or sauce may be added for a variety of dishes. Some of the possibilities are Spanish rice, rice creoles, rice croquettes and rice casseroles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Girl Scouts of America, who have been viewed with suspicion by some American Legion members, found a friend today in another group of veterans.
Middle Westerners may be succumbing to the trend toward fewer holidays on organized trading exchanges.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A Delaware court has cleared the way for the Omnibus Corporation of Chicago to sell its holdings in two New York City bus lines, it was announced today by Benjamin Weintraub, president.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs tied their club record for the number of home runs in one game tonight as they hit five of Warren Hacker's pitches out of the park in an 8-1 romp over the Chicago Cubs. Ted Kluszewski and Jim Greengrass each smashed two circuit blows and Ed Bailey one.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- An analysis of the two votes in the French National Assembly yesterday showed that Premier Pierre Mendes-France was being sustained by a large but variable majority. Party support or opposition hinges on the question at issue.

The unequivocal anti-McCarthyism of Clifford P. Case, Republican nominee for the Senate from New Jersey, has apparently raised an uproar among the G. O. P. diehards within the state. There is talk of rebellion; there are demands for Mr. Case's withdrawal; and Mr. Case was even reported to have promised to tone down his uncomplimentary remarks about Mr. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Eisenhower took a hopeful view of the world today and of the chances of keeping the peace.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -- The unexpected was the commonplace in the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today, and the chief victim was Victor Seixas of Philadelphia.
The former treasurer of the Pan-American World Airways Federal-Credit Union was arrested yesterday on a charge of embezzling $50,000 in five years.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 11 -- The drouth in the midwest has cut the production of the Illinois corn crop by 107,000,000 bushels, the state Crop Reporting Service and the United States Department of Agriculture reported today.

The great increase in new buildings along Madison Avenue north of Forty-second Street has created such pedestrian congestion, especially during the late afternoon rush hours, that it is literally hard to walk on the sidewalks.

Last fall President Eisenhower announced two plans for stimulating employment in surplus labor areas. Under one of these Government procurement agencies were directed to give special consideration to these areas in the granting of contracts. Under the other companies were offered special inducements to build defense facilities by permitting them to amortize their investment for tax purposes at an accelerated rate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The United States is conducting direct negotiations at Geneva with consular representatives of Communist China for the release of sixty United States citizens detained in Communist China.

The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiary, Canadair, Ltd., showed in the six months ended June 30 the highest earnings for any similar period in its history, John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 -- Nicolas Rossolimo, former French titleholder, gained undisputed possession of first place in the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Roosevelt Hotel today by defeating Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the United States ruler, in a game lasting fifty-nine moves.

" The American System of Government," by Ernest S. Griffith, director of the Legislative Reference Service of the Library of Congress, is published today by Frederick A. Prager. Designed to give a better understanding of the essentials of the Government, the volume includes chapters on all major aspects of national, state and local government, their organization, duties and procedures, political parties and on the written Constitution.
A decline last week of 1,594,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The stock market recovery that got under way Tuesday continued in more active trading yesterday. Closing prices were around their best levels for the session, with gains ranging from 1 to 2 points in most of the leading issues.

" FLIGHT TO AFRICA,"* by Johanna Moosdorf, is a mystery thriller marinated in European existentialism and tropical voodoo. Offhand I can't remember reading a stranger novel since Sherwood Anderson wrote "Dark Laughter" for Hemingway to parody. It is the kind of story where characters are always sounding off with piercing shrieks and impenetrable soliloquies.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 11 -- Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, whose life has been menaced because he mounted the throne of the French protectorate of Morocco almost a year ago, rode slowly through a mass of nearly 10,000 turbaned, white-robed men today in the vast Mechouar, or walled compound, of the Sherifian Palace.
Salt Lake County, Utah, comprising the Salt Lake City Suburban Sanitary District, opened bids yesterday on two bond issues totaling $8,100,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The State Department said today that it had not refused visas to Karol Kotula, Bishop of the English Lutheran Church in Poland, and Dr. Wiktor Minczyk, dean of the Protestant Theologcal Faculty of Warsaw University.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Adoption by Congress of the Administration's farm policy was not a political victory, President Eisenhower said today.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- Clifford P. Case, the Republican nominee for United States Senator, made it bluntly clear today that he was free to continue his criticisms of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy without jeopardizing official party support for his candidacy.

The world premiere of Warner Brothers' "A Star Is Born," co-starring Judy Garland and James Mason and filmed in CinemaScope and Technicolor, will take place on Thursday, Sept. 30, at the R.K.O. Pantages Theatre in Hollywood.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The new bookkeeping account that started today was marked by heavy buying of industrial equities and South African gold mining issues.
Paul O'Dwyer said here yesterday that questions about the former Mayor's tax returns were "old hat -- and it's election year."
MONTREAL, Aug. 11 -- Canada today faced the threat of an early national railway strike.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that it would put into effect on Sunday a new, low fare ten-ride ticket.

Without a discussion of the relative merits of what comes over the television screen, it seems to be agreed that the rooftop antenna is a nuisance, quite aside from fees for a landlord and the installer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate passed today a bill to the Port of New York for the first time in many years to full twenty - four - hour, 'round - the - clock shipping operation. The measure authorized shipping companies to request and pay compensation or overtime Quarantine Station duties by public health officers on ships entering all United States harbors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today the Justice Department had sent "some housing scandal cases" to Federal grand juries and "a lot of others are under intense study."
The American Federation of Labor blamed President Eisenhower yesterday for "the new anti-labor policy" of the National Labor Relations Board.

Prices of commodity futures on the local markets underwent mixed changes yesterday that were small for the most part. Onion futures, however, declined sharply on selling prompted by the larger-than-expected Government crop estimate of 31,063,000 sacks, or some 2,000,000 more than had been forecast earlier in trade circles.
Probably drawing her inspiration from the musical's recently acquired title, "On With the Show," Elizabeth Miele, its producer, announced yesterday a series of new production developments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has changed its plans and does not expect to sell any new issue in this country for the remainder of the year, Eugene R. Black, president, said today.
Jet-propelled punches by Archie Moore brought a whirlwind finish to Harold Johnson's bid for the Miamian's light heavyweight championship of the world last night at Madison Square Garden.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 11 -- With the eight-year Indochina war formally ended, Gen. Paul Ely, French military commander and Commissioner General, left for Paris today for consultations.

LITTLE ROCK, ARK., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Orval E. Faubus shoved aside a second term tradition and pulled one of the biggest political upsets in Arkansas history yesterday when he defeated Gov. Francis Cherry for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 11 -- Former President Hoover today advised educational organizations to be cautious in seeking additional Federal aid for schools.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Two councilmen who went prowling this morning in search of police laxity quickly made a name for themselves -- on the police blotter. Both men were charged with breach of the peace and one of them got top billing with the added offense of resisting arrest.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Dr. T. B. Cunha, chairman of the Goan Action Committee, said here today that the committee's plan to "march" on the Portuguese settlement of Goa on Sunday -- Indian Independence Day -- would be carried out according to schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has changed its plans and does not expect to sell any new issue in this country for the remainder of the year, Eugene R. Black, president, said today.
Jet-propelled punches by Archie Moore brought a whirlwind finish to Harold Johnson's bid for the Miamian's light heavyweight championship of the world last night at Madison Square Garden.
FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Army showed the nation today how television can be used to direct infantry operations in battle.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich and Mrs. Allison Choate, Apawamis, both bidding for their third women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship, will meet in one semi-final of the organization's twenty- ninth title tournament tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Mack Brothers -- Earle and Roy -- fought to no decision today at the meeting of the board of directors of the Philadelphia Athletics. The five-man board adjourned a day-long meeting without reaching a decision on the future of the financially distressed franchise.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 11 -- A demonstration against President Getulio D. Vargas verged momentarily on serious violence today. Military police patrols and other precautions in force tonight indicated the concern of authorities over further trouble.
Music had all kinds of charms Tuesday night at Central Park. It set feet to tapping and some fists flying.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 11 -- The conservative faction of Nebraska Republican politics rode to a convincing victory as Representative Carl Curtis of Minden captured the party nomination for the long term in the United States Senate.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ted Williams walloped two homers as Boston won the first game of a day-night double-header, 10--1 from Washington today, but the Senators came back to gain a split, 5--4, on Jim Busby's ninth-inning double.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee said today that the European allies of the United States could produce only one-fourth of their ammunition needs for an all-out war. It suggested the United States might make up the deficit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The dispute over raising the national debt ceiling, now set by law at $275,000,000,000, has been quietly settled by the acceptance on all sides of a compromise devised by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 11 -- United States District Judge Robert L. Taylor tonight issued a Taft-Hartley injunction to block strikes scheduled tomorrow against key atomic plants at Oak Ridge and Paducah, Ky.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Otto John said today he had defected to East Germany because he was convinced the policies of the United States and West German Govern ments ultimately would result in the renazification and remilitarization of Germany. He said their purpose was to wage a disastrous Western military crusade against communism.

Work has started on a series of "islands" the Air Force is to build out in the Atlantic Ocean. An important gap in the nation's radar defenses will be closed by this string of huge platforms along the Continental Shelf between Virginia and Newfoundland. Some of them will be as much as 125 miles out at sea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A new plan to recruit teachers by setting up accelerated training courses for married women with college degrees was announced here today.
More than 20,000 persons become blind in this country each year, the Rev. William F. Jenks, director of the Visually Handicapped Institute of Catholic University, Washington, declared yesterday.

THE rain earlier in the week may have improved conditions for inland fishing in this area. We shall know in a day or two. The last reports from the Upper Delaware Valley weren't good. The river was low; the tributaries were all but dry.

Millions of people in the United States live in areas that benefit by fluoridation of water supply. New York City, so often in the past a leader in programs for the improvement of public health, still lags behind hundreds of other, smaller communities in adopting this measure for reducing dental caries, especially among children.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Senate failed today to call up for consideration the bill to authorize repayment to former enemy aliens for property seized by the United States during the war.

A spokesman for retail trade called yesterday for simpler business laws that would permit no special privileges for either manufacturer or retailer. He advocated an immediate study to lead to a recodification of law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Treasury savings bonds sales of the E and H series in the first seven months of this year totaled $2,909,507,000, the highest January-July volume since 1945, the Treasury announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The Chinese Communist-inspired "Free Thai" movement, aimed at taking over Thailand as well as much of Laos and Burma, has moved its headquarters from China to northeast Burma, according to a report here.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Edwin Burke of Somerset Hills took the lead in the first round of the Elizabeth Goss round-robin golf tournament at the Plainfield Country Club today.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 11 -- The ruling junta signed today a political statute replacing Guatemala's 1945 Constitution and all laws, decrees and resolution of former regimes.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Declaring that his tax status had been investigated nine times, former Mayor O'Dwyer said today that he asked George Rutledge, revenue agent, why he waited until an election year to open his inquiry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Secretary of Agriculture is "more convinced than ever today that what we've been fighting for is the right thing" for farmers and the country.

Although they may not admit it, certain young people find the days of August long. It has been quite some time since school let out for the summer. A certain amount of freedom from the discipline of work is good; but beyond a point -- in this instance about Aug. 1 -- that freedom begins to pall just a little.
A showing of shoes for the autumn by Saks Fifth Avenue at the Savoy-Plaza yesterday indicated that boots may soon be as popular as "saddles" once were among flat heel styles.

MANILA, Aug. 11 -- The residence of the Philippine President, in one of Asia's beauty spots, Baguio, will be the setting of the Southeast Asian conference if it is held in the Philippines. It seems likely that the meeting, scheduled for Sept. 6, will take place here.
In buying its fall merchandise, Macy's has decided that college and career girls have about identical needs and tastes. Both want the newest young fashions and at a price.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Ho Chi Minh, president of the Communist-led Vietmirth, left his secret home in northern Indochina today to entertain members of the international armistice commission.
New York banks are experiencing a long-awaited seasonal shift from a decline to a rise in business loans, but thus far it hasn't amounted to much.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower said today that the performance of the American economy in his Administration has been the best ever.

The historic colors of Connecticut's Forty-third Infantry Division will be returned formally to Gov. John Lodge today at 1:30 P. M. by Brig. Gen. William Colbern, deputy commanding general of the First Army at Camp Lodge, the Connecticut military reservation at Niantic.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 -- Arturito Pomar of Spain took the lead in the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Roosevelt Hotel today by defeating Nicolas Rossolimo, former French champion, in thirty-seven moves.

KALIMPONG, India, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Almost 200 persons were buried when the palace of the Panchen Lama in the Tibetan town of Shigatse collapsed after having been undermined by floods, according to reports reaching here today.
Tolls up to 25 cents on the city's four big East River bridges would be an appropriate method of financing an increased police force, the Citizens Union said yesterday.

Archie Moore of Miami, who successfully defended his light-heavyweight title against Harold Johnson of Philadelphia with a fourteenth-round technical knockout in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, may risk his crown again in the fall.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The International Council of Christian Churches today announced the adoption of a resolution urging Christian mission organizations to separate from all World Council and International Missionary Council alliances.

Papers and discussions presented at Canada's Tomorrow Conference in Quebec City in November, 1953, will be issued in book form by Macmillan on Aug. 24. The title will be "Canada's Tomorrow." Edited by George Peel Gilmour, chairman of the conference and president of McMaster University, the symposium contains ten essays on the nation's future and a digest of the discussions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Philippe de Seynes, a member of the French delegation to the United Nations since 1949, has been proposed by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold for one of the posts of Deputy Secretary General contemplated in the reorganization plans under discussion. His confirmation is pending.

Two scripts have been lined up for production by Mary K. Frank, who made her successful debut in the managerial ranks as co-sponsor with the Playwrights Company of "Tea and Sympathy." Both will be done independently. Which comes first will depend on how quickly a director is engaged. Besides Kathleen Winsor's "America, With Love," which has gone through eight drafts, Mrs. Frank owns "Abracadabra."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Labor costs other than wages averaged $720 an employe last year, a rise of $76 in two years, the United States Chamber of Commerce reported today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Workmen blasted loose an estimated 1,800 tons of rock from Prospect Point on the American side of Niagara Falls today. It was in a partly successful attempt to dislodge a jagged end of the cliff left hanging by last month's huge slide.
Two Bronx teen-agers who ran off with several thousand dollars of family funds to get married found the law less forgiving yesterday than their parents.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today reported "business as usual" at the atomic plants here and at Paducah, Ky., after a strike called by 4,500 production workers was blocked by a Taft-Hartley injunction obtained at the request of the President.

PADANARAM, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Commodore John Nicholas Brown's big black yawl Bolero ate up heavy weather like apple pie today to win the Astor Cup in the last event of the New York Yacht Club cruise while some of her smaller opponents rattled their teeth out in half a gale.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Bob Hurst and Fred Lazard, Cherry Valley, carded a 34, 37 -- 71, one under par, to lead the qualifiers during the second day of play in the twentieth annual Arthur Man Memorial invitation tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

In a further effort to resolve the longshoremen's election May 26 to choose a collective bargaining agency the National Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered hearings on 666 of 1,097 challenged ballots.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -- The Friday night series of chamber orchestra concerts at Tanglewood ended tonight -- that is, Thursday. This was no typographical error. Since "Tanglewood On Parade," the five-ring circus put on by the student body of the Berkshire Music Center, takes place tomorrow, the closing chamber orchestra event was moved up a day.

KYRENIA, Cyprus, Aug. 12 -- A twenty-four-hour general strike in support of the aspirations of Cyprus' Greek-speaking majority for union with Greece was observed today, in unexcited fashion, by the islanders of this British colony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The contract bridge team of Milton Ellenby and William A. Rosen of Chicago, Lew Mathe of Los Angeles, John Moran of Houston and Cliff Bishop of Detroit -- winners of the 1954 Master Team-of-Four Championship by virtue of six straight wins in an eight-team finalist round robin -- last night captured their seventh and final thirty-six-board match.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Robert Goldstein and Robert L. Jacks, vice presidents of Leonard Goldstein Productions, returned from New York today with the news that the late producer's company would continue to make films for United Artists release.

Three young men who said that they were seeking narcotics held up a Forest Hills, Queens, physician at pistol point late yesterday in his office. After robbing him of $115 in cash, his watch and a quantity of drugs, they bound his hands and feet with electric cord and gagged him with a towel.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 12 -- Production employes of the Studebaker Corporation today voted 8 to 1 to take a pay cut rather than face a possible shutdown of the plant here. The ballot by members of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., was 5,371 to 626 in favor of accepting the wage reduction.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Al Rosen broke out of the worst slump of his major league career today with a three-run home run that helped the Cleveland Indians' Bob Lemon defeat the Detroit Tigers, 10 -- 1.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, the state match play champion, gained the lead in the second round of the round-robin tournament of the Garden State Women's Golf Association at the Plainfield Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Rockets launched from balloons probed the skies in the North Atlantic thirteen times last month to detect samples of a mystery particle found in the ionosphere.

THERE'S nothing like daytime television for fostering happy little "families." Some persons attribute their rise to Arthur Godfrey and all the little Godfreys, but actually the daytime "families" date to radio's heyday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 -- President Getulio Vargas indicated in a speech today that he had no intention of stepping out of office, as his opponents were demanding.
Homemakers are paying surprisingly less this week than they did a year ago for a wide variety of meats. Comparative prices were noted yesterday by the New York City Department of Markets.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 12 -- The ambitious project to link Denmark and Sweden by a bridge or tunnel will be held up for three years while a joint Swedish-Danish committee of experts is examining the practicability of the plans, Nordic Council delegates were told today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Patent Office published this week in its Official Gazette notice that the American Telephone Telegraph Company and associated companies had applied for registration of their famous service mark.

What Dr. Hugh M. Flick, director of the Motion Picture Division of the State Board of Education, refers to as "a modification of an ancient precedent" will permit the showing in this state of a scene of a buffalo giving birth to a calf in Walt Disney's film, "The Vanishing Prairie," it was stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 667,592 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,977 cars, or 2.3 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week; 117,757 cars, or 15 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 114,056 cars, or 14.6 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

THE lovely cloud galleons that have moved in great fleets across the city's skies in the last forty-eight hours were built up by a cold air mass from Canada and New England. The cold air had picked up moisture around the Great Lakes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- In the week ended Aug. 11, member bank reserves decreased $2,000,000, the Federal Reserve reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee tonight charged the Army with carelessness and inefficiency in awarding contracts.
An imposing building, complete with air-conditioning and terraces, will occupy the lower Fifth Avenue block at Eighth Street that once contained the famous old Brevoort Hotel.

Investment interests represented by Max Abramchik have purchased the three six-story buildings on plot 120 by 100 feet at 139 to 149 West End Avenue, northwest corner of West Sixty- sixth Street, from Frieda B. Ughetta and the 145 West End Avenue Corporation.

Decorative wood sculpture in the form of animals, birds and abstract forms are on view at the Willow, 182 West Fourth Street. The forms are hand modeled of California redwood by Stan Schwartz and Mel Steinberg.

BUFFALO, Aug. 12 -- Motions to dismiss criminal contempt charges against Elmer F. Lux, president of the Buffalo City Council, and two officers of Schine chain theatres were denied today by Judge John Knight of the United States District Court.

The President's Council of Economic Advisers is not issuing any midyear report this year, but yesterday Mr. Eisenhower released a 2,000-word statement on the economic condition of the nation, presumably in lieu of the lengthy and more formal document.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The pennant-hungry Milwaukee Braves, paced by the six-hit southpaw hurling of Warren Spahn, stopped the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 3 -- 1, for a sweep of their three-game series.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The Bavarian metal workers definitely think they have their employers on the run in their strike for higher wages.

For about forty years Americans in the Philippines celebrated today, Aug. 13, as "Occupation Day." It commemorated the establishment of formal American control in the Philippines. The celebration was dominated by Americans. Ardent Filipino nationalists, with good reason, didn't like it. It was an American holiday.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Guatemala's new Ambassador to Mexico said yesterday that his Government would grant former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman permission to leave Guatemala.
Shipments of rayon and acetate filament yarn and staple by domestic proudcers in July were below shipments in June and in July, 1953, according to the Textile Economic Bureau, Inc.

The Charles F. Noyes Company, real estate brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it was relinquishing the tenth floor, occupied by its executive offices, in 40 Wall Street to J. S. Bache Co., and will move to 42 Broadway.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 -- Pessimism is evident over the chances for effective results from the Inter-American Economic Conference. Sessions are scheduled to begin here Nov. 22.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate, in a surprise move, voted 85 to 0 today to outlaw the Communist party in the United States.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Gog," a science-fiction melodrama in Eastman color with Richard Egan, Constance Dowling and Herbert Marshall, will open at the Palace. Ivan Tors produced and Herbert L. Strock directed from a screen play by Tom Taggart and a story by Mr. Tors.

RACINE, Wis., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The newest member of the Army's "light tank" family, the M44 self-propelled howitzer, had its first public presentation today at the Racine test track of the Massey-Harris Company, its maker.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A pair of unseeded teen-agers from California, Barbara Breit of Hollywood and Darlene Hard of Montebello, tumbled seeded foreigners in the third round of the Essex women's tennis tournament today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Earl Stewart of Dallas fired a 65 and Walter Burkemo of Franklin, Mich., carded a 66 today to spearhead a mass assault on Tam O'Shanter's par of 36, 36 -- 72 in the first round of the "world" tournament.

TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner delivered a sharp attack on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today, but expressed doubt that the McCarthy issue would be a decisive factor in the New Jersey election this fall.

After two sessions of strong recovery, the stock market yesterday turned easier in quieter trading. Except for a few issues, losses were held to fractions. Aircraft issues were in somewhat heavy supply from the start, and selling in that group was a factor in the general decline.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Senorita Carmen Gutierrez Gomez-Flores -- a young, black-haired and dark-eyed Mexican girl -- quietly exchanged her elevator girl's uniform tonight for a frothy, pastel-blue dinner gown and made her American debut as a concert pianist in the United Nations Trusteeship Council Chamber.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Judge Michael L. Igoe of Federal District Court filed today in the United States Court of Appeals a document contending that Zenith Radio Corporation and its subsidiary, Rauland Corporation, should be allowed to proceed with their $16,000,000 anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America, General Electric Company and Western Electric Company.

The Fire Department yesterday switched assignments "for the good of the service" for four uniformed members who on Wednesday were penalized by maximum fines for improper conduct in refrigeration inspections.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture report on today's livestock markets fallows:

ROSLYN, L. I., Aug. 12 -- The Twenty-sixth Air Division (Defense) here announced today the award of an emblem to the tanker Sunoil, the first ship to enlist as a seagoing observation post of the United States Air Defense Command's "Operation Skywatch."

A permanent law requiring that at least 50 per cent of all Government aid cargoes be carried in American-flag ships became a virtual certainty yesterday as the House of Representatives approved unanimously a Senate measure that included the fifty-fifty clause.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 12 -- Premier Fazlollah Zahedi disclosed today that Iran would embark soon on an ambitious five-year development program. The plan will be financed by...
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Swimmers who may form the backbone of United States and Japanese teams in the 1956 Olympics begin competing today in Japan's national championships.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- Clement R. Attlee and seven British Labor party associates flew east tonight toward Peiping and talks with leaders of Communist China. They departed after conversations with Soviet Premier Georgi N. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party.

AKRON, Ohio, Friday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Pickets ringed the sprawling Firestone Tire Rubber Company factories here and at Des Moines, Iowa, early today as 5,500 C. I. O. United Rubber Workers struck Firestone plants in eight cities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- The Chicago Corporation, investment banking organization, is negotiating with a group of banks for a ten-year $52,000,000 loan, Richard Wagner, chairman, disclosed today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The 14,000 public service and utility workers of Hamburg went back to work today after arbitrators had awarded them their minimum demands to end a nine-day strike. The walkout had paralyzed Hamburg's public transport system and had reduced the water and gas supply of the city to a mere trickle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- A former employe of the Voice of America has complained he was dismissed as "punishment" for cooperating with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Senator William E. Jenner said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- It really wasn't needed, but there was an additional proof today of the horse-training skill of Mrs. Clara Elizabeth Adams and the race-riding skill of her son Dooley.

Net income of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company for the second quarter of this year amounted to $6,212,782, equal to 55 cents a share on the pipeline concern's outstanding common stock. This compares with a net of $4,781,753, or 42 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- Two industry-wide records in the production of steel were established at the Fairless Works of the United States Steel Corporation at nearby Morrisville during July, it was announced today.

The head of the house sat the other day upon a beach. His head pointed to the land behind, his feet toward the water. Above, the sun looked down, and beneath him nature's original radiant heat gently warmed his spine. Children played near by, fiddler crabs gave the orchestra a downbeat, and by opening his eyes just a trifle the head of the house could see an occasional sail far off near the horizon.
Louise Bennett, Jamaican folksong singer and writer, entertained a group of twenty-five children yesterday morning at the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center, 514 West 126th Street.
Five boys were injured, none of them seriously, when one exploded a stick of dynamite yesterday in a vacant lot in the Bronx. The lot is on Merriam Avenue, between 169th and 170th Streets.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Maurice Podoloff, president of the National Basketball Association, said today the league had awarded the services of Bob Williams to the Minneapolis Lakers.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Eagle-Picher Company today announced it had purchased 296,386 shares -- 98.8 per cent of the common stock -- of Fabricon Products, Inc., of Detroit, for $9,780,738.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Mandatory set-asides of most copper products for defense purposes were eased today in an order issued by the Business and Defense Services Administration covering the last quarter of this year.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner defended today a $91,000,000 appropriation being considered by Congress to defray the cost of deepening the Delaware River channel.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 12 -- Goan Nationalist volunteers will march into Goa on Sunday from two villages of India almost on the border of that Portuguese area, Peter Alvares, president of the National Goa Congress, said here today. The marchers will be completely unarmed and will carry only the Indian flag, he added.

The Transit Authority appointed three of its executives yesterday to a committee to hold a hearing today on objections by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to new operating schedules for the IND subway division.
LONDON, Ont., Aug. 12 -- At the end of the opening day's play for the Americas Cup, the United States golf team led Canada by a point, while the Mexican squad was scoreless.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 6 -- The famous Newport Casino may be sold.
City departments and agencies have asked the City Planning Commission for 1955 capital budget allocations amounting to $1,008,510,154.
Fresh eggs and fresh vegetables provide a combination that may be worked into many dishes. They are a particularly timely team now, for both are in good supply at moderate cost.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, one of Britain's most powerful labor organizations, directed its executive committee today to open negotiations at once with engineering employers for wage improvements.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 -- William O'Dwyer said today that he definitely would return to New York to fight for his reputation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Curtailment of the right of appeal to Federal courts in criminal cases decided in state courts was advocated today in a report submitted to the Conference of Chief Justices of the States.
TOKYO, Aug. 12 -- Hayato Ikeda, secretary general of the dominant Liberal party, said today that "Japan must not change her pro-American foreign policy."

April showers bring May flowers, but August breezes cause violent sneezes and watering noses and bronchial wheezes. May one thus introduce in fanciful verse a subject too horrible to examine in factual prose -- namely, the hay fever season?

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Hillsota turned in a blazing drive down the homestretch tonight to capture one of harness racing's richest prizes, the $35,000 Nassau Pace, at Roosevelt Raceway. In winning the mile and a half contest, the 4-year-old brown horse established a world record of 3:04 4/5.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 12 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies was accused tonight of having used the Vladimir Petrov case to influence the Australian election. He retorted that the charge was hysterical and dishonest.
The Republican party was characterized yesterday as "the party of depression" by New York State Democrats formally starting their 1954 campaign.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- Officials of the Israeli Foreign Ministry have let General Bennike know they hope he will press the attempt to improve border relations before ending his term as chief of the United Nations truce supervision organization.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Roger (the Terrible) Touhy, prohibition gangster overlord, was hustled back to Joliet Penitentiary today in an armed police motorcade.
A major round-up of suppliers of heroin and opium was achieved here Wednesday night and early yesterday as the culmination of an eleven-month investigation by the Federal Bureau of Narcotics.
An orderly throng of 5,000 from near-by tenements packed the sidewalks as a funeral service for Vito Marcantonio was held yesterday afternoon in the Ralph Giordano funeral home, 2242 First Avenue.
A $67,585,983 reorganization plan for the Long Island Rail Road, including a 20 per cent fare increase at 12:01 A. M. today, was approved yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Moscow's announcement that Dmitri Shostakovich and Aram Khachaturian have been named "People's Artists" of the Soviet Union is a pleasant contrast to much past news about these famous composers which has come from the Soviet capital. Instead of the party-line criticism of the past, the award to these two men now gives them a public Soviet position in the rank-conscious Soviet Union which is more nearly comparable to their giant stature among contemporary composers.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Britain will press for the creation of a network of mutually binding military guarantees among the eight powers meeting next month to discuss a Southeast Asian treaty.
Martin's of Brooklyn has thoroughly explored the subject of "back-to-college" fashions and there was no mistaking this autumn's style highlights in yesterday's presentation at the store.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- John Leib and Mrs. Caleb Whitaker of Piping Rock, the last team out in the Long Island Golf Association's mixed foursomes tournament, fired an 82 -- 13 -- 69 today to tie for the low net prize at the Piping Rock Club.

It will be Ruben Gomez of the Giants against Carl Erskine of the Dodgers at Ebbets Field tonight as the teams begin a three-game series that will have considerable bearing on the National League pennant race.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower called upon House of Representative and Senate conferees to strike from the farm bill several provisions that he said might be costly or injurious to farmers.
American Airlines, strike-bound since July 31, announced plans last night to disband its $7,300,000 monthly payroll unless the walkout by pilots ends over the week-end.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Winston Guest, former ten-goal polo player, has started a Supreme Court battle here in an attempt to revoke the terms of a $785,000 trust fund.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Hungary accepted today President Eisenhower's offer of United States food for flood victims.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that her department had "fared very well" in the current Congress.

On several occasions I have written to you about public issues that have been argued in the press, but I do not believe I have yet written a letter of thanks to The New York Times for its high standards of reporting, editorial comment and its reliability in general. I depend on it daily.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- James J. Kinneally, Democratic chairman of Rahway, was elected tonight Union County party chairman after a bitter fight during which the Elizabeth delegation tried to block the balloting.
Vito Marcantonio, as your news account of his death states, was a tireless, energetic Representative in Congress from East Harlem for fourteen years.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A group headed by Frederick W. Richmond of New York has offered about $9,000,000, for the assets of the Follansbee Steel Corporation, M. A. Follansbee, president, announced today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -- A 17-year-old Australian newcomer defeated Lewis Hoad in the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today.

The one-month nominating period for the biennial elections of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., opened yesterday. Forty-nine posts are open in the elections which begin Nov. 15.

It was with considerable interest and appreciation that I read the article written by Hanson W. Baldwin in The Times of Aug. 5. It is commendable that Mr. Baldwin should take our interests to heart. It is my belief that it is high time that someone should publicize this injustice to the retired military personnel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A statistically minded Senate parliamentarian figured out today that the Senate under the rapid gaveling of Senator Frederick G. Payne, Republican of Maine, has established an all-time record in bill passage.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 -- A generation of children is at war with a generation of adults and juvenile delinquency is an expression of this conflict, an international meeting of psychiatrists was told today.
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have arrested two more men in the year-old case of the $190,319 robbery of a Long Island bank.

ANNAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Walter F. Boone, whom the yearbook of the class of 1921 called "a darned good fellow," today became superintendent of the Naval Academy from which he was graduated thirty-four years ago.

Higher retail prices for watches -- the result of the recent 50 per cent increase on imported movements -- are not expected to affect sales. This is the opinion of manufacturers, who estimated that the higher tariff would mean a difference of $1 to $3.50 to the customer.

Advertisers in this country invested $7,809,200,000, a record total, in national and local advertising in 1953, Printers' Ink, weekly magazine of advertising, management and sales, will report in tomorrow's issue.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 12 -- Golfers have often remembered this city as the home of one of the game's ablest representatives, C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville. Although Sandy seldom mentions it, he is the only Canadian who has ever won the United States amateur golf championship. He did that back in 1932, defeating Johnny Goodman in the final.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A balky witness was ejected today from a hearing on orders of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, after the witness sought to have his subpoena quashed on the ground that the Senator himself faced "serious charges."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Foreigners' investments in securities of United States corporations approached the $4,000,000,000 mark by the close of last year.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs said it with power again today as three home runs and a triple drove in enough runs to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 6, for a sweep of the three-game series. Ted Kluszewski, Jim Greengrass and Wally Post hit the homers and Kluszewski smashed the triple.
The directors of the Westrex Corporation yesterday elected Eugene S. Gregg as president to succeed Frederick W. Bierwirth, who will retire Aug. 31 under the age retirement rule.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- The Federal District Court cleared the way today for a new attempt by the Government to take from Harry Bridges his American citizenship and send him back to his native Australia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A plan whereby surplus Government-owned butter might be processed into a top-notch brand of ghee (a semi-fluid butter) for the housewife of India was advanced here today by Irving C. Reynolds of Toledo, Ohio.
SEATTLE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Major changes in the nation's civil air regulations are in prospect to adjust them to jet-age flying.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 12 -- The Elmjacks defeated Bellport, 5 -- 0, and the Elmont Nationals traped Central Nassau-Hicksville, 1 -- 0, in the semi-final round of the section 11, of the region 2, New York State Little League championships on Hickey Field today.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Share values rose today in nearly all the industrial groups in continued active trading.

By taking both ends of a double-header with the Philadelphia Athletics before 13,890 spectators at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees shaved a half-game from the lead of the Indians. The runner-up Bombers now trail the Cleveland Tribe by two and a half games.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 12 -- The announcement by Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, that he is planning to return to Vietnam soon from France was received here today with considerable surprise. It had been generally believed he would remain in France in a kind of semi-retirement.

HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 12 -- More than 300 years ago Captain Miles Standish found that the waters of Cape Cod were teeming with fish, big and little. He also discovered some Indian corn growing in the flats behind some big sand dunes on the Massachusetts Bay shore. So the Pilgrims had plenty to eat.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Dr. Otto John's allegations and disclosures at his press conference were seized on today by the Opposition Social Democratic party to demand a special session of the Bundestag.

HONG KONG, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist Government has issued new regulations governing the residence, travel and departure from China of foreigners, the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency reported today.

Plans were announced yesterday by the Lower Colorado River Authority, Tex., for the sale of $27,000,000 of revenue refunding bonds on Aug. 24. The issue will be dated May 1, 1954, and will mature from 1955 to 1962.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- A five-cent-an-hour wage increase, retroactive to last Dec. 16, was given today to about 4,000 yardmasters on fifty-five railroads in a contract agreement between the Railroad Yardmasters of America and the carriers.
A special garbage clean-up drive was called off yesterday by the Deputy Commissioner of Housing, Bernice Rogers. She said some courts no longer were cooperating in the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Department store sales last week equaled the volume of the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- Doctors' certification that drivers with certain ailments are fit to operate a motor vehicle will be required for renewal of licenses that expire Sept. 30, the Motor Vehicle Bureau announced today.
ROME, Aug. 12 -- A team of seventeen young Italian cave explorers established today what they maintain is a world record for depth penetrated into the crust of the earth in a natural cave.
The American Federation of Labor has dropped its national radio broadcaster, Frank Edwards, on the ground that he failed to draw a line between news and opinion.
The Lewyt Corporation, which years ago introduced the canister-type vacuum cleaner, displayed its 1955 model yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower gave his blessing today to seventeen more Republican candidates for House of Representatives seats -- on the understanding that they back his legislative program.

Despite higher taxes and a drop in sales, Aluminium, Ltd., the leading factor in the aluminum industry outside the United States, increased its earnings in the first six months this year, as compared with the corresponding 1953 period.

Senator Ralph Flanders, Republican of Vermont, and his wife, Helen, left New York International Airport, at Idlewild, Queens, last night for a month's vacation in the British Isles. The Senator had planned to leave on Aug. 6 on the liner United States, but had delayed his departure pending Senate action on his motion for censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Buying of all grains and of soybeans gained momentum today. Initial price changes were not specially significant, but the absorption of futures in all pits expanded as the market firmed.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Traffic accidents in the Hutchinson River Parkway's hazardous "death valley" between White Plains and Connecticut have been reduced 50 per cent since rigid enforcement of the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit began in the spring.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- Aneurin Bevan, the leader of the British Labor party's left wing, had the benefit today of a short lecture on the Soviet view of schools and education.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Jackie Jensen doubled in two runs and scored two more to support Frank Sullivan's effective seven-hit pitching today for a 5-0 Boston second-game victory over Washington after the Senators had won the opener of a double-header, 9 -- 5.
Coffee and cocoa futures were under considerable selling pressure yesterday. Most other commodities moved in a comparatively narrow range in moderately active transactions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada, newly appointed head of the United Nations truce staff in Palestine, expressed measured optimism today about the situation there.

The first of a series of forums on waterfront theft and pilferage was held yesterday morning in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. This program is sponsored by the Security Bureau, Inc., in behalf of 170 member companies.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr., Hudson River, gained the final of the twenty-ninth women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Woodway Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower, facing the problem of how to get from the voters a working Republican majority in Congress that is also reliably pro-Administration, appears to be taking the middle of the road -- a favorite location -- between Woodrow Wilson in 1918 and Franklin D. Roosevelt twenty years later.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France moved into the field of European diplomacy today with efforts to break the deadlock in France over the European Defense Community army treaty and smooth the way for further negotiations with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Ray H. Jenkins returned to the scene of the Army-McCarthy hearings today and joined Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, in urging new rules to prevent abuses in Congressional investigations.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 12 -- An advance element of about a dozen United States Navy ships was authoritatively said today to be en route to Haiphong to assist in the evacuation of refugees from North Vietnam. It had been reported earlier that these ships were coming from the Japan area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Differences between the United States and Britain on the formation of a Southeast Asian defense pact have been largely overcome during the last month, diplomatic sources said today.

The temperature dipped yesterday to the coldest level ever recorded for the date in the eighty-three-year history of the Weather Bureau. At 5:05 A. M., the mercury reading was 56.3 degrees, breaking by one-tenth of a degree the previous record low for Aug. 12, set in 1889.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A third member of the gambling Davis family was in jail under heavy bond today while investigators piled up fresh evidence in the vice purge of Phenix City.
OTTAWA, Aug. 12 -- The Canadian Government's intervention in the threatened general railroad strike led to a tentative agreement today by the union and the companies to resume negotiations next week.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Bolstered by a big flurry in the first inning, Bob Feller hurled the 259th victory of his career tonight for the Cleveland Indians, defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 9 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A threatened strike on five major airlines was averted today when the lines agreed to bargain with the American Federation of Labor mechanics and ground crewmen on a nation-wide basis.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 13 -With official dedication ceremonies, the Kennecott Copper Corporation opened an ultra-modern $1,250,000 research center and pilot plant here today to handle an expanded research program for its four Western mining divisions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Wheat prices worked up to new high levels for the preset movement today, but the upturn met much profit taking and week-end evening up.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 (AP)--Lady Dunn, 5-year-old bay mare owned by Carl Scholl of Cincinnati and driven by Harold Miller, won the featured Greenport trot in 2:03 4/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Two medical magazines urged the British Government today to let doctors prescribe fake medicines under the free national health service.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The stock market ended one of its most active weeks in years today with industrial equities and South African gold mine issues still rising.
