NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Straight Clark called a halt to Australia's procession on the tennis courts today.

KNOXVILLE, Aug. 13 -- About 1,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L., electricians who walked off a construction project involving atomic plants here returned, to work today, but 670 other electricians stayed away from a second such project.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Aug. 12 letter to Senator Hickenlooper urging approval of the compromise atomic energy bill:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A Common Pleas Court Judge handed out stiff sentences today to eight men accused of bombings during last fall's strike at the plant of the North American Aviation Company here.
The Dodgers, it develops, have only just begun to fight.

" Action With the Seaforths," by Charles Monroe Johnson, is the only book published today. The author, a Tennessean, tells of his experiences overseas after he had hitchhiked to Canada and joined the Canadian forces at the outbreak of World War II.

The heavy volume of truck traffic created by the New York State Thruway may force the construction of a connection with the New Jersey Turnpike, according to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. Although Gov. Robert B. Meyner is opposed to linking the two routes, studies are still underway with a view to bringing about this junction. These are under the direction of the Turnpike Authority.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Proposals to alter the capital structure of The Times of London, to assure against control of the newspaper's passing from the hands of the families of Col. J. J. Astor and John Walter on the death of either of them, were announced today.
CAMP RIPLEY, Minn., Aug. 13 (UP) -- The highest officers in the Iowa - Nebraska National Guard Thirty - fourth Division had to "go through channels" to budge a 20-year-old private first class.

There seems to be a market in this state for Texas land in lots of two square inches, covered by deeds stating that they convey no oil, gas or mineral rights and that the purchasers are only buying pieces of paper.

A proposed local law that favors special trucking interests has been passed quietly by the City Council and the Board of Estimate. The measure is expected to be signed Tuesday by Mayor Wagner after a statutory public hearing that day.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 14 -- The Japanese Government announced today that "several Japanese nationals were involved" in spy activities conducted by Yuri A. Rastvorov through the Soviet mission here. The announcement by the Foreign Office said, however, that there was no evidence that any high Japanese Government officials were involved.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP)--Bob Toski, a 127-pound walloper from Livingston, N. J., turned Tam o'Shanter into a target range today with a 34, 31--65 for a 36-hole course record total of 132--12 under par--and a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $150,000 "world" tournament.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -Nine Philadelphia Communists were convicted in Federal Court today of conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the United States Government.
W. S. Egekvist has been appointed general manager of the infants' and children's division of Julius Kayser Co.

Despite President Eisenhower's hopeful report on the United States economic situation, some diplomatic observers are concerned because this year's recession here has lasted long enough to provide important debating points for Communist propaganda in the months ahead.
A one-day strike of 400 drivers Orange County was called off early yesterday before New York City's milk supply was seriously jeopardized.

Members of the New York Wellesley Club have arranged a tour of private homes in New York, to be known as Manhattan Adventure, to be held on Nov. 5 and 6 for the benefit of the Wellesley College Scholarship Fund.
Herbert N. Stevens has been elected vice president in charge of sales of Nordic brand products of the Atlantic Coast Fisheries Company, effective Sept 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Eisenhower's proposals for higher benefits and taxes, wider coverage and other changes in the Social Security system were approved by the Senate tonight with some modifications.

At the annual meeting of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in San Francisco yesterday, J. D. Zellerbach, president, told shareholders that an estimated net profit of $7,500,000 or $1 a share was made in the quarter ended July 31. This compares with $6,100,000 or 90 cents each on fewer shares earned in the 1953 quarter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Navy announced today it would honorably discharge 45,000 of its inactive reserve officers who had not participated in training for three years or more.
The executive council of the American Federation of Labor approved yesterday the final draft of a plan designed to keep A. F. L. unions from raiding one another.

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, said yesterday that Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, had given a false and exaggerated picture of unemployment in this state for political purposes.
McCOMB, Miss., Aug. 13 (UP) -The Government appeared today to have won its long running battle to collect Social Security taxes owed by Mrs. Mary Cain.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press) -Dr. Rosario Fontaine, Quebec's veteran chief pathologist, declared today that Emilie Dionne had "accidentally suffocated herself in her pillow" during an attack of epilepsy.

The formalities concluded with unexpected suddenness, the Long Island Rail Road leaves its bankruptcy status of five years' duration, begins operation as a railroad redevelopment corporation relieved of overlapping bureaucratic regulation, raises fares 20 per cent and starts what we hope will be a better way of life.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson of Milwaukee scored the Essex County Club tennis tournament's top upset today by eliminating Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4 to advance to the semi-finals. Miss Fry had been seeded No. 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13--One of the major problems in enforcing the Supreme Court's recent ruling outlawing segregation in public schools is overcoming the "superficial compliance" of some Southern school districts, Prof. Robert A. Leflar of New York University's School of Law said today.

The overwhelming vote of the United Automobile Workers' Studebaker employes to take a pay cut is a notable triumph of reason and understanding in labor-management relations. Caught between intensified competition with the "big three" automobile companies and wage rates in its plants a good deal higher than in Detroit, the Studebaker management had felt it would have to ask its 10,000 employes to take a 14 per cent reduction in wages.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Japan will test her young, improving swimmers tonight against American champions who may lead the United States to another team title in the 1956 Olympic Games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate will pay the fees of the lawyer who will defend Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the pending censure proceedings.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Thursday were 650 pints. This week's biggest donation totaled 375 pints at the Green Haven State Prison at Stormville, N. Y. At the Lockheed Aircraft Service International, Inc., at New York International. Airport 163 pints were given on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Yuri A. Rastvorov, a former Soviet intelligence officer in Japan, has received asylum in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Warren Olney 3d, the Government's chief criminal prosecutor, said today that more than 200 cases involving fraud, collusion or other irregularities in the housing field were now "in various stages of investigation" by Federal attorneys throughout the country.

The statement by Council President Stark about the danger to business and real estate interests from "undue emphasis" on crime conditions in the city is most unfortunate, to say the least. Mr. Stark believes such disclosures "could" frighten away residents, drive business out of the city and make women afraid to walk through the streets at night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso's triple scoring Nellie Fox from first base in the sixteenth inning ended a brilliant pitching duel between Jack Harshman and Al Aber and gave the Chicago White Sox a 1-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate rejected today a plea from President Eisenhower for enactment of the atomic energy bill in the "cause of world peace." Instead, the bill was returned to a second conference with the House of Representatives.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 -- Formal notes will be exchanged in the next fortnight by the United States and Canada defining the rights and responsibilities of each in the building and use of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

LUMBER production in the week ended Aug. 7 was 39.6 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 38.5 per cent and orders 24.8 per cent.
A tri-partite arbitration board awarded a wage increase of 5 cents an hour yesterday to 80,000 locomotive engineers on the nation's railroads.

Fifty years ago a Korean youth named Syngman Rhee was warning Americans that Japan's basic philosophy was one of military conquest and expansion. He wrote once of Japanese aggression, "Postponement is not a settlement. The forest fire will not extinguish itself."
" The Cretan Woman," presented earlier this year in Washington and then brought here for a limited run at the Provincetown Playhouse, next will make its stand on the Main Stem.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Herbert A. Bradley was ousted as president of the '120,000-member International Chemical Workers Union, A. F. L., tonight in an election that ended a bitter five-day fight at the union's eleventh annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Conferees of the House of Representatives and the Senate said tonight they expected to reach a settlement by tomorrow afternoon on the Administration's farm bill.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 13 -- A dispute last night in the Ecuadorian legation between two political refugees resulted in the wounding of Lorenzo Montufar Navas, a former Guatemalan Government press aide, and the arrest of Daniel Vanegas Vasquez, former Congressman.

The price of coffee declined sharply yesterday in futures trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The coffee bean, imported to this country primarly from South America, fell the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound, in an active market as traders unloaded their holdings.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 13 -- This city's administration will offer its cooperation in a creditors' suit, filed several days ago in Federal District Court in New York, to reorganize the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company.

The New York State branches of the Roman Catholic Central Verein of America and of its auxiliary, the National Catholic Women's Union, will hold their conventions over the Labor Day week-end at the Commodore Hotel here.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Employes of the West Lynn plant of the General Electric Company were told today of a two-year $4,000,000 modernization program to accommodate an expected growth in product lines.

Mayor Wagner is planning to renew next week in dramatic fashion his oft-repeated plea to Governor Dewey for the creation of an impartial commission to work out an equitable long-range program of city-state fiscal relationship.

Labor unrest in West Germany has been mounting so rapidly during the past few weeks as now to approach a national emergency, the outcome of which cannot yet be clearly seen. About four million -- one out of four of the entire labor force -- are either on strike or have presented their employers with wage demands under threat of open industrial warfare.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Visa requests for fifteen Communist youth editors to make an inspection tour of universities in the United States are being held up by the State Department, at least temporarily.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -President Getulio Vargas, in statements published today, recognized for the first time that his resignation was being discussed. But he insisted, "I will finish my term to the last minute."

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 13 -- The Minister of Justice's refusal to admit an 81-year-old German university professor into Norway has stirred up a lively controversy here. The dispute may lead to a review of the ministry's policy of admitting or rejecting Germans.

The article in The Times of July 28 entitled "Wider Use Urged of State Forests" is misleading, as are so many similar statements which have been made by those who wish to chop out places in the forest preserve for their particular purposes.

MOSCOW, Aug. 13 -- The newspaper Moscow Komsomoletz, organ of the Moscow Communist Youth Organization, published today an expose of begging by children. It criticized local authorities for lack of attention to this problem.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 13 (UP)--The Studebaker Corporation, whose production workers voted yesterday to take a pay cut, disclosed today that it planned to reduce the prices of its 1955 automobiles by about $100 and hoped to get a large defense contract.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr., Hudson River, routed Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, 7 and 6, in the scheduled 36-hole final of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Woodway Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Eisenhower Administration sought means today to sidetrack if possible, or to derail if necessary, a surprise legislative effort to outlaw the Communist party in the United States. The measure won Senate approval last night on a vote of 85 to 0.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A scheduled reading by Emlyn Williams of the works of Charles Dickens for charity was abandoned today because of a medieval law involving beards.

The New York Port of Embarkation will revert to its former system of hiring longshoremen and cargo carpenters from contracting stevedoring companies at the Brooklyn Army Base and the Staten Island Terminal, Brig. Gen. James Glore, port commander, announced yesterday. General Glore said the change-over would take place Monday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 13 -Governor General Ghulam Mohammed warned tonight that Pakistan "will not allow interference in our affairs by anybody."
OTTAWA, Aug. 13 -- This year's Canadian wheat crop is expected to be nearly a hundred million bushels short of last year's, which was the second largest in Canadian history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate approved today a temporary $6,000,000,000 increase in the national debt ceiling, now fixed by law at $275,000,000,000. The action was by a unanimous voice vote.
TOKYO, Aug. 13 -- Communist China's Government Council has approved unanimously a suggestion by Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister, that determined action be taken to "liberate" Formosa.
TORONTO, Aug. 13 -- Psychiatrists are becoming increasingly convinced that the treatment of or prevention of mental illness should be started for children under 6 years old.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 13 -- A strike of the 800,000 West Germany public employes appeared to have been averted tonight when the Public Service Workers Union decided to submit to a vote a compromise offer by the state and local governments.

THE sticks and stones that broke men's bones are immortally embedded in Houston Peterson's "A Treasury of the World's Great Speeches."* These are the words of men who risked a great deal to say what they thought was wrong as well as what they thought was right. The windy pieties of vicarious righteousness were not enough.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Friday the thirteenth was auspicious for "Tanglewood On Parade." The sun shone in the afternoon, and the full moon and the stars brightened the night. As a result, more than 10,000 persons had the liveliest and best attended demonstration in years of Tanglewood's many-faceted activities.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- World acceptance of a definition of blindness was recommended by the General Assembly of the World Council for the Welfare of the Blind, which closed it sessions here today.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 13 -Registration of 1,500 delegates, consultants and accredited visitors to the second general assembly of the World Council of Churches opening Sunday morning in the First Methodist Church of Evanston, will get under way tomorrow.

Business is improving in the nation's chain stores, according to a survey by The New York Times. Emulating the patter of retail business, generally, chain and mail-order sales showed a gain of 2.2 per cent this July over July, 1953.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 13 -- Arturito Pomar of Madrid and Abe Turner of New York shared the lead today in the tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Roosevelt Hotel.
LONDON, Ont., Aug. 14 -- The United States team of amateur golfers retained the Americas Cup today by the margin of one point.

The election of John Sloan Smith as president of the Aero Mayflower Transit Company, Inc., to succeed Parke A. Cooling, who becomes chairman of the board, was announced yesterday by the nation-wide household goods moving concern of Indianapolis.

The anxiously awaited move of Premier Mendes-France on the European Defense Community has now come, but it would be rash to throw one's hat into the air and cheer. Doubts and anxieties must remain, because the French are once more asking for drastic changes and safeguards which may or may not be acceptable to the other five member states who would form the European Army and a political assembly to go with it.
TRENTON, Aug. 13 -- State tax collections reached a record high during the fiscal year ended June 30. They totaled $211,259,152, nearly $15,000,000 more than in the previous year.
Guy Chassagnard is a young man who is going a long way, both literally and figuratively.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -The Government has compromised a $13,450,000 income and excise tax claim against the American Distilling Company of Pekin, Ill., and its stockholder trust for $1,549,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a State Department note to the Soviet Union on the case of Yuri A. Rastvorov, a statement by the Department of Justice on the authorization for his entry into the United States, including his, request for asylum and a biographical sketch, and a statement made by Mr. Rastvorov:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator William E. Jenner of Indiana called for the Administration today to repudiate its foreign policy commitments. He asked the Senate to kill the Mutual Security bill.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 13 (AP) -A United States soldier who tried to flee to Communist territory, threatened to fight against United States forces and denounced his citizenship was sentenced by a court-martial today to five years at hard labor.

A dispatch from The Hague reports that Dutch chess officials are incredulous at the information that lack of money for expenses will keep an American chess team from competing in the biennial international chess tournament opening soon in Amsterdam.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- A slow-up in drilling operations today forced postponement of blasting operations at Prospect Point on the United States side of Niagara Falls.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -Communist party members throughout the world got orders today to be more "critical."
TRENTON, Aug. 13 -- Superior Court Judge C. Thomas Schettino upheld today the right of Gov. Robert B. Meyner to suspend Louis J. Russo, assistant chief examiner of the State Civil Service Commission.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 13 -- The Anglican Congress voiced its unanimous approval here today of a proposal that equal status with men be accorded to women in the nonministerial areas of church work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Less than 2 per cent of the $7,512,000,000 worth of Treasury certificates maturing this month and next were turned in for cash in the recent refunding move.
CAMP SPRINGS, Md., Aug. 13 (AP) -- A man picked up as a speeder was formally charged tonight with being one of the three gunmen who robbed the bank at Andrews Air Force Base of $124,638 this morning.

The Procter Gamble Company, the nation's largest producer of soap, glycerine and foodstuffs made from vegetable oils, attained a new high record in sales in the fiscal year ended June 30, although competition has never been keener, Richard R. Deupree, board chairman, and Neil H. McElroy, president, reported.
Yuri Alexandrovich Rastvorov, to whom asylum was granted yesterday, is the latest of a growing group of Russians to choose freedom in the West.

Two persons were killed and six were injured last night in a head-on automobile collision near the New Jersey entrance to the George Washington Bridge. The traffic tie-up halted thousands of cars on the bridge and along the Manhattan approaches, extending as far as the Bronx.

A $30,000,000 bond offering by the Southern California Edison Company and the sale of $158,964,000 of temporary loan notes by the Public Housing Administration will mark activity in an otherwise dull capital market next week.

Development of a forty-five-kilowatt ultra high frequency television transmitter capable of putting out 1,000,000 watts of effective radiated power was announced yesterday by the General Electric Company. The power rating is the highest permitted to ultra high frequency stations by the Federal Communications Commission.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13--Ava Gardner, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer box-office queen, has been taken off salary suspension and will go back to work this fall in "Bhowani Junction."

THURMONT, Md., Aug. 13--President Eisenhower and his Cabinet held their regular Friday morning business meeting at the President's Maryland mountain retreat near here today and spent the rest of the day relaxing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The number of persons claiming unemployment insurance dropped by 63,700 for the week ended July 31 to the second lowest level this year, the Labor Department said today.

Whatever the merits of the proposal to outlaw the Communist party, the precipitate action of the Senate Thursday in improvising a bill to this effect on the floor goes contrary to the spirit of orderly government.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Some 25,500 workers went on strike today against Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, bringing to 55,500 the total number affected by walk-outs at plants of the nation's four big rubber manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Jim Finigan stole home in the eighth inning to score the decisive run as the Philadelphia Athletics broke an eight-game losing streak tonight by edging Washington, 3 -- 2.

PUTNAM, Conn., Aug. 13 (AP) -- A swift-moving, three-state manhunt tonight rounded up five desperate, long-term convicts less than twenty-four hours after they fled, armed and with a guard hostage, from a Massachusetts prison.

CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press) -- A spokesman for the British Empire Oils Company, Ltd., said last night that its directors were "happy" that its books and records had been seized for investigation by the Alberta Attorney General's Department.
Matters have reached a state with the Yankees where Casey Stengel's bullpen, worn down by overwork less than a week ago, is beginning to complain of rustiness.
President Eisenhower's report that the nation's economy is sound was buttressed yesterday by a statement from a New York State official.

The announcement in Washington this week of a new plan designed to encourage homemakers to enter the teaching field points up the fact that in recent decades here has been a decline in the prejudice against the hiring of married women as teachers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Chief Justices of the forty-eight states approved unanimously today a proposed amendment to Federal law that would deprive lower Federal courts of power to nullify state court judgments in criminal cases.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A vast forest fire raged today over an area near Big Delta, Alaska (cross on map).
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Government of Yemen charged today that Britain had violated her 1934 treaty for the maintenance of peace and the status quo in the small kingdom.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Delegates representing 3,000,000 workers in organizations affiliated with the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions gave their approval today to the visit that the Labor party delegation, headed by Clement R. Attlee, is making to Communist China.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 14 points off to 7 points up, with easiness centered in the near-by positions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Following is the 48-to-41 roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected a motion to adopt the Senate-House conference report on the Atomic Energy Revision Bill:

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Robert Miller of Nassau and his 19-year-old daughter, Connie, won the sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's father - daughter championship over the Tamarack course today.
The incidence of polio is continuing at a comparatively low rate in the city, according to Dr. Morris Greenberg, director of the bureau of preventable diseases of the Health Department.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP)--Motor vehicle output this week was the lowest of any five-day period of the year, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France's program for a reform of the French economy was passed today on the final and second reading by the National Assembly. It will go to President Rene Coty for signature.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -Casper Glubiak of New York received a patent this week for a dashboard lock that shoots the key out onto the car floor if the motorist forgets it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, deposed President of Guatemala, will be tried on criminal charges if and when the ruling junta gains custody over him, Lieut. Col. Luis Cruz Salazar, new Guatemalan Ambassador, said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Young Tom Dublinski, an alumnus of Utah, piloted the Detroit Lions to victory tonight, 31 to 6, over the College All-Stars before 93,470 at Soldier Field in the first big game of the 1954 football season. The gross receipts were $445,650.
The City Administration said yesterday that it would continue to attack in the courts the reorganization plan for the Long Island Rail Road approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

It has been most interesting to study Arthur Krock's sympathetic analysis of Danish politics in The New York Times of July 29. His conclusions are fair and correct, but on a single point a misunderstanding has arisen.

Lyman T. Corbin Company, Inc., religious publications, has taken a long-term lease on about 40,000 square feet of space in the six-story building at 45 West Eighteenth Street. The structure was the old Ssgel-Cooper depart!merit store.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 13 -- The attitudes that Protestants in forty-eight countries should take toward war and communism are shaping up as the big battle grounds to be fought over by the World Council of Churches.

The Federal Maritime Board has served notice on all steamship companies to file with the board before next Friday any objections they might have to an application by the American President Lines to call at all Atlantic ports north of Cape Hatteras on its round-the-world service.

HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Capt. Bill Nickerson was born over in Cotuit just ten miles west of here 52 years ago. He cut his first teeth, as they say here, on a fishing boat hawser. But Captain Bill's mother didn't want him to be a fisherman. She sent him to dancing school. He was good. In his late teens he became a teacher of the light fantastic.

Summer travel in this shrunken world is hardly recognizable by former standards. Vacationists who used to spend their two weeks with pay at Cape Cod or on the Jersey shore now think nothing of flying to three or four European countries for quick samples of the Old World's pleasures.
Apartment houses and onefamily dwelngs figured in real estate deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Supreme Allied Headquarters has completed its three-year plan for a new approach to Western defense. The proposals have been sent to the Standing Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Washington.

HONG KONG, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- Announcing today the foreign policy report of Chou En-lai, Peiping Premier and Foreign Minister, the Communist New China News Agency said he had stressed "the five principles of mutual respect for territorial integrity and sovereignty -- nonaggression, noninterference in another country's internal affairs, equality, mutual benefit and peaceful coexistence.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Western Big Three diplomats held their second meeting here today to consider a reply to the Soviet proposal for new conferences on European problems.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- An East Anglian farmer has unearthed about 300 silver coins believed to be part of the hidden treasure of the Iceni, an ancient British tribe. The Iceni are noted for a heroic but disastrous revolt led by Queen Boadicea against the Romans.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug., 13 -Portugal handed a note to the Government in New Delhi today regretting that India did not see fit to reply with prompt and clear acceptance to a proposal Portugal made last Sunday. The proposal was that observers from six other countries be sent as soon as possible to see what was happening in and around the Portuguese territories on the Indian sub-continent.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 13 -Bavarian workers and employers both accepted today as a basis of discussion a Ministry of Labor proposal for a settlement of the five-day-old metal workers strike.

Sometimes we New Yorkers must feel awfully mean picking on our own home town the way we often do. But so many other cities are so far ahead of us in so many ways that I think we can be forgiven if we are a bit impatient with our City Fathers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A sinking liner by Wally Moon in the ninth inning -- which Birdie Tebbetts, Cincinnati manager claimed was caught -- gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 10-to-8 victory tonight over the Redlegs. Tebbetts was thrown out of the game when he protested that Gus Bell, center fielder, had snared the ball and retired the side.

The High School Teachers Association charged yesterday that the single salary schedule for teachers was causing high school teachers to suffer an "economic and professional injustice." Under the schedule, which was authorized by the State Legislature in 1947, teachers receive equal salary rates regardless of the grade level on which they teach.

CHAMONIX, France, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- Two exhausted, half-starved French soldiers were removed today from an icy ledge 11,000 feet up on Mont Blanc after a five-day ordeal in constant blizzards and sub-freezing weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Pittsburgh exploded for four runs in the seventh inning tonight to back Jake Thies' three-hitter for a 5-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. This gave the Pirates a sweep of a twilight night double-header for they had routed Robin Roberts, 9 -- 5, in the opener.
Leading brands of white bread, produced by the country's big commercial bakers, are likely to increase in price, following a trend already set by two concerns.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- A "Madonna and Child," purchased for $450 from a New York antique dealer last April, was described today as a priceless Leonardo da Vinci original.

PARIS, Saturday, Aug. 14 -- In spite of a split in his Cabinet early this morning, Premier Pierre Mendes - France pushed ahead with his plan to get the European army treaty ratified after modification.
During the languorous summer days and evenings mental gymnastics over board games are apt to appeal to both young and old

The former home of the Jackison family at 53 East Sixty-seventh Street, just west of Park Avenue, has been purchased by !the 26 W Corporation, headed by Jack Goldberg, which will convert it into a ten-family apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent to 110.2 over the week ended Aug. 10, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products and processed foods were responsible for the advance.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 13 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today India was opposed to solving the question of the Portuguese colonial enclaves by military decision.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Tennis players, who traditionally are so temperamental they are upset by a polite sneeze in the gallery, will need steel braces for their nerves here Sunday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Del Crandall smashed a three-run homer with one out in the ninth inning tonight, breaking up a tie ball game and giving the Milwaukee Braves a 5 to 2 triumph over the Chicago Cubs. It was the Braves' seventh straight victoy and their eighteenth in the last twenty games.

Police patrols in mid-Manhattan and the Bronx made a number of arrests last night and early today as the continuing round-up of undesirable persons was stepped up for the week-end. The raids in the Bronx, in which fifty-three persons were held, were an extension of the Manhattan drive.
The city has begun an exhaustive inventory of all space occupied by departments under the Mayor, including both city-owned buildings and rented space.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 13 -- The Vietnamese Chief of State, Bao Dai, who is planning to return soon from his prolonged sojourn in France, has assured Premier Ngo Dinh Diem that the latter will continue to have full powers to deal with the difficult political situation here.

Over this week-end Pakistan and India will be celebrating the seventh anniversary of their establishment as independent states. They have much of which to be proud; some things over which to be gravely concerned.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- C. V. Whitney's fine stable will go after a big stakes-race double at Saratoga's old horse park tomorrow. Fisherman will fly the Eton blue silks in the eighty-fifth Travers and Pyrenees and Brown Hackle will try to hit the jackpot in the fifty-second Saratoga Special.

Another threat of an East Coast shipyard strike was dissipated yesterday afternoon. A seven-hour "emergency" meeting of the C. I. O. shipbuilders union ended with instructions for its participants to "report back to the membership."

MAN'S quest for betterment goes on. The latest contribution to culture is contained in a fancy package from Victor. Ten 45 r. p. m. disks snuggle in that package, which is named The Listener's Digest and is subtitled "The Exciting New Short Cut to Great Music."
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 14 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority's purchase of machines, raw materials, services and installation equipment has amounted to $1,555,009,825 in the last twenty years.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 14 -- Ambassador Abba Eban is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow to report on his recent talks with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and other United States officials.

DARMSTADT, Germany, Aug. 15 -- A German jurist who hates sending young persons to jail has warned the title, the Chocolate Judge. But he has seen juvenile deliquency drop 40 per cent during his term on the bench.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Nine hundred members of Delta Sigma Theta, outstanding sorority of Negro women in the United States, will assemble on Monday at 3:30 P. M. in the Chamber of the Economic and Social Council, to hear Mrs. Oswald B. Lord and Herbert Agar discuss the activities of the world organization.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 14 -- A drive to obtain commonwealth status for Alaska is being directed from a headquarters here. The Committee for Commonwealth, made up of representatives of business, labor and the fishing industry in principal Alaska cities, is using advertisements, pamphlets and a word-ofmouth campaign.

During the first quarter of last year shoe production was at the rate of about 550,000,000 pairs a year. Since sales were in the neighborhood of 500,000,000 pairs for the year, subsequent production had to be curtailed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -Plans for a study of conditions in the domestic oil industry by a Presidential committee were disclosed today.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has recently acquired two portraits of outstanding American historical and artistic interest. By Gilbert Stuart (1755-1828), they represent John Adams, second President of the United States, from 1797 to 1801, and his wife, Abigail.

A MAJOR international airline, experienced in overseas operations but unfamiliar to most New Yorkers, has completed its first passenger flight between New York International Airport and Barajas Airport in Madrid and last Wednesday was certificated to begin regular service across the north Atlantic.

CULVER CITY, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP) -- One American record was broken and several of Southern California's crack swimmers were beaten by four Australian teenagers who dominated an Amateur Athletic Union-sanctioned swimming meet today.

HAVANA, Aug. 14 -- Gen. Fulgencia Batista turned over the Presidency of Cuba today to Andres Domingo Morales y del Castillo. Senor Morales y del Castillo, who was Secretary to the President, took the oath at 5:20 P. M. to be Interim President until after the Nov. 1 election.

JACKSON, Mont. -- The West's high - altitude valleys, with their unique climate and the special ranching and living patterns that have emerged, are tops among the still relatively undiscovered places for play and relaxation.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- The overall New England business picture reveals very little change from week to week. Industrial production is down from a year ago but the decline has made no further progress since early spring. Most executives hereabouts are fairly confident that the fall will bring a pick-up in orders and output.

McCarthy, irritated by the refusal of the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System to grant him free television time to reply to a speech by Adlai Stevenson, barred camera crews of both networks from his press conferences. THE medieval legend of the monk who had only his juggler's tricks to offer as homage to the Blessed Mother has been delightfully retold for children in an attractive book. It should be especially welcome in this Marian Year. The hero in Miss Todd's version is a wandering youth who is befriended by the kindly monks of Cluny.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- British participation in the coming Southeast Asian defense talks, which was announced here today, will involve a major challenge to British diplomacy to avoid a permanent split among the Asian Commonwealth countries.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Warner Willcox of Orienta, second after the first three races yesterday, took the lead today by winning the last race as the men's Long Island Sound sailing championship continued off the Noroton Yacht Club.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The text of Premier Pierre Mendes-France's proposals for revision of the European Defense Community treaty was handed today to officials of the other signatory states and was studied by experts on the treaty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The House of Representatives, where the session's business would have been completed long ago but for the Senate's sluggishness, is rapidly approaching the boiling point over the continued delay in adjournment. Members are fussing and fidgeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -United States military cargo planes are en route to flood stricken East Pakistan with tons of medical supplies.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 14 -- The National Defense Committee against Communism, recently created by the ruling Junta and charged with writing a history of the Red conspiracy in Guatemala, said today it had gone through more than 200,000 documents seized in Communist headquarters and Government and labor union offices and private residences since the regime of President Jacobo Guzman was ousted at the end of June.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 14 -- An increase in the work week and a slight upswing in employment were noticeable during June, the Minnesota State Employment Services reported. The increase of a half-hour in the work week brought the average up to 40.7 hours and resulted in an 84-cent increase in average wages to $74.22, the report said.

TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Garcia Valino, Spanish High Commissioner in Morocco, said today Spain was pushing her policy of giving Moroccans an increasing share in the administration of Spanish Morocco.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- This was prize day for the Berkshire Music Center. Although there are no credits, degrees or examinations at the end of the six-week course at Tanglewood, a number of awards are available for outstanding students.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 8 -- Eighty scholars will soon begin writing a history of the Jewish people. The plans for this project, which will take five to ten years, were disclosed here today by Dr. Abraham A. Neuman, president of Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning in Philadelphia.

LIKE Persia, Arabia dazzles. The sunburned sands, the strangeness of the sacred cities, the endless guerrilla feuds, the tribesmen wandering carefree over a land still virgin -- these were things that stirred the blood, and still do, though the Arabia we dream about will soon belong to the past.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14 -Fifth Federal Reserve District building permits in July took the heaviest dip in recent years, with the result that the total for the first eight months of 1954, $196,563,000, is down more than 20 per cent from the $246,365,000 reported for the same 1953 months.

SOMETIMES a perennial is such a success in the flower border that gardeners want to set out more plants in the fall or even start a collection of its varieties. Such may be the case with phlox, for few perennials are so trustworthy and rewarding for the minimum of care they require.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., Aug. 14 -- It's ten miles as the gulls fly to Monomoy Point, the tip of the hook of sand that swings out from Chatham on Cape Cod and curls southward. From the lightship there you can see Nantucket on a clear day, and this was a Saturday made to order for fishermen, some white cumulus clouds, rippling waters.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 15 -- A lavish demonstration by about 1,000 South Koreans was held this morning at the Capitol grounds here to commemorate the sixth anniversary of the founding of the Republic of Korea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -President Eisenhower today expressed a hope for international unity in facing "new perils" that threaten the free world.

WHEN, on March 4, 1901, Theodore Roosevelt was sworn in as Vice President of the United States, his son, Quentin, decided he would not go "to hear father pray at the Senate." Instead the boy went off to the White House to await the arrival of those who did attend the ceremonies.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The negotiations between the French and Tunisian Governments on the conditions under which Tunisia will receive internal autonomy will be prepared next week, according to an announcement today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 14 -- The total assessed valuation in Nassau County is $2,105,287,521, a rise of 8.86 per cent. according to the annual report issued this week by Emil M. Podeyn, chairman of the Board of Assessors.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 -- Many children might be better off if their parents did not get so much expert advice on upbringing, two child-care specialists indicated today.

BLACKBERRY lilies are highly ornamental plants, with flower, foliage and seedpod of more than usual interest. Yet they appear to be more at home in the wild than in cultivated flower gardens. I knew this immigrant from China as a wild flower fifty years ago in the Ozarks of Missouri, but not until more recent years have I seen it under cultivation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Hooked up through the stretch in the Saratoga Special today were two of the best 2-year-olds in the land, ridden by a pair of the nation's top jockeys, and their duel was as exciting a bit of business as any racing aficionado could ask.
BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- A machine for counting blood cells automatically -- developed in spare time by the assistant director -is going through its paces at the Boston Blood Grouping Laboratory.

NOVA GOA, Portuguese India, Aug. 14-- Portuguese troops received blessings from Roman Catholic priests today before the tomb of St. Francis Xavier and then marched off to guard this colonial territory against "liberation" invasion from India.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 -- Hal Naragon broke an eleventh inning tie today with a single that gave the Cleveland Indians a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The triumph enabled the Tribe to maintain two and a half game lead ever the runner-up New York Yankees.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner tried his unpracticed hand at tournament tennis this morning in a valiantly fought match that led off the New Jersey all-amateur men's singles championships. He lost, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6.

TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- A quasi-judicial hearing into charges against two former associates of the late Gov. Harold G. Hoffman will open here Monday. Both men, top officials of the state Division of Employment Security, were suspended in June by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Aug. 14 (UP) -- A couple of 5-year-old mares, Foxy Adeline and Veribest, combined for the nation's largest daily double pay-off of the year -- $3,426.60 -- at Narragansett Park today.

SOUTH BOUND BROOK, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Twelve hundred members of the Ukrainian American Youth Association, many in brightly colored native garb for song and dance competitions, gathered here today for their third annual rally. Many of them are newcomers to the United States.

THE march of the milkweeds across the countryside is now well under way. SAINT JOHN, N. B., Aug. 14 (UP) -- A chimney sweep was plucked by a helicopter from a perch atop a 150-foot smoke stack today after he had been stranded there for six and onehalf hours.

McCarthy, there has been repeated reference to the last previous instance of such an action in the Senate chamber. GLASGOW, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- The Scottish soccer season opened today with sixteen league cup games. The Glasgow Rangers' 5-0 victory over Stirling Albion marked the program.

SHELTER ISLAND -- Civilization, embodied by tired New Yorkers craving tranquility, is storming the beaches of this green isle caught in the pincers of the easterly end of Long Island. RAMSEY, N. J., Aug. 14 (AP) -The state police arrested early today three college sophomores who live in Fair Lawn and charged them with setting off five powerful home-made bombs in Bergen County during the night.

ONE of the more controversial productions on Broadway last season, it may be recalled, was the late Andre Gide's "The Immoralist," which had stanch supporters and bitter opponents during its run of ninety-six performances at the Royale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- With his 7-year-old son clutching his hand through most of the eighteen holes, bespectacled Earl Stewart Jr. scored an amazing 65 today on Tam O'Shanter's rain-soaked course to take the fifty-four-hole lead from Bob Toski in the rush for the "world" golf title and its first prize worth $100,000.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP) -Scientists around the world are getting ready for one of the great research undertakings of all time -- a long year of simultaneous, global observation of this planet.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 14 -Dr. Hugo Eckener, the German dirigible pioneer, died in Friedrichshafen on Lake Constance today of a heart ailment. He was 86 years old.

CHILDREN, in spite of first impressions, are not garden pests. At worst they are something like earthworms: a bit bothersome and perhaps messy, but potentially useful. At best they can actually add to the pleasure of home gardening.

A $510,000 act of faith in the future of radio and the commercial appeal of Shakespeare and Dickens in that medium was offered last week by Gordon Gray, general manager of WOR. It was based on experience during the last year, when classical programs proved at least as popular as those offering Hollywood stars.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. -- The first thing the fresh-caught visitor to Mackinac Island notices, when he steps ashore from the ferry that has brought him from Mackinaw City or St. Ignace on the Michigan mainland, is the quiet.

THIS volume contains the four plays by Edmund Wilson which have been published before and a new one, "Cyprian's Prayer," now printed for the first time. All but "Cyprian's Prayer" are pictures of metropolitan highbrow circles at various troubled moments during the last thirty years of our history.

Everyone's favorite ball player, as someone put it, was at Yankee Stadium's Hall of Fame day yesterday -- and many of the diamond immortals who participated in the colorful program demonstrated to a delighted throng that time had not altogether dulled their talents.

Columbia University will commemorate the bicentennial of its establishment with a conference at which representatives of the American republics will discuss "the obstacles to freedom" in this hemisphere.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 14 -- Searing drought and heat continued to cut into Southwestern farm and ranch income prospects last week. Observers estimated that as much as a fourth of the cotton crop over the state already had suffered severe damage; much worse loss will occur unless good rains fall within the next few days.

I cannot agree with two main points of H. R. Trevor-Roper's splendid article, "World War I -- Start of an Age of Violence," of August 1 [in which Mr. Trevor-Roper traced the developments leading up to the conflict and concluded that the "men of 1914 'floundered into war,'" that the Germans, as the aggressors, "were driven not by ambition but by fear." -- Editor].

DEMOCRACY and freedom are not what they were when the Constitution was adopted. Legislation that would have seemed strange to Franklin and Jefferson has curtailed our liberties and molded our way of life.

The work-starved ship repair yards of this port are anxiously awaiting contracts under a bill authorizing $25,000,000 in repair, modernization and conversion work on military-type vessels now in Government reserve fleets.

MARSHAL TITO'S car, according to one variation of a story that is being told in Yugoslavia, was passing through a village when the driver found the road blocked by a flock of sheep. Honking his horn furiously, the driver signaled a left turn.

If you notice someone lurking near the return counter at Gimbels, or darkly watching customers as they leave Macy's New York, chances are it's a student of the New York University School of Retailing.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Four United Nations experts discovered a highly efficient cooperative organized among tribesmen in Burma to trap and train wild elephants.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 14 -Civic groups here are urging city officials to study the possibility of closing Ocean City's beaches to all but resort taxpayers and long-term visitors. Similar proposals are reported to be under discussion at neighboring Longport, Margate and Ventnor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Johnny Schmitz notched his seventh victory of the year -- equalling his total for the 1951-52-53 seasons -- when he limited the Philadelphia Athletics to seven hits today in pitching the Washington Senators to a 4-1 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Most officials in Government react sooner or later to the wear and tear of public life in Washington, but not all do it the same way. The late Ogden L. Mills once said he found that life here kept him in a state of "healthy irritation."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- India celebrated today seven years of freedom.
The privately owned American flag merchant fleet was five ships smaller at the end of July than it was a month earlier, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15 -- In the fading light of a wet, dismal day, after four hours of exhausting play, Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., won the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today. In an unforgettable final of eighty-three games, he defeated Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7, 12 -- 14, 6 -- 8, 10 -- 8.

The cruise ship Silverstar will be the first vessel to start a trans-Atlantic voyage from the nation's capital, Ronald A. Barnes, vice president of the Arnold Bernstein Shipping Company, Inc., agents for the ship, said yesterday. Mr. Barnes said the Silverstar would start a "one-shot" voyage from Washington to Bremerhaven, Germany, on Sept. 19.

FEZ, French Morocco, Aug. 15 -- French troops marched into this ancient capital of Morocco today to reassert French authority where forty-two years ago the soldiers of Marshal Hubert Lyautey marched in to establish it.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- There's an old racing expression: "Chicken today, feathers tomorrow." This Saratoga race meeting is a chicken-pot-pie session for Sylvester Veitch. But he knows all about the feathery part of the expression. Once upon a yesteryear he was so unsuccessful as a horse-trainer that he gave his horses away and quit the business.

Formation of the Western Pipe Line Company to build and operate a new common carrier crude oil pipeline from the Rocky Mountain area to the Midwest was announced yesterday by J. L. Burke, president of the Service Pipe Line Company.

FORT RILEY, Kan., Aug. 15 -- Maj. Gen. P. D. Ginder, commanding the Tenth Infantry Division, also took command of Fort Riley and the Army General School today. He succeeds Maj. Gen. Thomas L. Harrold, who has taken command of the Eighth Infantry Division and Camp Carson, Colo.
For little girls imbued with the "me too" spirit, we offer big and little sister dresses.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug, 15 (Reuters) -- Pope Pius XII recited the Angelus -- the thrice-daily devotion to the Virgin Mary -- before television cameras and microphones today.

A syndicate of investors represented by Jerome Dansker, president of the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, bought two four-story apartment houses on plot 110 by 100 feet at 29 and 35 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, from Caton Realty Inc.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 14 -- 12, today despite three consecutive home runs in the ninth inning by Gus Bell, Ted Kluszewski and Jim Greengrass. All three landed in the right-field bleachers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Eisenhower Administration still is confronted with the problem of getting a working "partnership" of the Federal and state Governments.
Retail sales of television receivers in the first half of this year were at a new high, according to the Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturers Association of Washington.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 3 -- The great preparations for Indonesia's first general election in history are reported to be making considerable progress in many areas.

In 1952 a record-breaking epidemic struck down over 57,000 victims, almost twice as many as the average over the previous five years. Last year the number of those laid low was still far above the average and this year there is apparently little, if any, improvement.

Regardless of the current persuasive arguments extolling the social dividends stemming from debt -- especially debt of the public variety -- the fact remains that the people do not trust it. Whereever they have control over it, they aspire to keep it down.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 15 -- Church leaders from every section of the earth joined in solemn worship today to open the second General Assembly of the World Council of Churches. Richly hued vestments of Eastern Orthodox prelates mingled with the ruffed collars of Scandinavian clerics and the business suits of American preachers, as the representatives of 168,000,000 Protestant and Orthodox churchgoers joined in singing, "In Christ There Is No East or West."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A growing list of investigations and surveys faces the Federal Tariff Commission for the fall and winter.
We can vote in this country. This is doubtless the principal source of our liberty. There is freedom of speech for citizens willing to take the consequences.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- The Secretary of the Navy, Charles S. Thomas, today described as "alarming" the lack of merchant ship construction in this country and failure to develop new ship types.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- The march today by Nationalists seeking an end to Portugal's 400-year hold on territories in India appeared to have dwindled to a trickle of demonstrators, most of them teen-agers.

Declaring that "the death sentence" of the United States has been pronounced in Moscow, the Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly yesterday reminded Americans and "other free men" that "we cannot live in peace with atheistic communism."
Leland Merrick, a Bronx publisher, has come up with an idea for bolstering the liberal point of view in this country and promoting the philosophy of democracy abroad.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The Disabled American Veterans open their thirty-third national convention here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Trade in lard futures last week was without special feature, except that the September was strong compared with the deferred deliveries. Hedge pressure was not specially heavy, although receipts of swine have been running larger than a year ago at this time.
PEIPING, Aug. 15 -- Clement R. Attlee and his British Labor party delegation were guests today at a feast given by Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier.

DUBLIN, Aug. 12 -- Americans visiting Ireland are impressed with the freshness and flavor of its foods. Because the country is so compact, it is possible to eat salmon and trout from the rivers and sole, brill (a European flat fish) and turbot from the sea within a few hours of their being caught.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Commentators in the last week have confessed that they are running out of adjectives in attempting to describe the current course of the stock markets. Going from strength to strength, new records are being set up almost daily.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A home run by Larry Doby in the opener and a four-bagger by Bob Avila in the second game today sparked Cleveland's league-leading Indians to 5-2 and 3-1 victories over the Baltimore Orioles for a four-game series sweep. The Tribe's sixth straight triumph put the Indians three games ahead of the New York Yankees.

Cotton futures prices moved erratically last week and were mostly on the downside at the close of the New York Cotton Exchange. The market started strong, but slumped sharply after the Department of Agriculture announced Monday afternoon its estimate of the 1954 crop. The forecast of 12,680,000 bales is about 400,000 bales higher than private agencies had predicted.

Five floors in the proposed office building at 20 Broad Street, adjoining the New York Stock Exchange on the south, has been leased by The Hanover Bank. The space contains 85,000 square feet and was taken in connection with expansion plans of the bank.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Hoover Commission named a task force today to study whether the Government has too much real estate, is paying too much for property and is using efficiently what it has.

Long before it became a canyon through what Christopher Morley once called the "downtown Dolomites," topography and custom designated lower Broadway's first mile as the route over which the city must sooner or later escort every visitor of fame and renown.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The International Harvester Company and the Diamond T Motor Car Company announced today an agreement whereby Diamond T will assemble some special models of motor trucks for International Harvester, and Harvester will manufacture for Diamond T certain components of Diamond T motor truck models.
The Communist party today called for public hearings before the House of Representatives voted on a Senate bill that would outlaw the party in this country.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 -- A junior edition of the Fageol family of speed-boat devil-may-care drivers today won the national championship of the fast-growing 7-liter class. This was 23-year-old Raymond Fageol of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, in his saffron-colored craft So Long, designed and built by Ed Jones and Rick Keller. The craft has one of the family's Fageol engines, built in their Kent, Ohio, factory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Purchases of grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade last week increased 22,000,000 bushels over the preceding week, but were much smaller than a year ago. Average daily purchases were about 56,000,000 bushels as compared with 52,000,000 bushels the preceding week and 70,000,000 bushels a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Philadelphia Phillies were deadlocked at 6 -- 6 after eight innings of a curfew-suspended nightcap today after the Bucs won the opener, 9 -- 6, with a 16-hit barrage.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Herbert V. Evatt, leader of Australia's Labor opposition, appeared before the espionage commission here today on behalf of two of his staff members who were named in documents before the commission.
Experiments to reduce appeal costs will be started Sept. 1 in the eastern upstate area by the Appellate Division, Third Department, of the Supreme Court.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 15 -- The market value of ordinary stock of I. G. Chemie (Interhandel), Swiss chemical concern, dropped 13 per cent here between last Monday and Thursday. During the same period, in Frankfurt, the common stock of Scherling A. G., German pharmaceutical company, fell almost 10 per cent.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Passenger service along Boston's inland waterfront was resumed last week with the return of the swanboats to the Public Garden lagoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., reported today that since he took office in January, 1953, foreclosure proceedings had been started, or ordered, on housing project mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration to the total of $32,089,476.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic nominee for the Senate from New Jersey, said today he agreed with a statement by the American Federation of Labor's executive council that the Republican Administration had stood by idly while the economy "drifts into the doldrums."

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Many houses that are not counted among the stellar members of the couture, contribute to the harvest of fashion inspiration in Paris. There is, for example, Hermes, outstanding for its classic woolen costumes and above all its beautiful leathers.
The latest communiques from the laundry experts to the homemaker include advice on washing permanently pleated skirts and a description of a new "controlled-suds soak" method.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Carlos Chavez, Mexican conductor and composer, has been denied admittance to the United States until his "security clearance" has been studied, a United States Embassy spokesman said here today.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- An airline hostess was saluted as a heroine today after a plane with thirty-seven persons aboard had crashed and burned at Blackbushe Airport, near here.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- Amendments to the European Defense Community treaty proposed by Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, have been transmitted to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, who is vacationing in the Black Forest near Baden-Baden.

DEAL, England, Monday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Coast Guardsmen on both sides of the English Channel kept up their watch today for the 300-ton Soviet Navy training schooner Alfa, reported missing by the Soviet Embassy at Stockholm.

Mrs. Walter Hecht has turned a hobby into a job. Long interested in different varieties of trees, she opened the Tree House on Route 22 and Hardscrable Road in Croton Falls, N. Y., to sell trees for interiors.

An airways-development survey being conducted in five Middle Eastern countries by a team of American experts is a wise and skillful move in "our efforts to bolster foreign economies," according to Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 -- From reports of the status of steel mill order books it now begins to look as though the strong spurt expected in September may be a little late in developing. Some pick-up is now anticipated in the latter part of the month, though at the moment there are signs of spottiness in the September books.

There was a mixed trend in the principal foreign exchanges last week. British sterling developed a slightly easier tendency, the Canadian dollar continued strong while the German sperrmark slipped to its lowest in several months. Other exchanges were firm on light trading.

Two important moves aimed at strengthening the defense of the United States against aerial attack have been announced recently. The creation of the unified Continental Air Defense Command under Gen. Benjamin W. Chidlaw is an administrative change which, it is to be hoped, will provide the coordination that is the key of any effective defense against bomber attack.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 15 (UP) -- East German shipyards on the Baltic are turning out submarines for the Soviet fleet, which is estimated to have 500 in service or under construction, Western officials reported today.
CAIRO, Aug. 15 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser returned here tonight from a pilgrimage to Mecca.
RAMSEY, N. J., Aug. 15 (AP) Two more towns filed charges today against the three Fair Lawn students accused of setting off five powerful home-made bombs in Bergen County Friday night.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France spent today in the country preparing the case for the revision of the European Defense Community treaty that he expects to present to the five other signatory states.
The American Airlines is scheduled to lay off 1,891 non-striking employes today as a result of the walkout of its 1,243 pilots.
The need for teaching the mechanics of elections was brought to the attention of your readers by a letter you printed on Aug. 8 from David Friedman.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 16 -- President Syngman Rhee told his people publicly yesterday for the first time that South Korea was not planning to renew the war in the near future.

NEWARK, Aug. 15 -- Mayor Leo P. Carlin said today he would nominate George W. Andress, deputy chief engineer, to the key post of Director of Public Works. Mr. Andress also will get the title of chief engineer, succeeding John S. Flockhart, named earlier this month as municipal business administrator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy demanded today that Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, return from his vacation in Europe to repeat under oath censure charges made by him on the Senate floor.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 15 -- Although tied with Arturito Pomar of Madrid, who shared the first two cash prizes with him, Larry Evans of New York was officially declared the winner of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation early today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A New Jersey minister said here today that baseball and movie persons, whom he blamed in part for the breakdown of Sunday observance in Philadelphia, were now in financial difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Some State Department officials predicted today that the United States, reluctantly and in a spirit of great disappointment, would support the proposals of France's Premier for revision of the European Defense Community treaty.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- A demand that Communist spies and sympathizers be ousted from the United Nations staff was made here today by the National Association of Women Lawyers.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- Rice has been turning bitter for Italian producers. A few years ago they were exporting much of their crop to the Far East. Now they are pinched by the return of Far Eastern rice to the European markets.
The American Safety Razor Corporation and a union representing its workers reached an agreement last night under which the company will continue operations in Brooklyn until next May 27.

Prayers for the success of the World Council of Churches, which opened its second assembly yesterday in Evanston, Ill., were offered yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince of the faculty of King's College, Halifax, N. S.

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Kenneth White and Pat Brady of the Penrose (N. C.) Club captured the honors in the twentieth Arthur Man member-guest invitation golf tournament today. They defeated Joseph Murphy and Jack Sabine of Rockville, 5 and 4 at the Seawane Harbor club.
FREJUS, France, Aug. 15 -- United States, French and British military units observed today the tenth anniversary of the Allied landings on the southern coast of France in a series of ceremonies.

TORONTO, Aug. 15 -- Attempting to free mankind from all of life's tensions offers serious dangers to the future of civilization, an international meeting of specialists in mental health was told tonight.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The prime subject of this summer's Berkshire Festival has been Berlioz. For the climax and conclusion of the six-week event at Tanglewood this afternoon, Charles Munch conducted the French composer's Requiem.
The National League pennant parade moves relentlessly on. Only the Giants are making no headway.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The proposals by Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, for modifications in the European Defense Community are viewed with considerable misgiving here.
ROME, Aug. 15 -- Most self-respecting Italian city dwellers who can afford vacations would almost as soon die as be seen inside the urban limits on Aug. 15.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 15 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan has failed to rouse South Africa with his "black menace" cry for the first time since he came to power in the 1948 election campaign.

THE green - painted swath that has snaked under Forty-second Street to guide shuttled pilgrims between the East and West Side subways the last thirty-six years will be painted over this morning and fade forever from questing eyes.

The Goldman Band ended its thirty-seventh season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts last night at the Central Park Mall. It was a perfect evening, with a full moon hanging over the bandstand, and with more people to hear the music than there were seats.

The walkout of 1,243 pilots of American Airlines is well into its third week and the financial losses are rapidly mounting. While other air transport companies have scheduled additional flights and are taking up some of the slack left in the nation's vital communications system, nevertheless thousands of innocent bystanders are being inconvenienced and hurt.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Iranian Majlis (lower house of Parliament) must accept or reject Iran's ten-day-old oil settlement with eight Western oil companies without amending its terms, a spokesman for the Western concerns said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Harry Sylk, head of a syndicate striving to keep the financially floundering Philadelphia Athletics here, today revealed terms of the offer his organization had made for the club last Tuesday.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis opened last night an emergency sixteen-day March of Dimes campaign for $20,000,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UP) -- More than 5,000 lawyers, judges and legal educators gathered today for the seventy-seventh annual convention of the American Bar Association. Discussions will deal with wiretapping, juvenile delinquency and Congressional investigations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Propelled by two scoring sprees of 94 and 80 yards by Halfback Hugh McElhenny, the San Francisco Forty Niners rallied four times to beat the New York Giants, 43 -- 35, in an exhibition game before 29,296 fans today.
In line with its purpose of aiding young men of high scholastic and leadership qualities, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday a broadening of its national scholarship program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The biggest golf prize in history -- $50,000 cash and a $50,000 exhibition contract -- today was captured by the smallest pro in the game, 127-pound Bob Toski, whose seventy-two-hole total of 274 gave him a one-stroke victory in the "world" tournament.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 15 -- Autograph fans mingled with photographers and religious dignitaries outside the First Methodist Church after the service opening the great assembly of the World Council of Churches today.
BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, Aug. 15 (AP) -- President Getulio Vargas of Brazil says the new $16,800,000 German-Brazilian steel mill here is "a new milestone in the progress of the steel industry."

MANILA, Monday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Under heavy guard, the Communist Huk leader, Luis Taruc, was arraigned today in the Manilla Court of First Instance on charges of rebellion, robbery, arson and kidnapping.

" American Demagogues: The Twentieth Century," a study by Reinhard Luthin of some representatives of the "I-am-the-Law" school of American government, will be published Oct. 4 by Beacon Press. Among those selected as aspirants for boss control are Huey Long, "Alfalfa Bill" Murray, "Pa" and "Ma" Ferguson, "Big Bill" Thompson, Frank Hague, Vito Marcantonio and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
KINGSTON, Ont., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Policemen and soldiers quelled a riot by 750 prisoners in Kingston Penitentiary today while firemen battled a fire in the penitentiary's trade shop.

The ship charter market moved into another period of shipowner ascendancy last week. Some rates improved slightly. Charterers were said to be yielding to the demands of the owners in several segments of the market.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Production activity at Hollywood studios no longer can be regarded as an accurate barometer of the movie industry's financial well-being. Although the nine principal producing companies are about 21 per cent behind last year in the production of new films, the industry is more optimistic about its future now than it was at this time a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, said today he would introduce a bill tomorrow calling for the dismissal of any Federal employe who sought refuge in the Fifth Amendment.

The American Labor party announced yesterday the publication of a thirty-two-page pamphlet entitled "A Program for Jobs in New York State," which is to be mailed to labor, legislative and community leaders.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- French industrial production has been steadily increasing since the beginning of the year and the index for living costs is stable or slightly lower, but foreign trade continues to show a troublesome monthly deficit.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Three unusual hooked rugs, showing familiar Long Island scenes, will be featured at the August Hooked Rug Exhibition that will open at the Southampton Historical Museum on Wednesday.

CHICAGO Aug 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers swept a doubleheader from the Chicago White Sox today, taking the opener, 2 -- 1, behind Steve Gromek's four-hit pitching, and routing Virgil Trucks to win the second game, 8 to 7.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The general trend of grain prices was irregularly upward last week, with wheat leading the advance.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Gene Conley limited the Chicago Cubs to seven hits today for the Milwaukee Braves' ninth straight victory, 2 -- 1, and their twentieth triumph in twenty-two games.

JUDGING from the increasing number of television weather girls, a new career has opened for young women aspiring to be weather forecasters. Local channels have at least five weather girls, who appear on weekdays to satisfy everybody's curiosity about the weather at a given moment and to speculate on what it will be the next day.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Three thousand Swiss watchmakers, pained by new United States import restrictions on their wares, opened a Don't-Buy-American week in retaliation today.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 15 -- The "Quit Goa" movement against Portugal took a moderate form today when forty-nine Goan volunteers crossed into the enclave peacefully from three points on the Indian border, demanding merger of the Portuguese territory with India.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Sacramento Valley farmers hope to see the start this fall of a series of canals that will make possible the irrigation of additional tracts of rich California agricultural lands totaling 205,000 acres.
