In their first change of ownership in more than fifty years, four five-story apartment buildings on the East Side have been purchased for investment by James McElroy from the Jaloel Corporation. The sale was for all cash and was negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., broker.

Yonkers Raceway will reopen tonight for a two-week summer meeting. The feature event on the eight-race card is the Yonkers Derby, a one-mile pace for 3-year-olds for a purse of $23,400. Post time for the first race is 8:40 P. M.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Ford Konno of Hawaii, upset in Saturday's 1,500-meter race, came back last night to win the 400-meter free style in the Japanese national swimming championships.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Harold R. Medina, Federal District Judge of New York, who presided at the nine-month trial that ended in the conviction of eleven Communist leaders five years ago, announced tonight in Chicago that he was not a candidate for Governor of New York.

The day the B-25 smashed into the Empire State tower, in July of 1945, just as World War II was drawing to a close -- that was a day! The reporters and the photographers, the country's best, surged around the colonel, flown hurriedly to the scene, as he entered the building.
The city may safely undertake in 1955 a capital construction program of $340,000,000 within its constitutional debt limit. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The legislative record of the Administration, on which President Eisenhower is placing the main reliance for a victory in the Congressional elections in November, should be complete at the end of this week.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Representative Charles J. Kersten, chairman of a special House committee on Communist aggression, said today the group would make a full investigation of Soviet intervention of Western Hemisphere countries, notably Latin America.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- The Foreign Ministry has abandoned its smart gray uniforms in favor of ordinary business suits. The same trend seems current throughout top Soviet officialdom.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Bill Cox of the host Noroton Yacht Club won the men's Long Island Sound sailing championship today, but not before a drifting match produced the most suspenseful finale in the three-year history of the event.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Union chiefs empowered to call a general strike to back contract demands resume long-stalled negotiations with Canada's major railways here tomorrow at the urging of the Federal Government.
A large concern has done something big about the vexing problems of coupons and their redemption.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 15 -- Robert Moses, as president of the Long Island State Park Commission, has returned to the verbal fray in which he has been engaged with James L. Dowsey, Manhasset lawyer, on the issue of the proposed rezoning of property in Oyster Bay Township.
The role of armor in modern war has received renewed emphasis since Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway assumed office as Army Chief of Staff.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Two New York men who were still at large were charged in a complaint filed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today with taking part in the $124,638 robbery Friday of a branch bank at Andrews Air Force Base.

Under the leadership of her dynamic Premier, France is at last approaching a rendezvous with history the results of which will go far in determining the future shape of Europe, the strength of Western defense against Communist imperialism, and the outcome of the whole "cold war."
The General Public Utilities Corporation and its subsidiaries increased their net income to $22,212,287 in the twelve months ended on June 30, from $19,381,090 in the preceding twelve months.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -- With the breeze practically nonexistent, nine of fifteen classes failed to produce finishes in the Rocky Point Sailing Club's program on Long Island Sound which was concluded tonight.

The man who has advised every President since Woodrow Wilson will round out eighty-four years on Thursday. For that day, Bernard M. Baruch has no plans except to take a dive into his swimming pool, as he does every day on the Oyster Bay estate where he is summering.

The secret of the success of a Christian congress lies in its spirit of hospitality, and not in the numbers attending it, the Right Rev. Edmund R. Morgan, Lord Bishop of Truro, England, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
The police stumbled across a stock of thirty pounds of marijuana, some of it recently picked, in the furnished room of a 19-year-old Bronx girl last night.
The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries show a decline of $3,804,306 in first-half-year earnings.

" Proffie of America: An Autobiography of the L S. A.," edited by Emily Davie, presents the exact words of the people who have made American history. Excerpts have been taken from the writings of Christopher Columbus through to the present at' cover every important field of endeavor, giving the background of America, her ideals, struggles, achievements and thoughts for the future.
A probationary patrolman was suspended without pay late yesterday on a charge of attempted extortion of $50 after arresting a man. The patrolman was held for arraigment in Felony Court.
Examinations will be held next Monday for young men who wish to qualify as cadet-midshipmen in the Merchant Marine Cadet Corps, Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator, announced yesterday.

HONG KONG, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- The texts of statements made by Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, and Clement R. Attlee, British Labor party leader, at a dinner given by Mr. Chou today in Peiping, were reported by the Peiping radio as follows :

MOUNTAINHOME, Pa., Tuesday, Aug. 17 -- Gloria Vanderbilt, wife of Leopold Stokowski, made her professional stage debut last night at the Pocono Playhouse here. It was a debut made to the flashing accompaniment of television and newsreel lights and the continual popping of press camera flashbulbs during intermissions.

TWENTY-FIVE teams have qualified for the twelfth annual United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament off Narragansett, R. I., Aug. 31 through Sept. 2. Fifteen of the teams will use four boats apiece, ten teams will have two boats each in the competition.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- A charge of dynamite blasted an estimated 1,700 tons of rock into the Niagara River gorge this afternoon to start a $20,000,000 emergency fund-raising drive by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Senate approved today citations for contempt of Congress against three individuals who challenged Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's legal right and authority to inquire into their personal beliefs and associations.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Aug. 16 -- Four of five young New Yorkers arrested by state troopers at Ideal Beach, East Keansburg, yesterday after they had threatened to beat two policemen here, received thirty-day jail sentences today.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 (AP) -- East and West welfare officials agreed today to distribute President Eisenhower's food aid to flood victims in Central Europe to all needing it, regardless of race, creed or political conviction. They decided all such help going behind the Iron Curtain should be plainly marked with the Red Cross.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An inter-party dispute over a proposed change in Israel's election laws raised a serious threat today to Prime Minister Moshe Sharett's coalition Government.

The cease-fire is now in effect throughout all of Indochina. The early, and somewhat fragmentary, reports that have come in thus far indicate somewhat less disorder and violence than had been feared. It is earnestly to be hoped that the optimism that has been expressed will be justified.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug 16 -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, flying silk for the first time since May, made a runaway of the betless race that was run seventh on Saratoga's nine-event program today.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- The Allied High Commission has taken steps to head off the movement to recartelize German industry in a test case submitted by the West German Government.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Chinese threat to Formosa, together with the danger of a strike on the British railways, checked the rise in the stock market today. Prices opened firm, but profit taking cut into the gains.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The first complete revision of the national tax code in modern history became law today.

As were many other residents of New York City, I was terrified by the statistics on crime released by Police Commissioner Adams. There is no one in the city who will take issue with him as to the ultimate need of increasing our police power and making it more effective.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Wheat futures turned weak today after a slight upturn, but there was commission accumulation and some local buying on the setbacks. On the other hand corn firmed after a fractional decline early in the day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, the middleweight champion, punched himself out of sparring partners at his Nice, Calif., training camp today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The State Department reversed itself today to permit Carlos Chavez, Mexican composer and conductor, to come to the United States to conduct orchestras in Los Angeles and Portland, Ore.

TRENTON, Aug. 16 -- The state charged today that a $2,500 "slush fund" for the personal use of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman had been set up in 1949 through collusion between a Newark concern and two former top officials of the State Division of Employment Security.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will fly to New York tomorrow to register as voters for the November election.

The stock market extended its gains yesterday in slightly increased tradings. The oils and some specialties stood out, with advances up to 5 points. Final quotations were generally firm and only slightly below the highest for the session.

Frankie Ryff, unbeaten Bronx lightweight, extended his victory skein to thirteen last night by gaining the unanimous decision over Dennis Pat Brady, a Bronx rival, in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Service today announced a number of tax-claim settlements, including one against E. Haldeman-Julius, late publisher of "Little Blue Books."

At a time when the United States is trying to build up a defense system for Southeast Asia one of our present allies in the Far East is running into serious trouble which, unless cured, could blow up into a real crisis next year. This ally is Japan, and the trouble is a rapidly deteriorating economic situation which might impair Japan's position a an anti-Communist bastion.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city's drive against slums would be intensified immediately in Brooklyn, where a backlog of violations in 17,000 buildings has accumulated.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A confession authenticated today the Federal Bureau of Investigation's solution of the $190,000 Floral Park, L. I., bank robbery on Aug. 18, 1953.

No longer will riders of the I. R. T. Lexington Avenue line have to strain their eyes in the feeble light of thirty-six-watt bulbs on the platforms of the subway's Grand Central station. A switch was thrown at noon yesterday to turn on 2,200 feet of fluorescent lighting that now bathes the area in brightness.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 16 -- Canon Theodore O. Wedel of the Washington Cathedral (Protestant Episcopal), Washington, addressed the first evening plenary session of the second general assembly of the World Council of Churches here today.
Imaginative French design and American talent for adaptation were united in the fur collection shown yesterday at Jay Thorpe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The House of Representatives today voted, 305 to 2, to outlaw the Communist party in the United States. Last Thursday the Senate had voted 85 to 0 to do the same thing.

The Certain-teed Products Corporation has entered into a purchase agreement with the owners of about 70 per cent of the outstanding capital stock of Wm. Cameron Co. of Waco, Tex. Certain-teed will pay $11.50 in cash and one-half share of Certain-teed common for each share of Cameron.

When President Eisenhower yesterday signed the tax revision bill passed by Congress, a historic step in this country's fiscal policy was taken. This is the first complete revision of the Tax Code in seventy-five years, a period in which the nature of our taxation system has changed drastically, while the economic importance, and volume, of taxes have increased tremendously. Such a revision was long overdue.

YONKERS, Aug. 16 -- Adios Boy, J. S. Turner's crack pacer, gave his supporters in an opening-night Yonkers raceway crowd of 20,910 some uneasy moments before going on to capture the $23,400 Yonkers Derby tonight. Sent to the post as the $3.50 to $2 favorite, the Turner entry beat his half brother, Adios Harry, by a length.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Another strong West German labor union joined the nation-wide agitation for higher wages today. It now involves a fourth of the Federal Republic's 16,000,000 workers.

New York City banks are still short of reserve funds, although the banking system as a whole has an abundance of excess reserves held idle in country and small-city banks. As a result, the market rate on borrowing Federal funds -- that is, free balances held on deposit in the Federal Reserve Banks -- continues to be approximately 1 7/16 per cent, a shade below the Reserve Bank rediscount charge of 1 1/2 per cent.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 16 -- The World Council of Churches is irrevocably committed to the "tangible and concrete" unity of all Christendom.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Congress agreed today to raise the national debt limit by $6,000,000,000 and pressed on doggedly in other legislative areas with the last of the Eisenhower program.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The forces of President Woodruff Randolph won a first-round victory over an opposing faction today at the ninety-sixth convention of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., here.

Appointment of Richard C. Brockway as executive director of the division of employment of the State Labor Department was announced yesterday. Mr. Brockway succeeds Milton O. Loysen, who resigned recently to take an executive post with the Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Three admirals and a business man advised the Navy today to adopt a uniform Naval Reserve policy and stick to it.

Teen-age craft workers showed products of their skills yesterday at an exhibition at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The thirty-two exhibits ranged from home-built cameras to a radio-controlled automobile. Also included were a scale model of a jet aircraft engine, an operating plastic model of car engine and a closed-circuit television set.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- Construction is under way of an office building at the Republic Pictures Studio in North Hollywood.
Many husbands at this time of the year find themselves alone, their wives having left them -- temporarily -- in favor of the relatively cool airs of the Catskills, Berkshires, Poconos or seaside.

A summary of advertising spending in this country by years and by types -- which is to say how media fared -- is contained in a "road map of industry," No. 973, being sent to associates of the National Industrial Conference Board.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 16 -- A Brown University astronomer, who waited seventeen years for the chance to make a new test, says that the solar eclipse of June 30 added proof of his theory concerning the zodiacal light of the sun.
Cheaper coffee is in store for the American housewife. The reason -- relaxation of foreign exchange controls in Brazil.
The action of the Senate in voting to outlaw the Communist party in the United States is, it seems to me, one of the most alarming pieces of legislation passed by that chamber.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Jerry Desio, pro, and Irving Mishkin of the Harrison Country Club teamed effectively for a best-ball score of 30, 34 -- 64 and a two-stroke victory in Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur competition at Fenway today.

The price of coffee and cocoa tumbled yesterday in futures trading on the New York exchanges. Both commodities were influenced by the change in the value of the Brazilian cruzeiro for export. Most dealers in coffee and cocoa expect the dollar to buy almost one-fifth more of those items than it did on Friday.

The brokerage and investment banking business of Blair, Rollins Co., Inc., will be carried on in the future under the name of Blair Co., Inc., according to a joint announcement made yesterday by Joshua A. Davis, chairman of the company, and Emmons Bryant, president.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Premier Mendes-France's proposals to revise the European Defense Community treaty have produced an atmosphere of a crisis here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UP) -- An American Bar Association committee declared today that any lawyer who takes refuge in the Fifth Amendment before a Congressional committee automatically disbarred himself.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 3 to 18 points higher than on Friday.
The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., failed yesterday to patch up differences over proposed economy schedules on the IND subway division.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 6 -- A gigantic explosion on the desolate northeastern coast of Siberia was what brought death to scores of walruses in 1951, it was indicated in a report just released here by the Arctic Health Research Center.

NEWARK, Aug. 16 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport today was granted an increase in school bus fares from 2 1/2 cents to 6 cents by the New Jersey Public Utility Commission here. The new fares will take effect with the opening of the schools next month. Pupils throughout the state will be affected.
Adrian D. Joyce, chairman of the Glidden Company, Cleveland, announced plans yesterday for a pilot plant at Sparrows Point, Md., to make titanium metal by a new electrolytic process.
A plan to rename East River Park so that it will recall to New Yorkers the days when the area was one of the greatest wooden shipbuilding centers of the world will get under way today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 16 -- Portuguese forces shelled and recaptured a fortress today from Goan Nationalists who seized it yesterday, press reports here said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today as he signed the tax revision bill:
Bernard M. Baruch gave qualified approval yesterday to the work of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16 -- Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo told Parliament tonight that Indonesia's neutralist foreign policy was facing a new test in view of the efforts to establish a Southeast Asian defense organization.

The country's chemical giant came through yesterday with its 200th consecutive quarterly dividend on common stock. Sitting in Wilmington, Del., directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared the third quarterly interim dividend of $1 a common share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The State Department expressed its official opposition today to major revisions of the European Defense Community treaty proposed by Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb, Britain's Ambassador to France, is flying to London for consultations on the European Defense Community crisis precipitated by Premier Mendes-France.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Digby Morton, first among Britain's top designers to crash the United States fashion market with an exciting line of blouses, has turned to sun-drenched Spain for new ideas.
A machine that extracts priceless disease-killing compounds from the blood of healthy human donors for use in treating the sick has been perfected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Eisenhower today pledged United States support to Vietnam in solving the "difficult problems of peace." He also congratulated the people of Guatemala for having broken "the shackles of international Communist direction."

The proposal to secure adequate personnel for the public schools in the present period of teacher shortages by providing accelerated courses for married women with college degrees may be the best of the available alternatives.
TORONTO, Aug. 16 -- What happens to a child from conception to birth may affect his mental health thereafter, an international meeting of psychiatrists, social workers and educators heard today.
New York City needs a larger police force and the current almost daily exchange of recriminations between City Hall and Albany over the fairness of state aid to the city does nobody any good.
The new management of the Long Island Rail Road will take over tomorrow morning and is expected to approve immediately the purchase of $15,000,000 worth of new passengers cars.

Stockholders of the Long Island Trust Company, Garden City, L. I., have oversubscribed heavily, the company's capital stock offering of 11,500 shares it was announced yesterday by Frederick Hainfeld Jr., president. Mr. Hainfeld said the period for subscription to the new snares expired at 3 P. M., last Thursday, at which time the total subscriptions amounted to 18,761.
Foreign traders agreed yesterday that full effects of the new Brazilian foreign exchange plan, which precipitated a sharp break in coffee prices, are still uncertain.
The heroine of the siege of Dienbienphu unwittingly caused yesterday what may become known as the siege of Bellevue Hospital.
LONDON, Ont., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Ted Lenczyk, the golfing doctor from Newington, Conn., led a wave of lesser-known United States players into the second round of the Canadian amateur championship today.

BILOXI, Miss., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Tom Bonner of the Alaska Conference defeated Bill Connery, of the Euro-African Command, in the opening round today of the Air Forces world tennis tournament at Keesler Air Force Base.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Mediation talks aimed at ending the eighteen-day-old 'American Airlines' pilots strike recessed tonight after "exploratory" discussions.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 16 -- Forty-six persons were killed yesterday when a French plane transporting Vietnamese refugees from Hanoi crashed in Laos, about 300 miles north of here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- An increase in dairy price supports was killed today as conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives agreed on a bill that nearly paralleled President Eisenhower's farm program.

Most of us think of chianti as an Italian wine in a round, straw-covered bottle. We are surprised to learn that aged chianti never is found in that picturesque vessel, but rather in a more prosaic, high-shouldered, Bordeaux-type bottle.
Linens and domestic wholesalers are raising their estimates on fall business.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 16 (UP) -- All groups listed as subversive or as Communist "fronts" were banned today from the Indiana World War Memorial Building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Senate speedily passed the revised Atomic Energy Act tonight by a vote of 59 to 17 after only forty minutes of questions and discussion.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Sixteen allied nations by agreement today eased strategic controls on their trade with Communist nations of Europe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- A grim picture of education, created to a large degree by lack of Government support, was delineated here today as the thirty-seventh annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., convened.

Operations in the nation's steel plants were at 64 per cent of theoretical capacity last week, the same rate as the week before and a shade better than was expected. But the rate will probably dip to 62.1 per cent this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
A young thief posing as a delivery man robbed an East Side triplex of $46,860 in jewels, furs and cash yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Ted Lepeio, Red Sox third baseman, doubled to right in the ninth, scoring Sam Mele with the tie-breaking run for a 6-5 victory tonight over the New York Giants in an exhibition game before 37,710 fans at Fenway Park.

SDE BOKER, Israel, Aug. 10 -- The neo-Nabatean water conservers of this pioneer Negev settlement have grown a nice stand of corn and a whole field of enormous sunflowers. They also have raised their own tomatoes and watermelons.

RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Average prices on several tobacco markets of the huge eastern North Carolina flue-cured belt ranged today from $46 to $50 a hundred pounds in the first hour of opening-day sales. The Federal-State Market News Service said the practical top price for opening sales was $68.

Robert H. Schaffer was sworn into office yesterday as acting Postmaster of New York. Four hundred persons at the ceremony in the main post office heard him promise to work toward improving the postal service and gaining better working conditions for postal employes.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Peter Vangundy, Bishop's First, Eclipse Queen and Gracie Coleen captured top money today as Illinois-bred horses competed for the richest prizes in harness racing history.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Pakistan was in position to gain its first victory over England and tie the four-match series here after today's play in the fourth and last cricket test.
Directors of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., at a meeting yesterday in Hawthorne, Calif., declared a dividend of 80 cents a share for payment Sept. 9, and voted to split the stock two-for-one.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 16 -- The Netherlands announced today her opposition to the revisions of the European Defense Community treaty proposed by Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France.

With an ancient motor bugle horn quavering "Tallyho," nine antique sports cars puffed through Manhattan yesterday. The tenth got traffic-bound and missed part of the motorcade, which started at the western approach of the George Washington Bridge and ended at Rockefeller Plaza.

President Getulio Vargas appears to have weathered the storm that struck Brazil after the attempted assassination of Carlos Lacerda, the crusading, anti-Vargas editor of La Tribuna da Imprensa. An Air Force major was killed in the Aug. 5 shooting and, since everyone involved or under suspicion in the attack came from the Presidential Guard or from the President's own family, popular indignation ran high for some days.

Averell Harriman, an announced candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, entered the dispute between Mayor Wagner and Governor Dewey over financial relations between the city and state yesterday.

Shareholders of the Bank of Montreal are being offered rights to subscribe to 900,000 additional shares of capital stock, at $30 a share in Canadian currency, on the basis of one new share for each four shares held on Aug. 16. The offer will expire on Nov. 26.
City officials are negotiating with several shipping concerns in an attempt to revive the idle Staten Island waterfront.

OTTAWA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Many Commonwealth countries have gradually reduced import curbs, but with few exceptions this has not produced any impressive increase in Canadian exports. In fact, the first half of 1954 saw serious declines in shipments, particularly to Britain and Commonwealth countries in Southeast Asia.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) Britain came out today against including Formosa in the area that would be protected under the Allies' project for a Southeast Asia defense pact.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Members of the Civil Aeronautics Board, which waived civil air regulations governing the length of consecutive flight time for which pilots might be scheduled, were assisting in the new attempt to get the airline and the pilots together.

CAIRO, Aug. 16 -- A high Army officer disclosed today that some disagreements had arisen between the British and Egyptian negotiators writing a detailed draft of the preliminary Suez evacuation agreement signed July 27.
Two hold-ups and two muggings were added to the city's catalogue of crime yesterday, but fast-moving police scored arrests in half the new cases.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Dr. Hanns R. Teichert, who spent $450 for a painting that he now believes an original by Leonardo Da Vinci, said today that "Madonna and Child" had been subjected to ultra-violet and black-light tests.

It seems to me that it was questionable for a justice of the United States Supreme Court, while traveling abroad, to make derogatory remarks about the manner in which our sister democracy handles her colonial affairs. The New York Public Library asked yesterday for allocation of $3,500,000 in the city's 1955 capital budget. The money would be used for new branch buildings and improvement of existing structures.
Robin Roberts and the Philles were too much for the Dodgers at Ebbets. Field last night. The Phils won, 9 -- 6, in a somewhat loosely played game before a Ladies Night crowd of 25,951 (15,814 paid).

There was an indication yesterday of the growing influence of television on the legitimate theatre with the announcement that the Theatre Guild is planning to develop three recent video scripts into stage productions.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 16 (AP) -- At his home here, Bobby Jones said Mr. Mitchell's remarks "are utterly ridiculous and without foundation."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 16 -- The Thai Government struck back today at recent Peiping propaganda against this country's relationship to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The 1954 Citizens for Eisenhower Bandwagon got off to a stormy start tonight, but only the Democrats attached any symbolism to this.

The Moscow radio broadcast a virulent attack against United States civilization last week while Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and his colleagues were assuring the British Labor party delegation of Soviet friendship for the Western world.

PEIPING, Aug. 16 -- Communist China's Premier, Chou En-lai, told British Labor party leaders tonight that his country was ready to strive with the British people for the safeguarding of the peace of Asia and the world.

Arthur Klotz withdrew yesterday as a candidate for a Democratic nomination for City Court Justice. His action makes possible a Democratic coalition with either the Republican or the Liberal parties on candidates for local judicial office this year.

WHEN a fellow returns to the store after being off on a holiday, the first thing he should do is study the shelves, examine the merchandise and see what changes have taken place since his departure. The first item to catch the eyes a once neat and glossy package which bore the label, "Giant pennant hopes."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Stockholders of the 75-year-old Newport Casino, at a special meeting today, voted unanimously to reject the $150,000 offer by Allen J. Rooke and associates of Warwick, R. I., for the Casino real estate.

A telephone building in upper Manhattan to cost $1,300,000 was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The two-story structure will occupy a site bounded by Broadway, 213th and 214th Streets and Tenth Avenue.

In what will probably be its last week of legislative activity, the Eighty-third Congress still has before it three major bills that are now being whipped into final shape. No matter with what promise of efficiency and high hopes of precision the Congress begins its labors in January, it almost invariably winds up in a mad midsummer scramble to get home, whether it is under Democratic or Republican management.

Pan American World Airways will add a second weekly cargo flight to its trans-Atlantic schedules on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president and traffic and sales director of the company. A four-engined Douglas DC-6A, built for the transportation of air cargo, will be used in the new service.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Trainer Charley Goldman today scoffed at suggestions that Rocky Marciano, heavyweight king, might be overtrained on Sept. 15, if he maintains his present rigorous training program.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 16 -- The five presidents of the World Council of Churches received the honorary degree of Doctor of Sacred Theology tonight from Northwestern University. The Right Rev. George K. Bell, Anglican Bishop of Chichester, England, and chairman of the council's Central Committee, received the honor during an evening plenary session of the Second General Assembly of the world religious organization.
A spry, century-young Norseman zipped into town yesterday his wheelchair, ready to take in New York and President Eisenhower during his two-day layover in port.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 17 -- A vast increase in the Soviet Union's virgin land grain program was announced today. It would increase the seeding of new lands to 37,100,000 acres in 1955 and to as much as 74,100,000 acres in 1956.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, implied in a debate here today that there had been corruption at the White House level in connection with an atomic energy power project.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Joe Culmone went into the lead among the riders at Atlantic City today by scoring twice for the Leslie Jane Stable.
The State Roads Commission of Maryland plans to sell $25,000,000 of highway construction bonds, second issue, Series F, on Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company earned a record $24,622,670 in the first six months of 1954. This compares with a profit of $22,997,684 for the corresponding 1953 period. The company is calling for the redemption of its $5 preferred stock, which involves $59,288,145.
A taste for mushy cornmeal proved the undoing of many a carp yesterday in the fifth annual junior fishing contest of the Department of Parks.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- After a layoff of two weeks, Tony Trabert returned to competition in the national tennis doubles championship at the Longwood Cricket Club today, his twenty-fourth birthday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Labor party leader, set off a courtroom clash today in his first appearance before the royal commission investigating Soviet espionage in Australia.

The dominance of the Cardinals and the Dodgers in the National League batting picture for the past eleven seasons seems a cinch to be repeated this year, with Brooklyn's Duke Snider and St. Louis' Stan Musial currently running one-two in the hitting race, according to The Associated Press.

ROME, Aug. 16 -- A force of policemen and carabinieri was present today in the market place of Benevento in southern Italy, to prevent the hotly criticized semi-annual "child market." In this market, children from poorer families have been auctioned in the past to work for a year in the fields of wealthier farmers.

Today's new film is "Paris Incident," a French-made comedy-drama with Gerard Gervais, Pierrette Simonet, Olivier Hussenot and Christian Fourcade, at the Plaza Theatre. Henri Decoin directed and Mme. Goulian produced from a scenario and story by Alex Joffe. The Arthur Davis release has English titles.

Young people who take part regularly in church activities have fewer problems at home, in school and with themselves than do youngsters who attend church rarely or not at all, a study of 5,279 high school seniors and college students indicates.

Speaking from her own experiences, a play-school specialist said recently that the kind of information mothers sought most frequently was how to provide their children with simple but creative play projects in the home.

The second of this summer's free programs of chamber music in Washington Square Park drew an audience of 5,000 last night. This was 1,000 more than last week and the extra listeners were accommodated on the lawns of the western half of the park.

WESTBURY, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Hedgewood Fingo, 6-year-old bay horse owned by Penuel and Holloway of Frankford, Del., scored a length victory in 2:05 2/5 over Madge Hy tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in the Illinois Mile-Pace. Dynamic Hal was third. The winner returned $8.90, $4.60 and $3.60 across the board.

BARSTOW, Calif., Aug. 16 (UP) -- A Barstow hospital spokesman said today that the Las Vegas, Nev., publisher, Herman M. (Hank) Greenspun, injured seriously in a two-car collision, was expected to recover "but it will be a long, hard road."
ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today reported that in 1953 utility companies in New York State got $10,647,000 in rate increases -- the smallest annual total since 1946.
Lower taxes enabled the Tide Water Associated Oil Company in the first six months this year to lift its net income to $18,167,000 from $17,487,000 in the corresponding period last year.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Argentine President Juan D. Peron handed back to Paraguay today the military trophies taken from this country in the war of 1865-70.

I am surprised that the doctrine has not been laid down that any nation which applies for admission into the United Nations should first hold popular elections honestly supervised by United Nations representatives showing that a clear majority of the people in that country are in favor of the power in control.
Three of the Yankee semi-invalids will accompany the world champions to Philadelphia this afternoon, where three night games are scheduled with the Athletics.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The stock market here remained irregular today, but the undertone was described as satisfactory. Early losses were partly recovered in a firmer close.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 17 -- Despite disorders and terrorism in Morocco in the last year, French military authorities have less to worry about here than in their other French North African protectorate of Tunisia.

As each summer week nears its halfway point, the question arises, What will it be this week-end? Will the climbing sun rouse late sleepers from their beds while the faithful alarm clock stands silent and unwound? Or will it be the children, anxious to be up and out, who rattle the doors and break the pleasant slumbers?

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -The British Foreign Office tonight officially denied as "completely untrue" a charge by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that Britain had been exporting industrial diamonds to Russia for a number of years.

Congratulations on your timely editorial "Time to Fluoridate!" The fluoridation of New York City's water supply, which means the adjustment of the fluoride content to the most effective level to help insure strong healthy teeth, has been a plank in the program of the Health Division of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City since the division was organized two years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Arthur S. Lall, Indian Consul General in New York since 1951, will replace Rajeshwar Dayal as India's permanent representative to the United Nations.
A plan to affiliate the Police Academy with the Baruch School of Public Administration of City College was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The special Senate committee considering the censure motion against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today selected as its counsel E. Wallace Chadwick of Chester, Pa., a lawyer and once a Republican member of the Eightieth Congress.
The field of television news reporting and interpretation has begun to assert itself with unusual vigor, a move that definitely is in the public interest.

MANILA, Aug. l7 -- President Ramon Magsaysay announced today that he was planning to notify the seven other nations attending the Southeast Asian conference that it might have to be held in Manila instead of Baguio because of possible bad weather.

Backed against the wall in the Light National League pennant race as a result of having lost seven of their eight previous starts, the Giants eased the pressure a bit by downing the Phillies, 8 -- 3, before 15,668 spectators at the Polo Grounds last night.
Coffee price reductions became general here yesterday in retail stores, on the heels of a 10-cent a pound drop Monday in the wholesale price of Martinson coffee.
TRENTON, Aug. 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson will make several speeches in New Jersey in behalf of Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

April 15, 1955, will be Black Friday indeed unless something is done about it in Albany. For there will then be a coincidence of due dates for both federal and New York State income tax returns by individuals, a cruel and unusual punishment accidentally emerging from the kindest of motives in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that its index of industrial production, widely used pointer to the nation's economic health, held steady in July at the same level as in May and June.

The biggest capital expenditures in their history are being planned by a number of the country's largest industrial corporations. This was disclosed yesterday by The Advertising Council on the basis of a telegraphic survey.

If our country is to survive against the Soviet conspiracy for world-wide domination of all free and God-fearing nations I believe we must wake up to the realization that we can no longer continue with "appeasement" tactics and the theory that we can "get along" with the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that purchases of butter by household consumers since prices were reduced under a Government farm support program April 1 had been running about 5 per cent higher than last winter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -Ship conversion, modernization and construction projects embodying the bulk of the Government's new maritime improvement program appeared assured tonight.

The industrial property at 62-68 Monitor Street in Jersey City, N. J., has been purchased by Jack L. Chasin from Harry Krupp in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker. Formerly the headquarters of the Central Avenue bus line, the one-story garage type building with about 10,000 square feet of floor space will be occupied by the Garden State Construction Company for the repair and storage of its heavy equipment.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 17 -Mario Del Guercio and Joe Massucco of the Westchester Country Club won the Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball one-day tournament over the Old Oaks course today. They turned in a best-ball net score of 31, 33 -- 64 to triumph by one stroke in a field of fifty-five teams.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Two Middle East business men today offered to supply American spaghetti manufacturers with 13,000,000 bushels of durum wheat in case a shortage develops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Deputy Housing and Home Finance Administrator, William McKenna, said today that "graft in high places" involving "considerable sums of money" had taken place in the Federal mortgage insurance program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Boston Red Sox survived a ninth-inning rally to defeat Washington, 4 -- 3, tonight. Frank Sullivan, who required aid from Sid Hudson in the ninth to halt a threat by the Senators, registered his tenth victory.
Net income of the B. F. Goodrich Company for the six months ended June 30 was 8 per cent above that of a year ago, despite a 13 per cent drop in sales, the rubber company announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A mix-up in clearances today delayed four United States Air Force flying boxcars of the East Pakistan flood-relief airlift more than three hours at Calcutta's Dum Dum Airfield.

LONDON, Aug. l7 -- Senior commanders of the armies of the British Commonwealth, whose combined forces number approximately 400,000 regular soldiers in peacetime, will begin a three- day meeting of potential importance tomorrow.
" Sing Me No Lullaby," a new play by Robert Ardrey, will be the first attraction of the season at the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street. It will begin a six-week run on Oct. 5.

Interval Concerts, an organization, which, in 1950, began presenting concerts in the ordinarily music-less interval between the ending of the summer season and the opening of the winter one, last night stepped into the breach for the fifth successive year.

The Foreign Ministers of six European nations, including Premier MendesFrance and Chancellor Adenauer, are scheduled to meet in Brussels in a last-ditch effort to save the European Defense Community, which has been plunged into a crisis by the latest French revision of it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -President Eisenhower made it plain today that the United States Seventh Fleet would go into action to break up any Chinese Communist invasion of Formosa.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 17 -- A church leader from Communistdominated Hungary told the World Council of Churches today that Christians "everywhere" should voice "courageously and resolutely" their independence from "all social systems."
TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP)-- A plan for three new modern towns along the St. Lawrence River and the relocation of another -- a plan that may cost as much as $100,000,000 -- was unnveiled today.

TRENTON, Aug. 17 -- Former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman and two of his aides concealed illegal use of state funds for many years by means of fraudulent vouchers, a former associate of the three testified under oath here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- An international chase for the custody of a 5-year-old girl ended in Supreme Court here today with an agreement between her divorced parents to share custody. They held a two-hour conference in chambers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- House investigators said today it was in bad taste to pour or drink beer on television. They recommended that wine makers and brewers and the radio and television networks consider steps to curb or eliminate such advertising.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- The National Theatres Corporation, one of the largest movie house circuits, announced here tonight that arrangements to show the Ezzard Charles-Rocky Marciano heavyweight championship fight next month had been canceled.
Anti-Communist measures, pending in Congress, were denounced yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union, the Socialist party and the New York State American Labor party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- It is a rule of politics that you never make a personal attack on a national hero if you can avoid it, but the Democrats have started their Congressional campaign by rewriting the rules.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill met tonight on the European Defense Community situation with a number of senior British diplomats, including the Ambassadors to France and the Soviet Union.

Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) announced yesterday that it was expanding its use of airborne weather-detecting radar equipment. The airline said it had ordered radar sets capable of spotting storms up to 150 miles ahead of aircraft in flight.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Pakistan marked its recent entry into full international cricket with a 24-run victory over England in the fourth and final test at the Oval Ground today. The final score was Pakistan 133 and 164, England 130 and 143.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Two of Britain's most powerful railroad unions are to meet this week to consider calling a nation-wide strike. Many of their members are demanding a walkout following rejection of their wage claims by the British Transport Commission.

Efforts to settle the strike of pilots against American Airlines are going on in Washington; and in the interest of the public as well as of orderly labor-management procedure we very much hope they will soon bear fruit. As a letter from the company, published in an adjoining column today, makes clear, the strike has been called despite the existence of a contract.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A shake-up in the editorial board of one of the Soviet Union's leading literary magazines was announced today.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France will go to Brussels tomorrow in the hope of persuading the other foreign ministers that not much less than the drastic revision he proposed will enable him to get the European Defense Community treaty through the French National Assembly.

The preparation of the city's capital budget for the calendar year 1955 has entered its more public phase with the City Planning Commission hearing the arguments in support of departmental requests for $1,008,510,154 in permanent improvements to be built or bought.
Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, complained yesterday that it was not good politics to run down the Port of New York on the grounds of labor troubles and antiquated piers.

Autumn brides would do well to check with Mrs. Ruth English of Rosette Pennington's Brides Shop for fashion suggestions. In yesterday's showing at the shop at 20 East Fifty-sixth Street, Mrs. English offered many a sage bit of advice.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 17 -- The Netherlands has come to the conclusion that acceptance of the European army treaty proposals of the French Premier would mean an end to the dream of European integration.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 17 -- A fresh, puffy northwest wind that blew from ten to fifteen miles an hour greeted 151 youngsters participating in the sixth annual Manhasset Bay three-day race series that began today.

BEEMERVILLE, N. J., Aug. 17 -- New Jersey bankers deserted their glass-topped desks today to watch a demonstration of the latest farming methods at Rutgers University's 1,200-acre Dairy Research Farm here.

As a result of a press conference held Aug. 8 The New York Times and other local daily newspapers endeavored to correct some serious misunderstandings about epilepsy which resulted from the report of the death of Emilie Dionne.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The United States again may consider limited bartering with Russia for critical raw materials in exchange for surplus butter or other food, Thruston B. Morton, Assistant Secretary of State, said today.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug 17 -- If intelligence and ingenuity were all that were required to compose an effective opera, then Rolf Liebermann's "Penelope," which had its premiere here last night, might well be considered a successful effort.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Admiral Corporation had sales of $105,201,498 and net earnings of $2,558,850, equal to $1.09 a share, in the first six months of this year, John B. Huarisa, executive vice president, announced today. Both showed declines from a year ago.

The F. W. Woolworth Company, in the first semi-annual report in its seventy-five-year history, yesterday listed sales at a record $308,956,528 for the six months ended June 30. Net earnings also improved over the 1953 period, largely as a result of a smaller tax bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Senate voted for a second time today, 41 to 39, to make membership in the Communist party or other organizations giving aid to its conspiratorial program a crime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Senate and House of Representatives remained at odds today over the proposed coverage of self-employed professionals and farm operators in the Social Security insurance system.

Once Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China issued his threat last week to "liberate" Formosa it became imperative for the United States to make it clear that we would not allow this to happen. President Eisenhower said yesterday that if the Chinese Reds intend to take Formosa they would have to run over the United States Seventh Fleet to do so.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 17 -- Henry Sims, president of Winthrop College, has been advised to codify his administrative policies or resign for the good of the institution, a state college for women at Rock Hill.
The City Planning Commission had the unusual experience yesterday of receiving a request from a city commissioner for less money than his department had asked earlier.

TRENTON, Aug. 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, sharply criticized the Republican-controlled State Legislature today for its failure to resume its 1954 session voluntarily at this time. He accused it of evading its responsibility to the people and its leaders of "unstatesmanlike" behavior.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., were told by a psychiatrist that they ought to go back to school and learn how to handle children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (UP) -- A former Chinese Communist soldier who escaped to United Nations forces during the Korean war said today the Chinese people were living in "utter misery" under the Reds. Tsun-hsien Chang, 38 years old, who arrived from Honolulu with four other former Red soldiers on a tour of the United States, also said at a news conference that the Red Army's morale was "very low."

It seems strange that your editorial on the American Airlines strike of pilots which you carried on Aug. 16, as well as your first editorial on Aug. 3, completely ignores the existence of a collective bargaining agreement between the union and the company permitting the very operation under which dispute has arisen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Senate passed by voice vote tonight an Administration bill to extend the unemployment compensation system to nearly 4,000,000 additional workers.

Harold Baer, a Liberal party candidate, was endorsed yesterday by the New York County Democratic organization for one of two vacancies on the City Court bench. The endorsement cemented a Democratic-Liberal alliance designed to increase Democratic membership in the Legislature and Congress.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 17 -- The Swiss Government feels it has become politically imperative for it to seek compensation from the United States for the blow dealt to the Swiss economy by last month's increase in watch tariffs.
Virgil C. Rice has been appointed director of manufacturing of the Norge appliance division of the Borg-Warner Corporation, Chicago.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 (AP) -Joe Frazier of the Cardinals smashed a three-run pinch homer off Jim Wilson tonight as St. Louis snapped Milwaukee's nine-game winning streak with a 4 -- 1 triumph.

Dr. Corliss Lamont, author and lecturer on philosophy at Columbia University, said yesterday that he would fight a contempt citation voted against him and two others Monday by the Senate. He said he was determined to carry his case "through to the United States Supreme Court" if necessary.
The operator of the largest fleet of trucks in New York State -- the Department of Sanitation -- started yesterday to put its 8,000 drivers through extensive tests to determine their driving ability.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -President Eisenhower signed a bill today that grants freedom to a Yugoslav woman who had lived in bondage in the United States for nearly five years.
The September price for fluid milk (Class 1-A) produced for the New York metropolitan milk marketing area will be $5.28 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts).

" The Vanishing Prairie," Walt Disney's second True-Life Adventure feature, broke all box office records for an opening day at the Fine Arts Theatre, according to the management. Admission receipts for the Monday performances totaled "slightly over $2,100," or "approximately seven dollars more" than the opening day returns for "The Cruel Sea," the showcase's previous record holder.

PRESIDENT and Mrs. Eisenhower's appearance in Broome Street yesterday to register for absentee ballots didn't throw the Board of Elections officials off stride at all. They've had the President before, and keep getting important officials every year.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Tahar ben Ammar, Tunisian Premier, and one of his ministers, Mohamed Masmoudi, began talks with French leaders here today to settle details of the forthcoming formal negotiations for Tunisian autonomy.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 17 -David K. E. Bruce, special United States observer with the Interim Committee of the European Defense Community, conferred today with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. Evidenty they discussed the methods to be employed at the Brussels conference in dealing with the treaty amendments proposed by the Premier of France.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The merger of Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company into Standard Oil Company (Indiana) became effective today, officials of the two companies announced. Pan American had been functioning as a subsidiary of Standard Oil, which owned about 78 per cent of its stock prior to the merger.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 17 (UP) -- A state survey on public school segregation was interpreted today as indicating that Florida was not ready for immediate mixing of Negroes and whites in classrooms.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 17 (AP) -- The early voting was light as Wyoming's residents made their choices from a record field of 190 candidates for national and state offices in today's primary election.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -- The new exchange regulations designed to stimulate the sale of Brazilian products abroad have drawn hostile remarks from a variety of sources.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 17 -- The plan to establish a joint Scandinavian Market by easing customs barriers took a big step forward today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -Herbert Hoover Jr., son of the former President, has been nominated by President Eisenhower to be Under Secretary of State.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 17 -- A high South African official said today that the Government aimed to win over four colonial powers in Africa to a policy of maintaining white supremacy.
The Minnesota Pipe Line Company has borrowed $12,500,000 privately on two issues of notes.
TORONTO, Aug. 17 -- The medical profession is still holding "primitive" and "naive" concepts about the causes of illness, it was asserted here today.
A collection of fall designs for home seamstresses was presented at Macy's yesterday by Advance Patterns.

PEIPING, Aug. 17 -- Eight British Labor party leaders on a goodwill tour of Communist China sat down with Premier Chou En-lai at a lavish banquet tonight and watched dances by elfinlike Indonesian girls. The banquet was given to celebrate Indonesian Independence Day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- An expansion goal for titanium calling for a processing capacity of 37,500 tons a year by the end of 1956 was announced today by the Office of Defense Mobilization.
MUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 17 -The United Nations Command demanded today that Communists account for 2,840 missing United Nations soldiers whe were not returned in the prisoner exchange last year.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) -The chairman of the National Steel Corporation today assailed the plan of a Brazilian steel company to borrow about $40,000,000 from the Export-Import Bank to expand its plant at Volta Redonda, Brazil.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 17 -- On guard against outrages by the underground Irish Republican Army, the Northern Ireland Government drew a tight security network today around Queen Elizabeth. She was on a four-hour visit to Belfast to launch the 20,000-ton passenger liner Southern Cross.

Earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in the first half of this year rose nearly 25 per cent to a record $28,134,192, although sales fell 2.9 per cent behind the volume for the same period a year ago.

Does it ever occur to readers how their newspaper comes to them so neat, how there manages to be no blank spaces at the bottoms of pages, how stories don't break off at the tops of pictures or ads without picking up somewhere else?

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 17 -- The forthcoming American tour of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, one of Europe's great musical ensembles, is being snagged by visa troubles. The orchestra's first post-war visit, designed in large measure as a goodwill gesture, may, as a result, produce less of the same.
Smith, Barney Co. and associates are offering $2,100,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds of Henderson, Ky., due from 1955 to 1989 at yields ranging from 1 to 2.90 per cent.

Four Brooklyn youths were charged yesterday with a series of crimes that included beating and kicking a man to death, horsewhipping young women and burning the soles of a vagrant's feet, beating him, and throwing his body into the river.
A newspaper photographer's persuasive arguments caused a taxicab driver late yesterday to change his mind about jumping off the Manhattan Bridge.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Hossein Fatemi, Iran's Foreign Minister during the Mossadegh regime, was indicted on five counts of treason today and will be tried before a military court next month.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 17 (UP) -Strong relief pitching by Virgil Trucks and Morrie Martin, plus the hitting and base running of Minnie Minoso, carried the Chicago White Sox to a sweep of a twilight-night double-header with the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 -- Pressing foreign-policy issues may avert the break-up of a coalition of Israel's two largest parties. The coalition forms the basis of the Government headed by Prime Minister Moshe Sharett.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Defense Minister, declared tonight, "Down with war!" But he added, "If it is necessary, we will fight."

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net gains of 7 to 19 points. The far deliveries showed the greatest advance, July, October and December establishing new highs for the life of the contract.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. l7 -- The Indonesian delegation to the United Nations announced here today that it would ask the General Assembly to urge the Netherlands to negotiate with Indonesia on the political status of Western New Guinea.

THE fisherman who wants to spend a day at Montauk Point need not worry about the cost of such an outing. For a $10 bill he can buy transportation there and return, fish from any one of the thirteen open party and charter boats, with bait thrown in. This bargain is available on Saturdays and Sundays through John McCann's bus service.
Mayor Wagner and Senator Herbert H. Lehman held a long political conference over a breakfast table in Washington yesterday at which the topic was the selection of a Democratic candidate for Governor.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) -The Cleveland Indians overcame a one-run deficit in the ninth inning tonight and beat the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 3, on Bobby Avila's single with the bases loaded. The victory was the seventh in a row for the Tribe and the eighth pitching triumph for Bob Lemon in the last four weeks.

WENDOVER, Utah, Aug. 17 -- Zipping around the Bonneville Salt Flats at a two-mile-per-minute clip in a forty-inch-high, aluminum-paneled MG of special design, Capt. George E. T. Eyston today established seventeen American and international speed marks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Unfavorable crop reports from Western Canada, where rust damage continues, and advices from the American spring wheat country of extremely variable yields induced considerable buying of wheat today.

President and Mrs. Eisenhower enjoyed New York's hospitality yesterday morning on an eighty-minute visit to register and apply for absentee ballots for the November elections. They registered as Republicans at the fourth-floor Board of Elections offices in the Police Academy, 400 Broome Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Charles W. Penchard, who will be 100 years old Aug. 28, intends to begin his second century by going, as usual, to his real estate office. Unassisted, he makes the three-mile trip by bus almost every weekday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. l7 -- The House of Representatives, racing to adjourn by the week-end, gave final Congressional approval today to the Administration's new Atomic Energy Bill.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Greyhound Corporation stockholders voted today to absorb Pacific Greyhound Lines, its West Coast affiliate. The terms were approved by a stockholder vote of 8,270,600 3/4 to 20,542.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- British veterinarians, who have watched man benefit from experiments on dogs, reversed the situation today with a fourteenday reducing diet for overweight dogs that had been tried out on humans first.

Maurice Evans is preparing for another appearance on television in a Shakespearean role. He will do "Macbeth" on N. B. C.-TV, from 4 to 6 P. M. on Sunday, Nov. 28. This production, like Mr. Evans' two previous Shakespearean video offerings, will be under the sponsorship of the Hallmark greeting card company.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- While their captain, Harry Hopman, was defending them against charges of complacency at Newport in a clubhouse press conference, three Australian teams advanced to the third round of tht national tennis doubles championships without the loss of set today.

TERRY MOORE had been quietly minding his business when the call came. His business was two-fold. He was running two bowling alleys in St. Louis and scouting for the Phillies on the side. But the strikes and spares phase of his activity was crowding out the strikes and balls part. This, he determined, would be his last year as a scout.
Shareholders of the Kimberly- Clark Corporation at the annual meeting yesterday in Neenah, Wis., approved a two-for-one split of the common stock.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Growers and shippers today announced plans to spend more than $10,000,000 to advertise fresh fruit and vegetables during the next twelve months.

By Act of Parliament British television viewers will soon enjoy -- or suffer, as the case may be -- the special brand of living-room entertainment Americans have had for many years. Now they, too, can watch commercials. A new television network, carrying commercials, is to be established to compete with the British Broadcasting Corporation, the Government-operated network which has reigned in the broadcasting field for thirty years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 17 -- Arriving this morning for a two-day "invasion" of Republican Greenwich, Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democratic candidate for Governor of Connecticut, staged a meet-the-people-tour of local shops, banks and factories.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- The Vatican, through the Sacred Congregation of Rites, has granted clergy in the United States, the optional right to administer the sacraments of baptism matrimony and extreme unction in English.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 25 -- As in the country of which it is a territory, "living in Alaska is what you make it," according to one young couple here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -The most spectacular manhunt in Brazil's recent history led to the capture early this morning of a former Presidential bodyguard accused of having planned and directed the shooting that has kept the country in crisis since Aug. 5.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 17 (AP) -Three of America's top players -all favorites -- were defeated today in the Canadian amateur golf championship, but twenty-seven contenders from the United States advanced to the third round.
Johannes Selliaas, 101-year-old Norwegian with the breezy outlook of a teen-ager, will sail for home today aboard the liner Stavangerfjord after a whirlwind two-day tour of the city.

YONKERS, Aug. 17 -- Billy Haughton, leading money-winning harness horse driver in 1952 and 1953, was severely shaken up when Willway fell about 100 yards from the finish line in the seventh race at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Haughton, though bruised, did not require hospitalization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -The Internal Revenue Bureau has accepted a Brooklyn clothing manufacturer's offer to settle for $500,000 a claim for $736,669.09 in back income taxes, interest and penalties.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 17 -The still keen eyes of Bernard M. Baruch, who will be 84 years old Thursday, were instrumental today in guiding a helicopter to the estate of the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilts.

Donations of blood on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 327 pints. Included were 153 given by employes of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:
CAIRO, Aug. 17 -- A United Nations truce unit found Israel guilty today of two attacks on the Egyptian-administered Gaza Strip. In one attack the Israelis killed an Arab workman.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- At the Saratoga track the horses are saddled back of the stands, under the trees, and the horseplayers are able to get close- ups of the proceedings. They're able to rub elbows with owners and trainers and jockeys.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 17 -Studebaker, which had gone through a receivership in the depression days of the early Nineteen Thirties, recovered under the guidance of Mr. Vance and Mr. Hoffman to set records in production and sales.

The stock market lost much of its earlier gains in the late trading yesterday and final prices were completely mixed. The oils, motors and a few issues in which there are special developments finished higher, but well below their best for the session.

Army authorities at Fort Dix, N. J., asserted yesterday that no further review was possible of two courts-martial that recently acquitted a lieutenant and a sergeant of charges of "cruel and unusual mass punishment."

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Clyde McCullough's grand-slam home run in the finale and four-baggers by Hank Sauer and Ralph Kiner in the first game sparked the Chicago Cubs to a double victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today, 5 to 0 and 6 to 1, to end a ten-game losing streak.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -The Yankees almost took a giant step forward tonight, as "Operation Soft Touch," more familiarly known as a series with the Philadelphia Athletics, was launched at Connie Mack Stadium. Manager Casey Stengel's men did their part here, routing the A's, 11 -- 1, but at Cleveland, the league-leaders refused to cooperate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of a statement made by Stephen A. Mitchell, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, on President Eisenhower's comments on the chairman's hints of corruption in an Atomic Energy Commission contract:
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 18 -- The Senate completed Congressional action on the compromise farm bill early today, giving President Eisenhower a major victory.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The states's department of agriculture estimated today the state would produce 15,334,000 bushels of apples this year, 17 per cent more than in 1953.

The Japanese call it sashimi, in Ecuador it is seviche and as lomi lomi it is an important part of a Hawaiian luau (festive meal). The dish -- usually served as an appetizer, though it may be the main course -- is raw fish dipped in soya sauce (Japan) or steeped in citrus juices (Ecuador) or lemon and tomato juice Hawaii).

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer rushed through the stretch with Titanic to win the $3,500 Missouri BB Pace by a neck from Meadow Abbe in 2:05 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Third, a length and a half back, was Snap Up.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A Democratic leader's hint of corruption at the White House level got a shrug and a snort from President Eisenhower today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- The Pirates, supposed to be the Dodgers' "cousins," disowned the relationship tonight by beating the Brooks, 4 -- 2, before the third largest Forbes Field crowd of the season, 20,102.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
An attempt to pawn a woman's $2,000 diamond-studded watch for $20 led to the arrest yesterday of a man alleged to have stolen the timepiece and of two friends who tried to help him turn it into cash.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -- President Sukarno announced today that Indonesia had submitted her dispute with the Dutch over Western New Guinea to the United Nations General Assembly.
Many business executives seem to be in line for fatter bonuses, according to the American Management Association.

Coffee futures prices continued to tumble on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, influenced by the relaxation of exchange regulations in Brazil. The spot price of Santos 4's coffee was quoted at 71 1/2 cents a pound, off 5 1/2 cents.

A vacant plot 107 by 100 feet on the north side of Twenty-eighth Avenue, ninety-three feet west of 215th Street, in Bayside, Queens, has been purchased by Joseph Chorbajian from James P. Tonry. The sale was made through Philip Abatelli as agent. Gregory J. Melikian was attorney for the buyer, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Dr. Bryn Hovde fully deserved the praise which he received in your obituary notice. While the largest part of his active life was spent in Pittsburgh, where we laid him to rest on Aug. 13, he made contributions on a national and international scale to housing, to cultural and intellectual cooperation among nations, and especially to education.

Consolidated net income of the Ohio Edison Company, including its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, amounted to $19,740,081 in the twelve months ended on July 31. Walter H. Sammis, president, reported yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 17 -- Nine thousand tons of supplies for the Korean needy arrived in Pusan last night aboard the motorship Korea. They were gifts from individuals, groups and organizations throughout the United States.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- Packard and Studebaker, last of the independent automobile manufacturers to survive the rough road of twentieth-century competition, today were merged in an attempt to improve their business.

A banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Lehman Brothers and Salomon Bros. Hutzler will place on the market today a new issue of $8,700,000 of New Jersey Power and Light Company first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds due Aug. 1, 1984.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that he would regard it as quite serious if the French proposals for a revision of the European Defense Community treaty were so drastic as to require approval by the parliaments of the six participating nations.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The House of Delegates, the policy-making body of the American Bar Association, voted today to table a resolution advocating the teaching of communism in the public schools.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- For the third time since 1950 Mrs. John B. Balding of The Creek Club, Locust Valley, L. I., and Robert Balding carried off the Edward S. Knapp Trophy as winners of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Mother-and-Son Championship.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- John C. Ross, No. 3 man in the United States delegation and the last of the important appointees of former President Truman in the mission, resigned today.

A Brooklyn cab driver who has been hacking for eighteen years found a cloth handbag on the back seat of his taxi Tuesday night and dutifully turned it over to the police. He learned yesterday that the first important find in his career was a collection of jewelry valued at $16,000 to $20,000.

Psychiatrists surveying preliminary reports on four Brooklyn youths charged with violent crimes, including homicide, appeared to agree yesterday that the boys had never achieved normal emotional growth.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The Indonesians formally requested today that the General Assembly do something about the presence of the Dutch in West New Guinea.

Preventive measures in the area of Juvenile delinquency might well have been taken ten or twenty years ago. Successive Mayors have been satisfied with pious observations about parental delinquency and have then gone about appointing committees, wholly without power or understanding, to combat conditions far beyond their control.
A two-for-one split of the capital stock and a 25-cent increase in the quarterly dividend was voted yesterday by directors of the Sperry Corporation.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The New Boston Committee, a citizens' group formed four years ago to promote honest and efficient government here, today appeared to be on the verge of dissolution.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The Truax-Traer Coal Company today reported that net income in the quarter ended July 31 had decreased to $201,687, equal to 10 cents a common share, from $417,773, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. The reduction was attributed in part to lower production, but mainly to the fact that the figure for a year ago included non-recurring income of $189,070.
Those who smoke filter-tip cigarettes wrong-end-to, as well as those who smoke them from the proper end, have long been wondering, "What's in the filter tip, anyway?"
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Hoover Commission has expanded the study area of its committee on transportation to include the sea and air transport agencies of the armed services.

Letters Abroad, 695 Park Avenue, a committee of the National Council of Women of the U. S., Inc., which acts as a clearing house for personal correspondence between persons in the United States and abroad, matched 22,000 requests for correspondents last year. In its annual report, Letters also revealed some trends in the field of international letter writing.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- Attilio Piccioni, Italian Foreign Minister, left for Brussels to fight for the principle that the European Defense Community project is worthwhile only if it is a stepping stone toward a politically united Europe.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 18 -- The French protocol to revise the European Defense Community treaty was frowned upon by the foreign ministers of all the five other signatory countries who gathered in Brussels today to discuss it.
The formation of a new company to furnish technical services to concerns engaged in nuclear power development or interested in the industrial applications of radioactivity was announced yesterday.
The profile hat predominated in Gimbels' showing yesterday of twenty adaptations of French millinery.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 18 -- A minister from the African Gold Coast and a Greek theologian told the World Council of Churches here today that a divided Christendom was not only "scandalous" but also a "grave obstacle" to the building of men's faith.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Aug. 18 -- The possibility that the Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France may come to grief over the European Defense Community treaty is causing anxiety in French North African protectorates.
GRONINGEN, The Netherlands, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- A Russian cruiser fired on the 392-ton Dutch coastal vessel Dora in the Gulf of Finland Monday, the ship's owners learned here today.

The recent renewal of political hostilities between Mayor Wagner and Governor Dewey over city-state financial relations can be attributed to a belief, on both sides, that the issue will influence many votes in the fall state elections.

As the Foreign Ministers of the six nations comprising the European Defense Community meet in Brussels today to pass on the drastic changes demanded by France, it is evident that it will take superlative statesmanship to overcome the crisis facing them. Nothing else can save the project from a collapse which would have incalculable consequences for Europe and for the free world.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- W. Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, accused the Republicans in Albany and Washington here tonight of starting what he called "a cold-blooded campaign to camouflage the real facts about unemployment"
