WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States and Canada agreed formally in an exchange of notes today upon joint construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
VIENNA, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Rumania has reshuffled her Communist Government, dismissed one Vice Premier and increased the number of Vice Premiers from three to five, the Bucharest radio announced today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18 -- Gradual desegregation of the Tennessee public schools will be proposed to the United State Supreme Court by state attorneys. Desegregation would begin with the first grade and move upward over a period of years through the elementary and high schools.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Wheat prices showed much strength early in today's session and there appeared to be accumulation on the setbacks. But with weakness developing in corn and soybeans prices had a sharp recession from the top levels of the day.

Four new housing developments will be started by the New York City Housing Authority in the next six months. The cost of the projects, three in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx, is estimated at $48,000,000.

A syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. will offer to investors today a new issue of $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds of the Southern California Edison Company.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 -- Argentina has renewed her trade agreement with the Soviet Union for another year even though the latter did not live up to its major commitments under the 1953 pact.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 480,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end, total supplies were 156,328,000 barrels, compared with 156,808,000 a week earlier and 141,655,000 a year ago.
Shyness and love of books and music emerged yesterday as a behavior pattern for the four adolescents accused of having brutally beaten defenseless persons in Brooklyn.
YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- Thousands of persons were jolted shortly after 7 o'clock tonight by an explosion that apparently was a part of the construction work on the New York-Buffalo Thruway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Senate today voted for a $1,500,000,000 increase in the borrowing power of the Commodity Credit Corporation, raising the limit to $10,000,000,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.

Maybe the Giants are really out of their slump. On a pair of homers by Dusty Rhodes that were good for five runs and a solid job of pitching by Sal Maglie, the New Yorkers defeated the Phillies, 6 -- 2, for the second time in a row yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The United States Seventh Fleet will do "whatever is militarily expedient" in the defense of Formosa, Admiral Stump said here today.
SELLA VAL SUGANA, Italy, Thursday, Aug. 19 -- Dr. Alcide de Gasperi, former Premier of Italy, died today at the age of 73, the official news agency ANSA said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Eight skippers registered repeat triumphs in the second day of competition in the sixth annual Manhasset Bay junior race series. There were fifty helmsmen on hand as the youngsters continued the point-scoring fight leading to the Clinton M. Bell Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Only the signature of President Eisenhower was needed today to make law of a farm bill that would let prices perform a greater role in guiding crop production.

DACCA, East Pakistan, Aug. 17 -- Seventeen United States Air Force planes, flying from three continents, are bringing tons of supplies for victims of a flood that has inundated 36,000 square miles of East Pakistan -- an area as large as Illinois.

Coffee futures again dived the 2-cents-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. This was the third consecutive day of limit declines. The price fall was influenced by the easing of the Brazilian exchange rates which permits the dollar to buy more coffee.

A bullish flurry in defaulted dollar bonds of the Greek Government was touched off yesterday by announcement that Athens had agreed to take up with bondholders' representatives on Sept. 20 the question of putting the Greek debt back into good standing.
Sales and earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in the first six months this year were the third highest for any half year.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Seven more Labor party members of Parliament are to visit Communist China.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- Robert Schuman, leading proponent of European integration who as Foreign Minister signed the European Defense Community treaty on behalf of France, declared today that the proposals Premier Pierre Mendes-France, now was submitting in Brussels would be unacceptable.
Aggregate draft indebtedness of Latin-American countries to United States exporters continued to increase in July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

" We Remained," by Col. Russell W. Volckmann, has been scheduled for Sept. 21 publication by Norton. It is an account by the commander of the American- Filipino guerrillas in Northern Luzon of the three-year fight behind the Japanese lines in the Philippines.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 18 -- For the first time since 1936, the Metropolitan Golf Association's triangular competition for the Stoddard Trophy ended in a tie today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, Auxiliary Roman Catholic Bishop of Chicago, today denounced "demagogues" and "emotional charlatans" who preached fear and intolerance as the path to national solidarity.
Passage by Congress of bills outlawing the Communist Party drew varied comment in statements issued yesterday.

The Under Secretaryship of State in our country is always a position of importance but it is especially so at the present moment. In Britain, France and most other European countries the "Permanent Secretary" or "Secretary General" or whatever his title may be is a civil servant from the diplomatic corps.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A typhoon that hammered southern Japan with crushing winds and torrential downpours yesterday switched course today and lost much of its punch as it veered eastward toward the Pacific Ocean.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States announced today that four of its six divisions in Korea would be withdrawn "within the next several months."

LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. told a Democratic audience tonight that Republican "mishandling" of the Long Island Rail Road situation might cause further fare increases.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Somewhere along the line one of the two top teams in the American League might stumble. The Yankees are determined not to be "it."

Birth rate statistics tell us that a baby is born every eight seconds --a prospect that pleases manufacturers of baby products. Since sales are made to mama and papa, many of these products are designed with adults in mind.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 18 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, arrived here tonight for the conference of the six European Defense Community treaty powers with the hope of avoiding a rupture with France.

Directors of the American Oil Company at the first board meeting of the newly reorganized company yesterday elected D. J. Smith as president. Robert E. Wilson was made chairman of the board. Formerly a marketing company, American has become an integrated organization with its own production, refining and transportation facilities.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Directors of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet, junior company of the famed Sadler's Wells Ballet, rejected today wage demands of the thirty dancers of the junior company and announced the cancellation of performances that had been scheduled to begin at the Sadler's Wells Theatre in September.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Senate's two inquiries into the official conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy moved forward slowly today.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- With four cases of poliomyelitis diagnosed at Shrub Oak, the community in Yorktown was declared an emergency area by the New York State Health Department today.
PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, hero of the battle of Dienbienphu, will be released by his Vietminh captors in the near future, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Conferences toward settling the nineteen-day-old strike of pilots and copilots against the American Airlines were suspended today without an agreement.

ISLAND PARK, L. I., Aug. 18 -- A Coast Guard air-sea operation rescued a fishing party, including an Assemblyman and two Nassau County officials, early this morning after their disabled craft was spotted by a Coast Guard plane twelve miles off the south shore of Long Island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Senate without dissent confirmed Herbert Hoover Jr. today as Under Secretary of State, less than twenty-four hours after he had been nominated.

Why is it that the meals are better during vacation? All right, cook, do not jump -- and put down that skillet. It is not a weapon, and besides no offense was intended. Winter and summer, at home and away, the cook is the same, and a remarkably fine one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States is now modifying its foreign policy much more rapidly than is generally realized either at home or abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Bishop John Peter of Communist Hungary would violate his entry visa to this country if he held a press conference at the World Council of Churches, the State Department said today. The Bishop yesterday addressed the conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A compromise agreement tomorrow on the bill to outlaw the Communist party was predicted late tonight by Senator William F. Knowland, majority leader.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- radical reorganization of the Soviet school curriculum will place more emphasis on preparation for work in the factories and fields and on inculcation of "love for work and respect for working people." At the same time, much greater attention will be paid to anti-religious propaganda.

Following the trend of the last two days, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday that it would reduce retail coffee prices 10 cents a pound in its stores throughout the nation.
The boom in toll turnpike building is making a part-time historian of one of Wall Street's bond veterans.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Homestretch Eddie, a 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by William R. Cudney of Alloway, N. J., and driven by William Hudson, won the featured Indiana Pace in 2:16 over the mile and one-sixteenth route tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Arnold Cohen of New York, who had an accuracy percentage of 99.84, was announced tonight as winner of the annual shorthand speed contest conducted by the National Shorthand Reporters Association.

Collector of Customs Robert W. Dill notified all inspection and are personnel yesterday that no vacation could be taken between Aug. 23 and Sept. 17 because of the volume baggage expected to arrive then at the city's piers and airports.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A British correspondent with the Labor delegation in Peiping, John Ridley of The London Daily Telegraph, who had been in China before the Communist take-over, gave this description of Peiping under the Reds:

George Gainford, a boxing manager, has filed suit in Supreme Court for $150,000 against Kid Gavilan, world's champion welterweight. In his complaint, Mr. Gainford said he entered into a contract in 1947 with the fighter for 10 per cent of his earnings.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it intended to sell $250,000,000 of new bonds at competitive bidding on Sept. 21. The bonds will be dated Sept. 15 and will mature on the same date in 1984.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Washington Park stewards today indefinitely suspended a veterinarian and two horse handlers, but exonerated Harry Trotsek, the trainer, in the alleged doping of Hasty House Farm's Mister Black.

" The Barefoot Contessa," Joseph L. Mankiewicz' romantic drama in Technicolor co-starring Humphrey Bogart and Ava Gardner, will have its world premiere at the Capitol Theatre early in October for the benefit of CARE, the world-wide relief and rehabilitation agency, it was jointly announced yesterday by Paul Comly French, executive director of CARE, and Arthur B. Krim, president of United Artists.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox, led by Minnie Minoso and Chico Carrasquel, handed the Baltimore Orioles their eighth straight defeat tonight, 4 -- 1, as Sandy Consuegra won his fifteenth game of the season. Minoso and Carrasquel made three hits apiece.

After drifting lower in early dealings, stock prices yesterday improved selectively and final prices were irregularly higher. The steels, aircrafts and some oils started out under pressure, but recovered most of their losses.

Women soldiers and a male master sergeant shared honors yesterday at a retreat parade at Fort Jay, Governors Island, marking the tenth anniversary of the arrival of Women's Army Corps members at the post.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The President of Britain's Board of Trade is touring the Lancashire cotton textile industry to look into fears expressed there about Japanese and Indian competition.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The New Jersey Public Utility Commission today authorized the Atlantic City Electric Company to sell 72,000 shares of 4.1 per cent cumulative preferred stock to five insurance companies and one bank.

THE gathering of the Hall of Fame immortals at the Yankee Stadium last Saturday had to be regarded as a command performance, even for a guy on vacation. The lure of the old-timers was so irresistible that a busman's holiday was in order. If this be treason, make the most of it.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Western diplomats completed today a preliminary draft of a joint reply to a Soviet invitation for two conferences on European problems later this year.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the close last Friday was the largest in more than twenty-two years -- 3,079,590 shares -- the Exchange reported yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Saul Weinsier of Fresh Meadow took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Women's Cross County Golf Association's! 54-hole medal play championship at Glen Oaks today. Mrs. Weinsier posted 40, 41 -- 81.

A brief meeting yesterday afternoon between representatives of shipyard workers and the Bethlehem Steel Company ended with another break-off of negotiations, but without any threat of an immediate strike.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 -- The Circus Saints and Sinners received gratis from the State Division of Employment Security last year a wide variety of office furniture, equipment and supplies, as well as theatrical costumes, an official of the Jersey agency testified under oath here today.

A prudent lender of credit to home owners for improvement of their property does not need Federal Housing Administration insurance, according to the Instalment Credit Commission of the American Bankers Association.

Our leaders have been saying much about the need for "closer cooperation among the Western Allies," about the advantages of "integration in Europe" or of "more unity in the West." In these indefinite remarks there does not seem to be reflected a clear realization that what we need most is organization -- adequate in amount and suitable in design.

PEIPING, Aug. 18 -- Members of the visiting British Labor party delegation and British correspondents entered a Chinese Communist jail on a conducted tour today. They were not allowed to speak to any of the 2,000 male and female prisoners.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Karl Olson's single with two out in the eleventh inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 9-8 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

Color is an intrinsic part of the decor, not merely an accent or a background, in B. Altman's Young Homemakers model rooms, which open today. One single color confronts the eye in many of the seventeen rooms on display.
The wanton brutality attributed to four Brooklyn youths shocked and perplexed investigators yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Motion picture studio union officials were warned today that their efforts to prevent the filming in England of American-sponsored television movies could lead to a boycott of Hollywood's theatrical features in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The State Department denied today that it had intended or ever considered demanding the recall of Georgi N. Zaroubin, Soviet Ambassador, on the ground that he insulted the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Senator McCarran, who had a big hand in drafting the changes in the bill to outlaw the Communist party, said they were designed to "preserve and maintain in full force and effect the Internal Security Act," of which he is the author.

UP on Cape Cod last week, Bill. Hill, skipper of the Sports Port in Hyannis, took us on an expedition back in the pine woods to meet Ralph Perry, a little roly-poly leprechaun of a man standing not much over five feet in his socks.

The Fund for the Republic announced yesterday the election of W. H. Ferry as vice president. In making the announcement, Robert M. Hutchins, president of the organization, said Mr. Ferry had withdrawn from partnership in Earl Newsom Co., public relations counsel, of 597 Madison Avenue.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Five American teams and Australia's three tandems gained the quarter-finals in the national tennis doubles championships today on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.

It is something of a novelty for the City Planning Commission to hear a department head drastically reduce a request for construction funds. Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Commissioner of Hospitals, recommended that building of $52,677,000 in facilities previously sought from capital budget funds be deferred until the need was restudied.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Wyoming Republican voters chose the state's lone Representative in Congress, William Henry Harrison, to oppose a Democratic veteran of Washington politics, former Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, in the Nov. 2 election for the United States Senate.
Twenty - eight public school teachers are scheduled to be called for questioning about possible membership in the Communist party when the school term begins next month.
Washington, Aug. 18 -- Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, since 1946, is expected to be nominated for a new four-year term.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Sammy Boulmetis booted home five winners, including three in a row; today at the Atlantic City race track.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Warren Spahn, flashing the form that made him the leading earned-run pitcher in the National League last year, limited the St. Louis Cardinals to five hits tonight to give the Milwaukee Braves a 3-1 victory before 40,370 fans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- John Morrell Co. announced today that it had acquired the beef-slaughtering plant of the Tobin Packing Company in Estherville, Iowa, and the majority of the common stock in Roberts Oake, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has advised producers of winter-grown fresh vegetables to cut acreage 4 per cent below 1953-54 levels. The Department also suggested a 10 per cent cut in 1955 winter season potatoes grown in Florida, but no change in the Texas winter potato crop.

The American Sulphur and Refining Company announced yesterday it had acquired from the Standard Oil Development Company exclusive license to a process for extracting sulphur from ores by means of solvents.
Strong support is growing for the re-establishment of Townsend Harris High School for superior students.
Fashions geared to both business and college life were shown yesterday at Saks-34th.
The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to hold a public hearing Sept. 15 on its own plan to clear and redevelop six areas considered substandard in the southwest Bronx.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- In a bout of savage flurries that left both fighters battered and groggy, Gil Turner tonight gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Al Andrews and started back on his way to welterweight contention.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- World food production rose faster in 1953-54 than the increase of population, but the hunger of the world's underfed millions decreased by only an infinitesimal amount, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today.
DENVER, Aug. 18 -- An advance party was busy today preparing for President Eisenhower's summer vacation, which is expected to start here next week-end -- if Congress obliges with adjournment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation has before it a report from the Revenue Service approving tax refunds to the General Motors Corporation totaling $206,000,000, an informed source said today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the Eisenhower Administration had disillusioned the public about the "great crusade." He declared the Republican party was "divided, embittered and querulous."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A Panamanian delegation that has been negotiating with the United States Government since Sept. 10, 1953, will return home with a set of counter-proposals to demands made by Panama.
A new board of directors, which includes 60 per cent of the old board, took over control of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday after the road had spent five and a half years in bankruptcy.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A spritely French-Canadian -- Joseph Le Blanc of Montreal -- beat favorites from two nations today in the Canadian amateur golf championship, including the defending titleholder, Don Cherry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- In spite of difficulties encountered by four members of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra in obtaining United States visas, the projected tour here by the organization will proceed as scheduled, the Netherlands Embassy announced tonight.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Gabby grandpas, meddling aunts and ancient tramps shown in the films are prejudicing Americans against old age, eight state lawmakers complained today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Clifford Mooers' Traffic Judge today scored a victory by a nose over Rock Pilot in the $23,850 Prairie State Stakes at Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Officials of two Government agencies worked overtime today to make good on President Eisenhower's unusual offer to open the books on his controversial proposal for new private power facilities in the Tennessee Valley area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Ignoring a request by President Eisenhower to delay action, the Senate today passed a bill intended to give Reserve officers of all the armed services the same promotion opportunities held by regular officers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The White House today announced the appointment of John tt. Sfambaugh as assistant to Clarence B. Randall, special consultant to the President for foreign economic policy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Conn McCreary dearly loves to ride a horse that stays back in the pack in the run to the stretch and then cuts loose with an up-and-at-'em charge. He had that kind of mount in the $23,850 Diana Handicap today and she carried him to a length-and-a-half victory.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 489 pints of blood Tuesday. The largest collection, totaling 152 pints, was taken at the Bulova Watch Company, 75-20 Astoria Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, on the first day of a two-day donation.

LUDLOW, N. J., Aug. 18 -- A young man stepped into a cabbage patch near here late one day recently and beckoned to a group of Puerto Rican migrants. The response was instantaneous. They dropped their tools and eagerly followed him into a barn that serves as a school.
PARIS, Aug. 18 -- French and Tunisian leaders agreed today to begin a conference to establish Tunisia's internal autonomy Sept. 4 or 6 in Tunis.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 -- The Dodgers beat the Pirates tonight, but the surprising young men from Pittsburgh scared the Brooks mightily before the 3-2 triumph was achieved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Having broadly hinted that favoritism for the financial interests of a golfing partner may explain why the President personally ordered the Atomic Energy Commission to execute the controversial Dixon-Yates contract for power supply, and got himself in trouble by doing so, Chairman Mitchell of the Democratic National Committee has shifted his target to the mysterious "They."

Helen Hayes will be seen at the New York City Center this winter in James M. Barrie's romantic comedy "What Every Woman Knows." Kent Smith will serve as her co-star, and John Stix, the young director who guided the actress in the revival of "Mary Rose" for the American National Theatre and Academy, will attend to the staging.

Chairman Stephen A. Mitchell of the Democratic National committee has done his best to reduce this year's political campaign to the lowest possible level. He had a perfect right to question the wisdom of the President's action in ordering the Atomic Energy Commission to contract for a private power plant to replace T. V. A. power which the Commission was using.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, was urged yesterday by the New York City C. I. O. Council to repudiate his previous endorsement of Representative James G. Donovan. Mr. Donovan is seeking renomination and re-election as a Democrat in the Eighteenth District, East Harlem. He is unopposed for the Republican nomination.

GAEVLE, Sweden, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Audun Boysen of Norway betterred his own world record for the 1,OO0-meter run today when he raced the distance in 2 minutes 19.5 seconds in an international track and field meet at Stroemvallen Stadium.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Attempts to enroll some Negroes in Dade County white schools will be made in September, an attorney representing the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today.
A pangolin from the "death area" of Spanish Guinea, West Africa, awoke yesterday to find itself on the Jersey City docks.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Illinois Terminal Railroad accepted an offer of $20,015,635 for the line today from a group of railroads.
TORONTO, Aug. 18 -- The effects of unhappy marriages on children were labeled today as a great, potentially destructive force menacing Western society.
HOUSTON, Tex., sold $7,000,000 of street improvement bonds due from 1955 to 1979 to Drexel Co. and associates yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.0876 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., meeting here for the thirty-seventh annual convention, re-affirmed the dismissal of its secretary - treasurer, Irvin R. Kuenzli, after seven hours of wrangling that ended early this morning.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The stock market setback continued today, although selling again was light. Prices fell gently and closed for the most part without recovery.

Your editorial of Aug. 12 advocating the fluoridation of New York City's water supply fails to state the following vital facts: Fluoride is a poison; placing it in drinking water is injurious to older people and to those suffering from such diseases as cancer and damaged kidneys; also it does not prevent the decay of children's teeth.

The shocking series of brutal crimes in Brooklyn for which four boys from 15 to 18 years of age are held leaves one aghast and bewildered. The usual motives seem to be absent. The usual explanations of home background do not sufficiently explain.
YONKERS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Rose Adios won the $8,000 Pelham Pace tonight before 17,070 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Military officials were skeptical today about Chinese Communist threats to invade Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- An appropriation bill entailing cuts of nearly $800,000,000 in foreign aid outlays proposed by President Eisenhower was approved tonight by a conference committee of the Senate and House of Representatives.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Scoring all their runs on homers by Bobby Avila and Al Smith, the Cleveland Indians defeated Detroit, 4 -- 0, today for their eighth victory in a row. The shutout was the sixteenth triumph for Early Wynn, who allowed six scattered hits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Government may guarantee up to 100 per cent of mortgages on new ocean vessels under a measure passed by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Three-dimensional pictures, the new, wider type screens and projection equipment required to keep pace with recent developments in motion pictures have proved a boon to the export branch of the movie industry.

Letters from our readers provide the subject for today's column. Some ask questions, as in the case of a Connecticut woman whose home-baked whole-wheat bread does not rise to look as tall and fat as the commercial product. Another offers a recipe she discovered in her own kitchen.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 -- Greece will submit the dispute with Britain over Cyprus to the United Nations General Assembly on Friday. Only British agreement to bilateral talks with Greece would avert the move and no one here expects such an accord.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 -- Mr. Pearson explained today the reason for Canadian participation in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Nellie Fox's fourth straight hit drove in the winning run for a come - from - behind 4-3 Chicago victory over the Baltimore Orioles today. A torrential rain in the ninth inning held up the game an hour and seven minutes.
Wolfram Block of Emden, Germany, is another of the many foreign tourists who have seized the glad hand of America.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- A reversal of the party positions on the ratification of the European Defense Community treaty appears to be in the making here. The move results from the protocol to the treaty that Premier Pierre Mendes- France proposed today in Brussels to France's five partners in the proposed accord.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Jack Burke Jr. of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., carded 34, 32 -- 66 over the soggy par-72 Elks Country Club course today to take the first-round lead in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, tonight accused fellow Senators of talking one another to death and "picking the taxpayers' pockets" to pay the cost of printing millions of useless words.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Republican Day speech at the Illinois State Fair in Springfield yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission called a halt on the downtrend of Texas oil production today, ordering an increase of 67,235 barrels a day in the allowable for September. That will mean a permissive flow of 2,792,276 barrels a day.
A reversal in circus entertainment was rehearsed yesterday afternoon with 150 children in the principal roles instead of grown-ups.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Only a part-time salmon fisherman, who took up golf on a bet, kept the United States from making a sweep into the semi-finals of the fiftieth Canadian amateur golf championship.
TRENTON, Aug. 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared here today that inaction by the State Senate had made "impossible" his plan to reorganize state motor vehicle procedures next year.

A 21-year-old candy vender was charged early today with homicide in the killing of a passer-by during a wild fusillade in front of a Harlem tavern. The police said he also wounded two other men before he was shot and captured by an off-duty patrolman.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower's visit today to the Illinois State Fair was the second in the 102-year history of the event by a President of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions' defensive backfield kept the Philadelphia Eagles in check tonight while Bobby Layne, quarterback, passed for two touchdowns in a 17-14 victory before 45,600. The exhibition at Municipal Stadium was the annual Philadelphia Inquirer charities contest.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Peter Thorneycroft, president of the Board of Trade, said today the British Government had made "the strongest representations" to the Government or India regarding the quota and tariff restrictions it had imposed on British textiles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Government is preparing to move for a new perjury indictment of Owen Lattimore, Far Eastern expert.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Neither San Francisco, its birthplace, nor any other city has yet bid for the privilege of entertaining the 1955 session of the General Assembly during its tenth anniversary observance next year.

Trade reports yesterday that Brazil had removed the unofficial minimum price from cocoa dropped prices the 1-cent-a-pound limit in all positions on the New York Cocoa Exchange. There was some trading before the rumors reached the floor but by noon there was very little activity.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower called on all religions today to join in "simultaneous and fervent" prayers for peace.
DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 19 -- Millions of victims of the East Pakistan flood were threatened with greater disaster as the waters of the Brahmaputra River rose today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton, a prominent figure in the Army-McCarthy dispute, is being retired for health reasons at the end of the month, the Army announced today.

That a member of Pennsylvania's highest judicial tribunal should have used your columns to reprove a previous correspondent, John R. Fitzpatrick, for suggesting control as a more effective weapon against communism than outlawry, may have surprised your New York readers.
Because of overcrowding, due in part to the current police campaign against upsurging crime, 500 inmates of the workhouse on Rikers Island will be transferred today to Hart Island.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 -- Big Don Newcombe failed to finish a game for the ninth straight time today, but, thanks to "early foot" by his mates, gained his seventh triumph.

A shopping center at Deer Park Avenue and Mohawk Drive in Babylon, L. I., has been sold by Michael and Anthony Savino, builders, to the Small Investors Real Estate Plan, Inc., which has acquired it for fifty-three individual investors. The property in turn has been leased to the Sire Plan Management Corporation which will manage the investment for the owners.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The state is opening a drive to make smokers pay the 3-cent-a-pack New York tax on cigarettes they buy by mail from other states.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., meeting here in its thirty-seventh annual convention, today adopted a militant program for Federal aid to education.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Izvestia, Soviet Government newspaper, published an apology today for "irritating inaccuracies" in a recent article on the living conditions of Scottish coal miners.

Mayor Wagner has appointed a special committee to study the advisability of enlarging the Bronx Terminal Market to provide facilities for wholesale produce dealers now housed in the ancient Washington Market on the lower West Side of Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Chief Justice of the United States declared here today that the "American system" was under test and that "the way it works" would "in the long run do more to make it secure and the object of adulation than the number of hydrogen bombs we stockpile."

OMAHA, Aug. 19 -- Directors of the Air Force Association called here today for the definition of nuclear weapons as legitimate and conventional instruments against aggression. They said they saw no evidence that peaceful coexistence with the Soviet Union was possible.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The Metropolis Country Club team, consisting of three amateurs with their professional, Harry Cooper, won top honors in the John Hoffhine Memorial tourney today.
MILLBURN, N. J., Aug. 19 -- Two uranium-hunting geophysicists found the railway station's concrete platform a hotter radioactive sample today than the slope of South Mountain, 300 yards away.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Government today abandoned plans for a further expansion of primary aluminum production.
The Dior flat look received only disapproving glances from passers-by yesterday as the first copies appeared in a Fifth Avenue shop window.

Alcide De Gasperi was the greatest Italian of the post-war generation, a statesman who may well rank with Cavour when historians add and subtract the accomplishments and defects of his career. He was one of a select group of men whose actions transcended the limitations of their native countries to become European in scope.

The appointment of the Rev. James J. McGinley as dean of the Fordham University School of Business was announced yesterday. Father McGinley succeeds the Rev. Michael McPhelin, who has become associate director of university development.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it inadvertently had failed to note a later reversal on appeal of the convictions of two men it named in an announcement last week.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 19 (UP) -- A wage dispute involving about 4,500 unionized A. F. L. workers at two atomic research plants was settled today, while, in Washington, a Presidential panel took up a dispute over travel pay sought by 8,000 A. F. L. construction workers here.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 19 -- The somewhat dim but plausible outlines of a possible compromise on the French proposals for a revision of the European Defense Community treaty became visible tonight to those gifted with imagination and aware of the resources of diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- An American scientist descended 1,700 feet into the iV[editerranean Sea last week in an attempt to solve one of the ocean's mysteries by photographs, the National GeoTaphic Society reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that in his first year in office the commission had eliminate dmore than half the procedural steps formerly taken in processing work.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Ministry of Transport reiterated today that British ships that engaged in trade with Communist China did not carry and prohibited strategic materials to that country.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Britain and Communist Hungary completed a trade agreement tonight calling for the exchange of 10,500,000 ($29,400,000) in food and goods in twelve months, the British Treasury said. The agreement runs from Sept. 1.
Deacon, the sociable greeter crow at the Children's Zoo in the Bronx Zoo, collapsed and died near his perch Wednesday at the end of a day's work. He was 14 years old.

The new contract between the New York City Transit Authority and the various unions is filled with repeated guarantees of management's right to manage and, on the other hand, union assurances of acceptance of this right and union promises to cooperate in economical operation of trains, buses and maintenance.
LITTLE FERRY, N. J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Stage Coach Inn, a night club on Route 46 about eight miles west of the George Washington Bridge, was virtually destroyed tonight by wind-lashed flames.

The first section of a 467-foot dock similar in general construction to the radar platforms being installed by the Government off the Atlantic Coast, was launched yesterday at the Pusey Jones Corporation shipyard in Wilmington, Del.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed "unreserved admiration" today for the record made in Palestine by General Bennike. The general has served as Chief of Staff since June, 1953.
Alternate-side parking will be extended next Monday to the East Side area from Central Park to the East River, between Fifty - ninth and Eighty - sixth Streets.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 1 to 10 points net lower than Wednesday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- In their sharpest form of the tournament, Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall of Australia defeated Gardnar Mulloy and Arthur Larsen today in the quarter-finals of the national tennis doubles championships.

The Eisenhower Administration is still not satisfied with the country's tax laws and will continue to work on the problem, it was asserted yesterday by Marion B. Folsom, Under Secretary of the Treasury.

OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ford Konno of the United States, an Olympic champion, nosed out Bill Woolsey, a team-mate, and Yoshihiro Shoji of Japan in the 400-meter free-style race in the last day of an international swimming meet tonight.
A 17-year-old Bronx youth was shot and critically wounded last night when he apparently was mistaken as belonging to one of two feuding teen-aged gangs.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System is showing an unusually deep faith in Jack Paar. It has assigned him to go on television at 7 o'clock in the morning and tell jokes that will make people laugh.

PEIPING, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Clement R. Attlee and seven other British Labor party leaders dined tonight at Peiping's famed Summer Palace, former home of the Chinese Emperors, on the eve of their departure for Manchuria.

THE HAGUE. The Netherlands. Aug. 19. -- The Netherlands Foreign Ministry published today a biting commentary on Indonesia's plan to have the forthcoming United Nations General Assembly discuss her claim to sovereignty over West New Guinea.

" Modern Germany: Its History and Civilization," a study of the rise, fall and resurgence of modern Germany, will be published Sept. 7 by Macmilan. The author is Koppel S. Pinson, professor of history at Queens College, who has based his book on more than twenty years' study.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Public Works Department today received low bids totaling $8,768,812 for contracts that will include construction of the first 12.89 miles of Thruway between Buffalo and the Pennsylvania border.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- In its final form the anti-Communist measure, which for a time did extreme violence to several constitutional guarantees including due process of law and the right of American citizens to adhere to the political philosophy of their choice, is mainly a philippic and implies no attempted abridgment of the freedom of the courts to decide the applicability of its penalties to those individuals who may be arraigned under its provisions.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- Only 3,116 fans, the smallest crowd ever attracted to an after-dark contest in which the Yankees were involved, saw the world champions batter the Philadelphia Athletics, 8 -- 5, for their tenth straight victory tonight.

" HE is not in our social set. Lincoln's an amusing enough fellow, but he is not the kind of man a Todd would be interested in." In spite of such well-meant words of caution, Mary Todd, a proud and brilliant daughter of Blue Grass aristocrats, married Abraham Lincoln, a self-educated frontier lawyer whose father was nearly illiterate.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Halfway between the village of Montauk and the lighthouse on the point of Long Island you turn left into a lane that leads you to an attractive gabled house on the eastern shore of Lake Montauk. That is Rosie's house.
Following is the text of remarks by President Eisenhower at the Assembly of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Louis S. Rothschild, Federal Maritime Administrator, has set up a new policy on the transfer of idle Liberty freighters to foreign flags.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $45,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today his plans to reshuffle the United Nations high command under which the posts of assistant secretary general will be abolished.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 19 -- The Boer-British hostility that divides the white population of South Africa has flared up again.
A 59-year-old post office employe with a reported weakness for horse racing was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of misappropriating $1,433.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Paul Gregory has completed arrangements for the purchase of "The Naked and the Dead."

BRUSSELS, Belgium. Aug. 19 -- The hope of the West German delegation to salvage the European Defense Community treaty improved somewhat today after Belgium's Foreign Minister had submitted a proposal to disjoin the new substantive and interpretive clauses proposed by the French Premier.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 19 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan gave his opponents a thorough trouncing in the provincial elections here yesterday.
Four Brooklyn youths, each handcuffed to a detective, identified yesterday a bruised body dragged from the East River as that of a man they had killed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- An angry row over the weighing time was settled late today and the Carl (Bobo) Olson-Rocky Castellani world middleweight title fight will be held tomorrow night as scheduled.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- A successful fashion industry is rising out of the ruins of West Berlin. New factories have been built on the sites of old ones and are busily employed rebuilding the industry that had had such a good start before World War II.
M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., giant textile concern, announced yesterday that it had acquired the 109-year-old Wamsutta Mills.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A strike against the Anaconda Copper Mining Company was called today by the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, an independent union. It is set for Monday.
The chief of the Transit Authority's police force reported yesterday "a very serious crime situation" on the city-owned subway, elevated and surface lines.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Securities prices continued to fall here today but were looking steadier at the close.

ROME, Aug. 19 -- A line of woebegone people moved all day up a dusty lane to a little house in Sella Val Sugana, where Dr. Alcide De Gasperi, Italy's great post-war Premier, lay in state. He died at 2:30 this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug 19 (AP) -- Western railroads today rejected Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson's request for a 50 per cent reduction in freight rates on hay and livestock for drought-stricken areas.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 19 -- Four destroyers of the United States Seventh Fleet made a "show of strength" visit today to the Tachen Islands, Nationalist outposts guarding the northern approaches of Formosa.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The competition -- and the fun -- went out of the beverwyck Steeplechase today when Mrs. Clara Elizabeth Adams' Escargot suffered a crippling injury. The winner of seven straight races made a three- legged clearance of the water jump in front of the stands and then was taken off the course in a horse ambulance and destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, attacked Senator McCarthy today with a Senate speech of tribute to Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican of New Jersey, who is leaving Congress after this session.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Congressional action was completed tonight on the foreign aid appropriation bill, the last of the session's money measures. It now goes to the White House.

Three portions of the sixteen-acre Juniper Ledge estate in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., have been purchased by separate buyers from H. Fisk Tarbox, an executive of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, according to Previews, Inc. The sales were negotiated by Donn Mervin of Ossining as broker. About ten acres of the property, mostly woodland, remains to be sold.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Following is the text of the address delivered by Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, at the dedication of the American Bar Center here this afternoon:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Defense Department accused the Chinese Communists today of holding fifteen United States airmen against their will as "political prisoners."
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Finance Minister U Tin told Parliament here today that the Government would seek loans from the World Bank over the next few years.

MANILA, Aug. 19 -- Plans for an eight-nation foreign ministers' conference Sept. 6 on a Southeast Asia treaty organization are taking definite shape here, both as to the pact and physical arangements.
YONKERS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Red Sails, winner of the Detroit Pacing Derby in June, scored an upset in the rain and mud tonight at Yonkers Raceway by winning the $28,500 Good Time Pace.
TORONTO, Aug. 19 -- A former chief psychiatrist at Sing Sing prison said today that existing penal institutions were "self-defeating" and should be completely reorganized.

The passage of the conference version of the new agricultural support bill means a major victory, in principle, for the concept of flexible farm price supports. Instead of being forced to support "basic" crops at 90 per cent of that mythical concept, "parity," the Administration will have a choice of support prices down to 82.5 per cent of parity for those crops -- cotton, wheat, corn, peanuts and rice.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Cincinnati swept a double-header from the Chicago Cubs today, 7 to 0 and 6 to 3, to climb into fourth place in the National League by less than a percentage-point margin over the Philadelphia Phillies.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- An Austrian politician bitterly attacked the Western High Commissioners of Austria today for rejecting two laws passed by the Austrian Parliament. He accused the West of siding with the Communists to keep discord and hatred alive in Austria.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 19 -- Three of Thailand's top leaders said yesterday that the country would admit United States troops only if invaded, according to a usually reliable Government source.
There is no sign yet in New York City of the upturn in business lending common at this time of the year.

A total of 634 pints of blood was collected Wednesday by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Included were 308 pints taken at Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., and 123 at the New York Naval Receiving Station, New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

A magistrate in Queens lashed out yesterday at four youths arraigned before him on robbery charges and, noting their previous records. said that justice had been a "revolving door" for them. He said that justice had been turning the defendants in and out of jail "and merely postponing the time of new crimes."

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 20 -- The Far East Command announced today that the United States Second Infantry Division would be withdrawn from South Korea to the United States and the Twenty-fifth Division to Hawaii "in the immediate future."
JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada arrived today to deal with the problem of Israeli-Arab relations.
Washington officials indicated yesterday that they expected major court tests when attempts were made to put into full effect the bill, if it became law, outlawing the Communist party.

A Brooklyn couple discovered yesterday that children are cheaper by the baker's dozen. After delivering their thirteenth baby, the hospital told them that this one was on the house. When William, the smallest (seven pounds, five ounces) and cheapest of the Arthur Wallace family was born at 7:15 A. M., he became the thirteenth Wallace baby in sixteen years to be delivered at Midwood Hospital, 19 Winthrop Street, Flatbush.

When advertising men use pictures of money, securities or postage stamps in their product they come close at times to the province of the counterfeiter. The National Better Business Bureau, Inc., which seeks to keep advertisers out of trouble, made it clear yesterday that restrictions are still in force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Federal Mediator Leverett Edwards met today with both sides in the pilots' strike against American Airlines and scheduled another meeting for tomorrow. Mediation officials had no comment on the progress of today's talks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Sales by hardware wholesalers last year totaled $2,329,000,000, a gain of 4.1 per cent compared with 1952, the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce announced today.

POTSDAM, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Teachers themselves have been "slow learners" when it comes to training pupils with lower than average intelligence, according to Joseph C. McLain, principal of Mamaroneck High School.

Earl Browder, who was denounced and dismissed from his post as national secretary of the Communist party in 1946, has agreed to testify on the "organizational strength" of that group before the Senate Rules Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 685,277 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- About 44 per cent of the $29,000,000,000 worth of defense and defense-supporting industry expansion programs authorized by the Government since Oct. 30, 1950, had been completed by March 31 this year, it was announced today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 19 -- Full support of a national campaign by organized labor against state anti-closed shop laws was voted today by delegates to the ninety-sixth convention of the International Typographical Union here.

Dr. Norman Jolliffe, director of the city Health Department's Bureau of Nutrition, will leave for Formosa and India on Aug. 30 to study nutrition problems. In Formosa, he will give courses, on public health nutrition at two medical schools.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Following is the text of the Communist Control Act of 1954 outlawing the Communist party and stripping Red-infiltrated unions of rights under the National Labor Relations Board (S3706) as it passed the Senate and House of Representatives in amended form today:

The happy combination of tight pitching and the home run clicked for the Giants again yesterday. A seven-hitter by Ruben Gomez and homers by Davey Williams, Ray Katt and Bobby Hofman carried the New Yorkers to a 5-0 triumph over the Phillies before 6,530 spectators at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ted Williams broke a batting slump today with a single and double as Boston defeated Washington, 11 -- 6. Williams, who had gone hitless seventeen straight times, also received four walks as the Red Sox pounded four pitchers for sixteen hits to sweep the three-game series and supplant the Senators in fifth place.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 19 -- Rupert Lockwood, Communist newspaperman, maintained today his refusal to give evidence to the Royal Commission on Russian Espionage on the ground it might be used to fram a criminal charge against him.

PANAMA, Aug. 19 -- Renegotiation of the United Fruit Company's contract with the Panama Government resulted in an agreement whereby the company's Chiriqui Land Company subsidiary would pay a 12 per cent additional annual income tax on net earnings.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 19 -- India has suggested to Portugal that her representatives confer in New Delhi next Tuesday on Lisbon's proposal that neutral observers study the situation in and around the Portuguese enclaves in India. Nationalists from Goa, one of the enclaves, seek to "liberate" the colonies.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service has reached an agreement with major international airlines under which most passengers arriving here in transit to another country will be paroled in the direct custody of the carrier companies.

Although at least one newspaper noted editorially that it seemed a pity so few people observed the anniversary -- when it occurred, the other day -- of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, there were after all a number of persons who remembered it.
THE teen-age sadists who killed two park vagrants and beat and set fire to others cannot be explained by the neighborhood in which they were bred.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The seventh annual American Dance Festival under the auspices of Connecticut College got under way tonight in Palmer Auditorium with a program by Jose Limon and his company, together with two guest artists: Yuriko and Daniel Nagrin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A modified bill to outlaw the Communist party in the United States was approved by both houses of Congress today, with only two votes against it.
Tampa, Fla., sold $4,500,000 of hospital revenue bonds due from 1956 to 1984 to John Nuveen Co. and associates yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.77 per cent.

CAIRO, Aug. 19 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egyptian Premier, said today that mutual defense pacts between the Arab world and the Western powers would have to wait until the Arabs had overcome their residual suspicion of Western imperialist intentions.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Gordon Jones, a major leaguer for only two weeks, throttled the pennant-hungry Milwaukee Braves with eight hits today and posted a 2-1 triumph for the St. Louis Cardinals today on Solly Hemus' sacrifice fly behind Wally Moon's triple in the tenth inning.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 19 -- A warrant for the arrest of Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, the former President, was issued today on formal charges of implication in the assassination of Col. Francisco Javier Arana in June, 1949.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Eight hundred more French Union prisoners of war reached freedom today from Vietminh camps. First official reports did not list Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries among those liberated.
One of the many virtues of the home freezer is its function as a "lunch bank." In it may be stored sandwiches, cakes, cookies, fruits and beverages, all packaged and ready for summer picnics.

PANAMA, Aug. 19 -- President Jose Antonio Remon said today at a news conference some progress had been made on a revision of the treaty with the United States. "But much remains to be done," he added.

It is only natural that we think of an airlift as a military operation. It is true that the spectacular Berlin airlift was one of supplies for the needy, but no one could have been unconscious of its overtones in a cold war. It was a test of strength, physi cally, and a display of purpose, morally.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 -- Detroit's troublesome Tigers split a double-header with the league-leading Cleveland Indians today. The Tigers got fourteen hits off three Cleveland pitchers in the second game to win, 8 -- 2, after losing the opener, 4 -- 3. The Detroit victory snapped the Tribe's winning streak at nine games.

Three new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Victoria is "Dragnet," a melodrama starring Jack Webb and featuring Ben Alexander, Richard Boone and Ann Robinson. The Warner Brothers release was written by Richard L. Breen and directed by Mr. Webb.

Twenty years ago this month, on Aug. 20, the United States took a historic step forward in the field of international cooperation by joining the International Labor Organization. Happily, the decision made at that time has proved to be mutually advantageous to the United States and to the I. L. O.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The National Association of Evangelicals said today it had requested the State Department to make representations to Colombia about criticism of Protestantism by President Gustav Rojas Pinilla.

The provision as carried in the tax reform bill giving relief to double taxation on corporate dividends was pretty scant. However, we who over the years have striven for legislation to mitigate the effect of double taxation of corporate income by allowing a limited credit against the income tax of the shareholder receiving dividends, should be grateful.
Increasing concern that spreading strikes may squeeze copper supplies next month was reported among consumers yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley took the lead in the Women's Cross County Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal-play championship at the Sands Point course today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Fred Hibberd Jr. of the American Yacht Club added another victory to his impressive string today. His second place in the Manhasset Bay Junior Lightning Class series captured the competition with six points.

After four months of negotiation, which at times became bitter, the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., agreed yesterday on a wage increase of 2.68 per cent.

THIS was after the Hall of Fame game at the Stadium last Saturday and the baseball immortals were sitting around, telling lies. At least some of their tales seemed to strain the truth a bit, although nothing actually was impossible for these fantastic performers of yesteryear. There was considerable kidding of Bill Terry for smashing a line drive home run into the grandstand not far from the right-field foul line.

The charge that "Hollywood is the arch-foe of the nation's senior citizens," made Wednesday at Albany in a report of the New York State Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging, was decried yesterday by the Motion Picture Association of America.
SPRINGFIELD Ill. Aug 19 -- President Eisenhower opened the 1954 Congressional campaign today by taunting the Democrats for predicting an economic depression.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today that Britain was repaying the dollars it had drawn since World War II. This move was taken by fund officials today as tangible evidence that Britain was moving toward convertibility.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley found only a few anti-trust cases that he believed should be dismissed. He said the Government had dropped only five anti-trust cases in the last year.

OTTAWA, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's official reserves of United States dollars and gold rose by $29,600,000 in July to a new high of $1,892,800,000. It was the third consecutive monthly increase in the reserves, which had dropped to $1,810,500,000 last April.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Seven weary Senators, judging the Army-McCarthy dispute, abandoned tonight any hopes for unanimity and sought ways to break their deadlock before Sunday morning. Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, and acting committee chairman, said that if the failure to reach any majority agreement continued beyond Sunday it might be necessary to postpone a final report until mid-September.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration announced today it had named Frank Meistrell, 51 years old, of New York, to replace its former general counsel, Burton C. Bovard.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. called last night for an open Democratic state convention, meaning one in which delegates would be free to vote their own preferences without dictation from party leaders.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation and its consolidated domestic and Canadian subsidiaries had an estimated net income of $2,558,000 in the quarter ended July 3, it reported yesterday. In the corresponding period last year, the net income was $1,617,000.

Abraham A. Zimmerman 24 years old, a research assistant in chemical engineering at New York University, was cut yesterday noon when a retort of chemicals exploded in his face in a laboratory. The explosion occurred in a small room in the basement of Nicholas Hall, a Chemistry Department building, near University Avenue and 181st Street, the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Earle and Roy Mack hinted today they had found an "angel" to save the Mack ownership of the Philadelphia Athletics and another source reported the plan involved selling their father's stock for $600,000 to someone who would then invest $2,000,000 more to rebuild the club.
American cities are pitching their tax hooks increasingly toward non-property levies for needed revenue, according to a recent survey by the Tax Institute, Inc., a nonprofit research organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- All grains and soybeans met broader buying demand on the setbacks that featured the early part of the session today, and developed a stronger tone. Wheat buying resistance appeared on fractional declines, with a rally to above the previous closing level.

More coffee prices are down. At Bohack stores, Savarin and Maxwell House coffees will sell at $1.16 a pound this morning, a 10-cent drop from yesterday's price. A spokesman for Safeway Stores reports that a wholesale drop of 10 cents a pound reported yesterday would be reflected at retail Monday.
TOKYO, Aug, 19 (UP) -- Communist China announced today pardons for 417 Japanese war criminals out of a total 1,000 believed held by the Reds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A 1,700 - kilowatt nuclear power plant, so compact that it can be transported by airplane in sections, is to be built at Fort Belvoir, Va., les than twenty-five miles from the Capital.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- A Brazilian Air Force spokesman absolved the Government of President Getulio Vargas today of any responsibility in the fatal shooting of Air Force Maj. Rubens Florentino Vaz, which plunged Brazil into a serious political crisis.

Heavy thunderstorms drenched most of the metropolitan area last night. A downpour that began in the city at 8:35 P. M. caused a ten-degree drop in the temperature within two hours, to cap an uncomfortably warm and muggy day.
Slight changes in one-way and round-trip fares are due to go into effect Sept. 1 on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. The changes will be both up and down.
Abraham Lincoln's story about the hog and the crooked fence -- which President Eisenhower cited yesterday in his attack on the "prophets of gloom and doom" -- was told by Lincoln in a court trial.

There has been an alarmed outcry in the Republic of Korea over the announcement that the United States proposed at some time within the next few months to withdraw an additional four divisions from Korea. The alarm is natural and understandable, since the Korean "man in the street" who has joined in the protest demonstrations cannot be expected to understand the strategic considerations that have dictated the American decision.

A particularly painful dispute within the family of Western nations and the North Atlantic alliance goes before the United Nations today when Greece submits for General Assembly consideration her complaints against Britain about Cyprus and requests a plebiscite in that island on union with "Mother Greece."

Westchester voters will be asked soon to approve the most costly single improvement in the county's history -- a $12,000,000 to $15,000,000 sewage treatment plant on the shore of the Hudson River at Yonkers. Linked to an old network of trunk sewer lines extending as far north as White Plains, the plant would replace two outmoded structures to serve an area of eighty-eight square miles containing 58 per cent of the county population.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The Balmain boutique collection ought to be an event in the lives of women who yearn for the Balmain look of sleek elegance but who must budget.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Plans are being considered for consolidation of the Westchester Bank and Trust Company, which has eight offices in White Plains, New Rochelle and Valhalla, and the First National Bank and Trust Company of Tuckahoe, which has a branch in Eastchester.

Pressmen on New York City newspapers have voted to accept a fact-finding panel's recommendation of a $3.75 weekly package increase. The vote, taken Wednesday night and announced yesterday, was 427 to 33.
Combined Canadian and United States production of newsprint have set a record for July of 600,303 tons, it was reported yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau.
Hastening to complete arrangements for the approaching fall season on Broadway, three producing groups signed players yesterday for incoming attractions.
Panama is exploring a plan to set up her own merchant marine onbecause she has no ships to carry on her own foreign trade, although she has the fourth largest merchant fleet registry in the world.
The Argentine naval training ship Bahia Thetis, which arrived here quietly enough four years ago, boomed a hearty hello to New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The purchase by an operator of a large Greenwich Village corner from the Edward Swann estate was announced yesterday along with reported plans for improving the site with a six-story apartment building.

The stock market yesterday extended its gains selectively to the highest level of the present upward movement, with the industrial issues leading. Some profit - taking was evident throughout most of the session, but final prices were much below their best for the day and only irregularly higher.

The bill depriving the Communist party of legal rights is an emphatic expression on the part of Congress that communism in this and every other country is "an instrumentality of a conspiracy" on behalf of the Soviet Union. With this judgment we believe practically every loyal American would agree.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 20 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, said today that this country should retaliate against an aggressor with every weapon in its arsenal, including nuclear weapons.
Justin R. Snyder has been named manager of the government contracts division office in Washington, D. C., for Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., Clifton, N. J.
Joseph J. Tumpeer has been appointed senior vice president of the Witco Chemical Company and will direct its Pioneer Asphalt division. Mr. Tumpeer has been associated with the company since 1921.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- The British Labor party mission to Communist China arrived today in this big industrial center, which has been virtually isolated from Western visitors since the Communist regime took over five years ago

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today announced the suspension of Maurice H. Golden, assistant chief construction examiner of its Los Angeles office, on charges of irregularities.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug, 20 -- India has resumed her propaganda offensive against Goa, Portuguese enclave on India's west coast.

The need for better training of policemen in New York has long been recognized. A School of Instruction within the Police Department was organized more than a century ago. In various reorganizations it traveled through changes of name -- Police Training School, Police Academy, Police College, and in 1934 back to Police Academy, as it is today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) --The i St. Louis Cardinals tonight tied a National League record by executing six double plays, but lost to Lefty Joe Nuxhall and the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3--2, when the potential tying run was thrown out at the plate in the ninth inning.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The Bavarian Metal Industry Association refused today to negotiate with the Bavarian Metal Workers Union on the compromise proposal to settle the strike advanced by Richard Oechsle, Bavarian Minister of Labor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The demand for grain futures was slow today, but on the other hand there was no aggressive selling and prices held in a moderate range most of the session. There was week-end evening up. Buyers showed little disposition to follow rallies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- For the second consecutive year, Belgium continued here today to boycott the United Nations General Assembly Committee on Information from non-self-governing territories. The seat reserved for the Belgian delegate remained vacant as the committee opened its fifth session, and elected Awni Kahlidy of Iraq as chairman.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Mexico gained a 2-0 Davis Cup lead over Canada today, winning both opening singles matches in the North American zone semifinals.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Aug. 20 -- The state has ordered the school bus here to pick up the Conlin girls hereafter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The consumers' price index rose a tenth of a per cent from mid-June to mid-July, mainly because drought conditions pushed up food prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The United States presented to the Czechoslovak Government today a claim for $271,384.16.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for July averaged 28,556 bales for each working day.
A missionary official has departed for Africa to confer with Christian leaders on the problems of congested populations in the continent's cities.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had permitted the Hempstead Bus Corporation to revise its fare structure, effective Aug. 29. The company operates seven routes in Nassau County in and between Freeport, Baldwin, Lynbrook, Hempstead, Mineola and Hicksville.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Pete Cooper of Tampa, Fla., buoyed by the first hole-in-one of his career yesterday, carded a five-under-par 67 today and took the second round lead of the Fort Wayne open golf tourney with 135.

The Edlar Realty Corporation has sold the gasoline service station and two-story business building on a triangular plot bounded by West 126th and 129th Streets and Old Broadway. The seller was the Liek Real Estate Company, of which Aaron Keil is president.
James A. Lynch, discharged union official who has been active in an insurgent labor movement at the Yonkers Raceway, was barred yesterday from all harness racing tracks in the state.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 20 -Bill Cox of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound took the lead today in the region 2 eliminations for the Mallory Trophy, symbolic of the national sailing championship. Cox and his crew of Walter Crump and Wallace Lineburgh had two firsts and a second in three races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The failure of France and Italy to ratify the European Defense Community treaty presents a serious obstacle to the adequate defense of West Europe, President Eisenhower advised Congress today.
Our Giants are on the move again and last night at the Polo Grounds they really moved in the grand manner.

Reports that the city's auxiliary civil defense force had shrunk from 21,000 to 2,000 and was threatened with collapse were denied yesterday by Herbert R. O'Brien, director of the New York City Office of Civil Defense.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The stock market was stimulated today by the British decision to repay the dollar debt to the International Monetary Fund.

Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won the fourth annual Women's Cross County Golf Association's fifty-four-hole medal play championship yesterday over the North Hills course in Douglaston, Queens.
A lone gunman stole a $4,000 payroll in Brooklyn yesterday morning and made his victims drive him over the Williamsburg Bridge to downtown Manhattan where he took a cab and escaped.

A new one-story building at 57-15 Northern Boulevard in Woodside, Queens, has been leased by the Reading Tube Company of Reading, Pa., which will use it as its Eastern district distribution terminal. The building is owned by the Queens Structure Corporation and was leased through the Greiner - Maltz Company as broker.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The Hampshire team of Gus Salerno and Mrs. Edward Wolinsky triumphed in the pro-women's tournament held by the Westchester division of the Professional Golfers Association at the Briar Hall Club today. A record total of eighty-six teams competed.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Pronto Don, leading money winning trotter from the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of Duquoin, Ill., established a world record of 2:10 1/5 for a mile and a six-teenth tonight at the Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States expects the French to leave behind for the Vietnamese Army the military equipment the United States supplied for the Indochina war, United States officials said today.

The stock market closed irregularly higher yesterday in slower trading. The aircrafts, steel and some specialties were in greatest demand. Closing levels generally were below the best of the session, reflecting the usual week-end selling.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The Illinois Central Railroad announced today it would issue $60,000,000 of new thirty-five-year first mortgage bonds to refund a thirty-year issue sold two years ago. The action was described as the concluding step in the road's fifteen-year debt refinancing program.

The end of the second session of the Eighty-third Congress has come at last, as it comes to all sessions and to all Congresses. After a momentary breathing spell we may assess what it has done and not done, and strike a balance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will review the record of the Congressional session in a half-hour radio-television address from his Denver vacation headquarters at 9 P. M. Eastern daylight time Monday, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The House Committee investigating Communist aggression heard testimony today disputing a statement by Bishop Janos Peter of Hungary that his country permitted religious freedom.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 20 -- In this sultry and somewhat disorganized North Vietnam capital, various "Go South" slogans have been daubed in black on the faded, pastel-colored building fronts in the downtown area.

Representative art treasures of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will soon be sent on a series of exhibitions throughout the country by the American Federation of Arts. They are drawn from various periods in the development of oil painting, ceramics and Far Eastern textiles.

Possibly due to a memory lapse arising from the consumption of beetle-infested beans, your editorial writer on Aug. 15 overlooked a third way to get one's bush beans -- the natural way. No dusting, no hoeing, no worry about dry spells, no beetles, and (I think) better-tasting beans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The nomination of Trevor Gardner to be Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Research and Development appeared tonight to have been swamped in the backwash of the Oppenheimer case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today directed the Tariff Commission to investigate the effects of barley imports on the price support program and on the consumption of domestic barley.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Eva Le Gallienne, the noted stage actress-director-producer whose name is synonymous with the old Civic Repertory Theatre in New York, will make her motion picture debut in "Prince of Players."

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 20 -- The second program in the American Dance Festival, sponsored by Connecticut College in Palmer Auditorium, last night had one premiere on its schedule. This was a short solo called "Man Dancing" by Daniel Nagrin, one of the festival's guest artists.
MONTREAL, Aug. 20 -- The death of Emilie Dionne is still being investigated, although the official inquest has closed. This was revealed today by Quebec's chief pathologist, Dr. Rosario Fontaine.
