When the City Council meets again next week we hope it will be disposed to expedite consideration of legislation to repeal the fifteen-year-old Lyons Law. This law requires that, with certain exceptions, no one be hired as a city employe unless he has already resided here for three years; he must continue to live here if he works for the city.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 20 -- a newspaper man accused of having written a document for the guidance of Soviet espionage agents admitted today that parts of it had a strong resemblance to material he had supplied.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- A motorist who made motion pictures of a trip down the Saw Mill River Parkway to prove his argument that the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit was "ridiculous" failed to win his point with Westchester County Parkway Police today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today vetoed a bill to permit Government employes living in the District of Columbia to engage in partisan political activity.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer fought desperately tonight to prevent the door to German nationalism from being reopened through the collapse of the European Defense Community treaty.

New York City housewives paid a little more for groceries last month than they did in June. The retail food price index advanced 1.8 per cent in July, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.
Bobbie Burns' homeland is preparing to show the world that it has a lot more than excellent whisky, breath-taking scenery and sturdy Highlanders.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- It was ten and out for the Yankees tonight. After ten straight victories the runner-up New Yorkers dropped a 4-3 decision to the Boston Red Sox and forthwith dropped to three and a half lengths behind the league-leading Cleveland Indians.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The American League leading Cleveland Indians took their batting practice in the first two innings tonight, scoring six times to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 2. Included in the early Indian uprising was Al, Rosen's twenty-first homer of the year.

A civil anti-trust suit was filed yesterday by the Government in Brooklyn against the Seafarers Sea Chest Corporation and Seafarers International Union of North America, A. F. L., Atlantic and Gulf District.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A further indefinite delay of days or weeks appeared inevitable tonight on the Senate subcommittee reports fixing responsibility for the controversy between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

The Port of New York Authority asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to suspend and investigate a proposal by trucking companies represented by the Eastern Central Motor Carriers Association to increase pick-up and delivery charges between New York and southern points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said after a conference with Secretary of State Dulles today that the State Department was trying constantly to improve Israeli-Arab relations.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- For the first time since the winter of 1951-52 United States coal is being imported by Britain.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Three Yugoslavs evaded fellow students here yesterday and asked the United States military police for political asylum from their homeland's Communist Government.

The five-story building containing five stores and forty apartments at 2537 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by the Marquib Realty Corporation, of which George Farkas is president, to a client of Martin Teichman, attorney.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 1 to 11 points lower than on Thursday, with the near-by months relatively steady.
HANOI, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Healthy and well fed, 460 French Union soldiers came out of Communist captivity today after a farewell propaganda serenade by women singers and a brass band.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks became the American League's first eighteen-game winner tonight, pitching the Chicago White Sox to an 8-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 36,544 fans at Briggs Stadium.

CAMBERLEY, England, Aug. 20 -- Top commanders of the British Commonwealth have recommended to their governments that the Commonwealth division of 22,000 men in Korea be cut during the coming year proportionately to planned United States withdrawals.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- The journal of the Composers Union, Soviet Music, today called on Soviet musicians to write some peppy, tuneful, light songs, some fox trots and tangos that people can dance to, and leave the question of whether such music is jazz to the "scholastics."

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The fall and winter collections of leading "couture" houses here soon will reach the stores of the major cities of Germany and of many foreign countries. The clothes are now being exhibited in elegant showrooms, many of which belie the wreckage that lies but a few blocks away.

Through a heavy downpour yesterday afternoon 125 crewmen and officers of the Argentine naval training ship Bahia Thetis stood at rigid attention in Riverside Park at Eighty-ninth Street as a wreath was placed at the foot of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument.

A 1937 Chevrolet coupe has been parked for the last eight years in front of 451 Vermont Street, Brooklyn, and residents of the area are getting impatient. Neighbors of Victor Kaminsky, who drives a police patrol wagon for the Seventy- third precinct and who owns the car, said yesterday he had parked it in front of his home shortly after World War II and then had proceeded to ignore it.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and the United States are negotiating "piecemeal" arrangements to reduce tariff and immigration restrictions on the border movement of goods and labor for the power phase of the big St. Lawrence Seaway development.
The decision of the Studebaker workers to accept the pay cut proposed by the corporation and thus avoid a close-down of the plant carries an important and valuable lesson for all of us.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- Canada's trade deficit is increasing, figures for July revealed today. The Bureau of Statistics estimated the deficit for last month to be $15,500,000, more than double that of July, 1953. For the first seven months of this year Canada's imports exceeded exports by $191,200,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Robert W. Burgess, director of the Bureau of the Census, announced today that questionnaires will go out early next year to more than 3,000,000 businesses for information to bring the Government up to date on the nation's sales, manufacturing and mining industries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower signed to-today three of a series of bills Congress passed to deal more stringently with Communist subversion and espionage. The bill outlawing the Communist party still awaits the President's action.
Following, as gathered by The New York Times, are some of the editorial comments by newspapers of the country on the compromise anti-Communist bill passed by Congress:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Justice Department officials explained here today reasons for the filing of the antitrust action against the Seafarers Sea Chest Corporation and Seafarers International Union of North America.
SAG HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 20 -- This village, which was one of the leading whaling ports on the Eastern seaboard when homes were lighted with whale oil, will open nine of its old homes tomorrow.

MONTREAL, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Australian pair of Peter Thomson and Kelvin Nagle shaved seven strokes off par today and took a four-stroke lead after the first day's play in the second annual Canada Cup golf tournament.

The second highest mountain on earth has now been climbed. After suffering much, after enduring severe storms and frustrations, Desio's Italian climbers have reached the summit of K-2, 28,250 feet high. I applaud their courage and their perseverance, but I am too human not to be saddened for I held permission to take the fourth American expedition to K-2 in 1955.

The police said yesterday that a 15-year-old boy had admitted firing the shot that late Thursday night critically wounded another teen-ager. The shooting, believed part of a gang feud in which the victim was a nonparticipant, took place in a doorway at 179th Street and Arthur Avenue, the Bronx.

Efforts of the Internal Revenue Service to "regain the confidence of the American people" will be aided considerably by the revision of the national tax code, it was asserted yesterday by Norman A. Sugarman, Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 20 -- Israel is not completely satisfied with United States efforts to allay fear here about arming the Arab states.

MANILA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Leo Espinosa of the Philippines stopped Jake Tuli of South Africa in the ninth round of their ten-round bout tonight and stayed in the running for a title crack at the world flyweight champion, Yoshio Shihai of Japan.
A 1955 capital budget allocation of $108,425,000 for the construction of twenty-seven new schools and the modernization or enlargement of ten old ones was asked yesterday by the Board of Education.
The Air Line Pilots Association, representing 1,243 striking pilots of American Airlines, offered late last night to end immediately the three-week walkout on the basis of two alternative proposals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A nomination sent to the Senate by mistake was withdrawn today and a substitute was submitted and quickly confirmed.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Clarence Cecil Pell Jr., star polo player and twelve times national singles racquets champion, was freed in $1,500 bail today to await a jury trial next month on charges of leaving an accident scene, drunken driving and assault on a policeman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower today rejected Tariff Commission recommendations for higher lead and zinc duties and offered instead an expanded stockpiling program to strengthen the domestic mining industries concerned with those metals.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 20 -- The International Typographical Union, A. F. L., concluded its ninety-sixth convention today after a week of business sessions which found President Woodruff Randolph's administration upheld against the attacks of an opposition minority.
A Kings County grand jury accused the Brooklyn Adolescents Court yesterday of extending "ill-considered leniency" to "serious young repeating offenders."
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 20 -- A Protestant minister from the Soviet Zone of Germany told the World Council of Churches here today that the gulf between Communism and Christianity "cannot be bridged."
Legal efforts began yesterday to transfer the leader of the Brooklyn teen-age homicide gang from jail to hospital on the ground that he is insane.
POTSDAM, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- A psychiatrist criticized today the system of 100 per cent promotion in use in some schools, and questioned its psychological soundness.

The provincial elections just concluded in South Africa resulted, not surprisingly, in another electoral gain for Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party. This well-organized and well-financed political machine delivered the voters to the polls, while many United party supporters stayed away, too apathetic to bother voting.
Plans are being completed for the modernization of the triangular nine-story office building at 56 Beaver Street, corner of South William Street.

" English Wits," a collection of biographical studies compiled by Leonard Russell, will be published by Macmillan later this month. Among the fourteen wits described are Alexander Pope, Dr. Johnson, Oscar Wilde and Charles Lamb. The fourteen contributors include Msgr. Ronald Knox, Sir Desmond MacCarthy and James Agate.
TORONTO, Aug. 20 -- Two Russian scientists spoke today at an international meeting of mental health specialists and indicated that Soviet citizens were healthier than anybody else.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower scored a significant election-year victory today as Congress broke a three-day deadlock on the Administration's Social Security bill and sent the measure to the White House.
Stockholders of Julius Kayser Co. at a special meeting here yesterday approved the purchase of certain property and assets of the Diamond Hosiery Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Parties interested in an application of the Colorado Interstate Gas Company for a $6,508,000 annual natural gas rate increase met informally again today on the possibility of reaching a compromise on the size of the rise.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Jose Antonio Soares was arrested today as a major suspect in the Aug. 5 assassination of Maj. Rubens Florintino Vaz of the Air Force. The slaying plunged Brazil into a major political crisis.
Potatoes shared the spotlight with coffee and cocoa yesterday on the New York commodity futures markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The White House saluted the record of the departing Eighty-third Congress today as the whole Republican leadership drew together to support that record in the coming Congressional campaigns.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Model changeover lay-offs at Chrysler Corporation held motor vehicle production this week to just above last week's 1954 low point, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 20 -- A young woman who was believed to be Miss Joan Ross-Dilley, missing tennis star, was found here today and was under treatment as an amnesia victim.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- The first anniversary of the deposition of the nationalist-minded Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, was observed today throughout the troubled French protectorate with calm.

Lambasting Robin Roberts for twelve hits, including home runs by Duke Snider, Carl Furillo and Sandy Amoros that accounted for five of their runs, the Dodgers downed the Phillies, 6 -- 4, at Ebbets Field last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- With $68,900 first money and possibly the year's 3-year-old championship at stake, a field of nine -headed by High Gun, Hasty Road and Errard King -- will run in the $115,250 American Derby at Washington Park tomorrow.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Burma proposed today that the fall session of the General Assembly take up a report on the continued presence of Chinese Nationalist forces within her borders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Westinghouse inventors patented this week an electric furnace that melts metal while suspended in the air.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Segregation became an issue here today as the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., ended its thirty-seventh annual convention.

In its bleak and desolate way, the roof of the world has stood as a summit of human achievement since Moses came down from Sinai. Like a magnetic horizon, it has drawn in, challenged and, for long years, thrust back those who have sought to gather its elusiveness into the realm of knowledge and experience.
TOKYO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Communist China called again today for the "liberation" of Formosa and declared, "We shall not stop until this objective is attained."
ATHENS, Aug. 20 -- Greeks staged demonstrations all over the country tonight.

LAFAYETTEVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- A twelve-mile stretch of the Taconic State Parkway from this community northward to West Taghkanic will be opened to traffic in mid-September. The grading of a further extension of eight miles to Martindale will begin at once.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Wiley J. Clark and his wife, both Negroes, clung to their newly purchased home here tonight in the face of neighborhood opposition that flared up in a brick- hurling row last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Bob Rush pitched shutout ball after the first inning and Bob Talbot, a substitute centerfielder, scored all Chicago's runs today as the Cubs tripped the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A weary Eighty-third Congress adjourned tonight after session-end ceremonies that lacked much of the usual color, but reflected a wide sense of relief over the end of a long, hard grind.

Victor L. Anfuso announced yesterday his resignation as a city magistrate to devote his full time to campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Eighth District, Brooklyn. He is a former member of Congress who was squeezed out in reapportionment.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Playground gates in Philadelphia are swinging open these days on a strange, new world that has left the tot-lot clientele amused, intrigued and delighted. It is a world dominated by such things as giant turtles that do not go anywhere, a spiral slide and a "goat mound" without any goats.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 20 -- A new chemical process for producing a group of compounds important in biological research, including the study of cancer, has been developed by a research scientist at the British Columbia Research Council.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Swedish Royal Air Force disclosed today that a jet pilot had survived a crash landing caused when the plane flew into a richocheting bullet fired from its own guns.
Carmine G. DeSapio predicted last night that Senator Irving M. Ives, not Governor Dewey, would be the Republican candidate for Governor this fall.
The Kuklapolitan Players, creation of Burr Tillstrom, are moving their "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" program to a two-station American Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Eighty-third Congress, the first in two decades to be in Republican control while the party also held the White House, adjourned tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- C. V. Whitney, whose horses have won seventeen races in seventeen days here, probably will have the favorites in both of tomorrow's stakes. The colonel will be represented by Fisherman and Cold Command in the Whitney Handicap and by Pyrenees in the Grand Union Hotel Stakes.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Australia and the United States each qualified a second team for the semi-finals of the national tennis doubles championships today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Aug. 20 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, decorated combat officer, denied today Army charges of collaborating with the enemy while a prisoner of the North Korean and Chinese Communists.
Net income of the South Penn Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the first six months this year totaled $3,141,214, against $3,328,515 earned in the corresponding half of 1953.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, forcing the fighting all the way in relentless fashion, successfully defended his world middleweight title tonight with a fifteen-round decision over the No. 1 contender, Rocky Castellani of Cleveland.

Truman Capote once wrote a lovely horror story -- if there is such a thing -- called "Master Misery." In it a young city girl discovers, to her delight, a mysterious and moneyed man who buys dreams from people.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Irving Breakstone, Illinois American Legion commander, said today that his department had rescinded its ban on support of the Girl Scouts of America.

In an article published in The New York Times on Aug. 18, it was reported that Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Commissioner of Hospitals, "did not believe that a $17,000,000 new hospital in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was justified." Plans for such a hospital have been pending for several years, but Dr. MacLean indicated that they had been dropped.

The public market for new capital is showing more than usual activity for late August. It looks as if underwriting syndicates will be kept busy with both public bidding and negotiation transactions right up to Labor Day. An even heavier flow of new marketings appears likely to get under way thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Senate and House of Representatives swiftly passed a bill today for a 5 per cent pay rise for 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 Federal employes. Both chambers acted, though, in the face of predictions from their majority leaders that President Eisenhower would veto the measure in its present form.

There is a good deal of irony in the news that the Soviet Government has now begun a new and extensive propaganda campaign against religious belief among its people. For more than a third of a century atheism has been emphasized in Soviet propaganda and education; the bulk of the present Soviet population has been subjected to anti-religious indoctrination from the nursery school and kindergarten.

Bail totaling $150,000 was fixed yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, for three men indicted on charges of robbing the Floral Park, L. I., branch of the Franklin National Bank of $190,319 on Aug. 18, 1953.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Additional work on the Hudson River bridge here of the New York-Buffalo Thruway will cost $4,852,595, bids indicated today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Government will mark time for some months before expanding its purchase program for low-grade manganese ore.
I am referring to your editorial of Aug. 14 titled "Checkmate?"

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Harvie Ward of San Francisco and Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., gained the final of the fiftieth Canadian amateur golf championship by scoring easy victories today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Two proposals designed to curb unethical practices by lawyers were approved today by the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 20 -- More than 100 delegates to a union workshop on economic conditions adopted a resolution today decrying President Eisenhower's "prophets of gloom and doom" speech. They challenged the Administration to fulfill a 1952 campaign promise to prevent recession.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Average primark market prices increased 0.1 per cent to 110.3 of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher prices of processed foods more than offset price declines for farm products. Average prices of industrial commodities remained unchanged this week.
Capt. Andrew MacKellar has been named to command the new Cunard liner Saxonia when she begins service between Liverpool and Canada on Sept. 2.

BONN, Aug. 20 -- Axel L. Wenner-Gren, the Swedish industrialist, has bought 42 per cent of the stock of Bochum Verein, one of West Germany's leading steel plants. This was believed to be Mr. Wenner-Gren's first major move in his plan to introduce the monorail train on the world market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Following is the 55-to-16 roll-call vote by which the Senate today defeated an amendment by Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Majority Leader, to attack a postal rate increase to a bill raising the pay of Federal workers by an average of 5 percent.

PEIPING, Aug. 20 -- It has now been confirmed that the British delegation will meet Mao Tse-tung, Communist China's Chief of State, next week during its three remaining days in Peiping before going on south to Shanghai. The exact time and place of the meeting still are being kept secret.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 20 -- By 17 votes to 9 last night the Federal Parliament of Central Africa deleted from its immigration bill a clause that would have prohibited the entry of any person suspected of being a Communist and who did not swear or solemnly affirm he was not a Communist.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. At the Paramount is "King Richard and the Crusaders," starring Rex Harrison, Virginia Mayo, George Sanders and Laurence Harvey. The Warner Brothers production has a supporting cast headed by Robert Douglas and Michael Pate. The screen play, by John Twist, was based or Sir Walter Scott's "The Talisman." David Butler directed and Henry Blanke pro- duced.

Most of the thousands of acts of honesty, kindness and virtue committed daily in this or any other large city go unrecorded as the commonplace normal, while crime makes news and sometimes shocking news. So it is a pleasure to take note of the case of Fritz Morris, 49, of Brooklyn, father of two girls.
Negotiations between shipyard workers and the Bethlehem Steel Company remained deadlocked yesterday as Federal mediators sought to "narrow the area of disagreement."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Greece appealed to the United Nations General Assembly today to hold a plebiscite in Cyprus to decide whether the island should remain under British control or be united with Greece.
DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 20 (AP) -- An upturn in business activity after Labor Day was forecast today by Clifford F. Hood, president of the United States Steel Corporation.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Big tuna were romping on Nebraska Shoal and along the Rhode Island shore today. Eight boats were out hunting them. Two were lucky; they got fish. Two others were not so lucky; they had fish hooked and lost them. The others went home empty-handed.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
Two of the foremost advocates of a strong American merchant marine said here yesterday that 1954 had been a legislative year that saw the making of maritime history.
A resounding success on the West Coast, "That's Life," a revue patterned after the popular "Lend an Ear," will try its luck on Broadway next November.

TRENTON, Aug. 20 -- An official of the State Employment Security Division swore here today that several years ago former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman had admitted accepting kickbacks and splitting them with an associate. The official added that Hoffman was "disturbed" because he felt that this aide was "holding out on him."

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 20 -- For the second consecutive year the Newport Music Club has brought two-thirds of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony to this seaside resort to give a three-concert summer festival. The first concert was presented tonight at the Newport Casino.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Saturday, Aug. 21 -- After a diplomatic battle lasting until after 1 A. M. today the foreign ministers of the six signatories to the European Defense Community treaty managed with difficulty to avoid a breakdown of their negotiations.

The struggle to save the European Defense Community has reached a climatic point this week-end. The foreign ministers meeting in Brussels struggled far into the night Friday without reaching agreement concerning the revision proposals submitted by French Premier Mendes-France.

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., Aug. 21 -- William R. Smith, captain of the Notre Dame football team in 1936, committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself in a barn at his home here, the county physician reported today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A 68 by Jimmy Demaret lifted the United States team into a three-way tie for third in the second annual Canada Cup golf competition today behind Argentina and Australia, deadlocked for first.

Down in Corpus Christi, Tex., there appears to be a pianist who has evolved a style that is, and probably will remain, unique. His name is Red Camp and on a ten-inch LP, Red Camp Upright (Sounds of Our Times) he plays in a manner that combines the headlong drive of the barrelhouse pianist with the long, fluid line of more recent jazzmen.

RICHMOND, Aug. 21--Improvement in Fifth District department store trade in the last four weeks has narrowed the 1954 deficit to 1 per cent. With the vacation season nearing a close, leading retailers look for a continuance of a moderate uptrend.

The Times of Aug. 15 reported that the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws unanimously recommended adoption of legislation replacing the elected coroner with a trained medical examiner in states where the outdated coroner remains.

ROSWELL, N. M., Aug. 21 (UP) -- The elite among United States Air Force bombing crews converged on Walker Air Force Base here today for the week long "world series of bombing" to determine the crew that is the most accurate.

In the most optimistic report it has yet issued, the Food and Agricultural Organization has reported that last year, for once, the world's food production rose more rapidly than did population. The increase, related to population, was slight, however, and hundreds of millions of persons still experienced hunger as a present reality or near threat.
TOKYO, Aug. 21 -- Japan's economic problem, now again disturbing this nation's Western allies, can be stated very simply:

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Democratic county committee contests are scheduled in thirty-nine of Suffolk's 239 election districts on Sept. 14, with Herman L. Bishop's move to unseat Adrian Mason of Patchogue as committee chairman the feature of the election.

I WAS interested in the remark of Carrel Collins in his review of Faulkner's "A Fable" that "apparently no one has remarked the parallel" between the structure of "The Sound and the Fury" and that of Holy Week.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Batista Pereira of Portugal won the third international cross-channel swimming race here today, leading eleven male and three female competitors from Cap Griz Nez in France to South Foreland Point in England. His time was 12 hours 25 minutes.

MOTORISTS traveling the New Jersey Turnpike have had such lusty appetites that a $2,000,000 program is under way to enlarge the eating facilities along the route. Last year, with more than 6,500,000 customers spending about $3,500,000 on food at Turnpike dining places, the road's restaurant facilities were overtaxed.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 21 -- The scheduled Region 2 elimination series of the national sailing championships ended in a tie today with the three participating skippers each having 18 1/2 points for the six-race series.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 21 -- Doug Ford of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., used only twenty-six putts today as he shot a third-round 66 to take the lead in the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament with 205.

THE terrifying Iron Maiden of Nuremberg Castle -- an instrument of human torture hinged to admit a victim who, as the iron form closed, was impaled on its spikes -- furnishes both title and theme of this strong novel.

ROME, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The tribunal of the Diocese of Rome has taken the first step toward beatifictaion of a Polish archbishop who narrowly escaped execution by the Russian Communists thirty years ago, it was disclosed today.

VENICE. THIS is undoubtedly the most improbable and uniquely beautiful city in the world. But some of the very things that make it a sight-seer's paradise, and a director's and cameraman's delight, also make it a producer's nightmare.

WATCHUNG, N. J., Aug. 21 -- The two top teams, William Y. Dear Jr. and Gordon Brown of Morris County and William Walsh and Frank O'Brien Plainfield, gained the semi-final round in the twenty-second annual four-ball championship at the Twin Brooks Country Club today.
Thank you for your article t praise of "TV l{eeItal Hall" lal Sunday in The Times.

PEARL LANG will present a new group work next week-end at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass. Set to the Bach-Busoni "Toccata, Adagio and Fugue" in C Major, it is entitled "And Joy Is My Witness."
TELEVISION'S first real color season, which begins tonight at 8 o'clock when C. B. S. puts on a tinted version of "Toast of the Town," adds up to a ridiculous situation.

EVIDENCE keeps piling up to encourage business optimists and confound pessimists. The school that believes that the downtrend in our economy has ended, as evidence by the achievements of retailers, is finding support in the performance of mail order and chain store companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government hopes to present its chairman a belated but somewhat awesome birthday gift early in January.
PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Private music lessons will be offered for the first time at Princeton University during the academic year 1954-55.

When the new anti-Communist bill went from the Capitol to the White House last week many Congressmen were uncertain as to just what was in bill they had passed, what it meant, and whether it was constitutional. This is what the bill says about the Communist party and party members:

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- An entire season, perhaps even a pennant, might have been wrapped up in the twelfth inning at Fenway Park today. For that was the round in which Don Lenhardt smashed a two-out, bases-loaded single that delivered the two runs the Boston Red Sox needed to inflict a 10-9 defeat upon the world champion Yankees.

SOCRATES tells of the occasion when he found the great man Protagoras talking to a small group of young men: "As I suspected that he would like a little display and glorification, I said, 'But why should we not summon the rest to hear?'

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- An organization to promote democratic ideals and constitutional government in China -- supporting neither the Communist government nor the Chiang Kaishek government of Formosa -- has been incorporated in California as a Crusade for Free Democratic China, Inc.

" THE influence of the Quaker movement * * * has always far exceeded the numerical strength of the Society of Friends" writes Patrick Pringle in "The Prisoners Friend" and his biography of Elizabeth Fry helps us to understand why. So too does Catherine Owens Peare's life of John Woolman, for each of these Quakers typifies the courage and the selfless service to humanity which are essentials of their faith.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 21 -- Punkin Vine, the 3-year-old bay son of Vineland who was bought as a yearling for $750 on the condition that payment be made only if the colt won that much, ran again with some of thoroughbred's "high society" today and ran as if he meant to stay there.

RICHARD STRAUSS' "Die Frau ohne Schatten" will be presented by the New York City Opera during its spring season. Although the work dates from 1919, this will be its first production in the United States. It will be given in Hugo von Hofmannstahl's original German.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Thomas H. Danaher, 30-year-old former United States Marine Corps pilot of Wichita Falls, Tex., landed at Shannon Airport in Ireland today after flying the Atlantic Ocean in a small, single-engine plane.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- In a message from Geneva, Dr. J. G. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations Commissioner for Refugees, today asked his staff here to disseminate as widely as possible information on the critical financial situation confronting the program for care of especially needy cases under his supervision.

THEY built the biggest thing of its kind on earth, there in the Northwest. Grand Coulee Dam took cement enough to put a six-lane highway around our whole country. A tall dam, tall as the Washington Monument, almost a mile wide.

A VETERAN freelance writer and photographer for leading newspapers and magazines, Jean Lyon spent more than three years roaming India with an expert reporter's eye and a tireless Leica before she decided to set down her impressions in a book.

Dr. Wertham analyzes motives for murder and he suggests that most "important is the task of reducing those conditions under which destructive tendencies arise and grow." He says that "is primarily a matter of education."

The University of Rochester will initiate a program of studies on "world awareness" to give its undergraduate students a wide understanding of the "realities" of Asia, the Middle East and Africa. These regions of the world have been largely ignored in the American undergraduate curriculum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- For at least one more year Uncle Sam will remain the reluctant landlord of Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Richland, Wash., near where the Hartford atomic plant is located.
Re "Summer Theatre Biz," by Seymour Peck, with drawings by Carl Rose (July 11): May I say that it is true and not true.

LONDON, Ont., Aug. 21 -- Harvie Ward Jr. of San Francisco wore down Big Bill Campbell with iron play today and crushed his American Walker Cup teammate, 5 and 4, to win the Canadian amateur golf championship.
DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 21 -- This has been a week in the annals of friendship between Pakistan and the United States that Bengalis say they will never forget.

Women headed by Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, chairman, and Mrs. Walter S. Fischer, vice chairman, are active in the plans for the performance of "Fragile Fox" on the night of Oct. 28, at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Institute of World Affairs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Rocky Castellani isn't convinced that Carl (Bobo) Olson is too much for him. He and his manager, Al Naiman, want another crack at Olson's world middleweight title.
MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A 744 1/2-pound tuna, the largest caught in Eastern United States waters this year, was brought to gaff here late today by two men in a row boat.

The 1937 Chevrolet coupe that had been parked for eight years in front of its owner's Brooklyn home, despite neighbors' complaints, was finally towed away yesterday by the Police Department. The owner of the car received a summons for overtime parking.
The police seized 343 more persons as undesirables in Manhattan yesterday and early today, raising the number of arrests in their four-week crusade past the 1,500 mark.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 21 -- South Africa, following this week's Nationalist victory in provincial elections, is on the road to becoming a republic, Johannes G. Strydom, Minister of Lands, has declared in a post-election message.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 21 -- A million and a half Texans, some of them bitter over the state's bolt of the Democratic party in 1952, will go to the polls next Saturday to settle one of the state's fiercest political fights in years.

Jacob Saliba has been elected a director and executive vice president of the Brockway Motor Company, Inc., and Charles C. Severance has been named vice president in charge of manufacturing. James E. Cambria has been elected vice president in charge of sales.
OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 10 -- The course Japan may be expected to follow as a result of Communist gains in Indochina now has become considerably clarified.

AFTER more than 6,000 years the Madonna lily continues to be grown and cherished by gardeners of many lands. Although it is thought to be one of the oldest plants in cultivation, it is today one of the most popular and familiar of all lilies.

The stock market last week chalked up the highest averages in nearly a quarter of a century. Setting the pace for the forward movement were the industrial shares, jogged along by higher dividends and stock split-ups.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 21 -- The Council of Southern Universities will meet next month to work out details of a multi-million-dollar scholarship program to raise the level of graduate study in the South's universities and colleges.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The United Nations' Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold, said today that exclusion of Communist China from the United Nations was a "weakness" in the world organization. But, he said, perhaps this is not the time to consider admission of the Peiping Government.

PARIS, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Resistance veterans laid wreaths of flowers in busy thoroughfares and lonely side streets today on memorial plaques to their comrades who fell during the weeklong battle to free Paris ten years ago.

Rain and wet grounds prevented the Dodgers from playing the Phillies at Ebbets Field yesterday. Since this is Philadelphia's last 1954 series in Brooklyn, the contest was immediately rescheduled as part of a double-header today.

ONE of the traditional rules-of-thumb for bridge columnists is this: Report only hands misplayed by experts or well played by poor players. It isn't news when an expert plays well; he's supposed to do that. But it's good news when he plays badly, because it makes all the tyros feel better.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Tonacatepeque is a village of weavers in El Salvador. Until a few months ago, 400 looms stood idle there and unemployment was rife. Now, nearly a score of looms are shuttling again, and families are earning $3.50 a day, more than they have ever earned before.

THE obvious way to save money on coffee is to stop drinking it. But reports from those who have undertaken this drastic step are not encouraging. The effort required in giving up this popular beverage, which has advanced appreciably in cost since the first of the year, apparently exceeds the monetary gain that may accrue.

SALEM, Mass. -- To most first-time visitors Salem means Nathaniel Hawthorne and the "House of Seven Gables." With all due respect to Hawthorne, there is an irony here that might have pleased the old tale-teller himself.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The South Korean Government today called upon the United Nations Command to "take prompt action" for dissolution of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission or else "to stand aside" while the Republic of Korea handled it.

Faced with increasing sales losses from the invasion of imports, the American bicycle industry is no longer keeping quiet about its plight. Most of the invaders are "lightweights" from England, West Germany or France.
On Sept. 21, the Republican and Democratic parties of New York State will hold their conventions to nominate candidates for Governor.

BORN in 1780 to a member of the Irish House of Commons and the daughter of an earl. Augustus John Foster entered the diplomatic service young. He held posts at Naples, Washington -- where in 1811 he was Minister Plenipotentiary -- Copenhagen and Turin.

Your "Ethel Barrymore in Mid-Career" (Aug. 15) called pleasantly to mind many magical performances by this great lady. However, it is impossible to recall, as your writer did, Miss Barrymore's winning an Academy Award for her work in "How Green Was My Valley."
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- The first step toward lightening the severe Soviet laws imposed against abortion in 1936 has been taken by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union.

NOT since "Lust for Life" has Irving Stone written so good a book as his new one. An ambitious novel about Mary Todd and Abraham Lincoln, it covers a period of more than twenty-five years, capturing the color and clutter of its time, injecting heart into history and making real one of the most misunderstood marriages in the American past.
OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Dave Freishtat of Baltimore today won the men's Canadian junior singles tennis crown by defeating George Mandel of Astoria, Queens, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

ARE wages keeping up with profits and the cost of living? Are you inviting lung cancer when you light a cigarette? Are we in the early stages of a depression without knowing it? Will toothache abandon you if there's fluorine in your drinking water or the latest miracle ingredient in your toothpaste?

ACCORDING to the naturalist Comte Georges Louis Leclerc de Buffon, man's favorite animal is that large, dexterous beast, the elephant. But since an elephant can neither trot nor run nor gallop nor swiftly pace, it is difficult to explain his attraction, even for Buffon.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 21 -- Forty-three acres in the heart of this city will be available for redevelopment as a result of the transfer by the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway of its freight yard operations to new yards outside the city.

SINCE 1941 Martha Foley's sensitive and catholic selections from the short stories of the year have served a double purpose: they have given pleasurable entertainment, and they have provided the interested reader with an index by which to judge the prevailing condition of what is still one of the busiest departments in American Literature, Incorporated.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Constituent Assembly adopted today a legislative reorganization program that indicated popular elections were at least a year away.

MANILA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Rafael Lacson, suspended Governor of Negros Occidental Province, and twenty-one co-defendants were sentenced to death today for the murder of Moises Padilla, a political rival, three years ago.

THREE months before his death in December, 1951, a Cleveland corporation lawyer named Grover Higgins made a striking change in his will that sent chamber music stock soaring in Northern Ohio and promises a lasting effect on the bull market in chamber music nationally.
TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- The quasi-judicial Hoffman hearings that opened here last Monday are expected to continue until late this fall.

IN his review of "Elisha Kent Kane and the Seafaring Frontier," Trevor Lloyd says, "as a scientist Kane was capable of making the astonishing unscientific guess that an 'open polar sea' existed around the North Pole."

IT is a compliment to America's constant growth -- gastronomically speaking -- that most cookbook authors no longer feel called upon to guide their readers through culinary fundamentals before going into the particular phase of wining and dining they want to write about.

The Kings County District Attorney's office announced yesterday it would seek first-degree murder indictments against the four Brooklyn youths charged with the brutal and senseless killing of two men.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Ray Jablonski's bases-loaded single in the eleventh inning gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs tonight at Busch Stadium.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 14 -- After three months of what they call a combined operation against the Czechoslovakia Communist regime, the directors of Radio Free Europe believe they have substantial evidence that opposition to the Reds can be stimulated and guided from the free world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- British sources here maintained today that the current agitation in Cyprus for union with Greece resulted -- at least in part -- from a Communist propaganda campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The text of the bill outlawing the Communist party contained four variations in language from the final version of the measure that was sent to the White House this week for President Eisenhower's signature.

TRADITIONAL English diplomacy was left by the wayside last week when Tom O'Brien, member of Parliament and General Secretary of the National Association of Theatrical and Kine Employes, appeared as guest speaker before a meeting here of the Hollywood A. F. L. Film Council.

THE artist should be, not the judge of his characters and their conversations, but only an unbiased witness. I Once overheard a desultory conversation about pessimism between two Russians; nothing was solved -- and my business is to report the conversation exactly as I heard it, and let the jury -- that is, the readers, estimate its value.

In Korea, in Washington and in the United Nations, the United States has again called attention to the illegal detention of American aviators in Red China as "political prisoners." There is a group of fifteen who should obviously have been returned in the prisoner exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Judged either on the basis of cold statistics or hot political emotions, the signs point to an extremely close November battle for party control of the Senate in the next two years of the Eisenhower Administration.

AN imposing number of piano records has been released by Westminster over the last few months. One of the most enjoyable contains music that has virtually vanished from the repertory -- a disk devoted to piano music by Chabrier and Saint-Saens, played by Ginette Doyen.

LINDEN, N. J., Aug. 21 -- A drizzling rain caused postponement of the American Le Mans twelve-hour endurance race scheduled for today at the Linden Airport. The race, open to American and foreign cars, was deferred until tomorrow, with the start slated for noon.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Red spider mite, minute insects that have been thick all summer, will probably be around until frost. They infest the undersides of leaves on privet hedges, deciduous and broadleaved evergreen shrubs, some fruit trees and even vegetables. Foliage looks bronze, yellow or gray. Spray every ten days with malathion or aramite.
TORONTO, Aug. 21 -- The director of the World Federation for Mental Health said today that he knew of no statistical evidence that Soviet citizens were healthier than other people.

An entertainment, known as the Anniversary Cocktail Dance, will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 4 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association. The occasion will mark the eighty-second anniversary of the founding of the association.

ONE'S importance in Hollywood is oddly measured by many things, not the least among them being the length of time, the number of handshakes, busses, and winks, and the amount of ordinary hellos needed to make a fifty-yard dash across a studio commissary.

THE many books of Lin Yu-tang ("The Importance of Living," "My Country and My People," "The Vermilion Gate," etc.) have always been true bridges to a better understanding between East and West. We were forcibly reminded of this fact the other day, when we encountered Dr. Lin at a farewell luncheon given in his honor by his new publishers (Prentice-Hall), on the eve of his departure for Singapore.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21--An Air Force test plane has just broken the world's altitude record. Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said here tonight. He added that the record-breaking craft "will go higher."

Re the provocative article, "Why Do They Commit Murder?" (Aug. 8) by Frederic Wertham [in which Dr. Wertham, a noted psychiatrist, rejects the notion that mysterious, deeply hidden irrational forces make a murderer, or that all murderers are abnormal -- Editor] :

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Flying Cloud from Sea Cliff, L. I., sailed by Theodore Reyling, captured the fourth and final race to win the Atlantic Class sailing championship with 100 points as the series concluded off the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Educators, attempting to weather seemingly impossible conditions brought about by a national shortage of 300,000 qualified teachers, are beginning to see some prospect of relief.

FOR twenty years Gordon Haight, Professor of English at Yale, has devoted himself to the preparation of the massive Yale Edition of the letters of George Eliot. The publication of the first three of the six volumes nearly concludes this long and especially arduous labor of scholarship -- and wholly justifies it.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 21 -- Vigorous campaigns for the Republican nominations for Governor and Lieutenant Governor are speeding toward a hectic close at the Sept. 14 primaries in Vermont, the traditional stronghold of the Republican party.
The Liberated Young Democrats of New York State urged the Legislature yesterday to take all steps necessary to "root out and expel" communism.

IN March of 1945 Richard Strauss, then 81, began a work for ten violins, five violas, five 'cellos and three double basses. He finished it a month later and called it Metamorphoses. That work, composed by an old man on the eve of Germany's great defeat, is now available in its first recording, a disk made for Angel by twenty-three members of the Orchestre Nacional de la Radiodiffusion Francaise, under Jascha Horenstein.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Manufacturing employment in the Federal Reserve District of Philadelphia increased 14 per cent between 1949 and 1953, acaccording to a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank. Increases were noted in all industries making durable goods.

IF Susan Camille MacNamara threatens to "devour" her alter ego as Mazie almost did, Ann Sothern has some remedies. Among these, the ash blonde actress believes, is her forthcoming appearance in one of the few show business mediums she hasn't used -- live color television.

The American housewife has scored an international victory over high prices. The easing of Brazil's foreign exchange rules was prompted by a threatened internal economic crisis, but the resulting cheaper prices for coffee reflect Brazil's graceful acceptance of the dictum of Mrs. Housewife.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Fred Hibberd Jr. of the American Yacht Club led home a fleet of sixty starters in the Huguenot Y. C.'s sixtieth annual Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (UP) -- John Sternberger, 16, of Dayton, Ohio, won a four-way shoot-off today for the handicap championship, one of three preliminary contests on the second-day program of the American Trapshooting Association's annual shotgun tournament.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 21 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has received a personal message from Sir Winston Churchill offering encouragement and moral support in the difficult negotiations to save the European Defense Community treaty.

The First Army controller, Col. Louis W. Haskell, who was a senior officer of Gen. George C. Marshall's mission to China in 1946, will retire from the Army Aug. 31. He has been in the service thirty-one years.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- On the outcome of the Brussels conference and the subsequent action of the French parliament on the European Defense Community treaty will depend not only the future of West Germany's rearming but the character of European integration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--Congress turned from lawmaking to full-time political campaigning today as members headed home for one of the most crucial off-year elections in recent ...

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Six weeks of virtually normal juvenile life in an experimental camp at Graye-sur-Mer, in Calvados, France, has proved that diabetic children can indulge in many forms of athletics and live nearly normal lives, the International Children's Center said in its annual report today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A classically partisan and somewhat old-fashioned struggle appears to lie ahead for this Congressional election year in the wake of the Republican Eighty-third Congress.
Ohrbach's will shift its cash-and-carry retail operation from Fourteenth Street to Thirty-Fourth Street on Thursday and other retailers in that area don't know yet whether to cheer or fear the move.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Another segment in the world-wide system of defensive alliances against Communist expansion is about to be formed in Southeast Asia.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins of the National Football League have obtained an injunction to prevent a star tackle. Laurie Niemi, from playing with British Columbia Lions.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- Dr. Otto John, former West German intelligence chief who defected to the Communists, denounced today as "untrue" President Eisenhower's pledge that the United States would not launch a preventive war. Dr. John alleged that a "top United States source" had told him otherwise.

DAHLIAS will soon be coming into bloom, which is good news for all as this lovely flower is always a satisfactory one to arrange. Among its assets are long cut-flower life, sturdy stems and wide range of flower color, size and appearance.
THE junior and senior high school years afford a perfect setting for teen-age novels -- a time to look ahead happily toward hoped-for experiences.

THERE is a portion of the gardening year -- near at hand -- which brings joy to the hearts of all dahlia growers. Gardeners who have worked hard all spring and summer caring for this popular flower are soon to be rewarded, whether the blooms are to be used on the show table or in the home.

" TWO years ago, I convinced my mother she should vote for a Socialist," said Yoko Hamada, an attractive young Japanese woman. "My father, who supports the conservatives, was furious when he found out what had happened. There was a dreadful argument. Last year, my mother voted as father told her she should."

EVER since G. B. Harrison's edition of Shakespeare's works was published two years ago, this column has been intending to say something appreciative. In the interval the book has seen a lot of service and looks better all the time. For "Shakespeare: The Complete Works" (Harcourt, Brace) is practically a one-volume encyclopedia that contains not only the plays and poems but also all the background material needed to out the plays in perspective.

TEXAS, this summer, has more than its usual share of heat and dust, a good deal of it being generated by a political campaign. On Saturday, Texas Democrats will nominate a candidate for Governor and, Texas being a one-party state, despite its defection to President Eisenhower in 1952, the man they choose will also be elected Governor.

IN 1867 the Great Plains -- extending from the foothills of the Rocky Mountains eastward to the great bend of the Missouri and from central Canada on the north to the dry wastelands of the eastern part of the Southwest on the south -- was dark with millions of buffalo, the great, humped, courageous animal that might well have been taken as the American Symbol instead of the eagle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Libya, which became independent in December, 1951, completed in one day in July the first stage of her first census. The second part will be finished in September. It will cover the large proportion of Libyans who are nomads and semi-nomads.

WE are well past the point of discovering that the True-Life Adventure films, which are now quite as much of a fixture with Walt Disney's studio as his familiar animated cartoons, are a new kind of nature picture wherein nature itself is made to seem to conform to the conventions of Disney humor and sentiment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A triple by Ernie Banks, followed by Steve Bilko's second homer of the season, each produced two runs in the first inning today and carried the Chicago Cubs to a second straight victory over the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 2.

BESIDES the two new works by George Balanchine on the schedule of its late summer season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet will have interesting elements of novelty in its casting, as Maria Tallchief is away on leave.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 20 -- The Congress has adjourned and gone home, and what is important in the domestic political world now is not what the Congressmen think but what the people think.

THE biography of Einstein by Antonina Vallentin deals almost exclusively with the man, his family life, his friends, his personal habits, his personality and his activities outside the realm of science. Drawing heavily on her intimacy with the Einstein family, her presentation has the ring of authenticity.
The job of making chemical plants socially acceptable to their communities is becoming increasingly exacting -- and expensive.
VENICE, Italy, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Hollywood has entered four star-packed dramas and a comedy in the fifteenth International Film Festival, which opens here tomorrow.

RECURRING dry summers have made gardeners as well as farmers, suburbanites as well as country people, aware of a water problem. Gardeners in the East have a particular awareness, for they have been accustomed to watering their plantings whenever needful and have never had to value water or consider irrigation systems as have their cohorts in the Southwest.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Measured in terms of the number of words per dollar -- written and spoken words on the subject -- East-West trade is certainly one of the greatest issues of our time. As a contribution to either the free world's economy or that of the Communist bloc of nations, it remains comparatively unimportant, except for a few small countries and a few special commodities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Joseph Gavegnano's Errard King, today whipped High Gun and Hasty Road in the $115,250 American Derby at Washington Park to stake a strong claim for 1954 3-year-old laurels. Ridden by Sammy Boulmetis, the colt followed pace-setting Hasty Road in the mile-and-one-eighth race until the final turn and then moved ahead to stave off the final drive of High Gun to win by two lengths.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Results of today's soccer and rugby games:

COFFEE has been called "a triumphant stream of sable," "the divine draught," "a wine which no sorrow can resist." Though most Americans do not speak of it quite so extravagantly, they show their solid regard for it nevertheless by drinking two-thirds of the world's exportable coffee.

MANY shade trees, almost limp during the dry spell of July, have responded remarkably well to the rains that broke the drought earlier this month. New terminal shoots are appearing on elms, maples and pin oaks.
A team of American educators is about to leave for South Korea to spend a year teaching the Koreans how to teach themselves along democratic lines.

THE peacock of the title is a beautiful woman whose pride gets in the way of her happiness. In this story of contemporary marriage, by a successful actress turned popular novelist, practically all of the principals change partners in a highly civilized manner.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The attempt by the Russian bear to snuggle close to the British lion has brought out a strain of Missouri in many Britons.

TORONTO, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- American football fans will get their first glimpse of the Canadian professional game on television next Saturday when the Eastern Big Four league will open its season.

PHOTOGRAPHY ANNUAL 1955, out on Thursday, continues to be the biggest bargain in the field at $1 a copy. More than 250 pictures in as many pages give the purchase a generous sampling of what today's photographers, as reflected in the selections by Bruce Downes, editor of Photography Magazine, and his staff, are concerned with in the choice of material and its treatment.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Torch Key, a 4-year-old bay gelding owned by William Alberg of Glen Head, L. I., and driven by Warren Dennis, won the featured $5,000 Maryland Trot in 2:05-1/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

WHILE many sections of the country have been experiencing record heat and drought conditions, Boston -- and northern New England -- has been "enjoying" one of the coolest and wettest seasons in years.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 21 (UP) -- A rating system developed by an economics professor at Penn State lists Army as the East's top collegiate football power for the eight-season span from 1946 through 1953 .
BEAR MOUNTAIN--The Bear Mountain and Harriman sections of Palisades Interstate Park, which most people refer to simply as Bear Mountain Park, have never lacked for visitors at any season of the year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sunday, Aug. 22 -- The conference of the foreign ministers of the six nations of the European Defense Community ended in disagreement at 2:40 A. M. today.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A musical revue, "The Village Vanities." featuring leading summer residents and a chorus line of debutantes, will mark this year's end - of - summer musical benefit for Guild Hall.
PENZANCE, England, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The castle of St. Michael's Mount, the legendary island home of the giant killed by Jack, became a national shrine today.

THE Winston Adventure Books, a series which presents lesser-known figures and episodes in history, number twenty-eight now with the addition of these four new titles. The pattern familiarly found in teen-age historical fiction is used in each of these new ones: a young boy meets under propitious circumstances a valorous man who helped shape history.

MORGAN CITY, La. -- The six big harvest festivals in the Cajun Country of southwest Louisiana will highlight the state's calendar of events for the next two months. Tourists who expect to be in this part of the nation during September or October can plan to join the "natives" at their distinctive shrimp, sugar cane, cotton, sweet potato, dairy and rice festivals.

New Jersey Republican State Committee headquarters released yesterday a detailed analysis of the record of former Representative Clifford P. Case, the party's nominee for Senator, in the face of what it termed the "outrageous attack" on him.

A SHARP-EYED member of the editorial staff of The New York Times, who specializes in Russian affairs, found the article in the June issue of "Sovietskaya Kultura," the organ of the Soviet Ministry of Culture, and brought it to our attention.

IT would ordinarily be safe to generalize that a book confined to a limited area of Papua, in southeastern New Guinea, written after a twenty-one years' sojourn by a French missionary priest, could whet no particular appetite save of those who acquire hobbies in such fields.

A Nassau County surgeon, Dr. Ralph U. Whipple of Manhasset, who learned his navigation while a student at Princeton and Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, yesterday won the Captain Billop Trophy. This is the award for cruising power yachts in the revived predicted log race sponsored by the Richmond County Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Chicago area business will improve during the remainder of the year, according to a majority of members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago. The optimistic outlook came in the form of replies to a special question asked by the group's business survey committee in checking July business sentiment and operating conditions.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovak railroad transport is suffering because too many technical experts have been purged, President Antonin Zapatocky conceded today.

ALTHOUGH tiger hunting has a rather limited appeal to the average American sportsman, this fact should in no way detract from the popularity of "The Tigers of Trengganu," which deals primarily with the life, habits and habitat of the Malayan tiger.
Music lovers will have a wide choice -- from a complete Puccini opera to an all-Mozart program -- in the concerts presented by the New York Public Library in Bryant Park daily from noon to 2 P. M.

The treaty for a European Defense Community was initialed in Paris twenty-seven months ago. Since then, it has been ratified by the West German and Benelux (Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg) parliaments. Italian ratification is expected soon.

GRINNELL, Iowa -- This is the place where the young man went when Horace Greeley said, "Go west, young man, go west." In fact, it is named for that young man -- Josiah Bushnell Grinnell, who founded the town a century ago.

THIS rather naive but bravely told story should not be chosen as a reader's introduction to Polynesia -- the "South Sea Islands" of hammock navigators and easy-chair skippers. But it is valuable supplementary reading to such narratives as Clifford Gessler's "Road My Body Goes" and "The Reasonable Life" or even Sir Arthur Grimble's "We Chose the Islands.

BUFFALO, Aug. 21 -- Governor Dewey will lead a group of state and local dignitaries here Thursday in ceremonies marking the official opening of a fifty-seven-mile section of the New York State Thruway linking Buffalo and Rochester.

LOS ANGELES, Aug 21 -- The motorist who veers frantically from lane to lane in an effort to get ahead of other drivers even on a high-speed freeway may be only exhausting himself in a wild-goose chase.

RECENT reports from Germany indicate a renaissance of dueling, a sport which in its Bismarckian hey-day reached the point where virtually no German student could join a college fraternity without the fresh sabre-scar glowing across his cheek as a badge of honor and proof of manhood.

Foremost well describes Paul E. Reinhold, chief executive officer of Foremost Dairies, Inc., which he built from three ailing companies to one of the world's leading enterprises in the dairy industry.
CAIRO, Aug. 21 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser astonished Egypt tonight by lumping together the Moslem Brotherhood and the Communists as a "corrupting force."

THE D. D. R. (Deutsche Demokratische Republik) of East Germany is a segment of the former German Reich which is slightly smaller than the State of Pennsylvania, but which, in the present world struggle, has an importance out of all proportion to its size.

SHIP BOTTOM, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Like a nor'easter, a controversy has blown up on Long Beach Island, between Barnegat Bay and the Atlantic Ocean here. Natives and old-time summer residents from Philadelphia are split into two camps about how to meet the expected "invasion" from the New York metropolitan area, now that the Garden State Parkway is in business.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Edinburgh's eighth Festival of Music and Drama opens here tomorrow and the vanguard of tens of thousands of visitors already is jamming the city.
Edward F. Lodge Jr. has been appointed general traffic manager of R. M. Hollingshead Corporation, Camden, N. J., manufacturer of automotive, aviation, industrial and household chemical products.

The motor city of Detroit will find many prominent golfers on its highways and fairways during the next few days. The United States Golf Association's fifty-fourth amateur championship will begin tomorrow morning at the Country Club of Detroit, Grosse Pointe Farms.

OAKLAND, Calif. -- A neatly lettered green and white sign at the foot of Broadway, bearing the inscription "Jack London Square," is notice to the world that Oakland is in competition with San Francisco's Fishermen's Wharf.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 21 -- The South African Government is believed to be maneuvering toward an eventual effort to get an agreement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that probably would involve establishment of NATO bases here.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 21 -- Plans for improving this state's 121,000 miles of rural roads and city streets over the next ten years have been laid before the Minnesota Highway Study Commission by two outside agencies of technical consultants.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Earlier in the week, Alfred Vanderbilt decided not to send Native Dancer after the money in today's $58,300 Whitney Handicap. He elected to shoot for the money with Social Outcast, a jayvee member of his racing team. Social Outcast now rates a varsity letter. He won.

A group of New York business men will leave for Israel on Tuesday to study economic conditions there, it was announced yesterday by Ira Guilden, head of the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds.

RICHARD HAYDN is the actor, but it is clear this morning that his talents do not begin and end with that trade, ennobling though it be. He also is a minor genius with the pen. His "The Journal of Edwin Carp" is a wonderfully amusing book of the type that is not quite caricature and yet not far off that antic.

This community has been shocked and stirred in the past few days by the revelation of the crimes of a small group of adolescents. There are strong overtones of sadism in the story of brutal beatings, whippings and finally killings. There can be no doubt that we are faced with serious psychoses, whether or not they come within the legal range of the definition of "insanity."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The sea gulls will be back in time for the opening of the General Assembly Sept. 21. They are part of the scene, and the headquarters would not be quite the same without them.
ATHENS, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Women's organizations in Greece have united to fight for full equality.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and the Bureau of the Budget made public today a documentary account of the Dixon-Yates power contract, which Democratic leaders have condemned as scandalous.

DENVER, Aug. 21 -- President Eisenhower flew into Denver today with a sackful of bills and notes and drafts for two or three speeches. He plans to make this city his base of operations for six to eight weeks. The program includes desk work, political travels, speechmaking and relaxation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Nylon body armor has proved so effective in reducing the number of battle casualties among American troops who fought in Korea that the use of similar devices should be considered for civilian defense in event of a hydrogen or atomic bomb attack.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, announced today that an invitation had been extended to the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick of New York, to join the university faculty.

In contrast to the usual reductions made in the appropriation requests of the President, Congress has increased the total funds he sought for medical research. It raised the research appropriation for the National Institutes of Health from $71,218,000 to $81,268,000.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Aug. 21 -- School district voters here decided today to extend bus service to junior high school students who live a mile or more from school. This was an outgrowth of the battle of a father for the right of his daughters to ride to class.

HYERES, France -- There are almost as many legends and stories about the islands off the south coast of France as there are fashionable hotels on the mainland. The islands are beautiful and sunny the year around, and their air is balmy with the fragrance of pine and eucalyptus forests.
Ship construction in this country's private shipyards reached a four-year low last month by dropping 100,000 deadweight tons of vessel work.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 21 -- A Negro educator and religious leader charged here today that the modern church was crucifying Christ anew . . . this time on a "racial cross."
The Eighty-third Congress passed no legislation that could be construed as unfavorable to the oil industry.

THERE were humor and gaiety and color and a vast zest for life in that group of Bunyanesque characters known as the Irish-American A. C. Whales. They provided one of the most vivid chapters in sports history. They were weight throwers for the most part, all massive men with appetites to match.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 21 -- The International Amateur Athletics Federation today recognized twenty-nine world records including John Landy's 3:58 mile and the controversial javelin mark of 8.41 meters (263 feet 10 inches) made by Bud Held, former Stanford star.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21 -- For the second time in four months, Larry Doby broke Bob Turley's pitching spell by tripling in the sixth inning with the bases loaded for a 4-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. The triumph widened Cleveland's American League lead to four and one-half games over the second-place Yankees.
President Eisenhower's clear-cut statement opposing any thought of a "preventive war" has met with the whole-hearted approval of the entire nation.

MIDSUMMER brings hot days, warm nights, sweet corn, tuna salad, the picnic, the vacation, the sunburn and insects. Especially insects, for it is one of the ironies of life that just when everybody wants to be outdoors, outdoors is full of small invertebrate creatures of the land and air.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The English soccer season got off to a ragged start today in slush and rain with the favorite and glamor teams losing in a series of high scoring upsets.

ATHENS, Aug. 21 -- British Ambassador Sir Charles Peake protested today to the Greek Government over an incident yesterday in Canea, Crete. There an unidentified person threw a stick of dynamite into the British Consulate premises, doing damage to the building but causing no casualties.

HISTORICAL fiction is debased currency nowadays, but every so often you hear the ring of an honest coin in the lot. One such is Jere Wheelwright's "The Gray Captain," which casts a small unwavering beam into "the night of the Confederacy" and proves something we often forget: that no writer can light up the past for us as movingly as a historical novelist of ability and integrity.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Mississippi voters decide Tuesday whether to return James O. Eastland to his third term in the Senate or elect a man who charges Senator Eastland with being "a part-time Senator who votes Republican as much as he does Democrat."

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Bob Keegan gained credit for his fifteenth victory of the season today but needed help from Jack Harshman and Don Johnson in the ninth inning to preserve a 2-1 triumph for the Chicago White Sox over the Detroit Tigers.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 -- With the ore trade falling off as a result of decreased steel production, wheat looms as a major item for the Great Lakes shipping industry.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Two Marines today won the high-power rifle championships of the American Rifle Association matches. Chief Warrant Officer T. R. Carpenter of Encinitas, Calif., took the service rifle division with an aggregate score of 628 of 650.

HENRY ADAMS and other historians have quoted certain colorful bits of description and characterization from the pen of Sir Augustus John Foster, and portions of his notes on the United States have appeared in journals, but it is only now that the public can see all of them in print.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Minimum standards for economic, social and legal treatment of stateless persons by governments will be formulated in an international instrument to be prepared at a United Nations conference, meeting here from Sept. 13 to 24.

Two modern motorships have been assigned to the East Asiatic Line's direct service between Copenhagen and New York. They will replace the familiar Falstria and Jutlandia now in the company's service to the Far East for which they were built.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 -- Two previously unpublished centuries-old documents, throwing new light on the Jewish struggle for civil rights in the New World, have been found in the Amsterdam Pewish community by Dr. I. S. Emmanuel, scholar who has been doing research in Holland.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 21 (AP) -- There apparently is a wide gap between the way the Army says it would like to train and the way it actually does.

HOBBS, N. M., Aug. 21 (UP) -- A pro-segregation Baptist minister said today that hundreds of parents had pledged themselves to keep their children out of the public schools here unless the local school board reverses its decision to abolish segregation.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- New car inventories continue to decline, but the reduction is being achieved the hard way.

A CONCISE searching study of the effects and potentialities of nuclear energy is being prepared for presentation on N. B. C.-TV from 8 to 9 P. M., Monday, Sept. 13. Its title, taken from the rhythmic counting of the seconds that precedes each test blast of a nuclear device, is "Three, Two, One -- Zero !"

WHILE searching for a missing uncle, bespectacled Walt Powell encounters adventures on a lonely Florida beach. They involve a friendly young engineer turned natural scientist and several hostile seafaring men looking for the wreck of a ship. Convinced that the sunken vessel with its tin and platinum is the key to his uncle's disappearance. Walt forms a striking theory as to its location. In a dramatic dawn descent by diving suit, he outwits his enemies.

FIFTY years ago, from atop a 300-foot tower at the St. Louis World's Fair, the name of a 31-year-old inventor flickered in electrically lit letters eight feet high. The inventor himself, who had come to New York three years before from Yale with a crude wireless detector that had failed, was living high in St. Louis.
Donald Douglas, aircraft manufacturer, recalls a grim early year when his children's pet goose went into the oven for the Christmas dinner.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 21 -- As the week ended here, Korean civilians remained confused and apprehensive.
