CHEROKEE, N. C. -- If you drive through the Great Smoky Mountains National Park you cannot miss this little town strung along the valley of the Oconaluftee River at the junction of U. S. 19 and 441. From Asheville, N. C., which for all practical purposes is the southern terminus of the Blue Ridge Parkway, Cherokee lies fifty miles to the west on U. S. 19.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The first of a series of three festival concerts in memory of Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, who died last Nov. 4, was held this morning at the Temple of Music in South Mountain, Pittsfield.

RETURNING from a reconnaissance in the Ohio country on March 12, 1752, the Maryland frontiersman Christopher Gist encountered an inquisitive Indian when he made camp on the Monongahela River not far from modern Pittsburgh. The Indian was an emissary from the Delaware chiefs who lived on the upper Ohio.

MANILA, Sunday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Vice Admiral A. M. Pride, new naval commander in the Philippine and South China Sea areas, renewed yesterday United States pledges that the United States seventh Fleet would defend Formosa against any Chinese Communist invasion.
Dr. Julius H. Comroe Jr. has been added to the scientific advisory board of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee, formed earlier this year to study the relation of tobacco use and health.

As the reorder flow increases, resident buying offices are getting a clearer picture about the outlook for fall. "Items" rather than large categories of goods appear now as the profit-makers of the next few months.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- The Soviet Union's grant of "full sovereignty" to the East German Government and the refusal of the non-Communist world to recognize the new status of that regime have placed the diplomatic representatives of eleven countries in Berlin in a unique position.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Chicago's helicopter air mail carrier -- Helicopter Air Service -- celebrated this week the completion of five years of service to this city and forty-four suburbs.

LIST Collier Young as an indedependent - minded spokesman for one of the West Coast's more ingenious independent film units, Filmakers, partnered by Ida Lupino and himself, and, it would appear, doing very nicely, indeed.

THEATRE parties, boon or bane of the theatre -- it all depends on which side of the footlights you are -- will have a new wrinkle added with the coming of "Fanny," the new musical which producers Joshua Logan and David Merrick are preparing for a Nov. 4 debut at the Majestic.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- The Soviet Government announced tonight that in the next two years it would build 402 new factories and 200 temporary works to produce reinforced concrete for a program of building factories, homes and farm structures.

The first Europeans to gain a firm foothold on the subcontinent of India since Alexander the Great are the most reluctant to withdraw. The British gave up British India to the Republic of India and Pakistan seven years ago.

IN Vancouver, Wash., just across the Columbia River from Portland, Ore., the Department of Interior has formally designated as a national monument a sixty-acre tract of land on which once stood Fort Vancouver, the first permanent settlement in the State of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 21 (UP) -- The third championship effort proved to be the charm for the "whiz kids" from Monongahela, Pa., who carried the PONY League's national trophy home today after notching a perfect record in the world series.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- The United States Davis Cup team of Tony Trabert and Victor Seixas today brought an end to the winning streak of the new Australian combination of Rex Hartwig and Neale Fraser.

THE key fact about contemporary Africa is that she is the last great uncommitted continent in the clash of ideology that divides the world. Both democracy and communism are unknown to the large majority of her peoples.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The National Mediation Board offered a plan today to both parties for immediate cessation of the American Airlines strike pending a final settlement.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday defended the Kings County grand jury recommendation that the present jurisdiction of the Brooklyn Adolescent Court be abolished.

ROME, Aug. 21 -- Funeral services for Alcide De Gasperi, held today in all Italian dioceses, were attended by many hundreds of thousands of persons in a great outporuing of affection and respect for Italy's noted post-war leader who died Thursday.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A University of Maryland scientist has a new theory that explains the origin of the tornado and identifies it -- surprisingly -- as one of the best friends mankind ever had.

HANOVER, N. H., Aug 21 -- Dartmouth College geographers are scattered all over the northern face of the world this summer, at Thule in Greenland, at Hebron in Labrador, at the northern tip of Ellsmere Island and at the mouth of the Mackenzie River, where it pours into the Arctic Ocean.
MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The cruise ship Agamemnon steamed out of Marseilles today with Kings, Queens, Princes and Princesses aboard.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will open its fortieth annual convention today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- A silent battle is going on in the deep jungle of Malaya for the hearts and minds of the aborigine tribes who fled into the jungle fastnesses hundreds of years ago.

The Giants, nursing a winning streak of four games, were slowed down a bit yesterday when rain and wet grounds forced a postponement of the second contest of their series with the Pirates at the Polo Grounds.

CAREFUL attention to this nosegay of eighteen sprightly short stories leads to a sprightly generalization: if you like one you'll like them all. For Thyra Samter Winslow has a style (vivacious staccato); she has favorite subjects (the fading actress, the stage-struck ingenue, the shrewish wife, the patient husband, lonely people anywhere); and she has a theme (the impermanency of career and marriage.)
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Canada kept its Davis Cup hopes alive today when Lorne Main and Brendan Macken, team captain, defeated Mexico's second-string doubles combination.

ORDINARILY there would be no reason for an enthusiast of crime fiction to open a novel called A SWELL-LOOKING BABE (Lion, 25c), especially when the jacket copy hints that its subtitle might well be "What The Bellboy Saw."
LOUIS STETTNER'S first one-man show opened last week at Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, in a setting that displays this talented photographer's work with dignity and appreciation.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A driving rain that made a soggy mess of the grass track hobbled the runners In the Scottish Highland Games today, but seemed to add luster to Desmond Koch's surprising victory in the caber toss -- an old Scottish specialty.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Inspector Stuyvesant Pinnell, chief of Nassau County detectives, said today he hoped to pin "a half dozen or more" Long Island holdups on George McKinney and Ronald Martin, two of the three men accused of robbing $190,000 from the Franklin National Bank branch in Floral Park on Aug. 18, 1953.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 21 -- Adlai E. Stevenson accused President Eisenhower tonight of complacency and failing to recognize that the nation's economy had not expanded in proportion to the population growth.

Although recent rains have made gardeners all but forget the drought, it will be a poor backyard horticulturist who fails to absorb a few vital lessons. One is that a sure way to successfully circumvent future arid times is through drought-resistant plants, and authorities in various sections of the country herewith offer their own unwatered garden success stories.
The campaign of '54 is on.
An actress, Mildred Dunnock, and a producer, Norris Houghton, will give courses at Barnard College this fall, it was announced yesterday.

The first Cohn blood fractionation machine to be manufactured on a commercial basis was shipped to Paris this week. Four other Cohn machines are now being manufactured commercially for the medical schools of Duke University, the University of California, the University of Pennsylvania and the City of Hope Medical Center in Duarte, Calif.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 21 -- The exposition to mark the fourth centennial of Sao Paulo was opened officially today by Guilherme de Almeida, president of the exposition committee, in the presence of foreign ambassadors and Brazilian officials.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- The trend to civilian dress in the Soviet Union has now spread to most of the score of nonmilitary ministries and institutions that have worn uniforms since wartime days.

Clement Attlee and his Socialist friends must be very naive and very credulous if they accept at its face value Chou En-lai's statement at the banquet given in their honor on Aug. 16 that "the Chinese people and Government are willing to adopt every step to further friendly cooperation and to expand and develop trade between China and Britain."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Col. Herman Beukema, one of the nation's foremost educators, ends a long military career at the end of this month when he retires as head of the Department of Social Sciences at the United States Military Academy.

THE many events and accomplishments of the Berkshire Festival and of the Berkshire Music Center, which ran concurrently with the festival and contributed brilliantly to its offerings, came to a conclusion last Sunday afternoon with the performance of the Berlioz Requiem given especially in honor of Serge Koussevitzky.

ANSHAN, Manchuria, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- The British Labor party goodwill mission today inspected China's greatest steelworks. The group was the first Western delegation to see the plants since the Chinese Communist Government was formed in 1949.

Diplomatic observers trying to fathom the power relationships within the Soviet Union's ruling group have uncovered what appears to be an important new clue It is that Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov apparently was the individual who succeeded to Lavrenti P. Beria's place in the Central Committee of the Communist party when the former secret police chief was purged in July, 1953.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21 (AP) -- John R. Alison, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, was elected president of the Air Force Association today. Mr. Alison, 41-year-old World War II fighter ace, succeeds Gen. George C. Kenney, World War II air commander in the Southeast Pacific Theatre.

For the second week weather like that of last year stimulated department store business. However, two stores were open on a Monday night this year that were closed last year and one store was open on a Saturday that was closed last year.

After sixty-seven years of docking all of its ships in Hoboken, the Holland-America Line is now considering shifting its passenger tonnage to the Manhattan side of the Hudson River, it was learned yesterday.

COLLECTORS and dealers the world around have bought more than $42,500,000 worth of stamps and postal stationery at the Post Office Department's Philatelic Agency in Washington during the past thirty-two and a half years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee's research and development panel recommended today that the Atomic Energy Commission broaden its program of supplying radioactive isotypes for medical research.
Re: "Metternich's Edifice," a letter by Robert Strausz-Hupe (Aug. 8) on Arnold Toynbee's article, "The Revolution We Are Living Through" (July 25):

PHILADELPHIA -- A fifteen-mile piece of the Pennsylvania Turnpike's Delaware River extension is scheduled to open today, the first step in linking the Pennsylvania toll road with the New Jersey Turnpike.

IN a disarming note prefacing this book, its author explains that he has attempted "to reanimate certain limited aspects of life in the eighteenth century, and to compose a novel with the climate flavor of a folk ballad." In this endeavor some readers may consider he has succeeded; others may think the most fitting description for "Captain Lightfoot" is a rollicking yarn.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 21 -- University of California's Santa Barbara College of Arts and Sciences has been moved to a 408-acre campus at Goleta.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The State Department today set for Sept. 13 to 17 public hearings here on United States proposals for revisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
KOHLER, Wis., Aug. 21 -- As the strike of United Auto Workers, C. I. O., against the Kohler Company completed its twentieth week today, there were two diametrically opposed views as to its progress.

Performances of "Fanny," a new musical with Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak, have been taken over to raise funds for two philanthropic organizations. A pre-opening performance of the production Nov. 3 at the Majestic Theatre will be a benefit for the New York City Mission Society.

NEW to Western rail travel this summer and attracting wide attention are the big dome cars on Santa Fe's El Capitan and San Francisco Chief and the low-priced meals on El Capitan and Union Pacific's Challenger.

LITTLE COMPTON, R. I., Aug. 21 -- The little red hen who launched the $4,000,000,000 poultry industry of America, the famed Rhode Island Red, had her day in this tiny state today.

Trimper, in the presidency for the coming year.

In the account of Britain's imminent excursion into commercial television appearing in The Times, I noticed that advertisers are to have no control whatsoever over the entertainment content of video programs. What the audience is to be given will be determined quite independently of the sponsor.

THE development of a real improvement in travel comfort on the airlines is in progress and an announcement last week indicated that excellent progress was being made. Even though the airlines are flying higher than ever, and thus above more bad weather than they did in the past, turbulence is still a problem.

The National Academy of Sciences and the National Research Council have approved a resolution for the Secretary of State and the International Council of Scientific Unions asking that scientific rights to explore oceans and sea bottoms over the continental shelf be safeguarded.
CAIRO, Aug. 19 -- The leaders of Egypt, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia have planned a Moslem missionary invasion of the African Continent to compete with Christian missionaries working there.

CHICAGO, Aug 21 (AP) -- Frank Maritote, Al Capone's brother-in-law and one-time ace muscle-man for the Capone organization, was shot to death tonight in the second Chicago gangland-style slaying in four days.

ARCO, Idaho, Aug. 21 -- Atomic Energy Commission scientists demonstrated here today the operation of one of the hottest nuclear reactors in the nation. The demonstration showed that man was becoming the master of atomic energy in much the same way that he learned to use coal and oil for power.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Somewhere between boom and doom, the economy is clicking along.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senatorial judges in the Army-McCarthy controversy today fixed an Aug. 30 deadline for filing their verdict or verdicts.
Plans have been completed for the opening of a huge river-rail-truck terminal serving the heavily industrialized Pittsburgh area.

THE seventh annual Aix-en-Provence Music Festival, which ran from July 10 to 30, followed the tradition set by its predecessors in devoting most of its opera evenings to Mozart. But this year's festival also took some brave new steps by presenting two operatic manifestations of a different order.

AN autofocusing 4x5 enlarger has been added to the Omega line by Simmon Brothers of Long Island City. The new Automega D-3 has the features of the Omega D-2 and handles negatives from 35mm to 4x5; it also permits the operator to shift from one print size to another without having to refocus.
NEWARK, Aug. 21 (AP)--Nine-year-old Betty O'Neal was freed from a narrow space between the walls of two buildings today after being wedged in it for eighteen hours.

AUGUST brings a peak of bloom to one of the national capital's newer and most unusual parks, Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens, which contains what has been authoritatively called the nation's most diversified collection of flowering water plants.

ALTHOUGH hardy waterlilies have studded ponds and garden pools all summer with starry pink, white or yellow blooms, it is only toward the end of August that aquatic displays begin in earnest. It is then that the tropical waterlilies start to unfold.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 21 -- The first maneuvers to be conducted by a civil defense marine transportation unit in New York State are to be held here Wednesday afternoon as part of the New York State Sheriff's Association's three-day convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee said today the party's Midwest farm conference late this month would emphasize "the golden broken promises" made by Republicans in the 1952 campaign.

The largest tanker ever built in France is in the "new work" listing by the French shipbuilders Association for August. The list numbers four ships to be started, three to be launched and eight to be completed during the month.
About three years ago Alex Lewyt, the industrialist and inventor of the canister-type vacuum cleaner, was almost run over by a boy's "pushmobile."
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 14 -- This capital, one of the noisiest in Latin America, is about to become a city of silence.

The appointment of Wilbur K. McKee as director of New York University's newly established Office of Special Services to Business and Industry was announce yesterday. He also has been named an assistant dean of the university's Division of General Education and Extension Services.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 20 -- Michael Blundell, Minister Without Portfolio and member of the War Council, indicated in a signed article in a weekly journal today that the trend of action in the next few months was intended to bring the Mau Mau terrorist phase nearer to its end.

Gilbreth, and copyright is in the names of the Robert Gilbreths and brother Frank.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Two scientists are working with a device for putting the tang in cheddar cheese with sound instead of time.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- More young couples are having their homes furnished at state expense in Socialist Sweden.

The Eighty-third Congress has adjourned for all legislative purposes. Now that the books are closed, it is time to look at the record of this first Republican Congress, under a Republican Administration, in twenty years. Judged in the light of the President's own program, which in general we have supported, we would say that the record has on the whole been a creditable one.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- San Francisco's $50,000,000 International Airport with expansive new terminal facilities, costing $14,000,000, will be dedicated next Friday.

THE memorial exhibition at the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield, Mass., of about eighty paintings, mainly portraits, by Ellen Emmett Rand (1875-1941) does justice to a fine artist whose work rarely falls below the level of charm and distinction that she reached at a comparatively early age.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Nearly a thousand persons from forty-four nations attended the World Assembly for Moral Rearmament at Caux, Switzerland, this week-end, according to spokesmen for the sponsoring group.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 -- The Brazilian political crisis that seemed virtually settled two days ago has flared up again. Tonight there appeared to be a distinct possibility that the armed forces and public opinion might force President Getulo Vargas to resign.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 22 -- The famous letter written by George Washington to the Newport Jewish congregation on Aug. 21, 1790, was read today by Dennis King, the actor.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- About 9,500 National Guardsmen and Reservists arrived here today, including 4,000 from New Jersey, for two weeks of maneuvers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's great race horse, Native Dancer, will race no more. After a workout at the Saratoga track today there were signs of recurrence of a foot injury, and his owner announced the colt's retirement.

WENDOVER, Utah, Aug. 22 -- Taking advantage of perfect weather today on the Bonneville salt flats, Donald Healey, English designer-driver, today set a total of ten new international and American speed records, including a mark of 192.62 m. p. h. over the measured mile.

LINDEN, N. J., Aug. 22 -- The team of Andy Winfree of Greensboro, N. C., and Jim Reed, of Tarrytown, N. Y., drove a Jaguar to victory in the twelve-hour American-Le Mans endurance race for sport and stock cars today. The event, which ended at midnight, was witnessed by a crowd of 15,000 at the Linden Airport.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 22 -- The first of five separate services of holy communion for delegates attending the general assembly of the World Council of Churches was held this morning at Evanston's First Methodist Church.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Frank Bolling drove in three runs with a single and two sacrifice flies today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 7-to-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox before 18,874 fans at Briggs Stadium.

Smith, member, New York State-Wide Committee of the Pure Water Association of America.

The first half of this century has been a period of crises for individuals and society in which each person has become either a creator or resolver of conflicts, the Rev. Dr. Lowell R. Ditzen, guest preacher, declared yesterday at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 22 -- German Sperrmarks in large amounts were thrown onto the Zurich market last week and the rate fell on Wednesday to 92 Swiss francs, or $21.50, a hundred.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas ridiculed the Eisenhower Administration today for claiming a legislative victory in what he termed the "dismal" record of the Republican - controlled Eighty-third Congress.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- A modest house of worship built after regular working hours and on week-ends by members of a congregation of Jehovah's Witnesses was dedicated here this afternoon at King Street and Clermont Avenue.

PARIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Forty French Union guards fired on 2,500 rioting Vietminh war prisoners protesting their return today on a Norwegian cargo vessel to the Communist-led Vietminh regime, a French Press Agency dispatch from Saigon reported.
TEANECK, N. J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The four-day international police pistol tournament closed today with the New York Police Department taking more trophies than any other group.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Reports that Arthur S. Flemming may be about ready to announce a plan for maintaining a long-term war production base gained new impetus today. This was in the wake of the Defense Mobilizer's cancellation last week of the aluminum production expansion program.

The police seized 599 hoodlums, vagrants and sidewalk loiterers in their fourth and largest weekend round-up of undesirables. The arrests were made over a 48-hour period that ended last midnight. From midnight until 2 A. M. today seven more were arrested.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 22 -- This city, with a reputation for pioneering in municipal development, is completing a new airport which is considered a trail-blazer in two respects.
PARK FOREST, Ill., Aug. 22 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, resumed here today his criticism of the Dixon-Yates power contract.

The Rev. Michael J. Deacy, preaching yesterday at the solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, called for stronger devotion to Mary, the mother of Christ.
Three sailors on a week-end pass stole a taxicab in mid-Manhattan early today, sending cab drivers, policemen and a private detective on a chase in which one sailor was shot and wounded.

In a recent letter to The Times, Geraldine Fitch urges that the United States supply Chiang Kai-shek with weapons so that Nationalist and South Korean forces may more effectively attack the Chinese mainland. MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mexico advanced to the final round of the American Zone Davis Cup competition today by winning the last two singles from Canada for a 4-1 victory.

The Bershaw Realty Corporation, of which Harry Paprish is president, has sold the six-story 101-family apartment house at 37-21 Eightieth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, to a client of David B. Applebaum Co. the latter was co-broker with Irving Kotzen in the transaction. Maxwell G. Cutler was attorney for the seller and Louis Reibel acted for the buyer.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics and the Washington Senators played to a 4-4 second-game deadlock today after Joe De Maestri's singl in the twelfth inning drove home the winning run for a 3-2 first-game Philadelphia triumph.

The Grace Line's Forty-Year Service Medal has been awarded to Capt. Albin A. Andersen, commodore of the company's fleet. Formal presentation was made last week by William G. Holloway, board chairman of W. R. Grace Co.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- After his return from his visit to Prime Minister Churchill, Premier Pierre Mendes-France will report Tuesday on the European army treaty to the combined committees of the National Assembly in what is expected to be a crucial meeting.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 22 -- Members of the Air Force Association undertook today to minimize friction between their home towns and the Air Force over the noise of jet planes.
DENVER, Aug. 22 -- The United States Navy will move 80,000 to 100,000 Vietnamese from North Vietnam to new homes in South Vietnam.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- Seventy-two matches will mark the opening day's program of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The league-leading Cleveland Indians crushed the Baltimore Orioles, 12 -- 1, today for a sweep of the three-game series. It was the sixteenth straight victory for the Indians over the Orioles.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 22 -- The members of the Newport Music Club are taking pride in their second outdoor music festival. The three-day event, which ended tonight, has been most successful and, in view of the good attendance, another festival next year has already been decided upon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- American Airlines and the striking Air Line Pilots Association, Inc., agreed tonight to a temporary settlement of a dispute that grounded all the line's planes for more than three weeks.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight he was confident the Brussels conference had improved the chances of French ratification of the European Defense Community treaty despite failure to reach agreement on the proposed French amendments.

The Armstrong Cork Company in the first half of this year had a consolidated net income of $5,818,540, or $3.56 each on the 1,517,194 common shares outstanding, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $5,167,253, or $3.32 each on 1,415,103 shares, in the first half of 1953.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The action of the Government of Tanganyika in permitting the importation of Japanese textiles beginning next January was welcomed here today by E. F. Hitchcock, chairman of the Tanganyika Sisal Marketing Association.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Red China accused the United States today of "occupying Formosa and thus violating the Cairo and Potsdam Declaration."

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The Labor party called today for a fixed date to be set for home rule in each of the territories Britain governs. The date would be based on an estimate of how soon a democratic government would be practicable.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Stan Musial's two doubles paced the St. Louis Cardinals' thirteen-hit attack on five Cincinnati pitchers today as the Redbirds rallied twice to gain a 9-7 victory over the Redlegs.
The World Glory, the biggest tanker built in this country, will make her debut in New York harbor on Wednesday.

A life of the late Damon Runyon, sports columnist and short- story writer, will be presented by Random House on Friday when it issues Damon Runyon Jr.'s "Father's Footsteps." Based on the author's memory of his father and his father's letters, the book tells the story of how fame distorted the lives of four people: Runyon, his wife and his two children.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, said today that his six-man committee had agreed to keep alive all forty-six censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 22 -- The governing Nationalist party has decided that the League of Nations mandate on South- West Africa has terminated and the territory has become a part of the Union of South Africa.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market continued to move irregularly last week, but closed the period with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices were 9 to 24 points higher, an increase of from 45 cents to $1.20 a bale. Higher prices were recorded in the more distant deliveries.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory here has made three fundamental discoveries involving cancer of the breast, a University of Chicago scientist said today.

For the first time since the last war a major conference between Western Powers ended in open disagreement when the Brussels meeting on the French amendments to the European Defense Community pact collapsed with a frank acknowledgment of failure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The breakdown of the Brussels conference on the European Defense Community has brought the United States close to the point where it may have to reappraise its basic policy toward Europe, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The outcome of censure charges filed in the Senate against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy may depend on the talent of two lawyers who have come into the national spotlight almost overnight.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Oil operators have completed 345 deep test wells through July in the United States and before the year's end a new record will be posted, the Oil and Gas Journal reported today.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Curly Lambeau is out as head coach of the Washington Redskins football team and the new head coach is Joe Kuharich, an official of the team said tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Universal-International has engaged Charlton Heston to star in "The Private War of Major Benson."

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- A generally strong tone in the leading cash wheat markets of the country, together with increasingly gloomy reports about spring wheat production in this country and western Canada; brought enough support into the market last week to give a somewhat firmer undertone. It was difficult, however, to enlist buying support except on recessions.

A New York syndicate declared last night that its proposal to construct a 600,000 kilowatt generating station in Tennessee for the Atomic Energy Commission would have saved the government $150,000,000.

MASON CITY, Iowa, Aug. 22 -- A Braniff Airlines passenger plane, caught in a blinding storm, crashed on a farm south of here today and eleven of the nineteen persons aboard were killed. The twin-engined plane was demolished, but did not burn. First arrivals at the scene said it bounced 500 feet after first hitting the earth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period Aug. 14 through Aug. 21:

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman today joined the Democratic attack on the voting record of Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, who, like Mr. Harriman, frequently has been mentioned in the race for Governor of New York.

BIG-SCREEN color television made its debut last night, which marked a major occasion for the Columbia Broadcasting System. It not only put on the first color show ("Toast of the Town") of the new season, but also provided two new 19-inch color sets, built by one of its subsidiaries, for an invited audience gathered at the network's headquarters at 485 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has dismissed part of a complaint charging twenty-four tomato processing companies with combining to boycott and destroy a cooperative tomato growers association in Ohio, Mississippi and Indiana. The Commission acted by supporting an initial decision of F. T. C. hearing examiner Everett F. Haycraft.

Senator A. S. Mike Monroney asserted last night that the United States could not win the leadership of the world by offering military supplies "to all comers, no matter how generous these supplies might be."
Toy sales this year may pass the billion-dollar mark for the first time in history, according to the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. Last year's retail volume was about $900,000,000.

God is the master builder but a partnership between God and man is necessary for work of any greatness, the Rev. Dr. Ernest M. Halliday declared yesterday morning at the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
LOMAX, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Officials said that a loose rail coupling might have caused the derailment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- News of the development in South-West Africa toward an independent status and union with South Africa confirmed rumors that have reached United Nations headquarters here, but official reaction must await the convening of the ninth General Assembly on Sept. 21, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche said today. Dr. Bunche is director of the Trusteeship Division.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Per capita income in the United States reached a record high level of $1,709 in 1953.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 22 -- French Premier Pierre Mendes-France will visit Prime Minister Churchill tomorrow on a mission some informed observers view as an effort to make a decided change in policy as a result of the European Defense Community deadlock.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- The 30,046 fans who saw the Yankees lose, 8 -- 2, to the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park today possibly sat in on the death of a dynasty.

IT seems from this vantage point that not enough attention has been paid to the fact that Branch Rickey will retire as general manager of the Pirates at the end of the 1955 season. That's important news because the Mahatma may be the most important executive in the game. It was he who altered the character of the sport with his farm systems and indelible is the imprint he will leave on the game.

The initial Broadway appearance of Jennifer Jones, a leading Hollywood star, is heralded once more. This time the Academy Award-winner for "The Song of Bernadette" (1944) actually has been signed by Lyn Austin and Thomas Noyes to act in "Portrait of A Lady."

Property on the lower West Side that has been owned by the Trinity Church Corporation for 249 years is passing to new control with the signing of a contract for the purchase of four five-story buildings at 30-47 Vestry Street and 54-56 Laight Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- "Parenthood in a Free Nation," a new basic course for parents, has been drafted by the Parent Education Project at the last three weeks at workshop sessions at the University of Chicago.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- It is not easy for a man to cut himself off from his country and his people. It is perhaps even more difficult for one who, like myself, has made a certain name there and received recognition as a creative artist. But freedom counts for much, and indeed is so important, particularly for the artist, that life without it becomes almost unbearable. That is the case in Poland today.
LOMAX, Ill., Aug. 22 -- The Santa Fe Chief left the rails today on its run from Chicago to Los Angeles, killing four persons and injuring at least fifty-three.

Four hundred fifty children swarmed through the picnic grounds of the Belmont Race Track yesterday afternoon on the first annual picnic of the Coordinating Council for the 105th Precinct in Queens Village.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- I want to tell you about my life in Poland. Perhaps it will explain why I took such risks to escape and why people in Poland are so bitter and unhappy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Bobby Thomson celebrated his return to regular duty with a two-run homer to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 12-to-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs before 30,093 today.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 22 -- An attempt by a pair of thieves to open a night deposit vault of the National City Bank of Long Beach was thwarted tonight by the unexpected return of the bank custodian.

Your column recently printed a letter concerning the issues implied in the recent debate on the revision of the Atomic Energy Act of 1946 and concluded that the "filibuster" was essential to develop the full implications of that bill. There remains at least one concept in the bill that has apparently received little attention from the Senate or the House.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 22 -- Jordan was accused by the Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman today of flooding the United Nations truce organization with fictitious incidents.

Newspaper circulation and income are the best in history. But income might be $100,000,000 more a year. This was the word brought to the annual meeting of the Texas Daily Newspaper Association in Galveston on Saturday.
Foreign exchanges moved irregularly last week. Turnover was not particularly heavy but at times special situations acted to speed up the pace of the market and an increase in transfers.
The twenty-ninth regatta in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's championship series failed to produce a finisher yesterday. There was no breeze.

The new national formula of preferential automobile liability insurance rates for adult owners who drive solely for pleasure will be extended today to New Jersey. More than 50 per cent of the state's insured autoists will get reductions up to 18 per cent.

HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Aug. 19 -- Substantial progress has been made in speeding up the evacuation of Vietnamese refugees from Haiphong since the United States Navy began sealift operations here early this week.

The failure of Congress to face up to the necessity of adopting a uniform code of committee procedure seems all the more deplorable in the light of an excellent report on this subject just accepted by the American Bar Association.

We all have "something that could be used for the betterment of our living," the Rev. Ian A. G. Easton declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street. But despite this, he said, "mankind is busy fencing itself in."

CLASSICISTS will be delighted to learn that the original green and red guide lines in the subway shuttle system, which are being superseded by fluorescent directionals stemmed directly from the legend of Theseus' slaying of the Minotaur in the labyrinth in Crete.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, has set up a special military committee to study the problem of how United States prisoners of war should conduct themselves under Communist "brainwashing."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Republican National Committee announced today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon, Senator Everett Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, and Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, would lead a three-day campaign "workshop meeting" at Cincinnati next week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Joseph C. Ellis, 45 years old, Senate financial clerk, today shot and killed himself after seriously wounding his wife, Elizabeth, in the face, the police reported.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 22 -- A pair of decisive victories today brought to an end the region II semi-finals for the national sailing championship. Bill Cox of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound was the triumphant sailor.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Australia's hold on the national doubles tennis championship was broken today. In the final of the seventy-fourth tournament Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati defeated Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3, before a gallery of 5,000 at the Longwood Cricket Club.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 22 -- A working model of an electronic instrument designed to make possible mass testing for early cancer has been developed here at Airborne Instruments Laboratory, Inc.
An Emperor, a President, a Prime Minister and a First Lady have given ship models to the Marine Museum of the Seamen's Church Institute, according to W. E. Greyble, curator of the exhibit.

MASSENA, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said today that Governor Dewey had claimed "credit for things he didn't do" in connection with the St. Lawrence Seaway and power development.

A plot containing 29,000 square feet on the north side of Montauk Highway, between Lincoln Avenue and Hiddink Street, in Sayville, L. I., has been sold by Philip Yarrington to the All States Realty Corporation for improvement with a gasoline station.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Service police have rounded up thirty young airmen at Chanute Air Force Base suspected of being members of a secret "pachuco" terrorist society.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Russians swept the board in the women's European rowing championships today, winning all five titles.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 22 -- The eighth Edinburgh Festival of Music and Drama opened today under gray skies and drizzling rain. But before the first opera, ballet, concert or play had begun, two memorable displays already were open to cheer the damp and dispirited visitor.

The Association of American Indian Affairs yesterday appealed to President Eisenhower to veto the Utah Indian Termination Bill. It would end Federal supervision over four small bands of Paiute and Shoshone Indians in Utah.
UPPER NYACK, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- The Nyack Field Club was dedicated here this afternoon with the members of the 165 founding families and their friends in attendance.

NO one knows how many bison once roamed the Great Plains. In uncountable millions they moved north each spring and south each autumn, huge, ugly creatures with heavy forequarters and slight hindquarters, small eyes and shaggy manes. Most were members of four gigantic herds. The northern range of one overlapped the southern range of the next.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Nobody yet knows what it was. But like countless mysterious objects that have whirled through the heavens in recent years -- or at least caused people to stare at them -- this one was a flying saucer to a lot of folks today.

A trade association representing 800 printing concerns in the metropolitan area questioned yesterday the wisdom of recommendations by the Temporary State Commission on the Courts. These would substitute typewriting and mimeographing for the present printing of records and briefs in appeal cases.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Russians swept the board in the women's European rowing championships today, winning all five titles.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 22 -- The eighth Edinburgh Festival of Music and Drama opened today under gray skies and drizzling rain. But before the first opera, ballet, concert or play had begun, two memorable displays already were open to cheer the damp and dispirited visitor.

School teachers and the police should have more authority to control children, Patrick J. Fogarty, justice of the Bronx Domestic Relations Court, said yesterday as two boys were arraigned before him. They were Joseph Figueroa, 15 years old, of 1791 Bruckner Boulevard, and Robert Monzon, 13, of 1472 Southern Boulevard, both the Bronx.

The refusal of President Eisenhower to raise tariffs on lead and zinc was a statesmanlike and courageous decision. It strengthens the hope that the hearings to revise the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade next month can be oriented toward more liberal policies.
Merchant shipbuilding in the world's yards aggregated 1,305 vessels, of 11,875,317 gross tons, on July 1, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.
DENVER, Aug. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed a law today under which up to $3,000,000 worth of alien property confiscated during World War II could be turned over to charitable organizations.

Alexander Schneider, the violinist-conductor and his chamber music associates gave a third beautiful concert in Washington Square Park last night. The audience was estimated by a Park Department official between five and six thousand.
YONKERS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Rose Adios lowered her mile mark for 3-year-olds by a fifth of a second at Yonkers Raceway tonight while winning the Harrison $5,000 pace in 2:04.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The State Department had no comment to make today on the breakdown of the Brussels conference except to say that it created a "very serious situation".
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The nation's two biggest labor unions roundly criticized President Eisenhower today for vetoing the Federal pay rise bill.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 23 -- Excessive taxation and the paperwork it entails is driving thousands of independent retailers out of business, W. W. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation, warned here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Aviation Week magazine said today two meteors had become satellites of the earth and were revolving with it 400 to 600 miles out in space.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- In quiet trading, the stock market here turned slightly dull today although several industrial issues improved.
The Giuseppe Giulietti, one of Italy's largest supertankers, arrived in New York yesterday on her maiden voyage manned by men who own her.

KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 23 -- Charges that Gov. Robert B. Meyner was "insincere" and that the State Legislature was dominated by Protestant ministers were made yesterday by the Rev. Thomas J. Conroy, pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church here.

" Rescue Below Zero," by Ian Mackersey, an account of an incident that occurred to the British North Greenland Expedition in September, 1952, will be published Sept. 30 by Norton. The expedition had gone to Greenland to spend a winter in research.

Operations of the nation's steel mills this week are estimated at 62.7 per cent of capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Calculated to produce 1,496,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, it compares with last week's actual rate of 61.8 per cent.

In August one usually does one of two things with one's lawn. Assuming, that is, rain has been scarce or wholly absent for much too long a time -- as indeed, despite some relief, it was this summer, in this part of the country.
DENVER, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers said that 15,000 of its members went on strike today against the Anaconda Copper Mining Company.

Stocks took their worst beating yesterday since Aug. 6, with industrials bearing the brunt of the attack. Only aircrafts showed gains as a group and even among these early advances were sharply reduced.

Josephine Hull, star of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," is out of the Howard Teichmann - George S. Kaufman play because of an injury she suffered last Friday. It is the second time during the New York run of the play that the actress has had to relinquish her acting assignment because of an ailment.

Consumption of paper in the United States in the first half of 1954 was only slightly below that of the comparable period of last year, it was reported yesterday by E. W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

Following his failure to change the European Defense Community pact at Brussels, Premier Mendes-France has paid a dramatic visit to Prime Minister Churchill, the originator of the European Army idea, to discuss the crisis now facing Europe and the whole Atlantic community.
DENVER, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today announcing the "pocket veto" of a bill to grant 1,500,000 Federal workers a 5 per cent pay increase:

IN the Upper Peninsula of Michigan the winters are hard and long, the hunting and fishing are good, the scenery is beautiful and the people are tough. Finns, Swedes, French Canadians, Cornishmen and various other kinds of Americans, they work in lumber Camps and iron mines, on farms and in shops. Whatever their occupation, they are rugged individualists, to a man.

MATSUYAMA, Japan, Aug. 11 -- The new Japanese Army, still in a formative stage, is a well-fed, well-paid body of troops. It has already acquired some popularity in the country regions from which most of its recruits are drawn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, said today a House Merchant Marine subcommittee which he heads wou.d hold hearings in West Coast centers in October.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Headed by the national champion, Tony Trabert, an international field of thirty-two players started play today in the invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

Plans are being worked out by conferees at Ruthrauff Ryan on how to make friends and influence potential recruits among the nation's youth on behalf of the Air Force. That organization has $1,000,000 to spend on behalf of its effort to keep its rolls filled, and R. R., which won the account over sixteen other agencies, is losing no time in carrying out its mission.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 (UP) -- About 200,000 Mississippians are expected to vote tomorrow in a Democratic primary featured by the most heated Senatorial campaign since the early Nineteen Forties.

Directors of the Western Pacific Railroad Company, at a special meeting to be held on Aug. 31, will consider a proposal to retire the road's outstanding preferred stock. F. B. Whitman, president, said the proposal would entail the exchange of $100 par value of new 5 per cent thirty-year sinking fund debentures and a fraction of a share of common stock for each share of preferred.
Thirty-five postal employes from the metropolitan area attended yesterday the first session of a five-day training course that will qualify them to instruct mail truck drivers on safe driving.
The "thrill-seeking" adolescents are, as your editorial of Aug. 19 points out, indeed past understanding. Society must now turn to preventive measures which anticipate police action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today friendly foreign nations had got $2,500,000,000 in revenue last year -- and might get more this year -- from American military spending abroad.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- The West German state and local government employes rejected as insufficient today an offer to increase hourly wages by five pfennigs (about a cent) and monthly salaries between 3 and 7 per cent. Their union, representing approximately 800,000 West German public employes, had demanded an increase of 10 pfennigs and 10 per cent respectively.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- Using a wedge with the skill of a magician, Billy Joe Patton won his opening-round match in the United States amateur golf championship at the nineteenth hole today.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- An international commission of lawyers heard here today Antoni Klimowicz' story of his escape from Poland to Britain. They are studying legal aspects of his case that might aid others seeking refuge from Communist countries.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The Brookmeade Stable's Gandharva won a big-money race at the Saratoga track today. She collected $44,650 of the $59,050 gross in the sixty-third running of the Spinaway Stakes for 2-year-old fillies.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Stockholders of Society Brand Clothes, Inc., today approved a proposal to selling its clothing business to Hart, Schaffner Mark, Chicago's largest manufacturer of men's wear.

Sheet steel shortages and rigid Government controls on construction are the only two factors holding back the British steel office equipment industry from enjoying the greatest boom in its history, according to Morris Wright.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Aug. 23 -- A lay-off of 3,000 production workers at the Republic Aviation Corporation soon, owing to delays in completion and delivery of Air Force jet fighter-bombers and photo-reconnaissance planes, was announced by the company here today.
A group of Republican candidates brought suits in Supreme Court yesterday to void Liberal party endorsements of Democratic candidates for Congress, the State Senate and the Assembly in Queens.

An investment banking group headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis is offering today to the public 200,000 shares of common stock of the Electronics Corporation of America at $12 a share. Other underwriters are F. S. Moseley Co.; Shearson, Hamill Co., and the Stone Webster Securities Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Census Bureau, in a new estimate for the November elections, said that this year for the first time the nation will have more than 100,000,000 persons of voting age. This is exclusive of 2,500,000 voters in the armed forces.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- If for nothing else, the current festival will be remembered for its revival tonight of Rossini's neglected masterpiece "Le Comte Ory."
The drive to rid the city of hoodlums and undesirables continued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A group of New Jersey poultry farmers appealed to the Federal Government today for special economic aid to counteract low poultry prices, but got no assurance of help.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 23 -- Saeed Hassan, a secretary in the Ministry for Economic Affairs, said today that "very senior" Pakistani Government officials and leading industrialists would visit the Soviet Union in September or October.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the Brown Company, large paper pulp manufacturer, said today sale of certain properties of the Brown Corporation, Canadian subsidiary of the Brown Company, to the International Paper Company had been discussed.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Anxious to be in a good inventory position for the holiday season, retail buyers bought briskly yesterday at four giftwares shows in five of New York City's hotels. More buyers are on hand this week to view the exhibits of more exhibitors than attended similar showings in the spring.

A gift to Columbia University of 6,500 acres of undeveloped property near Ringwood, N. J., in northern Passaic County, was announced yesterday. The donor was an alumnus, Norvin Hewitt Green of New York.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Greenwich's twelfth banking office will be opened in October by the First National Bank, which announced plans today for a branch office in the Glenville section of town.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The Duke of Edinburgh was cheered by thousands of onlookers today as he landed at Aberdeen after an Atlantic crossing in the royal yacht Britannia.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Two New York area girls who survived the hardships of refugee life in World War II, and came to this country to attain top high school honors, have received $1,400 scholarships to Mount Holyoke College.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 23 -- A K. L. M. Royal Dutch airliner bound from New York to Amsterdam crashed and sank in the North Sea today ten miles from the Dutch coast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Barbara Stanwyck, who finished "Cattle Queen of Montana" two weeks ago for Benedict Bogeaus, will make another picture for the independent producer in October. The movie is entitled "Bow Tamely to Me," based on a magazine story by Kenneth Perkins.

The apartment building accommodating seventeen families on plot 75 by 143 feet at 75 Fairview Avenue in Jersey City, N.J., has been purchased by Max Haberman from Etta Shoenholz. The sale was negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc.

TORONTO, Aug. 23 -- A 1921 50-cent piece has been purchased by a Cleveland collector for $1,400, one of the highest amounts ever paid for a Canadian coin.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23 -- By cooperation the United States can save at least five years in the development of commercial atomic power in South America with actual benefit to the United States' own atomic program, Robert LeBaron, who is intimately associated with that program, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- In the last hours of the Eighty-third Congress the House was treated to an effective display of the art of satire, a rare talent in the political trade. The demonstrator was Representative Melvin Price of Illinois, and other Democrats promptly caught the idea.

The art of dining is expressed not only in gourmet foods but also in attractive accoutrements for eating. A pleasant blending of usefulness and beauty is seen in new cutlery, stainless steel and silverware patterns now coming into stores.

Decorations were presented yesterday on Governors Island to two former Army corporals in recognition of their resistance to Communist indoctrination and inhumane treatment in North Korean prisoner-of-war camps.
A Kings County grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday against four teen-age Brooklyn hoodlums charged with killing two men for thrills.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Joe Kuharich put the Washington Redskins through their paces for the first time as head coach today following the sudden removal yesterday of Curly Lambeau by George Preston Marshall, Redskin owner.

The shock which all of us received reading of the unbelievable crimes of the four young lads in Brooklyn and the growth of juvenile delinquency poses a problem not only for psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers but for all citizens of New York.

The manpower problem caused by return of airmen to civilian life constitutes a major "headache" of the Air Force, according to Lieut. Col. Robert P. Keim, the Air Force's information service director in the New York area.

WENDOVER, Utah, Aug. 23 -- Breaking two international and twenty-four American records in the first six hours, a team of five British and American drivers was zipping around a ten-mile circular course today in an assault on all twenty-four-hour speed marks for Class D cars.
The rules for trading in futures in broiler chickens were released yesterday by the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading will open on Sept. 7 and the first delivery option will be December.

Israel has made marked progress in solving its public health and juvenile delinquency problems, the fortieth annual convention of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The ultimate answer to the effectiveness of the anti-subversion bills adopted by the Eighty-third Congress is expected to rest overwhelmingly with the courts.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 23 -- Accountants should pay more attention to the man in the street in presentation of annual reports of business concerns. Philip A. Chester, managing director of the Hudson Bay Company made this appeal at the opening conference of the annual meeting of the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The application of George E. Roosevelt to become one of the resident directors of the Long Island Rail Road was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Brooks Atkinson, after listing a dozen of our Government's current practices, wonders if we want it that way. The source of his wonder is clear, for in raising his voice against these acts, he stands almost alone among our eminent intellectuals.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP) -- James Schoonmaker's Dingo, sailing under the colors of the Central Long Island Sound fleet, today won the opening race of five in the fifth North American championship of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association.

Prices of cotton futures moved 11 points lower to 2 points higher yesterday, with the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange showing the greatest weakness.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands. Aug. 23 -- Indonesia produced 3, 487 long tons of tin-in-concentrates in July, a post-war record for a single month, the International Tin Study group reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, and bituminous coal industry representatives met with an interagency coal committee today to discuss proposals for aiding the economically distressed industry.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Comic Books will hold a special meeting next week-end in an effort to draft legislation that would bar the glamorizing of brutality and sadism in publications available to minors.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 23 -- The Rev. Four former members of Hungary's Parliament and Ilona Massey, the Hungarian-born actress, told a Congressional inquiry here yesterday that the masses in their motherland were unhappy and restive under Communist rule.

A subway motorman, trapped in the telescoped cab of his train when it crashed headlong into the concrete wall of an underground terminal, was freed last night after a dramatic seven-hour struggle. David Moclair, 52 years old, of 1130 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, was rushed to Fordham Hospital in a critical condition after the long ordeal, which ended only after his left foot was amputated.
PORT ANGELES, Wash., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A mountain-climber trapped in a crevasse by his own heroism was found dead yesterday on towering Mount Olympus.

Today's new film is "The Egyptian," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the novel by Mika Waltari, in CinemaScope and color, with Jean Simmons Victor Mature, Edmund Purdom, Gene Tierney and Michael Wilding heading the cast, at the Roxy Theatre.
The Department of Parks appealed yesterday to the City Planning Commission to provide $36,362,474 in the city's 1955 capital budget for improvement of the park system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced it has issued fifty-six new certificates allowing rapid tax write-offs for part of the cost of new production facilities totaling $63,506,730.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress, central organization of the British labor unions, cautioned the Conservative Government today against following economic policies that might lead to widespread wage demands.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Americans soon will get their first look at a pretty teen-ager who may eclipse Princess Margaret as fashion arbiter for the smart young set in Britain.

Two five-story buildings containing twenty apartments at 142 and 144 Henry Street in Brooklyn have been sold by the Gustave Realty Corporation to an investing client of Lawrence King, attorney. The Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation was the broker and Sidney Kramer was the attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Government cancellation of an aluminum production expansion program has given new impetus to reports that officials may soon announce a long-range plan to keep the nation's war production machinery in readiness.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 22 -- United States and Chinese Nationalist military circles here see no imminent Communist military threats to the Nationalist stronghold of Formosa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States and Pakistan signed today an emergency assistance agreement covering aid the United States already was rushing to flooded areas in East Pakistan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The Indonesians here indicated today that if West New Guinea were turned over to them, it would "open the road" toward eventual Indonesian participation in the proposed Southeast Asian defense pact.
Although second-quarter business improved materially, sales and earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America were substantially lower in the first six months of this year than a year ago.

PEIPING, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The British Labor party's goodwill mission, headed by clement R. Attlee, will meet Mao Tse-Tung, Chinese Communist chief of state, tomorrow. It will be the first time the 61-year-old Communist leader has talked with Western political chiefs since his Government came to power in 1949.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Helen Schade would not be too surprised, in these topsy turvey days, if a giant crawled down the side of her house and asked for Jack, the bean stalk boy.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Six locomotives to ease the war-caused transportation shortage in Korea were started on their way to Pusan today on the freighter Philippine Bear.

Premier Mendes-France's proposed changes in the E. D. C. treaty are unacceptable to the other parties -- West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Italy and Luxembourg. NEWARK, Aug. 23 -- Superior Court Judge Frederic R. Colie upset today a 1952 order of the Essex County Tax Board that had raised by $2,000,000 assessments on selected commercial properties in suburban areas of Essex County.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 23 -- Bishop John Peter of the Reformed Church of Hungary, and a delegate to the Second General Assembly of the World Council of Churches, said here today that "in no sense of the word" could he be called a Communist.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Roy Meadows of Grimes, Iowa, broke 95 of 100 targets today to win the veteran's championship for women over 50 years of age, an opening event of the fifty-fifth Grand American Trapshoot.

BIG bluefish and big bluefins seem to be taking up most of the salt water spotlight now, with the bluefish plentiful and fat in the waters of The Race, and bluefin tuna showing in good numbers off Rhode Island.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France stopped tonight in Normandy to talk with President Rene Coty on what to do about the European Defense Community treaty in the French National Assembly.
DENVER, Aug. 23 -- President Eisenhower said today that he would not sign a bill raising the pay of Government workers 5 per cent.

Every high school student here struggling with German, Latin or some other foreign language knows how useful a German-English or similar dictionary is. But for most of us, once our days of foreign language study are over, such dictionaries recede over the horizon.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Two generals agreed today that the Army should tell its story both to the public and to its own ranks as frankly, accurately and completely as possible.

TRENTON, Aug. 23 -- An official of the State Division of Employment Security swore here today that his superior officer had told agency employes last spring that former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman was receiving transcripts of their secret testimony to state investigators.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs were nearing the equivalent of 1 per cent a year.
A fight for control of the far-flung billion-dollar Montgomery Ward Co. appeared to be in prospect yesterday.

May I point out, in connection with your "Topics" of Aug. 2, that the first inauguration date was April 30, 1789. From Federal Hall Washington walked with his official party up to St. Paul's Chapel for a service of thanksgiving, in accordance with a resolution which had been adopted by Congress.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 23 -- Although the war in North Vietnam has been over for almost a month, the French high command remains officially silent on the number of French Union prisoners of war it expects to recover from the Vietminh and prisoners it is planning to return.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Some influential United Nations delegates a trying to work out a compromise in the race between Prince Wan Waithayakon and Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens for president of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The Government announced today it would guarantee a $465,000 American investment in a French company producing styrene monomer, a chemical product used in synthetic rubber and plastics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Buying demand continued slack in the grain markets today, and all cereal futures worked lower early in the session. Long liquidation was indicated in wheat, while there was scattered selling in the coarse grains.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will use its facilities Thursday to broadcast an editorial opinion of its own.

MONTREAL, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Roman Catholic Bishops in Quebec and other French-language areas of Canada have been given permission to perform parts of certain religious ceremonies in French rather than Latin.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 23 -- The battleship Missouri left her home port here shortly after noon today and headed for the West Coast and inactive duty with the Navy's mothball fleet. The 45,000-ton ship, the scene of the signing of the formal surrender of Japan after World War II, received a rousing send-off.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 -- Egypt demanded today that the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization reopen the case in which Israel is accused of maintaining a fortified stronghold disguised as an agricultural settlement at El Auja in the demilitarized zone on Egypt's Sinai frontier.
A thirty-six-inch water main that broke at about 7 A. M. yesterday at Thirty-second Street and Madison Avenue had a slightly off-beat effect in this tight-knit city.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 23 -- A group of Yale University sailors spoiled the American debut of a six-man Oxford University crew tonight, turning back the visitors in two of three races in Manhasset Bay.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Juvenile delinquency in Britain dropped 14 per cent last year.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 23 -- Before leaving Brussels to visit Prime Minister Churchill, Premier Pierre Mendes-France indicated that if the European Defense Community treaty were not ratified, he would join the United States-British plan to grant approximate sovereignty to West Germany.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 513 pints of blood on Friday. Among the day's donations were one of 332 pints at the United States Naval Air Station, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, and one of 105 pints at the Manhattan blood center, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23 -- A new drug made from brewer's yeast has been found effective in treating dogs with many types of body irritations, including those that cause loss of hair, two Yale University scientists said today.

Dodger rooters cast supercilious glances at their brothers from across the river as if to say, "Get outa our way, ya bums ya. Here we come!"

ROME, Aug. 23 -- Italy's postwar Premier, Alcide De Gasperi, who already is beginning to be called "the rebuilder of Italy," was buried here today amid manifestations of grief and affection from the people he led out of ruin and despair at the end of World War II.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union and its East European satellites have turned Imdonesia's second international economic fair here into a major propaganda vehicle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Admiral Felix B. Stump, Commander in Chief of United States Forces in the Pacific, said today he saw no "positive indications" of an imminent Communist Chinese assault on Formosa.

Billy McNeece, Central Islip (L. I.) middleweight, gained the unanimous decision over Garth Panter, Salt Lake City, in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. McNeece weighed 165 1/4 pounds, Panter 161.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Representative B. Carroll Reece said today that Congress ought to investigate "the source and nature" of the pressure behind newspapers that have been critical of his inquiry into tax-exempt foundations.

Potato futures closed 1 point lower to 8 higher yesterday in the most active trading in the history of the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume was 1,477 car lots (45,000 pounds to a car) compared with 1,429 on Aug. 22, 1952, the previous high.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 23 -- Thornton Wilder's "The Matchmaker," which is a rewritten version of his farce, "The Merchant of Yonkers," had a very cordial reception here tonight as one of the principal exhibits of this year's Edinburgh Festival.
ATLANTIC, Iowa, Aug. 23 (AP) -- "Ten seconds to live."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The United States Information Agency is opening an offensive in the battle for the minds and sympathies of the people of Indochina.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- For the professional man, life under a Communist system is more difficult altogether than for the worker or peasant. This is particularly so in the case of the creative artist.

CHANUTE AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., Aug. 23 -- Seventy more airmen suspected of being members of a secret terrorist society were rounded up today for questioning. Maj. Gen. Byron E. Gates, commander of the base, ordered "positive proceedings," including court-martial charges, against the young outlaws.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 -- The Argentine Society of Authors, one of the country's oldest and most respected cultural groups, has protested to the Interior Minister against a police edict prohibiting the society from presenting its usual course of lectures on nonpolitical subjects.
VANCOUVER, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Vancouver Sun says discussions are under way for construction of a second huge aluminum plant in British Columbia.
DENVER, Aug. 23 -- President Eisenhower told the nation tonight it could be proud of the Eighty-third Congress.

Gen. Mark Clark casts aspersions on diplomats who "do not understand military needs" and seek to please the Governments to which they are assigned. But do generals have all the answers?

Charles I. Brady has been named district sales manager for lighting products in the New York City-Newark area for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

The five-story building on plot 75 by 100 feet at 325 East Thirty-eighth Street, formerly occupied as a research center by New York University, has been leased for thirty years by the Chiropractic Institute of New York from the 325-29 East Thirty-eighth Street Realty Corporation, of which Samuel Fuchs is president. Spear Co, were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Four Republican Senators filed today a majority report said to be mildly critical of both sides in the Army-McCarthy controversy. The Republican accord came as something of a surprise. It apparently reflected the success of appeals for party unity in the face of a tough Congressional election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- American Airlines and the striking Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., removed tonight the last barrier to temporary settlement of their dispute. It was agreed to resume operations at 12:01 A. M. Wednesday.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Thirty-four young women from Darien and New Canaan will be presented here on Sept. 10 at the sixth Autumn Cotillion in the Wee Burn Club.

Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, said yesterday that he hoped criminal prosecutions would result from a four-day Senate inquiry into Federal Housing Administration abuses that he will begin here this morning.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) plans to build a $17,000,000 petrochemical plant in the area Toledo-Lima, Ohio, Clyde T. Foster, the president, announced yesterday. He appointed Edward F. Morrill general manager of the company's new petrochemical division, effective Sept. 1.
American shipyards received yesterday the first order to build a new merchant ship in almost two years.
Thirty-five thousand Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel next year, and of these 25,000 will be from South Africa, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, said yesterday.

High school fashions presented at Abraham Straus yesterday could easily have passed college entrance examinations -- they followed the flannel, corduroy and alpaca trend set by this year's collections of campus fashions.
Sea transport activities of the armed forces, long the object of criticism by private shipping, allocated in the last fiscal year a total of $383,359,304 in business to the private industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Jim Hegan and Bobby Avila committed throwing errors in the middle of four Philadelphia hits tonight and the seventh-place Athletics scored three runs to beat the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 4 -- 1, behind a fine pitching performance by Johnny Gray, a rookie.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Julius Petty, 47-year-old fur dealer and cotton buyer from Stuttgart, Ark., emerged today as America's champion trap-shooter from 16 yards.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- The Distributors Corporation of America, a new producing distributing company headed by Fred J. Schwartz, president of the Century Theatre Circuit in New York, will provide an additional source of financing for independent producers operating in this country and abroad.

Several specimens of the greater snow goose, which sheds all its primary feathers at one time, were discovered in that earthbound state by a recent expedition to an Arctic island.
