Five-year-old tightrope walkers toed the lines smartly, an 8-year-old strong man lifted 100-pound weights, and a snorting bull wearing two pink shoes and two black ones performed before a completely credulous circus audience yesterday.

Five new corporate issues totaling $74,600,000 will be offered to the investing public today. They consist of bonds, debentures, preferred and common stock in the public utility and food distribution fields. All of the financing is for expansion purposes of the companies involved.

New York City welcomes the 250 Police Academy graduates who were sworn yesterday and assigned to Commissioner Adams' experiment in intensive policing of a given area in East Harlem. The new men are badly needed, and we could use thousands more.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Mill buying was in evidence in the wheat market today in a fairly big way for the first time in several weeks.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The sharp division of French opinion and emotions regarding the European Defense Community treaty, which will show up in the National Assembly's debate on this subject Saturday, has arisen from a complex of causes.
Thomas Grace, former New York State director of the Federal Housing Administration, testified yesterday that he had received $48,500 in fees from his family law firm while he was a Federal official.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- On the wall of his office hangs a chart at which William M. Case can look -- gloomily -- all day long.
JAMESBURG, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Two young prisoners who fled from the State Home for Boys tonight were captured by two angry motorists a few hours later and turned over to the police.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The colt Uncle Gus is a candidate for most-improved-horse-of-the-month honors. He was claimed on Aug. 3 for $10,000. Today, in an allowance race, he beat 2-year-olds that have been placing in stakes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The United States Government, engaged in a fundamental review of its entire European defense policy, expressed a lingering hopetoday that France would ratify the European Defense Community treaty.

Stocks on the New York Stock Exchange stood on July 31 at the highest average month-end price since June, 1946, the institution reported yesterday. The figure was $47.61, against $45.68 on June 30, 1954, and $47.99 on June 30, 1946.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Sam Boulmetis took the spotlight again at Atlantic City today by riding three consecutive winners going into the featured event.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Prices fell slightly and the volume of business contracted in the stock markets here today. The only exception was in South African gold minings, which rose in active trading.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 -- The restoration of Morven, historic Princeton estate, as New Jersey's first executive mansion has been delayed indefinitely by a lack of sufficient funds. If it is to be accomplished at all, the State Legislature will have to increase to $150,000 or more the $67,575 already appropriated for this purpose.

The National Gypsum Company has increased its dividend 5 cents for the second time this year, making it 45 cents, to be paid on Oct. 1. The company also announced yesterday a $15,000,000 eighteen-month expansion program.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- Playing at a better-than-par pace, Billy Joe Patton moved through the second round of the United States amateur golf championship today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Oxford University's sailing team rebounded from a defeat at the hands of Yale's skippers yesterday and triumphed over the Eli's in the Manhasset Bay One-Design Class, 2 to 1, on Manhasset Bay today.

Large numbers of German made radios and radio-phonographs are scheduled to reach the United States market within the next six months. They will feature portable and table models to receive both types of broadcasting, amplitude and frequency modulation.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 24 -- Steven Smithwick of Marblehead, Mass., sailing his International 210 Swifty III, captured the first in a series of five races in the annual national championship series in Vineyard Sound this afternoon.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Rise Stevens, opera star, who has been vacationing at Westhampton, will give an outdoor benefit concert in the natural amphitheatre at Boys Harbor on Saturday evening.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The chairman of the Democratic State Platform Committee said here today that he did not believe depression would be an issue in the fall campaign.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 24 -- President Getulio Vargas killed himself with a pistol shot through the heart this morning. A few hours earlier he had agreed under pressure to relinquish his office to Joao Cafe Filho, Vice President.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The Resident General of Morocco, Francis Lacoste, began his conversations with Government leaders here today concerning plans now being drawn up to bring about a settlement between France and the violent nationalist movement in the French protectorate.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (UP) -- A home run by Sid Gordon provided the margin of victory for the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight as they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8 -- 7.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Mrs. James Mertz of the American Yacht Club moved into a three-quarter-point lead in the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams trophy series for the twenty-seventh women's national sailing championship which began today at the Riverside Yacht Club.

The International Business Machines Corporation has entered into an agreement with the Prudential Insurance Company of America to borrow a maximum of $100,000,000 on 3 3/4 per cent notes maturing on May 1, 2055, Thomas J. Watson, chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A special Senate committee outlined today five categories of charges on which it would hold hearings on whether Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, should be censured by the Senate.

The Structural Processing Corporation has leased a new building at 59-30 Fifty-sixth Road in Maspeth, Queens, through the Queens Industrials, brokers. The company specializes in anodizing the exterior aluminum shells which are being used extensively in new office buildings.
The net earnings of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad equaled 87 cents a common share in July, compared with $1.01 a year earlier, C. McD. Davis, president, said yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- Premier Mario Scelba gave Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador, today a summary of the problems created for Italy by the failure of the Brussels conference on the European Defense Community. Mrs. Luce said she would forward the information to the State Department.
Exporters said yesterday that they were continuing to ship to Brazil on orders covered by official import licenses and by commitments for payment of dollar exchange.

Prices edged lower on small volume in yesterday's stock market, made an uncertain rally in the final hour or so and closed with a moderate loss. The New York Times combined average fell 0.76 to 223.86.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations, arrived in New York today with a friendly greeting for Americans and the hope that they would work hard for peace, international security and friendship.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced yesterday the granting of a loan of $61,000,000 to the Pacific Railroad (Ferrocarril del Pacifico) of Mexico. The loan will be used to finance an extensive modernization program estimated to cost about $80,000,000 and to take four years to complete.

The Atlas Corporation, a closed-end investment trust, reported yesterday that its net asset value on June 30, after taxes, was $38.82 a common share. This compares with $37.82 a share at the start of this year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The pacesetting Giants' final swing of the year around the Western loop of the National League got off to a sprightly start today.

Completely integrated "ore to product" operations will characterize a plant to be built by Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. The multi-million-dollar aluminum sheet and foil rolling mill will be built early next year near Ravenswood, W. Va.
BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation unanimously voted today to recognize Red China as a full member.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the Premier of France that Britain was completely in agreement with the United States in insisting that the European Defense Community question be pressed to a decision soon.
The pay-as-you-go plan of installment buying has been applied -- with highly successful results -- to the buying of advertising.

Getulio Vargas retained a strong grip on the imagination and affection of many Brazilians. Sometimes he was known by his nickname, "Ge-Ge" and again, when he appeared in public, his followers would greet him with a chanting shout, "Getul, Getul!"
The United States has more church members and more churches today than at any previous time in the nation's history.

There have been few events in the whole history of Latin America more stunning than the suicide of Getulio Vargas, President of Brazil. In the first shock of pity and amazement no one can hope to calculate the consequences, but they are bound to be profound, first of all for his country and then for the rest of the hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that United States armed forces would be justified in defending against Communist attack some of the small islands between Formosa and the Chinese mainland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Norman Armour, who has said farewell to the public almost as many times as the late Sir Harry Lauder, is preparing to come out of retirement for still another tour of duty as a diplomatic trouble shooter.
JACKSON, Miss, Wednesday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator James Eastland, veteran of twelve years in the Senate, easily won' a third term in Mississippi's Democratic primary election last night.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- The Labor party goodwill mission to Communist China was derided in the House of Representatives tonight.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- The administrative tribunal whose jurisdiction extends to the three largest specialized agencies of the United Nations opened a series of hearings here today, two of which involve American "loyalty" or "security" cases.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- The highest realized prices and lowest marketing costs in three years were shown today in the fourth annual report of the British Wool Marketing Board.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Israel returned without answer today a letter inviting her delegates to attend a meeting of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission.

THIRTY seconds before noon tomorrow, Nathan M. Ohrbach will step from the Empire State Building's northernmost portal on Thirty-fourth Street, cross the pavement to his new eleven-story store (formerly McCreery's), and, with one of the brass keys on his heavy pocket ring, throw the establishment open to trade.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices rose 7 to 28 points. The far months showed the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Government will spend "several hundred millions" this year to put its wartime production facilities in "stand-by" status for immediate resumption of war work.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Air Force today announced the development of a new electronic tube producing 4,000,000 watts of radar power, more than 250 times as much as was used to bounce radar pulses to the moon and back in 1946.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had dismissed proceedings aimed at depriving Otis Co., Cleveland investment house, of its broker-dealer license to deal in securities.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. disclosed yesterday that he had been assured by Mayor Wagner that the Mayor would not become a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor "under any circumstances."

No more will British authors need to call their fictional characters Homer or Sadie to divulge their nationality to the English reader. Now, because of the recent publication in England of "The American Thesaurus of Slang," the author will be able to air his knowledge of American expressions and even call his characters Lancelot and Ernestine if he pleases.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24, (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, led by Bobby Thomson, who was in the starting line-up for the first time, defeated Robin Roberts the third time in four years tonight as Warren Spahn allowed seven hits in hurling a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 24 -- The scheduled election of six new presidents of the World Council of Churches was unexpectedly delayed for twenty-four hours tonight on a motion put before the General Assembly by Pastor Martin Niemoeller of Germany. The vote was 158 for postponement to 146 against.

The President's action in giving a pocket veto to the bill to raise the wages of 1,750,000 federal workers by 5 per cent has produced understandable disappointment among those affected. The general issue of the pay of these workers, as well as other features governing their employment and compensation, will undoubtedly come up again at the next session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The nation's economy has maintained the stable pace it achieved in the second quarter as the summer progressed, the Government announced today.

THE Robert Montgomery Players, television's own summer stock company, are having quite a ball for themselves while the boss is away coaching President Eisenhower on video techniques. In their tightly knit circle of six performers, they have put on plays (Monday, 9:30 P. M., N. B. C.-TV) featuring comedy, murder, romance and other types of drama.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles said at his news conference today that he deeply regretted the death of President Getulio Vargas and had sent an expression of his profound sympathy to the Brazilian Foreign Minister.
A bill to establish a Mental Health Board was introduced yesterday in the City Council with the backing of Mayor Wagner.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers tripped the Boston Red Sox, 8 -- 7, tonight before 17,637 fans at Fenway Park to retain their hold on fourth place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today an application by the New England Transportation Company for permission to buy three smaller bus companies.

" The Private World of William Faulkner," by Robert Coughlan, will be published Oct. 6 by Harper. It is an analysis of the various threads of Faulkner's artistic and personal career and an attempt to present a portrait of the man. Subtitled "The Man, the Legend, the Writer," the book ends with a chapter analyzing Faulkner's newest work, "A Fable.

David S. Meister, real estate operator and investor, has purchased a site in White Plains, N. Y., for improvement with a building which will be used as a drive-in bank by the County Trust Company. The parcel, comprising 19,000 square feet, is at the westerly corners of Aqueduct Road and Wilson and Russell Streets.

RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 24 -- Joao Cafe Filho, President of Brazil through the suicide of Getulio Vargas, has devoted most of his life to militant political journalism. He was exiled to Arentina by Senhor Vargas in 1937, but was allowed to return the following year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 24 -- District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta of Nassau County has started a quiet investigation into reports of kickbacks by ushers at Roosevelt Raceway. This became known when six of the track's ninety-four ushers were subpoenaed yesterday and today by Mr. Gulotta's office for questioning.

A New York woman has refused to accept a portrait of her-self by Salvador Dali, the surrealist artist, although her attorney has admitted that the painting resembles her, a suit in the State Supreme Court here revealed yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A psychiatrist told the British people today that the continuous rain and gray skies they had been experiencing might make them irritable and depressed but would not cause any lasting ill effects.
A Bronx grand jury handed up first-degree perjury indictments yesterday against Mrs. William Howell and a New Jersey couple.

On the theory, amply supported by the fact, that diamonds cannot be bought without money, the Jewelers Vigilance Committee, Inc., is acting to stop a rash of "something for nothing" advertisements in the jewelry trade.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- With the consent of the French Cabinet Premier Pierre Mendes-France decided today to ask for a National Assembly vote on the European Defense Community treaty as it stood, but not to advocate its ratification.

Due to the importance of the subject, may I be permitted to comment upon the excellence of the presentation made in The Times on Aug. 5 by John R. Fitzpatrick on outlawing the Communist party. The latter, whose legal talents are appreciated in our capital, maintained that, in our efforts to deal with Soviet agents in this country, our emphasis should be upon proper identification and exposure.
An ominously dark Yankee picture brightened somewhat last night when the Bombers trounced the Baltimore Orioles, 9 -- 2, as they opened a nine-game home stand before 15,553 fans at the Stadium.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The British Government refused today to turn over to Poland a young Polish seaman who received political asylum here after he had been removed from a Polish vessel by policemen July 31.
Net income of the Beneficial Loan Corporation and its subsidiaries amounted to $7,387,544 for the first half of this year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 -- The Dodgers' final drive through the West got off on a high note tonight when they unleashed a sixteen-hit ttack on two Redlegs pitchers and won at Crosley Field, 12 -- 4.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The stormy North Sea was search for traces of the Dutch airliner that disappeared en route from New York with twenty-one persons aboard. So far only bits of wreckage and a lone child's body had been found.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, Nikita S. Khrushchev Communist party secretary, and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov are vacationing on the Black Sea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Jack Harshman pitched a four-hitter and smashed his second home run of the season tonight to pace the Chicago White Sox to a 4-0 victory over the Washington Senators.

The three-story dwelling containing three apartments on lot 40 by 41 feet at 7 and 9 Sniffen Court, a small street off East Thirty-sixth Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, has been resold by Edward Schwartz, operator, who bought the parcel recently.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Following is a transcript of the news conference conducted this morning by Secretary of State Dulles with his answers in indirect discourse as required by the Secretary's rules:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter that President Getulio Vargas left before killing himself:

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals will present an argument against radio and television coverage of the Senate committee hearings concerning the proposed censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The first move in more than five years to ease trading regulations with the Soviet Union and its satellites, except Red China, was in final preparation today at the Department of Commerce.

DENVER, Aug. 24 -- By waving a radioactive wand here, President Eisenhower on Labor Day, Sept. 6, will break ground for the first atomic plant dedicated to peacetime purposes. The plant will be built just outside Pittsburgh.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Negotiations between India and Portugal over details for the appointment of neutral observers to report on the Goan situation virtually broke down today.

Ten more witnesses appeared yesterday before the regular August Kings County grand jury as the District Attorney's office pushed its case against four teen-age Brooklyn hoodlums charged with killing two men for thrills.

The First Boston Corporation and the First Southwest Company jointly head a group of underwriters offering today a new issue of $27,000,000 Lower Colorado River Authority, Texas, revenue refunding bonds due from 1955 to 1970.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has indicated he will seek a bipartisan foreign policy in cooperation with the opposition Social Democratic party should the French reject the European Defense Community treaty.

In reviewing the work of the Eighty-third Congress and urging election of an Eighty-fourth that would carry on his program President Eisenhower has in a sense officially opened the fall campaign. His was a partisan speech and should be so recognized.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, accepted tonight a Republican invitation to testify Sept. 2 before the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy in the matter of the Dixon-Yates power contract.

THE wildfowlers who have been worrying about the 1954 regulations can relax and begin making definite plans for the fall shooting. The season dates and bag limits for ducks, geese, woodcock and jacksnipe have been announced by the Department of the Interior, and are substantially the same as those of 1953.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The new law to outlaw the Communist party, signed by President Eisenhower today, will take a long time to enforce.

Gustavo Lobo, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, announced last night that the exchange had set limits on price fluctuations at 100 points daily on coffee futures, including the current month, until further action by the board of managers.
The Swedish-American Line is considering bids from shipyards in six Western European countries for construction of another large luxury passenger ship, similar to the 8-month-old liner Kungsholm.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Virtually the entire region of eastern India has been damaged by floods this year that caused extensive damage to crops, property and cattle besides displacing millions of persons.

A plan to transfer 450,000 Jews from North Africa to Israel because of "the threat of ren wed anti-Jewish outbreaks by Arab extremists" was outlined here last night. Three thousand delegates to the fortieth annual convention of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were told of the proposal by Moshe Kol, world chairman of the Youth Aliyah (immigration) movement, Jewish child-rescue agency.

NEW JERSEY anglers have had to scour the off-shore waters recently in order to come in with a few school tuna in the fish box, but the in-shore bluefishing has provided compensation that the row-boat brigade classifies as a "bonanza."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins called upon the principal Senatorial accusers of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today to document their charges against him.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France has received a letter from Adlai E. Stevenson telling him that the people of the United States are unanimously interested in the ratification of the European Defense Community treaty.

VIENNA, Aug. 25 -- Stefan Kiripolsky, Czechoslovak refugee employed by the Vienna office of Radio Free Europe to interview other Czechoslovakian refugees, apparently has been kidnapped by the Russians along with a Czechoslovak woman friend.
DIBRUGARH, India, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Swirling waters from India's Brahmaptura River today cut off the tea-producing state of Assam from the rest of India.

MANILA, Aug. 25 -- Ever since independence in 1946, Filipinos have regarded continued free trade with the United States as a sort of gift horse. Today, President Ramon Magsaysay dispatched a mission to Washington for a good long look into the horse's mouth.
In a Washington dispatch by C. P. Trussell to this newspaper describing the manner in which the new bill outlawing the Communist party was passed, the following paragraph deserves attention:
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 25 -- The question arose today as to whether the Superior Court in Connecticut could judge the actions of a political convention.

The dropped waistline was noticeable by its absence in yesterday's showing of new fall furs and coats at Macy's. For American women, this store is retaining the waistline at its normal point with detail used to highlight hip interest.
An advertising executive and his wife were terrorized for two and a half hours early yesterday by two armed men, who leisurely ransacked their home in Queens in a search for money and jewels.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 25 -- Labor party members of Parliament refused today to give their leader, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, a leave of absence from party duties next week to continue his fight to exonerate two aides before the Royal Commission on Russian Espionage.
The draw for the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national singles championships men and women, which will begin Saturday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens, was made yesterday.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 25 -- After a delay of twenty-four hours, six clergymen who had been nominated as presidents of the World Council of Churches were elected here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (UP) -- A triple by Hal Naragon with two out in the tenth inning scored Bill Glynn from first base and lifted the Cleveland Indians to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that India feared the proposed Southeast Asian alliance would do more harm than good.
Nine newspaper writers, cartoonists and photographers and nine authors of books and magazine articles were announced yesterday as winners of the semi-annual Christopher literary awards.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Saxon Stable's Noble Risk and the Woodley Lane Farm's Red Hannigan, a 30-to-1 shot and the 2-to-1 favorite, respectively, finished in a dead heat in the $28,252 Providence Stakes at Narragansett Park todoy.

Two industrial buildings and an adjoining plot of 16,200 square feet at 937 to 957 Saw Mill River Road, Yonkers, N. Y., have been sold by George Rosenberg and Arthur Cohn and the estate of Arthur Rosenberg to Edward Petrillo, president of the Yonkers Contracting Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon announced today that he would make a series of thirteen appearances in eight states beginning Sept. 13 on his first campaign swing to retain Republican control of Congress in November.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States has decided to go ahead with plans for an international atomic energy pool, even if the Soviet Union persists in refusing to take part.
LIBERTY, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Sullivan County reported today that it had freed itself of ragweed and that New York's hay-fever sufferers might now safely visit its summer resorts.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill will preside on Friday at the first British Cabinet meeting to be held since Parliament rose a month ago for the summer holidays. Sir Winston will motor from his country home at Westerham in Kent and return after the meeting, it was reported.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 25 -- Indications at least superficially favorable to Gov. Allan Shivers' bid for re-election -- and to continued dominance of Texas politics by the conservative "States' rights" wing of the Democratic party -- marked the final phase of one of the state's hottest political campaigns today.
YONKERS, Aug. 26 -- Adios Boy and Adios Harry, the two leading 3-year-olds, will race against five other outstanding horses in the $10,000 Hudson free-for-all Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 25 -- Whatever the voters' verdict may be come November, the Republicans expect to be outgunning hereabouts this Saturday.

The regional Red Cross blood program received donations of 555 pints of blood on Tuesday. Bank Day, with employes of downtown banks giving blood at the Federal Reserve Bank, 33 Liberty Street, produced 126 pints, and the first day of a three-day collection at the International Business Machines Corporation, 99 Park Avenue, brought in 106.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Because the General Assembly had no part in the setting up of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea it is without competence to disband or to withdraw the commission, representatives of the United Nations said today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- The chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Bundestag outlined today the basis for a new West German foreign policy should the French National Assembly reject the European Defense Community treaty.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday to close 11 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The fifth European Games opened today with a double Zatopek victory and a marathon mix-up that saw a Russian runner enter the stadium first and then run the wrong way -- to his left.

DENVER, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower committed himself today to go to Hawaii for "Admission Day," but the time of the trip is quite indefinite. That's because enactment of the Hawaii statehood bill must come first. The President is committed to a renewed drive for that bill in the next Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that the Brooklyn Paint and Wall Paper Dealers Association, Inc., answering an F. T. C. complaint, had denied conspiring to restrain trade. The association represents about 200 paint and wallpaper dealers in the Metropolitan New York area, the commission said.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- British trade union leaders decided today against doing business with communism, but at least one in dividual officer accepted an invitation to visit Communist China.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 25 -- The youth of this quaint New England village have been preparing for a week for the dedication of a brand new $125,000 boys' club. On Saturday afternoon Hoyt Perry, president of the board of directors, will lay the cornerstone.

The New York Times, known the world over for dispassionate and factual news, supported me editorially whenever I ventured to stand for public office. Twelve stormy years is a long time, with campaigns for the State Senate in 1942, for City Council in 1945, for Congress in 1950 and 1952.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Lucio Pabon Nunez, Minister of the Interior, said today a misconception of Colombians by United States citizens was at the bottom of charges that this country persecuted Protestants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The careful procedure with which Senator Watkins is laying the base for the committee hearings on proposals that Senator McCarthy be "censured" lends substance to the hope that this may be the model Congressional inquiry so often promised and so rarely produced.
Arguments for and against fuller schedules on the IND division of the city's subway system were presented last night at a public hearing attended by about 100 persons in the Commodore Hotel.
Heavy pressure in the early afternoon sent stock market prices sliding yesterday, but a late-hour recovery trimmed losses before the bell.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., Aug. 25 -- A severe rainstorm last night washed seven tons of rock from the Canadian side of the Niagara Gorge near Horseshoe Falls, Ontario Park officials said today.
ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 25 -- Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer charged today that State Department and political interference had kept the United States forces from winning the war in Korea.

SULLY-SUR-LOIRE, France, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- One of France's historic castles in the lovely Loire Valley will be put up for auction shortly because its owner went broke on a treasure hunt in its subterranean network of tunnels.

The two leading contenders for the Democratic nomination for Governor and a group of leaders who will have a major role in resolving the contest between them spent most of yesterday together on a social outing at the thoroughbred races in Saratoga Springs, N. Y.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The conviction grew in Paris today that Premier Pierre Mendes-France was not merely resigned to the defeat of the European Defense Community treaty in the National Assembly but desired that defeat in order to seek an alternative policy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Christian X. Palamas, the chief Greek delegate to the United Nations, charged today that the British administration in Cyprus was helping the Communists there. This aid, he said, was aimed at disrupting the nationalist movement, which is calling for union with Greece.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A new Congressional inquiry into the system of screening Federal employes was in the making today.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland headed back for a third term today after a sweeping victory in the Mississippi Democratic primary.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals moved into fourth place and Stan Musial took the National League batting lead tonight as the Redbirds backed their rookie hurler, Gordon Jones, with a sixteen-hit attack in a 13-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

DENVER, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower's vacation headquarters here reported today that another country, Yugoslavia, had accepted the President's offer to furnish food and medical aid to flood victims in the Danube River basin.

While the urgency of need for new school construction in any particular area of the city should be weighed carefully against school needs elsewhere, and the decision made without favor, the Board of Education must continue to be a major beneficiary in the capital budget program. The request made for 1955 exceeds a hundred million dollars and covers twenty-seven new schools and modernization or enlargement of ten others.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- William F. Schnitzler, secretary treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, criticized the national administration, with specific reference to unemployment and to Cabinet personnel, in an address here today at the convention of the National Federation of Post Office Clerks.

The subject of diplomatic recognition, often raised in your columns, is a most interesting topic, and yet one on which the American lay public is uninformed. Too often the issues of admission to membership in the United Nations and the criteria for diplomatic recognition, per se, are confused.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 25 -- Clyde E. Herring, Democratic candidate for Governor, today sharply criticized the Iowa State Fair Board for granting free admission to the fair grounds during President Eisenhower's scheduled appearance here Monday.

Papers have been filed in Supreme Court in a $500,000 libel action brought by Paul Crouch, former Communist and later a Government witness in hearings of Communists against The New York Herald Tribune, its president, Whitelaw Reid, and two of its writers, Stewart and Joseph Alsop.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Pat O'Neal of Larchmont, the Long Island Sound titleholder, led the way through the East Coast semi-finals of the Sears Cup National junior sailing championship off the Black Rock Yacht Club today.

A mysterious new device, apparently developed to assist customs inspectors in the examination of incoming baggage, was used yesterday on Pier 88, Hudson River, to screen the luggage of 2,666 passengers debarking from two ocean liners.

Savory chicken paprika, smoky-tanged lentils and steak stroganoff with a rich, delicious gravy were among the outstanding canned foods tasted yesterday in The New York Times test kitchen. They were brought by the packer, slight gray-haired Imre Sandor, who learned to make them when he was a young chef in Hungary.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Representatives of the United States, Britain, Australia, New Zealand, France, the Philippines, Thailand and Pakistan will meet at the Southeast Asian defense conference in Manila Sept. 6.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The stretch-running Delta splashed over muddy going to a length-and-a-half victory today in the world's richest race for 2-year-old fillies, the $102,760 Princess Pat Stakes at Washington Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The Netherlands delegation emphasized today that Dr. Eelco N. Van Kleffens was still vigorously in the race for President of the 1954 General Assembly. The Assembly opens Sept. 21.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- The Dodgers routed the Redlegs, 13 -- 2, tonight before 10,908 at Crosley Field and cut the first-place lead on the idle Giants to three and one-half games.

Mrs. Mary Moody Northen was elected yesterday to head a $400,000,000 financial empire comprising more than fifty corporations, mostly in Texas. She is the oldest daughter of the late W. L. Moody Jr., who built up the combination of enterprises from a cotton merchandising firm in Galveston.

The housewife has a new ally in her battle against dirt and bacteria Atomic energy, in the form of radioactive bacteria, is being domesticated by American manufacturers and research laboratories to discover new facts about cleanliness.
TORONTO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Dave Douglas of Grossinger, N. Y., came in late today with a blistering eight-under-par 63 to take the lead in the $26,500 open golf tournament at the Scarboro course.

Bishop Albert Bereczky, head of the Hungarian delegation to the general assembly of the World Council of Churches, was invited yesterday to testify under oath before a Congressional group on whether there was religious freedom in Communist Hungary.
LIBERTY, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- A runaway truck was stopped here today by the driver of another truck, narrowly averting an accident like the one on the same hill July 24 when three persons were killed.

Twenty passengers aboard a sightseeing vessel were shaken and required treatment for abrasions and contusions late yesterday after the craft struck an abutment of the Harlem River Bridge, at 225th Street.

WHEN Willie Mays was stopped after hitting safely in twenty-one straight games, he fell short of the Giant record of twenty-four games, held by Freddie Lindstrom. That's a name you don't hear often nowadays and yet there's many an old-timer who thinks that Lindy was the best third baseman the Giants ever had.
Communist sources said last night that the party would openly defy the new law that outlaws it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox pounded Bunky Stewart for seven runs in the first two innings and coasted to a 7-2 victory over Washington today. Billy Pierce notched his seventh triumph on a six-hitter, fanning ten.

The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy has obtained a building permit to construct a copy of the Stratford (England) Globe Theatre on its recently purchased seven-acre tract on Shore Road, Stratford, Conn.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 25 (UP) -- A former United States Government employe charged today he had been dismissed from his $10,000 a year job with the United Nations because of "adverse comment" about him in a letter from the United States State Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- This country's failure to back up its business men abroad is one of the major reasons why Americans are reluctant to risk capital in foreign ventures, the Department of Commerce has been advised.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- An Air Force colonel, arrested on burglary charges in Nevada and held by the Air Force for alleged unauthorized possession of classified documents, was brought to Walter Reed Army Hospital here today for psychiatric examination and military investigation.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- Wilhelm Prinz, a high ranking. west German Communist leader, announced today he had fled from East Germany and broken with communism because of "communist brutality." He said the brutality was worse than he had suffered in a Nazi concentration camp.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- A thunder and lightning storm forced a forty-minute halt during the fourth round of the United States amateur golf championship at the Country Club of Detroit today.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- A regular Austin sedan has been successfully equipped with an experimental gas turbine engine, the British Motor Corporation announced today.

PARK RIDGE, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Two teen-age boys are spending seven days and nights on an around-the-clock airplane spotting vigil here. They have a double purpose: to provide the regular spotters with a full week's vacation and to dramatize the need for additional volunteers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Costa Rica proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly consider establishment of a world food reserve.
Fath had the drop on Dior's low waistline in a showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of Paris designs tailored in Holland for Continental Modes.
Mounting complaints over heavy explosions along the route of the New York-Buffalo Thruway culminated yesterday in the cancellation of blasting permits in Yonkers and Hillburn, N. Y.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Patty Vee, 6-year-old bay mare owned by James Hawkins of Xenia, Ohio, and driven by Tom Walters, won the Kentucky Pace in 2:05 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, scoring by a half-length over Merle Rose. Nemma Hal was third.

MUROC, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Capt. Joseph McConnell Jr., the world's leading jet ace, was killed today when he crashed while testing a modified version of the Sabre jet -- the swept-wing fighter in which he scored sixteen kills in the skies over Korea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Trevor Gardner, whose confirmation as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force was blocked in the Senate last week, is to remain in charge of research and development as a special assistant to Harold E. Talbott, Air Force Secretary.

Cattle in large numbers are roaming the Western plains, the feed lots are filling up and heavy supplies of meat will fill warehouse freezers, butchers' cold rooms and supermarket freezer cases in the fall. The American Meat Institute, looking ahead to what it believes might be the biggest cattle run in history, is making plans for a wide-scale promotion campaign to increase the over-all demand for beef and move the supplies to the consumer's table.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Arnold Riegger of Seattle won two shoot-offs to take two championships in the American Trapshooting Association's annual tournament today when nine perfect 200 scores were made by the 930 shotgun experts.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 -- The Edinburgh Festival is inclined to be cautious in the choice of programs. Tonight it threw caution to the wind and presented a memorable performance of Arnold Schoenberg's vast work "Gurrelieder."

AMES, Iowa, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, tonight denounced "self-appointed patrioteers" who, he said, sought to impose "thought control" on American educational institutions.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- Summer reading among Boston school children has been zooming upward this season under the impulsion of imaginary rocket ships soaring through outer space.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped announced today that it would award citations for outstanding service to John F Hennigan, personnel director of Capital Airlines, and Mrs. Nellie M. Brown of Dayton, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration reported today a "substantial increase" in the last fiscal year in the mileage of airways operated by it over the United States.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 26 (AP) -- An authoritative United States military source said yesterday that all available American forces would help the United States Seventh Fleet defend Formosa against a Chinese Red invasion.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- A study of trends in international migration between the two world wars was published today. It pays particular attention to the age and sex of the migrants and will provide a basis for economic, demographic and social analyses of such migrations.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted yesterday a $9,000,000 budget for 1954-55. This fund will support its medical, social welfare, Youth Aliyah (child immigration), vocational education and land redemption programs in Israel and Jewish education in the United States.

The excellent eggplant, now arriving from nearby and averaging about a nickel a serving, takes to so many treatments they would fill a slim book. One Armenian restaurant in the city daily features a "patlijan of the day" (eggplant dish) and goes for weeks without repetition.

Behind Eddie Lopat's best pitching job of the season, the Yankees handed the Baltimore Orioles their fourteenth straight defeat yesterday at the Stadium. Home runs by Yogi Berra, Hank Bauer and Irv Noren marked the 5-1 triumph of the Bombers.
John Saunders has been appointed men's clothing buyer for Stern Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- An American aircraft company and a Dutch concern announced plans today to produce together a twin-engine plane to replace the DC-3 -- the old two-engine work horse of the airlines.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Red Sox climbed back into a virtual fourth place tie with Detroit today by beating the Tigers, 5 -- 3. Boston now has a percentage of 443, just one point behind Detroit.
LONG POINT, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Governor Dewey declared tonight that the Democratic party leadership of the state was composed of "reactionary obstructionists."

With the Southeast Asian defense conference and France's decisive vote on the European Defense Community both due within the next two weeks, Mao Tse-tung, ruler of Communist China and ally of the Kremlin, has now launched his own assault on American policy sponsoring such projects, and has presented his own program for "peaceful coexistence" to make the world safe for Communist expansion.

In these days of deep summer the leaves are a darker green. They are hard, almost crisp in texture. When the year was young, in May, these same leaves were lighter green, with a hint of yellow in them. And they were soft, like the coat of a fawn or the velvet on a buck's antler. Such a leaf, crushed in the hand, made no sound.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 -- The dramatic farewell note left by President Getulio Vargas when he shot himself yesterday has been the subject of speculation and discussion here.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, announced yesterday that the directors had authorized the sale of $75,000,000 of new thirty-five-year bonds.

The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it would picket the Brooklyn Army Base today. It charges job discrimination against its members by a private contractor at the base.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 18, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
GUATEMALA, Aug. 25 -- A bill outlawing communism was signed by the ruling Junta today. It enters into effect immediately.
Gerardo (Jerry) Rega, 37 years old, suspected by the police as a bookmaker and "loan shark," was found shot dead early yesterday at the wheel of an expensive automobile in the East New York

Election of James T. Haviland as senior vice president of the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company and American Motorists Insurance Company, two companies of the Kemper group, was announced yesterday by Hathaway G. Kemper, president.

On a 15 per cent increase in gross revenues over last year's the Hilton Hotels Corporation realized a net profit from operations of $3,037,254, in the first six months of this year. This is 19 per cent more than the $2,543,073 cleared in the corresponding period of 1953, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported in the semi-annual statement yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Physicians should advise their patients "to sprint up to 25 years, to trot from 25 to 40, to walk from 40 to 60 -- and after 60 they can dawdle at golf."
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves parlayed five hits and a pair of Philadelphia errors into a 4-3 victory over the Phillies tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Britain, whose naval supremacy in the world was finally surpassed by the United States during World War II, drew pointed attention today to the steady rise of a new world naval power -- the Soviet Union.
Two of the country's foremost criminal lawyers -- Lloyd Paul Stryker and James D. C. Murray -- will defend two of the four Brooklyn youths accused of the wanton murder of two men.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The drop. was the sharpest in about two years. The decline was laid to forecasts that lower prices would be realized at the new series of auctions which will open in Australia next Monday. The previous auctions ended on June 30.
PEIPING, Aug. 25 -- At the party tonight given by the Mayor, there were many Government officials.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Late blight in Maine potato fields "has become very serious and is spreading rapidly," Agriculture Commissioner Fred J. Nutter said today. Mr. Nutter and Deputy Commissioner E. L. Newdick visited "several hundred" fields in Aroostook County and central Maine.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Fairfield County is battling a serious elm beetle infestation that has ravaged thousands of privately-owned trees, causing a premature dropping of foliage. Householders are now being plagued by the tiny insects, which are invading buildings in search of a winter refuge.

A concert to benefit Puerto Rican students in this city will be held Oct. 11, it was announced yesterday by Edward G. Miller Jr., chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York City.

The two recent articles announcing the formation and progress of the committee for the reopening of the Townsend Harris High School provide just about the most encouraging reading anywhere in your paper.

In the first day of enforcement of restrictive parking regulations from Fifty-ninth to Eighty-sixth Street between Seventh Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, 109 automobiles were impounded yesterday for illegal parking, according to the Sanitation Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and Senators H. Alexander Smith and Mike Mansfield will head a twenty-four man United States delegation to the Southeast Asia defense conference in Manila Sept. 6, the State Department announced today.
The nations $25,000,000,000-a-year electric light and power industry gives no indication that a business recession can be expected.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 25 -- French authorities here pressed today for a speed-up in the return of French Union war prisoners held by the Vietminh. It was virtually certain the North Vietnam prisoner exchange would not be completed within the time fixed by the Geneva cease-fire agreement.

The continuing build-up of the backlog of new corporate bond issues to be marketed next month is causing some softening of prices among new issues of public utility bonds bought by investment banking syndicates over the last month or so.

It must come as a surprise to most Americans to read such news items as we are getting from Brazil these days. One learns that the American Embassy in Rio de Janeiro and some of our consular offices elsewhere have been attacked by Brazilian mobs. American business installations Iave suffered the same fae.
Six members of a Passaic, N. J., family were seriously injured last night when their car smashed into an abutment at the Brooklyn entrance of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- George Nader, who was featured as the magazine photographer in "Carnival Story," is about to replace Jeff Chandler for the second time in a Universal film.

With the slight swagger of a champion, the giant tanker World Glory made her way up the Hudson River yesterday morning, receiving along the route New York's salute as the largest cargo ship ever to enter this harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Arthur J. Connell, National Commander of the American Legion, arrived in the capital this afternoon to head the executive staff preparatory to the organization's national convention here Aug. 30 to Sept. 2.

This is the time of year when one of the best of all pastimes gains a host of new friends. Dating back to somewhere beyond antiquity, it always has had admirers of the contemplative sort, seasoned scholars with a knowledge of how best to spend an earned vacation.
The directors of Ideal Cement Company announced plans yesterday to declare on Oct. 15 a stock dividend of one additional share for each share held on that date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration issued new regulations today. Commissioner Norman P. Mason said they would "eliminate windfall profits" by builders on rental apartment projects.
An impasse was reached yesterday in negotiations between twelve New York and New Jersey teamster union locals and twenty employer associations for a contract to cover 30,000 drivers.

New York City has borrowed $45,000,000 on an issue of tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes are dated Aug. 26 and are payable on Nov. 4. The notes were sold by allotment to twenty-three banks and trust companies, here, as follows:
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The opening of a new bookkeeping account on the stock markets here today was marked by a recovery in prices and a rise in activity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration issued new regulations today. Commissioner Norman P. Mason said they would "eliminate windfall profits" by builders on rental apartment projects.
An impasse was reached yesterday in negotiations between twelve New York and New Jersey teamster union locals and twenty employer associations for a contract to cover 30,000 drivers.

New York City has borrowed $45,000,000 on an issue of tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes are dated Aug. 26 and are payable on Nov. 4. The notes were sold by allotment to twenty-three banks and trust companies, here, as follows:
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The opening of a new bookkeeping account on the stock markets here today was marked by a recovery in prices and a rise in activity.

Today's new film is an English import, "The Woman's Angle," at the Fifth Avenue Cinema. The marital drama has a cast headed by Edward Underdown, Cathy O'Donnell, Lois Maxwell and Claude Farell. Leslie Arliss directed the Stratford Pictures release and Walter Mycroft produced.

New York University announced yesterday that Frank Jay Gould, financier, had given the university title to his thirteen-acre estate at Ardsley-on- Hudson, N. Y. The estate will be used for conferences and other general education meetings, Dr. Henry T. Heald, university, chancellor, said.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 25 -- The Jones Beach State Parkway Authority is moving, at distances varying from one to four blocks, seventy dwelling units housing Mitchel Air Force Base personnel.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Mr. Stevenson confirmed today that he had sent a personal, handwritten appeal to Premier Mendes-France urging France to ratify the European Defense Community treaty.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 -- Rioting, some of it Communist-inspired, broke out here briefly this morning as the body of Getulio Vargas was flown to his home in the State of Rio Grande do Sul for burial.
AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 25 -- Republican leaders are worried over persistent field reports that Gov. Burton M. Cross is threatened with defeat in the Maine election Sept. 13.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Navy made known today its intention to cut down the Pacific Fleet now that fighting had stopped in Indochina as well as in Korea.
DENVER, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower is "delighted" that Mr. Stevenson, his 1952 opponent for the Presidency, wrote French Premier Mendes-France as he did about the European Defense Community.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Long Buckby Town Council's campaign to censor the sentiments carved on tombstones has petered out.

The Federal Court of Appeals has reversed a lower court order that required the Gdynia-America Line to pay the Lambros Seaplane Base, Inc., $6,200 for a plane picked up at sea as salvage in 1950, it became known yesterday.

TRENTON, Aug. 25 -- A top official of the State Employment Security Division was accused today of intimating that money could have resulted in the defeat of a bill in the State Senate. The official was identified as Thomas B. Faherty, supervisor of purchase and stores in the agency.

If it is any comfort to its watery eyed sneezing victims the proper name for the torment is "allergic rhinitis" and not "hay fever." It may be -- of course -- that to find out that sufferers have actually been contending with a misnomer all these years will not serve as any measure of relief for the 1 to 2 per cent of the population that is allergic to the ragweed plant growth and pollination.

The Thruway pushes through to a new and important destination today as Governor Dewey opens another sizable section, from Rochester to Buffalo. The traveler can now use the Thruway from Utica almost to the shores of Lake Erie, and before many months can travel east and south to the banks of the Hudson to await completion in 1955 of the Nyack-Tarrytown bridge.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The capsized rowboat of two teen-age youths who set out yesterday on a trip across the choppy waters of Long Island Sound was found near here today.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Tom Brown Jr. today produced the best and fastest tennis displayed thus far in the invitation tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Ne ws said today that Chrysler's president, L. I. (Tex) Colbert, told the company's 100,000 workers Monday that the future might be "just too bad" if the company's competitive position was not improved.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. James Mr. Mertz of American Y. C., Rye, N. Y., the 1950 champion, regained the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy by winning the twenty-seventh edition of the women's national sailing championship today off the Riverside Y. C. in a fading southerly.
A Senate investigation of Federal Housing Administration irregularities brought out yesterday that a $15,000 Brooklyn investment had yielded a $4,000,000 profit.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 24 -- The regime here is faced with a threat of an autonomy movement in South-West Africa.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Ne ws said today that Chrysler's president, L. I. (Tex) Colbert, told the company's 100,000 workers Monday that the future might be "just too bad" if the company's competitive position was not improved.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. James Mr. Mertz of American Y. C., Rye, N. Y., the 1950 champion, regained the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy by winning the twenty-seventh edition of the women's national sailing championship today off the Riverside Y. C. in a fading southerly.
A Senate investigation of Federal Housing Administration irregularities brought out yesterday that a $15,000 Brooklyn investment had yielded a $4,000,000 profit.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 24 -- The regime here is faced with a threat of an autonomy movement in South-West Africa.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 25 -- Chinese Nationalist President Chiang Kai-shek tonight made an urgent appeal to all Chinese as well as "foreign friends and international organizations" to help bring relief food to millions of flood victims on the Communist-held mainland of China.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Eddie Arcaro did the opposite to what the Foxcatcher Farms' trainer, Dick Handlen, told him to do with Parlo in the $29,600 Alabama Stakes today, and Handlen was quite happy that the quick-thinking jockey disregarded the riding instructions. For Parlo, at 9 to 1, was the winner.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Representative Charles R. Howell told a Democratic audience here tonight that President Eisenhower had got his baseball analogy mixed up in his television report to the people last Monday night.

From time to time over the years the Broadway theatre has been charged with fostering what is termed a "black market" in the sale of theatre tickets. The charge was resurrected recently by the Citizens Union and in traditional fashion dismissed by the New York Ticket Brokers, Inc., with the comment that it was "typical hot weather stuff -- strictly summer stock."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices on active months were 3 points lower to 8 points higher than on Wednesday.

Directors of Chemical Bank and Trust Company and of Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company have approved unanimously a plan for merging the two banks, according to an announcement made yesterday by the chairmen of the banks, N. Baxter Jackson and Dunham B. Sherer, respectively.
Longshoremen of the American Federation of Labor called off yesterday the immediate threat of picketing at the Army Base in Brooklyn.
Two men were killed by lightning in Munsey Park, L. I., yesterday as scattered showers and thunderstorms hit parts of the city and the suburbs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- King Commander, the highweight under 154 pounds, took the lead in the first run through the backstretch and stayed in front for the rest of the way in the $11,375 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Plant-withering rust, which has sharply cut this year's Canadian wheat crop, has hit hardest at durum wheat in a wide belt of the Canadian prairies and North Dakota. One authority has estimated the average loss at 65 per cent.

Although the Yankees crushed the Detroit Tigers, 11 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday, the second-place New Yorkers gained no ground in their pursuit of the Indians. Rising to the occasion, Cleveland won its night contest at Washington and maintained its four-and-one-half-game American League lead.

YONKERS, Aug. 26 -- Adios Boy made it a front race all the way to take the $10,000 Hudson pace by a length before a crowd of 17,382 at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Howard Camden sent the 3-year-old to the fore from the No. 2 post and kept him there through a 2:01 3/5 mile, only four-fifths of a second behind the track record.

Mayor Wagner received from Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy yesterday a report declaring that the city's public assistance case load increased by 2,185 persons in July. This was the eighth successive month to show such an increase.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Secretary General Dog Hammarskjold released today a list of thirty nominees for five seats to be filled this year on the International Court of Justice.
The unseasonal midsummer decline in business borrowing from New York banks is continuing, largely because tobacco companies are paying off outstanding loans at a time when they usually are borrowers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The oyster season will soon be here again. Considering all the things that can happen to the bivalves from birth on, the oyster fancier is lucky that any find their way to his table.
PARIS, Aug. 26 -- France and the three Associated States of Indochina opened a conference today to revise their relationships.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Prices continued to improve in almost every section of the stock market today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Wheat futures were under a little pressure early here today and there was not much mill buying to stimulate local support. But later the market recovered and registered small gains for the day.

Richmond County, Ga., sold yesterday $2,850,000 of public building bonds due from 1956 to 1984 to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.718 per cent. The bonds, which bear interest of 2 1/2 per cent, were reoffered at yields ranging from 0.8 per cent to 2.4 per cent.
I wish to commend The New York Times for the publication of the double series of articles about Poland by Antoni Klimowicz and Andrzej Panufnik in the Aug. 23 and 24 issues.
Another important court battle has been all but won against price cutters by fair traders, who stand firm for a manufacturer's right to fix minimum store prices of his product.

A new building containing 20,000 square feet of space at 48-49 Thirty-third Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Bridgeport Brass Company which will use it as a warehouse. The structure, owned and built by the R. G. R. Construction Corporation, of which Nathaniel Ratner is president, was leased through the James H. Burns Company, industrial broker.
New orders for machine tolls -- the devices that make machinery used in all sorts of manufacturing -- slipped badly in July.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Western Big Three diplomats held their fourth meeting at the Foreign Office today on drafting a reply to the Soviet notes on a conference on European collective security.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- An Air Force B-25 flying through a rainstorm-over the rugged Coast Range Mountains "plowed right into the rocks" today killing all eight men aboard.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Russians have produced enough uranium in East Germany since World War II to make forty-four atomic bombs, a West German Government survey said today.

Purchase by an investor of the eleven-story office building at 38 Park Row, facing City Hall Park, was announced yesterday in a deal involving about $900,000. The seller was the Beepark Realty Company, represented by Borrok, Steingart Borrok, attorneys.

Directors of the Froedtert Corporation, large Milwaukee grain processor, approved retirement of its preferred stock yesterday through a refinancing program with a $3,500,000 loan from the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $197,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Danny O'Connell singled to short center field with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today and the Milwaukee Braves gained a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
The New York City Health Department has made a strong recommendation that fluorine be added to the city water supply to help reduce tooth decay.
Three tax experts -- two attorneys and an accountant -- pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to conspiracy to obstruct justice in two tax evasion cases.
DENVER, Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower today signed a bill to assure continued use of United States cargo vessels for foreign aid and stockpiling purposes.

ALBANY, Aug. 26--No children's camp will be listed in the 1955 directory prepared by the State Commerce Department, unless its owner, or director, submits a sworn affidavit that the camp does not advocate subsersive activities.

The New York Post Office demonstrated yesterday that safe driving was another guarantee of the postal legend that "Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds."

Barton's Bonbonniere will begin work soon on a three-story addition to its factory and executive office at 80 DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn. A row of stores on the site, at the corner of DeKalb and Hudson Avenues, is being razed to make way for the addition which is scheduled to be completed by the end of November.
" Operation Snowflake" is being planned in the command post of the United States Steel Corporation.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru sharply criticized the United States and European powers today over their approach to Asian problems. He said their "out-of-place and out-of-date" policies ignored Asia.
MANILA, Friday, Aug. 27 -- Luis Taruc, former top leader of the Hukbalahap rebels, pleaded guilty today to charges of rebellion with murders, robberies, kidnappings and arson.

I probably have as low an opinion of the current "mess in Washington" as has Brooks Atkinson, and I thoroughly disapprove of many of the actions which I can guess he has in mind. However, his lack of specific, accurate charges or examples makes his letter, in many of its phrases, a libel on the United States and powerful ammunition for Communist propaganda.

The possibility of a trucking strike next week was lessened yesterday when employers offered the unions a new proposal for contract extension pending negotiation of a master contract covering 30,000 teamsters in the New York-New Jersey area.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 26 -- Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders from many parts of the globe were at loggerheads here today on how to interpret the main theme of the second general assembly of the World Council of Churches: "Christ -- the Hope of the World."

Shipments of gas-operated central heating equipment increased 8 per cent during the first seven months of this year over the same period of 1953, according to the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association. The overall rise, however, was due to a 13.2 per cent increase in shipments of gas-fired furnaces.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26 -- Brazil was struggling back toward normal today after the tension and disorders that followed the suicide of President Getulio Vargas Tuesday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and his Government colleagues have given up the Kremlin as a living place. They also are planning to give it up as the seat of Government.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- Four players who never previously had reached the semi-finals, occupied the last four places in the United States amateur golf championship tonight.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 26 -- South Africa will propose to Britain joint control of Britain's Simonstown naval base on the Cape of Good Hope in preparation for British withdrawal from the base, according to a Rand Daily Mail report today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Al Smith's tie-breaking home run into the left-field bullpen on the first pitch of the eighth inning carried the Cleveland Indians to a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Military informants said tonight that Chinese Communist attacks such as the one on the Island of Quemoy reported by the Peiping radio presumably would not bring the Seventh Fleet into defensive action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Members of the Screen Writers Guild voted last night to recommend a constitutional amendment barring Communists from holding membership in the newly created Writers Guild of America, West, Inc.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Ross Carino Jr. of Ryewood, an 18-year-old New Rochelle High School senior, won the medal in the thirtieth annual Westchester junior championship today. Carino carded a par 37, 35 -- 72 over the Wykagyl course to lead by two strokes.

I read carefully and with deep satisfaction your editorial of Aug. 20, "Dispute Over Cyprus." I find myself (and I am convinced that all Greeks feel the same) in complete agreement that this dispute is "particularly painful."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Jerry Lynch drove in both Pittsburgh runs tonight with a sacrifice fly and a single as the Pirates beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2 -- 1. A bonus right-hander, Laurin Pepper, gained his first major league victory.

Governor Dewey was accused yesterday by the two leading candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor and the Democratic state chairman of waging a political campaign of demagoguery, deceit and vilification.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Six days have elapsed since the adjournment of the Eighty-third Congress, but the text of its anti-Communist legislation as signed by the President is still unavailable to applicants. It is not procurable at the Senate Bill Room, where printed copies of the laws are distributed.
A small safe containing nearly a quarter million dollars in cash and securities was stolen yesterday from the Riverdale home of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Lichtenstern.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Department of Commerce today eased its regulations on trading with the Soviet Union and its European satellites.

TORONTO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Wally Ulrich, the ex-Marine from Rochester, Minn., moved to the front at the halfway mark in the $26,500 Labatt open today when he shot a 6-under-par 65 for a thirty-six-hole total of 130.

A move within the North Atlantic United Kingdom Freight Conference to establish a minimum rate of $25 a ton on all cargo moved in "express" liners has been defeated. The rate change was to have gone into effect on Wednesday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 26 -- Talks between Communist China and Indonesia on the problem of double citizenship have been delayed again. As a result there are growing signs of Indonesian irritation over the outcome, which may affect 3,000,000 Chinese in Indonesia.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Australia's players defeated the United States today in a match between the international lawn tennis clubs of the two countries at the Westchester Country Club.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- The Brooklyn club today announced the "all-time" Dodger team, as picked by the writers and broadcasters who travel with the Brooks -- and when Manager Smokey Alston saw the selections perhaps he wondered why his club was not in first place.

A bill ending federal responsibility for some 177 helpless, poverty-stricken, neglected Paiute Indians in remote corners of western Utah may not be the most important enactment of the Eighty-third Congress, but it is one of the most objectionable.

July was the first month this year in which net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company exceeded the comparable 1953 figure. A net of $312,468 was reported yesterday for the seasonally low income month, compared with $278,358 in July, 1953.
F. A. Jolles, Herbert W. Mason Jr. and Patrick J. Ryan have been elected directors of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., according to Henry H. Reichhold, chairman.

For the second successive day the stock market ran downhill and also for the second day it seemed to be testing its brakes. Once again a sharp decline was halted in midcourse and prices recovered easily despite the softness of traditional leaders.
The son of an immigrant junk dealer began a fight yesterday for control of the nation's second largest mail-order and retailing concern, the billion-dollar-a-year Montgomery Ward Co.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- British imports of plywood made entirely of softwood from the United States and other dollar-currency countries will be virtually free from Government control starting tomorrow, the British Board of Trade announced today.

A Brooklyn complainant in a petit larceny case spent the better part of yesterday trying to bail out the evidence so he could go to work in it. The evidence was a 1940 car -- old, but the only thing standing between its owner and a daily two-mile hike to work and back.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 -- The Administration will seek an increase next year in postal rates, an increase in postal clerks' salaries, and a reclassification of postal employes, Eugene Lyons, Assistant Postmaster General in charge of personnel, said here today.

Reporting a sharp drop in sales and earnings of ACF Industries, Inc., for the quarter ended July 31, John E. Rovensky, retiring chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he was neither optimistic nor pessimistic about this fiscal year, but "very optimistic about the long-term prospects of the company."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon said here today Thailand would like a Southeast Asian defense arrangement as near to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as possible.

ANN ARBOR, Aug. 26 -- The University of Michigan regents today dismissed two faculty members who refused last May to answer questions by a House of Representatives subcommittee investigating communism.
BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Russia let the world have a long look today at the big guns of its rebuilt track and field team as its team began piling up points in the European games.

NEWVILLE, Pa., Aug. 26 -- More than 300 representatives of the agriculture and electricity fields today joined John Stamy, 36-year-old Cumberland County dairyman, in inaugurating what farm experts call the most completely electrified farm in the country.
Only 312,376 persons have joined the Civil Defense Corps in England and Wales since the opening of recruitment in 1949, in comparison with a volunteer enrollment in New York of 352,395.

How to sell a "model home" paint and repair job -- and what happened to each of three householders who bought one -- was told in detail yesterday at a Senate investigation of irregularities in the Federal Housing Administration.
Cash registers are ringing up greater sales for Federated Department Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest retail chains, and earnings are reflecting the better business volume.
ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Eight Albanians who fled their homeland described today life in the smallest of the Soviet Union's satellites.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Aug. 21 were unchanged from the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- In a surcharged atmosphere like that of a national political convention in the United States, the French prepared today for a showdown on the European Defense Community treaty, which everybody says he wants but nobody is eager to face.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Former President Truman will make his first major speech for Democratic candidates this year at a fund-raising dinner in Kansas City Sept. 16. the Democratic National Committee announced today.
Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, sailed for Europe yesterday, saying that "it looks as if we are much closer to the solution of the polio problem."

JOHN LANDY of Australia said in Switzerland the other day that he was finished as a miler and that he never would run that distance again. That's as it should be. If a guy can't win when he runs a 3:59.6 mile, it's time to quit. Seriously, though, the Landy decision is cause for regret. The hope in this corner is that the butterfly-chaser from Down Under will change his mind when he returns home.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (UP) -- A former bishop of the Unitarian Church in Hungary, Alexander St. Ivanyl, said today that Christian churches had "gone underground" in the Communist country.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Blasting for the New York-Buffalo Thruway was halted here tonight after the village board ruled that the contractor must obtain a local permit before operations are resumed. This follows similar action in Yonkers and Hillburn yesterday.

The daily coffee trading limit of 2 cents a pound has been reinstated on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, effective today. The limit was reduced on Tuesday night to 1 cent a pound when banking, shipping and commerce in Brazil were disrupted after the death of President Vargas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The American Legion's national commander said today the Legion next week would oppose the American Medical Association on its veterans' medical treatment policies.
