GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Four players were bracketed at 70 at the halfway mark of the second "Ike" golf tournament sponsored by The New York Daily News, when play was completed today at the Tamarack Country Club and at near-by Whippoorwill in Armonk, N. Y.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sandy Consuegra coasted to his sixteenth victory of the season tonight as the Chicago White Sox won the twilight first game of a double-header from the Philadelphia Athletics, 8 -- 1. Then the Athletics snapped back on the strength of Bill Renna's two-run homer and oJe DeMaestri's two-run triple to take the afterpiece, 4 -- 1.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- "H-hour strikes," said Dior in speaking of his new collection. One of his greatest, its impact has resounded around the word. But sound can be muffled by distance, and those far from Paris may still be wondering what the sound and the furry are all about.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders promised today to document the charges on which he wants the Senate to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Sales of department stores in the Second Federal Reserve District in July were 2 per cent under the sales of July, 1953, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 26 -- The state chairman of the Democratic party protested today what he termed the increasing political aspects of President Eisenhower's proposed visit to the Iowa State Fair on Monday.
Some 5,000 public school pupils miss from two days to two weeks of schooling each year because they do not have adequate shoes or clothing.

A total of 663 pints of blood was donated on Wednesday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Among the collections were 182 pints at the Bankers Trust Company, 9 Pine Street; 123 pints at Federal Hall, Wall and Pine Streets, and 108 at the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 26--The trade fair planned here by Mexican and United States concerns, once postponed, has finally been canceled. No one seems to know exactly why.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 26 -Religious unity never will be achieved through "human compromise" or mechanical organization," Archbishop Karl J. Alter of Cincinnati said here tonight.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation increased its earnings in the first half this year by $2,938,236 over a year ago. Yesterday it announced it would raise its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a common share.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 26 -- With some $8,000 worth of bluefin tuna in her refrigerated holds, the eighty-six-foot San Diego, Calif., tuna clipper, Western Pride, arrived late today.

There are different and significant viewpoints from which various parts of the world look forward to the conference on the defense of Southeast Asia that will open in Manila on Sept. 6. They reflect differences in political philosophy and in immediate aims.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 26 -- Although there is no new T. S. Eliot play this year in Edinburgh, the first musical novelty of the festival, "Practical Cats," depends largely on the poet for its success.
DENVER, Aug. 26--President Eisenhower will try for trout instead of birdies next week and will take along a veteran fisherman and predecessor, Herbert Hoover.

THE week-end fishing prospects appear to be excellent from Cabo Blanco, Peru, on the south, to Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, on the north, although the fishing pressure at these extremes is not likely to be greatly increased by local sportsmen.
Plenty prevails in fruit and vegetable markets this week.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Britain's rules against alien labor have cost the Liverpool Philharmonic the services of a conductor on whom it had counted for this season's regular concert duties.

TORONTO, Aug. 26 -- The Canadian National Exhibition will be opened tomorrow by the Duchess of Kent. This year the exhibition has the world's largest food products building, a new structure of modern design recently completed at a cost of $1,500,000.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 26 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali, who used to be met at the airport by thousands of cheering admirers, was greeted by members of his family, a few close friends and the press as he returned today from a brief visit to East Pakistan.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Ted Williams equaled the lifetime home run total of Joe DiMaggio tonight, hitting his 361st homer in the eighth inning of a game with the Baltimore Orioles, but the Red Sox lost, 5 to 3.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The French appear resigned to getting back fewer than a third of the 28,000 French Union war prisoners they estimate the Communist-led Vietminh is holding. The official deadline for exchanging captives in North Vietnam passed today and the French had received only 3,000.
The crowds of Thirty-fourth Street jostled themselves aside yesterday to make way for some Fourteenth Street visitors who have come to stay--Ohrbach's and its thousands of loyal customers.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 26 -- Contract negotiations between the Order of Railway Conductors and tre Railroads' Carrier Conference Committee, deadlocked since December, 1953, are expected to resume by Sept. 6, Roy Hughes, president of the union, said today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 26 -- Ecclesiastical views on prayers for President Getulio Vargas, who committed suicide Tuesday morning, have been cleared up after three days of uncertainty. The Roman Catholic Church forbade a religious burial but will permit masses for his soul.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--A "task force" of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government was set up today to study the Foreign Operations Administration.

John Meikle, slaying suspect who escaped from Bellevue Hospital Tuesday afternoon, was recaptured at 5:25 A. M. yesterday at St. Nicholas Avenue and 129th Street. He had been charged with homicide and with wounding two other men in an argument early last Friday at Seventh Avenue and 126th Street.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Lauchlin Currie, one-time administrative assistant to President Roosevelt, whose name has been mentioned in Washington investigations of Soviet spy rings, said today he might consider applying for Colombian citzenshp.

THE weirdest story of the American Airlines pilots' strike that ended a couple of days ago is how a swarm of mosquitos stopped A. A.'s powerful fleet. This happened last Tuesday, when pilots attempted to ferry some of the ships from Newark, where they had been laid up, to their hangars at La Guardia Airport.

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- Clement R. Attlee said tonight he hoped his goodwill visit to Communist China with seven Labor party colleagues would lead to "the stabilization of world peace everywhere."

CHICAGO, Aug. 26--Under cover of a leaden sky the Giants encountered stormy going today as they grappled with the Cubs for the last time this season on Wrigley Field. With the aid of a stout-hearted mound effort by Johnny Antonelli they contrived to break even before a gathering of 9,392 and thus maintain their three-and-a-half-game margin over the idle Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The Public Health Service said today that 2,207 new cases of poliomyelitis were reported in the nation last week, an increase of more than 15 per cent over the 1,905 of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Edward Lamb of Toledo, Ohio, publisher and industrialist, has called for a special meeting of Airway Electrical Appliance Corporation stockholders, a spokesman said today. The announcement said Mr. Lamb proposed the meeting at company offices in Toledo on Sept. 10 to discuss a move by two Airway officers to sell the concern to Firth Carpet Company.

Anthony M. Mauriello, a former assistant state attorney general, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner as the Republican member of the City Civil Service Commission. Mr. Mauriello resigned his state position just before taking his new job, which pays $12,000 a year.
BUFFALO, Aug. 26 -- The state's economic frontier widened today as Governor Dewey dedicated the second segment of the main New York-Buffalo Thruway.
PARIS, Aug. 26 -- A British lieutenant colonel at Supreme Allied Headquarters went one better than stepping into his commander's shoes. He stepped into his entire uniform.

REGINA, Sask., Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Claude Jodoin, 41 years of age, of Montreal was elected president of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada today. He is the youngest head of the congress in its seventy-year history.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Aug. 26 -- A three-day convention of 1,600 members of Jehovah's Witnesses will open tomorrow despite protests from the Morris County Committee of the American Legion.
Major steps to promote the city's campaign against crime and juvenile delinquency were taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

In his letter to The Times published recently Gordon D. Friedlander attempts to definitively outline the causes of crime as slums, poverty, overcrowded schools, inadequate recreational facilities and medical care, supplemented by comic books, parental indifference, movie and television murders galore.

Louis Hayward will star in a series called "The Lone Wolf," which is to begin Sept. 4 on WNBT from 11:15 to 11:45 P. M. In the filmed episodes, Mr. Hayward will pursue the wrongdoers. The series is based on stories by Louis Vance.

CHICAGO, Aug, 26 -- Representatives of five states bordering on the Great Lakes reported today that substantial port improvement were necessary to handle increased foreign trade that will result with the completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway project.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is going to try to blow that troublesome fog away from its superhighway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A seller who grants advertising allowances to some of his customers must tell any competing customers how they also can receive them, the Federal Trade Commission ruled today.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 26, -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood was outscored in medal play by Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair but won the Garden State Women's Golf Association round-robin tournament today at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- The Minister of Moroccan and Tunisian affairs said in the National Assembly today that the French Government had prepared a "vast program of action" to lead Morocco to sovereignty and democracy.
The 1955 registration for motor vehicle plates will be used as an enforced check on automobile liability insurance in this state.
Four Brooklyn teen-agers were indicted yesterday in Kings County Court for first-degree murder in the drowning of a 34-year-old man.

Having selected the protagonists for "Wedding Breakfast," Kermit Bloomgarden has designated Nov. 16 for the local premiere. Appearing in Theodore Reeves' four-character play will be Lee Grant, Harvey Lembeck, Virginia Vincent and Anthony Franciosa.

The Board of Estimate adopted a resolution yesterday approving a $10,850 contract for test borings on the site of the city's projected passenger pier and terminal at West Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets on the Hudson River.

Residents of the Farragut Gardens apartment project are deeply angered over the revelation that a $15,000 investment in the development yielded "windfall" profits of $4,000,000 to the original owners.
Two recently published books may be of special interest to amateur carpenters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A three-member panel of the United States Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Mrs. Mary Jane Keeney of New York on a charge of contempt of Congress. It ordererd a new trial.

While its former neighborhood competitor -- Ohrbach's -- was experiencing opening-day pangs uptown, S. Klein moved yesterday to fill the gap left on Union Square. It showed a collection of college clothes that represented the store's recent decision to place greater emphasis on high fashion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee has "directed" the Administration to refrain from granting any additional loan to the European Coal and Steel Community, set up to promote the economic unity of West Europe.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The country's railroads, which only recently granted pay increases and other concessions, today faced a new batch of demands from five brotherhoods of operating employes.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The man who took the splash out of the kitchen sink unveiled a grotesque, five-ton vehicle today that can roll like a ball through a swamp.

A long, confidential memorandum delivered last February to the Army by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, after an extensive investigation of alleged anti-Semitism at Fort Monmouth, N. J., came to light yesterday.
The Transit Authority ordered the members of its police force yesterday to work an additional eight-hour tour each week to combat crime in the subways.

Three men were arrested yesterday on charges of attempting to extort $535,000 from Serge Rubinstein, Russian-born financier. Rubinstein is fighting a deportation order based on a 1947 draft-dodging conviction.
CHICAGO. Aug. 6 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:...
ROME, N. Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A group of scientists today turned over to the Rome Air Development Center a device designed to keep the air waves clear for vital emergency communications.

Quemoy Island, which remained a Nationalist outpost after the Communists seized the Chinese mainland in 1949, is located in Formosa Strait southeast of Fukien Province in China. It is fifteen miles east of Amoy and has a population of about 50,000. Its chief town also is called Quemoy and has a population of about 6,000.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Dancers in the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet Company accepted today compromise proposals made by the management after a wage dispute that had threatened to disband the group.

A sterner attitude toward the misbehaving driver is visible on many fronts. An instance is the report of New York State's Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, James R. Macduff, that revocations of driver licenses for drunken driving convictions are running 53 per cent above last year's.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A 34-year-old Canadian today stepped out of the rain-soaked tent he has been sleeping in since Monday and captured trapshooting's second greatest prize -- the Preliminary Handicap -- at the fifty-fifth Grand American.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- For the first time since 1947, a group of United States, British and French correspondents was taken today on a tour of the Stalin automobile works, one of the largest industrial establishments in Moscow.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 26 -- South Africa now has a political party that favors the apartheid, or racial segregation, policy of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan but is opposed to his aim of establishing South Africa as a republic.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP) -- F. Gregg Bemis of the Cohasset Yacht Club, sailing his Alar, today won the International 210 yacht championship by scoring the highest number of points in the two-day event in Vineyard Sound off Cape Cod.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 27 -- The United States Fifth Air Force announced today plans to take many of its Sabre jets and other planes out of Korea and shift headquarters to Nagoya, Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 678,624 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,653 cars or 1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 138,822 cars or 17 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 155,605 cars or 18.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Karl Franz Schmidt-Wittmack, Bundestag Deputy who defected last week to East Germany, said today secret negotiations had taken place recently between United States and German generals to create a forty-eight-division West German army.

" LIFE WITH FATHER" took up residence again on C. B. S.-TV last Tuesday from 10 to 10:30 P. M., a new time period for the comedy series based on the Clarence Day Jr. stories. It would be interesting to know what Father Day thinks about being shunted from his former Sunday night hour to make way this fall for a dog named Lassie.

TRENTON, Aug. 26 -- An official of the State Division of Employment Security swore here today that secret testimony given by its employes to state investigators last spring had been "leaked" to former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman and two of his aides.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An eight-power conference will probably be held if the French National Assembly rejects the European Defense Community treaty.
Amendments, effective today, to the New York City and State Sanitary Codes governing labeling of hazardous substances should be of interest to homemakers.

A home-made maharajah won his way into the public prints the other day when gullible photographers went along with the theory that anyone wearing a turban must be at least an Indian prince of the blood.
The Columbia Broadcasting System presented last night what is called the first network editorial in the history of television -- an appeal for permission to cover the McCarthy hearings next week.
Fruits that are delicious for eating out of the hand and for making into jams and jellies for later use are now coming from the orchards and vineyards.

An upsurge of Christian faith in South Korea since the end of the Korean conflict was reported yesterday by a "death march" survivor. He attributed this to courage displayed by Christian Koreans in the face of Communist persecution and to aid from Christians abroad to Korean refugees.

There is no law that says a candidate for Governor must be picked in a smoke-filled hotel room, or in the board room of a Wall Street bank. But traditions are strong, and one must salute the leading New York City Democrats who, in a body of twenty-five, chose the paddock at Saratoga Springs as a scene of pre-convention deliberation.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Dawn at Socorro," a UniversalInternational Western in Technicolor, is at the Palace. Rory Calhoun, Piper Laurie, David Brian and Kathleen Hughes have the principal roles.

A police launch will be assigned to the waters near the Twenty-fifth Precinct in East Harlem beginning next Wednesday. On that date an additional 250 men will be assigned to the area in an experiment to determine what constitutes adequate manpower for the prevention of crime.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday for the first seven months of this year a net loss of $3,955,782. This contrasts with a net income of $22,257,854 in the similar period of 1953. Gross revenues were $495,749,183, a decrease of $117,075,078 from the $612,824,261 for the 1953 period. Net operating income was $22,516,718, compared with $49,833,454.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers decided today to concentrate on the work rule in an effort to obtain more money for the organization's 80,000 members.

The property at 56 South Munn Avenue in East Orange, N. J., now occupied by the Covenant Orthodox Presbyterian Church of the Oranges, has been purchased by Vinton Apartments, Inc., for improvement with an apartment building. M. I. Sientz was the broker and the attorneys were Syd Jacobs for the buyer and Douglas C. Baker for the seller.
BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Russia made a fine show of strength in the European games today when its athletes won seven of eight gold medals at stake on the third day of the meet.
The cotton futures market opened 2 points higher to 2 points lower than on Thursday, and held steady on the New York Cotton Exchange all day. Closing prices were at gains of 11 to 15 points.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York and second-ranking prelate in the Church of England, called today for prayers for good weather to save Britain's harvest from destruction.

The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday its net income from transportation operations was $25,668,252 or $2.84 a share in the first seven months of this year. For the similar period last year the company had a net income of $36,749,890 or $4.06 a share.

Determined not to permit Soviet Russia to halt progress in the free world, the United States has taken the lead in working out with several of its allies a new plan for putting the atom to work for peaceful purposes -- with Russia, if possible, without Russia, if necessary.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The cable ship Recorder, 3,300 tons, newest, largest and fastest vessel of Cable and Wireless Company's fleet, was heading at reduced speed tonight to Gravesend after having been badly damaged in a collision.

The Edward Fields Company, manufacturer and distributor of hand-woven rugs, has leased a building of 12,000 square feet to be erected at the southeast corner of Miller Street and Thirty-second Avenue in Flushing, Queens, by Abraham Daniels.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 27 (AP) -The Tennessee Vallel Public Power Association, in le-I Jers to high administration officials, has demanded that action be delayed on the Dixon-Yates contract until its 'members inspect it.

CHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Leaders in this resort community of 1,200 expressed alarm today over conditions at near-by Camp La Guardia, where disorders last week-end resulted in seven arrests and two accidental deaths.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs made the National League's first triple play this year and Ted Kluszewski hit a ninth-inning home run, his thirty-seventh, to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 -- 2, tonight.
Cattlemen and tanners are wondering how far down is "bottom" as it relates to hides. For more than a month hide prices have been at the lowest level since the beginning of World War II.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 -- Trailing the Cards, 4 -- 2, going into the ninth inning tonight the Dodgers tied the score on a two-run homer by Walt Moryn, then scored four times in the tenth to win, 8 -- 4.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Efforts for a new negotiation on the European Defense Community treaty between France and the five other signatory states were made today both in the Cabinet and in the National Assembly.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Louise Brough, the top-ranking player in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club, was extended before defeating Mrs. Helen Perez, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, in the quarter-final round today.
VIENNA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Chancellor Julius Raab opened the forty-third Congress of the Interparliamentary Union today with an appeal for a free Austria.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Gene Baker's squeeze bunt in the twelfth inning today scored Hal Jeffcoat to give the Chicago Cubs a 4-to-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27 -- An early meeting of the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty powers will be necessary to consider alternative policies if the European Defense Community is rejected in France, diplomats here believe.
DENVER, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower administered a pocket veto today to a bill to establish special rates or overtime, Sunday and holiday pay for some quarantine inspection personnel.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The vast Bemberg industrial holdings in Argentina, values at $250,000,000 before President Juan Peron's Government took them over, will be sold to the Argentine Brewery Workers Union.

The combined men's and women's national tennis championships begin today at 1 o'clock on the turf of the West Side Club at Forest Hills, with most of the world's top amateurs entered. The senior singles and the mixed doubles also will be played.

For a few days next week, if their plans go through, two old friends -- one considerably older than the other -- will be trying to take trout out of St. Louis Creek, 10,000 feet up in the Colorado Rockies, seventy miles from Denver. One, the younger, is not only a fisherman but a cook.
SEOUL, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Government-proposed bill to restrict foreign news agencies operating in South Korea has failed to reach the floor of the National Assembly.

After four successive days of declining prices that wiped 5.59 points from The New York Times combined average, the stock market took a turn for the better yesterday. While volume dried up to the smallest since mid-June -- only 1,740,000 shares against 2,060,000 on Thursday -- stocks pushed ahead in gingerly fashion. They lost part of their gains by the close.

RICHLAND, Wash., Aug. 27 (AP) -- More than 3,500 workmen turned back today from a $40,000,000 construction job at the Hanford Atomic Works project because of a dispute over which union should cut holes for pipes and conduits.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Government trade officials prepared formal protests today for presentation on Sept. 8 and 9 at United States Tariff Commission public hearings on possible import curbs on oats and barley.
DALLAS, Aug. 27 -- A million or more Texans will go to the polls tomorrow in the culmination of the South's hottest political battle since 1952.
After a brief but stormy visit to Brooklyn, a truckful of jumbo shrimp and Australian lobster tails was back early today at the Fulton Fish Market where it belongs.

The biggest cattle run in history, expected to result in record supplies of beef beginning the middle of next month, assures home cooks of plenty of reasonably priced steaks, rib roasts, hamburgers and meats for savory stews this fall and winter.

SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Aug. 27 --Blasting permits issued to New York State Thruway contractors here were canceled today after hundreds of protests over a blast last night that sent rock over the east end of the village.
The continued popularity of the handy, small table is evidenced in the many new designs now available.
The National Labor Relations Board certified the old International Longshoremen's Association yesterday as bargaining agent for dock workers in the Port of New York.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- A team of Federal and private industrial diagnosticians visited economically-ailing Lawrence today and tentatively decided that there was nothing wrong with the patient that a dose of new industries could not cure.
BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Capt. Ignatius N. Tripi became commander of the Naval Supply Depot here this afternoon in a ceremony in which he relieved Comdr. Charles S. Sharrocks as head of the base.

All coffee positions except the spot September option showed early strength yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Before the close prices fell the 2-cents-a-pound limit. The volume, 153,000 bags, was the heaviest day's trading since Dec. 21, 1953.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Aug. 23 -- New Zealand was tilled by So4 cialist governments for fourteen consecutive years until 1949.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Britain announced today that a ten-member delegation, led by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, would represent this country at the ninth annual session of the United Nations General Assembly beginning in New York Sept. 21.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Eli Lilly Co., Indianapolis, received a patent this week for a pill that can be identified by a doctor but remains a mystery to the patient.
Governor Dewey has been subjected to increasing pressure from Republican legislators and leaders to "clarify" his attitude toward acrenomination.

Three New York fire engines with their crews rushed up to the Astor Hotel yesterday noon on a business call, but they were too late. The fire was out. As usual, the Astor's own volunteer fire company had beat them to the put-out.

The I-T-E Circuit Breaker Company and its subsidiaries, manufacturers of electric power equipment used in the transmission and distribution of electrical energy, yesterday reported lower sales and earnings for the first six months this year.

The usual pre-Labor Day lull in underwriting activity is not developing this year. August so far has been an active period for the public market for new capital, and it promises to remain so right to the end.

A study of problems that have been created for Protestant churches on Brooklyn Heights by population shifts was made public yesterday by the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- Two more college students have come to Russia from the United States on a fact-finding expedition.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 (UP) -- An American, Billy Gilliam, scored a technical knockout over Germany's Hein Ten Hoff, former European heavyweight champion, in the seventh of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight before 10,000 fans at West Berlin's Sports Palace.

The Yankees, who have been running on a treadmill in their agonizing pursuit of the Indians, moved a step closer to the league leaders last night. The Bombers' 4-0 triumph over the Detroit Tigers, combined with Cleveland's loss to Washington, put the New Yorkers within three and a half games of the top of the American League standings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy delayed tonight a showdown hearing on the disputed Dixon-Yates power contract, which had been scheduled for Thursday.
MIAMI, Saturday, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Atlantic hurricane Carol has grown into an 115-mile-an- hour blow aimed at the coast of the Carolinas.

TRENTON, Aug. 27 -- A trucking contractor swore here today that he had accepted a $100 bribe from a top official in the State Division of Employment Security and that he had paid another employe of that agency $2,100 in kickbacks.

NEWARK, Aug. 27 -- The Nellie Bly, a Pennsylvania Railroad express that has been running between New York and Atlantic City for more than fifty years, will run only between Trenton and the shore resort after Sept. 26, if the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission approves a petition that was filed today by the railroad.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- Two players with contrasting backgrounds gained the final of the United States amateur golf championship today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Fourteen was the magic number today as three 14-year-olds outshot the biggest trap-shooting field in history to sweep the major honors in the fifty-fifth Grand American Handicap.

John J. Neale has been appointed president and director of the Lane-Wells Company. He succeeds Rodney S. Durkee, who was named chairman. Walter T. Wells, former chairman, assumes the new position of founder-chairman. Lane-Wells specializes in services connected with drilling and maintaining oil wells.
GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- The most recent "man without a country" has at last found a home.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A group of Syrian lawyers charged today the United States had "insulted the Syrian people" by attempting to force the Government to bar Communist China's participation in the Damascus International Fair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- An error by Dave Philley, right fielder, in the tenth inning enabled Pete Runnels to score the winning run tonight as the Washington Senators downed the first-place Cleveland Indians, 3 to 2.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 -- Brazil's new President came to the country's highest office as an unknown quantity so far as his own people were concerned, though he has devoted his life political activity.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- The second conference of the World Assembly of Youth ended here today amid booing and catcalls after ten days of discussion on world problems.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Pronto Don failed in his bid to pass Good Time as the world's leading money winning harness horse when the aged chestnut gelding finished third in the $10,000 Indiana Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Katharine Cornell will give her first performance in "The Dark Is Light Enough" at her favorite tryout place, the Erlanger Theatre in Buffalo, on Nov. 24.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The appliance distributing concern of Trilling Montague has agreed to turn over to the Borg-Warner Corporation of Chicago all records of its Norge products service agreements made during the twelve months prior to the suicide of Harry Montague last June.

The Soviet bosses have been going to interesting lengths recently to give the impression that the spirit of Warren Gamaliel Harding dominates their thinking. "Back to Normalcy" seems to be their slogan and the revelation that they have decided to move out of the Kremlin to lodgings and offices elsewhere in Moscow is in a pattern which is now a year old.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Nationalist authorities conceded today that a party of Chinese Communist commandos had made a sneak raid on the Nationalist-held island of Quemoy this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A witness before the Senate Internal Security subcommitte, invoking constitutional protection, has refused to say whether he worked through various groups identified as Communist fronts in seeking repeal of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Universal-International, which not long ago had difficulty hiring top stars when it wanted them, now has one of the largest collections of such personalities under contract for one or more pictures.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 -- The southern city of Porto Alegre was reported in a state of terror tonight. Troops were seeking to prevent a fresh outbreak of the rioting that has cost six lives in the last three days.

PARK RIDGE, N. J., Aug. 27 -- The United States Air Force joined today with the New Jersey Division of Civil Defense in honoring two teen-age airplane spotters. Since last Saturday, the youths have maintained the observation post here on an around-the-clock basis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Two United States icebreakers have forged the final, stubborn link in the Northwest Passage across the Canadian Arctic.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- J. D. Streett, president of the Laclede Christy Company here, announced today the management is resisting an effort by the H. K. Porter Company of Pittsburgh to take over control.
The Communist party wired yesterday to President Eisenhower for the complete text of the Communist Control Act, saying all efforts to get an authoritative text have been in vain.

In this country, the Christmas season is a combination of Santa Claus, Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, crowded department stores and a religious celebration. In the Puritan settlement of Massachusetts 300 years ago, any celebration of Christmas was prohibited.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent to 110 (1947-1949 equals 100) in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices of farm products and processed foods were responsible for the decrcase.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Two triples and Johnny Groth's sixth home run produced eight runs in a big third inning tonight as the Chicago White Sox trounced the Philadelphia Athletics, 11 -- 0, with Harry Dorish going the distance for his fifth victory.

The romance of chess is a very real thing to Mrs. Rita DeLieto. Last January she married a chess expert she met at a chess club and this week she displayed her originally designed chessmen at the International Gifts and Fancy Goods Show at the Astor Hotel.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 27 -- The Chinese Reds are now taking over the last of around $90,000,000,000 of British enterprise in this city -- banks, public utilities, factories and once-flourishing businesses. The last of the dwindling group of British businessmen are finally being granted exit permits.

Plans for a new apartment house in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx were announced yesterday by the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation, brokers, who sold a plot on the west side of Palisade Avenue, north of Independence Avenue, to the Rosedale Engineering Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower himself thought up the idea for that new "greenhouse" that has recently adorned the President's official car.
Every 'teen age lad in the country about to take his girl to their first formal high school dance may be affected by action taken yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Mr. Daley declared here that "Mr. Eaton and I have no liability." Mr. Eaton, in Nova Scotia on vacation, was not available, but Mr. Daley said he spoke for both.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- London's two biggest dailies are massing their resources for a newspaper war for the support of school children.
KAUFBEUREN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- The feathery tufts of smoke rising from the chimneys of the neat, new houses in the Neugablonz section of this city symbolize that community's devotion to hard work.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Andrew J. Crevolin today issued a public apology for his "unfortunate remarks" about horse racing.
A major Harlem policy ring was smashed last night with the arrest of seven men and one woman. Records seized by the police indicated the ring collected $10,000 a day from bettors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Donald McClave of Greenwich, Conn., settled for sixth place today in the final race of the five-race international Luders-16 class yacht competition, but he won the over-all championship.

MELBOURNE, Aug. 27 -- Net profit of General Motors-Holdens, Ltd., rose from 4,010,000 (Australian) ($9,022,500) in 1952 to 7,287,000 ($16,395,750) in 1953. The dividend on ordinary stock held by General Motors Corporation in the United States was increased from 30 per cent last paid in 1951 to 100 per cent.
A group of mothers applied the final strokes to their vacation painting project this week under the eyes of some loving critics -- their children.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A former Veterans Administration clerk accused of cashing two forged $10,000 death benefit checks, one right in the Treasury cashroom in Washington, was arrested today in near-by Glendale.

The New York Summer Festival took over Washington Square last night for an outdoor jam session. Cooperating in the event was the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, which rounded up entertainers from various night clubs in the Village.

Let me congratulate you on your excellent editorial "Caution Called For," which appeared in your issue of Aug. 11. I am fully in accord with your statement, "the path of common sense and of moderation must be scrupulously followed if we are not to lose everything we seek to preserve."

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- There was good buying support here today in the wheat market at times, but buyers were inclined to go slow in following rallies. Weather conditions were still unfavorable in western Canada and reports from Europe were of a disturbing character.

NOW that the fishing is passing its peak, with the exception of striped bass, which are scheduled to begin their fall run shortly, most of the sportsmen seem to be giving more attention to plans for the hunting season.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug 27 -- Paul-Henri Spaak outlined today the six main points of disagreement at the recent Brussels conference.

The League of Women Voters and its president, Mrs. Rita B. Morris, are to be commended for calling public attention to the ridiculous waste of the President's time when he was forced to make a quick trip to New York City to register personally for the forthcoming election.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Television station WPTZ defended today its filming of a police arrest and interrogation as "news that the public is entitled to know through its newspaper, radio and television shows."

DENVER, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower went fishing for trout high in the Rockies today and in a few hours his catch went over the legal limit. The unofficial count on the President ran from fifteen to twenty-five -- rainbows and browns. The legal limit is ten.
The promotion of Christian brotherhood offers the best hope of jobs and security for everyone, says the annual Labor Sunday message of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

Fall men's wear business will be excellent, according to Harry Doniger, president of David D. Doniger Co., producer of McGregor sportswear. Orders already shipped and bookings on hand portend a good season, he said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Representative Carl Hinshaw, an authority in Congress on nuclear development, urged today that United States immigration laws be relaxed to admit more foreign-born scientists.

VIENNA, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today he "would not say no" if Communist leaders proposed to talk over East-West problems while he was here. Mr. Wiley is attending the meeting of the Interparliamentary Union.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 27 -- A top official of the World Council of Churches accused a member of Congress today of "highly improper and unfair" conduct.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 27 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today the new law outlawing the Communist party was "hastily drawn" and indicated he thought it might do more harm than good.
PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Poland has offered France a treaty of alliance and mutual assistance and has warned that the setting up of a European Army would lead to a third world war.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Soviet children now have a comic strip all their own, featuring the adventures of a lazybones, troublesome, day-dreaming rabbit named Zaika Zaitzev, Zaika means rabbit in Russian. This comic strip is the first for Russian youngsters.

Plans for altering the four-story house on lot 20 by 100 feet at 354 East Fifty-first Street, near First Avenue, into small apartments have been announced in connection with the purchase of the property by Edward Schwartz, operator.

The contest between Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Averell Harriman for the Democratic nomination for Governor has brought to light some interesting divisions and alignments within the Democratic party, particularly in the New Deal wing.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Inability of the buyers to be represented any earlier has caused old-belt tobacco warehousemen of Virginia and North Carolina to delay opening their auctions from next Thursday to Sept. 13.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 -- The Democratic nomination of Dr. H. C. Byrd for Governor of Maryland in the close primary of June 28 was conceded today by his opponent, George P. Mahoney.

STARLIGHT, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Samuel D. Gershovitz of New York, executive vice president of the National Jewish Welfare Board, today was named 1954 recipient of the "Sam Beber Distinguished Alumni Award" of the B'nai B'rith Youth Organization.

The baseball world series, wherever it may be played, will be easy to follow for anyone anywhere who has a radio set, according to plans announced yesterday by the Mutual Broadcasting System. The network will offer play-by-play descriptions of the games over radio stations throughout the United States, as well as those of the Dominion network of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- A long-hoped-for continental touch for United Nations Headquarters has finally been abandoned. There will be no outdoor dining terrace here because of atmospheric conditions in the neighborhood.
Donald A. Milton has been appointed manager of the product cost control department of Chrysler Corporation, Detroit.

Twelve general trucking unions in the New York-New Jersey area agreed yesterday to extend their contracts with employers for thirty days -- or until Oct. 1 -- thus ending the threat of an industry-wide strike in that period.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The British Admiralty said today that a Soviet fleet of three cruisers and twelve destroyers was moving south down the Norwegian coast at a distance approximately twenty miles off shore. However, the officials emphasized that there appeared to be nothing "sinister" about the situation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Details of the nation's largest peacetime ship building and repair program were announced here today.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 27 (UP) -Delegates to the tenth annual AMVETS convention today accused the policy-making body of the American Medical Association of "indulging in activities intended to deprive veterans of benefits to which they are justly entitled."

As summer draws to a close and the woods become dry, the danger of forest and brush fires increases. Areas of beauty are destroyed and lumber -- a valuable natural resource -- is laid waste. But that is not all. Hillsides swept by fire no longer hold the rain as before.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The United States, long regarded in Europe as a hamburger haven with a frying fixation, is growing rapidly to the stature of a culinary world power, a food expert said today.

MANILA, Saturday, Aug. 28 -- The Philippines is making known to United States her determination to obtain an agreement on a much stronger and militarily more effective treaty than is now contemplated in draft pacts circulated among the nations that will confer here starting Sept. 6 on a Southeast Asia defense arrangement.

TORONTO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Canadian Football with its strange rules and familiar American "imports" will invade United States living rooms tomorrow with the telecast of the Ottawa-Toronto opener of the Big Four season.

The recent hideous crimes committed by four youngsters from Brooklyn bring into sharp focus our obsolete thinking regarding the causes of delinquency and our miserable failure in handling our growing delinquent population. Since each person has a different personality make-up, is reared in a different family in his own subculture and faces thousands of situations eliciting thousands of various emotional reactions, all alert citizens must remember that the causes of crime are infinite and relative.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who is having his biggest cash-collecting year in racing at the age of 80, sent out his tenth Saratoga Cup winner today.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- The Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France won wide support from the National Assembly tonight for its policy of making peace with the Nationalists of Morocco and Tunisia by putting these French protectorates on the road to democratic self-rule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., testified today that it intended to dispose of minority interests in television stations if it was authorized to acquire full ownership in up to five stations.
A vacationing police lieutenant yesterday subdued a young woman motorist who, he said, twice tried to run him down on Queens Boulevard.
OXNARD, Calif., Aug. 27 (UP) -- An airplane with scoop-shaped wings hovered today over Oxnard Airport at eleven miles an hour, the speed of a running man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland financier and board chairman of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, clashed with the Internal Revenue Service today over a claim for $1,572,234 in back Federal taxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Of eighty countries polled this year only sixteen still withhold all political rights from their women citizens, according to a memorandum issued today by the Secretary General of the United Nations.

Corn will find its way onto many shopping lists this weekend, for it is at its lowest price of the season, a city-wide average of 6 1/2 cents a pound. It is not only at its cheapest but also at its best, for, coming from near-by gardens, it has that just-picked taste that is so desirable, especially in corn.

Criticism that Burlington Mills Corporation might have acted unfairly in its recent purchases of stock in Pacific Mills and Goodall -Sanford, Inc., was answered yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The institution reported that its investigations had uncovered no sign of discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture eased restrictions today on regulations governing Federal subsidy payments to farmers for planting winter cover crops. The change would increase subsidies available in areas damaged by drought but not hurt seriously enough to be designated as drought disaster areas.

A seven-year tenure as general secretary of the Student Volunteer Movement will be given up Wednesday when the Rev. Edward H. Johnson will take up his duties in Toronto as secretary for Overseas Missions of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 27 --Trouble is brewing for the United Nations office employes who intend to build homes on the old James Speyer estate. They bought the property three months ago for conversion into a community for 350 families from many nations.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Clement R. Attlee left his seven British Labor party colleagues today to visit foreign ships in dock in this Communist Chinese city.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 27 (UP) -- Schenectady, N. Y., won the Little League world series today by defeating Colton, Calif., 7 -- 5, in the final before 7,500 fans.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., reached an agreement today granting 23,000 production workers wage increases of at least 6 cents an hour, to end 'a fifty-one-day strike in the company's ten plants.
The urgency of $172,062,000 in transit improvements was stressed yesterday by the Transit Authority in a hearing before the City Planning Commission on capital budget needs for the next year.

United Air Lines, Inc., will spend $25,000,000 on new aircraft and equipment, W. A. Patterson, president, announced yesterday. The board of directors, meeting for the first time in San Francisco, elected two new board members, increasing the number to twelve.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The United States is building up a detailed case against Communist China for the death of three Americans killed when a commercial airliner was shot down off Hainan Island July 23, Administration officials said today.

American Airlines announced yesterday it would lay off 1,300 of its 17,268 employes and cut back operations as the result of the twenty-five day strike by the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., which ended Wednesday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 27 -Tommy Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club won the second "Ike" golf tournament staged by the New York Daily News by carding a par 71 at Tamarack today for a total of 141.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 -- India does not propose, for the time being, to extend "formal" recognition to Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, the three Associated States of Indochina. Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made this announcement today in the upper house of Parliament.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower was "the victim of his own staff" when he recently vetoed a measure that would have increased postal workers' salaries, Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, told the National Federation of Post Office Clerks in convention today.

In your editorial of Aug. 17 criticizing Mayor Wagner's request for a commission to be appointed by Governor Dewey and himself to study state-city fiscal relations, you misconceive the nature of the problem. It is by no means limited to state aid; indeed, perhaps the more important factor is that adequate taxing powers be made available to New York City to enable it to finance its heavy burdens.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 27 -- The stockholders of the Middletown National Bank today defeated the proposal to consolidate with the Central National Bank and Trust Company of this city. The proposition failed to attain the necessary two-thirds vote of the stock represented at the stockholders meeting.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 27 (UP) -Federal Judge Robert L. Taylor extended today to Oct. 30 a Taft-Hartley injunction against a strike of atomic production workers at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Manufacturers' shipments ran at about the same level in July as in June, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today. New orders, however, were reported slightly lower.

The Army made public yesterday a letter addressed last June 24 to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith, advising that no substance had been found in allegations of anti-Semitism at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

Military personnel -- now hurtling through the skies in sleek, jet-powered instruments of war -- usually have flown faster from place to place than most civilian passengers on commercial airlines -- and perhaps they will so continue.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company of St. Paul, Minn., and the Glass Container Manufacturers Institute, Inc., have taken office space in the twenty-six-story building at 99 Park Avenue built by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, of which Norman Tishman is president.
The New York Regional Red cross Blood Program received 768 pints of blood on Thursday.

KNOKKE-LE-ZOUTE, Belgium, Aug. 27 -- The Liberal International Council sent to the French liberals today a message expressing the hope that the French National Assembly would approve the European Defense Community treaty.

WASHINGTON, Aug 27 (AP) -- The Institute of Ethnic Affairs, Inc., has called upon President Eisenhower to veto a bill that would end Federal supervision over some 200 members of four small Utah bands of Indians.
With the vast majority of Americans, I cherish a fervent hope for the ratification by all of the Western European nations of the European Defense Community.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The stock markets remained cheerful today, although week-end profit-taking caused a little irregularity in the movement of prices. Industrial shares again were active, while South African gold mining issues rallied briskly after slipping during the morning.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, the national singles and doubles champion, and Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco will meet tomorrow in the final of the invitation grass court tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports predicted today that 150,000 to 200,000 cars are expected to be cut from new car field stocks by September - October changeover shutdowns. This, the agency said, would reduce inventories to the lowest point since early last year.

Three men were held yesterday in connection with the attempted extortion of $535,000 from Serge Rubinstein, financier. The men had been arrested on Thursday, one in Rubinstein's apartment at 814 Fifth Avenue and the others outside the building.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Texas offered a home today for Old No. 494, which was retired twenty years ago as the last steam locomotive of the Boston Maine Railroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- San Francisco dedicated a new $14,000,000 terminal at the city's International Airport today and thereby completed a $50,000,000 development program designed to provide one of the world's most capacious and efficient centers of air transportation.
TORONTO, Aug. 27 (UP) -Wally Ulrich of Rochester, Minn., maintained a one-stroke lead after 54 holes of the $26,500 Labatt open golf tournament today.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27 -- The Giants met the enemy head-on tonight and forthwith turned in a performance that could well have spiked the pennant prospects of at least one of their two remaining rivals.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Chrysler division retailers in twenty-eight cities got a pep talk from factory executives yesterday over a closed circuit television hookup.

Lumber production in the week ended Aug. 21 was 38.3 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 33.4 per cent and orders doom 23.4 per cent.

Thirty-seven thousand passengers on forty-seven rush-hour trains of the New York Central and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads reached their destinations from five to forty-nine minutes late last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today named crops which will be included under acreage allotments for farmers next year.
All testimony in the Federal Housing Administration inquiry that points to income tax violations by "windfall" builders will be turned over to the Internal Revenue Service.
A full-scale copy of Thomas Alva Edison's "Black Maria," the first motion picture studio, will be dedicated Sept. 22 at the Edison Museum in West Orange, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission reported today the privately owned electric utility industry had net income of $1,030,225,000 in 1953, an increase of 8.8 per cent over the $947,094,000 for 1952. Total 1953 operating revenues of the companies were $7,136,337,000, an increase of 9 per cent over the $6,549,164,000 reported for 1952.
The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday the World War II treason conviction of John David Provoo, former Army staff sergeant.

An editorial in The Times of Aug. 12 makes the claim that I have "thus far failed to take a forthright public stand against (Senator) McCarthy." Knowing The Times' reputation for fairness, I can only conclude the editorial was based on insufficient information.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The national employment situation has continued to show seasonal improvement, James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today.

WHO knows the name of the Union general who turned back Lee at Gettysburg? Far fewer Americans certainly than those who know the name of the Confederate leader. There he sits today, mounted, in stone and bronze, east of the Emmitsburg Road, looking bleakly across the level fields toward Seminary Ridge, where the Confederate line ran, and in sight of that great equestrian statue of Lee.
The single-screw tanker World Glory, the largest cargo vessel built in the Western Hemisphere, took on a spare propeller yesterday before sailing on her maiden voyage.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Indochina truce commission said today that it would send inspection teams to the prisoner exchange between the French and the Communist-led Vietminh at Viettri Saturday and probably at Samson Sunday.

SIX years ago Rumer Godden gave us "The Doll's House," a novel in miniature which is well on the way to becoming a classic. "Impunity Jane" is also a doll's story -- shorter in length, designedly narrower in scope, with fewer philosophical overtones, yet so far as humor, imagination and style are concerned it is all of a piece with the first book.

So large is the number of teenagers who fail to return to school after working during the vacation period, that James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, has issued a special appeal to these students, urging them to continue their schooling.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Chester J. La Roche's Master's Choice, ridden by the owner's daughter Rosalind, was a triple winner as the fifteenth Fairfield junior hunt horse show ended today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Athens' request to the United Nations that the inhabitants of the British island colony of Cyprus be given an opportunity to vote for union with Greece is one of the few really new problems to come up here for a long time.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski, Cincinnati's powerhouse, doubled in the tying run and rode home on two long flies, giving the Redlegs a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. The rookie right-hander, Corky Valentine, pitched all the way for his eleventh triumph.

Mr. Lundberg looks over the situation with a jaundiced eye and writes in a style that at its best suggests the irony of the late Thorstein Veblen.

FAIR LAWN, N. J., Aug. 28 -- Merchants here and in a score of other communities in northern New Jersey are facing the Hamlet-like question: To open or not to open on Sunday. The issue affects roadside businesses and commercial amusements.

DURING the past nine years the delivery of new airliners over the Atlantic has been limited to flights made from the west to the east. However, beginning next year the airlines' ferry pilots will be engaged in two-way operations between this country and Europe.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Robert T. Moore, a business partner of Robert C. Greenlease, whose son was kidnapped and slain eleven months ago, died today of shotgun wounds the police said were self-inflicted.

IN his introduction to these tales of adventure and exploration, Charles Neider states that his anthology is unique. This is a large claim, and it is a pleasure to report that Mr. Neider has filled it to the letter. For once the publisher's dream of pleasing most everybody seems to have been realized.

OTTAWA, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- During August and September, the most extensive northern sea-supply operation ever attempted by Canada is delivering over 4,000 tons of special equipment and supplies to five joint United States-Canadian Arctic weather stations in the Queen Elizabeth Islands.

The isolation of a protein material called properdin, reported in the journal Science by researchers of Western Reserve University, opens up fascinating new vistas in medical science. Properdin, according to the report, is believed to play a major role in the natural resistance to disease which all animals enjoy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- Factory employment, payrolls and working time declined 1 per cent in Pennsylvania from mid-June to mid-July, says the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank. Vacation shutdowns were chiefly responsible.

MIAMI, Aug. 28 -- The United States' chief delegate to the United Nations told the national convention of the American Veterans of World War II and the Korean war today that he did not believe that the Chinese Communists could take Formosa.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 28 -- An "electrical esperanto" is being developed by the world's electrical engineers, a retired Yale professor said today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- President Cafe is being forced to a serious test of strength with organized labor in his first days of office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Persons who may be called at the hearing on misconduct charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were questioned in secret today.

DENVER, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Following is the statement issued by President Eisenhower as he signed the bill:

The Assembly's vote on this question sustained the Premier, 451 to 122, and the size of this margin is impressive.
Brazil permitted the dollar price of coffee to fall to avert a threatened internal economic crisis, but the move had the reverse affect on some other coffee-producing countries in this hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The State Department has started a big reorganization of the nation's diplomatic corps to strengthen Secretary John Foster Dulles' foreign policy direction.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug 28 (AP) -- The biggest shotgun barrage in the Grand American trapshoot's fifty-five-year history ended today.

Retailers were disappointed at this week's performance by department stores. In the same week last year the weather was hot and business dipped sharply. Last week's weather was warm enough to have the same effect on business, in the opinion of merchants.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- After more than two years of delay, the French National Assembly now is confronted with the greatest single issue it has faced since the war -- the long-pending and passionately disputed European Defense Community treaty.

TRENTON, Aug. 28 -- Former Gov. Walter E. Edge predicted today the election of Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey. The 81-year-old political veteran announced that he would take an active part in the campaign.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 -- Young hoodlums in Mexican- American gangs here deride the idea that there is any "Pachuco blood brotherhood" in the nation.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Ferman Hanover won the mile and one-sixteenth Massachusetts Pace in 2:11 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

TWO of the most prominent bridge players have names that are pronounced the same, and out-of-towners have been getting them mixed up for at least twenty years. The names are spelled differently -- one is Fry and the other is Frey -- but bridge players are not necessarily good spellers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 28 -- More evidence of a fall upturn in retail business was manifest in this district last week. Encouraged by the initial response to promotions of fall wearing apparel, store executives indicated they would revise upward their budgets for later requirements for the season.

Television is preparing for a new season. The hubbub of activity suggests greater variety, opulence and imagination in TV fare than the American family -- sitting in its parlor with eyes fixed on the screen -- has ever before been offered by this medium. Some $300,000 may be spent on each of several dozen "spectaculars" -- large-scale musicals built around such personalities as Betty Hutton, Frank Sinatra, Ethel Merman, Betty Grable and Harry James.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- Andre Francois-Poncet French High Commissioner in Germany, returned today from Paris where he had conferred with Premier Pierre Mendes-France.

PORTSMOUTH, R. I. -- Vacationists who like to get away from it all, without getting too far away, have only to travel to the nation's most densely populated state and take passage out to Prudence Island.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 28 -- (Reuters) -- British ships are steaming into Shanghai harbor at the rate of one a day along with a fleet of other European vessels, Communist Chinese authorities said today.
In an attack on excessive "glamorizing of crime," Magistrate Anthony J. Maglio dealt firmly yesterday with several defendants in Brooklyn Week-End Court.

A seminar on world politics to discuss "The Impact of the New Germany'' is being held this week and through Sept. 4 at Harcum Junior College, Bryn Mawr, Pa. It has brought together sixty political and educational leaders from the United States and Europe under the sponsorship of the Foreign Policy Association, the American Foundation for Political Education and the Junto Adult School of Philadelphia.

LINCOLN, Ill., Aug. 28 -- Lincoln College, the first named for Abraham Lincoln and the only one so named during his lifetime, is seeking $100,000 for rehabilitation of its buildings and to add a dormitory.
Another important predicted log cruiser race has been inserted into a busy season that has seen the family cruisers steal the show.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Splash, the red-hulled Lightning jointly owned by Sis Hibberd and Jon Butler from the American Yacht Club took class honors in the Yacht Racing Association regatta conducted by the Beach Point Yacht Club today on Long Island Sound.

WITH the possible exception of John Wilkes Booth and one or two others, Billy the Kid is the liveliest legend in this country. He lays in the shade such notables as Wild Bill Hickok, Black Jack Ketchum and Jessie James. John Chisum, the most dashing of old-time cow kings, is remembered mainly for his partnership with Billy.

A few fronds in the sumac clumps show red, the goldenrod comes to bloom, the field asters lightly frost the fence rows, and the elms, the ash and many of the maple trees begin to look tired. Bittersweet and basswood berries hang fat and plump, ready for color. Elderberries are ripe.
The decision of the Watkins committee to exclude radio and television broadcasts from the McCarthy inquiry has, naturally, evoked strenuous protests from the broadcasting industry.

SINCE August seems to be the gladiolus show month throughout the country, it might be a good plan to take inventory now and see how some of the varieties fared. Many of the old stand-by gladiolus have had their merits unchallenged and won time and time again.
FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 28 -- Jules Bischoff and Bennett Mazur, Linwood Park tenants and New Jersey Democratic leaders, issued a statement tonight praising the Government's announcement.

THAT old saying about fullbacks -- the bigger they are, the harder they fall -- is one the producer of movies can profitably ruminate. Size is a tangible advantage in the usual well-knit dramatic film, but it can also create a bad unbalance when the story is puny or weak.
It is unfortunate that the recent death of Emilie Dionne has added further misunderstanding to the already much misunderstood problem of epilepsy.
The underwriting community is husbanding its resources to cope with one of the heaviest demands to be made on the new capital market this year.

YONKERS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Rebel Land, a black son of Scotland owned by Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Dias of Rehoboth, Mass., captured the featured $5,000 York-town Pace before 23,927 fans on the final program of Yonkers Raceway's two-week summer meeting tonight.

I have just read the article by C. B. Palmer, "A Farmer Looks at Farming '54" (Aug. 1). In spite of some inaccuracies, it does serve to show the narrow, parochial view some farmers take of their po sition.

" THE Klondike gold rush was in many ways the most fascinating, as well as the last outburst of the mass spirit of adventure on the American continent," writes Richard O'Connor in a book which tells not so much about the men who voyaged North to find dust and nuggets as it does about the parasites who lived off their toil in the icy creeks.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the French people tonight by radio that he would not resign, although he had been advised to do so.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France won the approval of his opponents tonight for a new negotiation on the European Defense Community treaty on the terms he desired.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Masonic ceremonies celebrating the 175th anniversary of Gen. John Sullivan's campaign against the Six Nations of Indians in 1779 reached their climax here today with afternoon and evening programs.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Aug. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton closed his thirty-seven-year military career today when he took his last garrison review as commanding general of this Signal Corps post.

ONE of my favorite contributors to this section of The Times is Ivor Brown of The London Observer. On several occasions I have belabored you with my admiration for his word anthologies, but Mr. Brown's literary usefulness by no means ends with his scholarly yet human approach to words and the uses to which they may be put.

THIS is a gripping novel of the conflict between the white and Negro races. In some cases the white writer who tries this topic falls over backward to be condescending to the minority. William A. Owens, a native Texan who teaches writing at Columbia University, does not make this mistake.

THE flying eagle design of the new 4c blue airmail stamp, which will be issued at Philadelphia on Friday in connection with the American Air Mail Society convention, is a modification of an original drawing by Edward R. Grove of Drexel Hill, a suburb of Philadelphia.

THE solid Broadway success of the George S. Kaufman-Howard Teichmann comedy "The Solid Gold Cadillac" is not being ignored by the West Coast film makers, it was revealed last week by one of the co-authors of the Josephine Hull vehicle. According to Mr. Teichmann, a succession of telephone calls to the office of producer Max Gordon finds two acquisition contenders leading.

It's difficult to believe that the same network (N. B. C.) that's doing such a terrific pioneering job in children's TV programming ("Ding Dong School" and the new Charity Bailey show, "Sing-a-Song") also puts up with the hysterical ravings and rantings of a "Howdy Doody" program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- There are two main theories here about how to elect Congressional candidates. The prevailing attitude among the professional politicians is that House and Senate races turn more on individual candidates than they do on national party affiliations, and that local conditions and issues have a greater bearing than do national problems.

SENATOR JOSEPH R. McCARTHY is once again the principal figure in a Senatorial inquiry; and, with perfect if accidental timing, there now appears a new study and analysis of McCarthy's work. Sponsored by the vigorously anti-Communist American Committee for Cultural Freedom, it is a valuable contribution to the growing literature on the junior Senator from Wisconsin.

Pravda has served notice that the Soviet Government intends to participate in the industrialization of non-Communist underdeveloped countries by sending Russian and other Communist technicians to those countries. A part of the move would be through the United Nations technical assistance program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Stan, an English-bred racer, scored his second major grass stakes victory of the season today. Stan passed the Brookmeade Stable's County Clare in the stretch to win the $55,900 Meadowland Handicap at Washington Park.

Mr. Hadas comments: "Once it is granted that these (the Gospels) may be subjected to the objective scrutiny appropriate to secular texts," etc. Is this reviewer really a scholar at Columbia? For whatever one may say of the book, the last thing about it is novelty.

TWO years ago Canadian author Ethel Wilson created a modest literary stir with "Lilly's Story," an affecting saga of a middle-aged woman's struggle for happiness and respectability. Now in "Swamp Angel" Mrs. Wilson examines the life and hard times of middle-aged, unhappy Maggie Vardoe, who is enough like Lilly to be her sister.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- The wise weather men are not able to affirm that there is anything definitely queer about the way the elements are behaving this year. But they concede the weather has been particularly bad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, attacked today the postponement of a scheduled hearing on the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Patrolman Henry Luty stopped a 1940 Plymouth sedan last night in one of the city streets because of the noise its Passengers were making.
DALLAS, Sunday, Aug. 29--In a major triumph for Texas' conservative "states' rights" Democrats, Gov. Allan Shivers last night won nomination for a third term by a margin of nearly 100,000 votes.

Recent reports of intensive Soviet work on bilingual dictionaries, linking Russian with languages as different as Urdu and Swahili, suggest that a vast field has been opened for Soviet propagandists. The Soviet brand of Russian has long since moved toward becoming an Orwellian kind of "Newspeak" in which the very meanings of words, as defined officially, are based upon ideological presuppositions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Eugenio Gudin, Minister of Finance, said today that the new Government of President Joao Cafe Filho would encourage investment of foreign capital here. He declared the regime also would make all possible efforts to relax official controls on finance and trade.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, who has been conducting an investigation of huge profits on Government-insured housing projects, defended the Federal Housing Administration and the building industry here today.

WHITE PLAINS -- Westchester County is facing the most perplexing park problem that has arisen since its system of seventeen pools, beaches, golf courses and picnic areas began to take shape thirty-two years ago.

Retailers have been coming into the New York market looking not only for regular fall merchandise but for goods for special events, according to resident buying offices. August fur sales were generally good. Merchants are encouraged by the response to fall openings and mail reorders have been fairly heavy.
The big advertising agencies appear to have won their battle with Broadway.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- Elmer (Trigger) Burke, 37-year-old New York gunman, escaped from the Suffolk County Jail on Charles Street this afternoon with the aid of two accomplices.
DENVER, Aug. 28 -- The farm price support bill, product of a long, dramatic political fight, became law today.
DENVER Aug. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by President Eisenhower with his signing of the farm bill today:
LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Bright sunshine brought out the crowds today for the second week of the British soccer season.
THE late Frances Alda, a witty prima donna, divided humanity into three categories: men, women and tenors.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Sam Mele's single in the eleventh inning scored Ted Lepcio with the winning run today as the Boston Red Sex defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, at Fenway Park.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 28 -- A three-point program aimed at improving Nassau County medical services was announced today by Dr. Stuart T. Porter of Floral Park, the new president of the County Medical Society.

THE seventh annual American Dance Festival, sponsored by Connecticut College in New London, had two major premieres on its recent schedule together with several minor ones, but it was not primarily as a creative event that it excelled this year.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: It is too late to fertilize again this year rose bushes, evergreen and deciduous shrubs. Feeding stimulates new, tender growth that is likely to winterkill. Do feed early-flowering perennials such as peonies and boost tomato and chrysanthemum production by an application of balanced fertilizer.

A forty-two-year business career -- thirty-four years with United States Lines -- will end this week with the retirement of Dalven L. Donohoo, the company's general cashier. A hundred of his friends and fellow employes gave a testimonial dinner for him last Wednesday at Miller's Restaurant, 144 Fulton Street.

THE English folk tale of the malicious imp with a secret name is the basis of this fantasy about a country girl who became the Queen of Norfolk. Pretty, lazy Doll Codling was chosen as King Nollekens' bride because she was (mistakenly) thought to be the best spinster in all the countryside.
Nature has a lesson about color transmission which television color engineers have only recently learned, according to a new study by a University of California scientist.

IN a preface to his "Collected Plays," Terence Rattigan, one of Britain's leading playwrights, says that he does not think that the theatre is the proper place to express ideas. Since his plays fill two stout volumes (British Book Centre, Inc.) he improves a golden opportunity by writing two prefaces.
VIENNA, Aug. 28 -- Senator Marius Moutet of France today asked the Interparliamentary Union to call on the great powers to make good their promise to free Austria.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Greenland's polar climate has moderated so consistntly that communities of hunters have evolved into fishing villages. Sea mammals, vanishing from the west coast, have been replaced by codfish and other fish species in the area's southern waters.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- The B. F. Goodrich Company and the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., reached an agreement today on a wage increase averaging 6 1/2 cents an hour for 15,000 employes in nine cities.

THE record of the Eighty-third Congress will be placed under microscopic scrutiny in search of political forred for the coming campaign. The searchers undoubtedly will uncover grist for their mills but they'll find little that will disturb the business man, whatever the man in the street may think.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (UP) -- If there were any lingering doubts that the buyer's market has been re-established in the automobile field, the re-establishment of f. o. b. stores in Detroit has dispelled it.
