WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Communities with right-wing tendencies often wonder whether they can bar groups with left-wing reputations from meeting in public school buildings. In a test case that arose in Westchester County the question is to be answered by the United States Supreme Court.

A HANDSOMELY representative exhibition of paintings by Yves Tanguy, and by his wife, Kay Sage, is now being held at the Wadsworth Atheneum at Hartford. An associate of the Surrealists during their fruitful years a generation ago, and one of the few painters listed on their official roster of artists, Tanguy must be the most authentic Surrealist in these parts, having long since exchanged the ferment of Paris cafe battlegrounds for the placidity of Connecticut.

THE "Open House Days" in New England have been enjoying another success this summer. They've become quite a thing. A dozen or so antique homes in a community are readied for visitors and the susceptible out-of-stater comes in his convertible to buy a ticket and absorb culture.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- James E. Fitzsimmons of 1174 Sheepshead Bay Road, Brooklyn 35, N. Y., headed for home tonight as happy as a horseplayer who had just bet on eight straight winners.

ST. PETERSBURG -- Along the west coast of Florida the formal dedication on Labor Day of the twelvemile Sunshine Skyway across Tampa Bay is thought of as an event of national significance. For years to come, it is assumed, the sweeping chain of causeways and bridges will be as much the mark of the west coast as skyscrapers are of New York City.

The Giants lost to the Milwaukee Braves, 5 to 2, yesterday. Their lead over the second-place Dodgers, as a result, was cut to two and a half games, for Brooklyn defeated the St. Louis Cardinals by 7 -- 3. The Yankees toppled the Detroit Tigers, 4 to 2. They remained three and a half games behind the leading Cleveland Indians, who trounced the Washington Senators, 5 -- 2.

DENVER, Aug. 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's vacation headquarters announced today the United States was shipping 25,000 tons of feed corn -- valued at about $1,900,000 -- to Danube River flood areas in Austria.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 -- Whatever else may be going on in this pop-eyed baseball campaign, no one can yet say the "Braves is dead."

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- British observers of China believe that that enormous country is passing through one of the quieter passages of its Communist transformation, but a passage of critical importance none the less.

ABOUT twenty miles outside of Washington and around the outskirts of New York and other cities, nests for "birds" are being built throughout the heat of summer. The "nests" are bases for guided missiles; the "birds" are slender supersonic Nike anti-aircraft rockets, designed to seek out and destroy with uncanny accuracy enemy bombers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The government reported today that 38,000,000 young Americans would enroll in the nation's schools and colleges this fall -- and would run into a shortage of 370,000 classrooms.

Wall Street traders are uncrossing their fingers and breathing with no more than their usual heaviness, for they have found the new tax law has not materially narrowed the old tax loopholes for stock market operations.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- One of Moscow's favorite fragrances, a perfume known as Svetlana's Breath," is back on sale again after an absence of many months.

WITH a new school season just ahead, educators are again raising the question: Should the study of the theory and practice of communism be a part of the curriculum? The American Citizenship Committee of the American Bar Association, after a year of examining the question, recommended that it should.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 28 (AP) -- About 250 persons have been locked up in attempt by Premier Fazlollah Zahedi to smash an anti-Government network in the Army and the police, informed sources said today.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 28 (UP) -- Mr. Stevenson supported Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, today in his "scandal" charges against the proposed Dixon-Yates power contract.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday that if he were nominated for Governor he would be glad to engage in face-to-face debate with the Republican candidate in the best Lincoln-Douglas tradition.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Nassau County's two "rebel" Republican candidates lost today the second round in their fight to get on the Sept. 14 primary ballots. They said they would appeal to the Appellate Division on Monday.
A New York Times correspondent at President Eisenhower's vacation headquarters in Denver last week wired this description of the political tempo there:

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Mrs. Ala Story, director of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art, has returned from New York with seventy works of art which will provide a stimulating autumn program for this city's midtown museum.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A pilot program to increase the number of elementary school teachers was announced today by the University of Chicago's Department of Education.

THERE is a certain kind of novel reaching us from the British Isles that, though admittedly light reading, is still as pleasant to take as gin and tonic. Elizabeth Cadell is one of the English authors who has been delighting readers on both sides of the Atlantic for some time.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 28 -- The World Council of Churches gave a clean bill of health here today to the "responsible" free enterprise system.

I was much interested in the letter published on your editorial page recently from Howard A. Meyerhoff on the mistake we are making by drafting our potential scientific manpower out of college before training is complete. Since I am in wholehearted agreement with the opinions expressed by Mr. Meyerhoff on that subject, I was disappointed in his conclusion.

The French Line made a surprise announcement last week that a subsidiary had launched the first of two 2,800 gross-ton freighters for specific service from the Continent to the Great Lakes, via the St. Lawrence River.
The Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital, East Forty-ninth Street and Rutland Road, Brooklyn, will celebrate its thirtieth anniversary in September by starting a $3,000,000 fund-raising campaign.

The coffee-drinking habit, because caffeine raises the blood pressure, can reasonably be classified with the other drug habts--addlction to opiates, alcohol, barbitm'ates and nicotine-according to an' editorial in the New, England Journal of Medicine. Similarly, an addiction to "cola" drinks, where the kick also comes from caffeine, should probably be classified as drug addiction, the journal maintains.

IT'S dahlia showtime across the nation and blooms anywhere from two to fourteen inches in width will be on parade, whether the affair be a large or small one. Growers with visions of blue ribbons in their eyes will choose the finest of their tended blooms as the hopeful entries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- San Francisco's repute as a gateway to sunken treasures, seldom for behind that of the Cocos Islands and piratical hideaways of the Carribean, is being re-freshened up again as A. P. (Sandy) Settle of Oakland and John True of Sausalito, professional deep sea divers, prepare to look for the City of Chester.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that the Republicans were heading into the mid-term campaign with a feeling of "practical optimism."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Democrats are a problem for resident Washington philosophers who are supposed to come up at least once a week with neat pear-shaped thoughts on the precise trend of events.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 -- Another World, Walter J. Appel's 3-year-old chestnut filly, who showed she was partial to running on grass earlier this week in an allowance test, emphasized that fact today by accounting for the most important victory of her career.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 28 -- A Hindu minority member of the Constituent Assembly found wide public support among Moslems today when he declared that the Government was "not aware of the magnitude" of the flood problem in East Pakistan.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Russia's famous collection of modern Western art, including some of the world's finest Picassos, Matisses and Cezannes, has been reopened to the general Soviet public.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 28 -- Lajos Szentgali, a 22-year-old lieutenant in the Budapest fire brigade, ran the fastest 800 meters since 1939 today and helped Hungary blunt the Russian surge in the European track and field games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said that this country now had a "workable" agricultural law.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Charles W. Penchard switched from his csutomary highball to a cocktail today to celebrate his 100th birthday anniversary.

EPITAPHS seem to have gone out of fashion in modern, streamlined cemeteries, beautifully landscaped and groomed as they are. To find stories and sermons on stone, one must explore old burial grounds, brushing aside the weeds from hoary monuments draped with moss and lichen.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Tank corps veterans of both World Wars dedicated today a living memorial to the 1917-18 commander of their training ground here -- the man who today is President Eisenhower.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs turned three walks, two singles and an error into four runs in the fourth inning today and went on to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5 to 2, before a Ladies' Day crowd of 14,572.

ONLY a barely perceptible fraction of our large hunting population will take advantage of the first opportunity to hunt this season, for the rail season comes and goes with the majority of hunters unaware of its passage.

RENE HARDY, author of "The Sword of God," was a hero of the French Underground and a wartime Resistance organizer. Twice he was captured by the Germans, but at war's end he was imprisoned by his own countrymen to face Communist-inspired charges of treason.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- An outdoor gathering of Roman Catholics from the Archdiocese of Chicago to celebrate the Feast of the Nativity of Mary will be held on Sept. 8 in Soldier Field. The Marian Year tribute is expected to attract 150,000 persons to the lakefront amphitheatre.

GEORGETTE HEYER has written another of her waggishly frolicsome, pertly paced historical novels sure to please her fans. The background is the rugged English Derbyshire country and the time, shortly after Napoleon's defeat at Waterloo.

A joint commission to study major maritime problems and review the scope of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 will be sought in the next session of Congress by Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland.
About 150,000 Americans visited Spain last year, 4,000 per cent more than went there only seven years ago, the Spanish State Tourist Department reported here yesterday.
DENVER, Aug. 28 -- President Eisenhower approved a temporary six-billion-dollar rise in the Federal debt limit today with some misgiving about its adequacy.

THAT twice in the past year the United States has reversed its program of military preparation marks the dilemma of strategy in our time. In the summer of 1953 the Pentagon was still holding with the principle of balanced force and preparing to cut back a scheduled air-power build-up.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 -- The Cincinnati income tax, or payroll tax ordinance, contains three violations of the Federal Constitution, according to a decision by Judge Louis J. Schneider of Common Pleas Court.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- At the Moscow agricultural exhibition Russians solemnly told a party of British experts that a Hereford bull on display there was a Russian breed. So declared Sir James Watson, chief adviser to the Ministry of Agriculture, on his return here.

HONORS in the race for size among annuals, whose seed was sown in spring, always go to a castor bean plant. By summer's end this plant with bold and handsome foliage is certain to be three to twelve feet tall -- and closer to the latter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- A purified protein derivative, an innocent-appearing cream-colored powder, is potentially one of the deadliest substances known to man. Yet in the skilled, cautious hands of scientists it has in the last few years helped to protect 90,000,000 children against tuberculosis -- a disease that claims a life every seven seconds.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Communist organ Pravada said today Europe would "inevitably" be divided into two armed camps if the European Defense Community plan went into effect.

TRENTON, Aug. 28 -- New Jersey has been described by leaders of both major political parties as a pivotal state in the coming election. An impressive victory by either party might well be the key to the political complexion of the next Congress.

Although there have been in the world many rebellions and civil wars whose anniversaries could be observed by Americans, one uprising deserves especially to be mentioned. It is the Slovak national uprising which started ten years ago, on Aug. 29.
HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 22 -- The partnership of Israel and the United States Operations Mission is producing spectacular advances in basic elements of this nation's economy.

Americans anywhere in the country soon may be able to safe-guard their vital documents and other valuables from atomic blasts or other destructive forces for as little as $10 a year, A. L. Hammell, president of the Railway Express Agency, announced yesterday.

TORONTO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Teddy Toogood's 39-yard dash up the middle and a 35-yard touchdown pass enabled the Toronto Argonauts to beat the Ottawa Roughriders, 13 -- 6, today in the first Big Four Interprovincial Football Union game ever televised to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Panama Canal Company reports that ocean-going commercial shipping is showing a healthy increase.

On an October day in 1930, a Brazilian from the pampas named Getulio Vargas rode into Rio de Janeiro at the head of a gaucho army and seized control of a country larger in area than the United States, with a population of 55,000,000 and vast, undeveloped riches.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 28 -- With Gov. Howard Pyle unpopposed for the Republican nomination for a third two-year term, Arizona today looked toward the primary Sept. 7 to see who would be his Democratic opponent.

Home television sets utilizing tiny transistors, about the size of pencil erasers, instead of a large array of vacuum tubes, are now a stronger possibility as a result of a new development by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

THIS is the light and sprightly story of the transformation of oversensitive, diffident Greg Seaver, who can't face up to people, into a likable, resourceful fellow able to make his way, apparently, in any company.
WAYNESBORO, Va., Aug. 28 (UP) -- Mr. Benson expressed confidence today that his farm program would be "good politics" in the coming congressional campaigns.

WITH traffic complexities steadily increasing, there is a heavy upswing in attendance at professional driver - training schools. In addition to beginners, the students include licensed motorists who seek to keep abreast of highway procedures by taking refresher courses.

SIDE by side with the literary giants every age produces there is a smaller breed of bookmen whose names and fame, well known to their contemporaries, are generally interred with their bones. Writers such as these keep literature a living reality day by day, even though they produce nothing for the ages.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- A former prisoner-of-war of the Chinese Communists told the United States District Court today that the Army was illegally keeping him in service on charges of having collaborated with the enemy.

One naturally thinks of the fading summer season as a period of relaxation. The holidays may be drawing to their close, but there are still a few idle days to be enjoyed, a few more deep breaths to be drawn. This is not true, however, in the world of public affairs. We are in a period of singular tension, however much it may be disguised by summer languor.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- South Korean Premier Y. T. Pyun accused Britain today of "defeatism" toward the Communists.

L. C. Irvine sells insurance all over the world. He travels almost 100,000 miles a year, generally by air, and visits such odd-sounding places as Bulawayo, Southern Rhodesia, and Chittagong, Pakistan. He presents some stiff competition to the famous Lloyd's of London.

WHEN Dick Wishart's family moved to Plymouth. England, in 1699, the boy was thrilled at the prospect of life in a busy, adventurous sea port. The Wisharts made friends with an amiable and mildly eccentric inventor named Wistanley who had also just moved to the town with the avowed purpose of erecting a lighthouse on the rocks outside the harbor.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 28 -- The Army's third court-martial of a former Korea prisoner accused of collaborating with his Communist captors will start Monday at Fort Sam Houston here.

THE sixty-third annual convention and trade show of the Photographers' Association of America, which starts tomorrow at the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago for a five-day run, will have a free evening for the public Tuesday night for the first time in the association's history.

Marvin E. Fowler of Washington, D. C., was installed last night as Grand Master of the Provincial Grand Lodge of the Masonic Order in the United States at a special session of the order at the Astor Hotel. The installing officer was the Earl of Elgin and Kincardine, Deputy Grand Master and Governor of the Masonic Order of Scotland.

Those of us professionally engaged in educational work in world affairs and American foreign policy were deeply pleased and gratified to read Senator Kennedy's excellent article "Foreign Policy Is the People's Business" (Aug. 8).
A forty-one-year sea career that started "about as junior as anyone could possibly get" has ended for George B. Davidson, chief engineer of the Cunarder Queen Elizabeth.

Officials of the Chautauqua Institution estimate there was hardly a day during the summer that there were less than 12,000 people on the grounds of the institution at Chautauqua, N. Y. These people came for the varied activities offered there, and many of those activities were musical.
SEOUL, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The United States Second Division, one of four being pulled out of Korea staged a massive farewell parade near the west central front today.

The social contacts of Rose O'Neal Greenhow were all translatable, sooner or later, into political manipulation. Her collection of acquaintances was varied and choice: some were unquestioning servitors, some were to be used only when directed, and at least one -- William H. Seward -- was pliable mostly when drunk.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- Pope Pius has approved the Mission de France, a body of French priests engaged in propagating religion among French rural populations. At the same time he established a new prelature nullius to be at their head.

France last week was in the throes of decision on the centerpiece of Western plans for organizing European security. Yesterday afternoon, for the first time since it was signed twenty-seven months ago, the French Assembly began discussion of the European Defense Community (E. D. C.) treaty.

THERE are times when Dean Whitmore, stage manager for N. B. C.'s "Television Playhouse," thinks yearningly of the blue Pacific Ocean. True, there was a war on when he was there last, but even on a PT boat his life was something less hectic.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 -- The voices of doom heard so loudly throughout the land only a few months ago have been stilled by the vigorous comeback of the Mexican economy.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 28 -- Following is the text of an address by Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Democratic Presidential nominee, to a Democratic conference on farm problems here tonight:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Eisenhower made -- unwittingly, no doubt -- the understatement of the week when he said at his Denver summer headquarters Tuesday that the bill to outlaw the Communist party, which he had just signed, "will require further careful study" before its full impact is known.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 28 -- Paddy Young of New York City, trailing on points at the end of nine rounds, knocked out Joe Taylor of Binghamton tonight at 1:27 of the tenth round in their nationally televised bout at War Memorial Auditorium.

I shake your hand for "How Not To Do-It-Yourself" (Aug. 15) by Eugene Rachlis. I gave up all that doing-it-yourself hokum in early childhood; couldn't make the grade. I confess, though, it left something of a void.

PARAMOUNT, the only major studio not using CinemaScope, formally introduced its own Vista Vision process of making pictures for big-screen presentation with a press preview showing last week of white Christmas."

The suicide of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil on Tuesday and the attendant riots and agitation against North Americans and United States property in various parts of Brazil have suddenly dramatized the fact that there are points and developments of exceptional gravity for us in Latin-American affairs today.

Legally, this year's Democratic candidate for Governor will be chosen by vote of a majority of the 1,018 delegates at the State Convention which opens here Sept. 21. Actually, he will have been picked some time before at a conference of party leaders and top officeholders, and the delegates will do no more than make the selection official.

DENVER, Aug. 28 -- The National Jewish Hospital here announced today that a new combination of drugs could bring under control within two months "the toughest cases of previously untreated pulmonary tuberculosis."

INDIA and Pakistan, who seldom lack topics for argument, now are embroiled in a dispute whose outcome, though scarcely apt to shake the world, is anxiously awaited by a nervous West Pakistan populace. The quarrel is over a vine leaf known as piper betle, the indispensable wrapper for betel nut, or pan chew, a fragrant compound which surpasses the cigarette in both the number and devotion of its Asian users.

ONE of the misfortunes of our time is that the rising generation of politicians is slightly tongue-tied. At precisely the period in history when the free world needs the gift of eloquent expression and when democracy is defied by half the world to redefine its creed, the free world now lacks a political leader who has both the ability and energy to speak and write memorable English.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Chicago area's amazing growth in the half-century since 1904 was highlighted this week in a brochure released by the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry in connection with its golden anniversary observance.

HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 28 -- Dubious about the completeness of the French Union prisoner of war list submitted by the Vietminth, French authorities have asked Ho Chi Minh's regime to supply them with a supplementary prisoner list. They also urged the International Armistice Commission here act on that request.

CHILDREN'S pleasure in acting to rhythms has created a need for appropriate music. Satis Coleman is known for her excellent singing series for young children. Now she has written music without words for children to interpret through action.

FOR a long time the Borgias have been among the hardy perennials of historical literature. Year in, year out, their name keeps on blossoming in bookseller's windows with exemplary regularity. In this biography of Lucrezia, Joan Haslip, author of lives of Lady Hester Stanhope and of Parnell, makes no startling revelations but tells the story in a clear and straightforward way.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Southpaw Jack Harshman gained his thirteenth victory of the season today, but needed help from two relievers as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 5 -- 2, at Connie Mack Stadium.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company announced today plans for the construction of a huge power generating plant here. The initial investment will be about $45,000,000.

CENTEREACH, L. I., Aug. 28 -- This community's Board of Education was assured today that contractors would complete ten one-story frame buildings by next Saturday, four days before the opening of the school term.

GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- If one asks how the world economy is doing, the answer must be that there are at least three sharply contrasted "economies" -- those of the Communist empire, the Western industrial countries and the backward areas -- and that they are undergoing very different types of development, or at any rate, change.
ISLIP, L. I., Aug. 28 -- A series of mysterious brush fires in the Sayville area early this summer may have been solved this week with the capture of three Oakdale boys, 6 to 10 years old.

ROME, Aug. 26 -- Hundreds of experts will meet in Rome next week to discuss population problems. They will study the constant world-wide increase in population and suggest ways in which living standards can be improved for all.
Dr. Fritz Bock, president of the Austrian Expressway Corporation, arrived here yesterday to make a transcontinental tour to study American express highways.

Animals, including man, have an inherent resistance to disease which keeps most creatures pretty healthy most of the time. This resistance is a far more potent factor than are man-made agents for fighting infection. Last week reports from two scientific studies suggested that the mechanics of disease immunity may now be better understood and that resistance to disease may be bolstered when it is low or lacking.

" BAFFLING" is perhaps the key-adjective to describe the critical reception of William Faulkner's new novel, "A Fable." The bouquets outweighed the brickbats by a comfortable margin, yet there is no escaping the fact that even the more enthusiastic critics could not always pinpoint the reason for their enthusiasm.

WEEDS in lawns are as out-of-date as the horse and buggy, thanks to modern chemicals. Today's weedkillers are so simple to use that an interested home owner no longer has to tolerate the rat-tailed seed heads of plantain or the rosettes of dandelions marring an otherwise attractive lawn.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Teen-agers tattooed with the sinister cross of Pachuco turned up in Chicago today. The development spurred new investigations, including One by the Fifth Amy to determine if near-by Fort Sheridan were involved.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The Government announced today a drastic plan to force builders to pay back millions of dollars of windfall profits reaped under Government-insured mortgages.

NEW home owners, however much or little garden they plan, know that a lawn is as essential to the outside of their house as a refrigerator is inside. Some of these new home owners may even think that a good, green turf is as easily ordered as any appliance.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 28 -- The Iowa State Fair, which has provided the background for two novels and two motion pictures, opened for its 100th year today. The live stock and farm products exhibits, the midway and a series of speeches are expected to attract an attendance of 600,000. The fair will run through Sept. 6.

The school crisis facing many suburban communities that have mushroomed since the war is dramatized in Levittown, Long Island, where the shortage of school facilities has reached a state of emergency. In Levittown's case, the problem created by the influx of families to new housing developments has been aggravated by an abnormally high birth rate -- 52 per 1,000 population, or more than double the national average.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- If you like low-slung autos that look like space ships on wheels, take it from James Zeder -- you have not seen anything yet.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Brazilian Labor party, formerly headed by the late President Getulio Vargas, broke with the Government of Senhor Vargas' successor tonight and took up the cry for release of arrested agitators.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Eastern Suffolk's fall harvest sales will get under way on Monday with the opening of the Southold Auction Block on Youngs Avenue, Southold. Such late summer and early fall farm produce as cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, lima beans and cucumbers will be sold daily.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--A determined drive by the American Legion to get Congressional action on Universal Military Training by next year began here today.

There's a $718,000,000 prize at stake in the battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's second largest mail-order and retail enterprise, which had its humble beginning in 1872 in a barn on an Illinois farm.

NEXT week-end brings to a close what used to be the great American summer vacation. For families with school-age youngsters it will still be the end of the season, and resort hotels, inns and lodges throughout the East, anxious to make the most of the long Labor Day holiday, are planning elaborate programs, ranging all the way from special stage shows and costume balls to regattas and sports contests of various kinds.
THIS last week before Labor Day, a mother stands Janus - like -- looking back at a summer too quickly gone and ahead to the challenge of the youngsters' new school year.

PHILADELPHIA -- Convention Hall here, the acoustics of which were improved at a cost of $500,000 back in 1948 for the benefit of orators at the national political conventions, will soon resound with the voices of some 10,000 devotees of Welsh singing, and perhaps another 3,000 curious visitors who will be welcome to join in.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The National Catholic Welfare Conference called today for a revolutionary experiment in "moral" labor-management relations to show the world that the United States economy could meet spiritual as well as Materialistic goals.
TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Aug. 22 -- Portraits of the deposed Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, are now, by order, displayed prominently in public places.
Mortimer May, president of the Zionist Organization of America, said last night that the State Department's proposed policy of arming the Arab states would not thwart the advance of communism.

Leonard W. Barden, Southern Counties Chess Union champion, and A. Phillips, both of London, finished in a tie for first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the British Chess Federation, concluded yeterday at Nottingham, according to a news report received from England.

As the summer is nearing its end, news releases from the nation's orchestras are piling up. Dates, guest conductors, soloists and items of repertory, on the whole, have a familiar look. Perhaps San Francisco, Buffalo and Seattle will be the cities feeling the greatest change.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A historic social step will be taken next month when public schools in five "border" states and the District of Columbia begin mixing Negro and white children in compliance with a Supreme Court decision.
NASHVILLE, TENN., Aug. 28 -- Tennessee Republican leaders are looking for a suitable candidate to run this fall against Senator Estes Kefauver.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson tonight charged the Eisenhower Administration with irresponsibility, bad faith and broken promises to the nation's farmers. The Republicans, he said, had accomplished the "remarkable achievement" of producing, at the same time, the lowest farm prices and the highest cost of living in recent years.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, who longs to be a dancer but has realized he makes better music and more good Yankee dollars with his fists, defends his welterweight title here Wednesday night against the challenge of Johnny Saxton of New York.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Government of Ceylon, determined to provide employment for an increasing population, is welcoming foreign investment without attaching strings.

QUEBEC, Aug. 28--The Supreme Court of Canada will decide ultimately whether the form of worship practiced by Jehovah's Witnesses is a religion and whether the Witnesses constitute a religious denomination.

THERE was a time when a common sight on Fifty-seventh Street was that of young, intent men staggering under the burden of huge portfolios and stacks of canvases. These latter were unmistakable attributes of the "artist-seeking- a - New - York - gallery."

TORONTO, Aug. 28 -- Bud Holscher, a 23-year-old newcomer to the tournament trail from Santa Monica, Calif., rallied today with an 8-under-par 63 to win the $26,500 open golf tournament at the Scarboro Country Club with a 72-hole score of 269.

Programs for junior year and graduate study abroad are listed in "Group Study Abroad 1954-55," published by the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street. The report lists study opportunities for American college students in Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Mexico, Peru, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.

URANIUM, as Gordon Dean, former chairman of the United State Atomic Energy Commission, once said, "is where you find it." The best uranium, that is to say the richest rock in the world, comes from the four big C's -- Czechoslovakia, the Congo, Colorado and Canada. Nowhere today is it being unearthed more richly than around this mosquito-ridden shack town on the northeastern shores of Lake Athabaska in Saskatchewan, Canada, called simply Uranium City.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 -- So far the Dodgers have made a clean sweep in the West. The Brooks made it two straight over the Cardinals, 7 -- 3, at Busch Stadium today for their fourth consecutive triumph. Matters may become a bit more complicated for them in Milwaukee, with four games in three days, but the Brooklyn spirit is better and the confidence high.
A Macy store that will open in the $35,000,000 Bergen County shopping center in the fall of 1956 will be a branch of Macy's New York.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 28 -- The delegation of Pakistanis due here next week with other guests from the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in Nairobi have become temporary "Europeans." They will have all the privileges accorded Europeans, live in proper hotels and go where they please.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 28 -- Capt. Barney Griffin, 80 years old, who confesses he "can't swim a stroke" after 60 years in sail and steam, has entered the retired skippers race to be held off Northeast Harbor Sept. 11.

THE news that Sir Laurence Olivier is going to make the battle scenes of his 'Richard III" in the country outside Madrid produced some of those tolerant smiles which even quite kindly people reserve for the seeming foibles of film makers.

IN the days before movable types, people got much of their news from minstrels, who gave lyrical coverage to upheavals in governments and the deeds of heroes. To judge from records of the United States Copyright Office, song writers still have one hand on the keyboard and the other on the newspaper.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Tony Trabert, the United States tennis champion from Cincinnati, today won the Nassau Bowl invitation men's singles tournament for the second straight year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Top State Department officials are watching the European Defense Community debate in the French Parliament like pallbearers at the grave of an old friend. They are convinced they are watching an unnecessary tragedy, but they feel that, under the circumstances, the least they can do is to remain quiet during the ceremonies.

ACCORDING to the programs as announced, and being carried through as this article was sent to press, the ninth Music Festival at Brevard, N. C., came to an end today in the open-air concert hall of the Transylvania Music Camp.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- Arnold Palmer of Cleveland, a 24-year-old player who virtually grew up on a links, became the United States amateur golf champion today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Cleveland Indians rallied with three runs in the eighth inning and added another in the ninth to defeat the Washington Senators, 5 -- 2, today. The victory kept the Tribe 3 1/2 games ahead of the New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The "Grade 14" bureaucrat whose office rug is wearing out can't get a new one unless he's promoted to Grade 15. So the rug problem has become a "most difficult thing to manage," an Agriculture Department property supply official said today.

COURSES in advertising photography have been so popular at the Hunter College School of General Studies that Stella Pandell, who began with one course, is now giving three in basic airbrush work for beginners, an advanced course and a complete course in advertising art and reproduction.

A REASONABLY representative summation of the lengthy career of Duke Ellington, from his Cotton Club days in the Twenties to the present, is provided by four recent, separately issued twelve-inch LP's.
WASHINGTON Aug. 28 -- The Washington home of the late President Woodrow Wilson will be preserved as a memorial.

HARTFORD, Aug. 28 -- Gov. John Lodge has named a committee of nine members to explore every means possible, to keep a branch factory of the American Woolen Company from moving out of the city of Norwich in eastern Connecticut.

The seventy-third national amateur singles championships started quietly at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, with most of the ranking contenders deferring their appearances until today.

Representative Carl Hinshaw performed an important service in his speech before the American Legion in Washington last Friday. He directed attention to the dangerous shortage of scientific and technical manpower in this country and to the need for taking steps to remedy that situation quickly.

I WAS shocked by John W. Aldridge's review of Charles A. Fenton's "The Apprenticeship of Ernest Hemingway." * * * What I object to is the basic assumption of Mr. Aldridge that scholarship is dangerous and secondly that Mr. Aldridge should review a book that falls into that category.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The United States Information Agency is facing its greatest challenge since it was placed under new management as an independent agency a year ago.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Rocky Marciano was relaxing on a red leather deckchair in front of his cottage on the edge of the mountain-top airport, a man utterly at peace with the world. He's a peaceful guy, too. Of course, he does occasionally engage in violence and blood-letting, but that is merely a by-product of his business transactions.

A COLLECTION of sidelights on the writers of Greece and Rome, this modestly titled volume is divided into two parts. The first, and for general readers the most valuable, is concerned with the book trade -- the production and distribution of books.

ALTHOUGH, while I was still at Oxford I often heard talk of T. E. Lawrence from his close friend Robert Graves, I was privileged only once to set eyes on that extraordinary man. The occasion may be worth recalling. It took place at a London gallery which contained paintings and drawings by Augustus John, among them several studies of Lawrence in his Arab headdress.

Apropos the debate which is raging in the capitals of the world about SEATO (the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization) may I place before your readers a proposal I have put up to my friends of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee for a basic economic program for the vast peasant population of South and Southeast Asia?
GREENVILLE, Va., Aug 28 (AP) -- Mr. Benson said today the supply outlook indicated that prices of cotton, corn, rice and peanuts would be supported at or near 90 per cent of parity next year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- There is no reliable scientific formula for deciding just which adult criminals should be granted probation, but the relatively new theory of probation has become a recognized remedial method.

The stock market ran out of steam last week, forfeiting more than all the gains made earlier in the month. Prices were under pressure during the entire period, with many of the so-called "blue chips" losing ground. After a steady run-up for seven months, it was only natural that profit-taking should grow.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 28 -- Herman T. Stichman, state housing commissioner, charged tonight that "scores of thousands" throughout the nation and particularly in New York would pay higher rents on their homes in the future because of laxity on the part of the Democratic national Administration between 1946 and 1952.
PROBLEMS are where you find them, and for a producer working in the new field of color television, they may turn up anywhere.
TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- A Japanese diplomat committed suicide today after he had confessed to giving secret information to a Soviet spy ring.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 28 -- An effort to raise $75,000 to preserve for research sixty-five acres of virgin forest outside this city is lagging, Dr. William H. Cole, Rutgers University scientist, said today.
After studying the picture story "Drought in the Midwest," (Aug. 15) I conclude that something is askew. The caption under the two tanks of water said the tanks held 12,000 gallons of water.

The Yankees cleared the decks for their forthcoming contests with the White Sox and Indians by polishing off the Tigers, 4 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday. It took the Bombers only 1 hour 52 minutes to bag their fifth straight victory of this final 1954 home stand against Western opposition.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Puerto Rico has just marked its sixth straight year of increases in tourist traffic, and the Commonwealth Government is making plans to turn 'this Caribbean island into a major year-round vacation center.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 26 -- To compete with the helicopter passenger services from Brussels to Rotterdam; Cologne and Lille, main line railroad times to and from Brussels have been cut by between twenty-five and forty minutes.

THE novels of Nicholas Blake (criminous pseudonym of the British poet C. Day Lewis) have been among the purest of strict detective puzzles, with one memorable exception: the vivid and free-wheeling spy-romance-adventure, "The Smiler with the Knife" (1939).

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 28 -- Settlement of the two-week-long Kennecott strike that has made 11,000 copper workers idle in Utah, Nevada, Arizona and New Mexico was announced this morning by S. Lyle Johnson, Federal mediation commissioner, and officials of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, and the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers.

RAPID CITY, S. D., Aug. 28 -- A giant B-36 bomber crashed into a small hill and burst into flames in a landing attempt at Ellsworth Air Force Base, and the Air Force reported today that twenty-four men had been killed and three injured.
DENVER, Aug. 28 -- During his vacations in this area, President Eisenhower conducts the nation's business from a second-floor office here that is probably smaller than your doctor's waiting room.
GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- Getting back to work after summer vacations, Western Europe finds itself in the best financial position it has known for a decade.

The never-ending underground war between the intelligence services of the Soviet Union and of the free world has come into public view with unusual frequency this year. Only in the past few weeks, the Communists have made much propaganda capital of the defection of West Germany's former counterintelligence chief, Otto John, and the West German legislator, Karl F. Schmidt-Wittmack.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 28 -- President Eisenhower has signed a private bill enabling Dr. Liang Nun Wang, resident physician at Shore Memorial Hospital, Somers Point, to become a United States citizen.

THE conditions under which one reads a book are sometimes a good measure of its dramatic value. I read "Respectable Women" when my home town of Omaha, Neb., cooked in 100-degree-plus heat and yet so interesting was the story that I was able to forget acute physical discomfort.

WHATEVER the quality of television this fall, there is no denying a quantity of new programs. Last fall there was little on the channels that hadn't been encountered before, but during the approaching season TV's old-timers will have to struggle to meet the competitive novelty of newcomers.

ONE day in June the lights dimmed down on an M-G-M sound stage that had been converted into a makeshift theatre, and a single projector was beamed at a wide, deeply curved screen. This was the first "laboratory" showing of Todd-AO -- kept under wraps till now during the two-year period of its development -- behind which is the story of two men of the widest possible divergence.

KNOKKE, Belgium, Aug. 28 -- The International Liberal Council unanimously declared here today that it was essential to organize financial and technical collaboration to raise the living standards of all Asian peoples without curtailing their freedom.

WHEN F. B. I. agents finally caught up with dapper Courtney Townsend Taylor, one of the top men on their list of Most Wanted Criminals, and started to frisk him for concealed weapons, he nonchalantly drew a handsome black fountain pen from his pocket. "This is the only gun I need," he said.

DENVER, Aug. 28 -- President Eisenhower approved today two bills raising compensation payments to veterans and their dependents, but indicated that some of the beneficiaries did not need the increase.

DE PERE, Wis., Aug. 28 -- One national champion continued his reign for another year and two new titleholders gained the spotlight on Fox River today in the country's largest amateur speedboat regatta of the year.

JAPAN appears to be discovering photography as a mass hobby on a scale reminiscent of the resurgence of interest in the camera in the United States in the mid-Thirties, to judge from the report by Bruce Downes in the October issue of Photography Magazine, out Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- The European Defense Community treaty, designed to forge the political and military unity of West Europe, has been transformed into a sharp instrument of rivalry and division because the makers of the treaty overrated man's ability to transcend the fears and hatreds of the past.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Troops hurried today to put down Hindu-Moslem rioting in Hyderabad, adjoining Bombay state. A Bombay police official said the riots followed the hoisting of the Moslem Pakistanis' flag over Hindu temples.

LAWNS everywhere along the Atlantic seaboard have a drab and woebegone appearance; the only exceptions are those in New England and north into eastern Canada. For in that section abundant rainfall has continued since spring and the lawns are as green and verdant as the English countryside.
The experts believe that Iranian oil will not cause any serious price disturbance when it returns to the world markets.
A burglar who broke into a fashionable home in Queens and ransacked it from cellar to attic was found dead of starvation in the living room yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 28 -- Britain and Turkey have agreed to follow the same line in the Cyprus question. The line was determined during recent contacts in Istanbul between the British Ambassador, Sir James Bowker, and Premier Adnan Menderes and Foreign Minister Fuad Koprulu.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said today that the Republican party had embarked on a dual smile-smear campaign. He placed President Eisenhower among those who cheerfully tried to smile away the nation's ills while the McCarthy faction smeared sincere advocates of change or reform.

WHEN F. B. I. agents finally caught up with dapper Courtney Townsend Taylor, one of the top men on their list of Most Wanted Criminals, and started to frisk him for concealed weapons, he nonchalantly drew a handsome black fountain pen from his pocket. "This is the only gun I need," he said.

DENVER, Aug. 28 -- President Eisenhower approved today two bills raising compensation payments to veterans and their dependents, but indicated that some of the beneficiaries did not need the increase.

DE PERE, Wis., Aug. 28 -- One national champion continued his reign for another year and two new titleholders gained the spotlight on Fox River today in the country's largest amateur speedboat regatta of the year.

JAPAN appears to be discovering photography as a mass hobby on a scale reminiscent of the resurgence of interest in the camera in the United States in the mid-Thirties, to judge from the report by Bruce Downes in the October issue of Photography Magazine, out Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- The European Defense Community treaty, designed to forge the political and military unity of West Europe, has been transformed into a sharp instrument of rivalry and division because the makers of the treaty overrated man's ability to transcend the fears and hatreds of the past.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Troops hurried today to put down Hindu-Moslem rioting in Hyderabad, adjoining Bombay state. A Bombay police official said the riots followed the hoisting of the Moslem Pakistanis' flag over Hindu temples.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 -- Production has started at the Ford Motor Company's big new stamping plant in suburban Walton Hills. C. R. McCormick, plant manager, said there are immediate openings for 1,000 skilled men, including diemakers, welder repairmen and layout inspectors.

WHATEVER the quality of television this fall, there is no denying a quantity of new programs. Last fall there was little on the channels that hadn't been encountered before, but during the approaching season TV's old-timers will have to struggle to meet the competitive novelty of newcomers.

ONE day in June the lights dimmed down on an M-G-M sound stage that had been converted into a makeshift theatre, and a single projector was beamed at a wide, deeply curved screen. This was the first "laboratory" showing of Todd-AO -- kept under wraps till now during the two-year period of its development -- behind which is the story of two men of the widest possible divergence.

KNOKKE, Belgium, Aug. 28 -- The International Liberal Council unanimously declared here today that it was essential to organize financial and technical collaboration to raise the living standards of all Asian peoples without curtailing their freedom.
Seven new films, including imports from England, France, Brazil and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
The five-week-old police crusade against undesirables set a record of 715 arrests in Manhattan over the week-end.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Persons who in the recent reaction in the stock markets were expressing confidence that the end of the bull market was not yet in sight had their opinion confirmed much sooner than expected. Having negotiated the fortnightly settlement, the markets in the last few days have taken fresh forward strides on a broad front.

The American petroleum industry has not yet been called upon to produce jet fuel for commercial operations. The demand has been anticipated, however, and the airlines have been assured that, barring large-scale warfare, they will be supplied with all the fuel they may need for turbine-powered aircraft.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Jimmy Davis overcame a three-walk first inning to pitch Chicago to a 4 -- 1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates with a yield of just four singles in the second game of a double-header today after the Cubs had tallied five runs in the eighth to will the opener, 7 -- 4.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Dr. Salvador de Madariaga, Professor of Spanish Studies at Oxford University, will hold a visiting professorship during the fall term at Princeton. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced the appointment today.

DE LAND, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The gradual change of the orange from a dessert fruit to a juice medium has altered the entire citrus industry, and with development of new processes to provide whole, fresh juice, a new competitive factor has developed.

In his interesting report on East-West trade in your issue of Aug. 22, Michael Hoffman says: "It is quite inconceivable that the Soviet Union would continue for any length of time to swap oil for butter or manganese for girls' dresses."

If things turn out as planned, Jennifer Jones will have the distinction of restoring the ANTA Playhouse to the legitimate fold when she makes her Broadway stage debut in "Portrait of a Lady" on Dec. 9.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The day after Joe Louis virtually annihilated Max Schmeling, a friend asked the Dark Destroyer if he'd seen the movies of the sensational bout.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 29 -- Approximately forty Democratic House and Senate candidates today issued an agricultural manifesto blaming the Republicans for a philosophy of "scarcity and disaster."

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The head of the American Federation of Government Employes, A.F.L., said today that President Eisenhower's veto of a proposed 5 per cent pay rise for Federal workers would have the effect of driving competent employes out of the Government.

At a good many thousand summer resorts a good many more thousand Americans now are finding out that there is, after all, a caste system. It is not, of course, that democracy is reserved only for the winter months, and it may be that caste system is too strong an expression for what the thing is.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The starting point of the new hearings opening Tuesday, Senator Arthur V. Watkins said today, probably will be a charge that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has shown "contempt of the Senate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Theodore C. Streibert, director of the United States Information Agency, reported to Congress that the agency today was "better geared than ever before" to support United States objectives overseas.

Israel has four elements of strength that will enable her to meet challenges to her security, it was said yesterday by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, chairman of the national executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America.

DE PERE, Wis., Aug. 29 -- One of outboarding's most determined competitors, 20-year-old Don Baldaccini of Miami, had his moment of glory here this afternoon on Fox River in the national stock championships.
BINGHAMPTON, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Thirty-two competed in the championship class and sixteen in the experts' tournament at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association today.
The Air Force's "week-end warriors" closed their summer encampment at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, yesterday and returned to the civilian life they had left two weeks ago.
A month out of the Army, Sidney Schwartz played the tennis of his life yesterday to win a set from Lewis Hoad of Australia in the national amateur championships.
The job of resurfacing the Manhattan and Queens approaches of the Queensboro Bridge will be started on Wednesday, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday.
Twice as many television stations as in 1953 are offering merchandising or promotional aids to their advertisers this year, according to a survey by Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France put the National Assembly's debate on the European Defense Community treaty into high gear today by a long speech defending his ambiguous position on the issue.

Although television is barred from direct coverage of this week's hearings on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, N.B.C.-TV's "Today" program will present a "preview" of the hearing in Washington tomorrrow morning between 7 and 9 o'clock. Senator Arthur V. Watkins, head of the investigating committee, also will be interviewed on why television has been barred.

British sterling suffered a sharp break last week, selling down to $2.80 3/8, on Friday, lowest since October 13, 1953. The setback was linked to seasonal needs of commercial accounts, particularly the oil companies which made heavy demands upon the dollar market in London. It was hinted that there might have been some requisitions by the oil companies representing their consortium obligations.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- District Attorney Garrett H. Byrne tonight called a special session of the grand jury tomorrow to investigate the escape of Elmer J. (Trigger) Burke, New York gunman, from Suffolk County jail.

Leonard Jerome, Sir Winston Churchill's American grandfather, is the subject of a biography by Anita Leslie, entitled "The Remarkable Mr. Jerome." Scheduled for Sept. 23 publication by Holt, the volume presents a picture of an "era of gaslight and grandeur," of balls and parties at Versailles and the world of Jim Fisk, August Belmont and Commodore Vanderbilt, with whom Jerome matched wits in the financial world.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Mr. Stevenson appeared unexpectedly at a South Dakota Young Democrats' meeting today and told them the backing of their age group was of "enormous value" to the party.
TOKYO, Aug. 29 -- The Japanese were informed today that the Soviet Union was willing to discuss fishery rights in northern waters if the Government of Japan should make the first move.

Sales of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., rose 13.2 per cent to a new high for a first half year. The volume was $144,700,147, compared with the previous peak of $127,804,553, attained in the initial six months of 1953, according to the midyear report, issued for publication today.

GALILEE, R. I., Aug. 29 -- A grizzled seaman of Norwegian extraction today disputed one of the East Coast's most famous legends -- that of Leif Erikson's Rock on tiny No Man's Land, an islet off Martha's Vineyard. He said the inscription on the rock was forty-one years old, not 950 as is recounted.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Change in the climate and predations by humans for economic reasons are threatening several Arctic animals with extinction, it was found by scientists participating in the fourth General Assembly of the International Union for the Protection of Nature.
More coffee price cuts were announced over the week-end and one large food company reported it was coming out with an "instant" brew with an imitation coffee flavor to combat high costs.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The fleet competing in the New York Athletic Club's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta was greeted today with a 15-knot easterly. It sent the sloops off on schedule. In yesterday's regatta, light airs had caused a thirty-minute delay in the start.

A four-point program for encouraging private housing construction and for improving administration of the state's Multiple Residence Law was announced yesterday by Senator MacNeil Mitchell, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The San Francisco Forty-niners registered in every period today as they rolled to a 42-7 triumph over the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League exhibition game before 24,559 fans in Kezar Stadium.

Prices for cotton in this market moved upward last week, registering the broadest net advances in months. At the close, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 6 to 52 points. New life-of-contract highs were made by all active months, from July on.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that while it had reduced its "positive list" of strategic or scarce items forbidden to the Communists by more than 650, it had added about thirty commodities to the list.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Bishop K. F. Otto Dibelius told the World Council of Churches here today that the church must remain "steadfastly independent" of state control.
With the four weeks of horse racing at Saratoga Springs having been completed, the runners return to the metropolitan area today, when Aqueduct will open a twenty-day meeting.

A New Jersey physician, the chief surgeon of a Mexico City hospital for crippled children, and the president of the Central Council for the Care of Cripples in Great Britain were named yesterday as the winners of the first Albert Lasker Awards for outstanding achievement in the development of services for the physically disabled.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Republican campaign strategy to tighten the G. O. P. grip on Congress in November is taking shape today along these lines: "Run scared and convince the farmers they never had it so good."

As vacation tides ebb homeward with September's approach there's always a little time for wondering -- wondering why sun tans fade so soon and if those grains of fine white sand will continue to escape the vacuum cleaner. No matter what one does there's no way to avoid the wondering.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 29 -- It is increasingly clear that the suicide of President Getulio Vargas did not end but intensified the conflict that had brought it about. Brazil probably has a stormy political phase ahead.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Master Sgt. Joseph Benner, Army pistol coach from West Point and an Olympic champion, was high scorer in two free pistol matches today in eliminations to select a team for the international pistol shoots in Caracas, Venezuela.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 29 -- "Just like two peas in a pod," a phrase often glibly applied to twins by doting parents and other adults, might well be given some reconsideration in view of the results of a recent study reported last week at Smith College here.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Milwaukee's baseball fans today set a National League attendance record of 1,841,666 for a single season.

DENVER, Aug. 29 -- The following table shows in summary form the status of major legislation that reached President Eisenhower in the last week, as well as the status at other major bills that were in the legislative channels when Congress adjourned on Aug. 20:

Governor Dewey's administration and the record of the Republican-controlled Congress were "roasted" yesterday, along with frankfurters, clams and chickens, at Democratic picnics in four upstate counties.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 9 -- German shepherd dogs, nightsticks and the sabres and horsewhips of the mounted policemen were used to quell disorders in Stockholm last night. Gangsters and other underworld elements, some on motorcycles, took over control of the downtown streets, challenging the police.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The National Planning Association recommended today sounder credit and better management training to save thousands of new farm families from bankruptcy.

THE report last week that artisans were putting up an all-stained-glass facade at Steinberg House, 50 East Eighty-seventh Street, led some people to wonder where stained-glass workers were to be found in mid-twentieth-century New York.

CRISTOBAL, Canal Zone, Aug. 29 -- An American seaman who confessed under questioning to having jammed a wrench and a connecting-rod into the gears of the steering mechanism of his ship in a successful effort to prevent its sailing has started serving a year's term at hard labor in the Canal Zone penitentiary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will leave for Manila by air Tuesday to bring to a climax five months of effort to form a Southeast Asian alliance.
HANGCHOW, China, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Clement R. Attlee and seven fellow British Labor party leaders arrived today for two days of rest in this beauty spot in Chekiang Province.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 29 -- The green-gray uniform and the jackboot reappeared on the German scene last night at a meeting of leaders of the Stahlhelm, a war veterans' organization.

Dean Sturgis Lee Riddle of the American Pro-Cathedral in Paris, referring to France's hesitancy on a European Defense Community treaty, declared here yesterday morning that "in our world at the moment we are standing on a great Continental Divide."
Persistence in prayer will eventually transform a person's character and teach him what he really wants, the Rev. Dr. Norris L. Tibbetts said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Substantial upturns were registered in September lard prices on the Board of Trade early last week. But on the extreme advances longs started to take profits and it developed that they had lots of help in this respect, selling becoming general with sharp recessions from the week's top levels.
A single-seam skirt, while it can be executed in many versions, is basically simple.
DENVER, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower telephoned his congratulations to Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 -- With a "normal" summer in the steel industry nearing an end, there were signs last week of a pick-up in steel order volume. July and August were, statistically speaking, poor months. August operating rates will probably represent low points for the year.
A specialist on legislative matters, former Senator Joseph H. Ball, has been elected a vice president of States Marine Lines, Henry D. Mercer, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Vladimir Kuc, a little sailor with Russia's Baltic Fleet, beat Emil Zatopek and the fabulous Czech's world record today in the 5,000-meter race, and Britain's Roger Bannister won the 1,500-meter event as the European Games closed with an overwhelming Russian conquest.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The new amateur golf champion of the United States, Arnold Palmer, has no desire to compete for any of the pro game's pot of gold.

For years, since the end of the Second World War, the Army tried to increase its enlistments with promises of good pay, security and the chance to learn a trade. That kind of appeal seemed to be the best one in a country with democratic traditions of freedom and opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- France is being criticized more bitterly here today than at any time since the French surrender to Hitler in 1940, but even France's critics in Washington concede that Britain and the United States must share responsibility for the present crisis in the Western alliance.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- The Boston Red Sox handed a $65,000 bonus to Billy Consolo before the Los Angeles lad agreed to join them, but it was the Yankees who paid today.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., warned the American Airlines yesterday that its members would resist any speed-up by the company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Clint Courtney made five hits in five tries to pace Baltimore to a 5-0 victory over Washington in the second game of a double-header today after the Orioles had won the opener, 8 -- 4, Joe Coleman held the Senators to six hits to gain his eleventh decision in the second game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Sixty boys and girls who have been learning about the United Nations in the Police Athletic League's play street summer program will get a look tomorrow at the world organization's headquarters.

The recent letter of Manuel Pinto regarding the status of Goa cannot go unanswered on two principal counts: first, Mr. Pinto has a tendency to disguise some of his opinions as facts, and, secondly, recent events have shaken much of the foundation under Mr. Pinto's thesis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is on the spot this week as a Senate committee considers charges that he should be censured, but he still has his backers.
A young Air Force mechanic went through a nightmarish day yesterday frantically trying to locate his British wife who arrived here from London Saturday morning to spend a month with her husband.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs cushioned their fourth-place position today with a 3-2, 8-4 double-header victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. Ted Kluszewski belted a four-bagger in each game and raised his home-run production of the season to thirty-nine, tying Willie Mays of the Giants for the major league lead.

The awarding of twenty-seven fellowships to scholars and artists in the American republics, Puerto Rico and the Philippines was announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation. The grants total more than $100,000 and are for studies in science, education and art.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that the Eighty-third Congress had "defaulted in its responsibilities to the American people" and had compiled a "shameful" record.
MANILA, Monday, Aug. 30 -- Luis Taruc, surrendered head of the Philippine Communists, was sentenced today to twelve years in prison for rebellion.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 -- Israeli Government circles believe the United States is gaining the goodwill of the Arab nations, but it will have to win back the confidence of Israel before it can succeed as a broker for peace in the Middle East.
PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Premier Pierre Mendes-France's speech today to the National Assembly on the European Defense Community treaty:

Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, hailed the spate of maritime legislation passed by Congress this year as the greatest peacetime program for American shipping ever enacted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, made it clear today that Democrats planned to set off a good deal of political fireworks in the campaign over the disputed Dixon-Yates power contract.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley N. Barnes, the Government's anti-trust chief, is "seriously concerned" about the current number of business mergers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -The National Petroleum Council announced today the appointment of an advisory committee to study operations of the Government's oil shale plant at Rifle Colo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Weather developments were the main trading influence in the grain markets last week. Continued rain over the major part of the corn belt and in the Canadian West have affected both wheat and corn.

ALPBACH, Austria, Aug. 29 -- "The Bank -- One Main Artery of the European Economy" was the theme discussed exhaustively Friday and yesterday at this secluded mountain village in the Austrian Tyrol at the tenth annual rally of the European Forum.

EL PASO Tex., Aug. 29 (UP) -- A B-36 atomic superbomber, limping toward a civilian airport with six of its ten engines in flames during a practice landing drill, hit a power line, crashed and burned near midnight yesterday.
Queens detectives who began an investigation in July into the mysterious firing of a machine gun from an East River bridge solved the case yesterday with the arrest of ten teen-age boys.

The need for pre-terminal psychiatric and psychological centers, as pointed out in Alma Denny's excellent letter of Aug. 11, cannot be overemphasized. The billions spent for crime, punishment and mental hospitals each year, which cover mostly cases manifested by a basic misorientation toward people and the environment, would be reduced gradually were the preventative approach adopted as opposed to the "locking the barn door after the horse is stolen" method.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The possibility of the direct admission of West Germany to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as an alternative to the European Defense Community, has been carefully studied. Experts believe there are no obstacles from the juridical or military viewpoint. The stumbling blocks are all political and diplomatic.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- With Shakespearean banners flying from the pinnacles of the Stamford High School football stadium, thirty stars of stage, screen, radio, television and opera pooled their talents tonight to present "celebrity night," a gala outdoor variety program.

Nearly 10,000,000 Americans, representing one out of every seven families in the United States, each year avail themselves of consumer finance services from licensed companies, according to a study of the industry released by Paul L. Selby, executive vice president of the National Consumer Finance Association, Washington.
Readers often ask us what is meant by the French cooking term "saute." They want to know how you translate it into English. What is meant by a saute of chicken or veal, for example?

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Salvador V. Caro, insular Government Administrator of strikebound Puerto Rican docks, said today he would ask the island's biggest waterfront operator tomorrow for its records of the last two years in hope of facilitating negotiations.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of City Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro as a justice of the Court of Domestic Relations at an annual salary of $19,500. The appointment is for a full ten-year term.
The Rev. Dr. Howard F. Callahan mentioned four methods of making God "more real in our lives" in a sermon yesterday at the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church at 174th Street.
The Navy chartered fifteen American-flag merchant vessels last week for probable use in the evacuation of the Haiphong area of Indochina, which is to be ceded to the Communists.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 -- "Let's put the show on the road" once was a Dodger slogan. It might be appropriate now, for the battling Brooks today routed the Braves twice, 12 -- 4 and 11 -- 4, for their sixth straight victory since leaving home.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, one of the nation's largest operating utilities, reported yesterday a net income of $30,439,135 in the twelve months to July 31. This was equal to $2.37 a share on the outstanding common stock.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 -- The agreement between Iran and the consortium of eight Western oil companies, drafted last week, was completed tonight at a final meeting of negotiators of the two sides.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower asked for the election of a Republican Congress this fall to give his Administration "a clear-cut opportunity to carry out its four-year program."

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Publication today of the agenda for the Labor party conference next month lent added weight to earlier forecasts that Hugh Gaitskell, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, would defeat Aneurin Bevan for party treasurer.

The National Labor Relations Board, after doing a little arithmetic, has decided that the old International Longshoremen's Association ought to be certified as collective bargaining agent for dock workers in the Port of New York. IF its seasonal premiere was any criterion, the "Lux Video Theatre" will bear a new sparkle this fall. The drama series, formerly confined to half-hour original plays but now featuring one-hour adaptations of movies, resumed last Thursday (10 P. M. N. B. C.) with an impressively mounted production and a fine acting cast headed by Dorothy McGuire.

If two Brooklyn burglars had known the history of the Empire Chevrolet Sales and Service Company at 1 Remsen Avenue, they might have known better than to try to break open the concern's safe early yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 -- The Giants and Cardinals spent more than six hours belting each other in royal fashion today only to wind up with an even break in a torrid double-header that left a gathering of 30,477 wilted.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 29 -- The Lone Star State is headed for two more years in its individualistic, lone-wolf role in national politics.

The French must continue to use every possible means of persuasion and pressure in the case of the prisoners detained and unaccounted for by the Communist Vietminh in Indo-china. WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The United States exported $2,932,000,000 worth of farm products in the fiscal year ended last June 30, 4 per cent more than in the previous year, the Agriculture Department reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Ned Garver pitched six-hit ball to give Detroit a 2-1 victory over Philadelphia today after the Tigers had trounced the Athletics, 14-3, in the opener of the double-header.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A small businessmen's organization accused the Federal Trade Commission today of concentrating on "minor cases" while big ones involving price discriminations "wither on the vine."
OLEAN, N. Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Joe Bach resigned tonight as head coach of the National Football League's Pittsburgh Steelers. Walter Kiesling, line coach, was named to succeed him.
SEA BRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Fire early today destroyed the fashionable Sea Bright Yacht Club here with damage estimated at $100,000.

Herbert Mandelkorn's letter, published Aug. 21, commenting on the Times editorial, "Checkmate," is both informative and interesting.
