MILAN, Italy, Aug. 29 -- Large crowds, piles of objects and constant motion contributed to the vigorous atmosphere of the tenth Triennale of Milan as it opened in the Palace of Art in Sempione Park here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The national capital fell today to the thousands of past fighting men converging for the American Legion's thirty-sixth annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee will spend six weeks in Central and South America checking into the availability of strategic and critical materials.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that Maine's Sept. 13 election would be "the first state-wide test of the Eisenhower Administration's program and consequently will have great significance nationally."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Fritz Lang, the director, has acquired the motion-picture rights to "Journey to Nowhere." The Nedra Tyre novel, which was published last year, deals with a group of American traitors who kidnap the heroine of the story.
Despite the wind and the heaviness of the turf, wet from the morning rain, the players of the top echelon overcame all opposition yesterday in the men's national tennis championship at Forest Hills.

The Bureau of the Budget was deliberately inaccurate and misleading, it was charged yesterday, in compiling figures on the comparative cost of proposals to supply power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 30 -Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's Government moved in the direction of a more liberal news policy today. It announced the abolition of Vietnamese political censorship of outgoing foreign news dispatches.

Canned tomato juice is a thrifty alternative to fresh tomatoes, which, because of drought, are relatively expensive and in many cases poor in quality. A forty-six-ounce tin of the juice currently is offered for 26 cents in one chain.

Heating oil is to be delivered this week for storage in an abandoned slate quarry at Wind Gap, Pa. The quarry was converted into a storage facility by the Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

Julius Hulling has Been a New Yorker for nearly fifty years. But he was born in Mascoutah, Ill. -- on Jan. 20, 1972 -- and it was on behalf of a communal endeavor in Belleville, Ill., five miles from his birthplace, that he dropped in yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, told the National Association of Letter Carriers today that Congress was just as much responsible as President Eisenhower for the failure of postal employes to obtain a 5 per cent wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "urgently" rushed into a closed meeting of the special committee considering his conduct today, apparently to question the impartiality of Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, one of the six members.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- With the aid of a liferaft dropped from a rescue plane, two young off-duty Coast Guard seamen made their way safely to shore here today after their twenty-eight-foot cabin cruiser was destroyed by fire.
Two young Brooklyn girls were injured, one fatally, in separate accidents yesterday when they tumbled from the windows of their apartment houses.

The act of sedulously canvassing bookstores is known to be a pastime peculiar to a species, rare enough nowadays, the bibliophile The booklover, seldom mindful of the harsh practicalities of life, is willing to postpone the payment of bills, the buying of food and the purchase of clothes if he may be allowed to browse casually in a bookstore.

OTTAWA, Aug. 30 -- A new look at the whole problem of Western European defense was advocated tonight by the head of Canada's Foreign Affairs Department.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The executive committee of the Socialist party expelled four of its outstanding leaders after the Assembly had rejected the European Defense Community Treaty.
DUBLIN, Aug. 30 -- The Ford motor assembly works at Cork was closed down today "until further notice." This was the company's reaction to a sitdown strike over pay.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The deathwatch beetle has eaten so deeply into the beams of Westminster Abbey that the roof might have fallen in within two years if the damage had not been discovered.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- The Pakistani Government decided today to refer the dispute with India over the state of Kashmir back to the United Nations Security Council.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Hi-Lo's Forbes, the winner of the "Miracle Mile" at Roosevelt Raceway last year in 1:58 3/5, will make his final appearance Friday night when he parades before the crowd prior to the running of the special $15,000 Harvest Moon pace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action castigated the American Legion today for what it called "scurrilous, back-fence art" slurring the A. D. A. and former President Truman.

A Brooklyn man who ate wild mushrooms from a Queens park on Wednesday night died forty-eight hours later. The Health Department said yesterday that it was the first death attributed to mushroom poisoning in the city since 1949.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- South African gold mining shares and industrials scored the best gains in active trading here today. Elsewhere the markets were firm apart from British Government issues, which showed many small losses.
ATLANTA, Aug. 30 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark today advocated a policy of "toughness" as America's best deterrent to another world war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The G. I. came in for some friendly criticism today from five veterans of the Chinese Communist campaign in Korea who refused to go home after the armistice.

Another television set manufacturer has begun mass production of large-screen color sets prior to the introduction next month by the Radio Corporation of American of the latter's widely-publicized twenty-one-inch color picture tube.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 30 Six high-ranking officers of the United States Military Academy, including the superintendent, Maj. Gen. Frederick A. Irving, were honored today at a special review of the Corps of Cadets in ceremonies commemorating their retirement.

A large-scale building development is planned for the Third Avenue district between Ninth and Twenty-fourth Streets when the old elevated structure is removed in about a year. New structures will be fifteen to eighteen stories high, with stores on the street level and apartments for families of middle income.

MELBOURNE, Aug. 30 -- Prices at the opening of the wool selling season in Sydney today were 7 1/2 to 10 per cent lower for Merino fleeces than last season's closing rates. Better wools and heavier burred types showed greatest decline.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 -- The head of the United Textile Workers of America, A. F. L., denounced the Eisenhower Administration today as "doing nothing" to combat unemployment or to aid the textile industry.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Requests for the assignment of "special number" license plates -- at $5 extra each -- will be received by the Motor Vehicle Bureau at its office here beginning Wednesday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 30 -- A gathering of some seventy scholars and other experts tonight began considering ways of improving the communication of ideas to strengthen the democratic way of life.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 -Workers in local industries were urged to turn over any further Communist broadsides to Federal authorities. This action followed a thorough job of sending Red propaganda to employes of P. R. Mallory Company here, a manufacturer of electrical and electronic equipment, much of it on Government order.
Yonkers and Tarrytown, N. Y., lifted their bans yesterday against dynamite blasting in the construction of the New York State Thruway.

Piece de resistance of a recent lunch at the Twenty-One restaurant was first-of-the-season grouse flown here from Scotland. But we found equally as interesting the barley with onions and mushrooms that accompanied the game. It was a delicious alternate to wild rice and, we reflected, much less expensive.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 30 -William Montague Geer, investment counselor and lawyer, died here today of a self-inflicted bullet wound. Mr.-Geer, who was 69 years old, had been ill recently.
ROME, Aug. 30 -- Italian official circles were aghast this evening when the action of the French National Assembly on the European Defense Community became known in Rome.
MADRAS, India, Aug. 30 -- An anti-Communist front was inaugurated in south India today by Kamaraja Nadar, Chief Minister of Madras.

Sales volume of New York City's department stores in the first six months of the fiscal year -- February through July -- was 2 per cent greater than last year, according to a survey by The New York Times.

William F. Giesen, general manager of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, returned yesterday from a fiveweek European tour well impressed with his home port.

Miss Anne Morgan, daughter of the late J. P. Morgan, left a net estate of $281,451 when she died at the age of 78 on Jan. 29, 1952, according to an estate tax appraisal yesterday at the State Office Building.

The former Steinway Theatre at 31-10 Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, is to be converted to store use. The major portion of the property, comprising about 15,000 square feet, will be occupied by the Lerner Shops. The building has been purchased by a customer of the Edward A. Gangler Company, broker, and space has been leased to the Lerner chain.

DENVER, Aug. 30 -- Senator Johnson was quoted in the March 12 issue of The Denver Post as having said that Democratic leaders in Congress "Ioathe Joe McCarthy" and that most Republicans were "disgusted with him."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The trial of Cpl. Claude Batchelor opened today with a court-martial member, a Medal of Honor winner, excusing himself from service because he believed Corporal Batchelor was a traitor.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- A breakdown of the voting by which the National Assembly in effect rejected the European Defense Community treaty shows the deep split the issue caused in all political groups except three. They are the Communists and Gaullists on the opposition side and the Popular Republicans, the great majority of whom favored the defense community.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Jim Greengrass slammed a three- run homer in a four-run sixth- inning tonight to pace the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 30 -- Military commanders and planners at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, were deeply discouraged tonight by the defeat of the European Defense Community treaty in the French National Assembly.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- The doffing of uniforms by most Soviet civil ministries appears to have two purposes: to de-emphasize any military aspect of Soviet civil life and to re-emphasize the wearing of the uniform as the special prerogative of the army and other military services.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett called today for deeds to back up recent reassurances given to Israel by the United States and British Governments.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Nemma Hal, 6-year-old bay mare owned by William Lehner of Woodbury, N. J., and driven by Wayd Cotter, won the Colorado mile pace in 2:09 over a rainswept track tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

DES MOINES, Aug. 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower took time after his visit to the Iowa State Fair today to hear a plea for new efforts to free Iowa's Communist-held jet ace, Capt. Harold C. Fischer Jr.
Your correspondent's plea on behalf of retired Army personnel is not without merit, but to claim they are suffering an injustice is a far cry from the truth.

TRENTON, Aug. 30 -- The public hearings into charges of theft and fraud brought against two top aides of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman were abruptly recessed this morning as a defense attorney dramatically voiced his belief in the guilt of his client.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 30 -- The most interesting of the twentyone buildings installed in Sempione Park here for the tenth Triennale of Decorative and Industrial Arts is dedicated to children.
HOLLAND, Mich., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Beverly, Mass., entry was off to a fine start today in the three-day international junior championships for sailing crews on Lake Macatawa.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Grain futures were irregular on the Board of Trade today, wheat being unable to hold rallies, while corn and oats were strong.
TOKYO, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Communist China, in a new bid to weaken Japan's ties with the United States, announced today that it would let Japanese ships into the key Manchurian port of Dairen.

MOUNT GILEAD, Ohio, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Officials of the Hydraulic Press Manufacturing Company of Mount Gilead announced today that a group headed by Frederick W. Richmond of New York had agreed to buy the assets of the company for approximately $4,300,000.
MANILA, Aug. 30 -- President Ramon Magsaysay expressed shock tonight at the leniency of the punishment given to the nation's leading Communist, Luis Taruc.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- A New York team of four young architects and a professor was announced today as winner of the $20,000 first prize for a plan for redevelopment of Chicago's Downtown Loop district in the next 100 years.

An intimate revue called "Hello Paree," drawing its inspiration as well as its material from Gallic shows presented at the Casino de Paris, is being put together for Broadway this season by William L. Taub.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 -- The Government has begun an investigation of communism among military and police officers, Brig. Gen. Timur Bakhtiar, Military Governor of Teheran, said in an interview tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Bob Turley held the slumping Washington Senators to three hits today and the Baltimore Orioles swept the three-game series with a 3-1 victory.
Radio station WABC will provide special coverage of the Senate committee, which begins hearings today on the proposals for censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
An agreement among New York City Democratic leaders to refrain from taking sides in the contest for the nomination for Governor until after the Sept. 14 primary election came to light yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Governor Dewey, steering clear of Democratic charges that unemployment was mounting in New York State, today declared that "jobs are steadily and surely on the increase."

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 -- Carl Erskine served two three-run home run balls tonight and the Dodgers' winning streak of six games was snapped. The Braves won the game, 7 -- 5, and the Brooklyn defeat, coupled with the Giants' victory, dropped the Brooks two and a half games from the league lead.

I read with great interest the statement in The Times of Aug. 23 that Arthur Levitt, president of the Board of Education, in speaking on the problem of juvenile crime, "recommended the erection by the city of boys' clubs at strategic points throughout the city.

With the retirement of the great Native Dancer, some of the thrill has gone out of horse racing for the Messrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and William C. Winfrey. But they managed to extract more than a bit of enjoyment from the proceedings at Aqueduct yesterday.

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, Aug. 30 -- The Bethlehem Steel Company may open up large iron ore bodies in Southwest Africa and build a railway and ore port costing $84,000,000, according to an unconfirmed press report here.

Louis J. Glickman, real estate investor, has purchased the fourteen-story American Building at the southwest corner of Baltimore and South Streets, in Baltimore, Md., from the Charles C. Fulton Building Company. The Aetna Realty Company was the broker in the transaction and David Feldman of Margolin Feldman was attorney for the buyer.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Eliot Hearst, William Lombardy and Edmar Mednis of New York City, with two victories apiece, were in a five-way tie for first place with Roy T. Black of Buffalo and Fred Campomanes of Manila, the Philippines, after the second round of the New York State chess tournament at the Roberson Memorial Building today.

As the Watkins committee opens its inquiry into Senator McCarthy's conduct, the atmosphere of the hearing room will doubtless be dramatic enough but the usual paraphernalia of drama when McCarthy is the star will be notably missing. No bright lights, no whirring cameras, no popping flash bulbs during the sessions.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A raging hurricane -- carrying winds of 100 miles an hour at the center -- whipped the North Carolina vacation coast tonight. Churning waves tore out fishing piers and wind and rain cut power and communication lines.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- The graveyard that is the second division of the American League is crowded with teams that took an early lead over the Cleveland Indians, then folded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today created a special advisory committee to help him solve state-Federal problems of putting into effect his $50,000,000,000 highway improvement program.

Coffee futures prices fell the 2-cent-a-pound limit from the highs of the day in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. It was the twelfth consecutive trading day to produce limit declines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower has signed two bills dealing with Federal benefits, the White House announced today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 30 -- President Eisenhower said this evening that the United States had suffered a serious setback in the failure of the French to accept the European Defense Community plan, but that we must not be discouraged.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United States is in serious jeopardy through its system of stockpiling strategic and critical materials for war, a Senate subcommittee reported today.

Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, again paid tribute to Soviet Russia's sports progress yesterday. Brundage, who arrived from England on Saturday, repeated statements made in Moscow last month that the Russians had made great strides in athletics.

The fourth and last of the summer's chamber music concerts in Washington Square last night consisted of Bach's Suite No. 1 in C major. A drizzle that within ten minutes turned into a heavier downpour prevented the musicians from giving the two final numbers.

A group celebrating an Italian feast in Long Island City, Queens, their spirits and tinder undampened by the rain, set off a ten-minute array of fireworks last night that was seen and heard as far west as Riverside Drive in Manhattan.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The embargo on the sale of British arms to Egypt was lifted today as a result of the agreement on the Suez Canal base. The ban was imposed in October, 1951, after Egypt had abrogated the AngloEgyptian Treaty of 1936.
International air travel paid off handsomely in the first half of this year, according to a reliable barometer.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The decisive blow delivered to the European Defense Community by a procedural maneuver in the National Assembly today has provoked bitter attacks from two newspapers that were supporters of the treaty.
Bob Satterfield, light heavyweight from Chicago, knocked out Frankie Daniels of Bakersfield, Calif., in 2:44 of the seventh of a scheduled 10-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Six young Russians have completed a tour of Britain as guests of an English Quaker youth organization.

The Department of Justice has announced that it is concerned over the recent wave of accomplished and proposed corporate mergers and will study them carefully to see if any of them violate the anti-trust laws. The Clayton Act prohibits mergers tending "substantially to lessen competition."

In 1949, students of the National Peking University greeted the People's Liberation Army when it entered the city. Among them was Maria Yen (a pseudonym), who believed that communism promised a new life. But she soon learned that the "new order was a betrayal of her faith and hopes."

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- A retreat parade at Fort Slocum late today marked the retirement, effective tomorrow, of Col. Thomas W. Munford, commandant of the Army Information School. He will be succeeded by Col. Charles E. Brown.

DE PERE, Wis., Aug. 30 (AP) -Don Baldaccini of Miami, Fla., who apparently had successfully defended his Class A hydroplane title yesterday in the national stock outboard championships, was disqualified today by the judges.
Victorious in its fight to represent Port of New York dock workers, the old International Longshoremen's Association will turn its attention today to the problem of a new contract.
A Weather Bureau spokesman said here last night that the hurricane was expected to pass off the eastern tip of Long Island late this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- President Eisenhower's recent veto of a 5 per cent pay rise for Federal employes was called "unjustified and a breach of faith with Federal employes" in a resolution today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Ruth Jessen, 17-year-old Seattle girl, today led a field of sixteen qualifiers into the matchplay phase of the sixth annual United States girls junior golf championships after the two favorites were beaten in medal play.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Some Republican chiefs said today they were organizing a special drive in Kentucky to defeat the come-back bid of former Vice President Alben W. Barkley.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 29 -- A strongly nationalist book that has appeared here insists it is highly probable that the Negro is in no way inferior but can achieve a level of civilization equal to that of the white man.
Twenty large ocean liners are due here this week with close to 19,000 tourists returning from Europe.

SOUTHOLD, L. I., Aug. 30 -For fifty farmers with 22,000 cauliflower, all roads led today to Southold Auction Block. The farmers poured in from Jamesport, Calverton and a number of other communities of Eastern Suffolk.
MANILA, Aug. 30 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo undertook to define tonight the Philippine attitude on colonialism with relation to the Southeast Asian defense meeting beginning here Sept. 6.

Loew's, Inc., last of the big film companies to go through divorce proceedings as required by the Government's consent decree, yesterday announced the separation of its motion picture production and distribution business from its domestic theatre operations, effective tomorrow.
DES MOINES, Aug. 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower drew a laugh at the Iowa State Fair today when he insisted on paying the admission fee for himself and former President Hoover.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson charged today that, under the Eisenhower Administration, "this has been a year of futility -- or worse -- in meeting what may be considered the particular problems of labor-management relationship."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The President and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff came very close to contradicting each other today over the number of aircraft in the Navy.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, the first Army officer to be tried on charges of collaborating with the Communists while a prisoner of war in Korea, was accused today of calling former President Truman and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur "tools of Wall Street."

The money market in New York continues to be relatively tight. Excess reserves of the nation's banking system, although aggregating $1,000,000,000, are still generally lacking in the big financial centers and continue to be held instead by small-city banks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Sales and net income of Marshall Field Co. in the three months ended on July 31 declined sharply from the 1953 level, the big Chicago department store company's report disclosed today.
The American Broadcasting company announced yesterday an intensively localized campaign for radio that is expected to produce important newspaper advertising wherever the system has an outlet.

The J. I. Case Company, one of the largest full-line producers of farm machinery and equipment, reported yesterday a loss from operations in the nine months ended July 31, resulting from a sharp drop in sales.
PARIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Premier Pierre Mendes-France to reporters to day following the French Assembly's rejection of the European Defense Community treaty:
Some of the nation's leading political figures commented ruefully last night on the news from Paris that the French National Assembly had rejected the European Defense Community treaty.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- Johnny Antonelli, Milwaukee's gift to the Polo Grounds, tonight became the first pitcher to gain twenty victories in the National League this season as he hurled the Giants to a 4-to-1 triumph over the Cardinals before a crowd of 15,971.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- New York State editors today objected vigorously to proposals advanced by members of the bar to prevent pretrial publication of some types of information on court cases.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The Government announced today it would seek dismissal in Federal District Court on Thursday of an indictment charging Chicago area dairies with conspiring to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- British textile workers will give 1,000 ($2,800) to support the strike of Japanese workers at the Omi mills.

Operations of the nation's steel mills this week are estimated at 64.8 per cent of capacity, the American Iron Steel Institute reported yesterday. Calculated to produce 1,544,000 tons of iron and steel for castings, it compares with the actual rate last week of 63.5 per cent, which yielded 1,515,000 tons of products.

The sensational rise in popularity of home hair permanents has not cut as deeply into the beauty shop business as most persons imagine, according to Mrs. La Fon Vanek, president of the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association.
New York has become the first city in the world to have scheduled passenger helicopter service at night.

Friday's total of blood given to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 490 pints. Among the donations were 242 pints at the Pepsi-Cola Company, 46-02 Fifth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, and 111 pints at the Manhattan blood center at the New York Red Cross Chapter House, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 30 -West German Government leaders were agreed tonight on the imperative necessity of negotiating an alternative to the European Defense Community treaty.

ROME, Aug. 30 -- The Vatican today bluntly told churchmen attending the Second Assembly of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., that no Christian unity could exist without the Roman Catholic Church, and that it was impossible with the Roman Catholic Church without an acceptance of its faith, its system of worship and its hierarchy.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 30 -The World Council of Churches today called for a global ban on atomic and hydrogen bombs together with a "drastic" reduction of all other armaments.

A young woman, arrested last Friday by a vacationing police lieutenant who charged that she had tried to run him down twice with her car, was taken into custoday again last night. This time the charge was that she had consistently ignored traffic summonses.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The Paris openings confirm the status of synthetics in fashion society. They are received in the exclusive salons of the Diors, Balenciagas and Faths.

HOBBS, N. M., Aug. 30 -White and Negro children went to school together in harmony today in one of the first communities in the nation where racial desegregation had aroused talk of possible violence.
VIENNA, Aug. 30 -- United States delegates urged revision of the United Nations Charter at today's meeting of the Interparliamentary Union.

Measures taken under "Operation Stand-By" to keep a huge New Orleans ordnance center ready for rapid resumption of mass production of tank engines were described yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 -- President Eisenhower has promised Republican leaders the greatest effort of any President in the last thirty years to influence the outcome of the mid-term Congressional elections.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., Aug. 30 -A special Russell County grand jury today returned 545 indictments against fifty-nine persons, most of them former gambling figures here.

William Adam Schulz, New York regional director of the Federal Housing Authority, said yesterday that several windfall builders were proceeding with about $6,000,000 of new construction under certificates of eligibility granted four or five months ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The State Department did not trust itself tonight to comment on the French National Assembly's rejection of the European Defense Community treaty. It was "counting ten" this evening and promising to say something sensible tomorrow.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Communist East Germany has agreed to permit United States ships to dock at Rostock on the Baltic coast with President Eisenhower's proffered food aid for flood victims, International Red Cross officials said today.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- British official circles predicted tonight swift action on machinery to give West Germany its sovereignty, followed by intensive consideration of methods of rearmament.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The European Defense Community originally was proposed by the French. Its purpose was to prevent West Germany from having a national army. Even so, its provisions immediately encountered strong opposition within France.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Federal Judge John R. Ross today upheld the indictment of Herman (Hank) Greenspun, Las Vegas newspaper publisher, on charges of tending to incite the murder or assassination of Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy.

A syndicate headed by the seven Fink brothers, hotel operators, has acquired all the stock of the thirty-two-story Hotel Shelton Equities Company which holds a long term lease on the Shelton Hotel at Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Butchers hogs dropped 50 cents to 51 a hundredweight, while sows fell 25 to 50 cents in slow dealings today. The break carried prices to a new low for the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- When Allan Shivers was renominated for Governor of Texas in the Democratic primary last Saturday it marked the first time in many years that a Southern Democrat who bolted his party in favor of a Republican candidate for high office did not incur a political death sentence.

Greek and Roman classic motifs, colorful florals and small documentary prints are included in the fall collection of fabrics now available through decorators at Cheney, Greeff, Inc., 9 East Fifty-third Street.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 -The international consortium of eight major oil companies, formed to produce and sell Iranium oil, is willing to admit independent United States oil companies.

Abraham Straus took the bookish look out of back-to-school clothes yesterday with a collection of grammar school fashions that included several festive styles for wear after the sounding of the 4 o'clock bell.

DENVER, Tuesday, Aug. 31 -A strike threatened for today against twelve plants of the American Smelting and Refining Company was averted by an agreement between the company and the International Union of Mine Mill and Smelter Workers.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of Inwood and Mrs. Mortimer May, Middle Bay, held a four-stroke lead in the women's Metropolitan Golf Association 36-hole scotch foursomes tournament with a round of 39, 39 -- 78, at the Cherry Valley Club today.
Two women storekeepers in Queens forewent their usual morning tea yesterday and captured a thug who later admitted to the police fifteen robberies in the Astoria section.

RIMOUSKI, Que., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- For the world's largest cable ship, laying power cables across the St. Lawrence River was one of the shortest jobs of its kind in history. But for Quebec Province it was a big step in industrial development.

Reactionary tendencies that ruled in the stock market much of last week persisted yesterday. Nearly two of every three issues that crossed the Big Board tape closed lower on the day. All but one of the ten most active issues lost ground and the selling was general throughout the list. It was not a so-called "specialty market."
Mrs. Josephine Abercombie and Miss Betty Betz are co-chairmen of the junior committee furthering plans for the Blue Grass Ball to be held Sept. 23 at the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Treasurer reported today that Swedish hardboard was being sold to the United States at "less than fair value," to the probable detriment of American industry.

The Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday that the rise of public and private debt since the outbreak of World War II raised a question whether "the old fallacy of inflation has been revived under a new name -- purchasing power."
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The record of the Eighty-third Congress on liberalization of international trade was described here today as dismal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)--The Army announced today that six of its general officers would be retired tomorrow.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The Fenway team of Herman Barron and Jim Gaynor won today's Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at Apawamis. However, it took a match of cards to break a three-way tie for the honor.

The Atlas Corporation, a closed-end investment trust that specializes in investment situations, bought yesterday the Pick uranium mine in southeastern Utah. For the mine and its adjacent group of claims Atlas paid $9,000,000 in cash to Vernon J. Pick of Grand Junction, Colo., discoverer of the mine.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- W. M. Wickham's Winning Fleet won today's featured purse at the Atlantic City track before a crowd of 15,367.

Edward Small, veteran independent producer of films, will fient producer of films, will finance the producer-writer-director team of Clarence Greene and Russell Rouse in the making of twelve features. The pictures are to be made at the rate of four a year, with Messrs. Greene and Rouse personally producing one feature annually.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -President Eisenhower today signed the controversial Atomic Energy Act, which opens the door to private initiative in putting nuclear power to work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -President Eisenhower told the American Legion today that while there might be disappointment in progress of the European Defense Community treaty there must be no slackening of efforts toward it.
KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 30 (AP) -A southbound bus slammed into the rear of a trailer-truck on the rain-swept New Jersey Turnpike near here tonight. Nineteen persons were injured.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 30 -One New Yorker was drowned and another rescued today by the Navy after their cabin cruiser sank in the strong riptide between Long Island Sound and Block Island.

Conrad Hilton, president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, announced last night that he has rejected a new bid by William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., to buy the $67,000,000 Hotels Statler Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- David L. Cole of Paterson, N. J., labor relations expert, was named today to head a Labor Department advisory group on labor-management problems in the atomic energy field.
Six patrolmen fired a total of eleven shots yesterday morning to capture four young men accused of holding up a grocery store at 761 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx.

POINT JUDITH, R. I., Aug. 30 -- The little port of Galilee has grown overnight from a quiet refuge for local anglers to a teeming, flag-snapping rendezvous for 100 fishing craft and 300 sportsmen dedicated to the pursuit of the tuna in its (they hope) "giant" form in the twelfth United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, which gets under way tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury have topped 1 per cent a year for the first time in more than four months.

Warnings of traffic law violations that rule drivers off the road under a cumulative point system are being sent by the Motor Vehicle Bureau to motorists applying for operator license renewals. An explanatory folder compiled by Commissioner James R. Macduff goes out with each 1954-57 stub.

" Hunters of the Deep," a fulllength documentary depicting undersea life, will be shown tomorrow at the Edinburgh Festival in Scotland, according to a spokesman for Distributors Corporation of America, the releasing company.

The First National Bank of Boston warned yesterday that adoption of Government spending proposals revived by the Conference of Economic Progress would "open wide the floodgates for pressure groups to make raids on the Treasury."

MANILA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- State prosecutors said today that they were preparing fresh charges against Taruc. The prosecutors said they were not satisfied with the sentence imposed. Taruc, convicted only on a charge of rebellion, had pleaded guilty to a twenty-three-count indictment involving murder, kidnapping, arson and robbery.
Magistrate Leonard McGee disqualified himself yesterday in a case involving disorderly conduct charges against a business man who is being defended by the New York Civil Liberties Union.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The European Defense Community treaty, designed to rearm West Germany within a European army, was rejected by the French National Assembly today by a vote of 319 to 264.

Election of William A. Coolidge as a director of the Crucible Steel Company of America was announced yesterday by William P. Snyder Jr., board chairman. Mr. Coolidge succeeds W. W. Anderson of Detroit, who resigned to accept a Government appointment.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 31 -- The foreign ministers of the Nordic countries meeting at Reykjavik expressed the wish that Communist China be admitted to the United Nations without further delay.
Jack J. Timpy and Donald P. Else have been elected vice president and controller, respectively, of the American Motors Corporation.

IN Box 21, Forest Hills Stadium, during the national tennis championships this week, sits a burly man who knows exactly how the straining young athletes on the courts feel. The six-foot, 205-pound, graying spectator with the knowing eye is Francis T. Hunter, who heard the fans applauding his forehand smashes in that very spot thirty years ago.

The six-story business building on plot 105 by 81 feet at 68-70 Trinity Place through the block to 103-07 Greenwich Street has been sold by a syndicate represented by Herbert Asher, attorney, to an investing client of Spear Co., brokers in the transaction.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The majority leader of the State Senate told New York editors today that the project of transcribing Senate records during the 1954 Legislature had been an "Abysmal failure."
Trains carrying commuters to and from New York City yesterday were delayed because of signal and power failures in the wake of the storm.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 25 -- A rather modest shop, in whose windows, at this time of year, sports clothes are displayed, shelters one of Munich's more dramatic stories and careers. On the door at 11 Odeonsplatz is painted "Wernberg Co. Fashion and Sports."

A runaway hurricane that had changed pace overnight tore across eastern Long Island and northward through New England yesterday. Before it swept into southern Quebec with waning force last night, it took a toll of forty-seven lives, thirty-nine of them in New England, and caused millions of dollars property damage.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The second round of the Women Metropolitan Golf Association thirty-six hole Scotch foursome tournament scheduled today at the Cherry Valley Club was canceled because of rain.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 31 -- Victor Manuel Gutierrez, former Congressman who is considered the country's No. 1 Communist, took asylum in the Argentine Embassy yesterday, a Foreign Office spokesman announced today.

Sponsors of the third Interval Concert of the season at Carnegie Recital Hall last night had some bad luck. Harry Smyles, their oboist, became ill and so the Bach cantata, "Ich hab' genug,' had to be scratched. Instead, Paul Matthen, who was to have sung the cantata, substituted a group of songs by Purcell and Wolf, with Bertha Melnik at the piano.

There's a "new look" in Moscow fashions these days, but it isn't the one decreed by Dior in Paris, nor does it even relate to the ladies. It's off with the uniform and on with the "civvies" for tens of thousands of Muscovites who for years now have been going around in suits with something of a military air.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 31 -- Paul - Henri Spaak, Belgian Foreign Minister, said here today that the French National Assembly's defeat of the defense community project was "a gigantic victory for Soviet diplomacy, which has recently reaped one success after another, including the Indochina settlement."

Approximately forty Democratic candidates for the House and Senate, assembled at Sioux Falls, S. D., have issued a "manifesto" which can best be described as a peculiarly ill- conceived attempt to discredit President Eisenhower's agricultural program.

ATLANTIC CITY, Wednesday, Sept. 1 -- A general alarm fire, fanned by the outer fringes of Hurricane Carol, destroyed early today a fish market, five residential buildings, four fishing boats and a wooden pier in the Inlet section of this resort town.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 1 -- The United Nations and Communist commands began today the exchange of bodies of the dead of the Korean war.

The old International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to demand that waterfront employers compel American Federation of Labor dock workers to switch union allegiance as a condition of holding their jobs.

Sales and earnings of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation rocketed to new peaks in the first six months this year, under the impetus of near-record production of airliners and military planes. The Lockheed backlog fell to $1,171,135,000 from $1,687,350,000 a year earlier.
Attention is turned today to the oyster, which is being harvested in Long Island waters for the first time since last spring, when the season was closed by state law.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 -- There was no rebounding from last night's defeat by the Braves for the Dodgers today. The Brooks now have a two-game losing streak in the wake of their six-game winning skein.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates twice today, 14 -- 2 and 7 -- 3, for their longest winning streak of the season, six games. Hank Sauer set a new record for home runs against one team before 18,217 Ladies' Day fans.

VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Any parent who has faced the problem of amusing a bed-bound child for even one afternoon knows the insatiable desire of the indisposed young for "something that's fun to do" Staff members at Blythedale, a hospital and rehabilitation center her for orthopedically handicapped children, also know the problem. -- multiplied by sixty-five.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Meadow Abbe, a 6-year-old brown horse owned by Ernest Karam of New York and driven by Richard Thomas, won the featured Iowa Pace in 2:05 1-5 by a nose from Gates Hanover tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Middle-aged business men were stepping out after the city's big double-decker buses today like track stars.

How does it feel to be mugged? The Grand Inquisitor was seeking first - hand information, and he asked the question of a man who had just undergone an experience that we read about and hear about as not uncommon in this city today as happening to other people, with no part of town exempt from what the Police Commissioner has called a serious crime wave.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped to the lowest level in more than a year today on receipt of 10,000 salable head. Butchers were down 50 cents to $1.25 and Sows 50 cents to $1 a hundredweight.
Your recent editorial calling for the repeal of the Lyons Residence Law unfortunately overlooks the basic reason for the city ordinance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Secretary of State Dulles left for Manila tonight. The conference there will represent the first phase of the fruition of his many months of effort to bring a Southeast Asian defense pact into being.

Bonds called for redemption in August before maturity totaled $193,221,000, the smallest amount since June but the largest for any August since 1946. Last month's prepayments compared with $209,865,000 in July and only $15,984,000 in August, 1953. In August, 1946, the total was $447,901,000.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Ted Kluszewski of Cincinnati took the major league lead in home runs today by smashing his fortieth and forty-first of the season, but the Redlegs' five-game winning streak was snapped by a 9 -- 3 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 -- Republican leaders drafted today a 1954 election slogan based on a program of "peace, progress and prosperity."

MANILA, Wednesday, Sept. 1 -- The results of studies in Washington concerning a possible Southeast Asian defense treaty and the United States exchanges of opinion with the other countries concerned have been revealed here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund, bouncing back from a $7,500 deficit last year, reported today a $1,500,000 surplus for the year ended June 30.
CANTON, China, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- A spokesman for eight British Labor party leaders touring Communist China urged tonight a "closer communion" between the Peiping regime and the rest of the world.
After yesterday's rainstorm, which forced the postponement of play, a heavy program was scheduled for today in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices received by farmers increased about 1 1/2 per cent between mid-July and mid-August.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Queen Elizabeth's colt Landau today was nominated for the third Washington International race which is to be run .at Laurel Park in Maryland on Wednesday, Nov. 3.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest for any month since January, 1951, and for any August since 1932. Sales exceeded the three-million-share mark in four sessions, with the turnover of 3,614,150 shares on Aug. 4 the largest since Jan. 17, 1951.

Mrs. Gertrude Gretsch Astor of Centre Island, L. I., began a suit for separation yesterday against John Jacob Astor. and obtained a writ of attachment from Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy against his real property in New York.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved in a narrow range yesterday and closed 4 points higher to 20 points lower than on Monday.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- A high Government official said today that West Germany probably would demand full sovereignty instead of the limited sovereignty that was to have been received under the Bonn peace contract.
Nine-tenths of the airlines' arrivals and departures were made on schedule in New York yesterday despite the winds that occasionally reached sixty miles an hour.
Yesterday's was the fourth devastating storm that has struck the New York-New England area since 1938.

The six - story apartment house accommodating thirty-nine families at 100 Eighth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn has been purchased by Morris Morgenstern Son from the Milheck Realty Corporation.

The Soviet Government's chief purchasing agent in the United States threw cold water yesterday on the notion that there might be any immediate sharp rise in Soviet purchases here as a result of the easing of United States restrictions on exports to the Soviet bloc.
ROME, Aug. 31 -- As the World Congress on Population opened here today the Vatican maintained that birth control might not be legitimately used to combat overpopulation.
Sanitation Department mechanical broom swept loftily through four feet of East River flood water around a Bronx power plant yesterday to rescue a man stricken by a heart attack.

Net operating earnings before taxes of Federal Reserve System member banks of New York, northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., for the first half of 1954 were up 3.6 per cent to $234,400,000 from level of the comparable period of 1953, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Driving their motorcycle with sidecar into the rain and wind, two students from the University of Vienna arrived at noon yesterday in Times Square in four hours from Media, Pa.
Long Island received its worst storm battering yesterday since the 1938 hurricane.

The Maryland State Road Commission borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of serial bonds to finance state highway construction. The bonds, which will come due from 1955 to 1969, were sold to a syndicate of investment houses headed by Union Securities Corporation at an interest cost of 2.0621 per cent.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The grain markets here were generally weak today. Recent heavy profit taking has put too much weight on the futures for the current demand.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Aug. 31 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, who is being tried here by a court-martial on charges of collaborating with the enemy while a leader of a prisoner of war camp in Korea, was described today by two prosecution witnesses in conflicting terms.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- President Joao Cafe Filho, in a nation-wide broadcast tonight, appealed for the unity of the Brazilian people, above and beyond party lines, to solve the country's problems.

According to James Reston's Washington report, some of our policy- makers feel that our current complaint is "with France and not with Mendes-France." France, however, consists of more than 40 million people. They can no more speak directly for themselves than can the 160 million Americans.

Department stores in the Second Federal Reserve District are still careful about spending money for goods for future delivery but they do not mind buying merchandise for quick delivery when the prospects for sales are promising.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Westchester County was torn and flooded today by gusts of wind that reached sixty miles an hour, a rainfall of 3.57 inches that was a record for the year, and a tide in Long Island Sound that some boatmen considered the worst since 1938.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Following are the main charges in the Army-McCarthy controversy investigated by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations:

Chesapeake Industries, Inc., a holding company with interests in the movie, electronic and building materials fields, announced yesterday that it was negotiating with the Colonial Trust Company for an exchange of shares.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Thei only similarity between the{ Army-[cCarthy hearings and today's McCarthy censure hearing] was the junior Senator from %Vis-i eonsin--and even Joe was different.
For Teddy Atkinson, the magic number is "1." The popular jockey who persists in "riding them out" no matter what, needs only one more winner to make it 3,000 for his career.
A possible "break" in the unsolved murder in 1952 of Arnold Schuster is expected soon, it was reported yesterday in Kings County Court.

In your editorial of Aug. 18 you refer to the recent award in the arbitration of the demands of the locomotive engineers which were served on the railroads. You reiterate your opinion that arbitration and Government intervention should be employed as last resorts and that there is no substitute for collective bargaining across the table.
Pity the parents of the school aged youngster these next weeks. Indications are that back-to-school advertising will reach new heights in all media.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The rearmament of West Germany under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization through a pact involving the United States, the United Kingdom and the Federal Republic is being discussed by British officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The legal basis for the proposed censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy rests in a single, simple sentence in the Constitution, but his lawyer and the special committee argued today over the precedents that had ramified from it.

A farmers' market is planned for the store property at 63, 65 and 67 Market Street in Newark, N. J., which has been occupied for the last twenty-five years as a variety store by the F. W. Grand Company.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The confusion and division shown by their elected representatives in the National Assembly marked the opinions of French citizens today when they were asked what they thought of the Assembly's vote killing the European Defense Community treaty.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service is again considering flying inspectors abroad to board ocean liners in European ports and examine the documents of passengers and crewmen while the vessels are on the way to New York.
The Big Board list yesterday took its worst beating since June 8. As measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty representative issues, prices fell 4.03 points on the day.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- A controversy that could lead to a schism in the Socialist party, the largest group in the National Assembly, developed today as a result of the vote against the European Defense Community.
Mayor Wagner assigned Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein yesterday to seek new avenues of attack on the city's crime and juvenile delinquency problems.

The return of "The Blue Angel," a variety show starring Orson Bean, the quizzical monologist, has been arranged by C. B. S.-TV for Tuesday, Sept. 21, at 8:30 to 9 P. M. The show, which recently completed its summer schedule, is to be offered also on the three succeeding Tuesdays.

Cleveland landed the first punch of what may well be the tell-tale series of the American League pennant race. It could be a staggering blow. By walloping the Yankees, 6 -- 1, behind Early Wynn's two-hit pitching last night, the pace-setting Indians lengthened their advantage over the second-place Bombers to five- and-a-half games.

The New York City Ballet, recently returned from a summer on the Pacific Coast, where it gathered encomiums on every hand, opened a four-week season at the City Center last night and made us all proud of it once again.
First Army Headquarters set its sights yesterday on a Labor Day week-end free of fatalities to any troops in its area.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the National Assembly today that new talks would be held soon to settle the problems of European defense within the framework of the Atlantic alliance and of French-German reconciliation.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame estimated yesterday that the city would have $389,734,353 in borrowing power within its debt limit available for public works in the eighteen-month period from last July 1 to Dec. 31, 1955.

Work has been started on the foundations for the ten-story addition to the Schrafft's building of the Frank G. Shattuck Company at 58 West Twenty-third Street. Scheduled to be ready for occupancy next spring, the additional 178,000 square feet of space will give the company a total area of 388,000 square feet.
Competition in the pocket radio market is becoming keener.
Your issue of Aug. 24 quotes Aviation Week as stating that we now have two small satellites revolving around the earth at 400 to 600 miles from its surface.

THE National Broadcasting Company, which allows hardly a day to pass without signing some kind of talent to a television contract, has now signed Canada. Recently the network covered the British Empire Games in Vancouver, B. C., and last Saturday it began televising Canadian professional football games.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30 -- Pakistan, by supporting Moslem Malaya's bid for independence from British rule, will try to persuade Burma, Ceylon and Indonesia to join the proposed Southeast Asian defense alliance.

Two different groups, one official and one private, are exploring the possibility of some new agreement between Japan and the Soviet Union on fishing in the waters north of the Japanese archipelago. A recent development is the report that the Soviet Union is ready to discuss a new arrangement if Japan takes the initiative.

In our complicated world it is almost impossible to make a good decision that will not have some bad consequences. The British were right to lift their embargo on the sale of arms to Egypt. It merely puts Egypt back on the same plane with the other Arab states and Israel.

East Coast shipyards will be invited today to bid on repair of the first seven ships to be withdrawn from lay-up fleets under the new Emergency Ship Repair Act of 1954, Hewlett R. Bishop, director of the Maritime Administration's Atlantic Coast District, announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was silenced as being out of order today before the special Senate committee considering whether he should be censured for conduct unbecoming a Senator.

Fifty years ago an American hostess looked over her mother hubbard, decided it was too dull-looking for a tea party and Commissioned Lena Bryant to stitch up a maternity gown suitable for a public appearance.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $55,000,000 of thirty-five-year debentures of the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company at a price to yield 3.015 per cent.

If a youngster holds his body rigid while looking at distant objects, if he avoids close work or appears tense when doing it, a thorough eye examination is in order, according to specialists of the New York State Optometric Association.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell has issued several statements recently of improvement in conditions of unemployment in the United States. These statements call chiefly upon insured unemployment statistics for substantiation. Such statistics give only a partial picture of the country's unemployment situation.

An appeal for at least 1,000 volunteers to help the Brooklyn Red Cross Chapter to carry on its many services was made yesterday by Miss Margaret Nagel, a vice chairman of the chapter's volunteer service groups. The volunteers were needed, she said, to do jobs "so varied it would be impossible to list them all" on behalf of hospitals, homes for the aged, Veterans Administration clinics and other institutions.

BATH, Me., Aug. 31 -- Hurricane Carol pelted candidates of both parties in Maine as they moved into the important closing days before the nation's first general election on Sept. 13. The rain was driven by winds of up to seventy-five miles an hour.

Orders received at the Leather Show yesterday were much greater than expected, according to exhibiting tanners. The two- day show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, usually has been a preview of spring lines with little buying consummated, said Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners' Council of America, sponsor of the event.
Public debt, with all its implications, yesterday overtook the hitherto financially secluded village of Tuxedo Park, N. Y.

" ly Several Worlds," a personal recw"d by Pearl S. Buck, is planned for Nov. g publication by John Day. The author tells of "the great and the lowly, of epochal events and simple, everyday occurrences, of her own country and of others which have meant home to her." The span in time is from the Boxer Rebellibn to 1953 and the range is world-wide.

With completion of production facilities at Winnsboro, S. C., the United States Rubber Company will step up its output in the apparel textile field. Special emphasis will be placed on synthetic fiber blends for women's and children's dresses and suits and men's sportswear and sport shirts.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 31 -- This town of 300 on the western side of the Continental Divide took a part-time holiday to greet President Eisenhower and former President Hoover today.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31 -- In the presence of Princess Margaret, the big-scale production of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which the Old Vic Company is soon to take to the United States, had its premiere tonight as part of the festival here. It was received with great applause, but it was not primarily a Shakespearean occasion.

VIENNA, Aug. 31 -- The Interparliamentary Union adopted today a Hungarian proposal that would urge member Governments to admit to the United Nations those countries that had pressed for entry during the last seven years. The action was opposed by the United States, West German and Austrian delegations.

The defeat of the European Defense Community by a parliamentary trick in the French National Assembly, which Premier Mendes-France did nothing to prevent, has shocked the Western World into quick realization that it now faces what Secretary Dulles calls an "emergency situation" which endangers all Europe and demands urgent action to avert the grave consequences threatening the whole Atlantic community.

Directors of the Western Pacific Railroad approved a recapitalization plan yesterday by which the outstanding 5 per cent series A preferred stock would be exchanged for new income debentures and common stock.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- John Foster Dulles proposed today an emergency meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Council to chart a new course for Western military security.
Clifford W. Sweeney has been named production manager and Clayman C. Shafer appointed chief methods improvement engineer of Republican Aviation Corporation.
AL LOPEZ stared broodingly through the rain-beaded windows of his hotel suite yesterday morning watching the dying lash of the hurricane.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30 -- After a long period of tough sledding, United States-Mexican relations have shifted to a smooth road. The extent of the rapprochment has surprised but pleased officials of the two countries.

A new jet fighter plane being tested on the West Coast has flown faster than the speed of sound, the Convair Division of the General Dynamics Corporation, the plane's builder, announced yesterday in San Diego.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Because of Kid Gavilan's illness, his welterweight title defense against Johnny Saxton tomorrow night was postponed tonight until mid-October.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 31 -- Prices of Merino wool were at times 2 1/2 per cent lower today than yesterday at wool sales in Sydney.

Heavy liquidation yesterday continued to weaken coffee and cocoa prices on the New York exchanges. Coffee futures fell the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit and several of the cocoa options tumbled the 1-cent limit. The selling reflected unsettled conditions in Brazil and the decline in the asking price for the commodities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, predicted today an early "snowballing growth" for color television. Prospects for the color market are even brighter than they were for black and white television at its inception, he said.
TURIN, Italy, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Hungary and East Germany won one each of the two final events contested today in the European Swimming championships, as the Soviet threat failed to materialize.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 -- Flood waters swept into low-lying areas of this city in early afternoon for what may have been record depths.

The Federal Home Loan Banks will offer today, through Everett Smith, fiscal agent, $119,000,000 of 1 1/4 per cent series B-1955 consolidated non-callable notes, dated Sept. 15, 1954, and maturing on next March 15.
There were no claims by the victorious Indians, no concessions by the beaten Yankees in the rival dressing rooms, immediately after last night's big game at the Stadium.

Coming to the Broadhurst on Dec. 7, rather than in mid-November, will be Sidney Kingsley's new play, which is nameless at present. In comparison with Mr. Kingsley's serious works of the past, his latest represents a radical departure. This time the holder of the Pulitzer Prize and two Critics Circle awards has turned out a comedy dealing with sex.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' statement today on the French rejection of the European Defense Community treaty:
BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- Historic Old North Church lost its celebrated steeple today -- for the second time.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 -- Leo Durocher and his Giants, given at times to indulging in eccentricities, are beginning to put on the pressure again, and this time it could be the final squeeze.

Whenever lawyers suggest to newspaper men that the latter should impose some curbs on themselves in the reporting of pre-trial information, there is likely to be an explosive reaction in the name of the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, Aug 31. -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the first day's proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 31 -- The World Council of Churches ended its second general assembly here today on a note of cautious and prayerful optimism.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Ruth Jessen, a 17-year-old high school senior from Seattle, who won the medal, today defeated Eleanor Howard, Bridgeport, Conn., 8 and 7, in the opening elimination round of the United States girls' junior golf championship.

The office of District Engineer, Corps of Engineers, Department of the Army, New York District, with headquarters at 80 Lafayette Street, will be assumed today by Col. John T. O'Neil. He will succeed Col. Alfred H. Davison Jr., who has been transferred to Fort Leonard Wood, Mo.
CAIRO, Wednesday, Sept. 1 -- Redistribution of Egyptian Cabinet posts in which all members of the ruling military junta received portfolios for the first time was announced early today.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Little Kidnappers," a Britishmade comedy-drama, is at the Sixteenth Street Trans - Lux. Sergei Nolbandov and Leslie Parkyn produced the United Artists release for the J. Arthur Rank Organization, and Philip Leacock directed, from a script by Neil Paterson. Jon Whiteley and Vincent Winter portray the title roles.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Four police departments, communicating by radio this afternoon, arrested four safe robbery suspects within fifty-five minutes. Three New York City detectives were sent here tonight to question them.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 31 -- This summer resort and its neighbors in Monmouth County along the Jersey seashore bore the brunt of the hurricane's attack today on the state of New Jersey.

Sixteen high school students here have been selected to receive the Italian Charities of America Scholarship awards. The awards will be presented on Sept. 27 at the Italian Charities building, 83-20 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, Queens.

POINT JUDITH, R. I., Aug. 31 -- More than one-third of the fleet of eighty luxurious fishing cruisers that docked yesterday at Galilee for the twelfth United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament are now battered hulks, and more than half of the boats that survived are seriously damaged.

A review of three centuries of Jewish experience in the United States and an appraisal of contemporary material, spiritual and intellectual progress will be made in the forthcoming observance of the American Jewish Tercentenary.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged the Eisenhower Administration today with almost complete failure to keep election promises made two years ago.
S. T. Scheinman, a guest for the last three weeks at a resort hotel at Westhampton Beach, L. I., got up at 10 o'clock yesterday morning and stepped into two feet of cold salt water.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Following are the texts of the majority and minority reports of the Mundt subcommittee, which investigated the Army-McCarthy dispute, and separate reports by Senators Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, and Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan:

Frank H. Bartholomew, a vice president and director of The United Press, has been designated first vice president of that news agency, Hugh Baillie, president, announced yesterday. Mr. Bartholomew will supervise U. P. operations in the Far West, Central America, Alaska, Honolulu and Pacific areas.

New securities offered publicly here in August declined sharply from the volume of recent months. Bond flotations were the smallest since February, 1952. Stock offerings dropped to the lowest total in six months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Floats, flags, hands, prancing majorettes and thousands of indefatigable men who march for the fun of it treated the capital to one of its greatest shows today in the American Legion's national Convention parade.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- The University of California at Los Angeles today announced the acceptance of a gift from Samuel Goldwyn, the motion-picture producer, for the establishment of an annual $1,000 award for the "best original creative writing" submitted by a student in yearly campus competition.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- American Legion officials have quietly removed from a Statler Hotel room paintings linking former President Truman and communism.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (UP) -- John W. Salmon, suspended chief appraiser of the Los Angeles Federal Housing Administration office, testified today before a Senate committee investigating housing that he and his wife had received $23,300 and a car from concerns doing business with the Federal agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Personal income last month ran at an annual rate of $286,500,000,000. It matched the June rate but trailed the record of July, 1953, by $1,750,000,000, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug 31 (UP) -- The communists reported today they had freed five United States Air Force men they captured near the Tourane Air Base last June.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The first call for football practice was issued at the United States Military Academy today and thirty-seven cadets reported for a vigorous two-hour session that included calisthenics as well as a lengthy session on the blocking and tackling dummies.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Rejection by France of the European Defense Community treaty halted today the recovery in the stock markets. Profit tanking caused small losses, and, although a better tendency developed before the close, net price changes were irregular.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Amy-McCarthy battle of charge and counter-charge that ran through thirty-six days of April- to-June televised hearings ended tonight with both sides sharing censure.

The Sheraton Corporation, which operates a nation-wide chain of apartment, office and industrial buildings, set new sales and earnings records in the fiscal year ended April 30, the annual report of Ernest Henderson, president, disclosed yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Australia urged today that Laos and Cambodia be admitted to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Several nations will raise in the United Nations Assembly this year the problems of national controls over the continental shelf and over high seas fishing.
CIVILIZATIONS, historians delight to remind us, are artificial, difficult to create and even more difficult to keep in good running order.
Blocks of more than $22,000,000 worth of common stock of major corporate enterprises were involved in actual or planned secondary distributions by banking houses yesterday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 31 (AP)--The Army, trying to get reluctant Americans to come home from their Communist captors in Korea, did not promise immunity to them, a trial judge ruled today.
The Cunarder Queen Elizabeth managed to dock on time yesterday morning, but two other large inbound liners were delayed an hour by the storm.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 -- A drive for postal pay increases larger than the 5 per cent vetoed by President Eisenhower was launched here late today by the National Association of Letter Carriers, A. F. L.

TRENTON, Aug. 31 -- A witness swore here today that a stationery jobber favored by top officials of the State Division of Employment Security had admitted last Christmas to having given a $1200 cash gift to one of those officials.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The feverism seven-day attempt of one Swedish business man to act as the intermediary to try to avert World War II is recounted in an official British book published today.
The stories and editorials appearing in the press have done much to alert the people to their responsibilities in the crusade for a better and healthier city, free from crime and delinquency.
A total of 156 players has been named to the Metropolitan Golf Association's 1954 Handicap Honor Roll, Saul Lantzis, handicap chairman, disclosed yesterday.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Drawn matches involving the five players tied for the lead highlighted contests in the third round of the annual state championship today at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association in the Roberson Memorial Building.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Jack Palance, who was to have started work yesterday in "The Big Combo," co-starring Cornel Wilde, has withdrawn from the picture. He will be replaced tomorrow by Richard Conte.

The rampaging hurricane did a devil's dance through New England yesterday afternoon. It killed at least thirty-nine persons, stalled trains, blacked out cities, upset a historic shrine and turned thousands of vacationists into displaced persons.
PHIL RIZZUTO strolled over to the batting cage at the Stadium Yesterday, still a little self-conscious in his gold-rimmed spectacles. Yogi Berra grinned at him.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -Howard Page, vice president of Standard Oil of New Jersey, said today there "are many problems to be sorted out" before Iranian oil is put back onto the world market.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -- Thousands of workers in Sao Paulo are expected to obey a general strike call tomorrow. The degree of success may give the first real indication of organized labor's attitude toward the new Government of President Joao Cafe Filho.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Ruth Jessen, 17-year-old medal winner from Seattle, advanced to the semi-finals of the United States girls' junior golf championship today with a 6-and-5 victory over Betty June Bobel of East Providence, R. I.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles struck for three touchdowns in the first half tonight to beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24 -- 14, in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams.

No coffee will be shipped from Brazil at prices lower than 69 cents a pound, Horacio Cintra Leite, United States representative of the Brazilian Coffee Institute, said yesterday. Brazilian growers cannot move coffee at a loss, he said, and "will not sell a single pound at present "panic prices" on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
An American Federation of Labor picket line failed yesterday to halt work on the North River pier that has been the tinder box of interunion warfare on the New York waterfront.

Chicago, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Producers cut back shipment of hogs to mar today and: butchers and sows averaged about 25 cents higher. Salable receipts at 6,000 head. werel 2,500 below the advance estimate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today reduced its sales prices by an average of 19 cents a bushel on surplus corn, 10 cents on oats, 16 cents on barley, and 14 cents a hundred pounds on grain sorghum for September.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British aircraft industry, which is emphasizing technical superiority in a major bid to wrest world aviation markets from the United States, disclosed today details of record-breaking export orders.

Although purchases have declined in the pre-Labor Day holiday week, cotton textile sellers are looking for a definite upturn in business before the end of the month. Mill shipments are proceeding at a brisk pace, it was reported yesterday by Worth Street commission houses, and price-wise the market has a firm tone.
The bulls in Wall Street climbed back into the driver's seat yesterday. But they appeared to assert little aggressiveness in their position.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 -- The Giants' final swing of the year through the West ended on a disappointing note tonight.

George Geyer, whose own firm, Geyer Co., discontinued business on Tuesday, heads a new bank and insurance stock department of Blair Co., Inc. Geyer Co. until Aug. 5 was one of Wall Street's larger over-the-counter dealers in bank and insurance stocks. It did not deal with the general public, but made a market in such shares for banks and dealers.
A hollow mockery is being made of rent control that may well boomerang at the next election. Perhaps it is not intended by the Legislature. Perhaps, the courts will deal with its threatened abuses.
The slow adjustment of inventories to a generally lower level of business represents only a lag normal to the business cycle and is no cause for undue concern, according to the National City Bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged the Government today with a "do-nothing" policy in what he described as a "drift into defeatism" in world affairs.

Meteorologists hope that study of the weather records for Monday night, as Hurricane Carol approached New York, may. provide a new clue into the mysterious forces that determine-the path of destruction for a storm in this area.
MANILA, Sept. 1 -- The United States draft of a Southeast Asian defense treaty was accepted as the basis for discussion today at the first meeting of experts attending the Southeast Asian conference.
Three main kinds of summer squash -- green, yellow and white -- are now in peak abundance, the New York State Extension Service in Marketing reminds us.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -Johnny Schmitz blanked Detroit with seven hits tonight as the Washington Senators scored a 4-0 victory, their second in a row over the Tigers.

A dinner and supper dance will be given on Sept. 30 at the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the American Friends of Spain Foundation, Inc. The event will also mark the season's opening of the hotel's Empire Room.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A strong protest against a proposed amendment to the American Commodity Exchange Act has been sent to Washington from the British cotton textile industry.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon conceded today that the Republicans were behind in the fight for control of the next House of Representatives. He also called the race for Senate control "extremely close."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Kid Gavilan, the sick welterweight champion, will demand his $40,000 guarantee from Challenger Johnny Saxton whether their postponed title fight in October is held outdoors or indoors.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -- The Communist-organized Conference of Latin-American Women, held here since Friday, closed last night in a fiasco.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 -- Celal Bayar, President of Turkey, began today an eight-day state visit to Yugoslavia in reciprocation for President Tito's visit to Turkey in April.
Exquisite Form Brassiere, Inc., has purchased a 50 per cent interest in Winkies of Long Island, Inc., manufacturers of women's bathing suits.
