ABOARD U. S. S. ROANOKE, in the Aegean, Sept. 1 -- A seventeen-ship task force of the United States Sixth Fleet rendezvoued in the northern Aegean today on the eve of Operation Keystone II. This North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuver is designed to test the defenses of southeastern Europe.
An eight-man crew from the Norwegian freighter Tabor won the international lifeboat race yesterday in the Narrows, off Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.
A traffic light to ease congestion created by an amusement park on Northern Boulevard, Douglaston, Queens, is being installed -- with the $3,000 cost being paid by the park instead of the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the second day's proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Ernest Hemingway is going to write and appear in a motion picture about big-game hunting in Africa. The author and sportsman, who was injured in a plane crash last January while on a hunt expedition in northwest Uganda, has signed a letter of agreement to do the picture with Frank McCarthy, public relations executive for Twentieth CenturyFox, and William Lowe, former editor of Look Magazine.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept 1 (AP) -- The "Russian invasion" of near-by Bay Ridge, which caused a summer-long controversy here, has ended.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A streamlined car that has won the national speed trials for the past three years traveled 245 miles an hour today.
The Astarita Stakes, won by the 9-to-1 Two Stars, had its ninth running at the Aqueduct track yesterday, but there was more applause for a winner after the claimer that was run in the No. 3 spot.

The two-story business building at 2172 Eighty-sixth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by R. Berger to Sydney Siegal of Sid's Pants Shops for occupancy. Slomke Brothers were the brokers. The property occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet and is assessed at $22,000.

For the first time in eighteen years American Export Lines, Inc., has passed a quarterly dividend. It attributes the omission to declining business and a cash position weakened by the fact that the United States Government owes the company more than $34,000,000 in arrears operating subsidies.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -Formation of the Credit Life Insurance Company of Connecticut, to which a charter was granted by the 1953 session of the General Assembly, was announced today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 1 -- In his monthly broadcast tonight, Prime Minister Mohammed Ali told the nation that because of Pakistan's peculiar geographical features, "we have accepted the invitation" to attend the Southeast Asia conference in Manila.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Liberalized retirement and sickness and unemployment benefits for railroad workers and their widows are provided in a bill signed yesterday by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Pakistan has asked the United States for emergency assistance to meet a critical shortage of foreign exchange and consumer goods.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) -The United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., today reported new wage agreements with four more companies -- Baldwin Rubber Company, Richardson Company, Seiberling Rubber Company and Mohawk Tire and Rubber Company.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett said today that Israel was ready to meet any movement toward peace with Egypt.
OTTAWA, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Canada's new paper money will start trickling through the wickets of some 4,000 branch banks soon after Labor Day, a Bank of Canada official said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Sales of the International Harvester Company in the nine months ended July 31, were off 23.7 per cent from a year earlier and net income was down 25.5 per cent, John L. McCaffrey, president, reported today.
A pound of coffee costs less than a dollar again. Yesterday four chains announced cuts in the prices of their private brands.
The New York ship repair industry believes that this area has been slighted in a vessel-repair program started by the Government to aid the "hungry" yards.

TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 1 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, charged today that a Democratic administration would never have had "the intelligence or the political courage" that the farm program of President Eisenhower required.

Hugo E. Czerwonky, engineer-economist, who is the co-author with James H. R. Cromwell of "In Defense of Capitalism," has a new work on the schedule of the Public Affairs Press, Washington. Entitled "Freedom From Insecurity," the book proposes that "we abolish labor unions, abandon income and profits taxes and equalize the flow of money and the output of goods."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -Robert F. Jones, former member of the Federal Communications Commission, today took office as chief counsel of a Senate committee planning an investigation of radio and television networks.

Disrupted communications throughout the hurricane area made an over-all estimate of damage to fishing and pleasure craft impossible yesterday, but yachting experts put damage to sea craft at $3,500,000 in New England.

A new country has joined the list of nations exporting furniture to the United States. The first furniture from Israel went on display yesterday at the D. R. Bradley Company, 22 East Fortyninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Beyond the long-maintained conviction that somehow or other West Germany should be rearmed to play its indispensable part in the defense of nonSovietized Europe, Administration opinion probably has not progressed very far since the French Parliament shelved the concept of the European Army known as E. D. C.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Active buying by local professionals was largely responsible for a substantial rally in wheat prices today, after a drop in the early trading.

TRENTON, Sept. 1 -- A buyer in the State Division of Employment Security described under oath today how he ordered supplies for the agency and then successfully bid for those orders on behalf of a vender then vacationing in Europe. At the time the division was headed by the late Gov. Harold G. Hoffman.

The comprehensive appraisal of crime and delinquency, its areas of greatest concentration, its causes and possible remedies, which has been ordered by Mayor Wagner is a constructive approach demanded by the situation in New York City. Furthermore, the task has been entrusted to an excellent aide, Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein, a man not given to hasty, superficial judgments or methods.
Tuesday's hurricane considerably curtailed the volume of blood the regional Red Cross blood program normally would have collected.

The Manila conference, where East meets West in a common effort to build new bulwarks against Communist aggression, has started with preliminary discussions by experts of the eight participating nations charged with preparing a draft of a Southeast Asian defense pact for submission to the formal conference opening on Monday.

MANILA, Sept. 1 -- Pakistan's participation in the Manila conference provides a prospective strategic bridge between the two theatres of Western defense against communism. These theatres are Southeast Asia and the Middle East.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines announced today the discovery of an important oil field at Tecolutla, Veracruz. The field is an extension of the famed Golden Lane and proves for the first time that Golden Lane continues southward to the coast.
Buying was spotty yesterday at the second and last day of the Leather Show in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Major suppliers reported a fair amount of business on novelties and new items.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- The tabloid Daily Mirror appeared today to have won the first round in a British press war for junior readers.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 1 -- Brig. Gen. Herbert D. Vogel was formally installed today as chairman of the board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

A drop last week of 1,260,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 153,757,000 barrels, compared with 155,017,000 a week earlier and 141,475,000 a year ago.
HONG KONG, Sept. 1 -- Former Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee and seven other touring members of the British Labor party arrived here today from Canton after an eighteen-day sojourn in Red China.

Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy dismissed yesterday a suit by Marty Snyder, President Eisenhower's wartime mess sergeant, to invalidate the Republican primary designating petitions of Warren L. Schnur. The dismissal was based on a delay in serving Mr. Schnur with papers in the action.
The New York Foundling Hospital announced yesterday that it had purchased the blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue from Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Street, opposite its present location.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Sept. 1--Three musk ox calves left here last night by commercial airliner for Vermont where scientists will study them to see if the musk ox can provide an industry for the state's thousands of acres of abandoned farmland.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Del Ennis' grand-slam home run in the first inning helped the Phillies gain a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -Forty-six charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were referred by the Senate to the special committee headed by Senator Arthurr V. Watkins, Republican of Utah. The committee combined thirteen of what it felt were the most important charges into the following five categories:

LINDEN, N. J.,, Sept. 1 (AP) -A one-day walkout by 900 employes of the General Aniline and Film Corporation plant here was settled tonight at a meeting between management and the Independent Dyestuff and Chemical Workers Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The special Senate committee considering the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy piled up testimony today on charges that he had abused some fellow Senators and a general.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Following is the text of a speech tonight by Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, answering President Eisenhower's broadcast report on the achievements of Congress on Aug. 23 from Denver:
Conrad Hilton, who runs a vast hotel chain, has not yet closed the door on the idea of selling the ten hostelries that comprise the Statler group and then leasing them back on a long-term basis.
PARIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Robert Schuman, father of the European Defense Community project, declared today the plan was not dead.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 1 -- Pakistan veered away from the Commonwealth today. In his first-of-the-month broadcast- tonight, Prime Minister Mohammed Ali announced that "it would be to our advantage if we fell in line with the majority of countries and switched over to the right side of the road."

This city removed most of its storm scars yesterday but New England and Long Island dug slowly and painfully out of the havoc of Tuesday's hurricane. The revised toll taken by Carol, the season's third Caribbeanborn hurricane, stood last night at fifty-three lives, fortythree of them in New England, sixteen persons missing and property damage estimated variously between $300,000,000 and $500,000,000 from New Jersey to Maine.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams yesterday promoted Deputy Inspector John H. Mitchell to supervising assistant chief inspector to head the Commissioner's confidential squad.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and prices rose 10 to 18 points.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 1 -West Germany announced today the broad aims of a new foreign policy seemingly designed to isolate France from the United States and Britain. Apparently the policy is aimed at obtaining the right to rearm by negotiations with Washington and London only.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- France asked the United Nations General Assembly today to tighten its voting procedures so that tallies would remain final and delegates would not be allowed to "correct" their votes, upsetting decisions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Donald R. Heath, United States Ambassador to the three Associated States of Indochina, is slated for a new assignment, the State Department disclosed today.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- French officials said tonight they were pleased by reports from London suggesting a discussion of German rearmament by Britain, the United States and the six nations that signed the European Defense Community treaty.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 1 -- The last voyage of 193 United States war dead began here today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 -- In a brief, colorless ceremony this afternoon Communist China and Indonesia signed their first trade pact after more than two months of negotiations here. The trade agreement, which implements the set of trade principles reached by both countries in Peiping last winter, calls for two- way trade totaling 6,000,000 ($16,000,000).
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is in a tougher spot before the Watkins committee now than at any other time since he became a world figure.

FORT DIX, N. J., Sept. 1 -- The First Army Area Food Service School, which turns out 1,500 cooks and 200 mess sergeants yearly, shared some recipes and trade secrets with thirty civilian cooks here today. For graduation exercises, the new cooks built a stove and served beef stew and biscuits to themselves and their Army instructors.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -Striking gains toward recovery from the economic slump that prevailed earlier this year were reported today by President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines in his second annual state-of-the-nation speech.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 1 -- On an unfinished redwood table in the yard of his Rocky Mountain retreat, President Eisenhower signed the Social Security bill today.

A sale and leaseback transaction has been completed with the New York Life Insurance Company for a new office building in Charleston, W. Va., to be occupied by six affiliated companies comprising the Charleston group of the Columbia Gas System.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company yesterday announced plans to split its common stock three for one and revealed a sharp rise in earnings.

The state of Michigan achieved a tragic record during the Fourth of July week-end. It stood at the head of all the states in the number of traffic deaths -- thirty-three persons died in highway accidents, many of which could have been prevented.

Four hundred air travelers returning from abroad were delayed more than two hours at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday by a power failure that darkened part of the main terminal building for four hours.
Essential services were being restored yesterday in the New York suburban areas that were hit by Tuesday's hurricane.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Italy, whose population in a little more than problems of overpopulation and a high birth rate are among the most acute in Western Europe, may expect a leveling off of her fifteen years.

It was another evening of fine performances by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night. Twice in succession now the company has shown that it can take familiar pieces, including some that have become actually stale, and restore them to vitality and persuasion.

Three and a half hours after the match began, Jack Frost was returned the winner over Straight Clark in the national amateur tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday. It would be more appropriate to say that Clark lost another marathon, for in the recent Newport final he was beaten by Hamilton Richardson after four hours of play.

SILVER BAY, Minn., Sept. 1 -The multimillion-dollar investment in taconite development in Notrhern Minnesota in recent years illustrates how favorable tax laws attract industry, Prof. E. W. Davis of the University of Minnesota said here last night.

Today's new film is "Cangaceiro," a Brazilian-made melodrama with Alberto Ruschel, Marisa Prado, Milton Ribeiro and Vanja Orica in the leading roles, at the Normandie Theatre. The Vera Cruz Production was directed by Lima Barreto, from a story and screen play which he also wrote. The Portuguese-language import has English titles, Columbia is distributing.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- Habib Bourguiba, leader of the Tunisian Nationalists, warned today that the impending negotiations on internal autonomy for the French protectorate would fail if the Tunisians now under arrest were not freed.
The Federal Government yesterday declared twenty-five counties in five New England states to be disaster areas, eligible for rehabilitation loans, because of damage done by Tuesday's hurricane.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority, a reluctant partner in the DixonYates power contract, has complained to the Federal Bureau of the Budget that its "experienced judgment" is being ignored by the Atomic Energy Commission.

Operation 25 got under way yesterday with a pledge from the Police Commissioner to take a "deep personal interest" in making it succeed. This is the experiment in which the police force in an East Harlem precinct is being tripled for a four-month period.
Directors of Loew's, Inc., voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend from 20 cents to 25 cents a share. It will be payable Sept. 30 to holders of record of Sept. 14.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Sept. 1 -- The big blow and the resulting damage to charter and party boats at most of the important Long Island, Connecticut and Rhode Island fishing centers undoubtedly has put an end to most of the off-shore angling in these areas for the rest of the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Robert T. Stevens intends to continue as Secretary of the Army, his friends and associates said today, despite the criticism directed at him by Republicans as well as Democrats in the report on the Army-McCarthy hearings.
Most able-bodied women share a deep-rooted dislike for physically handicapped men according to a survey made public yesterday, and this dislike they find difficult if not impossible to overcome.

Brooklyn Morals Squad detectives have begun a drive to enforce the statutory prohibition against bingo and other charity games of chance in that borough's churches, synagogues and American Legion posts.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 1 -- Planning among prisoners of war in Korea for the establishment of a post-war, pro-Communist organization in the United States was described today in the court-martial of Cpl. Claude Batchelor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The death of Senator /%Iaybank came as only a handful of his ConJressional colleaes were still in Washington. The only formal activity was a hearing of a special Senate committee looking into a possibility of censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
HOLLAND, Mich, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Sears Cup, symbolic of international junior sailing supremacy, seemed headed for the trophy room of the Sandusky (Ohio) Sailing Club after three races today.

President Eisenhower again will be honorary chairman of Brotherhood Week, which will be held Feb. 20 to 27 under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, it was announced yesterday by Ben Duffy, general chairman.

Moscow, Sept. 1 -- In a move designed to preserve the historic atmosphere of Red Square, the Soviet Government has decided against completing the huge new skyscraper that had been projected in the Zaryadye area, virtually next door to the Kremlin.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP)--Strikes shut down six western Pennsylvania plants today and made about 6,000 workers idle.

Your editorial of Aug. 19 compliments Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Commissioner of Hospitals, for withdrawing requests for previously planned new hospital facilities on the ground that proper economies should be made.

Coffee futures prices fell the 2-cent-a-pound limit in early trading yesterday but by the close they had fully recovered and showed gains on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The rises were the first since Aug. 11. There was a sellers' pool early in the day but at the close there was a buyers' pool.
Richard H. Balch of Utica, the Democratic state chairman, was entered yesterday in the contest for his party's nomination for Governor by an up-state group.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., Sept. 1 -Lovemans, Inc., of Chattanooga, department store chain, has purchased the J. Fred Johnson Company, Kingsport's largest independently owned department store, Sam H. Anderson, president of the Kingsport store, announced today.

Thousands of music lovers must have felt sad when Monday night's chamber concert in Washington Square Park marked the finale to a distinguished series of offerings. This was the fourth and last time this summer that Greenwich Village and many of the "uptown tourists" descending upon it would thrill to the music of Alexander Schneider and his group.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Renewed activity and higher prices in the South African gold mining share market and a firmer trend among Government stocks provided the main features in the stock markets here today. Industrial shares and most other groups receded further from Monday's high-water mark, but prices tended to rally toward the close.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 25:

The State of Ohio announced yesterday that it would receive bids up to Sept. 28 for an issue of $30,000,000 of highway revenue bonds. Dated Oct. 1, 1954, the bonds will come due semi-annually on March 15 and Sept. 15 from 1956 to 1964.

There's life in the Yankees yet. Rallying from their defeat of the night before in the opener of their three-game series with the Indians, Casey Stengel's five-time world champions yesterday vanquished Cleveland's league-leaders, 4 -- 1, before a banner weekday crowd of 43,367 at the Stadium.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 (UP) -Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves yielded three hits in seven innings tonight and then coasted to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 1 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, on trial here as an alleged collaborator with his Communist captors, was described today as a debunker of communism who did everything possible to improve the lot of the men in the Korean prison camp where he was leader.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 -- A resolution urging the return to two mail deliveries a day was approved today by delegates to the convention of National Association of Letter Carriers, A. F. L.

A three-story library to be erected at the southwest corner of St. Nicholas Terrace and West 135th Street by the Board of Higher Education was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $3,000,000. Lorimer Rose are the architects.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The British Cabinet met today to discuss new means of rearming West Germany and granting it sovereignty on terms that are acceptable to the electorate and that avoid the necessity of French parliamentary decisions.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 1 -- Guatemala and the United States signed a general agreement for technical cooperation today, bringing Point Four in full to this country.

The Dow Chemical Company designated $33 a share yesterday as the subscription price of 200,000 additional shares of the company's common stock to be offered to employes of Dow and of its subsidiary and affiliated companies under a payroll deduction plan.

WHEN in 1930, two years after the death of Thomas Hardy, Somerset Maugham published "Cakes and Ale," that witty, pseudo-biographical novel about an eminent English writer, many readers and critics agreed with J. B. Priestley, who said, "It is impossible to escape the feeling that this is intended to be a portrait of Hardy."

Why not call the bridge the Thruway Authority is constructing across the Hudson's Tappan Zee after Alexander Hamilton? He was both New Yorker and builder of the American nation. Hamilton's intimate association with Washington, in war and in peace, makes bridges, next to each other and named for them, appropriate.

For the first seven months of this year national advertising showed a cumulative dollar volume gain of 8 per cent over the similar 1953 period, Printers' Ink reports. Though July showed a drop of 2 per cent below the June level, it was 2 per cent above that for July, 1953.
A force of several hundred insurance adjusters, moving promptly in the wake of "Hurricane Carol" indicated yesterday that damage claims would exceed $66,000,000.

Army procedures in judging Fort Monmouth, N. J., civilian employes as security risks were disclosed yesterday to have been attacked as unfair and unconstitutional in appeals to Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens.

The thirty-six days of hearings and million of words of testimony that marked the Senate inquiry into the dispute between Senator McCarthy and the Army have now been brought to an official close with the submission of majority and minority reports and two supplementary statements.

GENEVA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- David Leff, United States employe of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris who has refused to testify before a Federal grand jury in New York, asked the Administrative Tribunal here today to uphold his stand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission formally sanctioned today the rate cuts that West Coast railroads had made effective in June, 1953, on heavy shipments of mixed freight moving north and south along the coast.
School bells will soon be ringing, not only for children but for those parents interested in learning how-to-do-it.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Copper workers in four states returned today to their jobs at Kennecott Copper Corporation plants, ending a strike that cut the nation's copper production 50 per cent.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Fred Campomanes of Manila today upset Eliot Hearst of New York, the 1950 state champion, and tied Jack W. Collins, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, for the lead at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association.

The ninth annual "School's Open" traffic safety campaign arranged by the Automobile Club of New York will get under way tomorrow. The first of 22,000 posters cautioning motorists will be placed in areas adjacent to the city.

GRANDVIEW, N. Y., Sept 1 -Governor Dewey and the New York State Thruway Authority were urged today to accept a gift of land for a connection between the Thruway Hudson River Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike.

Seventy-nine building plots on Wilmot Road, adjoining the Vernons Hills golf course in Tuckahoe, N. Y., have been purchased by Greentree Estates, headed by Harold Jacobs. The buyers have completed a model of split-level homes to be built there for occupancy next spring.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 1 -- One of England's leading scientists said today that the human race could not survive if more than a few thousand large atomic bombs were exploded, regardless of where they fell.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) -A syndicate controlled by Robert R. Young, railroad financier, and Clint W. Murchison of Texas was disclosed today to have made huge profits out of two big Los Angeles county housing projects.

When the French Assembly defeated the European Defense Community plan on Monday by a parliamentary trick there was a wave of bitterness against France throughout the Western World. There was sorrow, too, in some instances because this particular attempt to make peace secure had been born in France -- the dream of great French souls.

Hurricane Carol, the third tropical storm in the 1954 season, has left us tragic notice that man is not yet the master of Nature. A hurricane in a day's time can generate as much power as all the world's machinery. In a day, Hurricane Carol killed half a hundred people and caused property damage amounting to half a billion dollars.

A new dress for the first day of school is as exciting to many as sizing up the new teacher. An outfit that pleases mother's practical turn of mind and also meets with daughter's ideas of dress is a big order for children's wear designers. But they have come through with flying colors -mostly in bold plaid.
New York's department stores continued to do business at a good pace in August, according to a survey by The New York Times. Dollar volume was 7 per cent greater than in August, 1953.

Earnings of the United States Plywood Corporation in the quarter ending Oct. 31 will be higher than in the previous three months when 65 cents a share was earned, Lawrence Ottinger, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
BUFFALO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- An Ohio theatre owner's $450,000 damage suit against five corporations of the Schine theatre chain and seven film companies has been settled out of court.

Title was closed yesterday in the leasing transaction involving new control of the Astor Hotel. The new group announced that the property will becontinued as a hotel operation and that Robert K. Christenberry, president for ten years of the Hotel Astor, Inc., the management unit, would continue in that capacity.
Twelve-year-old Mike Hegan will have quite a tale to tell his Little League team-mates when he returns home to Lynn, Mass., in a couple of days.

The New York Summer Festival Committee reported yesterday that more visitors came here this summer and spent more money than in any previous summer. Important business gains were noted in retail sales, newspaper advertising, hotels, ground and air transportation, restaurants, amusements and tourist attractions.
A 5 per cent gain this year in United States commercial exports was forecast at a trade-banking round-table conference yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The vision of a pennant for Ebbets Field this season is becoming dim. The Dodgers are rocking on their heels and, after their exhibition at Wrigley Field today, seem ripe for a knockout.

In my opinion we have been mistaken in our approach to the problem of Communist infiltration. We have failed to see that the people of the nations of the Old World, whom we have been helping, and the people of their colonial empires are not interested today solely in political freedom.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 1 (AP) -- David Caudle was driven to victory by Bill Haughton in the Delaware Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee challenged tonight President Eisenhower's claim to a high "batting average" of accomplishment in the Eighty-third Congress.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Lawrence Quincy Mumford was sworn in today as the eleventh Librarian of Congress by a fellow Ohioan, Associate Justice Harold H. Burton of the Supreme Court.
MONTREAL, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways, reporting lower income for the first seven months of this year, said today an over-all deficit for 1954 was inevitable.

The Fordham Rams started pre-season football training yesterday with forty candidates aiming for top positions vacated by sixteen of last season's letter men. The head coach, Ed Danowski, who is starting his ninth year with the Rams, put the squad through an hour and a half of calisthenics and blocking and ball handling drills.

The dream "House of Tomorrow" that fascinated and frustrated wartime housewives is the house many of us live in today. On this ninth anniversary of the ending of World War II, a backward glance at the dreams of architects and designers shows that a surprising number of predictions of the Forties have become realities of the Fifties.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Johnny Groth hit a two-run homer and his bases-filled walk added a third run tonight as the Chicago White Sox defeated Boston. 6 -- 3, for a split in their day-night program. The Red Sox won the afternoon contest, 7 -- 2.

SALTA, Argentina, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Salta Province senate convicted two Justices of the Salta Supreme Court today on charges of irregular conduct, prevarication and professional ineptitude for having ordered the release of David Michel Torino, an independent newspaper publisher.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- This city, like New York, has a police force that is seriously undermanned but London's crime record, unlike that of its American counterpart, is improving.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1 -A basic problem in government is how to persuade people to follow symbols that are true, a conference of scholars and experts agreed today.

If winter comes, advertising by trade associations will not be far behind. Four of them have announced promotional programs, generally aimed at promoting off-season sales and specifically at the Christmas gift trade.

Harry Rigby Jr., who teamed last year with Stanley Gilkey and Michael Grace to produce "John Murray Anderson's Almanac," has purchased the musical stage rights to "Mister Zip," the novel by H. Allen Smith, humorist and author.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The thirteen-month nightmare of Abraham Chasanow ended today as the Navy restored him to his job, conceding that he had suffered a "grave injustice."
GUATEMALA, Sept. 1 -- The governing junta was dissolved at noon today and Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas became President of the republic.

A five-story apartment house for forty-two families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 2675 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Helen Mandel to Samuel and Rebecca Greenwald for investment. Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers, arranged the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $129,500.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves dropped $95,000,000 in August, the Treasury announced today. That compared with a decline of only $4,000,000 in July.
VISP, Switzerland, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Franz Leopold Neumann, a professor of government at Columbia University, was killed today when the car in which he was riding skidded and crashed into a tree.
Nine persons were arrested yesterday on charges of illegal possession of narcotics as Operation 25 went into its second day.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Lumber and Sawmill Workers, A. F. L., today broke the back of the seventy-four-day-old Northwest lumber strike by accepting a Governors' peace plan.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 -- The Chairman of the United States Senate's Foreign Relations Committee came to Bonn today and denounced the Government of Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France.

The one-story building containing nine stores at 170 to 180 West Park Avenue in Long Beach, L. I., has been sold by Filomena Peyroleri to Joe Leibling. The property occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and is assessed at $107,350. Nathan Fenold was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 2 -- The Australian delegation will seek amendments to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. at the conference in Geneva next month.

Alfred Politz, head of the research firm bearing his name, announced yesterday development of a technique for measuring the effectiveness of outdoor advertising. Using an Air Force camera modified by his own technical staff, he says, the system provides a count of those exposed to outdoor advertising more accurate than the reports of the Audit Bureau of Circulations for print media.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil resigned today as the director of the Catholic Youth Organization for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago.

Sven Davidson and Lennart Bergelin, the pair that put Sweden in the Davis Cup interzone round, were defeated in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday. The fight for the title held by Tony Trabert now is narrowed to four Australians and nine Americans.

BECKLEY, W. Va., Sept. 2 -- The first section of the $133,000,000 West Virginia Turnpike, an eighty-eight-mile expressway through the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains, was dedicated and officially opened today.

SINCE production efforts in the light comedy vein are always welcome on TV, "Armstrong's Circle Theatre" can be credited for at least trying to lead off a new season with sprightly drama. In resuming over the N. B. C.-TV network last Tuesday from 9:30 to 10 P. M., it presented a play titled "The Beautiful Wife," a comedy that contained singing and dancing.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 -- The new Brazilian Government came out on top today in its first test of strength with its enemies. A projected general strike in Sao Paulo got only half-hearted support from the workers.
The United States Public Health Service announced yesterday that polio appeared to be approaching its seasonal peak with signs of a leveling off.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 2 -- In the backwash of last Tuesday's hurricane, local legends of wonderful things that happened during the big blow are being born.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- The Niagara Frontier State Park Commission today ordered Luna Island closed to the public for the rest of the tourist season after a state geologist had said there was danger of a fresh rock fall.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A group of twenty-three Negro children sought unsuccessfully to enroll in an all-white elementary school today in an action that might set the stage for a lawsuit.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company asked the Public Service Commission today, for a rehearing of its request for a rate increase of $69,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 1 per cent above sales in the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, Chicago, filed today a proposed $10,702,000, or 27 per cent, annual increase in wholesale natural gas rates with the Federal Power Commission. The commission turned the proposal over to its staff for study.

As a long holiday week-end approaches, two holiday favorites, ham and turkey, emerge as the most widely featured of the week-end specials. In some of the biggest chains, whole or full-cut half hams are selling at 59 cents a pound and ready-to-cook turkeys at 47 or 49 cents a pound.

Twenty-two tobacco dealers and cigar makers were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of conspiring to cheat the Government out of hundreds of thousands of dollars through the sale of nonstamped tobacco products. They waived examination to await the action of the grand jury and all but two were released in bail varying from $500 to $1,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 2 -- A political storm of major dimensions has blown up here suddenly over the expected arrival of Dimitri Zhukov, Soviet Ambassador and his staff. Mr. Zhukov, first Soviet envoy to Indonesia, is en route here by ship from Italy.
Stocks extended their recovery yesterday, but as on Wednesday the rally was not a strong one.
We're back in business."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Schuylkill Expressway, a fourteen-mile superhighway linking Philadelphia with the Pennsylvania Turpike at Valley Forge, was open to traffic today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- John E. Tobin of Yonkers. Democratic minority leader of the Westchester Board of Supervisors, will be the Democratic nominee for Supreme Court Justice in the Ninth Judicial District.

Former British Prime Minister Clement Attlee and his Labor party associates have now terminated their visit to Red China and are beginning to give their conclusions. Just how much they learned and how much good they may have done remains to be seen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The General Services Administration is re-examining a recent order that permits the Government to purchase foreign oil for the military, Edmund F. Mansure reported today.
ROME, Sept. 2 -- Pope Pius XII will broadcast over the Vatican radio at 8 P. M., Sept. 11, a special prayer he has composed against blasphemy.
A 58-year-old vagrant was held in $10,000 bah yesterday in Kings County Court as a material witness in the murder trial of four Brooklyn teen-agers charged with committing crimes for thrills.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, has been named chairman of the central committee of the World Council of Churches, it was announced today.

MANILA, Sept. 2 -- Philippine leaders were reported today to be inclining to the view that implementation of their mutual security agreement with the United States eventually would be more important to them than the Southeast Asia security pact as it is shaping up.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Max Epstein, philanthropist and art patron, who died Aug. 22 at the age of 79, left virtually all of his sizable collection of fine paintings to the Chicago Art Institute, filing of his will in the Probate Court disclosed today.

VIENNA, Sept. 2 -- The Inter-parliamentary Union concluded today its seven-day conference here after adopting a resolution calling for effective supervision and control by the United Nations of all atomic weapons and everything in the field of nuclear energy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 676,616 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,008 cars or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 141,845 cars or 17.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 50,744 cars, or 7 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

MANILA, Sept. 2 -- The United States is understood to have convinced most delegates to the Southeast Asia defense conference here that the treaty they are negotiating cannot bind signatories to automatic military action against aggression.
Centuries of economic frustration are ending for Coatzacoalcos, a small Mexican village that looks out on the Gulf of Mexico from the Isthmus of Tehuantepec.

Ordinarily the return of a group of tourists to a city as large and bustling as New York would not be news. But one group of tourists who have just returned to this city are of a special type, and their "tour" was of a highly significant character. This group was composed of sixty-one New York teachers and community workers.
It was well after midnight in the all-night diner off Times Square. Four or five newspaper men from the plant across the street were sitting in a booth drinking coffee and smoking cigarettes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Navy, having cleared one Hydrographic Office employe of securrity-risk charges, refused today to make known the status of four others who were suspended or who resigned under virtually identical circumstances.
PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The Ministry of Moroccan and Tunisian Affairs said tonight that a legal status had been restored to the Neo-Destour party, the most important nationalist movement in Tunisia.

An international atmosphere prevailed on Henry Street on the lower East Side yesterday afternoon. Children costumed to represent the United States and seven foreign countries sang and danced in ceremonies ending a nine-week program dealing with United Nations members.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States will propose an emergency meeting of the North Atlantic Council in New York late this month or early next month if no other Government suggests it first.
The General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., signed a new contract yesterday providing wage increases of 2.68 per cent for nearly 100,000 workers.

Ideal weather is in prospect for the entire Labor Day week-end. The Weather Bureau said yesterday the skies probably would be sunny and daytime temperatures would be "near normal" -- in the 80's -- right through Monday.

Wage earners in the nation's iron and steel industry averaged a record $2.368 an hour in July, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represented a gain of 5.8 cents an hour above the average rate that prevailed in July, 1953.

" Adventures in Politics," by Richard L. Neuberger, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from Oregon, will be published Sept. 30 by the Oxford University Press. Mr. Neuberger and his wife are the first husband and wife team ever elected simultaneously to both chambers of a state legislature.
The Transit Authority is planning to btlild a 700-footlong pedestrian overpass in Coney Island connecting the B. IV[. T. West Eighth Street station with the ,proposed Aquarium.

The New York County Medical Society has named Dr. Antonio Pisani, 82 years old, "general practitioner of the year." A physician for fifty-eight years, he has carried on his work from the same office at 2 Oliver Street for half a century.
OTTAWA, Sept. 2 -- Canada is pressing for an early meeting of the North Atlantic Council, an official announcement said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- India has been informed that Portugal would be entitled to ask the North Atlantic Treaty powers to consult on a threat to the security of Portuguese territories in India. But Portugal could not, under the treaty, expect the North Atlantic powers to come to the defense of Goa, one of her territories on India's west coast.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declared last night that the presence of radio and television at public hearings created a psychological barrier that made justice almost impossible.

Bert Stand, secretary of Tammany under several leaders, has been asked by a group of his district captains to resign as Tammany leader of the Fourth Assembly District. He told them last night that he intended to serve out his full term, which has a year to go, and to be a candidate for re-election.
In anticipation of the return of throngs of children to schools and their playing in heavy traffic areas, the National Safety Council presents some pertinent safety counseling.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $49,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Kansas Turnpike Authority and the State of Virginia announced yesterday plans for marketing issues of revenue bonds totaling $260,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Television Writers of America, an independent union, which recently lost a strike against the C. B. S., N. B. C. and A. B. C networks, has decided by referendum to dissolve, its western region president said today.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 2 -- Bombs, ancient birds and basic behavior patterns occupied the attention of about 3,000 amateur and professional scientists at the first session of the 116th meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here today.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The report that the Pakistani delegation intended to press for Malayan independence at the Southeast Asia defense conference received confirmation in part in official circles today.

The University of Rochester saw the completion last night of a two-day conference that should mark a milestone in Canadian-United States relations -- the first of a series of annual conferences under the auspices of a new program of Canadian studies at Rochester's lively and forward-looking university.

I have just received word that Jay Hormel has died at his home in Austin, Minn. Although he may not have been well known to the general public, I feel sure that all who did know him feel keenly the loss of a dear friend and a fine person.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- A positive lead by the United States and Canada in promoting freer world trade was urged tonight by Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Butchers and sows jumped 50 to 75 cents today as salable receipts fell below the advance estimate for the second straight day. Top was $20.75, paid for numerous loads of butchers scaling 210 pounds and more. Today's report of the livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer will team Spencer Tracy and Mongomery Clift in "Bannon," which is described by Dore Schary, studio production head, as a "hard-hitting romantic drama set against the background of the labor movement in the United States."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Total assets of national banks on June 30 amounted to $109,000,000,000, nearly $5,000,000,000 greater than a year earlier, Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, reported today.
A Queens teen-ager's troubled conscience led yesterday to his voluntary surrender to the police after a minor automobile accident. This in turn caused him to be held on a grand larceny charge.

Autumn begins for most of us not on the arbitrary date of Sept. 21 but hard on the heels of the Labor Day week-end. Many New Yorkers will be spending this week-end in preparation for their return to town.
DENVER, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A vast land of drought and floods will unfold before President Eisenhower when he makes a four-state flight Saturday.

RECIFE, Brazil, Sept. 2(UP) -- Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, arrived today from New York on a four-day visit to this oldest Jewish settlement in the Western Hemisphere.

An ominous development in the life of our country is the current stampede of business into mergers, described by a weekly news magazine as "the greatest merger spree in history." It is represented that the movement holds no threat of building up a set of competition-crushing monopolies, but on the contrary that it favors healthier competition through strengthening the positions of the smaller companies in the market who have gone into mergers.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- Former Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee said today he had suggested that Mao Tse-tung, Communist China's leader, tell the Soviet Union it would be "a good thing" if it "cut down on its armament."
Frederick W. Wahlers has been promoted to assistant sales manager of Merchants Chemical Company, Inc.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Britain is expected to propose to the Manila conference that a major air base development program be started in Southeast Asia as a priority defense measure.

In your Aug. 30 editorial, "Eyes on the Waterfront," dealing with the N. L. R. B. certification of the I. L. A., you point out that "* * * the employers have a right to expect that any contract they sign will protect them against capricious strikes and costly slowdowns."

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Adios Boy, the record-breaking 3-year-old pacer, today was ordered withdrawn from tomorrow night's $15,000 Harvest Moon Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. Charles Plumb, the presiding steward, took the action because reports of the colt's illness were confirmed by Howard Camden, trainer of Adios Boy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The public continued during July the slow increase in credit purchasing that had gone on since spring, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

The election of E. Roland Harriman and Alan Harrison Temple as trustees of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and as directors of the Centennial Insurance Company was announced yesterday. Centennial is a wholly owned affiliate of Atlantic Mutual.

MANILA, Friday, Sept. 3 -- The Philippine Army announced yesterday it had caught a Korean spy with documents and papers in his possession relating to the Southeast Asia defense conference. A statement from the Army's information office expressed belief he had been sent here by Communists to sabotage the conference.

Yankee pennant stock jumped a few points yesterday when the Bombers won the rubber contest of their three-game series with the Indians at the Stadium. By their 3-2 triumph, the New Yorkers cut Cleveland's lead to three-and-one-half games.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Sept 2 -- Workmen were busy here today at the bottom of a fifty-five-foot-deep pit at the base of Kings Bluff. They are driving twin shafts, thirty-one feet in diameter, to the west and east in the first subterranean tunneling for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.
Ten new ranges, five gas and five electric, were included in the new group of major appliances the Norge Division of the Borg-Warner Corporation showed yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Coffee futures continued to rise sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The strength entered the market on Wednesday and reversed a slump that began three weeks ago. All positions opened the 2-cent-a-pound limit higher and did not move from that level throughout trading.
Business loans of the New York City banks are continuing to drift downward in a reversal of seasonal experience.

A tall, well-dressed man held up a Howard Johnson restaurant at 35 East Fiftieth Street early today while twenty-five patrons were in the establishment and took $2,000 in cash from a drawer in the manager's office. He then kidnapped the manager, walked him to a subway station, pushed him into a train and fled.
The Detroit Sulphite Pulp and Paper Company has been acquired by the Scott Paper Company, it was announced yesterday.
LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Lou Little's twenty-fifth Columbia football squad opened practice for the 1954 season today. Forty-four candidates were on hand for morning and afternoon drills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Government said today that additional Federal grand jury investigations into tax cases would be undertaken in the New York area relating "to the integrity of persons in public office and to violations of their public trust."

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Thousands of New Englanders looked at their electric clocks today and realized that time not only had stopped during Hurricane Carol but also that modern living had retrogressed more years than most of them could remember.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Forty-six charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were referred by the Senate to the special committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah. The committee combined thirteen of what it felt were the most important charges into the following five categories:

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 2 -- Jack W. Collins of New York, the champion of the Marshall Chess Club, gained the lead today in the fifth round of the New York State Chess Association championship by defeating Florencio Campomanes of Manila in forty-six moves.

Another tale of abduction from West Berlin, harrowing rides in Russian cattle trains, and years of hard labor in slave camps was recounted yesterday by a woman who had not believed she would come out alive.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Private Hell 36," a Filmakers drama with Ida Lupino, Howard Duff, Steve Cochran, Dean Jagger and Dorothy Malone, is at the Paramount. Collier Young produced and Don Siegel directed, from an original screen play by Ida Lupino and Mr. Young.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 -- An analysis of specific ethical problems confronting the American people was proposed today at the close of the fourteenth Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion at Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A Republican National Committee official quoted Vice President Richard M. Nixon today as saying in effect that there was not much to choose between "the blasts" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and "the drawing room innuendoes" of Stephen Mitchell, Democratic National Chiarman.

ACCORDING to reports yesterday the Big Blow did not drive the bluefish from the northern New Jersey waters, for boats out of western Long Island and northern New Jersey fishing resorts returned with satisfactory catches.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 2 -- The United States has no military regulations defining the extent to which prisoners of war may "communicate" with their captors, the defense argued today in the court-martial of Cpl. Claude Batchelor.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Britain's Ambassador here called on Premier Pierre Mendes-France today to discuss the British attitude toward West German rearmament as it had been defined by the Cabinet in London yesterday.

CAIRO, Sept. 2 -- Egypt stands with the West, her leaders said today, but is not ready to enter a formal defense pact. Such a treaty, it was said, would appear to the public here to be a new form of colonial domination.

The French were the first to propose a European Union. It is with them a long tradition, from Pierre Dubois in the fourteenth century, through Henry IV, Saint-Pierre, Rousseau, Napoleon I, Saint-Simon, Napoleon III, Victor Hugo, to Aristide Briand.
The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., announced yesterday that, in reluctant accordance with the Taft-Hartley Act, it had thrown open membership to all qualified seamen.
DENVER, Sept. 2 -- Almost 4,000,000 additional workers, half of them Federal employes, are now covered by the unemployment compensation system.
GLASGOW, Sept. 2 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth opened here today an exhibition of Scottish manufacturing goods graphically demonstrating Scotland's remarkable industrial progress since World War II.

The recorded results of a political survey conducted by Columbia Broadcasting System reporters will be broadcast in a series of eight radio programs, beginning Sunday, Sept. 12, at 12:05 P. M. For the series, which is called "Campaign '54," opinions of bankers, business men, pool players, farmers and others in the various sections of the country have been obtained.

The first flight of the world's fastest propeller-driven, turbine-powered transport was announced yesterday by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif. The flight was made Wednesday night.

A leasehold for forty-two years on the nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 27 East Sixty-second Street, adjoining the corner of Madison Avenue, has been sold by the Modern Leasing Corporation to a client of S. Gilbert, attorney. There are thirty-six apartments and a store in the building, which occupies a plot 57 by 100 feet.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A wide open race for the $2,400 top prize in the $15,000 Rubber City open golf tournament developed today as five professionals took the first-day lead with 5-under-par 67's.

Gar Wood Industries, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $461,707 for the nine months ended on July 31. This contrasts with a net profit of $460,303, equal to 31 cents a share for the corresponding period a year earlier.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Delegates to the conference here between France and the three Indochina states have decided to replace their former four-power relationship by a series of bilateral accords. These would be between France and the countries of Indochina.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Roy Sievers and Mickey Vernon led an eighteen-hit Washington assault that beat the Detroit Tigers, 16 -- 6, today. Among Vernon's three hits was the 2,000th of his major league career. Sievers drove in seven runs and hit his twenty-third homer, a new high for a player with the Senators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The American Legion adopted resolutions today declaring:
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Store and gold mining shares continued to dominate the stock market today.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A new handbook on state and local government, will be on the desks of New York's public school teachers this fall.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday, closing 2 points lower to 15 points higher than on Wednesday.
Robert N. Rose, one of the few candidates for public office on whom both Democratic factions in Queens could agree, was ruled off the primary ballot yesterday because he was not an enrolled Democrat.

In an attempt to offset one of Brooks Atkinson's many justified points against the Eisenhower Administration J. M. O'Neill, in a recent letter to The Times, writes: "The United States Government has not denounced 'its predecessors in office as traitors.'"

In May it was recorded that "Blues Opera" should be classified as the most definite of all the Blevins Davis-Robert Breen projects. It still is. According to present plans, the Harold Arlen-Johnny Mercer-Robert Armstrong-Justus Schiffers show is to have its world premiere Dec. 8 or 9 in Paris.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept 2 -- The United States women's golf team today took a long step toward regaining the Curtis Cup from the players of the British Isles.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2 -- Thomas P. Wall, a 39-year-old Nashville attorney, was nominated by Tennessee Republican leaders today to oppose Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat, in the November election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The output of United States electric utilities was a record 40,077,004,000 kilowatt-hours in July. It was the first time that monthly production passed the 40,000,000,000 mark.
Schenley Industries, Inc., announced the election of Brig. Gen. James K. Herbert, U. S. Army, retired, as a director yesterday. General Herbert succeeds the late Louis A. Keidel.
NEWARK, Sept. 2 -- The Government's first test case to compel builders to return windfall profits gained under Government- insured mortgages seems headed for a protracted court battle.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A television actress was killed early today in a fiery auto crash that injured an Eastern newspaper man and two other persons.

The first effects of the scuttling of the European Defense Community in the French Parliament have rapidly become evident in the return of national rivalries and latent animosities, which find their most serious manifestation in the new estrangement between France and Germany.

ROME, Sept. 2 -- Family planning and birth control, delicate subjects in Catholic countries, were mentioned today in the World Population Conference for the first time. The meeting has attracted to Rome nearly 500 leading experts from sixty-six countries.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 2 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas promised today early elections for an Assembly to write a new Constitution. He spoke to several thousand Guatemalans gathered in front of the National Palace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Official copies of the new law outlawing the Communist party reached distribution points today after long delay, but the first lot had to be recalled.

Well, we live and learn. We had assumed that bingo and the dodo were equally dead, since Police Headquarters solemnly assured us in September, 1952, that bingo was a violation of the law and "the Police Department enforces all the laws." But now it appears that they've been playing in Brooklyn again and Deputy Chief Inspector Goldberg, head of the borough morals squad, has heard of it and gone after it.

The discovery at Karnak, Egypt, of a limestone slab bearing thirty-eight lines of hieroglyphics was described yesterday as "one of the most important historical discoveries of this century" by Dr. William C. Hayes, curator of Egyptian art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 2 -- A South Korean Government spokesman sharply criticized today the United States Foreign Operations Administration's work here. United States officials termed his complaint "groundless and without foundation of fact."

Lawrence E. McKeown, Democratic leader of Nassau County, and metropolitan area locals of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced yesterday their support of Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
President Eisenhower yesterday declared the hurricane-swept parts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island major disaster areas. His action makes them eligible for Federal aid.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- Reports that Ford Motor Company stock held by the Ford Foundation might be placed on the open market within the next few months were not denied today by company spokesmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) The House Committee on Un- American Activities warned the automobile industry today the Communist Party was moving its young intellectuals from white-collar jobs onto their assembly lines in Michigan.

ALL four women scorned social conformity and all four succumbed with enthusiasm to the lure of the Moslem world. And that's about all they had in common, the heroines of the four short biographies that comprise Lesley Blanch's "The Wilder Shores of Love."* A bizarre lot they are, too, as fantastic a crew of courageous and exotic females as ever was assembled in the pages of one book.
Residents of West Fifty-eighth Street, across from the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle, are swapping sleep for progress.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Andy Crevolin, owner of Determine, this year's Kentucky Derby winner, was suspended today by the California Horse Racing Board for saying he didn't always try to win with his horses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the third day's proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 2 -- The defending champion, Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Baltusrol, was eliminated in the New Jersey State P. G. A. tournament today because of a two-foot putt he did not think he had to make at the twelfth.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Delegates representing more than 625,000 electricians were warned today that they were losing billions of dollars in work because excessive "fringe" benefits made their fees too expensive for home owners, small business concerns and others.
Country tweeds have come to the town for the winter in a handsome collection shown yesterday by Peck Peck.

GLASGOW, Sept. 2 -- The Scottish industries exhibition, which was opened at Kelvin Hall here today by Queen Mother Elizabeth, is devoting an unusual amount of time and space to women's fashions and to household goods.

Among the critics of the Administration's anti-recession policy the most vocal, perhaps, are to be found among those who object particularly to its fiscal program. What the economy needs at the present time, this group contends, is increased purchasing power, and the way to create that purchasing power is by a policy of deficit financing.

TRENTON, Sept. 2 -- Thomas B. Faherty, a key defendant in the investigation of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman's irregularities, surrendered today to state investigators and was interrogated for three hours behind closed doors.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- The Ministry of Native Affairs has informed municipalities that Negro courts will be introduced in Negro towns, where Negro labor lives in the white portion of South Africa.

Joe Jones, the 4-year-old owned by Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, gave Conn McCreary an excellent opportunity to display his riding talents in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. McCreary made the best of the occasion, and guided the son of Stymie to a length victory over Combat Boots in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event.

The New York Shipping Association broadened and strengthened its organization yesterday to meet what many shipping and stevedore executives believe will be a crucial year in waterfront labor-management relations.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Stan Lopata's three-run homer in the third inning -- his tenth of the season and fourth off Harvey Haddix -- today led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals as Robin Roberts posted his nineteenth triumph.
Taking the labor out of Labor Day is a theme for a cooking column that should appeal to those charged with meal preparation over the week-end.

EVERY day more tenants are abandoning Bible House, the big, old-fashioned, red brick and brownstone pile in Astor Place that has turned out 77,000,000 copies of the Scriptures in hundreds of languages.
One crucial baseball series having been concluded here yesterday, another gets under way tonight, as the Yankees and the Indians turn over the local spotlight to the Giants and the Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- "Now, that [54 of 64 Administration projects approved by the Eighty-third Congress], after all, is a batting average of .830. And any baseball fan will tell you that's pretty good going in any league." (The President at Denver, Aug. 23.)

HOLLAND, Mich., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A consistent Kingston Yacht Club crew from Ontario, content to take a back seat until today, won the Sears Cup in the final race of the four-day junior sailing regatta at the Macatawa Bay Yacht Club.

The National Labor Relations Board charged yesterday that the New York Shipping Association and its member companies had discriminated illegally against longshoremen who were not members, of the old International Longshoremen's Association.
The Police Department, reversing the action of the chief of its Brooklyn Morals Squad, gave its blessing yesterday to bingo games that raise money for worthy causes and exclude professional gamblers.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept 2 -- Averell Harriman,, a candidate fod the Democratic nomination for Governor, told the Orange County Democratic Committee tonght that revelations of wrongdoings had hit close to the Governor.

In your issue of Sept. 1 you publish an interesting story regarding Boston's Old North Church and Paul Revere's ride. Your writer rates above the average in giving credit to two little-known men: Robert Newman, who hung the lanterns in the church tower as a signal light that the British were coming by sea, and William Dawes Jr., who rode with Paul Revere to warn the Americans at Lexington and Concord.
Guenther Baumgart has become executive director of the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association, Chicago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- A dozen Dodgers went to the plate and seven of them scored in the fourth inning today at Wrigley Field. That was the big contribution to a 10-2 victory over the Cubs which sent the Brooks winging homeward tonight three games back of the idle first-place Giants.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2 -- The first issue of Southern School News, a sixteen-page tabloid devoted exclusively to problems arising out of the Supreme Court decision against segregation in the public schools, was published today by the Southern Education Reporting Service.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- An American arriving in almost any country of Western Europe feels like a millionaire and often is treated like one. Arriving in the Soviet Union he feels poor, and something of a cheap skate as well.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Jackie Robinson and Peewee Reese were fined $75 and $50, respectively, today by Warren Giles, National League president, for their conduct in the ninth inning of last Tuesday's game in Milwaukee.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- The first attempt to break a strike in Detroit since 1939 will be made tomorrow by the Square D Company, electrical manufacturer. The United Electrical Workers Union, which was expelled from the Congress of Industrial Organizations five years ago as Communist-dominated, has been on strike at the company's Detroit plant since June 15.
The new offices of the City Department of Labor, occupying the fifth floor of a commercial building at 93 Worth Street, were opened yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France is expected to reorganize his Cabinet when it meets tomorrow to consider the resignations of three more ministers because of the defeat of the European Defense Community treaty.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill, Sept. 2 (UP) -- An Army court-martial board overruled defense objections today and agreed to admit as evidence the tape recording of a broadcast Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming allegedly made for the Communists in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The special Senate committee considering the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy completed the formal presentation of evidence today. It will probably be ready next Tuesday to start hearing his defense.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 2 -- Jordan charged today that 800 Israeli soldiers had attacked several Jordanian villages northwest of Jerusalem. The incident led King Hussein to warn that his country might be forced to "reconsider" its compliance with the Holy Land truce.

The third program of the New York City Ballet in its season at the City Center last night was by no means the strongest program in the world as far as repertory goes, but it was extremely well danced, well groomed and well presented, after the manner of this company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The American Legion urged today the immediate rearming of West Germany.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Yesterday's upturn in wheat continued in the early trade today. Buying interest flagged later, however, and an increase in profit taking caused a material recession from the day's price tops.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 3 -Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, ruled out today a West German-United States deal on rearmament and sovereignty at the expense of France. However, he continued to attack the Government of Pierre Mendes-France, the French Premier.
Permit me to make some brief comments on M. Samir Ahmed's letter published in The New York Times on Aug. 16:

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- Sept. 3 -- An attack by Israeli soldiers Wednesday night on Jordanian villages in the Latrun area was condemned today by the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission. Two Arab Legionnaires were reported to have been killed, four wounded, and three kidnapped.
NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- Charges that the Englewood Bard of Education discriminated against Negroes in revising school district boundaries will be aired at a public hearing in Trenton on Sept. 28.
Traffic costs mounted yesterday for a 24-year-old secretary who last Friday was accused of twice trying to run down an off-duty policeman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Air Force is laying out a 5,000-mile firing range in the South Atlantic for tests on new, long-range guided missiles.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Following the resignation of three of his ministers who had favored ratification of the European Defense Community treaty, Premier Pierre Mendes-France considerably reorganized his Cabinet today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- Two hundred thousand private homes are under construction in the Soviet Union the Government newspaper Izvestia disclosed today.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 3 -- Garbled voices and crackling static filled a courtroom here today as eleven officers listened to two monitored recordings of alleged propaganda broadcasts made by American prisoners of war in Korea in April, 1951.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The eighth United Nations General Assembly, which has been in recess since Dec. 8, 1953, will be called to order at 3 P. M. Sept. 20 to close its session formally.

Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Coast Guard's Eastern Area, announced yesterday that Capt. Carl B. Olsen had been appointed to his staff as area air and operations officer. Captain Olsen will replace Capt. Theodore J. Harris, who is retiring from the Coast Guard.
Charley Norkus, the ex-Marine heavyweight from Port Washington, L. I., took a split decision from Cesar Brion of Argentina, in a slow ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

WINNIPEG, Ont., Sept. 3 -Canada's largest grain elevator company, Searle Grain, Ltd., yesterday estimated the Western Canadian wheat crop at 366,788,000 bushels. This represents a drop of more than 213,000,000 bushels from last year's production and is 100,000,0O0 less than the estimate made by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics on Aug. 13.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 6 -Four railcar baby clinics, the only ones of their kind in the world, will roll this year 30,000 miles across the western plains of New South Wales.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The cargo airlines asked President Eisenhower today to take another look at the national aviation policy he recently approved.
The world series will open in a National League park on Wednesday, Sept. 29, and, barring two contingencies (three, including the weather), will go to its conclusion without a day's interruption.

Today's new film, at the Stanley Theatre, is a Russian-made musical package in Sovcolor titled "Stars of the Russian Ballet," comprised of excerpts from three ballets, "Swan Lake," "The Fountain of Bakhchisarai" and "The Flames of Paris."
DENVER, Sept. 3 -- President Eisenhower has approved bills terminating Federal supervision over some of the Indian tribes in Utah.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Gene Baker's double off the rightfield screen drove in the tying and winning runs in the ninth inning tonight as the Chicago Cubs edged the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3. It was the Cards' sixth straight defeat. The box score:

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Butcher hogs advanced 25 to 50 cents today while sows held steady today as salable receipts, totaling 4,000, fell 1,000 under the advance estimate. It was the third straight day of advance. The market plunged to 1954 lows Tuesday. Today's report of the Department of Agriculture follows:

DETROIT, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Bill Tuttle's tenth-inning single drove in Hoot Evers from second base tonight to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles before 15,611 fans at Briggs Stadium.

Two six-story apartment houses at 2895 and 2995 Botanical Square in the Bronx have been sold by K. R. F. Associates to an investor. The buildings contain 185 apartments and seven stores. They are assessed at $680,000 and were sold subject to a first mortgage of $482,500.
The American Federation of Labor dock union removed its picket line yesterday from Pier 32, North River.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ted Williams became the fifth leading home run hitter in major league history tonight with a two-run blast, his twenty-fifth this year, that sparked the Boston Red Sox to an 11-1 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics. Williams leads all active players in the home run department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Supreme Court has not yet set a deadline on when public schools across the country must open their doors to all comers, regardless of race.
HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 3 -Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, commander of the fallen Dienbienphu fortress, has been released by the Vietminh.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and closed 8 to 18 points down on active months.
DENVER, Sept. 3 -- In the name of safety, President Eisenhower issued a "fool the experts" appeal to all car drivers today.
It would be difficult to excel the effrontery of the Chinese Reds in taking members of the Attlee party for a conducted tour of the Kailan Mines.

The State of Connecticut announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 21 on an issue of $6,990,000 of bonds to finance various public improvements. Dated Oct. 1, 1954, the bonds will come due annually on Oct. 1 from 1955 to 1984.
MANILA, Saturday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Secretary Dulles declared today that "if the Philippines were attacked, the United States would act immediately."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -The Hardwood Plywood Institute, claiming severe industry losses, announced today it had asked for tariff increases and quotas on cheaply produced foreign hard plywoods.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 31.8 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports wired to The New York Times yesterday by regional associations. Shipments were down 31 per cent and orders 17.5 per cent. Following are the statistics in thousands of board feet.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- A fleet of forty-three sailing yachts, the largest in the event's history, started on the twentieth annual race from Stamford to Martha's Vineyard and return tonight.
The New York City Health Department announced yesterday that the peak of 1954 polio incidence apparently had been reached.
