CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Larry Doby smashed a tie-breaking home run high into Comiskey Park's right field stands tonight, giving a 3-2 victory to the Cleveland Indians over the Chicago White Sox. The result enabled the Tribe to maintain its 3 1/2- game American League lead over New York.
A 74-year-old man fought off two thugs, one with a pistol and the other with a blackjack, when they tried to rob him yesterday morning. He carried a $437 payroll.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Fred Hawkins of El Paso, Tex., celebrated his thirty-first birthday today with a 32, 32 -- 64 over the Firestone Country Club's 6,620-yard par-72 course for a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $15,000 Rubber City open golf tournament. His two-round total was 134.
The Soviet Government appears to have ordered a major expansion of civilian defense training.

According to Webster, a town is "any cluster of houses recognized as a distinct place." Using that simple definition, then, a community of homes such as that built on Long Island by Levitt and Sons and called Levittown is a town.

The Ryan Aeronautical Company expects net earnings in the fiscal year to Oct. 31 to be the best in the concern's history, according to T. Claude Ryan, president. Mr. Ryan made this prediction in issuing the nine-month income statement yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Douglas Aircraft Company disclosed today for the first time the details of its proposed DC-8 jet airliner.
The United States Senate, the judiciary and the top clergy of the Roman Catholic Church were among the examples cited yesterday to show that aging persons could be gainfully employed.
Because of a booking jam, a hazard usually encountered at this time of the theatrical season, Horton Foote's "The Traveling Lady" will be moving slower in its course to Broadway.
ROME, Sept. 3 -- Italians have been able to buy so much more in goods and services in the last few years as to indicate that the average person enjoys a much higher level of well-being.
The parlor organ, which was as popular in Grandma's day as television is today, is reappearing in the American home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Primary market prices declined 0.5 to 109.5 (1947-49 -- 100) over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Drops in average prices of farm products and processed foods were responsible, as average prices of industrial materials remained unchanged.

DORVAL, Que., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Graham Greene, British novelist, thanked the United States today for helping him publicize his view on what he called the "hysterical outlook" of United States immigration policy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Patrol films of Arlington Park races indicated today that the California owner, Andrew J. Crevolin, was wrong in his charge that the jockeys were "not trying."

PANAMA, Sept. 3 -- One of President Jose Antonio Remon's last official acts before dropping the reins of government for a week's leave was to direct the Foreign Ministry to rectify immediately racial discrimination against United States Negro tourists by the Republic of Panama.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Two men donned thinking caps in the fifth inning and because they did the Yankees scored an important 9-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight at Griffith Stadium. Casey Stengel, an old, ambitious manager, who is aiming for a sixth straight New York pennant and Jerry Snyder, a young, ambitious shortstop for the Nats, were the principals as age triumphed.

Minor traffic jams developed and crowds formed yesterday afternoon at Columbus Circle and Fifty-ninth Street, but it all was in good fun. To the tune of "Wearing of the Green," and with flags waving, members of the seventh annual Flight of the Gaels were preparing to return to the land of the green.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 3 -- The only major novelty of the Edinburgh Festival was given in Usher Hall tonight during the concert by the Halle Orchestra, conducted by Sir John Barbirolli. This was the Fourth Symphony of William Wordsworth, born in 1908, a descendant of the poet's brother and a pupil of Sir Donald Tovey.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- New studies based on laboratory tests indicate that gamma globulin offers more protection against polio than it previously was thought to exert, six medical experts reported today in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -Charles F. Kettering, the veteran inventor who originated the electric automobile starter, has devised a starter for dehumidifiers.

The first of a three-volume history by Maj. Gen. J. F. C. Fuller, British military expert and historian, is planned for Sept. 27 publication by Funk Wagnalls. Entitled "A Military History of the Western World," Vol. I will cover from the earliest times to the Battle of Lepanto.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 3 -- Documents purportedly written by Cpl. Claude Batchelor describing him as the Chinese Communists' choice to head a never-realized Communist underground organization in the United States were introduced in evidence at his court-martial today.
The Rev. Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian, will speak at 8:15 P. M. tomorrow at Wainwright House, Milton Point, Rye, N. Y., under the auspices of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World.
Policemen, firemen and hospital workers lost a desperate four-hour battle last night to save the life of a boy overcome by smoke in a fire he started himself while playing with matches.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -About 50 per cent of a $27,000,000 order for railroad equipment for India will go to United States producers, Harold E. Stassen said today.
A new supply and transportation department has been set up by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) with Robert C. Gunness as general manager.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d said today that the Ford Foundation was studying the possibility of offering some of its Ford Motor Company stock to the public, perhaps in about a year.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Play in the sixth round of the championship tournament at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association brought about important changes among the leaders today. The most noteworthy result was the first loss sustained by Jack W. Collins of New York. He lost to Karl Burger, New York.
After four years of controversy the United States Government and the American Export Lines are still at loggerheads over the cost of the liners Independence and Constitution.

It is difficult to reconcile President Eisenhower's criticism of the latest veterans' pension increase with his signature on the bill that gives it effect. The measure (H. R. 9962) opposed by both the Veterans Administration and the Bureau of the Budget, raises by 5 per cent pensions to veterans with permanent and total non-service-connected disability and to dependents of such veterans.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 3 (UP) -A 17-year-old Houston Negro, whose enrollment application was accepted and then rejected by the University of Texas, planned an appeal today to the school's Board of Regents.
A six-family dwelling at 468 Ralph Avenue in Brooklyn has been purchased for cash by Leonard B. Hart, operator, from Michael Kuzmyak. The buyer immediately resold the house to Ramon and Anna Serrano.
American families bought more groceries in July -- $3,105,000,000 worth -- than in any previous month in history, according to Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The New York State Fair will open tomorrow.
ROME, Sept. 3 -- The size and composition of the population of the United States came under scrutiny today at the World Populations Conference here.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The stock market here ended an active week with prices still rising despite profit taking. Sentiment was strengthened by the favorable gold reserve figures for August and by the disclosure that the number of employed last month set a record.

The problem of Cyprus offers an almost ideal case for the application of the modern efforts to carry through democracy and self-determination and to eliminate that much-hated colonialism which has wrought such havoc in Asia and bids fair to repeat in Africa.
Pennant fever in its most virulent form shrank the city last night to the size of a baseball.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 3 -- A Russian general on the military staff committee to the United States was ordered by a Judge here today to appear in court next Friday to prove it was he and not someone else riding in a car ticketed for speeding fifty miles an hour.
The exciting news that two United States Navy ice-breakers have penetrated McClure Strait in the Canadian Western Arctic was announced in your issue of Aug. 28 as a "first."
With the resumption of underwriting activity after Labor Day, local governments will figure prominently in the new capital market.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 3 -- Unique archaeological treasures in Africa are being neglected and even despoiled by the British who should be looking after them, according to Sir Mortimer Wheeler. Sir Mortimer is professor of archaeology at London University and a famous antiquarian.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Sea-born P. Collins Jr., newly elected National Commander of the American Legion, said today he planned to go to President Eisenhower to urge approval of the Legion's foreign and domestic policies.

A recent news item in this paper (especially timely on this very special week-end) told of a motorist who was called to court for exceeding the speed limit in Westchester County and pleaded guilty with a unique explanation. He had taken a newsreel camera in his car and driven in the same area where he had been convicted of speeding, stayed within the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit and photographed twenty-one cars passing him.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 3 -The Government of Denmark has decided that the people of this country are just a little too well off for their own good. It is about to tell them that they will have to take a slight cut in their level of consumption.

A call went out yesterday for a meeting of the Republican State Executive Committee next Wednesday at the Roosevelt Hotel. A primary purpose of the session is to draft an appeal to Governor Dewey to head the Republican ticket again this fall.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies ran their winning streak to five games tonight, combining top-flight pitching and solid hitting for 7 -- 1 and 10 -- 2 victories over the Pittsburgh Pirates. Granny Hamner led the attack with five safeties in nine trips, four of them double.
CAIRO, Sept. 3 -- Egypt's military rulers gave evidence today of embarrassment over dissemination within Egypt of a pro-Western foreign policy statement intended solely for distribution abroad.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Weakness in soybean futures unsettled grain futures on the Board of Trade here today, but there was enough buying support for wheat and corn to make good recoveries from the low spots and to close higher.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Baton Rouge, La., officials refused today to admit thirty Negro children to an all-white school block from Negro homes as an apparent South-wide drive got under way to break down public school segregation.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Jack Dittmer hit a twelfth-inning tie-breaking home run tonight as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 2, in a game interrupted by a 15-minute free-for-all that resulted in the ejection of two players.

FEW wildfowlers seem happy with anything short of a magnum these days, regardless of the type of duck or goose shooting they encounter on local marshes, so Remington Arms has indulged in a corporate shrug and is bringing out the "Wingmaster" slide-action shotgun in twelve-gauge magnum.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The number of French soldiers killed in fighting with Tunisian bandits Wednesday was put at nine today. At least twelve Tunisians were killed, according to French officials in Tunis.

To prevent further food spoilage, Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts yesterday invoked emergency powers to suspend Sunday and holiday closing laws for the Labor Day week-end. Since last Tuesday's hurricane, a million pounds of foodstuffs have spoiled in Massachusetts because of want of electricity and thus of refrigeration.

A closing chapter of the Hukbalahap rebellion in the Philippines has been written with the sentencing of the leader, Luis Taruc, to twelve years in prison and a fine of $10,000. It has been a sordid story of constant falsification, arson, rape, terrorism and murder.
Appeals for highway safety were made yesterday as the Labor Day holiday began under balmy skies and pleasant breezes.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- New York delegates to the National Association of Letter Carriers' convention today won a part victory in their battle against segregation, but failed to abolish dual charters within the organization.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 29 -The dirndl is still one of the most attractive costumes to be seen here. Centuries come and centuries go, but the traditional peasant dress lives on in new and modified forms.
For thirty-three years Al Murphy has been hopping at the wrong end of a bell. Now he plans to do the ringing for awhile.
No action was taken yesterday by the directors of the Advance Aluminum Castings Corporation on a dividend on the common stock normally paid on Sept. 15.

BREATHES there the man with soul so dead who never to himself has said that some day he would make a leisurely voyage in his own boat to the South Seas, sail about the Caribbean at his leisure or even just follow the paddle-wheels of pilot Sam Clemens down the Mississippi, down to New Orleans.? Philip Davenport, an Australian airline pilot, did just that, and tells about it in "The Voyage of 'Waltzing Matilda.'"*
TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- The British Labor party delegation told the Japanese today that peaceful co-existence with Iron Curtain nations would be the best solution of Asian problems.
A cement company is so tired of high gas bills that it has undertaken to drill a natural gas well.
Hamilton Richardson gained the most significant victory of his tennis career yesterday with one of the memorable performances of the season.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A three-member international tribunal today ordered the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome to reinstate Gordon McIntire of Kewanee, Ill., in his $6,000-a-year job, or pay him $11,000 damages for wrongful dismissal.
The appointment of three vice presidents by the National Broadcasting Company was announced yesterday by Sylvester L. Weaver Jr., president of the television and radio broadcasting organization.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 3 -- The Curtis Cup returned to American custody again as the United States women's golf team defeated the British Isles, 6 to 3.

" Cherchez la femme," that old stand-by of crime detection, led the police yesterday to the solution of nineteen muggings in Crotona Park, in the Bronx. Hunt for a woman in a pink blouse, a park robbery victim had told them.
The recent spurt of consternation over the crime problem in New York is, of course, a praiseworthy thing. However, it is certainly not new.

The Vagrancy Handicap will be the main attraction at the Aqueduct race track today. The seven-furlong test for fillies and mares will be run for the fourth time since its inauguration in 1948, and will have an added value of $25,000.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 3 -- Two thousand farm, village and city folk descended today on a sun-baked pasture just north of this normally sleepy town to view the ninety-eighth annual Flemington Agricultural Fair.
OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -There was new hope in Canadian Government quarters today that Canadian natural gas may eventually get an export outlet in the western United States.

The Kiw Realty, developer of shopping centers, has purchased a business parcel on Karkfield Avenue in East Northport, L. I., from Charles Johnson and will improve it with a retail store center. Carll S. Burr Jr., Inc., was the broker.

The spot September coffee position fell 115 points and the deferred September option 50 points yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Almost all the other positions were up the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit. Volume was 144,500 bags, the second most active trading day of the year.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- A back-to-work movement at the Square D Electrical Manufacturing Company, invited in quarter-page advertisements in Detroit newspapers, brought ninety-nine of 1,200 former employes back to their jobs today.

Wall Streeters on the "long side" of the market were pleasantly surprised yesterday. While many traders, before the opening gong, had expected considerable evening up of commitments before the three-day recess over Labor Day, the list instead moved ahead in slow dealings.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Dockworkers Union, A. F. L., and the Puerto Rico Steamship Association today signed a wage agreement to end the Puerto Rican dock strike.

During a recent trip to London and Paris I was impressed by the fact that these cities of millions accomplish their activities without the nerve-racking and economically deteriorating traffic jams for which my native city of New York is all too well known.

ABOARD U.S.S. SALEM, Sept. 3 -- Six-nation maneuvers in the Mediterranean will reach a climax tomorrow when this powerful task force of the United States Sixth Fleet launches an amphibious attack on a beach held by "enemy forces" on the west coast of Turkey.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams has called out selected specialists of the Michigan National Guard to help handle traffic in the Labor Day weekend.

John J. Lynch will retire Sept. 30 as Brooklyn's Commissioner of Borough Works to become a vice president of the Kings County Trust Company. The announcement was made yesterday by Chester A. Allen, president of the trust company.
DENVER, Sept.3 -- Peacetime espionage became a crime punishable by death today as President Eisenhower signed the seventh bill passed by Congress to combat communism in the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The Marquess of Reading, Minister of State in the Foreign Office, left by air today for Manila at the head of a British delegation of forty to the Southeast Asian defense talks starting Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Bing Crosby and Renee Jeanmaire, the French ballerina, will be co-starred in Cole Porter's "Anything Goes," which Paramount will film next January in its Vista Vision big-screen system.

It could have been that the beginning of the end of Brooklyn's reign in the National League was written across the brilliantly illuminated green of the Polo Grounds last night as Leo Durocher's Giants upended the Dodgers, 7 to 4.

A consistent theme has been running through all the news and comments on the rejection by France of the European Defense Community. Put in the form of a question the issue is this: "Why does Britain refuse to join the E. D. C. or some form of a European Army?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Administration moved today to cut short the quarrel between the Atomic Energy Commission and the Tennessee Valley Authority, which has delayed completion of the disputed Dixon-Yates power contract.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 3 -- State Senator Edgar A. Brown was nominated tonight by the State Democratic Executive Committee to succeed United States Senator Burnet R. Maybank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Construction continued to boom in August, with expenditures setting a record of $3,600,000,000. The figure was announced today in a joint report by the Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Thursday totaled 473 pints of blood. At the F M. Schaefer Brewing Company, 430 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, 157 pints were given for a sister and brother suffering from Cooley's anemia.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Bob Bowen of Los Angeles piloted a Shadoff Special over the Salt Flats at 248.26 miles per hour today for a national speed record.
RECIFE, Brazil, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, called on Jews throughout the world today to help Israel become strong and great.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The British Government is satisfied that its efforts to achieve a new basis for West Germany's rearmament are off to a reasonably good start.

TRENTON, Sept. 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said here today that, so far as he knew, no favors had been done for him, either as Governor or Governor-elect, by any employe of the State Division of Employment Security.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 3 -- Mme. Rose-Marie Ollier, formerly second secretary at the French Embassy in Canberra, has been arrested in Noumea, New Caledonia, following testimony by Vladimir Petrov, Soviet espionage agent who defected.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 3 -- Frank Harned of Rock Spring scored a 1-up victory on the twenty-second hole over Otto Greiner of Knickerbocker in the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State P. G. A. tournament at the Shackamaxon Country Club today.

" Phew! that was a rough one." Those were the first words Leo Durocher spoke when he followed the Giants into their dressing room after their spectacular come-from-behind triumph over the Dodgers last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A new demand was made today that the Internal Revenue Service again examine the status of Facts Forum.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Two research ships from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at La Jolla, Calif., may have made the deepest ocean sounding yet achieved by man.

Jerome Robbins' "Interplay" had its first presentation of the season last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center. Its performance has greatly improved since it was added to the repertoire several seasons ago, but it is still manifestly not up this company's alley.

MANILA, Sept. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, arrived today for the conference aimed at creating a Southeast Asia defense alliance. He also will be chief United States delegate in conferences with Filipino leaders dealing with the further implementation of the Philippine-United States Mutual Security Agreement.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Philip Scott, 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Gray brothers of East Providence, R. I., and driven by Frank Safford, won the $15,000 invitation Harvest Moon Pace by a neck from Prince Adios at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The special committee that is considering the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was defended by its chairman today. He said it was "as fair a group as you can find in the Senate."

One of the outstanding achievements of the last session of Congress was the new Social Security law whose enactment was completed when President Eisenhower affixed his signature last Wednesday. The law puts ten million more Americans under its protection, raises contributions and benefits for millions and brings us closer to a universal system of minimum social security than ever before in our history.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -- Seven foreign missionaries -- four Americans, two Italians and a Frenchman -- have been asked to leave India becouse of "objectionable conduct," Deputy Home Minister B. N. Datar has announced in Parliament. He did not disclose the names or affiliations of the missionaries.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Some rough going still lies ahead for the nation's smaller auto companies despite the mergers that made three companies out of six.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York came out yesterday in favor of a police crack-down on bingo games operated by churches and charitable organizations.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3 -- Evidence of what may be a sizable iron deposit in the Northwest Territories just north of Saskatchewan was discovered late last month during an aeromagnetic survey, it was announced today by the Ministry of Mines.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Government's tax claim of more than $7,500,000 against the late W. T. Rawleigh, Midwest patent medicine figure, has been settled for $600,000.
The term "bean-hole beans" is familiar to many Americans, especially in New England, but probably few have cooked or eaten the legumes prepared in this manner.

Brewing machinery and capital from New York, a brewmaster from Czechoslovakia and malt and bottles grown and manufactured in Israel combined last week to bring to the New York market one of its largest single shipments of imported bottled beer.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Sept. 4 -- Chinese Communist artillery bombarded two Nationalist-held islands off the China coast for more than five hours yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -Short - term borrowing costs of the Treasury, which topped 1 per cent last week for the first time in more than four months, have dropped slightly.
Your story of Aug. 25 concerning explorers on an Arctic trip finding greater snow geese without feathers, deserves top rating for the past six months, I am sure.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 3 -Brazilian Communists have intensified their propaganda against the United States and are turning it into a weapon against their own Government. They now accuse the Government of being a satellite of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- More Italian, Greek and Dutch relatives of American citizens than previously were allowed will be able to enter the United States under an amendment to the Refugee Relief Act of 1953.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Five persons were found dead today in the worst Alaska disaster involving a Government civilian agency airplane.

The happy ending to the Chasanow case reflects credit on the Navy, though the concept of security risk should, of course, never have been stretched so far as to give rise to a Chasanow case in the first place.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A Point Four official in Iran, Robert Alexander, has been ousted in a dispute over United States financial policy on Iranian utility jobs.

Motorists were warned yesterday to use extreme caution when going over hills designated as potentially hazardous by the State Traffic Commission. Otherwise they are likely to run into highway law violations.

The discount ogre in the old-line retailer's nightmare is a multiheaded monster. Its most familiar visage is the highly publicized discount store, but the traditional merchant is equally tormented by some other manifestations.

Two principal arguments were advanced by opponents of flexible price supports in the recent debate in Congress over the Administration's farm bill. These were that, (1) reducing support prices does not discourage overproduction; and, (2) little, if any, of the benefits of a temporary reduction in support levels would, in any event, be passed along to the consumer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The support price of next year's wheat crop may drop to about $2.06 a bushel under the new farm law, Government experts said today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- Denmark's Social Democratic Government announced today that the country might have to undergo a period of slight unemployment to get the economy out of its somewhat overextended condition.
IN this country, repertory is a dirty word. Mention a repertory theatre to some people and they think you belong in a side street somewhere and should charge two pins for admission.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 -- The people of Israel have been put through the wringer by events of recent months in the Eastern Mediterranean area. Iraq is to receive a United States arms grant. Egypt gets the Suez base and an offer of aid from the United States.
DIKILI BEACH, Turkey, Sept. 4 -- United States Marines played a familiar role in a strange setting today.

ISLIP, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Police agencies in western Suffolk County have been ordered to crack down on teen-age hoodlums who have been causing disturbances, engaging in gang fights and racing through residential areas in automobiles.

FOR young readers interested Lincoln there's no shortage of good books. Virtually every phase of his life has been chronicled many times over. Last year we had "Three Rivers South," a distinguished story by Virginia S. Eifert describing one of Lincoln's trips to New Orleans.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer refused tonight to accept the verdict of the French National Assembly in rejecting the European Defense Community treaty.

IT'S a lucky day that brings along a book like Donald Hamilton's SMOKY VALLEY (Dell, 25 cents). The two plot situations are trite -- the big shot who wants to hog the whole range and the tenderfoot who makes good when the chips are down -- but they're woven into a story that has everything calculated to make an exciting Western.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Bobby King, a 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Arthur McConville of Ogdensburg, Va., and driven by Del MacTavish, won the Oregon Pace in 2:12 over the mile and one-sixteenth distance tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

Four to six tropical cyclones build up to hurricane force each year and move out of the region of the equatorial doldrums into the Gulf of Mexico or up to the north and east along the Atlantic Coast. Fortunately, not many hurricanes come ashore.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 4 -- Two moves were made last night to fill this state's vacancy in the Senate: A Republican faction tried unsuccessfully to certify a candidate and a Charleston County mayor started a Democratic write-in campaign for J. Strom Thurmond.
FOR those who are interested in art history and the mysteries that obscure its pages, the problem of the Spanish Civil War edition of the Goya etchings is fascinating.

INDOCHINA is the backdrop for this tensely written story of My-Diem, the beautiful Annamite girl who played many roles -- Vietminh agent, wife, mistress -- and none successfully. The two Frenchmen who love her -- Andre and Lastin -- are in striking contrast.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 4 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, commander of the United States Eighth Army, announced today that United States logistic advisers to the South Korean Army would be withdrawn this month. A major effort of United States military forces in Korea lately, he said, has been to build up Korean logistic support units.

IN Manila this week eight nations, led by the United States, Britain and France, will meet to discuss the military defense of Southeast Asia. Their task will not be made easier by the fact that most of the Asians whom they seek to protect will view their efforts with suspicion and even antagonism.
When new Public School 201 opens this month, the Board of Education and Queens College will launch a pilot project to help new teachers.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Shelley Mann, 16-year-old Arlington, Va., high school swimming star, swam the 100-meter butterfly breast-stroke event in 1 minute 14 seconds today -- 2.6 seconds faster than the world record of 1:16.6 established five days ago at Turin, Italy, by Jutta Langeau of East Germany.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- The system of international trade among the Western nations is in a delicate state. Just how delicate will be clearer at the end of this month, when the world's top financial authorities will have had their annual conference in Washington at the meeting of the Boards of Governors of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Nine Canadians arrived in New York yesterday after a twelve-day, 425-mile canoe trip from Montreal. They looked tired.
First Army's headquarters staff on Governors Island now has a "duplicate" of itself.
MANILA, Sept. 4 -- Events in Manila this week have sharpened differences among Asians in the realm of foreign relations.

GUATEMALA -- The military Junta governing this country since the recent revolution was dissolved last Wednesday and with Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas occupying the presidency, Guatemala is making a real effort to restore its tourist industry.

DENVER, Sept. 4 -- The ship mortgage bill to facilitate private financing of new ship construction had President Eisenhower's approval today. It was one of the last four bills of the 1954 session of Congress that he signed.
Importers are finding it hard to work up much enthusiasm for the Customs Simplification Act signed last week by President Eisenhower.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Maj. William Hancock, an Army officer from El Paso, Tex., won the individual national trophy pistol match today as the national rifle and pistol championships ended.

FAR up along the storm-torn Connecticut coast are two exhibitions of contemporary painting and sculpture, well-worth visiting if only for the fact that some of the best participating artists have so far escaped the dragnet of New York dealers.

THOUSANDS of trees, many of them noble old specimens, were destroyed by Hurricane Carol which ripped across eastern Long Island and lower New England last Tuesday. Countless others that were not blown over suffered mangled tops, broken limbs and cracked or torn branches.

The hurricane "Carol" sideswiped NewYork City but had little adverse effect on retail sales. The sun came out on the afternoon of the day the hurricane hit and so did shoppers. This pexmitted stores to lift sales more than 20 per cent above the level of the same week of last year, according to retail observers.

A Mormon missionary, a ranchman knocked out by the fiery drought of the Thirties, and a hustling lease buyer in the best Western oil industry tradition, would seem ill-fitted to head a thriving independent oil refinery. Actually, they get along together very well for they are all in the person of Glenn E. Nielson, president of the Husky Oil Company of Cody, Wyo.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- The French and Tunisian Governments began formal negotiations in Tunis today to put the tightly controlled French protectorate on the road to internal autonomy.

THE last of Charles Beard's many battles, the one against the foreign policy of Franklin Roosevelt, was his hardest and bitterest. It lost him many friends and left other friends divided in their loyalties and hesitant in his defense.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Between now and November the voters will be hearing a lot about two gentlemen named Dixon and Yates who are in the business of generating and selling electricity.

The Giants routed the Dodgers, 13 -- 4, yesterday with a seven-run seventh inning that was marked by Henry Thompson's four-run homer. The victory increased the Giants lead to five games. The Yanks lost to the Senators, 5 -- 2, in a night game, but stayed three and a half games behind the Indians, who bowed to the White Sox, 8 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, director of the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department, said today that there was just no such thing as a "typical American working woman."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The possibility that President Eisenhower would make an appearance at the American Federation of Labor convention in Los Angeles Sept. 23 was being discussed here today.

WHEN crickets forsake the garden for the warmer recesses of the house it is time for house plants to leave the garden too. Of course bringing plants indoors now requires more than a little determination of purpose for September is a beguiling month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Canada gave the United States today her reasons for favoring a full meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on ways to arm West Germany.

"AT the very western coast of Ireland in a new and strange town called Drumcoole" at about the turn of the century, Mordecai Lippman paused in his flight from Russia. To him in time came other Jewish refugees.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- According to two leading Soviet scientists, the time when criticism in biological science was surpressed in the Soviet Union has passed.

Trevor-Roper's "World War I -- Start of an Age of Violence" (Aug. 1): "Documentary sources establish that the Russian General Staff as early as July 11 regarded war with Germany as imminently inevitable and that on July 30 Russian general mobilization against Germany and Austria began."
WATERFORD, Mich., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Puerto Rican policeman was established today as the man to beat for the all-gauge title in the fifteenth annual National Skeet Shooting Association championships.
HARTFORD, Sept. 4 -- Out-of-state trips taken by Gov. John Davis Lodge during his three and a half years in office have become a major campaign issue in Connecticut.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 4 -- When school bells start ringing in the northern New Jersey metropolitan area next week, they will open the most crowded classrooms many of these communities have ever known.

THERE is something supremely refreshing about a plain, unpretentious film that is much more concerned with characters than it is with performers of charades and more inclined to pictorial naturalism than to excessive scenic size -- especially when it happens to come off exceptionally well.

VIENNA, Sept. 4 -- A note embodying rejection by the Western powers of recent Soviet proposals for a new four-power conference has been sent to Vienna for consideration before being forwarded to Moscow. The conference proposal is rejected unless Russia should agree to free all-German elections and withdrawal of occupation troops from Austria.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- New York State had a record number of 241,581 men and women registered June 30 in the fourteen professions governed by the Board of Regents.

"I see where the experts are begging one another to stop blaming parents for everything that happens to a child," a young mother told us recently. "I wish the self-appointed safety specialists on this block would take up the same idea.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A three-week strike of 25,000 Firestone Tire and Rubber Company workers was settled tonight with a new contract granting the 6 1/2-cent pay increase pattern set in the rubber industry.

A NEW collection of Benedict Arnold relics will go on display at the Fort Ticonderoga Museum tomorrow. The new Arnold material, supplementing a large collection which is to be set out in its own special room when the Fort Ticonderoga East Barracks is completed next year, is the gift of Henry S. Baldwin of Lynn, Mass. Mr. Baldwin is a direct descendant of General Arnold and his first wife.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The obvious best horse is out of the question, but forty other United States thoroughbreds have been lined up as prospective rivals for Queen Elizabeth's Landau and other foreign starters in Laurel's international race on Nov. 3.

RUSSIA'S All-Union Agricultural Exhibition -- which the Soviets call the "largest farm show in the world" -- reopened Aug. 1 after a 15-year lapse and runs for three months. It occupies a 455-acre site on the outskirts of Moscow and is housed in more than 300 pavilions.

BONN, Sept. 4 -- The defeat of the European Defense Community treaty was perhaps more important as a turning point in the collective psychology of the German people than for what it did to United States plans to defend Europe.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Senator Alexander Wiley predicted today that the European Defense Community would yet come into being because it was necessary.

A library of more than 10,000 books and several thousand documents on American Jewish history will be made available next week to schools, libraries and museums throughout the country by the American Jewish Historical Society.

Australopithecus prometheus, the South African fire-using "man-ape" now appears to have been wrongly named. Letters this week in Science, journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and in the British journal Nature, report on a restudy of the charred remains of what has been believed to be evidence of the first use of fire by Stone Age men.

The Adult Education Program of City College's School of General Studies will observe its tenth anniversary this fall with an offering of 300 courses ranging from "How to See Europe on a Budget" to "How to Discuss and Argue Effectively."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Democratic National Committee today charged that "appeasement" by President Eisenhower of Old Guard "know-nothing" Republicans had undermined foreign policy and pushed the nation "remorselessly" closer to war.

To city folks, whose thinking on entertainment and recreation runs to scrabble, color TV and a ringside table at El Gismo. it may be a little surprising that this country still offers diversions they may only have heard about from their elders or read about in rustic novels.

A comprehensive study by Georgetown University of Government aid to shipping by sixty-six nations has shown that the practice of subsidizing merchant shipping is almost world-wide. It also highlights the many ways used by foreign nations in support of shipping in contrast to outright subsidies given by the United States.
HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, underweight and leaning on a cane, returned to freedom today after nearly four months of captivity by the Vietminh.

IN his novel of Burns' last five years, Mr. Barke writes again as a partisan, and few readers of Burns will be sorry that he does. For Burns loved human nature as few men could love it and has in return the love of mankind.

TRENTON, Sept. 4 -- New Jersey public schools will reopen next week with a record enrollment of 840,000 pupils. This marks an increase of 30,000 over last fall. Dr. Frederick Raubinger, State Commissioner of Education, predicts that the enrollment figure will pass the 1,000,000 mark by 1960.
BANGOR, Me., Sept. 1 -- Political storm warnings continued to disturb Maine Republican leaders today as they prepared for the final week's campaigning before the Sept. 13 election.

IN recent months Alfred Sheinwold, a bridge author of long experience and great prestige, and Edgar Kaplan, president of the Greater New York Bridge Association (this week-end conducting one of its major annual tournaments in New York), have been using a new signaling convention that reverses all the old rules.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Only one boat -- Such Crust V, now racing under the name of Trot-Along -- qualified today for Monday's Silver Cup classic on the Detroit River.
The National Association of Rural Educators was formed last week to improve the effectiveness of schools in small communities throughout the country.

Cut back long straggling canes of bush and climbing roses by not more than a quarter of their length. ]Pull out and discard pklox plants with off-color bloom and self-sown seedlings.

MANILA, Sunday, Sept. 5 -- The Philippines attained less than it sought in military assistance in yesterday's conference on the Mutual Defense Treaty with the United States, but got from Secretary of State Dulles the most solid assurance of protection yet given any Asian nation.

Dartmouth College will continue this fall its Teacher Internship Program, begun last year, under a second $35,000 grant from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education. Dartmouth is one of several colleges participating during the present academic year in this educational experiment designed to improve college teaching and to attract promising young men to careers in higher education.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Hal Price Headley's Georgian, a 28-to-1 outsider, upset the highly favored Royal Note today to win the $144,820 Washington Park Futurity by two lengths in record-tying time.

CHERRY PLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- The farmers who coax a living from the hilly woodlands that ring the valley of the Little Hoosic River have embarked on an experimental flood - control program that may set a pattern for small watersheds throughout the nation.

GOOD cooks long have tenderized tough beef by "boiling." Thanks to them, our culinary heritage now includes Austrian boiled beef, the New England boiled dinner and the French pot-au-feu (pot-on-the-fire).
The three-day Labor Day week-end began in fair weather and raised expectations early today that it would end with a national traffic death toll below predictions -- and possibly below average.

In his article on "Japan's 'Second Class Citizens'" (Aug. 22) William Jorden lays great stress upon two facts: (1) most Japanese women vote the way their husbands want them to; (2) a recent survey reports that most women in Japan wish they had been born men.

FANS of the intrepid, matter-of-fact Miss Pickerell, who have gone with her to Mars and undersea, will be delighted with her new adventure -- a rescue trip to the Arctic. If this fourth story is a bit more serious in tone than the earlier books, what it lacks in comic situation is more than compensated for by suspense.
ARRANGEMENTS are being made by the Motor Vehicle Bureau to have inspection stations ready by next May 1 for the compulsory periodic check-ups required under a law passed by the 1954 Legislature.

"Things are getting better all the time," Leo Durocher said yesterday after his Giants had walloped the Dodgers for the second time in a row. "But don't get me wrong. I'm not claiming anything," the Giant manager hastened to add.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Long Island leaders and the men and women who man the production lines at industrial plants in Nassau and Suffolk Counties will rub elbows next Sunday at the fifth annual Hospital Star Nite.

Referee Harry Harris said yesterday he would recommend that a petition designating Assemblyman Daniel M. Kelly as Liberal party candidate for the Assembly from the Seventh District in Manhattan be declared invalid.

MONTREAL, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Montreal Alouettes, led by their hard-charging American linemen, rolled to a 21-2 victory over Ottawa's Rough Riders today in a Big Four football game before 20,563 fans. The contest was televised nationally in the United States.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 4 -- Tommy Bolt of Houston, Tex., set a course record with a 9-under-par 63 today to take the lead with 201 at the end of the third round in the $15,000 Rubber City golf tournament.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The passing and place-kicking of George Blanda, quarterback, gave the Chicago Bears two of their touchdowns and two field goals in a 29-20 football exhibition victory over the Washington Redskins tonight.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 4 (UP) -- A scoring outburst that ran less than two and one-half minutes netted the Philadelphia Eagles 17 points and a victory tonight, 24 -- 13, over the Green Bay Packers at Hershey Stadium.
DARLINGTON, S. C., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Fifteen more strictly stock cars qualified today for Monday's fifth annual Southern 500 race.

ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Sixty-four players entered the open tournament for the championship of the New Jersey State Chess Federation, two rounds of which were completed today at the Orange Y. M. C. A.

The American who depends on any of the multitudinous steel products for health and livelihood and his neighbor about to buy a new suit of clothes may soon be affected by the wave of business mergers sweeping the land.

THIS first novel by a North Carolina author of Scottish antecedents presents a difficult task of appraisal. An historical romance, it develops to a considerable extent along the lines of modern detective fiction in the masking of motivations.
Financing of the nation's expanding network of toll expressways will soon be resumed after a long summer respite.

LAVINIA DAVIS, always a popular story-teller, here provides a blend of mystery, romance, and teen-age problems that is sure to delight the older girls among her audience. "Squeak," as the heroine is affectionately known, is an appealingly helter-skelter youngster, on the verge of growing up, and very conscious of the uncertainties of that age.
DENVER, Sept. 4 -- President Eisenhower extolled the value of free labor in a free country in a Labor Day statement today.

"To understand all is to pardon all," the French say. Commentators on this side of the Atlantic are just now applying that adage to the fiasco of the E. D. C. debate in the French National Assembly, trying to understand the French, with a view to pardoning their lapse from all that was expected of them.

LESLEY BLANCH has had the engaging idea of making a portrait gallery of four nineteenth - century European women whose lives are woven into the history of North Africa and the Near East. She has chosen well. One, the cousin of Josephine Beauharnais, became the mother of a Sultan of Turkey.

SOME of television's fifteen-minute musical shows have become entangled in their own production webs. Judging from two premieres last week, the musical show is detracting from its basically winning personality by trying to be overly clever. There is a premium on cuteness, gag situations and silly story lines -- anything to prevent a viewer from enjoying the music.

In 1939, when Seymour J. Phillips became president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, which makes the Van Heusen line of shirts, the company was operating at a loss. Sales volume was below $5,000,000 and the advertising budget was a weak $7,500.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UP). -- Paul Richards said today it would take a "terrific offer" to lure him away from the Chicago White Sox, but both he and General Manager Frank Lane said there had been no discussion of a new contract for the team's manager.
Tony Trabert's one-year reign as national champion ended yesterday in the Forest Hills Stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 4 -- Expectations of an early conference of the Colombo powers to discuss issues pertaining to Southeast Asia were revived today with publication of a New Delhi report that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India had called an urgent meeting of Indian diplomats in Southeast Asia.

Beauty of fabric and attention to detail are the characteristics of Italian design. Unlike the French, Italian couture makes no attempt to revolutionize fashion trends. Evening gowns of luxurious materials and embroideries are designed for continental women who dress elaborately for formal affairs.

The German people, 70,000,000 strong, comprise the most powerful nation between the North Atlantic and the Soviet Union. They command the crossroads of Europe. Germany's Rhenish provinces border on the Rhine and worship with Rome. The bleak Prussian plain faces East toward Poland, the Baltic lands and Russia. Bavaria shares the Danube basin with the Balkans.
Among the 31,000,000 children who will be returning to school this month will be 700,000 who are mentally retarded to the degree that they need special assistance.
BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 4 -- The development of Hell's Canyon, for years a controversial subject, has become the sharpest campaign issue Idaho has known since 1950.

DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 4 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker, the nation's riding champion, today booted home six consecutive winners, including Fair Molly in the featured $31,250 added Del Mar Debutante, for his best day of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (UP) -- A two-run outburst in the sixth inning, capped by Joe Taylor's run-producing single, gave the Philadelphia Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox today at Connie Mack Stadium.

BADLY buffeted by last Tuesday's hurricane, the northeastern coast's vacation areas worked feverishly to get in shape for a Labor Day week-end that could make or break what had been a middling season. By the time week-enders arrived, most shore resorts were ready to handle them, although many beach installations and hundreds of boats were smashed by the combination of wind and water.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT EISENHOWER, Sept. 4 -- Taking the "high road" over four Western states, President Eisenhower viewed nature's beauties and devastations on a 1,540-mile air tour today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Units of the United States Far Eastern naval force have put to sea as a result of Communist China's artillery bombardment of the Quemoy Islands.

THOMAS HARDY has been fortunate in the number of excellent books devoted to him. The author of the latest of these (no relation of her namesake and subject) is an English critic who has previously written studies of Swift and Donne.

Mrs. Walter B. Devereux has been named chairman of the fifth annual Animal Kingdom Ball to be held at the Pierre on Jan. 27. The dinner dance will benefit the new adoption service clinic of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Navy estimated today that the Soviet Union would supplant the United States as the world's leading naval power in ten years at the present rate of Soviet expansion.

Elated as they must be by the results of the Geneva conference and the death of the European Defense Community, Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and his colleagues undoubtedly are concentrating their attention now on how to take advantage of these developments.

Coffee prices have fallen sharply since Brazil altered her exchange rate on Aug. 16. Santos 4 grade (the base of most coffee consumed in this country) dipped to the lowest level of the year early last week. During the latter part of the week, prices began to climb again.

FOLK music fans and devotees of early music are apt to move in different circles. But since many folk songs are very old it seems likely that sooner or later there will be a rapprochement between the two groups. Columbia's Ballads of Long Ago represents a step in that direction, for it brings together the folk song team of Marais and Miranda and the Pardo Ancient Instrument Ensemble.

THORNTON WILDER'S "The Matchmaker" has caused a sharp division here, both among members of the ordinary public and among the critics. Since it is described as a farce, something of the sort was to be expected.

IN his latest novel, Robert F. Mirvish continues to improve in his handling of language, but in other respects falters. Conflict rages, exotic scenes unfold. But the people of the story, except in glimmers, do not really come to life.
HOLYOKE, Mass., Sept. 4 -- Frederick H. Cramer, 48, Professor of History at Mount Holyoke College, was born in Berlin in 1908, a son of a wealthy shipline owner.

ONE of the first visitors to the Denver White House this summer came away with the news that President Eisenhower's golf game isn't what it ought to be because he can't concentrate. This the caller got from the President himself two days after he arrived last month.
A PERIOD of suspense ended last week for Robert Montgomery and his associates in the production of the dramatic series which opens its fall season on the evening of Monday, Sept. 20, on N. B. C.-TV.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Twelve of fifteen classes failed to finish in the eighty-second fall regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today.

Last week both parties were kneading the statistics for fair in the hope of fashioning the image of victory in the struggle for control of the Eighty-fourth Congress. Each was successful enough to scare the other.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Gene Baker again provided the margin for the Cubs tonight as Chicago sent the St. Louis Cardinals to their seventh straight loss, 6 -- 5.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The wholesale district here reported a satisfactory level of business this summer as warm weather contributed to a marked reduction in retail inventories of soft lines and spurred reordering of merchandise.

SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 4 -- Another step in the Government's effort to counter the most formidable "secret weapon" of enemy nations -- "brain-washing" -- was signified in the opening here this week of the court-martial of Corp. Claude Batchelor.

British-American cooperation in studying the economic and social problems of our two countries has fortunately become so customary as to be almost commonplace. This fact, however, may tend to obscure the significance of a report, recently published at Cornell University on the wartime and post-war experience of "Milk Marketing in Great Britain," by two American agricultural economists with the willing cooperation of their professional colleagues in the United Kingdom.

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 4 -- The Detroit Lions walloped the New York Giants, 28 -- 13, in an exhibition game between the two National Football League teams before 25,000 fans tonight. Bobby Layne threw two touchdown passes for the victors.
NEWARK, Sept. 4 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, presented his views on "basic campaign issues" at a press conference today.

With the exception of the "small watershed" bill, it is difficult to point to any first-rank positive accomplishment in this area; but it is easy to mention a number of potentially damaging or destructive measures that failed of passage.

RUDOLF BING will not be back from Europe for another two weeks to announce his new singers for the Metropolitan. But engagements at the nation's leading opera house are hard to keep secret and, although singers' managers and agents keep trust with the Metropolitan in not revealing what they are bursting to tell, names have a way of leaking out. Two such leaks occurred last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Senator John C. Stennis said today the report of the Senate committee considering censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy would be issued "within a fairly short time" after the close of the hearings.

IT will not be long before the Mozart jubilee celebrations come to town. The composer was born in 1756 and, from all indications, a good part of the civilized world is making ready to do honor to his memory and his achievement.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 -- Del Crandall's second home run of the game in the eleventh inning today gave the Milwaukee Braves a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The South Korean Defense Minister has advised President Syngman Rhee that the United States expects to begin the "build-up" of South Korean defense forces this month.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The Chicago White Sox took advantage of two Cleveland defensive lapses in the sixth inning tonight and poured across five unearned runs for an 8-5 victory over the Indians.

ON a sultry afternoon in late summer when languor overcomes all of nature's creatures (bees and butterflies excepted), gardeners would do well to abandon routine chores and try their hands at the ancient art of dowsing.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 4 -- West Virginia Republicans are concentrating on the State's First and Second Districts in the hope of narrowing the Democratic advantage in Congressional representation this year -- but the prospects do not appear too bright.

Now that the Labor Day weekend has come and almost gone, instruction classes for current or would-be yachtsmen are being planned by the busy and unselfish skippers of the United States Power Squadrons.

NEARLY every American schoolboy knows that Rutherford B. Hayes was once President of these United States; not all of us are aware that he is also a national hero in Paraguay. The reason: during a war with Argentina in the Eighteen Seventies, which he arbitrated, he ruled that the Chaco area should remain with Paraguay. At least one town there has been renamed Villa Hayes, in his honor.

PAUL GREGORY is "fed up with the theatre" and may well devote all of his time in the future to the gentler business or motion pictures. LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jimmy Logie and Doug Lishman gave Arsenal a 2-0 victory over Tottenham today as a crowd of 54,000 turned out to see the team that tackles Russia's best next month.

THE first new ballet of the season will have its premiere on Tuesday evening when the New York City Ballet presents George Balanchine's "Western Symphony" at the City Center. This is a story-less work in classic form "which derives its flavor" from the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Dean Stone, the 24-year-old freshman southpaw of the Washington Senators, who had not finished a game since July 24 nor won one since Aug. 2, picked a fine spot to reform tonight at Griffith Stadium. It was different on both counts as he went all the way and dealt a damaging 5-2 defeat to the Yankees.

Gimbel, as "most gratifying and encouraging." The Summer Festival season began on June 21 and closes this week-end.
In a Labor Day sermon yesterday the Rev. Ralph Beryl Nesbitt urged that the youth of this country focus their professional aspirations on education, mass communication, government and social service.

BUFFALO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman urged tonight that President Eisenhower back his recent plea for genuine bipartisanship in foreign affairs by steps similar to those taken by the Truman Administration.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Hungarian swimmers captured two more crowns today as the European swimming, diving and water polo championships ended. Altogether they won nine of the eighteen events in the six-day, twenty-two nation tourney.

Unemployment in this state will be a major issue in the November elections, the Democratic State Committee emphasized yesterday. It made public a comparison of 1953 and 1954 labor statistics in support of its charges that Governor Dewey's Administration was putting out "misleading" figures.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- President Eisenhower is alert to the threat to Nationalist China territory, and orders to the United States Seventh Fleet in Far Eastern waters have not been changed, a White House spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission reported yesterday that it had authorized $324,000,000 of natural gas pipeline and booster equipment in the first six months of this year.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- Weary repair crews from all over the East today continued the task of replacing the network of wires that spell electric power and communications in New England. Y., Sept. 5 -- Britain, which has recognized Communist China, is nevertheless prepared to back the United States again in opposing membership in the United Nations for the Peiping regime under present circumstances. The journal was a present from his fiancee, Mrs. Maude Phelps, a widow, and was in honor of the eighth anniversary of their engagement. The cheap quality of its paper was more than atoned for by the hand some leather binding, which Maude had handtooled herself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today the production- consumption pinch which had been blamed for sharp price increases in coffee was about ended.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- France's 1955 budget will reach 3,950,000,000,000 francs, and the deficit of the treasury will be nearly 1,000,000,000,000 francs unless the Government changes the structure and the level of expenditures before the bill goes to Parliament in two months.
In an Aug. 26 editorial headed "Allergic Rhinitis" you remarked that the pollen count has been low this season primarily because of the drought. Boon to the hay fever victim, bust for the farmer.
Suburbanites eat more candy than do city dwellers, according to a survey by Barton's Bonbonniere. As a result of the study, Barton's decided to accelerate its plans to build outlets in the suburbs.

Lowell Thomas, explorer, writer, commentator and president of Cinerama Productions, has been signed to produce "Seven Wonders of the World" in the Cinerama wide-screen process.

The Republic National Bank of Dallas, which at June 30 had resources of $650,944,793, including deposits of $575,726,887, plans to absorb the National City Bank of Dallas. Resources of the latter institution at June 30 stood at $48,119,018 and its deposits amounted to $45,100,199.

CHARLIE GOLDMAN watches every Rocky Marciano workout at Grossinger's critically but worshipfully. It's not too often that he has to make a correction or suggestion as the Rockabye Baby hammers purposefully at sparring partners. SYOSSET, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Mrs. John J. McDonald, joint master of the Meadow Brook Hunt, and Mr. McDonald have offered Hunter's Home, their estate on Woodbury Road, for the Helping Hand Horse Show on Sept. 12, a benefit for the Community Church of Syosset. Mrs. McDonald is show chairman.

" Ugetsu," Japanese - made drama starring Machiko Kyo, Masayuki Mori and Kinuyo Tanaka, will have its United States premiere tonight at the Plaza Theatre. The opening, scheduled for 8:30 o'clock, is being sponsored by the Japan Society.

I., Sept. 6 -- The breakdown in the pooled United States weather services along this battered coast that allowed last week's hurricane to strike without warning to civilians is a mystery which they are determined to solve. The forthcoming revision of its trade agreement with the United States will mark an important turning point in the economy of the Philippine Republic, according to a bulletin issued for publication today by New York University's Institute of International Finance.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- Jerzy Berent, an official of the Population Division of the United Nations, forecast today a progressive "aging" of population in the West during the next fifty years.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The disquieting events in the Far East, coupled with the approaching end of the current bookkeeping account, cast a slight dullness over the stock market today. However, net losses were generally small and a firm undertone prevailed.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 6 -- De Coursey Fales' staysail schooner Nina won the Vineyard Trophy today for the third successive year when none of the rest of the fleet at the Stamford Yacht Club was able to post a better corrected time for the 234-mile event.
Frank Stranahan waved goodbye to golf's amateur ranks yesterday morning as he boarded a plane at Idlewild Airport and flew off to Brazil.
The annual Boys Club Ball will be held Oct. 21 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

SHIPPINGPORT, Pa., Sept. 6 -- With a wave of a neutron wand, President Eisenhower opened the era of atomic power for civilian use today.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 6 -- Members of the British Association for the Advancement of Science were shown samples today of a superfluid whose qualities, described as six-dimensional, may exist naturally only in the stars.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The chief counsel for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said tonight that witnesses would be called in his defense of censure charges.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Support of the public made possible the Federal Supreme Court decision of last May that outlawed segregation in public schools, Lester Granger, executive director of the National Urban League, declared today.

BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Harold Halsted's Chuckle finished third today to lead the three-day series and capture a leg on the William H. Picken Memorial Trophy, symbolic of Star Class supremacy in the week-end regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Peiping radio report that Red China planned to withdraw seven divisions from North Korea "certainly does not bring us any comfort," South Korean Premier Y. T. Pyun said today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 6 -- The Vietminh High Command declared today it had returned all French Union war prisoners held in North and Central Vietnam. A Vietminh broadcast said the return of these prisoners was completed Sept. 4. Fifty-eight French Union prisoners were released on that date at Viettri, forty miles northwest of Hanoi, the broadcast reported.

ATSUGI, Japan, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The guns were unloaded on a Neptune patrol plane attacked by two Soviet MIG's Saturday, but one gunner said today he managed to get in about 150 shots before the patrol plane went down.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department allotted $67,010,000 today to states, territories and possessions for operations of school lunch programs during the school year just getting under way.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A three-member international tribunal ruled today that the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization lacked the authority to order an American it employed in Paris to testify before a Federal grand jury in New York.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Sept. 6 -- The only art festival to be held under the auspices of a church will open here tomorrow night. It will be at the Kirk in the Hills, the pastor of which is the Rev. Dr. Harold C. Dewindt, former minister of the West Park Presbyterian Church in New York.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, hitting well behind Harvey Haddix, sent the Cincinnati Redlegs to their fifth successive defeat today, 8 to 1.

" Prison, Probation or Parole? A Probation Officer Reports," by Paul W. Keve, will be published Friday by the University of Minnesota Press. The author, assistant chief probation officer for the Hennepin County District Court in Minneapolis, recounts the details of some thirty cases he has handled.

The Labor Day week-end, traditionally the nation's last big fling of summer travel, drew to its close last night on highways heavy with traffic. The three-day holiday brought an end to the lives of more than 480 Americans who were killed in accidents, 334 of them by automobiles, seventy-nine by drowning and the others in miscellaneous mishaps.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- "Interlingua," the new international language of science, will be used for the first time at a big medical meeting here next week. The occasion will be the second World Congress of Cardiology, which is expected to attract physicians and researchers from more than forty countries.

The first annual report of the Waterfront Commission is a heartening record of progress toward breaking crime's hold on the docks. The bi-state commission is entitled to public thanks for the vigor with which it has begun its huge task. There is, however, a disturbing overtone of complacency in the commission's estimate of its own accomplishments.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Medley Hanover, a 3-year-old bay filly, owned and driven by Gene Pownall, scored a llength victory over Ceyway in 2:05 4-5 in the Labor Day Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Just Gay was third.
The tennis career of Victor Seixas is the triumph of the racquet over the bat.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 6 -- Chinese Nationalist fighter-bombers heavily bombed the former treaty port of Amoy and Communist-held Tateng (Twatin) Island, off the Fukien coast, today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- A stirring battle between Edward Bergin's Guinevere and Edgar Dunlaevy's Ann Marie for International Class honors was staged today as the Larchmont Yacht Club played host to the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship regatta.

JOANNA LORD was beautiful and smart and the daughter of the owner of The Dispatch. She had the gift of elegance and everyone who did not know about her envied her. Those who knew pitied her, for Joanna had been so badly burned in the country club fire that her arms and body were a mass of scars. Malcolm Archer, Joanna's husband, wanted to love Joanna, but he couldn't.
SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Quick thinking by a young New York business woman was credited today with preventing an explosion aboard a crashed Dutch airliner in the Shannon River.
The 17-year-old cabin boy of a Danish freighter anchored near Bedloes Island was arrested for homicide early yesterday after he admitted throwing the ship's mess boy overboard.

Victor Seixas and Doris Hart were rewarded yesterday for their years of striving to gain the pinnacle of American tennis. They were crowned as the new champions of the United States in the Forest Hills Stadium.

There is much food for reflection in the first installment of Clement R. Attlee's report on his recent trip to Russia and China, printed in these pages today. Those who had feared Mr. Attlee might fall victim to Communist flattery may be partly reassured by this report on Moscow.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The need for rehabilitation of increasing numbers of poliomyelitis victims saved by modern treatment was emphasized today at the opening of the Third International Poliomyelitis Conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- The United States called tonight on the United Nations Security Council to take up the "unprovoked attack" by Soviet planes on a Navy patrol bomber off the Siberian coast.

Controller Gerosa's announcement that New York City has been able to buy in a small amount of noncallable 7 per cent bonds once issued by two towns in Westchester County to build a road completed in 1873 is cause for satisfaction. The last bond in this issue, a curious example of what the Controller calls "horrible public improvement financing," does not mature until the year 2147.
The appointment of Joseph I. Lubin as treasurer of the National Civil Service League is announced by the league's president, Nicholas Kelley.

The $11,228,000 Pulaski Bridge across Newtown Creek, linking Brooklyn and Queens, will be opened to traffic on Friday. It will replace the forty-nine-year-old Vernon Avenue Bridge, which Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen described yesterday as outmoded, beyond repair and in "precarious" condition.

Six national religious leaders appealed yesterday to the chairmen of the Democratic and Republican parties to issue a declaration against racial or religious prejudice in this year's Congressional campaign.

VIENNA, Sept. 5 -- The "new course" proclaimed in Soviet satellite economic policy as a remedy for the failure of the old policy of unrestricted industrialization is now, after slightly more than a year of trial, itself an admitted failure.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 -- Two planes of advanced type were disclosed today as being in production, a new version of the Douglas DC-7 and an all-cargo version of the Lockhead Super Constellation.

The sixty-first observance of Labor Day as a national holiday brought statements yesterday from industrial, labor and church spokesmen hailing achievements in management-labor cooperation and calling for further steps to increase American productivity and standards of living.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Wendell B. Barnes, Small Business Administration chief, said today in a semi-annual report to the White House and Congress that "small firms have continued to lose ground competitively to larger firms" in the last year.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves stormed into second place in the National League pennant race today, blasting the Chicago Cubs, 13 -- 2 and 6 -- 1, before 43,207 fans who raised the County Stadium attendance over the 2,000,000 mark.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- The use of Michigan National Guardsmen to help state and local authorities handle Labor Day week-end traffic appeared tonight to have held down fatalities.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 6 -- Florida's West Coast today looked forward to a new era of tourism and industrial and business expansion as the $21,250,000 Sunshine Skyway was officially opened.
The charter market continued last week to rise both for tankers and freighters.

An attempt by Boston and Philadelphia wool interests to woo the public in the face of competition from man-made fibers is meeting with heartening response, according to the Wool Bureau.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Britain almost certainly will buy more wheat from Canada in the coming crop year, financial experts here predicted today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- South Korea's major industries would be denationalized to encourage foreign investment, under a bill introduced into the National Assembly. However, the proposal is being criticized on the ground that it would open the way to private monopoly.

In a doubly symbolic action which he timed for Labor Day and in which he represented the master magicians of the modern age, President Eisenhower waved a radioactive wand in Denver to break historic ground in two fields in order to turn the unleashed genie of atomic power from purely destructive purposes and convert it into a mighty and tireless servant and benefactor of mankind.

TOKYO, Sept. 6 -- Japan kept close watch today on the opening of the Southeast Asia conference in Manila. She hoped the meeting would result in economic aid from the United States that would benefit this nation directly or indirectly.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- More than a month after a regulation silencing automobile horns went into effect in the Paris region, the French were have discovered that they are not as undisciplined as their detractors often make them out to be.

Futures in frozen poultry were traded for the first time yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Only three lots (30,000 pounds) exchanged hands but brokers said they expected trading to be dull until producers and others in the industry became more familiar with the procedure.

National Airlines, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on June 30, had a record net profit of $4,465,743, equal to $4.42 a share, according to the report released yesterday by G. T. Baker, president and chairman.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 7 -- John Wellington, a 20-year-old junior end for Columbia, suffered a bad shoulder separation in preseason practice at Camp Columbia today. He will be lost to Lou Little's Lions for the entire season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Joan Crawford has signed an agreement with Robert Aldrich, the director-producer, to star in "The Way We Are."
Late travelers from the Labor Day week-end holiday returned to the city yesterday morning in a last-minute rush but there were no serious tie-ups.

Two Brooklyn youths went on trial yesterday before Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz on a charge of first-degree murder. They are accused of "beating, kicking and stomping to death" Thomas A. Condon, 40 years old, of 614 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn, on the night of July 10.

The price of lead advanced a quarter cent a pound yesterday to 14 1/2 cents, New York basis -- the highest quotation since early January of 1953. The increase was initiated by a domestic producer and quickly matched by other sellers.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The stock markets here were less active today than yesterday but the turnover in industrial shares remained high. Further profit-taking was matched by new buying. The undertone, therefore remained firm although price changes again were irregular.

Last night the New York City Ballet presented its first premiere of the season at the City Center. It was "Western Symphony," choreographed by George Balanchine to a specially commissioned score by Hershy Kay deriving from American folk tunes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Republicans and Democrats agreed tonight that Thomas E. Dewey's refusal to seek a fourth term as New York's Governor might have major repercussions in both parties. Not only the election just ahead, but the one two years hence will be affected, they feel.

Governor Dewey after a "rugged summer" of soul searching announced last night his decision not to be a candidate for a fourth term.
