MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey, chided today his Republican opponent, Clifford P. Case, for pledging, if elected, to support President Eisenhower 100 per cent.
White and Negro children sat down in the same classrooms together yesterday for the first time in some parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Forty-six charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were referred by the Senate to the special committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah. The committee combined thirteen of what it felt were the most important charges into the following five categories:

GUATEMALA, Sept. 7 -- The Government expropriated today the assets of eighty-nine former officials, prominent politicians and Communists of the two regimes of former Presidents Juan Jose Arevalo and Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.
Governor Dewey eliminated himself last night as a possible candidate for a Republican re-nomination.

The Temporary Commission on the Courts will hold two days of public hearings on suggestions for improving the management of the courts of New York State, Harrison Tweed, chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States was moving today to erect defenses against what the State Department has called the "threat posed by Soviet imperialism" in the Middle East.

ATHENS, Greece, Sept. 7 -- World Harmony, a 33-190-ton tanker and largest of its kind built in British shipyards, steamed into Phaleron Bay near here today to become the largest unit of the Greek merchant marine. King Paul will raise the Greek flag on her at gala ceremonies tomorrow.

NO matter on which network they appear, the Kuklapolitan Players put on a spirited performance notable for its soft humor and satire. Returning from vacation this week, the group headed by "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" transferred its repertoire from N. B. C. to A. B. C., which presents the show from 7 to 7:15 P. M., Mondays through Fridays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Frank Shea gained his second victory of the year and his first since July 25 today when the Washington Senators defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 5 -- 4, in a replay of a 4 -- 4 tie on Aug. 22.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Delegates from seven countries agreed today on up-to-date rules measuring the performance of the motors that provide electricity for railway locomotives.

The New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross reported yesterday that the collection of 9,687 pints of blood in August helped it pass through the summer months with "all Red Cross local blood commitments met."

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The world's first futures market for scrap iron and steel got under way today on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Both the buying and the selling interests, particularly on the part of scrap iron merchants, were active.
Steelmaking operations this week have been scheduled at 62.9 per cent of the industry's theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

During the last week of December, 1953, members of the American Economic Association and eleven other groups in the same general category met to exchange views on the economic outlook in the United States for 1954. While pointing out that any prediction made at that time had to be made without any real foreknowledge of what the Administration's economic program would be, these experts were in general agreement on two principal points.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 7 -- The Royal Commission on Russian espionage withdrew today its permission for Dr. Herbert V. Evatt to appear before it. The action followed Dr. Evatt's protest against the treatment of Mme. Rose-Marie Oiller, former second secretary in the French Embassy in Canberra.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- An extensive cancer study indicates that about one-half of all cancers in women originate in the breast or sex organs, compared with only one-eighth of the cases in these areas among men.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The Admiral Corporation has developed robotlike machines that assemble circuits equivalent to half of a television receiver chassis in a matter of seconds, John B. Huarisa, executive vice president, announced today.

Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue presented her fall and winter custom order collection yesterday at this store. She has not followed the Parisian influences of the elongated waist and less emphasized bosom, but has created the curvaceous clothes for which she is known. She was assisted by Steve Erklin.

TRENTON, Sept. 7 -- A business man, accused of realizing exorbitant profits in the sale of stationery supplies to the state agency that was headed by former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman, refused today to testify at a public hearing here. He pleaded the Fifth Amendment.

Cedric Belfrage, British-born author and editor of The National Guardian, has admitted meeting frequently with prominent American Communists. His purpose, he said, was to obtain information from them on international affairs.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Two pickets were arrested late today during a brief melee at the struck Square D Electrical Manufacturing Company when workers, complying with a company back-to-work move, left the plant at the end of their shift.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the fourth day's proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:
American chinaware and European glass and accessories are among the many objects on view on the newly decorated eighth floor of Macy's.

" You can't beat the hours." That was the tongue-in-cheek rejoinder of the late Tim Hurst when he was asked to give his views on umpiring. Baseball's men in blue do have a short working day. They seldom have to be on station more than three hours. It's a trying tour of duty, however, and it takes a man of rare talents to stand up to the job.

Rear Admiral Hollie J. Tiedemann of the United States Maritime Service, who supervised the training of thousands of seamen in World War II, will retire Oct. 1 as chief of the Office of Maritime Training of the Maritime Administration.
DENVER, Sept. 7 -- President Eisenhower returned to his office today after a twenty-four-hour medical check-up at Fitzsimmons (Army) General Hospital. Asked how he felt, he replied:
Major league baseball's pennant battles will become more torrid beginning today with the resumption of hostilities on all fronts.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to succeed Mr. Dewey, said last night that he sympathized with Mr. Dewey's desire to retire and wished the Governor and his family "every happiness and success in private life."

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Adam Frisco, a 5-year-old bay horse owned by Albert Gutzmann, of Waverly, Mass., and driven by Jimmy Jordan, won the Arizona Pace by a half length from Hedgewood Fingo in 2:04 3/5 for one mile tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Josedale Dandy was third. As the favorite, Adam Frisco returned $6,60 for $2.

After more than a score of increasingly serious incidents in which Communist pilots have attacked American and other Western aircraft and taken some seventy lives the United States has at last proposed to call Soviet Russia before the bar of the United Nations to answer for the latest assault.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Steady and significant advances have been registered in the United States over a relatively brief period on behalf of the Negro and other racial minorities, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization states in a report released today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and active months declined 5 to 12 points.
Shipping into the Port of New York in August continued to reflect the fact that every month so far this year except one has seen fewer ships arrive here than in similar months of 1953.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Canada is floating a $1,100,000,000 loan to help pay off the Fourth Victory Loan, the Finance Department announced today.

The establishment of an agency in the city's Department of Welfare to be solely responsible for the protection of dependent children in families on relief was recommended yesterday by a New York County grand jury.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Rye Town Board passed unanimously here tonight new zoning legislation covering three square miles of the unincorporated part of the town. The measure, drawn up to prevent the construction of crowded residential developments, was opposed by 200 property owners who desired even greater restrictions on home building.

Sunday will mark the opening of the American Jewish Tercentenary commemorating the first Jewish settlement in the United States. On Monday two histories about the Jews in America will be made available. McGraw-Hill will issue "Adventure in Freedom," by Oscar Handlin, Pulitzer Prize - winning historian, and World will publish "The Jews in America," by Rufus Learsi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- State Department officials said today that the refugee relief program to admit 209,000 displaced persons into the United States had been slow getting started because of red tape.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Buying of grain futures was well sustained here today. March, May and July wheat and all deliveries of rye made highs for the season. Profit taking was substantial at times, but the market showed more capacity for absorbing such sales than had been the case recently.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- In the wake of the Labor party delegation that recently visited Moscow and Peiping the flood of British visitors to the Soviet Union continues.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts today asked a special session of the Legislature to approve a $12,000,000 bond issue to finance repairs of hurricane damage. The Governor said that the money was needed to help cities and towns lashed by the storm on Aug. 31.

" Betrayed," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer World War II drama, starring Clark Gable and Lana Turner, which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The offering, filmed in Eastman Color in the Netherlands, was directed by Gottfried Reinhardt from a script by Ron ald Millar and George Froeschel.

Don M. Mankiewicz, short story writer and novelist, was chosen yesterday the winner of the $10,000 Harper Prize Novel Contest for his new novel "Trial." It has been scheduled for Jan. 3 publication by Harper.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States remained uncommitted today on the question of how the Western powers should first approach the issue of West German rearmament.
CAIRO, Sept. 6 -- United States economic aid, long a tempting mirage to an Egyptian Government wandering in the financial badlands, has proved disappointing on close examination.

The new American Federation of Labor pier union may try a mass "boring from within" tactic to capture control of its successful rival in the Port of New York, the old International Longshoremen's Association.

What makes people kill each other -- and themselves -- on the highways? There are all sorts of answers to that question, including the answer that they don't mean to but don't take pains enough not to. Few drivers, setting out for a holiday week-end, imagine that they are about to become statistics in which the police and the National Safety Council will be interested.

A ceremony is being planned for next month to honor members of the New York Investment Bankers Association with the best records for selling United States Government savings bonds in the drive which opened last April.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Chicago Union Stock Yards today welcomed a Hereford steer from Iowa as the one-billionth animal to enter its gates. The owner was paid $1 a pound for it.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Doubt was expressed here today that nuclear energy would make any significant contribution within the next twenty-five years toward supporting a growing population at rising levels of living. On the other hand, it was held possible that the development of solar energy might do so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Walter Winchell testified today that he had received a copy of the controversial Army Intelligence document that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy produced at the recent Army-McCarthy hearings.

MANILA, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- The eight nations who signed the Southeast Asia collective defense treaty today also adopted a Pacific Charter upholding the "principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples" in Southeast Asia and the Southwest Pacific region.

There was some easing of the New York money market yesterday from the stringent conditions which prevailed last week. The commercial banks nevertheless carried over the week-end a substantial deficiency in reserve position, evidently anticipating that the return flow of currency to the banks after the Labor Day holiday and other influences would replenish funds.
The New York Central System announced yesterday that it was considering plans to erect the largest privately owned office building in the world on the site of Grand Central Terminal.
At a meeting held yesterday by the American Catholic Psychological Association at Fordham University the Rev. Vincent V. Herr, of Loyola University, took office as the association's new president.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Disappointment at the amount of trade between Britain and Japan led today to a review of the payments agreement between the two countries. Talks, at Japanese initiative, began at the Treasury and were expected to last a week.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Big railroads can help the industry lick the "formidable" problem of high opperating costs if they merge with their weaker and smaller neighbor-roads, Donald V. Fraser, president of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Rail Road Company, said today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture report on today's livestock markets follows:

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Cpl. Edward Dickenson, con victed of collaborating with the enemy while a prisoner of war in Korea, objected today to his picture being taken without his stripes or ribbons.
Psychological tests given to front line United States infantry-men in Korea show that outstanding combat troops have higher intelligence than poor fighters and are generally superior to them.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A California state Senate subcommittee on horse racing today heard testimony that Clint W. Murchison and Sid Richardson, the prominent Texas oil men, had taken control of Del Mar racetrack with a cash outlay of between $10,000 and $15,000.
The Kips Bay Boys Club, devoted to aiding needy boys from 6 to 18 years old, will benefit from a theatre party on Dec. 1 at the Coronet Theatre.

Prices of a good many stocks soared as a result of increases in dividends in the first six months of the year, according to current issue of The Exchange, monthly publication of the New York Stock Exchange.

Four Puerto Rican Nationalists have pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy to overthrow the United States, Government. All may become Government witnesses, according to United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard.
Control of the Empire State Building was purchased yesterday by Col. Henry Crown, Chicago financier and industrialist.

I am one of several thousand passengers disembarking on a recent rainy day at Pier 90. During a year abroad our family was frequently scolded as if we and every American citizen were personally responsible for the ordeal of American immigration and customs procedures.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The nineteenth congress of the International Cooperative Alliance adopted today a broad program designed to remove many national barriers and aid the growth of international cooperative relations.

Despite increased school enrollments, coupled with teacher and classroom shortages, the American people are spending proportionately less of their income on elementary education than they did in 1930.

Of the many fruits that will be abundantly available in the next few weeks, three of the less familiar are up for consideration today, prickly pears, fresh figs and fresh Italian prunes. All three come to us from the West, the pears from southern California and Arizona, the figs from California and the prunes from Washington and Oregon.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer put up obstacles today to a nine-power conference in London Sept. 14, as suggested by the British Government.
The Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway made a new move yesterday to discontinue all passenger service on Oct. 7.

ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Emerging undefeated in seven rounds, Walter Shipman of New York, with a 6 1/2 -- 1/2 total, won the championship of the New Jersey Chess Federation today at the Orange Y. M. C. A.
Rough or smooth-surfaced, all-wool or blended, subdued in shade or glowing in all the richness of stained glass windows -- tweeds are probably fall's biggest fashion fabrics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Equal rights for political candidates were the aim of new regulations covering radio and television broadcasting issued today by the Federal Communications Commission.

Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, have agreed that the idea of West European unity is still alive, and that it suffered only a temporary setback in the rejection of the European Defense Community treaty by the French National Assembly.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 7 -- The prolonged negotiations between India and Portugal over the appointment of neutral observers to study the situation in Goa and other Portuguese possessions have broken down.
A fire that demolished the superstructure of the harbor lighter Express yesterday was extinguished by a New York City fireboat with the aid of harbor tugs from Bedloes Island.
MANILA, Wednesday, Sept. 8 -- A defense treaty for Southeast Asia and the Southwest Pacific was signed here this afternoon.

For everybody's sake it is a good thing that the case against ex-President Prio Socarras of Cuba has been settled. He was fined $9,000 yesterday and his former Minister of the Interior Curti $6,000 for conspiring to export arms from the United States to Cuba in violation of the Neutrality Act.

THE Giants beat the Indians, 13 games to 8, during spring training this year. Nothing important. Just thought someone might want this incidental intelligence for a long-range appraisal of the relative merits of these world series contenders. What's that?

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Sept. 7 -- A civilian bus driver was killed and thirty-two soldiers were injured, two of them critically, when a bus crashed at top speed into the rear of a slowly moving tractor-trailer just before dawn this morning.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 7 (UP) -- Cpl. Claude Batchelor, former war prisoner, described his Chinese captors in a long "confession" today as persons who quieted the fears of his fellow-prisoners, gave them food and shoes and never mistreated them.
" I'd like to find a creek some place where I could go out and fish alone," said the nation's Chief Fisherman recently, getting in the last casts and verbal licks of the season.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Despite new diagnostic techniques, poliomyelitis, both in its early and paralytic stages, may be confused with other diseases, the third International Poliomyelitis Conference heard today.
Sales in New York City's department stores last week were 31 per cent greater than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to a prliminary report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Any horse player who couldn't find a way to earn a profit, no matter how slight, in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday should take up handicapping carousel palfreys.

Word came to the Playwrights Company yesterday from Maxwell Anderson, a founder of the firm and holder of the Pulitzer Prize as well as two awards from the Critics Circle, that he would arrive from Hollywood next week. The purpose of the trip is to accelerate production activity on "The Bad Seed," Mr. Anderson's dramatization of William March's popular book.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Air Force will start in the next few weeks to rotate fighter-bomber and troop-carrier squadrons from the United States to Europe.

The annual fund drive of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will open Oct. 4 with a goal of $650,000. The announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Howard Phipps, president and campaign chairman.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The United States and Britain are convinced that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization provides sufficient safeguards against a revival of German militarism to answer the fears of France and other continental powers on that score.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 7 -- A school of professional space-theorists from Cambridge who call themselves the "new cosmologists" expounded today their ideas about the origin of the universe to the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

An accurate barometer of world shipping conditions, the going price of American-built Liberty ships or their British counterparts, is nosing upward again, primarily because of a slight improvement in world freight trade.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 8 (AP) -- A hard fought campaign for the Governorship of Arizona, matching Ernest W. McFarland against Gov. Howard Pyle, appeared a certainty tonight.
Mayor Wagner ordered yesterday the opening of a new front in the city's war against juvenile delinquency.

While rain was washing out the Giants' scheduled game with the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesday and making necessary a double-header starting at 1:30 P. M. today, the front office of the New York club was at work obtaining some pennant insurance from the Chicago visitors.

MANILA, Thursday, Sept. 9 -- Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister for External Affairs, announced this morning that Australia was taking immediate action to implement the economic phases for the new Southeast Asia collective security pact.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power borrowed $19,500,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds maturing from 1955 to 1984 at an interest cost of 2.26 per cent.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 8 -- The Hempstead Police Department's ten uniformed women school crossing guards started their second year of duty this morning, empowered to issue summonses and make arrests.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Early Wynn pitched an eight-hitter to register his twentieth victory of the season tonight while the pennant-bound Cleveland Indians gained their ninety-ninth triumph by beating the Philadelphia Athletics, 5 -- 2.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- New studies indicating that cancer of the lung invariably offers warnings as much as nine years in advance of the onset of sypmtoms were reported here today to the International College of Surgeons.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept 8. (UP) -- The "lost" tombstone of Abraham Lincoln's second son has been found, it was announced today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 8 -- Thailand's official spokesman interpreted today Chinese Communist arrangements with India and Burma as a ruse to prevent these two friendly neighbors of this country from interfering with a possible Communist attack here.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 8 -- Chinese Nationalist planes and warships struck again today at Communist gun emplacements and seagoing junks in the Amoy sector, along China's southwestern coast. The planes were officially said to have attacked positions on the mainland as well as on the Communist-held island of Amoy.

A Turkish shipping delegation is visiting the United States with an eye to buying at least five Victory ships here as part of plans to expand their fleet by as much as 80,000 tons within the next two years.
Persistence is the word for Averell Harriman.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8 -- Henry F. Holland, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, arriving here today, expressed the conviction that the "complementary economies" of Brazil and the United States could work out together the future of the two countries.

Hand carved wood weathervanes are on view at the Hampton Gallery and Workshop, Amagansett, L. I. The weathervanes, carved by Jane Wasey. sculptor. are of natural wood rubbed with white paint. The group includes one in the shape of a hand, with the index finger pointing the wind direction, and another in the form of a pike-like fish.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Frank Sullivan kept the Red Sox in fourth place today by pitching Boston to a seven-hit. 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 5,625 fans at Briggs Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Enterprise Company, publishing the Beaumont (Tex.) Enterprise and Journal, today accused the Federal Communications Commission of discriminating against it in a television channel contest "because it is a newspaper, and for no other reason."
L. Judson Morhouse, the new acting chairman of the Republican State Committee, is a 40-year-old upstate lawyer who has been active in state politics for almost twenty years.
Research workers are entitled to rewards for achievement, but what form such rewards should take is difficult to determine, executives in the field agreed yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Britain's current prosperity was reflected in statistics published today, showing a big increase in individual incomes in the last five years.

Today's new film is "Hello, Elephant!" an Italian-made comedy-fantasy with Vittorio De Sica, Sabu, Maria Mercader and Nando Bruno, at the Fifth Avenue Cinema. The Rissoli-De Sica Production was directed by Gianni Franciolini and written by Susi Cecchi D'Amico and Cesare Zavattini, from a story by Mr. Zavattini.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 1:

The Maritime Administration had asked thirty shipyards to bid on the conversion of a Liberty ship's propulsion equipment to a 6,000-horsepower steam turbine unit. At present, the vessel has steam reciprocating engines of 2,500 horsepower. Award of the contract is expected to be made next month.

The approval of five championship records, the election of officers for the coming year and the selection of a new date for the annual meeting were decided at the fall meeting of the executive committee of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

Puerto Rico's Nationalist party was portrayed in contrast yesterday. It was seen either as an underground conspiracy that had attempted revolt and terrorism, and plotted more -- or as a patriotic group appealing in public forums for the island's independence.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Three teams tied for the medal in the qualifying round for the nineteenth annual New Jersey state pro-amateur golf championship at the Montclair Golf Club today.
America's oldest little red schoolhouse, dedicated as a public shrine earlier this year, has been pressed into service again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII has named two prelates to be auxiliary bishops to Cardinal IVIooney of Detroit, Msgr. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate, annolmced today. They are Msgr. Henry E. Donnelly, pastor of St. Catherine's Church in Detroit, to be Titular Bishop of Tymbrias, and !%tsgr. John A. Donovan, pastor of St. Aloysius Church and Chancellor of the Archdiocese, to be Titular Bishop of Bulla Regia.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Averell Harriman said here tonight that "if I am a candidate I will be the Governor."

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 8 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano received the hardest punch on the chin today of his conditioning campaign as the world heavyweight champion reached the peak of training for next Wednesday night's title defense against Ezzard Charles at Yankee Stadium.

Combined operations of Safeway Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 19 resulted in a net income of $6,615,971, according to the semi-annual report released yesterday by Lingan A. Warren, president.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The signature of the collective security agreement for Southeast Asia was received today with satisfaction at the French Foreign Ministry.
OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- The Government is sharply reducing its estimate of this year's Canadian wheat production as reports of damage by wheat rust continue to come in.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Efforts by the Union County Gasoline Retailers Association to help stop a nine-month-old price war in the state, were abandoned today when dealers begain fixing prices to meet competition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A recent deluge of pronouncements on the political behavior of Europe by a United States Senator roving about the Continent is no more unusual than is the fact that Niagara Falls is continuous. But the source of the deluge is a reminder that Wisconsin has two overflowing Senators instead of having, like most states, only one.
Zinc shipments in this country last month were the second largest so far this year at 76,535 tons, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Two American epidemiologists reported to the third International Poliomyelitis Conference today added evidence of the value of gamma globulin in providing temporary protection against paralytic poliomyelitis.

ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 9 -- Lieut. Gov. Marvin Griffin apparently had won the Democratic nomination early this morning to succeed Gov. Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia on the basis of incomplete returns from yesterday's primary election.
Sixty-six women and nine men who will become school crossing guards in the Bronx when school opens Monday began a three-day training course yesterday.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., national amateur champion, and Tommy Sheehan, Detroit, were among the favored twosomes to advance to the second round today in the ninth Bill Waite memorial invitation golf tournament at the Shawnee Inn and Country Club.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 -- The 22,000-ton liner Saxonia tied up here this afternoon after a noisy welcome along this port's ten-mile waterfront. She completed the first maiden voyage in more than twenty years of a ship built specially for the St. Lawrence passenger trade.

The New York City Ballet at the City Center gave the season's first presentation to two ballets by George Balanchine last night. One was "Orpheus," with music by Stravinsky and scenery and costumes by Noguchi, and the other was "La Valse," to Ravel's music with costumes by Karinska.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- A plan to facilitate exchanges between national cooperative organizations was adopted today by the nineteenth congress of the International Cooperative Alliance.

Duke Snider wasted two home runs and Roy Campanella one at Ebbets Field last night when the Cardinals rallied in the ninth to score three times and beat the Dodgers, 6 -- 5, before 9,933 forlorn Flatbush fans.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Briarcliff Lodge is being revived as a 225-room suburban hotel after fifteen years of dormancy. Once a gathering place for social and political leaders and the home of many national conventions, it had been the Edgewood Park School for girls from 1939 until last June.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington covering 500,000 shares to be offered under its proposed stock purchase program for employes.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 8 -- Eleven Army officers hearing the court-martial of Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming today for the second time listened to tape recordings of three alleged propaganda broadcasts made in Korea by American prisoners of war.

Most of us used to think complacently that hurricanes were a peculiarity of the Caribbean and our southeastern coastal states. Three devastating blows in sixteen years, however, and the present possibility of a fourth in Edna, prove that New York and New England are now definitely a part of the hurricane zone.
Last week, after he had marked up the 3,000th success of his riding career, Ted Atkinson received a silver ice bucket from the Aqueduct management.

Fireboats, police launches, helicopters and all the other paraphernalia of a traditional harbor welcome will be on hand this morning as the John D. McKean, flagship of the city's firefighting fleet makes her maiden appearance in the harbor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- United States officials, looking for ways to win French approval of West Germany's contribution to Western defense, are beginning to study the possibility of tightening up the North Atlantic treaty.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency, with the approval of President Eisenhower, will form an Advisory Committee on Minority Housing this fall to promote the welfare of Negro and other minorities.

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar and poultry were stronger; coffee, wool, potatoes, hides, silk and copper showed mixed changes, and zinc, lead and burlap eased.
Elegance was the thread that wove several themes together in Bergdorf Goodman's showing of handsome fall and winter custom order designs yesterday.
The ultimate defense of the United States against Soviet attack is the ability to retaliate, Lieut. Gen. Leon W. Johnson, commander of the Continental Air Command, declared yesterday.
High state Democratic leaders decided yesterday to nominate Averell Harriman as the party's candidate for Governor.

During John Muir's lifetime (1838-1914), he covered most of the American wilderness alone and on foot. The journals he kept formed the basis of ten books concerning the wild and unsettled parts of the country and bringing to the attention of Theodore Roosevelt and others the importance of a conservation program.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Pravda, in a blistering attack today, accused Mr. Attlee of having slandered the Soviet Union and Communist China immediately after enjoying their hospitality.

A K. L. M. Royal Dutch Airlines plane from Amsterdam and Shannon, Ireland, landed safely at Gander, Nfld., yesterday with one of its four engines shut off. Nine of the forty-six passengers aboard the Super Constellation were survivors of the crash of a K. L. M. plane at Shannon last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that drought and extremely hot weather in August cut this year's cotton prospects 7 per cent.

Walls and floors are literally spotlighted in the model rooms installed in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, for the Sixth Annual National Homefurnishings Show. It will open to the public at noon today.

" * * * the major source of anxiety for many weeks now has been Chile," says Herbert Matthews in analyzing the problems of Latin America in the Aug. 29 edition of The New York Times (Page 4-B). It is an anxiety which we Chileans appreciate because anxiety is felt only for the destiny of what is cherished.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission heard conflicting arguments today over whether it should approve a proposed Louisiana-to-Michigan natural gas pipeline project.

There was apparently a wistful note in the fraternal talk that Paul Phillips, president of our International Brotherhood of Paper Makers, gave to the British Trades Union Congress in Brighton, England, on Tuesday. He hoped that some day United States workers could have "a true labor movement" like Britain's.
The tightest supply squeeze in copper since Korean War "scare buying" days seems slated for late this month and October.
Albert F. Watters has been elected vice president and operations manager of the International division of the Radio Corporation of America. He has been with the company since 1935.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Southeast Asian and Pacific defense pact is considered here as an extension of other security treaties in the area, complementing rather than conflicting with them.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 8 (AP) -- "Don't go far and be back in good time for lunch," called out Eugene Hart's grandmother, Mrs. Mamie Deckart, as he left home in 18 Schaffer Street, Brooklyn, late Friday morning. He had 17 cents in his pocket.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Hurricane Edna's threat to the Florida coast vanished today as the 115-mile-an-hour tropical storm curved to the north and the possibility grew that it might not strike anywhere on the United States mainland.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Adios Harry, a leading candidate for Little Brown Jug honors in Delaware, Ohio, this month, led a field of six tonight, winning the Georgia Pace by a half length from Knox Hanover in 2:02 at Roosevelt Raceway.

Prices of cotton futures advanced sharply yesterday following the publication of the lower-than-expected Government crop report. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, prices were 27 to 41 points, or $1.35 to $2.05 a bale, net higher on the day.

An exchange offering by the Western Pacific Railroad Company of new common stock and of a new issue of $22,500,000 of income debentures to holders of the 308,211 outstanding shares of the railroad's preferred is now effective.

THERE was something Ieonine about Pop Warner. It wasn't entirely his mane of hair, the square cut of his jaw or the rippling power he seemed to exude from his massive frame. Yet he walked in confident majesty, the king of the football jungle. Glenn Scobey Warner now is dead at the age of 83 but in memory will linger long.

The Grand Central Terminal looks as though it were built for the ages, but people probably felt the same way about the Grand Central Depot that it replaced. Apparently we begin to get restless about these buildings every forty years or so. Now the talk is of the greatest skyscraper of them all, if tentative dreams of Robert R. Young, the Central's new board chairman, and William Zeckendorf, the real-estate man, come to life.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Stockholders of the County Trust Company of Westchester today authorized a four-for-one stock split. Andrew Wilson, chairman, said 83 per cent of the 210,250 shares held by 3,350 persons were represented in the unanimous vote.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad elected George T. Carmichael senior vice president yesterday. He has been with the road for forty-six years and has been a vice president since 1942.

INCHON, Korea, Sept. 8 -- Koreans who held hopes that the United States Twenty-fifth Division would leave a substantial part of its arms and equipment for the use of the South Korean Army upon its withdrawal from the peninsula were disappointed this afternoon.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 8 -- The British Trades Union Congress approved today plans to rearm Western Germany under adequate international safeguards. However, the narrow margin of victory shocked advocates of rearmament.

WASHINGTON, Sept.8 -- Forty-six charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were referred by the Senate to the special committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah. The committee combined thirteen of what it felt were the most important charges into the following five categories:

BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 -- It has been said that pitchers, particularly left-handers, develop late. Exhibit A may be Tommy Byrne, who tonight at Memorial Stadium made a triumphant return to the mound staff of the Yankees with a solid, route-going 8-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
The Montana-Dakota Utilities Company borrowed $12,000,000 in the public market yesterday on two issues of mortgage bonds sold to investment banking syndicates at competitive bidding.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Nervousness over the outbreak of fighting between China and Formosa made for caution on stock markets today. Prices of industrial shares were marked up at first in anticipation of buying at the start of new bookkeeping account, but they reacted later. Store and South African gold-mining shares were particularly dull in the afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Big Ted Kluszewski started a four-run sixth-inning rally with his forty-fifth homer of the year as the Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9 -- 3, tonight and took fourth place in the National League from the losers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Hog receipts fell 3,000 under expectations today and the market responded with steady to mostly 25 cents higher prices.

John S. Knight, publisher, will become the first recipient of La Prensa Prize for American Friendship, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, publisher of La Prensa, announced yesterday. The presentation will be made at the annual dinner of the American Foundation in Rio de Janeiro on Oct. 12.
The public and advertisers generally are not deceived by extravagant savings claims and the use of superlatives in comparison advertising.
Two adjoining industrial sites in Flushing, Queens, have been purchased for improvement.

The sixty-five-family apartment house at 3110 Kingsbridge Terrace in the Bronx has been purchased by the Brookdale Realty Corporation, an investment group represented by James J. Leibman, lawyer. The buyers paid cash over a mortgage of $116,400. The sellers were clients of I. Godiner, lawyer. The Taylor Company was the broker.
The American Zionist Council announced yesterday a program to promote Jewish education, the study of Hebrew and Jewish youth activities in this country.

MEADVILLE, Pa., Sept. 8 (AP) -- T. F. Soles, chairman of Talon, Inc., said today none of the major stockholders "have expressed an interest in selling even a portion of their shares in the company at the present time."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 8 -- Twenty years of social Democratic Government have not dampened the spirits of Swedish private business.

ALTHOUGH good tides are not scheduled until next week, a check on the New Jersey rail situation reveals that a few have managed to pick up near-limits despite the brief periods in which the railboats have been able to navigate the wild rice flats.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Warren Spahn posted his eleventh straight victory today to proper the fast - closing Milwaukee Braves to within four games of the National League lead with a 5-2 decision over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

HONG KONG, Sept. 5 -- There is one striking difference between the Russians and the Chinese which impresses one at once in conversation. The Russian is always at pains to tell you that everything in Russia is not only equal to but superior to anything in the West.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox put down an uprising in the ninth inning tonight to defeat the Washington Senators, 2 to 1, before a chilled gathering of 6,735, the smallest night crowd of the year at Comiskey Park.

Brooklyn not only boasts the Dodgers, but also one of the finest Danish bakeries in the city. It is the Christian Dannerhoj, named after the man who founded it ten years ago at 7612 Fifth Avenue in the borough's Bay Ridge section.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- One of half a dozen critical Senate contests for the Republicans, involving two Californians with virtually twin careers, moved into high gear today as Senator Thomas H. Kuchel opened his campaign for re-election.

Iceland defeated Finland, 3 1/2 -- 1/2 in the third round of the international chess tournament at Apollo Hall yesterday to take the runner-up position to Russia in Group 1, according to a report from Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 8 (UP) -- A proposed constitutional amendment to permit Mississippi to abolish its public schools in favor of "private" institutions in order to maintain segregation easily passed its first test today.

The curse of a leisurely summer's inland waterways -- seaboard ones as well -- lies at the door of the internal combustion engine. Now wait a minute before getting sore. Motorboats are excellent things, and so are outboard motors, and no one would disparage them for a second as a means of going deep-sea fishing or across the lake to pick up Tom Collins mix.
WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The United States went into the lead at the end of the first day of the three-day eleventh international tuna tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A new research technique has uncovered a group of viruses that may help scientists solve some baffling medical mysteries.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- The Massachusetts Legislature passed early today a bill providing a $12,000,000 bond issue for hurricane relief.

Unwary persons are bilked of millions of dollars annually by "a lot of self-appointed, incompetent psychologists operating with a phony $25 mail order diploma," an official of the American Psychological Association said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Defense officials now credit the Chinese Communists with serious intentions to seize Quemoy Island, Nationalist outpost five miles from the mainland.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Leaders of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations refused today to accept Averell Harriman as the Democratic gubernatorial candidate.
ROME Sept. 8 -- The population of the Soviet Union is 200,000,000 to 250,000,000 inhabitants and probably is increasing more rapidly than that of any of the fourteen North Atlantic powers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Maj. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker, a hero of the Battle of the Bulge, heard Senator Joseph R. McCarthy denounce him again today as an officer unfit to wear the uniform of a general.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 8 -- There were 154 boats sailing today in rain and variable airs, mostly light, at the beginning of the twenty-second race week of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- Suggestions for an alternative to the European Defense Community treaty were put forward today shortly after the announcement that the British Government had delayed invitations for a nine-power conference next Tuesday.
MANILA, Thursday, Sept. 9 -- The signing of an eight-nation Southeast Asia collective defense treaty here yesterday is being hailed as a historic development in relations between Asia and the West.

Gasoline stocks last week declined 260,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, they were 153,497,000 barrels, compared with 153,757,000 a week earlier and 140,945,000 a year ago.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 8 -- The Englewood Board of Education, which on Sept. 28 must appear in Trenton before the Division Against Discrimination of the New Jersey Department of Education to answer charges of discrimination against Negroes, reported no incidents in the opening of school here today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the world's largest communications enterprise, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $10,112,810 in the first six months of this year. This was the best first half net in twenty-two years.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -- The regional conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization gave preliminary approval today to a resolution condemning an uneconomic trend of Latin nations toward a self-sufficiency in food production.

The five-story dwelling with elevator and roof garden on lot 20 by 100 feet at 46 East Seventy-third Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, has been purchased by Dr. Clifford J. Sager for his office and residence.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Robert Washington Martin gave a dance tonight at his home on Davenport Neck in honor of his debutante granddaughter, Miss Leslie Martin. Miss Martin is a daughter of Mrs. Robert R. Martin of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Martin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy testified today that a six-year-old guest in his house last night answered a question that he told Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker a "five-year-old child can understand."

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Gene Walet 3d of New Orleans, representative of the Gulf Yachting Association, held the lead tonight after two races in the North American yachting championship for the Mallory Cup.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The British campaign for immediate progress toward West German rearmament and sovereignty came to a standstill tonight. The Cabinet reluctantly concluded that the nine-power conference it had proposed for next week to deal with this problem must be postponed until later this month or next month.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 8 -- A ribbon-cutting ceremony at the L. Bamberger Company's new branch store tomorrow will highlight the formal opening of the $5,000,000 Princeton Shopping Center.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- In the largest department store in the Soviet Union, it has not been possible to buy an ordinary broom handle for six months, the store director, reported today in an article in Izvestia, the Government newspaper.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The ski jump here may have to give way before too long to a full-fledged uranium mine. Two amateur prospectors who spend their week-ends and days off poking around with Geiger counters have reported a "hot" discovery in the heart of the state park and have filed eight claims with the state for 320 acres.
The Kean bill for a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Act will pass at the next session of Congress, in the opinion of its author.

Two and one-half floors in the twenty-seven-story office building planned at 20 Broad Street, adjoining the New York Stock Exchange, have been leased by Smith, Barney Co., members of the Exchange and underwriters of securities. The company has had offices at 14 Wall Street since 1936.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Despite London's decision to postpone the proposed nine-power conference on West Germany French diplomacy today went forward with the preparation of proposals that would be submitted if the conference were held. It is the French plan to start discussions unofficially and to have concrete proposals ready for whenever the interested countries meet.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 8 -- Evidence that what is now Arizona was once at the North Pole and, physically speaking, "on top of the world" was put forward at today's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Thirteen million dollars' worth of new building and equipment destined to play a key role in converting the country's long-distance telephone system to dial operation was unveiled here today.

Ford Frick, Commissioner of Baseball, yesterday declared that unlimited television is "killing off minor league baseball, which in turn will kill off major league baseball." Frick suggested that broadcasters and baseball officials meet in an effort to solve the problem.
Averell Harriman and Senator Irving M. Ives emerged yesterday as the probable Democratic and Republican contenders for Governor in this fall's election.
VIENNA, Sept. 8 (UP) -- A cigarette smoker's life is not a happy one in Iron Curtain countries, a survey of Communist newspapers showed today.

Petitions nominating Thomas J. Curran as a member of the Republican state committee in the First Assembly District were upheld in court yesterday. At the same time petitions in behalf of Boris S. Berkovitch were invalidated.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday its recommendations of candidates for the State Legislature in ten of next Tuesday's Democratic primary contests.

One hundred and fifty-eight acres of land at Levittown, Pa., in busy Lower Bucks County, have been selected as the site for one of the country's largest shopping centers, it was announced here yesterday. The proposed development will represent an investment of about $41,000,000 and will get under way in January.
An all-male jury was completed yesterday in Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz's part of Kings County Court to try two Brooklyn youths on a first-degree murder charge. Two men alternates were selected.
Prof. Robert S. Woodworth, who for half a century has been one of the leading figures in American psychology, was honored yesterday by 160 professional colleagues at an advance birthday celebration.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 8 -- John Dioguardi, ex-convict president of a New York local of the United Automobile Workers Union, A. F. L., has been found innocent of "any illegal activities" but has resigned from the union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, challenged today the propriety of allowing Senators administrative assistants to question witnesses at closed hearings during investigations.

ABOARD U. S. S. SALEM, in the Ionian Sea, Sept. 7 -- North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in the Mediterranean have won another mock war and learned another real lesson on the need for improved communications.

In the second, a batch of Manhattan Bohemians are drinking moodily against the hell-red curtains of a mysterious cafe. And in the third the devil himself is triumphantly holding a hapless member of a future Yankee baseball team aloft on a barbarously pronged spear.

Hurricane Carol, which swept with sudden fury along the East Coast last week, left in its wake damage close to $100,000,000 to insured property. This does not include the millions of dollars of uninsured damage to property and loss of lives caused by floods and tidal waves.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 8 -- Governor Dewey fired the opening shots tonight in his campaign to elect another Republican to succeed him as Governor.

In the face of an official police rebuff, Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg, head of the Brooklyn morals squad and arch-foe of gambling in that borough, yesterday renewed his drive against charity bingo games.

Ilona Massey, the motion picture and television actress, has agreed to star in her first Broadway stage drama, "The Journey," a new play by Herbert Cobey. She will portray the role of Clytemnestra, the tragic wife of Agamemnon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Heavy profit-taking sales swamped buyers in wheat during the early part of the session here today and prices declined as much as 2 cents from the preceding close. There was an expansion of commission absorption on the setbacks, however, and a brisk recovery was registered in the late trade.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- Problems in personal relationships are causing people morel anxiety than international atomic age tensions, and call for greater assistance from community agencies, it was declared today at the opening of the biennial national conference of the Family Service Association of America.
DENVER, Sept. 8 -- Five Federal agencies were made responsible today for specific emergency duties in case of attack.

United States Senator Irving McNeil Ives, a master at walking political tightropes, has managed to carry the label "Jeffersonian Republican" despite opponents' gibes that he is "a Taft in sheep's clothing."

President Eisenhower has rejected Senator Knowland's plea that this country break off diplomatic relations with Russia in retaliation for the Soviet shooting down of an American plane last week-end. WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The soundness of tests conducted by the National Bureau of Standards on the battery additive AD-X2 was challenged today at a Federal Trade Commission hearing.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the world chess champion and the head of the Soviet team in the HamiltonRussell Trophy tournament at the Apollo Hall, was held to a draw in twenty-nine moves by Dr. Max Euwe, holder of the title in 1935, according to a report from Amsterdam yesterday.

Seven new principals have been engaged by the New York City Opera for its fall season, opening Wednesday, Sept. 29, at the City Center of Music and Drama, Joseph Rosenstock, general director of the company, announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 -- Great possibilities for reducing juvenile delinquency lie in the improvement of family relations through community agencies, the Family Service Association heard today.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- "Old Guard" Republican obstructionism was attacked tonight by Harrison A. Williams Jr. in the opening speech of his campaign for re-election to the United States House of Representatives.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 9 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, tonight opened his campaign for re-election here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Harry Dorish yielded only three hits to the Washington Senators today, but two of them were home runs by Roy Sievers and Jim Lemon for a 2-to-0 triumph over the Chicago White Sox before the smallest Comiskey Park crowd of the year, 1,842.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the 5,500 corporations that publicly report their cash dividend payments paid stockholders about $4,800,000 in the first seven months of this year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Reflecting a 14.8 per cent drop in sales, the net income of Montgomery Ward Co., second largest mail-order house in the country, declined to $12,401,602 in the sixth months ended on July 31 from $15,731,973 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The State Department hailed today the signing of an air base agreement between the United States and Libya as a step assuring continued economic and diplomatic cooperation between the two countries.

The Maritime Administration yesterday awarded contracts totaling $124,461 to East Coast shipyards for repair work on six attack transports and one attack cargo transport.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest merchandising organization, showed declines in sales and earnings in the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16 compared with the similar period of 1953.

BENGHAZI, Libya, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- An agreement giving the United States the use of air bases in Libya was signed here today.

Home builders will maintain a high rate of production in 1955 with the output of new dwellings reaching 1,200,000 to 1,350,000.
