RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 9 -President Joao Cafe Filho pledged his Government today to fight Communist subversion in Brazil by "all legitimate means." At the same time it will do everything possible, he said, to improve the lot of the average Brazilian.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, expressed hope today for the curtailment of the nuclear-weapons race. He said he was hopeful of a speedy agreement on president Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace proposals.
Hattie Carnegie's custom-order fall and winted designs seem to reach the peak of perfection in fashion.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The 1953 winners, George Rowbotham, Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Ben Smith, Detroit, advanced to the semi-finals of the ninth Bill Waite memorial invitation golf tournament today by defeating Bob Fife, Detroit, and Billy Goldthorpe, Philadelphia, 5 and 4.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- Once again the Soviet Union called on Europe tonight to accept its plan for general security and declared its willingness to reach agreements on all outstanding international questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Two indictments against former Representative Joseph E. Casey, Democrat of Massachusetts, were dismissed in Federal court today. He was charged with conspiring to defraud the Government in the purchase of surplus ocean tankers.

The New York City shopper concentrated his July purchases on items to make his vacation more pleasant or else he bought goods on which prices were lower because of excise tax cuts earlier in the year. Otherwise, except for specific exceptions, it was a dull month for department stores, according to an analysis of sales figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 9 -- The West German Government was taken aback tonight by the announcement of the impending visit of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary. After due reflection, however, a spokesman was authorized to say that personal contacts between Mr. Eden and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer would be welcomed.

Being on one's extra special good behavior is something of a strain and is likely to be followed by a violent reaction in the opposite direction. Judging by yesterday's furious Pravda attack on Clement R. Attlee this behavior pendulum has taken place in the Kremlin.

Stocks sagged most of yesterday, rallied in the fourth hour and lost strength near the close, but managed to close the day with appreciable gains. The better groups were the steels, oils, aircrafts, rails and papers.
MANILA, Sept. 9 -- Ramon Magsaysay, President of the Philippines, assured other free Asian nations today that the door was open if they wished to join the new Southeast Asia collective security pact.

The whistles and the geysers of water down the bay yesterday morning symbolized the welcome of all good New Yorkers to the new flagship of the fireboat fleet, the John D. McKean, "Engine 57." She will soon be ready for any action that the always unpredictable circumstances of firefighting may require.
Jackie Robinson yesterday was the victim of a practical joker with a strange sense of humor.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9 (AP) -Mississippi's Legislature today passed a law it hoped would keep Negroes out of the University of Mississippi Medical School, now under construction.
Charges and counter-charges have been leveled against the management of the LacledeChristy Company and a company attempting to gain control.
Representatives of industry were told yesterday that their plants and personnel were subject to conscription by local civil defense commanders in the event of a war emergency.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd warned the Eisenhower Administration today against half-way measures in cracking down on housing profiteers.

The new board of directors of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company has placed that road's stock on a regular $1.20 a share annual dividend basis. Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the new executive committee, announced yesterday that directors voted at a meeting on Wednesday a dividend of 30 cents a share on the common, payable on Sept. 30 to holders of record of Sept. 20.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building for sixty-one families on plot 100 by 135 feet at 574 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Eightyeighth Street, has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Louis Saritsky.

NEARLY 3,000 years ago somebody wrote a narrative poem in India about the adventures of the young Prince Rama. Various persons rewrote the poem and added new verses until about 200 B. C., when it assumed its present form. One of the characters in the poem is an exiled poet named Valmiki, who may also have been its original author.

Miss Miriam Stevenson is a young lady about to enter on her fourth year as an undergraduate at Lander College in Greenwood, S. C. Miss Stevenson is majoring in home economics. She is also one of the few girls in the United States or elsewhere who can prove that in the eyes of impartial judges she is beautiful.
The State Insurance Department's analysis of 135 union welfare funds has turned up twenty-one that are "badly run," forty-one that are "subject to serious criticism" and seventy-three "really good."

THE bluefish is as unpredictable as other salt-water migrants, here today and gone tomorrow, but those who fished the mouth of the Sherwsbury River near Sandy Hook yesterday were fortunate to be at the right place at the right time.

On reading his letter in The Times of Sept. 6 it seems to me that, like so many others, my former pupil in The City College, Sidney Sukoenig, misunderstands the position of those who favor the re-establishment of Townsend Harris High School.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Hog prices broke sharply today as receipts at Chicago and other terminals were much larger than expected. Salable receipts at Chicago totaled 10,000 head.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- The end objective of treating a patient severely disabled from poliomyelitis is maximum functional efficiency, Dr. Paul C. Colonna, of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia emphasized today at the third International Poliomyelitis Conference.
Democratic state and city leaders increased yesterday their pressure on Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to let the nomination for Governor go uncontested to Averell Harriman.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 9 -Steady golf enabled Mrs. T. A. Menzel, Innis Arden, to post a 42, 41 -- 83 during the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 36-hole seniors' championship for the Clara Rossin Trophy at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

Sauces for fresh vegetables are a timely topic, as this is the month when supplies of many varieties are at their peak locally both in quality and quantity. New Yorkers can feast eye and palate on a showy, colorful array of cabbage, peppers, celery, cucumbers, onions, eggplant, carrots, snap beans and beets.

CAIRO, Sept. 9 -- Maj. Salah Salem, prominent member of Egypt's ruling military junta, went on "leave" from his Cabinet posts today under circumstances suggesting strongly he might face a permanent ouster.

Curtis Dwight Wilbur, who died in Palo Alto, Calif., on Wednesday, was one of two brothers who held posts in two successive Presidential Cabinets. The late Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University, served for four years as Mr. Hoover's Secretary of the Interior.

YONKERS, Sept. 9 -- Wallachs new store in the $30,000,000 Cross County Shopping center here opened for business today without ceremony. John D. Gray, president of the company, and other officers greeted visitors.
ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company won permission today to increase its rates by an average 21 per cent for traffic within the state, effective Sunday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Twelve million dollars' worth of stock has been sold in Utah in the last few months to finance development of a uranium industry that a state official said today "is here right now."

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Delegates to the convention here of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations today cheered a charge that New York City Democratic leaders were deliberately trying to "throw" November's gubernatorial election.
The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that it would spend $10,500,000 more to complete its smoke control program at its Hudson Avenue generating station in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Federal District Court here refused today to interfere with Board of Education plans to integrate white and Negro pupils in the public schools.
Jersey City, N. J., sold $22,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 3.2587 per cent.

A SWIFTLY paced comedy with dialogue like a chain of firecrackers made its debut last Tuesday at 10:30 P. M. over the N. B. C.-TV network. If any other television show ever crammed as much sizzling farce into a half hour as did "It's a Great Life," the new weekly series, this viewer has failed to see it.

Industry can "look forward with confidence to copper being available in ever increasing quantities," William A. Meissner Jr., deputy director of the copper division of the Business and Defense Services Administration, Department of Commerce, said yesterday.

Shoppers will find some bargains in meat this week. A particularly good buy, according to a spokesman in the local office of the Department of Agriculture, is the pork loins being offered as week-end specials by a few chains.

DENVER, Sept. 9 -- Republican state chairmen from twenty-one Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states began meeting here today to discuss campaign techniques they expect to employ during the Congressional races in their areas this fall.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 9 -- A day as fine as a sailor could want left almost a third of the classes with unbeaten skippers today in the second regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week.
Yesterday the Dodgers bounded back at Ebbets Field to beat the Cardinals, 10 -- 1, behind the six-hit pitching of young Johnny Podres in the southpaw's first complete game since June 13.
ROME, Sept. 9 -- The case of Wilma Montesi, who was found dead on a beach April 19, 1953, re-emerged today when it became known that the passports of four prominent Italians had been withdrawn.

" THE FLIES" is Jean-Paul Sartre's version of the awesome Greek legend of the vengeance of Orestes on his malevolent mother and stepfather, Clytemnestra and Aegistheus. It might be described as a dish of horror sprinkled lightly with M. Sartre's philosophy of Existentialism.

Copper Kettle won the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday after a thrilling stretch run. The 4-year-old gelding, owned by Lawrence E. Jones and ridden by Jimmy Nichols, scored by a head over Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Bradley, with Mrs. Charles Silvers' Ruthred third.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The effect of bullish crop news from Canada seemed to have worn off in the wheat pit here today and prices declined. Coarse grains, however, showed a strong tone.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 9 -Henry F. Holland, Assistant United States Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today the United States had fortified its policy of improving the economic condition of the Americas to develop hemispheric strength.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Two Federal agencies estimated today that spending by American business men for plant and equipment this year would reach about $26,700,000,000, 6 per cent below the spending record of last year.
ROME, Sept. 9 -- The Vatican made some concessions today to those who believed that the only hope of the world overpopulation problem was in birth control.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The stock markets here shook off some of their recent hesitancy today and prices rose slightly.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- The problem of rearming West Germany. now the center of discussion in Western capitals, is that of organizing Europe and the Atlantic community so as to insure that the Bonn Republic shall remain part of the free world.
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Premier Mendes-France told the North Atlantic Council today that France would not be alone among the great powers in yielding her sovereignty in important fields.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The President's action on hand-blown glassware duty was his sixth tariff decision since taking office. In all these decisions, with the exception of imported watches, the President has refused recommendations for higher tariffs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -Forty-six charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were referred by the Senate to the special committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah. The committee combined thirteen of what it felt were the most important charges into the following five categories:
In an article from Milan on July 17 Herbert Matthews reported his impressions and experiences concerning the present condition of Italian trade unions.
A new convent and administration building for the child-caring home of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin at Mount Loretto, S. I., were dedicated yesterday afternoon by Cardinal Spellman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -The Democratic National Committee threw its weight today behind Edgar A. Brown, regular Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in South Carolina. The move was looked on as a sharp rebuff to ex-Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, who bolted the party in 1948.

Senator Irving M. Ives announced yesterday his willingness to accept the Republican nomination for Governor. If he gets it, he said, he will wage the most forceful and effective campaign of which he is capable.

Roaster buying to replace depleted inventories touched off a demand for futures that caused coffee prices to soar the 2-cent-apound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Directors of Servel, Inc., have elected Duncan Cameron Menzies as president, general manager and a director, Louis Ruthenburg, chairman, announced yesterday. In the executive posts, Mr. Menzies succeeds W. Paul Jones, who becomes vice chairman of the board.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- President Eisenhower mingled political conversations with problems of state and golf today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J. Sept. 9 -- Otto Greiner, Knickerbocker Country Club professional, and his partner, John Wilson Jr., a senior at Princeton, accounted for the chief upset in the New Jersey State pro-amateur golf tournament today.

It is unusual for The Times to amplify as poorly founded a position as that you took in your editorial of Sept. 4 "Veterans as Citizens." There is nothing preposterous in a theory that seeks to remedy in some measure the loss in mind, body and worldly goods suffered by every veteran of two World Wars.
The Nov. 30 performance of Noel Coward's comedy "Quadrille" has been taken over for the fall benefit of The New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP)-- A part-time hypnotist with an urge for a trip into the sky was in jail tonight after a flight in a home-made rig suspended from sixty gas-filled balloons.
PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Ruth Breitman of New York today was elected chairman of the National Jewish Welfare Board at the final meeting of the seventh National Jewish Youth Conference.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9 -- Lieut. Gov. Marvin Griffin today won the Democratic nomination to succeed Gov. Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia on the basis of almost completed returns from yesterday's primary election.

The City Stores Company, which operates a group of department stores, including Oppenheim Collins and Franklin Simon, yesterday reported a consolidated loss of $210,000 for the quarter ended July 31, on sales of $48,449,000.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- President Eisenhower set in motion today a three-year program to sell $700,000,000 in surplus farm products abroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, declared today that to fight an atomic war the United States might need more, rather than fewer, foot soldiers.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman said today that state motor vehicle agents throughout New Jersey had contributed, under pressure, at least $40,000 to the Republican political campaigns of 1952 and 1953.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM, the effervescent manager of the stampeding Milwaukee Braves, is definitely a man with a future. The trouble is that he's not quite sure whether it's only the distant future or the immediate future as well. Being a man who firmly believes that first things come first, Jolly Cholly is aiming point blank at the immediate future.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- United States anglers remained in the lead at the international tuna tournament today, although they did not share in the five fish caught during the second day of the three-day match.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Thin or underfed persons may have a better chance to survive radiation injuries in event of a hydrogen or atomic bomb attack.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, declared here today that he would issue a proclamation Monday calling the Republican-controlled Legislature back into session on Sept. 17. He said he had sent telegrams to every member of the Senate and Assembly informing them of his intention.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 13 points off to 6 points up. The tone at the close was barely steady. The market opened 2 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that the new Southeast Asian defense treaty was an "unfortunate" development that was bound to increase the sense of insecurity among the people.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (UP) -Cleveland's Indians made it 100 triumphs for the season today when they pulled out a 5-4 eleven-inning victory over the Philadelphia Athletics to go five and a half games in front of the New York Yankees.
The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association will begin negotiations for a new contract today.
An eight-day strike of 600 truck drivers against 150 garment-making concerns was settled yesterday. The drivers began to return to their jobs in the afternoon.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will undertake the production in French and German of a CinemaScope picture to be made in Casablanca with a cast of European performers.
The text of the statement by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams yesterday follows:

Dr. George B. Pegram, special adviser to the president of Columbia University and chairman of the Anglo-American-Hellenic Bureau of Education, was honored last night at a dinner in the Men's Faculty Club.

Six relieved survivors of the New York-bound K. L. M. plane that crashed into the Shannon River last Saturday, causing twenty-eight deaths, arrived here yesterday. They were among the passengers on another plane of the line that landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -Charles E. Slusser, Public Housing Commissioner, announced today that fifty-seven local housing authorities had sold $177,214,000 in short-term loan notes at an average interest rate of .674 per cent a year.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Willard Nixon, who thrives against the Tigers and the Yankees, scattered four hits today in pitching the Boston Red Sox to an 8-0 victory over Detroit before 3,897 fans at Briggs Stadium.
Howard Greer's fashion collection shown yesterday by Jay Thorpe was overwhelmingly feminine. Hip drapery, flying back panels and snug midriffs emphasized curves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy demanded today that the special Senate committee considering his censure read the controversial intelligence document that the Army-McCarthy subcommittee would not look at.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- Repeal of the public utility anti-strike law in New Jersey was recommended today by a special committee appointed by Gov. Robert B. Meyner last January. The committee's report, signed by eight of the nine members, was presented to Governor Meyner this afternoon.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Dr. Alexander Schiff today examined Ezzard Charles and said the challenger was in excellent physical condition.
A gleaming, black-hulled fireboat, the John D. McKean, proudly sailed up the harbor yesterday to join the city's firefighting fleet.

HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Construction of a new $250,000 railroad station here will be started before the end of the year, New York Central officials said today. All main line trains stop here to change power. The station serves 100,000 commuters from northern Westchester County and 30,000 general travelers from the north and the west monthly.

Repeated public calls by Nationalist leaders for armed revolution to overthrow United States rule in Puerto Rico, which reached a climax in an attack on the Governor's residence Oct. 30, 1950, were described in Federal Court here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, said here today that the time might come when the United States would have to use its nuclear weapons to preserve liberty.

Beginning Wednesday, WABD and the Du Mont television network will extend the roster of television's slimmest programming category -- good music -when the New York Concert Orchestra and Choir, under the direction of Margaret Hillis, begin a series of telecasts from 9 to 10 P. M.

Hardy Burt, producer of radio-TV shows supported by Facts Forum, yesterday accused Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, of issuing a "one-man report" against Facts Forum "replete with falsehood, unfounded charges and vicious innuendo."

Women, bless 'em, apparently are just as much born gamblers as they are bargain hunters. Give them a bingo card and a chance at a passel of cash prizes and the dreary chores of a housewife's workaday world vanish like yesterdy's potato peelings.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 9 -An earthquake struck northern Algeria before dawn today, demolishing a fifth of the city of Orleansville. By unofficial count it killed at least 800 persons. Some victims were buried in their beds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Department store sales last week were 13 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, it was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Gil Newkirk, a 200-pound New Yorker, gave Rocky Marciano another hardwork out today and in full view of the largest week-day crowd ever to watch the heavyweight champion train here.

Domestic steel production last month rose to 6,661,000 tons, a gain of about 33,400 tons over the July output, which was the lowest for any month since the widespread steel industry strike in the summer of 1952.

A comprehensive view of Europe's fashion boutiques is offered in Macy's sixth annual Accessory Bazaar, which will open on Monday. Most of the items are reproductions, made in Europe, of accessories by designers in France, Germany, Italy and Belgium.
LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 9 -This is Louis Little's twenty-fifth year as head man of Columbia football.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 -- No football ever took a crazier bounce than did the baseball hit by Enos Slaughter, leading off the eighth inning in the game between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles today. The bad-hop single that resulted cost Baltimore's Joe Coleman a no-hitter, although it did not prevent the right-hander from blanking the world champions, 1 -- 0.

Hurricane Edna, the fifth tropical cyclone of the 1954 season, picked up speed in its northward progress early today. Its whirling winds were about 300 miles south of Cape Hatteras in North Carolina and 600 miles south of this city.
TORONTO, Sept. 9 (AP) -Marilyn Bell, a 16-year old Toronto high school girl, finished a swim across Lake Ontario at 8:13 o'clock tonight. She began at Youngstown, N. Y., at 11:17 P. M. yesterday.
The appointment of Elmer Davis, news analyst and author, as a consultant to the Fund for the Republic was announced yesterday by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the fund.

As the result of splitting a double-header with the Chicago Cubs before 14,580 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Giants moved a step closer to the National League pennant. At the same time, the even break left Leo Durocher's charges more vulnerable to pursuit in the stretch drive by the Milwaukee Braves and Brooklyn Dodgers.

The demotion of Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg was termed "an amazing spectacle" yesterday by the Protestant Council of the City of New York. His subsequent resignation was described by the council as "the city's loss."

Mayor Wagner has been under pressure from leading Democrats to close down all bingo games in this city. They believe that such action would help elect a Democratic Governor and Democratic legislators who are committed to legalizing the games.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The Illinois Central Railroad today sold $60,000,000 of new thirty-five-year first mortgage bonds to Halsey Stuart Co. and associates on a bid of 99.30 for a 3 3/8 per cent coupon. The road will use proceeds to redeem $60,628,000 of consolidated mortgage 3 7/8 per cent bonds issued two years ago.
The research vessel General San Martin, ordered by the Argentine Government for its Antarctic Institute, will be completed in Bremerhaven, Germany, next month.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Spud Hart, 9-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Erwin F. Dygert of Chicago and driven by Sanders Russell, won the featured Idaho Trot in 2:14 2/5 for the mile and one-sixteenth distance tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 9 -Secretary of State Dulles stopped here today and assured the Chinese Nationalists they did not "stand alone" amid the threat of Communist aggression.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (UP)-The American Lutheran Conference will be dissolved at a national convention here Nov. 10 and the first nations all-Lutheran "free conference" in the history of Lutheranism in the United States will be held here the following two days, church officials announced today.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 9 (AP) -Miss Universe has shunned Hollywood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- During the week ending yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $256,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -Following is the text of a Soviet Foreign Ministry statement on Germany and European security, as made public today by Tass, Soviet news agency:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 -- Unless the "ghetto" pattern of segregated housing is eradicated school integration may be defeated, the National Urban League warned this afternoon in a resolution passed at its fortyfourth annual conference.
Operators of big stores in Europe are faced with some of the same problems that confront their counterparts in this country, some of New York City's leading retailers learned yesterday.

The possibility that the primary elections in this city may have to be called off next Tuesday appeared yesterday as the result of a threat by school custodians not to work on that day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The principal campaign against child labor in the school year now opening will be in behalf of bowling alley pinboys.

CENTREVILLE, Md., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Two New Jersey sailors, Howard Lippincott of Riverton, and Lawrence E. Low of Perth Amboy, tied for the first-day lead of the seventeenth annual International Comet Class sailing championship today.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Syracuse University football players have taken a leaf from the boxing book this season -- they're going through their paces wearing mouthpieces.

The election of officers of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, formed on Aug. 31 by the merger of Olin Industries, Inc., and the Mathieson Chemical Corporation, was announced yesterday by John M. Olin, board chairman, and Thomas S. Nichols, president.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 9 (UP) -- A defense witness testified today that Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, accused of collaborating with the Communists in Korea, once was threatened with death for working against the Reds.

A careful reading of the columns of The Times is always rewarding to the student of the contemporary scene. In the issue of Sept. 7, for instance, there is a report of a speech by Cardinal Spellman in which he is quoted as having said that it was "foolhardy for man to believe that he can piece together the shattered fragments of a civilization and rebuild God's world without God's help."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -Dr. Ronald Richter, Austrianborn scientist who once headed Argentina's atomic energy research, challenged Argentine experts today to disclose the results of their experiments so the world could judge whether he was a fraud or a physicist.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 9 -- Governor Dewey predicted today that United States Senator Irving M. Ives "will win the election and be a great Governor."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -Production of anthracite in 1953 was the lowest since 1881, the Bureau of Mines reports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. to take up United States charges that Soviet fliers broke international law by downing a Navy patrol plane Saturday.

In recording his impressions of Soviet Russia and Communist China former Prime Minister Clement Attlee has said several things that have made his erstwhile hosts squirm and some that have made Pravda squeal. DENVER, Sept. 10 -- President Eisenhower's principal business today at his Lowry Air Force Base office was a long consultation with Robert Cutler in preparation for a meeting of the National Security Council on Sunday. Mr. Cutler is special assistant for National Security Council affairs.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- The West German Finance Ministry has not yet indicated whether it is prepared to renegotiate the agreement under which the Bonn Government pays part of the Allied occupation costs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson wrote Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today that it would be strange if Democratic leaders did not loathe the Wisconsin Republican, who has labeled their political group "the party of treason."
HOMERVILLE, Ga., Sept. 10 (AP) -Mrs. Iris Faircloth Blitch is the second woman to win a Democratic nomination for Congress in Georgia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Western Big Three rejected today the Soviet proposal for an East-West conference on European security.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 10 -- Sweden has decided to free dollar imports of consumer goods on a large scale, the Government announced tonight.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Mexico won the international tuna tournament off this fishing village by landing two of today's eight fish, including a 595-pounder for the biggest of the day. The victory was the second straight for Mexico.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman arrived here today with the last of those who sought refuge with him when he abdicated as President of Guatemala two months ago. A chartered plane of TACA International Airlines brought the leader of Guatemala's deposed pro-Communist Government to this sanctuary. their children and Jose Manuel Fortuny, secretary general of the now outlawed Guatemalan Communist party.

Three five-story buildings with stores and offices at 1113 and 1115 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and 102 West Forty-third Street have been purchased by Jack Resnick, real estate operator, from Aaron Rubin. The property, which has been held at $325,000 was sold through John J. Reynolds, Inc., as broker. Charles Rubman was attorney for the buyer and Harold Lynton acted for the seller.

It is sad news to readers of books (a species distinct from readers of "best sellers") to learn that John O'London has ceased publication for "purely economic reasons." The loss is, of course, most tangible to English readers, for it was one of the few weekly literary journals that had survived England's difficult post-war years.

An application for letters of administration and letters of trusteeship in the estate of Joseph J. Lerner, made yesterday in Surrogate's court, disclosed that he left an estate of $3,389,495 in New York and more than $200,000 in Florida.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Clement R. Attlee was greeted by shouts of "go back to Moscow" when he arrived at Melbourne Town Hall tonight for a Victoria State Government reception.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. made it known yesterday that he would not withdraw from the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10 -- Experts took a look at the United States economic prospects today and saw on the horizon the beginnings of a moderate recovery.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Yale football has been on the upgrade under Jordan Olivar for the past two years. The portents are that it will continue in this healthy state for the next few years at least.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 10 (UP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro said today that United States and Belgian capitalists had expressed interest in exploiting the recently discovered Mutum iron ore deposits, near the Bolivia-Brazil border.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 10 (UP) -- Former Gov. J. Strom Thurmond today accused the national Democratic party of trying to "dictate" the South Carolina vote in his race against another Democrat for the Senate.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles displayed the heaviest punching of his training today as he pounded his sparring partners in a six-round drill.
Even the law of averages is beginning to work against Leo Durocher and his Giants.
ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- The State C. I. O. said officially here today it wanted Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. -- and no one else -- as the Democratic candidate for Governor.

Stocks continued to grind forward into higher ground yesterday. It was a market of small volume and small gains, with steels, base metals, rails, communications, papers and textiles all showing strength and aircrafts, motors and chemicals lagging.

In the testimony that Dr. Bella V. Dodd, an ex-Communist, gave before a subcommittee of the Senate Rules Committee, which appeared in the Aug. 27 U. S. News World Report, she made some statements that I am sure should interest all patriotic citizens.

Brooklyn defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 2 -- 1, in an abbreviated night contest in Ebbets Field, but the Dodger triumph did not become oficial until 2 A. M. today when Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, ruled that the umpires had "waited more than a sufficient amount of time and that this was a legal game."

The city opened its battle yesterday to reduce juvenile delinquency by blocking publication, distribution or sale of books, magazines and "comics" tending to encourage crime, sex perversion and disrespect for law and order.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- One of Great Britain's leading manufacturers opened a three-week tour of Canada today to find out why this country is buying a lot more Diesel engines from the United States than from Britain.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 688,492 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The supporting card to the heavyweight championship fight on Wednesday night was com pleted yesterday. Matchmaker Billy Brown will present an all-heavyweight preliminary card of five six-round bouts and two four-rounders.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Gene Sarazen, 52-year-old Germantown (N. Y.) gentleman farmer, today captured the annual Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association senior championship in a sudden-death play-off with Frank Strazza of Round Hill, Conn., at the Metropolis Country Club.

TAIPEPI, Formosa, Saturday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Nationalists bombed and shelled the Chinese mainland coast opposite Formosa yesterday for the fifth straight day, still unchallenged by the Communist air force.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Otto Greiner and John Wilson Jr. of the Knickerbocker Country Club, Tenafly, carried off the New Jersey pro-amateur golf championship today.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, commander of the French fort at Dienbienphu, which fell to the Indo-chinese Communists last May, returned to France today, incognito, for a ten-day visit. He was liberated by the Communists less than a week ago.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 10. (UP) -- Two condemned killers, using acid and a heavy angle-iron for weapons, broke out of the Hinds County jail today they wounded four persons in their escape through the city.

Before the bingo fracas balloons into a point of friction between religious groups (as it has done in a neighboring state and bids fair to do in our own) someone should say a word in favor of a more cautious and reflective atmosphere in the debate.

Some of fall's most favored fashions turned up in a preview showing of back-to-school clothes for teen-agers at Martin's in Brooklyn yesterday. The show will be presented for the public at 10:30 A. M. this morning at the store.

SALEM, Ore., Sept. 10 -- Despite the huge surplus of wheat owned by the Government, there is an actual shortage of top quality, high protein milling wheat, the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, told a large crowd at the Oregon State Fair today.

The new capital market faces a period of heightened activity next week. Underwriting syndicates are slated to make big inroads on the commitments facing them in the backlog of securities awaiting marketing.

A special trade mission from the Philippines has just arrived in the United States to discuss the desirability and possibility of certain revisions in the basic trade act that governs economic relations between our two countries. The application of the provisions of this act, held by many persons to be adverse to the Philippines, was suspended by an act of Congress for a period of eighteen months so that this study could be made.
A thirteen-state alarm has been sent out for an unemployed bartender who, according to the police, shot and killed his cousin at 3:10 A. M. yesterday in the latter's bar and grill in Queens.
Nat Holman, who two weeks ago was ordered reinstated at City College, received his old job back yesterday as coach of the school's basketball team.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 10 -- Sweden is a country in which it takes deligent research to discover an economic problem. If not unique, this is at least unusual in Europe.

THE public shooting preserve season will soon be in full swing in New York and adjoining states, and as a result of the increased popularity of this shooting, which insures the hunter of returning home with game, a number of new preserves have opened for business.
ROME, Sept. 7 -- An aerial photograph of Centocelle airfield has revealed that the remains of what is thought to be a vast and sumptuous Roman villa lie buried under the main runway.

A 15-year-old high school boy told Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and an all-male jury yesterday the vivid details of the stomping to death of Thomas A. Condon, a business man, in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn early on the morning of July 10.

Despite the divisions of opinion within their own ranks the free nations have again demonstrated in two separate actions that they can maintain a common front against Soviet aggression and will resist any Soviet attempt to break up that front by force, threat or persuasion.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 10 -- Allied military experts believe that if France does not approve some form of West German rearmament the defense of Europe east of the Rhine will be impossible.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- A United States-Soviet argument over birth control concluded the World Population Conference here today.

CENTERVILLE, Md., Sept. 10 (AP) -- By winning the morning race with a three-minute margin, Lawrence E. Low of Perth Amboy, N. J., gained the undisputed lead today in the seventieth international Comet class sailing championship.

BONN, Sept. 10 -- The Central Banking Council of West Germany has decided to liberalize the use of sperrmark (blocked mark) accounts just short of unrestricted convertibility. No date has yet been fixed for implementing the decision.
CAIRO, Sept. 10 -- Maj. Salah Salem, a key figure in Egypt's ruling military junta, patched up today differences with his colleagues and returned to duty after one day of "leave."
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Sept. 10 -Gamma globulin, used for the Prevention of paralytic poliomyelitis, measles and infectious hepa-prescriptions through regular medical supply channels after Oct. 1.

Six cameras will be used by the A. B. C. television network in its coverage of the Miss America Pageant tonight from Convention Hall in Atlantic City. The pickup from 10:30 P. M. until midnight, will be the first time that television has been permitted to look in on the proceedings.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- It had been suspected for a long time that the American League race was a two-team affair, but it was not until tonight this became a mathematical certainty.
The school custodians' salary dispute, which threatened to prevent the primary elections from being held here next Tuesday, was resolved yesterday after a conference of city and union officials.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- A pure white miniature poodle, Blakeen Van Aseltine, owned by Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson of Washington, advanced from the classes to take the best-of-breed honors in the thirteenth annual show of the Interstate Poodle Club today.

ORLEANSVILLE, Algeria, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Six new tremors today rocked earthquake-devastated central Algeria, where 600 bodies had been removed from the rubble of this provincial seat and outlying villages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the seventh day of proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The special Senate committee considering censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy decided today to accept in evidence the controversial Army Intelligence document that he had produced during the Army-McCarthy hearings.

The new Guatemalan Government under President Castillo Armas is continuing to act with moderation and common sense. The decision to give safe-conduct permits to ex-President Arbenz and his followers, who had taken refuge in various embassies in Guatemala City, was statesmanlike.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 10 -- Toledo, now in the midst of a scramble with other major Great Lakes cities for prospective St. Lawrence Seaway business, got a new master plan this week for developing its port for lake and sea traffic.
Despite the approaching front of Hurricane Edna all major airlines maintained normal operations early today from the metropolitan area airports.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. has asked the Appellate Division to overrule an adverse decision on a change of venue plea in a suit seeking to set aside its recently completed biennial elections.

Loins of pork -- a likely choice for the Sunday roast -- are selling in one chain for 35 to 55 cents a pound. The lower price is for the relatively bony rib end of the loin, the higher price for the meatier part. A pork loin has the flavor of fall when roasted as follows with potatoes and apples:
The double-jinxed Discovery Handicap, at a mile and an eighth, for $25,000 added, will be the top attraction at the Aqueduct track today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The American Red Cross ordered five top members of its disaster staff to New York from St. Louis and San Francisco late today to be ready to enter whatever areas Hurricane Edna may strike.
MONTREAL, Sept. 10 -- Paris has come to Montreal in a brilliant reconstruction of the Rue de la Paix in the form of a huge display of France's industrial crafts and products.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation signed a new two-year contract tonight, averting a midnight strike by 42,000 workers in twenty-six plants.
Bank investment specialists were assured here yesterday that demand and supply factors in the public capital market should make for a stable to firm bond market for the foreseeable future.

So many persons called the Weather Bureau offices at 17 Battery Place yesterday that the incessant ringing of bells got on the nerves of the forecasters. They finally asked the New York Telephone Company to disconnect the bells.

Determined not to be caught unprepared, as they had been by Hurricane Carol on Aug. 31, communities in New York, New Jersey and New England yesterday evacuated danger spots, mobilized defense forces, and fastened down virtually everything movable.
Many Protestant pastors who have comDleted 'their vacations l will resume preaching t 11 A. . services here tomorrow.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Ch. Carmor's Rise and Shine, owned by Mrs. Carl E. Morgan of High Point, N. C., and handled by Ted Young Jr., captured best-in-breed honors today at the seventeenth annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Club of New Jersey.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10 -- Iranian security forces have smashed a Communist espionage network in a series of dramatic arrests that began Aug. 16.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- New unemployment insurance claims rose during the first week of September for the first time in almost two months, the Labor Department reported today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Mike Garcia kept alive his chance to be a twenty-game winner as the Cleveland Indians' beat the Boston Red Sox tonight 4 -- 2. The victory was Garcia's seventeenth against eight losses and his fourth straight over Boston.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The United States Command protested to the Russians today what it called the "cold-blooded killing" of a German motorist by Communist police and demanded an end to "reckless" shootings on the highway leading into Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Following in the text of a letter from Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson today to Senator Arthur V. Watkins Utah, chairman of the special Senate committee hearing censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

HONG KONG, Saturday, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Communist China announced tonight that Huan Hsiang, head of the West Europe and African Department of the Foreign Ministry, had been appointed Charge d'Affaires in London.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Paul Richards denied today that he already had agreed to leave the White Sox, the club he has piloted for four seasons, to sign as general and field manager of the Baltimore Orioles.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Of twenty-seven invalid fathers whose families have been dependent on public assistance for years, fifteen were started on the road back to productive self-support through only three months of counseling and assistance by community welfare agencies.
A 16-year-old boy was locked up last night when he frankly admitted to the police that he committed burglaries for a living.

Hurricane Edna will be the most widely televised and broadcast weather event of the season when -- and if -- it strikes the metropolitan area. All radio and television stations are providing almost continuous bulletins on the progress of the storm and most have assembled staffs at potential high-damage points to offer "live" coverage of the disturbance.

Those who demand a tougher court policy in juvenile delinquency cases were described yesterday as victims of a new hysteria, aimed at children. The description came from five justices of the Domestic Relations Court and representatives of welfare agencies working with them. They met at a conference called by Justice Hubert T. Delany in the court, 135 East Twenty-second Street.
The churning winds of Hurricane Edna gathered northward momentum early today and were expected to sweep by the eastern tip of Long Island before noon.

TORONTO, Sept. 10 -- An unassuming schoolgirl was the toast of this metropolis tonight as more than 100,000 jammed the Canadian National Exhibition grounds in a celebration of her feat of swimming across Lake Ontario.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals rebuffed today a Republcan challenge against what the party described as a Liberal party "practice" of substituting major party candidates for its own in primary elections.

The case of the four "thrill killers' has evoked widespread horror and moral indignation. Now that they have been indicted, those feelings may temporarily subside, to emerge again when the defendants are brought into court. The law will take its course, whatever that may be, and then what will become of the public horror and moral indignation?

FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 10 (UP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn asserted tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was "inept" and labeled its legislative program "as dynamic as the dodo, as forward-looking as yesterday."

Your recent editorial on "anti-Yankeeism" in Latin America and particularly in Brazil was excellent from one standpoint. It demonstrated accurately one of the basic causes of this so-called anti-Yankeeism.

Dresser Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries, builders of equipment for the production, transportation, refining and supply of petroleum and natural gas, showed substantially larger sales and earnings in the nine months ended July 31 than a year ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The First National Bank of Chicago announced plans today to increase its capital stock to $100,000,000 through the distribution of a $10,000,000 stock dividend.
The Port of New York battened down yesterday in preparation for the worst that Hurricane Edna might deal out.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The stock markets here were quieter today, with prices showing no decided trend, though the undertone remained satisfactory. Industrials and South African gold mining shares resumed their advance at the outset, but the improvement was not fully held and both groups closed with irregular changes.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the Cabinet today that he foresaw no need of a special session of the National Assembly before Nov. 3. The Cabinet approved the first measure in his "reconversion" program for a productive French economy.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to hold in a narrow range yesterday, closing unchanged to 3 points lower than on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The District Board of Education reversed itself on a controversial desegregation issue, and decided to reinstitute a racial tally of pupil enrollment and teacher assignment.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and the United States agreed today to set up a Great Lakes Fishery Commission to stimulate productivity of the lake fisheries.
The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association returned to the bargaining table yesterday after nearly a year of turmoil and confusion along the docks.

At a special meeting of Foremost Dairies, Inc., held here yesterday, stockholders approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 10,000,000 shares of $2 par from 3,000,000 shares of $5 par value. Thus, the way was paved for a three-for-one stock split, which becomes effective on Wednesday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S. C., shattered par today with a blazing 67, nine under regulation figures, to take the first-round lead in the St. Louis women's open golf tournament.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (AP) -The State Horse Racing Board today granted two Texas millionaires permission to operate Del Mar Race Track for the benefit of a boys' foundation.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- It seemed perfectly safe tonight to predict that the Soviet Union would reject the position taken today in communications from the United States, Britain and France.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 10 (UP) -- A former prisoner of war testified today that Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor told fellow Americans in a Communist prison camp that United States commanders in Korea deliberately lost battles "to keep stock prices up" by the manufacture of armaments at home.
Sales meetings held in airplanes are getting more common, and what probably was the most heavily insured one in airline history was held the other day.

Cocoa fell the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The drop reflected reports of lower Brazilian cocoa prices. Liquidation met light buying interest but there was scale-down short covering.

In two new developments yesterday, Helen Hayes decided to bring her starring vehicle, "What Every Woman Knows," to the New York City Center on Dec. 22 and approved an extension of her West Coast tour in the comedy.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 10 -As Suffolk County prepared for Hurricane Edna it learned today that the first steps had been taken to repair the damage wrought by its destructive predecessor, Hurricane Carol.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The drought eased somewhat during August but too late to prevent "irreparable damage" to some of the corn, soybean and late hay crops, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

The Mayor and the Police Commissioner were officially requested yesterday to permit bingo games conducted solely by and for religious and charitable institutions and veterans' organizations. A resolution to this effect was filed with the City Clerk by Edward A. Cunningham, Bronx Democrat and chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A group of sixty-nine railroads today challenged the legality of a Post Office experiment in flying first-class mail for regular 3-cent rates.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Pending the development of a permanent measure against poliomyelitis, the best defense against the disease advised here today was personal cleanliness and avoiding contact with infected persons.

BROOK, Ind., Sept. 10 -- Friends and neighbors of the late George Ade have pledged new efforts to restore his English manor-type home on the bank of the Iroquois River. It has been vacant most of the time since the death of the Hoosier humorist and writer in 1944.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 10 (AP) -- National consumption of paper by 1980 will be four times greater than at present, reaching about one hundred million tons a year, Frank C. Ash, president of the Oswego Falls Corporation, Fulton, N. Y., forecast today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Wheat had a weak tone most of the session today, but met fair support on the setbacks.

A one-volume edition of James Fenimore Cooper's well-known "Leatherstocking" novels is planned for Oct. 1 publication by Pantheon Books. It will be titled "The Leatherstocking Saga." The novels have been edited by Allan Nevins, who eliminated repetitious passages and scenes not related to the careers and characters of the central figures (Hawkeye, Deerslayer and Leatherstocking).

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer announced tonight his Government considered membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the most practical and rapid means of solving the problem of West Germany's rearmament.

The quartet of chess players representing the Netherlands in the international tournament at Apollo Hall, yesterday was the first obstacle which the champion Russian grandmasters failed to take in their stride, according to a report from Amsterdam.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits said today that the foreign policy of the United States and the free world was "at the moment in a slump."
Carmen Basilio, Canastota (N. Y.) welterweight, outpointed Carmine Fiore, from the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

DENVER, Sept. 10 -- President Eisenhower and Republican chairmen from nineteen Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states met here today to discuss the best methods for obtaining a larger Republican majority in the new Congress.
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 10 -- The Trades Union Congress rejected today a Communist-led attempt to put it on record as firmly opposed to any form of wage restraint.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Frank Kellert, San Antonio farmhand making his first start at first base, pounded out a ninth-inning single tonight to give a 4-3 victory to the Baltimore Orioles over the Washington Senators.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- The United States urged the Soviet Union today to negotiate in good faith -- face to face or through the International Court of Justice -- to fix responsibility for air attacks involving their planes.
The celebration of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States will begin tomorrow and continue for eight and a half months in 250 cities and towns over the country.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 21.7 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 24.5 per cent and orders 21.8 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the left wing in the Labor party, said today that democratic freedom would come to Southeast Asia -- including Communist China -- when the people "get their heads above the starvation line."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The United States Information Agency said tonight that showings of Cinerama in Damascus, Syria, were so successful the local Communists were accusing the United States of "unfair competition."

DETROIT, Sept. 10. (UP) -- Jim Finigan's Ninth-inning single chased across two runners today, enabling the Philadelphia Athletics, to gain a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 1,389 fans at Briggs Stadium.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 10 (UP) -- The general manager of the American Power Association urged New York municipalities today to "compete aggressively" for a supply of low cost power from the St. Lawrence power project.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 8 -- A three-way Republican contest in New Hampshire for nomination for a two-year term in the Senate will hold major interest at primary elections to be held Tuesday in three New England states.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 10 -- The downtown section of this city looked like a deserted village at 9 o'clock tonight. The residents had returned to their homes in anticipation of Hurricane Edna, the second violent wind and rain storm in ten days.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants will produce 68,470 cars and 14,007 trucks this week, the lowest weekly count since late November, 1953.
Des Moines, Iowa, announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Sept. 30 on an issue of $2,500,000 of independent school district bonds maturing annually on Oct. 1 from 1955 to 1973.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- The Misses Margaret Huguley and Ellen Margaret McCance made their debuts tonight at a supper dance given in the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Huguley Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McCance, all of Mount Kisco.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Gen. Abdon Parra, Minister of Interior, announced tonight that negotiations to end the copper, coal and transportation strikes had failed and that the Army had taken control of five provinces, the major strike centers.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today estimated the world market surplus of raw sugar in 1954 at 254,000 metric tons and said Cuba had agreed to cut its export quota by 66,000 metric tons.

The $11,228,000 Pulaski Bridge across Newtown Creek, linking the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn with Long Island City, Queens, was opened to traffic at noon yesterday. An hour later, the Vernon Avenue Bridge, which the new span replaces, was closed.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Voluntary German assurances on the extent and nature of the Bonn Federal Republic's armed forces under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be discussed in Brussels tomorrow when Anthony Eden of Britain meets the foreign ministers of the Benelux nations, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A panel of physicians said today there was a "strong relationship" between cigaret-smoking and lung cancer but refused to list smoking as a "cause" of the affliction.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept 10 -- The Bank of Indonesia has expressed concern over the continued decline in the country's economic position and made it clear that serious times probably lay ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Following are the text of a speech made today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of the United States before the United Nations Security Council and excerpts from a speech by Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent to 109.7 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

" BEYOND THE HUNDREDTH MERIDIAN," by Wallace Stegner, is the story of John Wesley Powell, 1834-1902, one of the great movers and shakers in the opening of the West. Although Powell is most widely known for his spectacular pioneering voyage through the Grand Canyon of the Colorado, he was at least equally fearless and adroit in navigating the awesome rapids and echoing canyons of bureaucratic Washington.
Postal inspectors and city detectives captured two bandits at pistol point last night, thus foiling an attempted hold-up of a mail truck in the heart of Greenwich Village.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the F. B. I. will join forces, cinematically speaking, to thwart an atomic bomb espionage plot in "Canada's Great Manhunt," to be produced independently by Samuel Bischoff and David Diamond for United Artists release.

MORGANTON, N. C., Sept. 10 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, suggested tonight that Congress investigate the role of the Budget Director, Rowland R. Hughes, in the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- A controvesy that has divided the Greek religious community of Los Angeles for more than a year was settled today by the State Superior Court.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Minx, owned by Don Matthews and Jacob Isbrandtsen of the host club, won the first of the five-race national Raven Class championship off the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club today.
Two Brooklyn television tube manufacturers were released in $7,500 bail each as material witnesses yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 10 -- The Navy today ordered eighty warships and more than 250 propeller-type aircraft evacuated from local military installations here as "unpredictable" Hurricane Edna threatened to invade the Virginia coast late tonight or early tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay announced today the allocation of about $1,800,000 to initiate a greatly expanded research program designed to strengthen the commercial fishing industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A New York optometrist, who-says he has watched straphangers of medium height suffer and struggle on the subways for more than thirty years, received a patent this week on a hanger strap that is adjustable for short persons.

John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker in the recent sale of a hospital site on the blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue between East Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets to the New York Foundling Hospital by the Chanin Organization.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 10 -- The chief of Japan's new military establishment said today that his country planned to have about 150,000 men under arms by next spring.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates pushed across a run in the ninth on Dick Cole's scratch single to give them a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -Record yields per acre will probably be produced this year in five of the nine major burley tobacco states, including Kentucky, the biggest producer, the Department of Agriculture said.

Reason, understanding and the disinterested search for knowledge become the exception; passion, dogmatism and a brutal conformity become the rule.

Passengers arriving here by ship in August totaled 61,488, one of the highest figures in years, according to the monthly customs report yesterday by Collector Robert W. Dill.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Democrats are long on hope and short on cash as they approach the mid-term Congressional elections.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Nassau County's powerful Republican organization, alerted by court battles with two insurgents seeking places on the ballot, is showing unusual interest in Tuesday's elections.

THE novel -- whatever its other manifold distinctions and occasional backwaters -- is a form traditionally devoted to story-telling; and our first, almost instinctive response as readers is generally to the story told, to the people of the book and what they do.
QUEBEC, Sept. 6 -- Opposition to compulsory military service is lessening in French Canada.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Ned Garver stopped the Philadelphia Athletics on three hits today and the Detroit Tigers scored a 2-to-1 triumph. It was Garver's fourteenth victory of the season.

NEWARK, Sept. 11 -- The campaign headquarters of Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senate, announced today that Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, would address the Republican party centennial next Saturday at Monmouth Park, Oceanport, N. J.

Browning King Co. will open the fifth store in its men's wear chain Thursday at 666 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets. The old Gunther-Jaeckel Building has been remodeled by Horace Ginsbern Associates, architects, and Boriss-Breslow, general contractors, for the purpose.

THE art of punctuation is going through some queer shenanigans. It is still understood and practiced by the British, but among ourselves it has become a haphazard, hit or miss affair. This is not altogether surprising, given an elementary and secondary school system in which fundamentals have been tossed out the window, plus a deep-seated national antipathy to rules and regulations.

AMONG the vegetable curiosities to be seen in markets and gardens now is the purple cauliflower. In fact, it might win the title for the most neglected vegetable of all. But then the knowing gardener who has discovered this unique, colorful crop rates it far above the other members of the cabbage family.

FOR all its sophistication and glibness, Mr. Kaufmann's fifth novel is an old-fashioned, didactic story, crammed with purpose and uplift. Its hero is Alex Harris, a not-too-bright college teacher with an underdeveloped sense of ethics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Federal Housing Administration took its first direct step today toward claiming for the Government millions of dollars in "windfall" housing profits.

NOW is the season of the deluge, the annual fall outpouring from the presses -- be-ginning this week at full flood, and continuing at crest until the first Santa Claus appears on Fifth Avenue. The sampling below is gleaned at random by a reader already skimming with the tide.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- India accused Portugal today of "taking up a new position" on proposals for impartial observation of dispute areas between India and the three Portuguese territories in India.
Big Don Newcombe pitched his first complete game in more than three months and the Dodgers last night tumbled the Milwaukee Braves out of second place by beating them, 5 -- 3, at Ebbets Field.

WRITING with somewhat conscious quaintness under her married name, Mrs. Robert Henrey has established her personality and won a circle of devoted readers. Her two previous books, particularly. "The Little Madeleine," an account of growing up in Paris, displayed freshness, keen observation and lack of pretension.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- Miss California, a tall brown-haired drama student with blue-green eyes, tonight was crowned Miss America.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Hurricane Edna, apparently rent asunder by her own violence, reeled northeastward along the New England coast today with one final howl of wind that plunged many sections back into darkness for the night.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, under the direction of Sergei J. Denham, has been reorganized after an interval of two years and begins a new period of operation Oct. 1. On that day in Baltimore it opens a tour of 102 cities and 175 performances under the auspices of Coppicus, Schang and Brown (Columbia Artists Management.)
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The Soviet Union's share in the United Nations budget has been increased for the fourth consecutive year.

GARDENERS need not blame all their sweet corn troubles this year on the dry weather. Part of the wilting and drying up may be due to the bacterial wilt known as Stewart's disease. For this unusual disease has been particularly severe this season, especially on early varieties.

EARLY in September, 1654, a French privateer, the St. Charles, a frigate mounting five guns, commanded by Capt. Jacques de la Motthe, sailed into the harbor of New Amsterdam. Twenty-three of the frigate's human cargo were Jews, men, women and children, transported from the Dutch colony in Brazil via a Caribbean port, after much peril and adventure (including capture by pirates). They were the first families of Jewish settlers to come to this country.

WHEN a workman is unceasingly and exclusively engaged in the fabrication of one thing, he ultimately does his Work with singular dexterity; but at the same time he loses the general faculty of applying his mind to the direction of the work.

John Foster Dulles, in nearly twenty months as Secretary of State, has spent an aggregate of five months abroad on affairs of State. He has made thirteen trips totaling about 130,000 miles. His itinerary reads like a gazetteer and a catalogue of the key capitals in a world in turmoil -- London, Paris, Rome, Berlin, Geneva, Caracas, Cairo, New Delhi, Seoul, Manila.

WITH Robert Ardrey's "Sing Me No Lullaby" scheduled to open the Phoenix Theatre's season on Oct. 14, and "Sandhog," the Earl Robinson-Waldo Salt musical slated to follow, Nov. 23, Norris Houghton and T. Edward Hambleton, co-mentors of the Second Avenue playhouse, now are in the process of brewing additional heady plans for the remainder of the campaign.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The New York State Committee for the Prevention of Alcoholism has mapped an expansion program that ultimately will establish chapters of the organization in about fifty communities.

JOSIAH GREGG'S "Commerce of the Prairies" was published in New York 110 years ago this summer. It went through numerous printings and was issued in England and Germany, but for generations has been virtually unprocurable except in second-hand condition.

Five times over the past five years, Joseph R. McCarthy has been investigated by a Senate committee. But he has never undergone an investigation comparable to the one now being conducted under the chairmanship of Arthur V. Watkins of Utah. The task which the Senate entrusted last month to tile select Watkins committee was to weigh the charges that had been offered in support of the motion of censure introduced by Senator Flanders of Vermont.

PURISTS argue that science fiction is a genus of writing having no immediate kinship with what they disdainfully refer to as "fantasy." August Derleth refuses to accept any such absurd classification. In assembling this first volume of what he promises will be an annual series, he has eschewed all such tenuous lines of demarcation and has collected sixteen of the best of 1953's stories of fantasy.

The city of Toledo has now received a master plan for the development of its port for lake and sea traffic. An engineering and planning survey has resulted in a recommendation of an expenditure of $25,250,000 for a great cargo terminal and a splendid recreation area, dikes for two basins and a parkway parallel to the shore line.
Columbia University's third century begins this morning as about 650 Columbia College freshmen move into dormitories for a ten-day period of orientation into the life of a college man.
Two unusual vocational training schools, one Belgian and one British, will arrive in this country this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The human race will reap a macabre harvest of "defective individuals" because of the increase in "background radiation" caused by only the few atomic and hydrogen bombs that have been exploded to date.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer faces the voters of Schleswig-Holstein tomorrow in the first provincial election since the European Defense Community treaty was rejected by the French National Assembly.

The most difficult part of the job of meeting higher-education needs in the Nineteen Sixties and Nineteen Seventies will not be the expansion of physical facilities but the development of a large group of high-quality scholar-teachers, according to Prof. R. H. Eckelbury of Ohio State University.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and the United States "might well give more attention" to their neighbors in the Western Hemisphere in which are the fortresses and arsenals of democracy, Robert Moses, chairman of the New York Power Authority, said here today.

FALL travelers through the Southwest and New Mexico will find considerable gaiety around Taos and Santa Fe. For at this season when autumn weather is usually at its best, both resident artists and Pueblo Indians join in civic merrymaking.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 -- The coming evacuation of United States troops from Hokkaido, northernmost island of Japan and the one closest to the Soviet frontier, shed new light today on charges that G. I.'s have been a source of trouble to the Japanese.

In its first formal reaction the Soviet Government has given a very cool reception to the recent easing of the embargo on strategic goods exports by the United States and Western European nations to Soviet bloc countries.
HARTFORD, Sept. 11 -- Connecticut Republicans have promised to conduct an election campaign "free of appeals to racial and religious groups."
A 14-year-old Polish boy who escaped alone through the Iron Curtain last year, posing as a mute to avoid detection, arrived in Near York yesterday on his way to Boys Town, near Omaha, Neb.

This is the week-end of the harvest moon, which, regardless of calendar or equinox, is autumnal as a corn shock. The full moon doesn't come till tomorrow, but, as reasonably clear skies return, it will be a moon-lit weekend. The harvest moon is not a hasty moon; it comes early and stays late.

ON vegetable seed farms all hands are busy this month harvesting crops not to eat but to collect seed for next year's spring planting. Unlike the production of flower seed, vegetables are grown for this purpose across the length and breadth of the land.

When the fifty-seventh year of the city's school health services begins tomorrow, a single injection will be available for immunization against both diphtheria and tetanus. In the past, separate injections were needed.
An annual directive issued at Police Headquarters asked all commanding officers to instruct members of the force to give the subject of street safety special attention when school opens tomorrow.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 -- The United States' economy is undergoing exploratory surgery at the sessions of the American Statistical Association here to see how well the economic medicine of President Eisenhower is benefiting the patient.

Delivery bottlenecks seem to be developing in several types of goods because early fall business has exceeded pre-season expectations, resident buying offices report. Reorders are increasing, they note.

The Port of New York Authority has awarded a $1,728,420 contract for plaza reconstruction at the Lincoln Tunnel and authorized a $1,000,000 project for a new building and for some renovation at the Holland Tunnel.

The lead sentence in the Sunday column "fullbacks -- the bigger they are, the harder they fall," was not originally a football expression at all. It was first said by Ruby Robert Fitzsimmons and according to Bartlett was originally "The bigger they come, the harder they fall."

THE thirty - six musicians who have been teaching at the summer music school in Aspen, Col. -- and they include Mack Harrell, Rudolf Firkusny, Szymon Goldberg and Vronsky and Babin -- have agreed to shoulder the responsibility of running both the music school and the music festival at Aspen next summer. To help them in their now independent undertaking, the town of Aspen has already raised $25,000.

Birds that sing the same song over and over again appear to get bored with their efforts, according to a report to the American Ornithological Association meeting in Madison, Wis., last week. Philosophy Prof. Charles Hartshorne of the University of Chicago, a bird watcher, said that birds that sing only one simple song over and over pause long between repetitions.

TRACHOMA (literally "roughness") is a dread eye disease which affects from 15 to 20 per cent of the entire world population with painful granulation of the eyelids, often culminating in blindness. In certain parts of China it is the cause of 50 per cent of all blindness; in the state of Missouri, of 25 per cent.
SCHENECTADY, Sept. 11 -- Senator Irving M. Ives endorsed today the legalization of bingo on a local option basis.

FRESH grapes attract both eye and appetite at this season with their diversity in size, shape, color and flavor. Harvest of table varieties in California, which supplies ninetenths of all grapes sold and processed in this country, is expected to be a third larger than a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Sir Alexander MacFurquhar, resident representative in Pakistan for the United Nations Technical Assistance Board, described today the reclamation this year of 250,000 acres of land in East Bengal that added materially to the food production of the area.
