BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 11 -- The Benelux powers -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- accepted and endorsed today British proposals for rearmament of West Germany under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

HARTFORD, Sept. 11 -- More than $260,000,000 will be needed for school construction in Connecticut in the next six years, the State Education Commissioner Finis E. Engleman reported this week to Gov. John Lodge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Partly because of local pressures and partly because of President Eisenhower's expressed concern, the District of Columbia is abandoning its traditional dual school system without waiting for the Supreme Court to issue rules.
This year's short cotton crop may result in a cut of 2,000,000 bales in the carry-over from previous crops.

IN an era when the handling of humorous fantasy is, with a dozen exceptions named Perelman, White, Thurber and de Vries, pretty generally humorless and almost certainly fantastic, "The Year the Yankees Lost the Pennant" stands out as authoritatively as a .400 hitter would on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

St. Barnabas House, which provides shelter for homeless women and children, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Desperate Hours" on the night of Feb. 1 at a theatre yet to be named. The play is a dramatization by Joseph Hayes of his book of the same name.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Communist Rumania has charged the First Secretary of the Israeli Legation with having helped a Rumanian in an attempt to flee, and has demanded that the diplomat leave immediately, the Bucharest radio said today.

NEW ORLEANS -- Four major undertakings, one of them completed only recently and the other three progressing nicely, are big news for visitors to this tourist-drawing city as pleasant fall weather comes in sight. The completed task is the new $2,225,000 Union Station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Eisenhower has called his principal Cabinet members to Denver this week-end for a Sunday afternoon session on topics including the increased military activity in the Formosa Straits.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Sept. 1 -- The transition from colonial rule to complete "Sudanization" is proceeding at a whirlwind pace in the former Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 31 -- The forces of the drys in British Columbia seem to have won an unexpected moral victory, in a left-handed sort of way, in the nine months or so since more liberal liquor regulations came into effect.

THIS fall's fashions have been designed specifically for the mobility of modern life. Women today need wearable, compact clothes that are pretty but practical, smart but simple, elegant but easy. Ease, the word most applied to these styles, has been achieved by meticulous designer talent. Without binding the body, clothes complement the moving figure.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared today under searching cross-examination that the document purloined from Army Intelligence files should be made public.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Joe Miceli of New York scored a split decision over Wallace (Bud) Smith of Cincinnati in a spirited boxing contest tonight. The decision was loudly booed.

THESE poems are the tragic report of an overwhelming loss and they are superior in expression to many such testaments of sorrow. WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, left for Europe today for an assessment of problems of Western security.
MIAMI, Sept. 11 (AP) -- What is a hurricane like ? One Navy pilot declares that flying into one is like being "swallowed by an epileptic whale" or like "going over Niagara Falls in a phone booth."

THIS is the story of a nightmare journey across the United States -- with trailer. Only a mild, preoccupied professor with a madly energetic and optimistic wife would have attempted such a jaunt, particularly as they were accompanied by a baby and an outsize Scottish deerhound named Cholmondeley.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Pope Pius XII praised today the "enthusiasm" of the American children who had participated in tests of new cures for poliomyelitis. He made the statement at an audience granted to the third International Poliomyelitis Conference.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Averell Harriman had to face the competition of Hurricane Edna here today in his first political speech since being endorsed by a group of key Democratic leaders for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A saving of at least $120,000,000 a year through increased efficiency and streamlining of operations in the civil service and postal systems was predicted today by a House of Representatives committee.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 11 -- The national Woodrow Wilson fellowship program will begin canvassing more than 650 colleges this week for nominations toward fellowships for the academic year 1955-56.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Sharp Note, the 1952 Hambletonian winner, making his second start of the season after being sidelined for a year with a lung ailment, won the $3,500 Star Night mile and one-six-teenth trot in 2:13 1/5 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

THE prospect of Japanese movies ever building up to the point where they equal TV as competition to the domestic circulation of American films is one that the Hollywood producers need not view with alarm.

The prospect of new mergers in the men's clothing industry sharpened last week. Joseph H. Cohen Sons, Inc., long a claimant of the title of the "largest men's clothing producer in the country," announced that it planned to triple its annual volume of about $33,000,000 by the end of 1955.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11 -- Indications in the closing days of the election campaign in Maine are that Senator Margaret Chase Smith has assured herself of a second term by judicious political fence-mending during each of the fourteen Octobers since she first went to Washington.

SUNBURY, Pa. -- People who like to drive for the sake of scenery will find plenty to satisfy them in the valley of the Susquehanna River. By spending a night or two in motels along the way, New Yorkers can take in some of the finest mountain scenery in the East in a leisurely week-end excursion.

ROME, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A secret high-level investigation into the mysterious death of Wilma Montesi will be wound up Monday. The results will be turned over to a Rome court for further action.

BY all odds the most popular and most discussed painting in Moscow today is a Large canvas called "The Return," by S. A. Grigoriev -- a painting which is designed to tell a story and pose a problem. It depicts a husband who, having strayed, returns to his wife and family. He sits, downcast and somewhat ashamed; awaiting the verdict of his wife and children.

MASSENA, N. Y. -- Aside from taking on new industrial importance, New York State's "north country" bordering the St. Lawrence River is expected to become one of the state's important tourist objectives and recreation areas once the St. Lawrence Power and Seaway developments have been completed.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 -- The Montreal Alouettes increased their lead in the Big Four Football League to two games today when they trounced the champion Hamilton Tiger-Cats, 21 -- 3, for their fourth straight victory of the season.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers, winners of last season's league honors, tied Manchester United in the top spot today in English soccer.

The theft of so enormous a sum ($2,500,000) with -- at least so far as is publicly known -- complete avoidance of detection, is such an impressive feat that it's hardly surprising to find two new novels now added to the literature on the case.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 6 -- More than 2,250,000 long tons of iron ore have been shipped to the United States from deposits in southern Peru since they were opened early last year by a North American concern.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 11 -- The Government of Dr. Daniel F. Malan is seeking to escape from its political isolation by tightening its bonds with Britain. Efforts also are being made to patch things up with the British-oriented two-fifths of the white population in this country.

THE author of "The Castle" wrote a great deal more than used to be supposed. He had his eternal conviction of despair which he was always trying to make intelligible in words. When he was not composing stories and novels, he was keeping notebooks and journals, phrasing aphorisms, or sending off long letters to his friends.

Robert E. "Dumas" Milner has seen southern Mississippi transformed from a piney woods into a rising industrial area. At the same time he has grown from a childhood in moderate circumstances to the point of ownership of businesses that gross more than $20,000,000 a year.
FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Marian duPont Scott's Mighty Mo held on today to win the fifteenth running of the Foxcatcher National Cup steeplechase from Lowry Watkins' Tourist List.

Rocky Marciano, the undefeated heavyweight champion of the world, will risk his crown against a former titleholder, Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati in a scheduled fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night.

" WE are not real. We crave reality." This nostalgic epigraph strikes the keynote of Maria Kuncewicz's novel -- a folktale of divided loyalties. In "the struggle for reality" of a father and son in nineteenth-century Poland, "The Forester" re-creates that country's struggle for survival.

WITH justifiable pride, Victor has brought out on three records the performance of Falstaff by soloists and the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Arturo Toscanini, which N. B. C. broadcast on April 1 and 8, 1950.

ONE of the most conventional chores in the literary salt mines is writing the official biography (or ghost-writing the "autobiography") of a living business man. The rules of the art are rigid. Successes must be described in detail and failures minimized.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Bobby Walston, Philadelphia's leading scorer last year, piled up 18 points tonight on a pair of touchdowns, a field goal and three extra points as the Eagles swamped the Chicago Cardinals, 30 -- 0, in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams.
What Long Island suffered yesterday was a good, hard wind and rainstorm, but never a hurricane.

A NOVEL, based on a solid (and well-tested) framework, "Buccaneer Surgeon" adds something new to the tale of the Spanish Main in the days of Drake. This is the sense of honor and integrity the author succeeds in imparting to the two central characters in their conflicting relationships with each other.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 11 -- Col. Louis Wessels chief of the Special Branch of the South African Police, announced today that South African legislation was to be brought into line with United States legislation to control travel abroad of Communists and suspected persons.

QUEMOY, China, Sept. 11 -- The Chinese Communists still are sporadically pumping shells onto this Nationalist-held island from their positions in the Amoy area near-by. Now and then the windows of Quemoy shake and rattle under the impact of the Communist fire.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. assured his supporters today that he still was in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 11 -- Iran's governmental planning organization, established six years ago to apply oil revenues to internal economic and social development, is preparing to divest itself of its twenty operating companies and sell some of them to private investors.

DURING the past few years Daniel Lang, a staff writer for The New Yorker, has been acting as unofficial reporter on new weapons, nuclear and otherwise. He is not primarily concerned with the fission and fusion of atoms, the electronic "brains" that guide guided missiles, or other technical matters.

Sidney Hook's article "Should Our Schools Study Communism?" (Aug. 29) nails down all the arguments for the teaching of communism and other controversial subjects in its statement, "Hatred and fear of communism are not enough.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals collected eight hits today to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7 -- 2. Tom Poholsky of the Cards allowed six hits, all singles.

DENVER, Sept 11 -- A primary fight that recently has taken on the aspects of an old-fashioned mining camp brawl was nearing its climax in this state today as two prominent Colorado political figures sought the Democratic party's nomination for United States Senator.

The purchasing power of the average celrgyman's income is less today than it was in 1939, the Research and Survey Department of the National Council of Churches reports in the 1955 Yearbook of American Churches. The publication will appear Tuesday.
If it were not so handy, the term "war babies" should be stricken from the Wall Street vocabulary.

Fires in industrial plants are causing more concern than ever before. In the last twelve months in American industry, seventy employes were killed in fires, many more were injured and plant losses of more than $110,000,000 were sustained.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S. C., took a commanding eight-stroke lead today in the St. Louis women's open golf tournament, as she conquered slick greens and a troublesome wind for a three-under-par 73.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The old controversy is on again as to whether George Washington and Martha Dandridge Custis were married in her home or in her church.
Former Mayor William O'Dwyer has instituted a civil suit in United States Tax Court against a claim by the Internal Revenue Service that he owes $9,000 in additional income taxes.

IN the article by Waldo Frank on Thoreau's "Walden" we find this sentence: "Anyone [today] who tried to build himself a hut in somebody's woods a few miles out of town, without first acquiring a lot, would find he had tangled with more regulations than if he had rented an apartment on Main Street."

Plans for what was called the world's longest undersea pipeline were announced yesterday. The forty-eight-mile line will be laid in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana. It will be a twelve-inch, electric-welded steel pipe with a double coal-tar enamel wrap and a twelve-inch reinforced concrete coating.

CHICAGO, Sept 11 -- Business conditions in the Chicago area are showing definite signs of improvement, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago survey of August business revealed. Improvement stemmed mainly from an increase in production and employment and the firmer positions of volume and profit, the monthly questionnaire said.

THIS wild yarn of a trip to Mars taken by a crassly materialistic scientist, a young snob of a pilot and a beautiful gal stowaway is a foggy attempt at fusing together science, fiction and theology. I'm afraid the book is a failure on all three accounts.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- There was only one delay of consequence this afternoon and that followed the running of the $29,825 World's Plaground stakes. It was caused by a razzle dazzle finish in which the judges had to make a lengthy examination of photographs. The hurricane? It didn't hold up the program a minute.

THE relative importance of the makers of a nation's laws and the writers of a nation's songs is well understood. Who would want to listen to the junior Senator from -- oh, well, that one -- when he might be listening to Cole Porter?
Low-rent public housing may still be an issue in Congress, but the Federally subsidized public housing bond is no longer a hot potato as far as the investment world is concerned.

TOMATO plants are now at their peak of production in home gardens, market gardens and on farms. Red, pink and yellow fruits are picked from the vines at their most colorful as well as their most flavorful and juicy stage.

IF all the novels set in Greenwich Village could be piled up on top of Washington Arch, it would surely come tumbling down under the weight Storekeepers, newsboys and janitors in that area are so blase about appearing as fictional characters that they can't even be induced to buy the books as keepsakes any more.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Governor Dewey made a free-swinging attack on Democratic issues and candidates when he opened a vigorous personal campaign tonight for the election of Senator Irving M. Ives as his Republican successor.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 11 -- The contest between Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d, Republican incumbent, who has organization backing in his bid for renomination, and William P. Shea will be the only one in Tuesday's primary election in Suffolk County.

LAST Tuesday night "Marty" came home to the Bronx by way of Hollywood. Unmindful of swelling crowds, the traffic congestion on West Farms Road and a deafening subway roar overhead, a small but dedicated Norma Productions unit set up shop before the R. K. O. Chester Theatre to film Paddy Chayevsky's highly acclaimed television show of last season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- It has been fully established in the history of both the Senate and the House that a member can be formally "censured" by a majority. What happens after that to the member's status is not so clear, but the Senate at least once accepted an apology as full expiation of the offense for which it had voted censure.
Appliance Park, biggest private industrial development in Kentucky, will begin to roll refrigerators off its assembly lines for the first time next month.

HERE is another of Groff Conklin's "patterned" anthologies, a collection of stories about the problems inherent in the relationship between man and machines that think. Conklin groups such dangerous servants into three classes: robots, androids and computers.

THE most important thing to keep in mind about the Communist movement in Italy is that it has a true mass support. This is the case in no other country of Europe, least of all behind the Iron Curtain and not even in France, where the Communist vote is large and the Communists have ninety-six deputies out of 627 in the Chamber.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Washington Senators got only four hits -- all singles -- off Don Larsen today, but they put two of them together with three walks in the fourth inning for all their runs as they whipped the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 0.
ANN ARBOR, Mich, Sept. 11 -- Findings are probable before the poliomyelitis, season arrives next summer on whether the Salk vaccine administered to 440,000 school children this spring is effective.

Reports from Rome last week suggest that scientists who have taken part in the mass tests of the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis are satisfied that the vaccine will work. Everything in the tests has gone according to plan, said speakers in papers presented at the Third International Poliomyelitis Conference, held in the Orthopedic Clinic of the University of Rome.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 -- Canada's St. Lawrence ports expect to see full restoration within the next few years of the wide variety of passenger sailings they handled before the war. The maiden arrival here Wednesday of Cunard's 22,000-ton liner Saxonia marked the start of this improvement, which should see more than 100,000 tons of new passenger tonnage from two companies alone on the river route by 1960.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Liberal party council approved today a letter sent to Prime Minister Churchill last night uring the recall of Parliament and full British support for a "new and dynamic quest to achieve a united Europe."

As the 1954-55 academic year gets under way, the nation's public elementary and high schools have a record enrollment of 30,673,500 pupils. The increase over last year's record total amounts to 1,500,000.

A FEW years before the turn of the century, James Stuart Blackton, a young reporter-cartoonist for the New York World, was sent on a journey to New Jersey to interview Thomas A. Edison about his new pictures that moved.

OUT in the fastness of Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street there sprawls a red brick building, square and squat. Once upon a time (almost two years ago) this homely structure led the humdrum existence of a milk bottling plant.

While the indefatigable cruiser yachtsmen of the metropolitan area are holding their predicted-log finale of the season Saturday on Long Island Sound, an assembly of most of the country's best speed boats will be churning the waters of the Potomac at Washington Saturday and Sunday in the President's Cup Regatta. Both are banner events.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Britain, whose mile runners and jet aircraft have given the United States some stiff competition recently, added new speed laurels to her brow today.

THE DALLES, Ore. -- Oregon's most famous tourist attraction has been transformed from a looping lariat into a taut ribbon. The spectacular Columbia River Highway, twisting among the crags between Portland and The Dalles like a goat path, now has been augmented with a high-speed express road which clings to water level beside the greatest hydroelectric power stream in North America.

The eight-nation agreement that was signed in Manila last Wednesday has been designated and discussed chiefly as a defense pact. The need for it arose from a common danger. It is a joint effort to devise means to meet that danger. Since the threat is military in one of its aspects, it is natural and proper that meeting the threat should also involve planning for military defense.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- At a new woodland park a quarter-mile east of here, the thirty-first annual Yorktown Grange Fair will open Thursday and continue through Saturday.

JOHN FORD, whose great affection for the Ould Sod has never been a deep secret, is planning to return to Eire, where he filmed his affectionate and comic "The Quiet Man," to produce and direct a feature-length trilogy, it became known the other day.

Hurricane Edna, with a feminine propensity for changing her mind, took a path well out to sea from Long Island and the Middle Atlantic States yesterday. But even so, her seaward rush northward lashed landsmen with gales and torrential rains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security contended today that the Eighty-Third Congress had demonstrated that investigations fulfilled their function of aiding in recommending and framing of laws.

HUNTINGTON CENTER, Vt., Sept. 11 -- Three baby musk oxen captured by an American expedition on a barren tundra in the Canadian Northwest territory began a new life last week on a 640-acre Vermont farm.

One of the interesting -- and disturbing -- sidelights of the French rejection of the European Defense Community is the sense of being misunderstood and maligned that so many Frenchmen, led by Premier Mendes-France, are expressing. The letter we print today from Henri Pierre, United States correspondent of the distinguished Parisian newspaper Le Monde, is a case in point.
The writer, a former member of the Abbey Theatre, is the author of "Home Is the Hero," in which he plays a starring role. The play is due at the Booth on Sept. 22.

DURING September and October this year the ancient Italian city of Bologna honors, with a large exhibition, one of the glories of her artistic past, the seventeenth-century Baroque painter Guido Reni. There is reason to hope that this important event is due, moreover, to a genuine reawakening of interest in the culture of a city which has been, at certain periods, a dominant artistic capital.
The High School Teachers Association has urged its members not to perform any voluntary extracurricular services when the city's schools reopen tomorrow..

IF you happen to have a bright, young, humorous son who keeps all his classmates in constant stitches and is thinking of becoming a professional humorist, you owe it to him to buy him "The Benchley Roundup." He may not find every one of these pieces (written between 1915 and 1945) quite as funny as you might find them.

THIS is the story of a humane elephant, a town of tiny creatures named Whos, and various intolerant animals. It is probably the most moral tale since the first"Elsie Dinsmore," but since it is written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss it is a lot more fun.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 11 -- A strange situation has developed in the wake of the heavy Chinese Communist bombardment of Nationalist-held Quemoy Island off the Southeast China coast.

FABLES are in high fashion this year, and Aubrey Menen has produced a timely example. This young Indo - Irish writer has already written five percipient, satirical and compassionate tales, "Dead Man in the Silver Market" being the most recent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- The Yankees blew a two-run lead over the Chicago White Sox in the ninth and lost, 6 -- 5, in the tenth to fall six and a half lengths behind the flag-bound Cleveland Indians today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies took advantage of five Chicago Cub errors for an 8-2 victory in the second game and a sweep of today's double-header. The Phils won the opener, 3 -- 0, behind the two-hit pitching of Herm Wehmeier.
The Friends of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will hold their fourth annual luncheon on Nov. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

NOT out of sight but possibly out of mind, especially at this time of year, are the unobtrusive evergreens. Blending neatly into the home landscape, they are likely to play second fiddle to the colorful floral displays now around them.

Women coming to this country to take work in our colleges and universities are more interested in "American studies" than ever before. A listing, by study fields, of fifty-four university women from twenty-two countries who have received grants this year from the American Association of University Women shows that courses on American subject-matter are the most popular.

NEW YORK CITY is richer than most cities in historical lore. It is by far the richest city in America in terms of theatrical resources. It is poorer than most only in community spirit. With the opening of Battery Park Recreation Center there is at least one setting ideal for an outdoor historical drama.

WHO wrote "The Teahouse, of the August Moon" ? John Patrick, according to the program. As usual, the program is correctly informed. But it also declares that "The Teahouse of the August Moon" is "based on the novel by Vern Sneider," and this common situation raises a familiar and baffling problem.

WITH school opening in this city tomorrow and with daylight hours waning, motorists would do well to develop the quality of foresight as protection to themselves and others. This is particularly true in urban areas where traffic is often congested and erratic, and where skill in guiding the car can often prevent accidents.

DAWN POWELL'S parish, as her followers know, is wealth - infested, mink - mad Manhattan. Her arsenal, as this latest novel proves, retains its fire-power -- including the most exquisite acid since Dorothy Parker and a fastidious pair of pincers with which to tweak the soul.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- One of the largest collections of papers and manuscripts pertaining to a single Jewish family in American history has been obtained by the American Jewish Archives at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion here.

THIS homey, easy-to-read tale takes Betsy, her little sister, and their friends through another series of everyday adventures. In her characteristic, straight-faced manner, the author weaves humor into a number of near-calamities -- the fate of Policeman Kilpatrick's birthday cake, Billy's chagrin when his prized Easter egg backfires, and Betsy's efforts to earn enough money for a coveted Mother's Day gift.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- A five-hit shutout by Art Houtteman, his fifteenth victory against six losses, beat the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 0, today for the Cleveland Indians.
THERE are several factors that can spoil a hunting trip -- ill-fitting shoes, inadequate clothing, inclement weather, uncongenial hunting companions, and a bad guide.

Prime Minister Moshe Sharett of Israel, in a message yesterday, emphasized the need for his nation's economic consolidation to overcome "changes in the balance of power in the Middle East foreshadowed by the policy of arming the Arab states."
A program for advanced study in textiles will be discussed this week by industry executives, officials of Columbia University and the Textile Research Institute of Princeton University.
The boom in the investments markets has been a been to the makers of bond and stock certificates.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gerard Laureau of France, driving a French D. B. Panhard, today won the Ulster Tourist Trophy race, Britain's leading auto road run. Laureau's average speed for the ninety-four-lap, 660-mile race was 68.75 miles an hour.

IGOR GOUZENKO complains in the interview with Tania Long that writers in the free world write books that are escapist and allegorical. He wants the difference between good and evil put down in black and white.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 11 -- A $32,000,000 expansion program to include fifteen new wharves was among proposals made this week for the port of Houston.
A Navy plan to weed out inactive reserve officers, under way for about a year, has already had its effect on the rosters of the Third Naval District.

THE airline crashes that occurred during the past five weeks have raised questions as to whether they followed a particular pattern, whether there was any common factor that could be considered a contributing cause. It appears quite certain that the disasters were coincidental.

Hollywood, much concerned about its reputation, frowns on drinking among its workers and has gone so far as to put a ban on it in contracts. This move was the opening wedge for vodka, which sums up its advertising in the slogan, "It takes your breath away."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Rain, dew and even hurricanes -- anything that brings moisture -- makes weeds grow. Pull weeds out of rose beds that have been mulched and cultivate unmulched rose beds, cutting and vegetable plots. The hedge and shrub plantings also may need to be weeded, perhaps by hand.

DAVID DAICHES' excellent piece on the appeal of current American fiction in England missed a point that would have strengthened his argument. In citing a very few current English novels which stand up alongside American novels he includes one on the English side -- "altogether richer and more powerful" than the others -- "Bhowani Junction" by John Masters.

FAME has come to the tiny hilltop village of Castel San Pietro Romano. In the year since "quelli di Roma" ("those of Rome," as the townspeople call them) left San Pietro, many things have changed in the charming little hamlet, which lies about forty kilometers outside Rome, and its rustic face has been noticeably lifted.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gene Walet 3d of New Orleans today won the Mallory Cup, symbolic of the North American sailing championship, for the second straight year.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The final stages in Iraq's general election take place tomorrow with Premier Nuri al-Said already assured of a majority in the new Iraqi Parliament.

I OWE the parish an apology. On the night of June 4, 1950, I announced to all who cared to listen that I would never act in the theatre again. THIS is the first of Erskine Caldwell's novels to deal with relatively sophisticated and educated characters since he published "A House in the Uplands" in 1946. The settings include dimly lit bars in Sarasota and the French Quarter of New Orleans, a Galveston beach cottage, a house in Santa Barbara.
Mercury's dazzling price rise -- from $183 a flask to a record $305 in less than a year -- has astonished veteran traders long accustomed to the market's violent changes.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Unless industry analysts are wrong, the new-car retailer will do somewhat better profitwise next year.
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has announced that his election frauds bureau is preparing to play its usual watchdog role in the fall campaign, starting on Primary Day next Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Ntapie, tribal chief of Balafi in the Cameroons under French administration, has appealed to the Trusteeship Council of the United Nations for restoration or recompense for losses suffered during twenty years of imprisonment.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 11 -- A little thing like a hurricane threat didn't bother those who take their pleasure in dog competition today and the twentieth annual show of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club went on as scheduled.

PARENTS who deplore their children's lack of interest in poetry might do well to introduce this volume into the household -- in a casual manner, of course. Isabel J. Peterson, a teacher in the Laboratory School of the University of Chicago, has selected eighty-one of the most popular poems which she has read with children, thus giving us a cross-section of the children's own tastes.

MULLET KEY, Fla. -- This is a small island of 800 acres and over five miles of beaches, lying in the mouth of Tampa Bay about ten miles from St. Petersburg. It is a county park and within a few years is to be developed with all of the conventional man-made tourist attractions as the west coast's outstanding public recreation center.

The Giants increased their National League lead to four and a half games yesterday by defeating the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7 to 5. The Dodgers downed the Braves, 5 -- 3, and regained second place as Milwaukee dropped to third. In the American League, the Yankees lost to the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 5, in ten innings and fell six and a half games behind first-place Cleveland.

In the contest between Senator Irving M. Ives and Averell Harriman for the Governorship of New York, which now appears to be shaping up, the eyes of both Republicans and Democrats are being focussed on the middle-income vote.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 -- Kentucky-bred Never Say Die scored one of the most smashing victories in the ancient history of the St. Leger race today and his 78-year-old owner, Robert Sterling Clark, broke into tears.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 -- Amid the crop reports and production figures, consumer complaints and literary debates that crowd the pages of the leading Soviet newspapers, there recently have appeared several triumphal articles on the international theme.

Soviet city dwellers have on the average now only about two-thirds as much housing space each as they had thirty years ago before the country's industrialization, a former Soviet economist has concluded in a study published here.

AN old hand at science fiction, Mr. Russell demonstrates in this collection of eight short stories and one novella the talents which have made him so popular. The novella. "First Person Singular," invests the old story of Adam and Eve with new interest and excitement.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- The newest Hotel Statler, $7,000,000 addition to the Statler chain of hotels (now owned by the Hilton Hotels Corporation) took in its first guest last week. The 445-room (all outside), eighteen - story aluminum -and-glass skyscraper adds a Lever House touch to the sedate skyline of this capital city -- capital of Connecticut and of the American insurance business.

ENOS SLAUGHTER was sunning himself in front of the Cardinal clubhouse in St. Petersburg, Fla., one day last March. The Old Warhorse was jabbering away contentedly, sure of himself and his job. He spat reflectively and grinned.

PALMA DE MAJORCA, Spain -- A few years ago this Mediterranean island was almost unknown and totally unexploited. The tourists who stumbled upon it found remote and medieval charm -- cobblestoned streets, dim cathedrals, a fourteenth century castle overlooking the bay of Palma.

The Museum of Modern Art will put on public view today its most recent acquisition, "The Dream" by Henri Rousseau. For this, it is rumored, more money was paid than for any other painting in the museum's collection.

CAIRO, Sept. 11 -- Leaders of the major Middle Eastern states clearly have contracted marriage, strategically speaking, with the Western camp. However, up to this week none of them had had the courage to acknowledge the betrothal openly and bring the eager fiance home to meet the family -- public opinion in their countries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Resuming a practice that has lapsed since 1950, pupils of the Southampton Elementary School in grades one through seven will tour the woods, fields and beaches of this community in preparation for the annual Wild Flower Show at the Southampton Elementary School on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The use of "radar" to combat highway speeding is being subjected to new study.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The big business news in this area continues to be hurricane Carol and its aftermath. Power and telephone service have been generally restored. The repair bill of the New England Telephone Company was close to $5,000,000 and the aggregate costs of the various electric light companies servicing New England must have been substantially more.

WITH the same sure touch that characterized his novel, "The White Tower." Mr. Ullman has come up with a superb mountain-climbing story for younger readers. The author and his son recently climbed the Matterhorn, so it is not surprising that his fictional narrative closely follows the true story of man's first conquest of this icy citadel in 1865.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 11 -- In an appeal for unity before an apathetic audience of 5,000 persons, Prime Minister Mohammed Ali warned today that Pakistan's "weakness and defenselessness" might serve as an invitation to aggresion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Inaerior, Douglas McKay, said yesterday that a new safety device to be used in the Gateway Canal of the Weber reclamation project in Utah is expected to make it "one of the nation's safest large canals."

THE producers of "Omnibus," the experimental television program of the Ford Foundation TV-Radio Workshop, apparently have spent the summer carefully analyzing the brickbats and praise showered upon their efforts last season.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- An increase of 1,146 in new unemployment claims, representing the largest weekly gain since last May, offset boosts in building construction, steel production and automobile sales here last week. New unemployment claims climbed from 2,422 to 3,568 and continued claims from 18,709 to 19,319.

OLD IRONSIDES, as the 1st Armored Division was called, set an important record of combat in North Africa and Italy during World War II. George F. Howe, the division's historian, presents that record in this heavy, admirably illustrated volume.

UNDER a bill enacted by the Eighty-third Congress and signed by President Eisenhower, postage-due stamps in unused condition are to be made legally available for the first time to philatelists. The measure had the advance approval of Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield and of Robert E. Fellers, director of the Post Office Department's Division of Philately.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 11 -- High United States defense officials are nearing a decision on the investment of about $10,000,000 for a lightweight jet fighter for use throughout the North Atlantic Treaty air forces.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Soviet offers to send out technical experts to help poorer countries assisted by the United Nations appear so far to have met with less than enthusiastic response.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- A close examination of the United States system of social security was recommended to the British Government today in the latest publication of Political and Economic Planning, an independent research institution.

A split personality appears in a duplex apartment in New York City occupied by three bachelors. The apartment has two living rooms of equal size, furnished in completely different styles. A panoramic camera was used to take revolving pictures and achieve the over-all effect shown on these pages.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 11 -- The Wisconsin primary election on Tuesday will settle the question of whether the Wisconsin Republican Voluntary Committee, one of the strongest political machines in the country, is strong enough to purge two of Wisconsin's most popular Republican State officials.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- All new studies reinforce existing evidence that the fluoridation of public water supplies is a safe and effective measure for lessening tooth decay, the Journal of the American Dental Association reported in its current issue.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 11 -- The sudden death of South Carolina's senior United States Senator ten days ago has touched off an unprecedented succession fight. Senator Burnet R. Maybank was renominated without opposition in a Democratic primary last June for another full term starting Jam 2.

Many Virginians, who are neither gentlemen nor members of the First Families, are nervous these days. They are bootleggers. The Government has just nearly doubled the number of agents in the state representing the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division -- locally known and feared as "Rev-nooers."
In the article "Inside East Germany: A Refugee's Report" (Aug. 22) the statement is made that "about half the workers in East Germany earn between 200 and 240 Marks a month ($50 to $60)."
Riding high on the wings of a grand-slam home run by Whitey Lockman, the Giants brought down the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7 to 5, at the Polo Grounds last night and this really could prove the big one.
Storm effects of the hurricane yesterday caused cancellation of the fourth regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual race week scheduled to have been held off Port Washington, L.I.

High colors make current fashion news. Brilliant tones appear in woolen coats, suits and costume ensembles. These same tones are often carried through in hats. The effect is of one overall color. Blouses, too, may be dyed perfectly to the shade of a suit, carrying out the single color theme. Another instance of the use of striking color is a bright coat and hat with a dark dress.

ONE can say at once that Vincent Cronin, son of the novelist, A. J. Cronin, has here fulfilled the purpose of writing a modest, useful and scholarly guide to the principal monuments of Sicily and to the history of that lovely, multi-civilized island.
The U. S. S. Ticonderoga, a World War II aircraft carrier modernized to accommodate heavier and faster jet airplanes, was recommissioned yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

THE period of reappraisal of Western policy inaugurated by the repudiation of the European Defense Community in the French Assembly presents one of those rare moments in which private persons can enter into the discussion of delicate matters of high policy without fear of bringing into question existing decisions or of embarrassing their own Government in its undertakings.

Prime Minister Nehru recently stirred discussion in New Delhi by some suggestions on the proper attire for India's men and women Government workers. He observed that modern life calls for certain changes in Indian dress. Yet he made it clear he wants no slavish imitation of the West.
POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., Sept. 11 -- The bones of Chief Cornstalk, murdered Shawnee peacemaker, after almost 200 years still do not rest in peace.
Is dishwashing the distasteful chore it is made out to be by cartoonists and comedians?

OFF-POST saluting, which became required Army etiquette on Sept. 1 as the result of a letter (through channels) from Chief of Staff Gen. Matthew D. Ridgway, did not cause Times Square to erupt in a flash of right arms.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 -- A more aggressive attitude in their competitive selling methods by large department stores here was believed responsible for a 10 per cent increase in sales volume for the week ended Sept. 4, over a year ago, bringing the gain for the four weeks to 4 per cent.

SIX workshops in photography by Berenice Abbott, Alexey Brodovitch and Joseph Breitenbach will be given this fall at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. The term starts Sept. 30. Miss Abbott will teach basic and advanced courses and a "Studio Workshop: The Large Camera and its Swings."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 11, (UP) -- Eugene M. Zuckert, a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, today predicted that atomic energy eventually would be converted directly into electric power. But he warned against expecting atomic "miracles overnight".

ABOARD U. S. S. CORAL SEA, in the Mediterranean, Sept. 10 -- The 5,000-mile supply arm that enables the United States Sixth Fleet to operate without a Mediterranean base is being reconditioned for faster action.

CHICAGO -- New American electronic flash units designed for greater portability, efficiency and versatility shared the limelight with the first major foreign importation in this field at the Sixty-third Annual National Convention and Photographic Trade Show held here recently by the Photographers' Association of America.

SKILLFULLY adapting the comic strip technique, without benefit of speech balloons, Dorothy Dodworth has produced a very funny picture book. The plot is based on the age-old, yet ever-new, conflict between a small-boy tease and a little girl intent on minding her own feminine business.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- Thousands of Californians will go to San Pablo Bay, a northern arm of San Francisco Bay, for the centennial of the Mare Island Naval Shipyard, next Thursday to Sunday.

EVEN the city dweller who is too busy to look up can hardly fail to notice the arrival of a new fall season. Nights are cooler. The leaves on the occasional tree in the street are beginning to turn. And once more birds by the hundreds of thousands are winging south.

VAUGHAN Williams called his ballet score, Job, "a masque for dancing." It has been recorded by Sir Adrian Boult and the London Philharmonic (London). The masque, for those unfamiliar with the term, was a type of entertainment that came to England from Italy, flourished greatly through the reign of Elizabeth I and James I, then shortly after disappeared for good.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11 -- In Kentucky these days Topic A is the November election and, particularly, the contest between John Sherman Cooper and Alvin W. Barkley for the seat in the Senate now held by Mr. Cooper.
President Eisenhower yesterday hailed the 300th anniversary of Congregation Shearith Israel of this city and underscored the importance of renewing faith in religious principles.
The Democratic party's high command in the state shifted position yesterday on the candidacy of Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Governor.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- r.eindustry Fund of Long Island, a labor-management coalition formed four years ago to aid voluntar hospitals, will reach its $1,000,000 mark tomorrow ght. ;' . ). '

The Labor Day holiday took its toll on stock brokerage business in Wall Street last week, but investors continued to push prices higher. By the week-end the market's recovery, as measured by The New York Times composite index of fifty representative issues, had brought the price level back to where it was on Aug. 24.

New York City's department stores faced the task last week of matching sales figures with the same week of a year ago -- a very good week. In 1953 this was the week which followed a prolonged heat wave, making it a period when much delayed buying took place. In addition, business was hurt last week by stormy weather at its end.

WALTZING MATILDA, a 46-foot sailing cutter, was named for a song which depicted the free life of a swagman, or tramp, in the Australian outback. The cutter lived up to her name. She waltzed across two oceans, some 15,000 miles, and proved not only that shipwrights down under build truly and well but also that a sturdy boat with a cheerful and willing crew can always be expected to do her best.

RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Al Carmichael's 96-yard touchdown run was the highlight tonight as the Green Bay Packers routed the Washington Redskins, 31 -- 3, in an exhibition game between the two National Football League teams before a crowd of 16,000.
John J. Nagle has been elected vice president and a director of George D. Edwards, Inc., insurance brokers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Americans increased their savings bank accounts 7 per cent in the year ended June 30 while their checking accounts remained about steady.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said tonight the United States was "much less vulnerable" to enemy air attack than it was a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The hour neared tonight for the special Senate committee hearing charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to decide whether it should recommend directly for or against censuring him.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 12 -- More than 300 members of the Swiss Bankers Association met over the week-end at their forty-first annual rally, held at Gstaad, resort village high in the Bernese Alps.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia said today he doubted that President Eisenhower could carry a single Southern State if a national election were held this year.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The Japanese Government offered today to conclude a peace treaty with the Soviet Union along lines of the San Francisco treaty with the Western democracies.

HALIFAX, N. S., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Hurricane Edna sliced across the Maritimes Saturday night and destroyed more than two-thirds of Nova Scotia's bumper $4,000,000 apple crop in a costly last fling before dying in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 12 -- South Vietnam's Premier and the Army Chief of Staff barricaded themselves in their separate headquarters tonight and showed signs of resolving their dispute over leadership by means of arms.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12 -- Maine counted eight dead and millions of dollars in damage today as a dazed citizenry struggled to clear the debris of a second hurricane in eleven days.
Record sales earnings were achieved by the Winn Lovett Grocery Company, Jacksonville, Fla., in the fiscal year ended last June 26, it was disclosed in a report issued for publication today.

The Martinique Hotel, a 600-room landmark in Greeley Square, has been sold by Hotel Martinique, Inc., representing Frank W. Kridel and associates, to Robert Selby and Eugene Moses. It is assessed at $1,800,000, including land value.

I would like to commend The New York Times for the fine job it is doing in presenting to the American people as true a picture as possible of the Soviets and their country. I refer to Clement Attlee's article of Sept. 7 on his visit to Russia. It pointed out some good as well as some bad points, and I think your editorial did a good job in appraising it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- George Blanda failed to complete a pass in the first half but came back to toss three touchdowns in the last two periods to lead the Chicago Bears to a 28-24 exhibition victory over the New York Giants today.
A Columbia University chemist reported yesterday a new filtration process that promises a "potentially significant" increase in the production of uranium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Clyde L. Powell, ousted Assistant Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, was depicted in an official report today as "the czar of the nation's post-war rental housing program" who accepted more than $100,000 from apartment builders dealing with the F. H. A.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- For the first time since 1920, the Chicago White Sox reached, then passed, the 90-victory mark by sweeping a double-header from the Boston Red Sox, 5 to 3 and 7 to 5, before 13,637 today. The defeats dropped Boston to fifth place behind Detroit.

Under the guise of mounting fares he is the victim of burdensome, discriminatory taxation. It is levied on him alone by official decree in order that a hydra-headed transit system, incapable of profitable operation, may be continued.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 8 -- After our visit to the industrial northeast of China we returned to Peking [Peiping] to stay for a few days. Despite the noise of motor horns, I found it pleasant to be back in the city.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Pete Bostwick rode roughshod over the Brandywine Polo Club today, his five goals pacing the C. C. C.-Meadow Brook team to a 10-5 victory in the national open championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- When the special Senate committee considering censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, winds up its sessions, probably tomorrow, Capitol Hill will have lost its one remaining public attraction.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 12 -- The Chinese Nationalist Navy bombarded Hutowshan (Tiger Head Mountain), fifty miles southwest of Quemoy Island, last night as its patrol vessels continued to hunt for Communist invasion junks along the Fukien coast.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Western diplomats here are beginning to think that the protracted secret negotiations over Trieste are moving toward an early climax.

THOUSANDS of children, dragging tanned legs back to school today, would find Dr. Louis Perlman more incomprehensible than most adults. For Dr. Perlman has been going to school nearly sixty years and recently he acquired his medical degree, magna cum laude, after five grueling years at Heidelberg, which he calls "the happiest years of my life."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told an international conference of heart specialists today that their life-saving efforts could give statesmen "an example we can follow so we can work better to remove another cause from which men prematurely die -- war."

Twelve of the twenty-six competing nations in the team tournament for the Hamilton-Russell Trophy were admitted into the finals yesterday at the conclusion of the preliminaries, according to a report from Amsterdam.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- A new effort to bring comfort and legal protection to the world's stateless persons -- refugees and others who can claim no citizenship -- will be made at a two-week international conference opening tomorrow.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Today's American family -- the best educated, healthiest, best equipped, most mobile and most adaptable in history -- is also the most nervous, the most insecure and the least prepared for wholesome family living, a sociologist told educators yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The State Department is studying means to check on every foreign seaman coming to this country and still not delay friendly foreign vessels with red tape routines.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph S. Minnis, vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession (Trinity Parish), Broadway and 155th Street, preached his farewell sermon yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The integration of white and Negro pupils in the public schools of the District of Columbia will begin tomorrow with the official opening of the school term.

A record of more than 35,000,000 pupils, an increase of 1,600,000 over last year, will crowd the schoolhouses of the land this fall. The end of the long summer vacation today will find enrollments increased in the public private and parochial schools.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- "Miss America 1955," 19-year-old Lee Ann Meriwether of San Francisco, left today for New York and the Waldorf Astoria Hotel preparatory to a tour of South America.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Fifteen thousand veterans of Germany's World War II Afrika Korps held a reunion today. They were told a new German Army must be based on the old military principle: "bravery till death."
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 12 -- Dutch industrial and trade circles are expressing growing concern regarding American tariff policy and are making representations to the Dutch Government.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The detention of the three Americans had been protested by Britain, which has a charge d'affaires in Peiping.
Six hundred Jewish leaders met at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday to open a campaign to raise $51,000,000 in the next four months for industrial and agricultural development of Israel.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The European Assembly opens here Monday and the big question for the delegates is what to do about rearming West Germany now that France has turned down the European Army project.
The Rev. Dr. Irvonwy Morgan, general secretary of the London Mission of the Methodist Church of England, said yesterday that Christians "must advertise Him who led you out of darkness."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- The Milwaukee Braves kept their pennant hopes alive by rallying from a 5-2 first-game defeat to edge the Phillies, 2-1, in the second game of a double-header today.
Atomic energy may soon revolutionize building materials and architecture, according to an article in the September issue of Architectural Forum.

When the Wright brothers were working on the problem of controlled flight in heavier-than-air machines they gave some thought to the airplane's use in war but probably no thought at all to its use in diplomacy. Actually air travel has revolutionized diplomacy just as it has revolutionized war.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 -- Negotiations in London on the Trieste dispute between Yugoslavia and Italy were reported here to have reached an exasperating stage of haggling over tiny bits of land.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Republican National Committee today announced plans for a gigantic election "dress rehearsal" on G. O. P. National Precinct Day Oct. 8.

FIRE ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Community leaders on this narrow thirty-two-mile stretch of dunes and scrub lying off Long Island's South Shore held a meeting today to discuss ways of saving their summer retreat.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- It has been a year now since Soviet authorities launched their intensive drive for increased agricultural production and all over the Soviet Union the results of the first year's efforts are being calculated, commented upon and frequently criticized.

MONTREAL, Sept. 12. -- The average employed New Yorker spends 480 hours a year in crowded subways and buses traveling to and from his job, Henry Cohen, research director of the New York City Planning Department, estimated today.

Thirty new buses, each with a capacity of fifty passengers, are to start rolling today along the ten Manhattan routes of the Surface Transportation Corporation. Within thirty days twenty-five more such buses will be placed in service, the company said. The fifty-five vehicles, costing $1,250,000, will increase the company's operating units by 11 per cent in Manhattan and 6 per cent in the Bronx.

CAIRO, Aug. 27 -- Visitors to Egypt this fall may be able to see behind a pane of glass the 5,000-year-old-buried ship the Pharaoh Cheops built to carry his spirit through the heavens with the sungod.

A series of Monday night radio dramas, said to be based on hitherto unrevealed facts concerning government intrigue at high levels, will be put on by WOR-Mutual with all-star Broadway casts beginning Oct. 4 from 8 to 8:30 P. M. Phillips Lord, a WOR consultant, has gathered the material for the dramas from available sources throughout the world.
Mr. Redmond is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh F. Redmond of 8 Floral Lane, Yonkers. He was arrested in Shanghai in April, 1951, almost two years after the Communists had taken control of the city.

MEAUX, France, Sept. 12 -- Allied unity was counseled for the security of the West at ceremonies here today commemorating the fortieth anniversary of France's victory in the First Battle of the Marne.

An American Soccer League All-Star squad upset its counterpart from the Ontario Football Association 3 -- 2, at Zerega Oval, Bronx, yesterday. Richard Roberts, U. S. center forward, kicked the winning goal after thirty-two minutes of play in the second half.

Leo Durocher strove to mastermind his Giants to an important victory over the Cardinals yesterday. But it didn't work and in the end, after three hours and nine minutes of give and take, Eddie Stanky's Redbirds finished on top, 4 to 3, to the keen disappointment of 19,491 fans at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Democrats are finding that foreign policy is their most difficult issue in the current political campaign.

DENVER, Sept. 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today he did not foresee any early attempt by the Chinese Communists to invade either Quemoy or Formosa.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer conferred today on the problem of finding a basis for the rearming of West Germany that would be acceptable to all the powers concerned, particularly France.

Royalty, statemen and other international personages will take part in the third major phase of Columbia University's 200th anniversary observance this fall, it was announced yesterday by Richard R. Powell, director of the bicentennial.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs, with Ted Kluszewski driving in nine runs, routed the Pittsburgh Pirates today in both ends of a doubleheader, 11 -- 5 and 13 -- 2.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- One hundred thousand persons, industrial employes and their families, attended the fifth annual hopsital "star night" performances arranged by the Long Island Industry Fund at Roosevelt Raceway and Belmont Park this afternoon and tonight.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 12 -- A minister in the Malan Government returned from Kenya to report he found among Kenya whites almost unanimous support for the racial policy of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan.

The election to the board of directors of the Esso Shipping Company of C. J. Hedlund was announced yesterday by M. G. Gamble, president. Mr. Hedlund is manager of the coordination and petroleum economics department of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

The first was a 4-1 paralyzer, the second a 3-2 haymaker that left Casey Stengel's men reeling, virtually helpless and hopeless for the first time in six years.
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said yesterday that he expected no trouble at the polls during the primary election tomorrow.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12 -- Voters of the State of Maine will lead the nation to the polls tomorrow. In many cases they will go to the polls through rubble left by Hurricane Edna. It will be the first general election of the 1954 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Vice Admiral Robert P. Briscoe, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations, warned today that the United States fleet would be outdated by Russian naval power starting within four years unless this nation engaged in all-out ship construction.

As a first step in averting threatened friction between Negroes and Puerto Ricans in New York, a delegation of twenty Negro and white community leaders, including several of Puerto Rican descent, will make a study trip to the island next Saturday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Sept. 12 -- "Saturday Night Is My Delight," a novel by Torrey Hood about a fun-loving and somewhat boisterous Irish-American family living in Connecticut at the turn of the century, will be made into a movie by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

TOWARD the end of the tenth century, when Harald Bluetooth was King of the Danes and the mighty Styrbjorn sailed the Baltic, there was a thane in Skania named Toste who had five sons. One was killed by a bull and one was lost at sea. And one went a-viking into Ireland and was heard of no more and one served in the emperor's guard at Miklagard and came to an evil end.

The week-end's report from Iran about the discovery of a massive Soviet spy ring in that country and the arrest of hundreds of suspects, including many army and police officials, has all the elements we expect to find in a novel rather than in real life.
An emphasis on conservative, traditional floral designs is only one of this fall's decorating trends highlighted in a large group of home furnishings fabrics introduced here this week.
The ship charter market rose again last week, causing even normally pessimistic brokers to forecast smooth sailing for the next month if nothing happens in the meantime.

DETROIT, Sept 12 (AP) -- Ted Gray today won his first game since May 12, pitching the Detroit Tigers to an 8-3 victory over the Washington Senators and a sweep of their doubleheader. Steve Gromek pitched a six-hitter to win the opener, 5 -- 0, for his seventeen victory.
IN the beginning is the group show, or at least that is the way the metropolitan art season, slumbering since June, gets under way during these first September weeks.

HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 12. (AP) -- Vietminh police, technicians and administrators will move into Hanoi five days before the French leave in an attempt to Continued on 5Column 3 keep the city functioning and to smooth as much as possible its transfer from French to Vietminh domination.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Bullish influences, which have been pretty powerful in advancing prices for wheat recently, appeared to have been discounted for the time being in this grain and there has been much profit-taking on the upturns.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Howard Seymour's International, Mutiny; Alvin Cadiz' Atlantic, Zephyr; Warner Willcox' Class S boat, Twister, and the Bill Corwin-J. K. Stark-weather 210, Harpoon, were among the title winners as the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-second annual race week ended today.

Mayor Wagner emphatically reaffirmed yesterday his approval of action taken last week by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams in demoting Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg to the rank of captain.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Francis C. Erasmus, South African Defense Minister, said today that he was satisfied with talks with British officials regarding the defense of Africa and the Middle East against possible Communist aggression.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- A shakeout followed by a rally, which, on the whole, left the stock markets showing little change in security prices last week, was generally attributed to some uneasiness concerning the warlike trend of events around Formosa.

Tropical Hurricane Edna spun away into the frigid northern seas yesterday, but in her torrential wake were nineteen dead and damage in the millions of dollars. Much of the loss came from a final terrifying fling Saturday night and early yesterday through Maine and Canada's Maritime Provinces.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams reported yesterday that no murders had taken place in the Twenty-fifth Precinct since Sept. 1, when 250 rookie policemen were assigned to the East Harlem station house.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- A 5-year-old Scottish terrier from Kentucky, Ch. Edgerstoune Troubadour, completed a perfect dog show week-end for himself on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club today.

A sharp reduction in fire insurance rates on private dwellings and apartment houses will go into effect today throughout New York State. The new rates will be 5.5 to 25 per cent lower than before. They will cut the cost of fire insurance $2,000,000 in this city and $4,000,000 in the rest of the state, Alfred J. Bohlinger, Superintendent of Insurance, said.

Issuance of the second official cotton crop forecast sent prices on the New York market into new high ground last week, but by the close of trading on Friday the gains had been slashed to 4 to 35 points.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 12 -- Flags from several nations fluttered over the Allegheny Country Club grounds today where the United States women's amateur golf championship starts tomorrow.
DENVER, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Dulles' news conference at the summer White House today:
TOKYO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Cambridge University, handicapped by the loss of its top oarsman, today failed to qualify for the final of the All-Japan championship regatta at nearby Todabashi.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Up from the bright, sunlit waters of Lake Champlain rose today the gray, water-soaked, mud-stained skeleton of the Trumbull, a survivor of one of the nation's first naval engagements.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12. -- With Labor Day and vacation periods behind them, steelmakers will scan order books closely this week and next. They hope to see an improvement that transcends mere seasonal increases.
The Cunard liner Media docked here yesterday a day late after la short but violent brush with Hurricane Edna forty miles east of Nantucket Lightship.

Speaking before the American Psychological Association, Prof. H. C. Lehman of Ohio University recently pointed out that if present employment trends continue "any further increase in man's longevity will add primarily not to his work-life expectancy but to his years in retirement."
Christ's Sermon on the Mount is the "constitution of the Kingdom of Heaven," the Rev. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday at a solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 -- Minnesota will hold its primary elections Tuesday, but for most major party candidates these appeared to be only a gesture. The campaigns for state-wide offices already are being keyed to the general elections in November.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Germany's mighty Luftwaffe, supreme in 1939 and 1940, was overcome later in World War II because it was mishandled by the German High Command and outfought.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles and the Philadelphia Athletics divided a double-header today to remain deadlocked for seventh place in the American League. After staging a four-run seventh-inning rally to win the opener, 4 -- 3, the Orioles dropped the second game, 5 -- 4.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union party was decisively defeated today by the Social Democrats in the first important election contest since the rejection of the European Defense Community treaty by the French National Assembly two weeks ago.
ROME, Sept. 12 -- Italian-Yugoslav negotiations over Trieste have run into eleventh-hour difficulties that have imperiled their successful conclusion.

THE first of N.B.C.-TV'S color "spectaculars" has come and gone, and everybody can sit back, relax and view life a little more calmly. Betty Hutton made her TV debut last night in "Satins and Spurs," an original musical comedy that was the first of a color series to be presented every fourth Sunday from 7:30 to 9 P. M.

JUST because Rocky Marciano and Ezzard Charles staged a thriller in their first meeting last June, that's no guarantee the return match at the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday will make hearts, flutter and pulses race. The blunt truth of the matter is that the history of the heavyweight championship indicates that every return match is at best only a pale carbon copy of the original.
Four new films will arrive at local theatres this week. The programs follow.

Because of the delaying tactics of Hurricane Carol, the Rev. John O. Mellin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, preached his Labor Day sermon yesterday -- a week late.

Because of the delaying tactics of Hurricane Carol, the Rev. John O. Mellin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, preached his Labor Day sermon yesterday -- a week late.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- America's home owners spent an estimated $3,000,000,000 in the first five months of this year fixing up and enlarging their homes, the Census Bureau said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The special committee considering the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today completed its public hearings in their ninth day.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The Labor party's popularity in Britain is rising sharply because, some practical politicians assert, Clement R. Attlee, its leader, has done what Sir Winston Churchill has so often talked about: he has met the leaders of the communist world face to face.

New York City has borrowed $35,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on Nov. 5, at an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent a year, City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes, which are secured by taxes due on Oct. 1, 1954 and April 1, 1955, are subject to prior redemption on and after Oct. 26.
The New York Rangers, with seventeen Sunday dates and on Saturday, will play thirty-five games at Madison Square Garden during the 1954-55 National Hockey League campaign, it was reported yesterday.

Jance Rule, last seen on Broadway in "Picnic," will star as a small-town girl in a large city in "Diary," which will open the "Robert Montgomery Presents" winter series Monday at 9:30 P. M. over N. B. C.-TV.

Democratic leaderships at stake in today's primary election could influence the prospective contest between Averell Harriman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for the nomination for Governor.

Coppers, oils, chemicals and steels led an upward march of stock market prices yesterday as volume expanded to 2,030,000 shares after spending seven trading days below the 2,000,000 mark. The figure for Friday was 1,870,000 shares.

Ground will be broken in Harlem Monday for a twelve-story house with 211 apartments to cost in excess of $3,000,000 and to be built by the Bowery Savings Bank. Earl B. Schwulst, president of the bank, said the project was the first nonsubsidized apartment housing in Harlem since 1938.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- A warning that socialized medicine might become a real danger in this country was sounded here today by Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pravda accused The New York Times tonight of insulting the French National Assembly by saying it did not repersent the French people.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Dullness pervaded the stock market today, with British Government securities virtually the only major group going against the trend.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 13 (AP) -- A return to separate schools for white and Negro students in Greenbrier County was ordered tonight after some 300 students quit classes and marched through the streets with placards reading "no Negroes wanted in our schools."
TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- Chinese Communist forces could take Quemoy Island -- at a price -- but almost certainly would fail in an attempt to invade Formosa, high United States military forces here say.
OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's gross national product declined 2 per cent in the second quarter of 1954, compared with the April-June figure in 1953.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Egypt was censored for two armistice violations today and Israel was condemned once, the Jerusalem headquarters of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- American air and naval support of the Chinese Nationalist outpost at Quemoy Island in event of a Communist invasion effort was proposed today by Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey.
The nation's steelmakers scheduled operations this week at the highest rate since late June, reflecting a pick-up in demand for steel.
MADRID, Sept. 13 -- A Protestant church in Madrid has been closed by the Spanish authorities on charges that it had become a center of what was termed illegal proselytizing.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pitcher Dick Littlefield broke up a tie game with a one-run single in the eighth inning tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs. Only 1,148 fans -- the smallest night crowd in the history of Forbes Field -- saw the game.

The Lance Petrol Corporation has leased the one-story public garage and gasoline service station at 2306 Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn from the Surf Moden Garage, Inc. The lease is for fifteen years at an aggregate net rental of $124,250. Arthur S. Thomases was the broker and Samuel Breslin was attorney for the lessee.

The American Statistical Association held its annual meeting over the week-end at Montreal, where its members compared notes on the state, present and future, of the nation's economic health. The general verdict, as reported by Will Lissner to this newspaper, was that the medicine prescribed by the Eisenhower Administration was definitely benefiting the patient.
The United Nations Security Council has before it the official complaint of the United States Government listing the attacks of Soviet aircraft against American planes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Milwaukee's Braves kept alive in the torrid three-team scramble for the National League pennant by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 7 -- 4, before 11,189 spectators at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
Some information of general interest to those in the "huckstering" business was sent out yesterday following two separate surveys.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose, New Jersey representative on the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission, plans to retire from that post on Jan. 1. The 61-year-old veteran of both World Wars also will relinquish on Sept. 30 his position as chief of staff of the New Jersey Department of Defense.

" Tension," "stress" and "pressure" are words heard often these days as the tempo of life moves along at a pace that worries both students of contemporary behavior and those of us who muddle through each twenty-four hours without consciously appraising their tension-making character.

THE Broadway theatre season got under way with a whoop and a holler last night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The whoopin' and hollerin,' however, were not for a masterwork of the drama by a newly discovered genius but rather for the pickin' and singin' of a hillbilly musical revue called "Hayride."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Political oratory in the General Assembly hall soon will give way at intervals to symphony concerts, ballet and other performances more alluring to the general public.

Thirteen bands, sixteen floats, a dozen antique cars and an 1840 railroad train made Coney Island's midway gaudier and brassier last night. It was the opening Mardi Gras parade -- a mile long along Surf Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Witnesses before a State Department panel agreed today that the thirty-three-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade should be submitted to Congress to give it full legality.

Starting play in the finals of the international team chess tournament for the Hamilton-Russell trophy, the Russian grandmasters, who topped Group 1 of the preliminaries, defeated Sweden by 3 1/2 -- 1/2 yesterday, according to a report from Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Adlai E. Stevenson will be the "titular leader" of the Democratic party until or unless some other Democrat is nominated for the Presidency. Therefore his presentation of the Congressional campaign issues this year must be taken as the official party line.
Sharp declines in cocoa and coffee marked the trading on the commodity exchanges here yesterday. Other commodities were steady to slightly lower in comparatively light dealings.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 13 -- Finance Minister Harry Jayawardana left for Washington today to attend a meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction. He will also investigate the possibility of obtaining loans from the bank for Ceylon's productive development at reduced rates of interest.
The Puerto Rican Nationalist party in the United States planned last October to try assassinate President Eisenhower, a witness testified here yesterday.

The novelist F. Scott Fitzgerald once said that he, Fitzgerald, spoke with the authority of failure while his friend Hemingway spoke with the authority of success.
