One can effectively apply this summing-up to the fight camps of the heavyweight challenger, Ezzard Charles, and the heavyweight champion, Rocky Marciano.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 -- The full force of the Georgia Democratic party machinery will be employed in a campaign for approval of a constitutional amendment designed to maintain segregation in the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court has before it the question of whether $9,699 in income tax claims against former Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York and his former wife are justified.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Typhoon June began to blow itself out over the Sea of Japan today, leaving at least twenty-five dead, sixty-six injured and sixteen missing in the wake of its devastating sweep across Kyushu Island.

Raindrops and snowflakes are always radioactive when they fall and the amount of the radioactive hydrogen bomb material tritium that they contain gives a measure of the age of the newly fallen water. This was reported here yesterday at the opening of the 126th national meeting of the American Chemical Society in the Statler Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- A $15,000,000 project for reduction of pollution in the Hudson River was approved today by the Westchester Board of Supervisors. The plan is to be submitted to the county voters in the Nov. 2 election for final action.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 13 -- In another measure designed to keep a watchful eye on foreigners living here, the Government announced today the creation of a bureau for surveillance of foreigners. Establishment of the bureau implements last month's ordinance on foreign surveillance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A world survey of recently discovered facts on coronary thrombosis today showed heart disease to be most common where there was most fat in the diet.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of The New York Times, received the Kalinga Prize of 1954 today in recognition of the merit of his fifty years of science writing.

Night sessions were started yesterday in Small Claims Court to enable New York's wage-earners, housewives and shopkeepers to litigate their disputes without loss of time and money from their workaday jobs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today the Armed Services now were handing out postcards to their men in the United States so they might request absentee ballots for the coming general elections.
CAIRO, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian Government has decided to take over the writing of all sermons to be delivered in mosques throughout the country.
For those who have lived through the hubbub of the couture collections in Rome, Florence and Paris, it is a different form of excitement to see the models that have been selected for American wear.
The return of United Artists Corporation to the Motion Picture Association of America after an absence of nine years was announced yesterday.

Wasserstein Brothers, manufacturers of textiles, ribbons and velvets, have purchased the six-story loft building at 34 West Thirty-eighth Street from Mrs. Ray W. Constable. The buyers will occupy the entire structure for their millinery and dress division.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 13 -- Changes have occurred in the South American picture that could leave it clearer and brighter in the near future than it has been for many months.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Lee E. Daniels today was dismissed from a state job for interceding in behalf of a firm making a slot machine device.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Negotiation of an agreement that will restore internal sovereignty to Tunisia after eighty-three years of French administration started today.
Plans for a $1,000,000 testimonial to Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, were announced yesterday.
A plan to increase recreational facilities at twenty-five public housing developments as part of the city's campaign to prevent juvenile delinquency is under study.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 13 (UP) -- A witness in Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor's court-martial said today that at least part of the twenty Americans who joined the Communists and were in Red China were supposed to be smuggled back into this country as high-level Communist leaders.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, departed from Bonn today after having cleared some of the ground for a conference on West Germany's rearmament under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

The ruling of the United States Supreme Court in the public school segregation cases has sharpened the focus as the nation views again its over-all race relations situation. Undeniable improvements have been effected, especially since 1941, and every reliable report in many fields testifies to the progress chalked up in this difficult area which is so closely related to the great American ideal of democratic living.
The Southern New England Telephone Company announced yesterday plans for offering $14,666,000 of new capital stock to the company's shareholders for subscription.

Frankie Ryff, unbeaten Bronx lightweight, extended his victory skein to fourteen by gaining the unanimous decision over Ralph Dupas of New Orleans in the main bout of eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

The New York Herald Tribune resigned yesterday from the Publishers Association of New York City, to which twelve other newspapers belong for business, labor and informational purposes. The action preceded the association's annual collective bargaining with craft unions.
Individual Roman Catholic parishes in various parts of the city have postponed bingo playing in their churches "until further notice," apparently at the request of the Police Department.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 13 -- American products are ceasing to be exotic rarities in four of the most rapidly developing countries of Western Europe -- Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden. These comprise the prosperity belt of West Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Gang violence and corruption in Phenix City, Ala., which reached a climax last June in the murder of Albert L. Patterson, the Attorney General-elect, will be dramatized on the screen in "The Phenix City Story." Samuel Bischoff will produce the picture as the first of six films he has contracted to make for Allied Artists during the next three years.

Apple time is here again. Trees are thick with ripening fruit, but the Hurricanes Carol and Edna did their best to shake it from the boughs. Owners of backyard apple trees may be hard-pressed to dispose of highly perishable, gale-grounded apples.

PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, Sept. 14 -- Resurgent Democrats captured the Maine Governorship yesterday for the first time in twenty years. Their champion was Edmund S. Muskie, 40-year-old Democratic National Committeeman, who turned back Gov. Burton M. Cross' bid for a second term in a bitterly contested struggle.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 13 -- When it comes to revealing difficulties of a deeply personal nature adolescents are inclined to maintain resistance to even the most well-intentioned help, according to a report made public here today.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's presence here has led to renewed speculation that negotiations will be reopened soon for a military aid pact between the United States and Mexico.

A new issue of $65,000,000 debentures of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company will be placed on the market today mostly for the purpose of refunding outstanding debt now costing 4 7/8 per cent and 5 per cent in interest. The new debentures bear 4 1/4 per cent interest and are priced at 102 to yield 4.10 per cent. They will come due Sept. 1, 1974.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Lee Hills, executive editor of The Miami Herald and The Detroit Free Press, said today publishers and unions should work together to turn out better newspapers.

As things turned out, the Weather Bureau may have seemed to overplay Edna much as it had underplayed Carol, but Mr. Christy and his little band of weather-watchers atop 17 Battery Place deserve recognition for their outstanding week-end public service.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 13 -- Assemblyman John D. Young, Republican of Steuben County, who has been running for the G. O. P. nomination as Representative from the Thirty-seventh Congressional District, tonight asked voters of the Binghamton-Elmira area to vote for his opponent, Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican, and chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 13 -- The race committee's decision to sustain a Texas Corinthian Yacht Club protest enabled the visitors from Houston to score a second straight victory in their series with the Seawanhaka Yacht Club sailors, 53 1/2 to 51 1/4, today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Hog prices pushed up sharply in active dealings today, butchers showing the widest advance. They gained 75 cents to $1, while sows were 25 cents to mostly 50 cents higher. Salable receipts totaled 9,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The nine-day public inquiry into censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy fell far short of the record Congressional investigations.

TORONTO, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Ten companies comprising virtually the entire $124,000,000 Canadian electrical wire and cable manufacturing industry will go on trial late this year on charges of conspiring to operate a price-fixing combine.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The director general of the International Air Transport Association warned today of a deteriorating financial situation despite increasing business among the world's scheduled airlines.

A subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, headed by Representative John H. Ray, Republican of Staten Island, will inspect that borough's five private shipyards tomorrow to determine their needs and potentials in the light of any national emergency.
Events today: New York Summer Festival Band, assisted by Department of Sanitation Band, Battery Park, 12 noon; Interval Concert, the One People Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:40 P. M.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer denied tonight contentions that state elections in Schleswig-Holstein indicated popular feeling was shifting away from his foreign policies.
MONTREAL, Sept. 13 -- Economic statisticians are developing new and powerful mathematical instruments for forecasting changes in the economic climate.
The Board of Health, the city's top public health agency, adopted a resolution yesterday "strongly" urging fluoridation of the water supply as soon as possible to fight tooth decay.
All city streets seemed to lead to school yesterday morning as 1,219,525 youngsters answered the call of the new school year.

How a union welfare fund with an annual income of $250,000 went "broke" buying Catskill real estate at eight times its assessed valuation was described yesterday at a state hearing on welfare fund abuses.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 8 -- We made a five-hour flight from Peking [Peiping] to Shanghai, flying for miles over the flat plain, which is closely cultivated and set thick with villages. The only diversity was caused by the flooded areas. We had been told that the floods were under control and that the water was falling, but despite this the extent of the floods seemed to be very great.
Bonwit Teller combined custom designs by Yanni Evangelides with French imports in its showing yesterday.
TORONTO, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Thousands of persons stood in the rain today and cheered 16-year-old Marilyn Bell, the high school girl who swam Lake Ontario, as she rode in triumph to the City Hall.
DENVER, Sept. 13 -- President Eisenhower gave a word of encouragement today to nine Republican candidates, including one who is frankly running "scared."

A new woman's college, the first such in this city in twenty-five years, will open this morning. Part of Yeshiva University, it is the nation's first liberal arts college for women under Jewish auspices.

German dollar bonds were strong in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with new high prices for the year being registered for the German General Electric 6 1/2s of 1940 at 137 and the German General Electric 6s of 1948 at 128.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Two men threw rotten eggs and leaflets urging peace at the car carrying Anthony Eden as he arrived here today. The British Foreign Secretary had arrived by plane from Bonn to discuss with Italian officials ways of rearming West Germany as a result of the defeat of the European Defense Community project.

The people of New York State should have an opportunity to vote on a permissive amendment to the Constitution legalizing bingo on a local option basis for religious and charitable fund-raising. Church sponsorship of games of chance seems to us to have its dubious aspects, but we shall leave that decision to the churchmen, who plainly differ among themselves.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 13 -- The conflict between the Vietnamese Army and the Vietnamese Government became bitter today.
Sales of the International Minerals Chemical Corporation in the fiscal year ended on June 30 were the highest in its 45-year history, but earnings declined, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

BEFORE the New York art season can get well into its stride of thirty to fifty exhibitions a week, the Downtown Gallery is playing host to some thirty-five Chicago artists, most of them little if at all known in New York.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 13 -- Air and sea action against Amoy and near-by forts on the mainland continued today for the eleventh day.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- A General Assembly committee reported today it had not been able to break the deadlock on admission of new members to the United Nations.
One man's opinion on what constitutes a business or industrial leader was made known here yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 17 -- Mr. Attlee suggested today that Formosa be put under some form of temporary mandate to remove the danger of war.

THE waterfowl picture is quite bright for shooters along the Atlantic flyway, according to the latest report from Ducks Unlimited, which has completed a survey of the major breeding and rearing grounds of northern Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The Government's September crop report, issued Friday afternoon, was regarded as a bearish document in the grain market and started rather free selling today.
New Yorkers who would like to disprove the often-stated comment that they don't know as much about their city as some "out-of-towners" will have their chance starting next week.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., traditional foe of conference rate systems in international trade, lost a round yesterday in its longstanding fight against a practice under which an exclusive conference shipper receives a more favorable rate than an occasional, or noncontract, shipper.

The chain reaction set up by the French rejection of the European Defense Community has by no means exhausted itself. The defeat of Chancellor Adenauer's pro-Western policy in the Schleswig-Holstein elections on Sunday was a direct result of the French rebuff.
The civilian guard plan for school crossings got under way in the Bronx yesterday. The reaction -- from pupil to patrolman to school principal -- was: "It's good."

The annual luncheon and fashion show of the American Women's Voluntary Services will be held on Oct. 13 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, honorary president of the organization, will serve as chairman of the event.

As a prviate citizen I charge that the Commissioner blundered in his demotion of former Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg. The paradox of his foolish position is that, whereas the Commissioner strongly affirms that the laws must be enforced, he strongly denies that subordinates may enforce the laws unless the enforcing has his sanction.

YONKERS, Sept. 13 -- Russeks opened its first suburban store today, utilizing 9,000 square feet in a modern structure at the Cross County Shopping Center here. Other Russeks stores are in New York, Brooklyn and Chicago.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The character of American life cannot be properly understood without study of the role of ethnic and religious groups in a free society, speakers declared here today at a conference of the American Jewish Historical Society.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Container Corporation of America, big manufacturer of fabricated products, today announced acquisition of 190,000 shares of the common stock of Mengel Company of Louisville.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- A revision and extension of the Brussels treaty to include West Germany and Italy is under discussion. This is considered one possible means of linking Britain more closely with the European powers and thus smoothing the way for West Germany's entry into the Atlantic alliance.
" The Pony Cart," a new play by Roger Garis, co-starring Louisa Horton and Lamont Johnson, will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street.

Eye specialists from at least thirty-two nations convened here yesterday for the second part of their seventeenth International Congress of Ophthalmology. The first part had been held Friday and Saturday in Montreal, it was learned, to avoid any possible difficulties over the United States Internal Security Act.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active early yesterday, but trading quieted, and closing prices were 4 points higher to 8 points lower than on last Friday.
DENVER, Sept. 13 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that the National Security Council, in its meeting here yesterday, made no new policies but it did reaffirm devotion to the old ones.

Next month the Indiana University Press will publish the first volume in the Latin American Classics Series, a project that will introduce to English-speaking people representative works of Latin American literature and thought. The first book will be "The Cross and the Sword," translated by Robert Graves from Manuel de Jesus Galvan's historical novel.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- A ten-ton statue of Christopher Columbus, who sailed southwest from Spain and brought traffic to America in 1492, will move forty-five feet northeast in Tibbitts Park here tomorrow to ease traffic congestion.

IT was Marc Antony who said: "I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him." That goes here, too. The Yankees are ready for interment and funeral services will be held any day now. Their demise will be accepted throughout the country with dry-eyed restraint.

Concern over the problem of increasing paper work in industry, business and government has prompted the calling of a two-day conference at New York University's School of Commerce Building, Washington Square, beginning Monday.
The strong left arm of Johnny Antonelli restored order in the ranks of the Giants yesterday.
President Eisenhower designated yesterday the hurricane-raked parts of Maine as a disaster area and said rehabilitation funds would be allocated after a survey by Civil Defense officials.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- Now that it is obvious to all that the Yankees are about to be dethroned, the big question is: Who will manage the Bombers next year?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Diplomats from twenty-six countries began a new effort today to write an international pact that would guarantee certain fundamental legal, economic and social rights to the world's millions of stateless persons.

Although he admitted that the ticket sale was a little behind that of the June fight, Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, said yesterday that he was confident that Rocky Marciano and Ezzard Charles would draw $500,000 in their return match at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night.
Mid-twentieth century traffic is chasing the last newspaper out of the downtown Manhattan area that used to be known as "Newspaper Row."

The Republic Steel Corporation disclosed yesterday that it planned to buy the equipment and inventory of a Follansbee Steel Corporation plant at Follansbee, W. Va., and move them to Republic's Gadsden, Ala., mill.

Out of business for a day because of last Saturday's storm, the Queens County Jockey Club was operating again at its old stand at Aqueduct yesterday. As its main attraction, it presented the thirty-seventh running of the $18,725 Babylon Handicap, a number won by Edmund P. Bixer's Bunny's Babe.

READING, Pa., Sept. 13 (UP) -- Irving S. Taubkin, promotion manager of The New York Times, said today that classified advertisements last year produced an estimated $600,000,000 and accounted for more net revenue than national advertising.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Remorseful Communists who want to "rejoin decent society" were urged today by Herbert Brownell Jr. to tell their stories under protection of the new immunity law.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 13 -- Except for one outstanding reversal, the favorites advanced through the opening rounds in the women's United States amateur golf championship today. Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., the defender, moved ahead, downing Mary E. Nelson of Manoa, Pa., 10 and 8, to equal the record matchplay margin esatblished in 1938 by Patty Berg.

Automatic dismissal of public employes in the state who refuse to testify freely about their duties before authorized investigating agencies was urged yesterday. The proposal was made by the Temporary State Commission on Revision of the Civil Service Law.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 13 -- Members of fifteen European Parliaments met today in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe to discuss the setback to continental unity caused by France's defeat of the European Defense Community treaty.

A one-story industrial builjding containing 10,000 square feet of space at 37-15 Thirty-fifth Street ill Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the A. T. V. Film Productions, Inc. The building will be altered to accornmoffite two 3,000 - square - foot soUnd stages which will be used as additional studio space by the concern which has its main offices in iV[anhatn at 1600 Broadway.
TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today called the New Jersey Legislature into special session on Friday, although the regular 1954 session has not yet ended.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Season No. 13 is coming up for Harvey Haman as head football coach at Rutgers but he isn't crossing his fingers. He figures he had all the bad luck coming to him a year ago. Things went from bad to worse for Rutgers from the start of practice in 1953, with some of the most valuable men lost before the playing season opened.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Top-seeded stars sailed through their first day of singles play today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament without trouble

Aspirants for places on the Republican state ticket will be considered by the Republican State Executive Committee at a meeting in Syracuse next Tuesday. The two-day state convention will begin the next day.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The British Government is cautiously weighing the far-reaching defense proposals that South African officials suggested on their recent visit.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 -- Harold E. Stassen, head of the Foreign Operations Administration, plans to visit Yugoslavia and Spain at the end of next month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he "would take the story of Communist infiltration" to the people this fall when he campaigns for Republican Congressional candidates.
It was heartening to read in The Times of Sept. 6 your pleasure at the efforts of Bernard Gimbel and his associates in managing New York's Summer Festival so successfully.

DENVER, Sept. 13 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed the week of Oct. 3 as National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week. He called on national, state and local Government officials as well as industry and labor leaders to participate actively in the observance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the ninth day of proceedings of the Senate select committee to study censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin:

A conference of twenty-six countries opened at the United Nations yesterday to consider the broadening of legal protection and of civil rights for the millions of stateless persons who as a result of wars, territorial transfers and political persecutions have no citizenship or land they can call their own.
Milton Wolf, national commander of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, denied yesterday that the organization was subversive or Communist-controlled.

Good retail business in the last two weeks has given confidence to retailers that sales will be satisfactory for the remainder of the fall and into Christmas. As a result they have been buying briskly at two trade shows.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy tournament, a 54-hole medal-play event for the women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester counties, marked its silver anniversary today with a field of eighty-four in the first round at the Apawamis Club.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 13 -- Dr. Frank J. Soday, one of the South's foremost industrial scientists, was selected today to head the Southern Association of Science and Industry, a fourteen-state regional resource development agency.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company informed its stockholders yesterday that Commissioner Wilson Cowen of the United States Court of Claims had filed a report of his findings in the suits by the company against the Government.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 13 -- An Iranian artillery major committed suicide last night as security agents hunted him in a mop-up of remnants of a Communist espionage ring in the armed forces.

LINDEN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Thirty-six persons, including thirty-one men in the armed forces and five civilians, were injured, several seriously, early today when a busload of soldiers returning to Fort Hancock and Fort Monmouth crashed into the rear of another bus halted for a traffic light at Route 1 and Wood Avenue here.

The startling Democratic Gubernatorial victory in normally Republican Maine will certainly set Democratic mouths to watering in anticipation of November. Not only did the Democrats succeed for the first time in twenty years in electing a Governor but they seriously reduced the usual Republican margins in Senatorial and Congressional races.

" MEDIC," a weekly program of unusual magnitude that dramatizes medical case histories, made its debut last Monday from 9 to 9:30 P. M. over the N. B. C.-TV network. It isn't often that television craftsmen throw off the shackles of mediocrity and transcend the boundaries of mere entertainment as they did in the premiere.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- On this date a year ago, the Yankees clinched their fifth straight pennant. But today, as runners-up, the Bombers were merely playing out the string, while hammering the Detroit Tigers, 11 -- 0.

Domestic production of aluminum last month amounted to 250,592,575 pounds, or only slightly below the record high output of 252,323,794 pounds produced the previous month, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday:
SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives said tonight that the Government should take a "protective and cooperative" attitude for business not a dictatorial one.

DRIVING an automobile in New York can be a chore, a bore, a dull or irritating experience. Or it can be a thrill, an adventure, an escape from virtual immobility to free, gliding motion. For the special students of Martin Leiter, who operates the Luxor Auto Driving School in the Bronx, it is such and adventure.

Stocks rose yesterday for the ninth successive session. The improvement was small, and limited largely to motors, electrical equipments and oils. It carried The New York Times' combined average up 0.37 point to 226.31.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 14 -- Benjamin Britten's new opera, "The Turn of the Screw," was warmly applauded at its world premiere at La Fenice Theater tonight. The British composer wrote the work expressly for the International Festival of Contemporaneous Music being held here.
Count Ferdinand Sarmi, creator of the Elizabeth Arden custom order collection presented yesterday at 691 Fifth Avenue, is a devotee of the longer waisted look.
The manager of a Brooklyn manufacturing plant was held up by two young men yesterday and robbed of a payroll envelope containing $7,850. The bandits left behind another envelope with $2,230.
" A Story for Rosh ha-Shanah," a telecast dedicated to the 300th anniversary of the Jews in America, will be seen over WABC-TV, Channel 7, on Tuesday from 7:30 to 8 P. M.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- A special committee of city attorneys reported failure today in a study aimed at finding some sources of municipal revenue that were practicaly unknown.

The Temporary Commission on the Courts will hold hearings here tomorrow and Friday on a proposed administrative office for the state courts. The hearings will begin at 10 A. M. each day in the auditorium of the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street.

The American Bankers Association reported yesterday that losses and repossessions on installment loans had so leveled off in the last four months as to permit greater flexibility in members' loan terms and more liberal screening policies.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer informed his Christian Democratic parliamentary group today that he would meet John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, in the near future. Dr. Adenauer indicated this meeting probably would take place at an international conference.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will address and report to the North Atlantic Council Thursday the results of his European tour.
DENVER, Sept. 14 -- Organized retailers gave President Eisenhower a cheerful outlook on the economy today and reported that he shared their optimism.
Eye specialists from thirty-two countries exchanged progress reports yesterday on their research into eye diseases and injuries.

Entries are being received for a contemporary fine arts exhibit featuring the work of American Jewish artists, Mrs. Nancy P. Dryfoos, chairman of the American Jewish Tercentenary fine arts committee, announced yesterday.

The New York Giants announced yesterday that they now were accepting mail orders for world series tickets. A club spokesman said that between 30,000 and 40,000 reserved seats were being offered for public sale, with a limit of two sets to a customer.
ROME, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- The text of a joint communique issued tonight by Attilio Piccioni, Italian Foreign Minister and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, follows:

The public hearings on labor union welfare funds being held under the chairmanship of Superintendent of Insurance Bohlinger are focused on conditions in New York State, but they will have wide national significance. The growth of these funds during the past few years has been prodigious, but has largely escaped public notice.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The stock markets here were brighter today than they had been for a week or two.
BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 14 -- Man, not science, is the evil force when scientific discoveries are used wickedly, President Eisenhower declared today.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of British socialism's left wing, asserted tonight on his return from China that human nature might prompt Communist retaliation on Chiang Kai-sheks forces in Formosa.

State investigators disclosed yesterday that officials of three small unions had bled their welfare funds for more in salaries, bonuses and other special benefits than the entire union membership got in insurance protection.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that scarves are "articles of wearing apparel" subject to the standards laid down in the Flammable Fabrics Act.

Mayor Wagner indirectly served notice yesterday on the Transit Authority that the city proposes to see to it that New Yorkers receive "the best type" of rapid transit service, even though operation of the transit system is under control of the authority and not the city.

The movement is in full swing, and in a few days will be all but complete. In the crowds arriving in the city there will be many tanned youngsters returning from summer camps looking healthy, refreshed and carrying an extra piece of luggage.

THE hunting prospects will vibrate no chord in thousands of sportsmen who will let the upland game season come and go while they get their exercise moving up and down the beaches in an attempt to pull a few striped bass from the fall migration.

The One People Ensemble. with Norma Holmes, Daniel Andrews and Yoko Matsuo, performed at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening in another of the series of Interval Concerts being presented there by Norman J. Seaman.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Before leaving by air tonight for financial talks in Washington, Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler listed three conditions to be fulfilled before the pound sterling could be made convertible.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 14 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown will benefit by a country fair to be held here on the lawns and beach of Peacock Point, estate of Mrs. Henry Pomeroy Davison, from noon until 5 P. M. on Sept. 25.
A spokesman for 700 embalmers in the five boroughs said last night that they would strike today for a shorter work week at the same pay they now received.

New York won a resounding victory over Chicago yesterday. The General Board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. voted to make this city the permanent home of the influential Protestant interchurch organization.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet Foreign Ministry statement on the Manila defense treaty as broadcast tonight by the Moscow radio:

Alfred E. Perlman, who became president of the vast New York Central Railroad System on June 14 following Robert R. Young's successful proxy battle for control of that $2,600,000,000 carrier, was elected a director yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 14 -- Foreign Minister George K. C. Yeh said today that the Chinese Communists' shelling of Quemoy and their intensified propaganda concerning Formosa were designed to "isolate" the Chinese Nationalists on the international front by posing a threat of war.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The Indonesian delegation belittled today the "self-styled Islamic Republic of Indonesia." The delegation said its threat to bring the matter of internal unrest in Indonesia before the United Nations was an attempt to confuse Indonesia's claim to Western New Guinea (Irian), a matter pending before the General Assembly.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, announced this week the appointment of the Rev. Dr. Robert H. Bonthius as college chaplain and Professor of Religion.
At 6:58 A. M., a New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad commuters' train leaves Danbury, Conn., for New York. Aboard is J. W. Halliday, a trainman. Also aboard is Julian Tamburri, a manufacturer.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Three officials of the American Federation of Labor Teamster Union in the Detroit area interrupted their trial in Recorder's Court today and pleaded guilty to soliciting and accepting bribes in connection with union activities.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Bob Friend a Pittsburgh right-hander, yielded five singles as he blanked Chicago, 4 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Cubs had trounced the Pirates. 9 -- 2, in the twilight opener.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Defense Department plans to spend $2,000,000,000 less than the $37,575,000,000 forecast by President Eisenhower in his budget message for the current fiscal year.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- A two-state group of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters today urged that all outlets of reporting be given equal access to public proceedings.

New York styles held their own in Bendel's showing yesterday of custom order fashions designed here and in Paris. Names famed on both sides of the Atlantic were represented in the collection and only in a few instances were the designs from across the sea somewhat more extreme than those created here.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 14 -- Twenty-year-old Virginia Dennehy of Lake Forest, Ill., vanquished the British champion, Frances Stephens, in the third round of the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

Walter P. Reuther asserted yesterday that the United Automobile Workers would take whatever steps might be necessary next year to obtain a guaranteed annual wage for 500,000 employes of the General Motors, Ford and Chrysler companies.

May I as a layman take issue with the experts in our State Department on the matter of our present position with relation to Formosa and Nationalist China. I start with the basic premise that it is of utmost importance to this country that Communist growth and expansion be halted everywhere in the world and particularly in the Far East.

This is no time for friends of Scouting to remain inarticulate. It was not too impressive when the Illinois Department of the American Legion started to pick on the Girl Scouts. But the national convention of the Legion now has criticized the Girl Scouts on vague and unspecified accusations of un-Americanism.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 12 -- Instead of going by plane, we traveled from Shanghai to Hangchow by rail. Hangchow is an ancient city of more than 600,000 people, far less touched by the West than either Peking [Peiping] or Mukden.

Sales of black-and-white television sets this year will be higher than in any twelve-month period of the industry's seven-year history, it was predicted yesterday by Frank M. Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America.
A one-time professional educator struck hard yesterday at business men who make a fetish of the sheepskin.

Contract negotiations covering 15,000 members of a deck officers' union opened yesterday with formal presentations of demands to the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. A pension plan is the principal aim.

The eleventh consolidated sale of Federally-subsidized public housing bonds authorized by 1949 Federal legislation took place yesterday, with fourteen local authorities borrowing $135,865,000 at an average interest cost of 2.3327 per cent.

Indiscriminate killing of all roadside vegetation, as a means of combating hayfever-inducing ragweed, was criticized yesterday by Frank E. Egler. He is chairman of the American Museum of Natural History's "committee for brush control recommendations for right-of-ways."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with active months 22 points higher to 1 point lower than on Mondays.
Strikes in copper mines and processing plants trimmed domestic production last month to the lowest level in several years and caused a reduction in deliveries to consumers and in producers' stocks.
MANILA, Sept. 14 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo left by plane for Washington tonight on a mission for President Ramon Magsaysay in connection with revision of the Philippine Trade Act.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 14 -- The Pakistan Government canceled today the five-month-old license of the Soviet Government's foreign insurance department. It had been operating in Pakistan since April under the guise of a private marine and fire underwriting company known as Ingosstrakh.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Martin (Skip) Purcell, national junior champion in 1952, gained a commanding lead today as competition began in the sixth annual associate members' regatta held under the auspices of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 14 -- South Korean officials charged today that the Czechoslovak and Polish members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission here had committed espionage.

Bingo appeared to have been stopped in all five boroughs yesterday, pending efforts to legalize it. Religious, charitable and other organizations that had been sponsoring bingo games seemed to have suspended them voluntarily or after police warnings.

Mrs. Lewis Armstrong has been named chairman of the committee for the Goddard Gala, a wine-tasting, dinner and dance, on Oct. 18 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event will be for the benefit of the welfare program of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

BONN, Sept. 14 -- West Germany's banking authorities announced today the virtual unfreezing of capital owned by foreigners and hitherto held in so-called sperrmark accounts. The sums involved are some 690,000,000 marks ($154,761,904), plus "several billion" marks worth of German stock owned by foreigners.

EZZARD CHARLES fought the best fight of his life against Rocky Marciano three months ago. It still wasn't good enough, even though the bold challenger somehow contrived to survive fifteen rounds with the Brockton Blockbuster.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Mississippi Senate approved by a 42-2 vote today a proposed constitutional amendment to permit the Legislature to abolish public schools as a means of retaining segregation.
The formation of a youth squad of two assistant district attorneys to combat juvenile delinquency in Queens was announced yesterday by T. Vincent Quinn, the borough's prosecutor.

RYE, N. Y. Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, the defending champion and four-time winner, led by three strokes in the women's Tri-County Golf Association open championship for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy after shooting a 40, 39 -- 79 at Apawamis today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Red Schoendienst and Rip Repulski hammered successive home runs to highlight a three-run eighth inning that paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The uneventful start of racial integration yesterday in this city's public schools is not being duplicated by the District of Columbia Fire Department, now under orders to end segregation practices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- John J. McCloy, chairman of the Chase National Bank, said today United States withdrawal from the thirty-three nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) would "be a miscalculation of where our vital interests lie."
BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Joe Coleman, who had hurled a one-hitter in his last appearance, pitched five-hit ball tonight as the Baltimore Orioles gained a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

Soviet chess players gained the lead among twelve countries competing for the Hamilton-Russell Cup at Apollo Hall yesterday, when they defeated Great Britain, 3 1/2 -- 1/2, in the second round of the final, according to a report from Amsterdam.

The Fair Campaign Practices Committee is to be congratulated on the timely and useful task to which it has set its hand. The committee is sponsoring a "code" which it believes spells out the conscience of America for the conduct of political campaigns -- a document that deserves conscientious reading by every American citizen.

New York and several other states had primary elections yesterday, and the one generalization that can usually be made the day before and the day after is that the vote is light. Since the usual reaction of the public to a primary is a bored yawn, what is the use of having them?

Some statistics on today's brides were given in a talk by Virginia Maves, editor-in-chief of Modern Bride Magazine, at a dinner last night of the Electrical Women's Round Table at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 14 -- Eddie Erdelatz is trying manfully to put on a new look of cheerful optimism this year but his innate skepticism keeps breaking through when he talks about the Navy football team.
SYOSSET, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Prospective high school students in this and two other North Shore communities found school doors slammed in their faces today.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 14 -- The Committee on General Affairs of the Council of Europe reached a compromise tonight on a draft resolution for an integrated European defense that would permit West Germany's indirect participation in the Atlantic alliance.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14 -- Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, flew here today from Bonn, where he had held two "confidential" talks with Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 14 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, accused of collaborating with his Communist captors in Korea, told a court-martial today of seeing his assistant shot to death by the Reds.

Thoroughbreds on the distaff side had a "day" at the Aqueduct track yesterday. Fillies and mares were eligible to compete in seven of the eight races. Five events were run exclusively for them. And most of them were unpredictable.
Hoyt Wilhelm's efficient lock-up job drew the spotlight from a highly controversial play in last night's Giant victory over the Braves.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 14 -- Edmund S. Muskie was elected Maine's first Democratic Governor in twenty years largely because he made up his mind long ago that he was not going to be afraid of the Republicans.

The Brooklyn Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 4 -- 0, for their sixth straight triumph last night. Johnny Podres hurled his second shutout of the campaign before a ladies night crowd of 13,058 (9.877 paid) at Ebbets Field.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. asserted yesterday that he was not engaged in a personal fight with Averell Harriman or any other individual in the Democratic party.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 14 (UP) -- Negro students were banned from white schools by Greenbrier County school officials today after 700 white residents voted to remove bodily any Negroes who attended classes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Jubilant Democrats declared today that the Maine election results indicated a trend that would give their party control of both the Senate and the House in the next Congress.
Your recent comments on hurricane "Carol" prompt me to draw your attention to what I think is the greatest obstacle to perfecting warnings for one day ahead.

Plans for a large parking lot and a bus service that together will enable New York-bound motorists to dodge the daily rush of the Lincoln Tunnel were announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

Operating revenues of Anderson, Clayton Co., Inc., in the fiscal year ended on July 31 were lower than those of the preceding year but earnings were higher, according to the consolidated report issued yesterday.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright, Republican organization candidate for renomination, won an easy victory over William P. Shea in the party primary in the First Congressional District. The district consists of all of Suffolk County and forty-six election districts in eastern Nassau County.

A Soviet propaganda maneuver boomeranged last month when a shower of tomatoes and a hail of boos greeted twenty-one Soviet Moslem pilgrims in the streets of Mecca. The story of the Soviet propaganda reverse was told yesterday by two Moslem refugees from the Soviet Union who went to Mecca and organized an anti-Communist maneuver.
R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company will put heavy advertising support behind its products -- Camel, Winston and Cavalier Cigarettes and Prince Albert Smoking Tobacco -- in the 1954-55 season.
Absent from the local stage since 1949, Tallulah Bankhead breezes into the Morosco at 8:15 this evening with "Dear Charles" after a record-breaking jaunt over the strawhat circuit.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Paul Richards resigned as manager of the Chicago White Sox today to "run the whole show" for the Baltimore Orioles. He was immediately replaced in the Sox job by Marty Marion, who had been serving as a coach.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, is expected to fly to Europe soon for a final round of high-level consultations on the problem of rearming West Germany.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said here yesterday that he intended to look into a recently announced alliance between a C. I. O. union and the old International Longshoremen's Association.

The Bowery Savings Bank's start of construction next week on a $3,000,000 twelve - story apartment house in Harlem is an encouraging development, interesting on several accounts. For one thing, this is said to be the first unsubsidized large-scale housing in that area for about fifteen years.

The inspection of hydrants, up to now the privilege of a politically favored few, was transferred yesterday from its unrestricted "exempt" status to a strictly Civil Service function. By order of Mayor Wagner, the existing set-up will end Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese Army has agreed to leave Saigon, thereby easing a tense situation between the Vietnamese Army and the Government.

Winners of scholarships offered annually by the American Theatre Wing Professional Training Program were announced yesterday. Rosemary Shein of Bronxville, N. Y., was selected for the Mary MacArthur Scholarship donated by Helen Hayes in memory of her daughter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Establishment of a permanent private national commission to deal with this country's growing health problems was proposed today by Benson Ford, vice president of the Ford Motor Company.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 14 -- The curse of King Midas has descended upon hundreds of workers here who cannot escape the sad consequences of having too much gold, or, in this instance, dollars earned with industry.

Africa has been the subject of many books published this season. But they have dealt mainly with the northern or southern region of the continent. Soon to be published are two volumes than concern the central area. One is "Madami," by Anne Eisner Putnam in collaboration with Allan Keller, which Prentice-Hall will issue Sept. 23.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Buying of wheat futures was active today until near the close, when there was free selling. Heavy rains in the Northwest that continued to delay the completion of the harvest were a steadying influence.
Fewer American-made automobiles are being exported to Europe and fewer European-built standard motor vehicles are being sent to this country, Henry Ford 2d said here yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 14 -- William S. Lutz, chief fiscal and personnel officer of the State Division of Employment Security, sought today to refute charges of theft and fraud brought against him by Gov. Robert B. Meyner. He also contradicted parts of the testimony of previous witnesses and vehemently denied a number of accusations directed at him by them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Albert M. Cole, Federal Housing Administrator, told Senate investigators today that three New York City builders had run an investment of only $90 into $1,251,079 in "windfall" profits on three apartment house projects.

Amendment of the American Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to permit a simplified method of paying construction differential subsidies to American ship owners was proposed here yesterday by Senator Charles E. Potter.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians moved within two victories of clinching the American League pennant by scoring four runs in the first inning tonight for a 4-2 triumph over the Washington Senators.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Problems of taxation and convertibility of money occupied much of the second-day sessions of the tenth annual general meeting of the International Air Transport Association here.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 14 -- The struggle between Islam and communism for control of Indonesia has sharpened during the last twenty-four hours.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Uhleen Fingo, 4-year-old brown mare owned by C. T. Black of Berryville, Va., and driven by Earl Avery, scored an easy three-length victory in 2:04 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway to capture the Tennessee mile pace.
DENVER, Sept. 14 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today gave his military aide, Lieut. Col. Robert L. Schulz, one of the finest presents a military man can have -- a surprise promotion.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 14 -- Maine Republican leaders were surveying today the aftermath of a political hurricane that swept them out of the Governorship for the first time in twenty years.

At a special meeting of the Hussmann Refrigerator Company in St. Louis yesterday stockholders approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 2,000,000 shares of $5 par from 1,000,000 shares of no par value.

One of the most inexpensive trips to Europe on record -- total cost 15 cents -- came to an end yesterday with the arrival of the superliner United States and her impromptu passenger, Eugene Hart, a Brooklyn lad.

The recent attempt at enforcement of New York State Penal Law, Section 1370, which provides a jail sentence of not more than two years and a fine of not more than $1,000 or both for any person who contrives, draws or assists in a lottery, including bingo, has led to the punishment of the enforcer.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Sept. 15 -- In a hotly contested primary election Wisconsin's state Republican organization failed yesterday to purge itself of an outspoken anti-McCarthy state official.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Domestic manufacturers of wool knit gloves and mittens today proposed to the United States Tariff Commission that imports of such products be limited to 34 per cent of the total available for civilian consumption.

Foreign Secretary Eden arrives in Paris today with an impressive volume of support for an alternative to the rejected European Defense Community. All accounts are agreed that he is seeking to expand the 1948 Brussels Pact to include Western Germany and Italy and to join this "Little European" group to the Atlantic community through NATO.
Directors of the Western Electric Company elected three vice presidents yesterday.
The Waterman Pen Company celebrated its seventieth birthday yesterday by naming a new president and by introducing a new fountain pen.

A generally lower trend prevailed on the local commodity exchanges yesterday in moderately active trading. Losses were registered by futures in cocoa, hides, rubber, tin, zinc and silk, while copper and lead bucked the down-trend. Coffee and potatoes closed mixed.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- An unidentified American from New Jersey has rescued the home of the late George Bernard Shaw from possible sale by public auction.

That water-colors and a primary election can form a perfect blend was demonstrated last night in the parish hall of St. John's-in-the-Village Protestant Episcopal Church, 224 Waverly Place. Nobody had planned it that way, but it came out all right to the edification of both voters and art lovers.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the national champion, won without trouble but Ken Rosewall of Australia had a fight on his hands in taking second-round matches in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The special Senate committee considering the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy unanimously rejected today his demand that the committee replace its counsel for the drafting of its report.
ROME, Sept. 14 -- Italy and Britain reached "complete agreement" today on a plan for aligning West European nations in a security pact devoid of supranational features.

The Sheraton Corporation of America, operator of a nationwide chain of hotels, is negotiating to buy the Astor Hotel here from Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate company headed by William Zeckendorf. The deal is expected to materialize within the next few days, Ernest Henderson, president of the Sheraton, told shareholders at their annual meeting in Boston yesterday.

Candidates with the backing of the regular party organizations appeared early this morning to have won most of the contests for party nominations that were up for decision in the metropolitan area in yesterday's primary.
I have read the letter of Mr. Vernon critical of my article "Keynes International" in Economics and Finance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Universal has made a new start toward filming "Song of Norway" and plans on putting the operetta before the camera next year. Edward Hope has been working on the screen adaptation for a month and studio executives are enthusiastic over the way the script is developing.

George Balanchine's setting of half a dozen little pieces by the late Charles Ives was presented for the first time last night by the New York City Ballet under the title of "Ivesiana." It is a suite of choreographic etudes built upon the extraordinary music of a difficult but much neglected composer, and it has inspired Mr. Balanchine to some characteristic composition in the extra-classical department of his creative equipment.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Two American newspaper men and a merchant sea captain imprisoned by the Communists since March, 1953, crossed the Communist Chinese frontier to freedom, today.

Rocky Marciano will risk the heavyweight championship of the world tonight against Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati. The boxers will meet at the Yankee Stadium in a fifteen-round bout that is scheduled to begin at 10:30. There will be no local television of the contest.

The Duchess of Kent alighted at La Guardia Airport late yesterday afternoon in a Royal Canadian Air Force plane for her first visit to New York. She arrived from Montreal, where she wound up a three-week visit to Canada.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The candidates supported by regular Republican party leaders in the only two election contests in Westchester County won their fight tonight, according to early, but indicative, returns.
Strict immigration laws, it appears, may keep Nicholas Levitsky, a Russian-born refugee from Red China, traveling the Atlantic Ocean indefinitely.

Today's new film is "The Gay Adventure," starring Burgess Meredith and Jean-Pierre Aumont and featuring Paula Valenska, at the Beekman and Gramercy Theatres. The comedy drama was produced in Europe by Anatole De Grunwald and directed by Gordon Parry for Renown Pictures, United Artists is distributing.

Business in the nation's chain stores slipped a bit in August, according to a survey by The New York Times. The sales of forty-three companies totaled $1,038,486,000 or 1 per cent less than in August, 1953.

IN the spring of 1911, when Arthur Tuckerman was 14 years old, he took home from the private school he attended in Washington a report card that was particularly disgraceful. His father was upset. But with a subtlety worthy of his diplomat grandfather young Arthur suggested that the reason he wasn't learning much might be the school's fault.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joseph B. Johnson, 61-year-old business man, won the Republican nomination for Governor tonight on the basis of nearly complete returns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee entered a new protest today against the ability of the Soviet Union to have three votes in the United Nations General Assembly while other member nations had only one each.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 14. The Iranian Government is informally urging the Soviet Union to hasten the departure of its military attache on the ground that he was linked with the Communist espionage ring dicovered in the Iranian armed forces.

Merchandise-hungry retail apparel buyers are pouring into town. Having underestimated their needs for early fall, they are looking for goods that can be shipped quickly to round out depleted stocks. They are also shopping for holiday merchandise and showing a determination to buy that hasn't been in evidence since the spring of 1953.
The musicians of the former N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra have formed a permanent organization to keep the orchestra alive, it was announced yesterday.

Five Chinese anti-Communists, former prisoners of war of the United Nations during the Korean fighting, arrived here yesterday on a goodwill mission. They will be here ten days as part of a three-month world tour to express their gratitude to the United Nations for aiding in winning them their freedom from Communist China.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- The Soviet Union officially denounced the Southeast Asian defense pact tonight as being directed against security in Asia and against the freedom and national independence of the Asian peoples.

The monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America noted yesterday the placing of a new private shipbuilding contract for the first time in two years. However, the council's figures on ship construction in this country continued to show a downward trend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Administration increased its estimate of the Federal deficit for the present fiscal year to $4,700,000,000 today, despite a sharp cut in national security spending.

Milwaukee's gallant fight to remain in the National League flag race was all but snuffed out at the Polo Grounds last night as the Giants turned back Charlie Grimm's Braves, 2 to 1, in the opener of a three-game series.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Bullets from Czechoslovakia whined over a four-man United States patrol yesterday in an Iron Curtain border area where two United States Army groups ran into trouble earlier this summer.

A young Australian home economist, Miss Norma Jean Findley, paused long enough in her sight-seeing of New York the other day to give us her impressions of American cooking (Southern style) and to tell us something about food in her home city of Melbourne.

European fashion designs were outstanding in the Harry Frechtel collection shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. This group, which includes also some simple, tailored styles by Frechtel, is available at Lord Taylor.
BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Robert F. Murphy, a newcomer to state-wide politics, was nominated by the Democrats early today to run for Governor.
What was described as the world's largest wholesale liquor warehouse was opened yesterday in Long Island City, Queens.
Man may war in the future over sources of energy as he has in the past over food, chemists at the 126th national meeting of the American Chemical Society were told here yesterday.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The United States Department of Agriculture estimates the 1954 New England potato crop at 59,203,000 bushels, off 19 per cent from the ten-year average.

TO theatregoers eager at this time of year to speed the drama on to new and noble heights. "The Pony Cart" is a depressing experience. It is the work of Roger Garis, a professional writer in other fields, and it opened the season at Theatre de Lys last evening.
The Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, under the direction of Eugene Malek, will open its thirty-second season with a rehearsal tonight at 8 o'clock at 189 Second Avenue.'

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The new chief of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine has warned the Security Council that recent Israeli - Jordanian border incidents could develop into hostilities that might spread "like brushfire."
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 130 pints of blood on Monday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 14 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, took a wide early lead in his three-way race for nomination for re-election tonight, and both of Val Bjornson's opponents conceded in the contest for the Republican nomination for Senator.

In your issue of Aug. 23 Paul Heffernan raises a hoary issue in the field of foreign trade policy. Are we getting anywhere, he asks, in the development of a tolerable trade policy through multilateral agreements? He answers his question in the negative and then offers a proposal as hoary as the issue: the proposal that nations should seek to improve their trade relations through bilateral agreements, rather than multilateral organizations.
Thirty young women will be introduced to society at the Gotham Ball, which will be held Nov. 25, Thanksgiving night, at the Plaza.

A New York syndicate issued a detailed analysis yesterday claiming it could save the Government and consumers $150,000,000 over thirty years as against the Eisenhower Administration's Dixon - Yates contract. The issue involves supplying power to the Tennessee Valley Authority.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- A four-point guide to give historians and educators a clearer understanding of American Jewish history was offered today by a conference of prominent historians.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The long-disputed markings on the surface of Mars may be the outlines of swirls and furrows cut into the dust, sand or volcanic ash of the planet by the force of winds.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Wednesday, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Representative Norris Cotton early today won the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat of the late Senator Charles W. Tobey.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Would you like to charge rental for telegraph poles on your land?

A syndicate of underwriting houses headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and White, Weld Co., will place on the market today a new issue of $7,500,000 par value of preferred stock of the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company at a price to yield 4.162 per cent to investors.

THE small exhibition of European works of art illustrating scenes from the life of the Virgin, which opens today and will be on view at the Metropolitan Museum until Oct. 17, has been planned in connection with the Marian Year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Justice Department is using its new witness immunity law in re-opening grand jury investigations into World War II Russian spy rings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Charles E. Daniel, newly appointed Democratic Senator from South Carolina, said today he would again support President Eisenhower in 1956 if the President sought re-election.

History does not often give nations a second "last chance" to come to their senses. The French rejection of E. D. C. is an unmitigated disaster if one believes that West German rearmament is the sine qua non of Atlantic security.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The first step toward resumption of Supreme Court arguments on school segregation was taken today when attorneys for three Southern states filed notice they wanted to take part in the legal debate.

Forty years ago Miss Ruth Vanderbilt Twombly began an association with the Community Service Society that ended with her death early this month. Never one to seek the limelight, she worked hard and diligently over the years, serving on numerous committees that were concerned chiefly with improving health conditions among New York families.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Pronto Don is expected to set a money-winning record for harness racing in the $25,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

John H. Harris, the sponsor of "Ice Capades of 1955," which opened last night at Madison Square Garden, is a man not easily daunted by competition. He chose the date for his premiere without displaying any deep concern that Tallulah Bankhead and a heavyweight championship fight (later canceled) were scheduled to compete with his attraction for patronage.
For the third time this season the Dodgers played and won a ball game under atrocious weather conditions when they beat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 10 -- 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
The United States must be willing to pay whatever price is necessary to save its freedom, according to Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Alfred A. Valdmanis, former Economics Director for the Newfoundland, pleaded guilty today to charges of having defrauded the Newfoundland Government of $200,000. He will be sentenced Friday.

The contention of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that proposed new work schedules on the IND subway would be detrimental to the health and safety of Transit Authority employes was rejected yesterday by an impartial adviser.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 -- President Joao Cafe Filho called on all Brazilians last night to help end the financial crisis strangling the country.

American, Italian and French design inspiration mingled in Arnold Constable's showing of cocktail and evening fashions by Filcol yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. This manufacturer's original designs were interspersed with adaptations of the French and Italian couturiers' recent creations.
HONG KONG, Sept. 15 -- Bedbugs, brainwashing and isolation -- that was the Communist China encountered by three Americans who returned today after eighteen months as prisoners there.

Old furniture styles have been given a new treatment for eleven redecorated rooms now on view at Altman's. The furniture reproduces that of eighteenth century England, France and Italy, but the fabrics and colors used in the room settings are those of today.
CinemaScope will finish its first year today after titillating thousands of movie fans and adding considerably to Bausch Lomb Optical Company's coffers.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is about to make another special offering of its stock to company employes at a price $20 below the market value. The offer, which will extend from late October to Dec. 15, will be the second to be made under the authority of the employes' stock purchase plan approved by the stockholders in 1950.

The Electro Metallurgical Company plans to start construction immediately of the nation's largest titanium plant, a $31,500,000 installation to produce at least 7,500 tons a year of the strong, lightweight metal at Ashtabula, Ohio.
The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint of unfair labor practices yesterday against Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., and Local 895 of the International Longshoremen's Association.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- When slot machines were banned from military reservations by the Pentagon in 1950 the officers' and noncommissioned officers' clubs at the Mitchel Air Forfce Base here turned to bingo as the second best thing.

The elegance of Italy has been translated into modern American room settings on display in Macy's seventh floor Plan-a-Home Row. Brushed-with-gold prints by Riverdale that are derived from Florentine patterns are used in the rooms as draperies, cafe curtains, bedspreads, and sofa and chair upholstery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that business men stepped up in July the rate at which they were reducing their stocks of unsold goods.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Edward R. Fay Jr., Democratic candidate for Congress from Fairfield County who at 49 is still young enough to run for office and a train at the same time, opened his campaign at 8:22 o'clock this morning.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 15 -- Some Chinese Nationalist planes again attacked artillery positions today on and around Amoy Island, the Ministry of Defense announced here. The attacks were small and a military spokesman declined to specify how many planes and ships were involved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives set out today to investigate nearly 300 Government educational programs about which Congress and the United States Office of Education appeared to know little if anything.

The saga of two New York union officials who drew $32,760 a year in compensation from the union welfare fund and spent most of their time in Florida and the Catskills was spread on the record of the state investigation into welfare abuses yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 -- Floyd Odlum, United States financier, is negotiating with the Argentine Government for an integrated three-way package deal to help the country develop its oil and uranium resources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- John Foster Dulles again served notice tonight that the United States stood ready "at all times" to strike back at Communist aggression in Southeast Asia or the Pacific "by means and at places" of its own choosing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The Army today announced that Lieut. Gen. Williston B. Palmer, combat commander during World War II and the Korean conflict, had been named First Deputy Chief of Staff for logistics.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 15 -- Democratic hopes for a victory in November soared in Wisconsin today as votes were counted in yesterday's primary election.
The Western Maryland Railroad achieved yesterday an interest saving of 1 per cent on $13,846,000 of bonds not due until 1976.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Two Republican leaders, embarking on campaign tours, cited Maine election results today as evidence of the need for Republicans to unite and work if they wanted to retain control of Congress.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 -- Vice President Nixon declared tonight that the election of a Democratic Congress this fall would produce "two years of calculated, deliberate efforts to discredit the Eisenhower Administration."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- As the world's standards of living rise, its number of physically handicapped will increase correspondingly. Dr. Howard A. Rusk, of New York, predicted today. He spoke at the sixth world congress of the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples.

In the six-furlong fifth, Mrs. George D. Widener's 2-year-old colt Islander raced for the first time since he beat the excellent Summer Tan in the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park in May. Islander, at 11 to 10, made an up-front run in the backstretch but dropped back to third on the turn and dropped back to seventh, under the whip, in the stretch.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., Sept. 15 -- The three unions at the Arma Division of the American Bosch Arma Corporation, whose strike closed the plant for ten weeks a year ago, voted today to cooperate with Charles W. Perelle, the company's new president, by waiving demands for wage increases this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Air Force today brought court-martial charges against Col. Robert Orr, decorated veteran of World War II and Korea who was arrested on a burglary charge in Las Vegas, Nev., July 2.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The rubber match in a Utah political battle was assured today with the nomination of Mrs. Reva Beck Bosone, who is the only woman ever to represent this state in Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Wheat futures lacked aggressive buying to maintain rallies today through much of the session. And there was some selling on the announcement by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson of the elimination of the "total acreage" phase of the new farm bill.
Helen Hayes and Joseph Cotten have been signed for major roles in "Light's Diamond Jubilee," a two-hour, four-network TV celebration to be shown on Saturday, Oct. 24 at 9 P. M.
The H. K. Porter Company, Inc., has announced that it has acquired a substantial majority of the common stock of the Laclede-Christy Company.

New indications that glaucoma -- eye ailment that is one of the principal causes of blindness -- may sometimes be caused by nerve failure were presented yesterday at the Seventeenth International Congress of Ophthalmology.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Striking workers at the United States-owned Braden (Kennecott) Copper Company's El Teniente mine agreed tonight to end a twenty-eight-day-old walkout and return to their jobs tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Until the ballots for Congress are counted throughout the nation on Nov. 2, it will not be established whether the 12 per cent slump from 1952 in the 1954 Republican vote of Maine for seats in that body means a national pro-Democratic trend of equal magnitude or a pro-Democratic trend at all.

Some early-rising sightseers in town yesterday took in one of the city's outstanding smells. They visited the Fulton Fish Market during morning working hours.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A number of what the Federation of Citizens Association here called "hardship cases" were shown in the first public school integration statistics issued here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- When President Eisenhower chose Dr. Willard Frank Libby to succeed Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth of the Atomic Energy Commission he selected "a very tough customer -- a strong-willed individual who combines this characteristic with fairness and maturity."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Former President Hoover announced today the appointment of Neil MacNeil, retired assistant night managing editor of The New York Times, as editorial director of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- An important change is taking place in the attitude of business and government leaders in northwestern Europe toward European economic integration.
The defeat in Tuesday's primary of most of the candidates backed by James A. Roe for party nominations appeared to spell the end of his Democratic leadership in Queens.

Gasoline stocks continued to decline last week, falling 218,000 barrels to 153,279,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A year ago gasoline stocks totaled 141,488,000 barrels.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century won the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy for a record fifth time today by finishing the three-day women's Tri-County open golf test at Apawamis with a 54-hole score of 245. The margin of victory was two strokes.

At various points along the line, six of the nine contestants took whacks at first place in the $15,000 added Requested Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Mrs. Philip Bieber's Bicarb took his whack at the best time -- in the last few yards. He won by a neck in the role of $13.90-for-$2 third choice.

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A sleek, ninety-two foot cabin cruiser named the Barbara Anne is being rebuilt and refurnished here, to be available for Presidential use Delivery is expected in about three weeks.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 16 -- The main address at the National People's Congress in Peiping yesterday was given by Liu Shao-chi speaking for the constituti onal committee, of which Mr. Mao is chairman.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday the election of Thomas J. Deegan Jr. as vice president-staff, with duties assigned by the president, Alfred E. Perlman, whom he will assist.
QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 15 (UP) -- The first commercial installation of Photon, a revolutionary photographic type composing machine, was announced today by the Quincy Patriot Ledger.
