FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 15 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, accused of collaborating with the Communists in Korea, broke down on the witness stand today as he told how the Reds forced him to watch thirteen fellow prisoners die of starvation and disease in a filthy cave.
CAIRO, Sept. 15 -- Leaders of Egypt and Iraq met today to exchange -- and to reconcile if possible -- their views on the defense of the Middle East, Arab unity and the future of the Arab league.

Edward P. Palmer, subway and bridge builder, bequeathed 49 per cent of his stock holdings in the engineering concern of Senior Palmer, Inc., 50 Church Street, to five associates or employes, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 15 -- The third International Congress of Internal Medicine opened today in Stockholm's Concert Hall. Four Nobel Prize-winners in medicine are among the delegates from thirty-two countries, including the Soviet Union, attending the four-day meeting.

Control of an important Times Square landmark passed out of the city yesterday. The Sheraton Corporation of America, a Delaware concern that has its main office in Boston, acquired an option to purchase the 750-room Astor Hotel for $8,500,000.

TRENTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A suspended official of the New Jersey Division of Employment Security testified today that the bureau's former director, the late Harold G. Hoffman, was "busted" after the 1946 Republican primary election and "owed a lot of money."

THE rain lay in dull puddles on the tarpaulin at the Pole Grounds yesterday and hung like a misty curtain from the uppermost rim of the stands. WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Early construction of the Cross-Westchester Expressway from the New York-Buffalo Thruway at Elmsford to the New England Thruway at Rye was asked today by the Westchester County Association.

THERE is nothing the matter with the fishing, but something has happened to the fishermen. Both charter and party boats have had few customers during the past few days, but those that went offshore returned with excellent catches.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left for Bonn and London tonight to negotiate a new plan for the rearmament of West Germany.
Cotton futures were steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices on active months were up 10 to 17 points.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight that Democratic gains in Tuesday's Maine election confirmed his feeling that "our people are tired of this unending diet of equal portions of niceness, non-sense and nastiness" served up by the Republicans.

PARIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- James Goldsmith, a central figure in a runaway romance and tragedy involving an heiress to the Patino tin fortune, reported tonight that his 4-month-old daughter had been kidnapped.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 15 -- Parliamentary supporters of the now defunct European Defense Community in the six nations that were to have formed it agreed today to group together within the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe, which is holding its fall session here.

The opening of a new school year finds city youngsters in attendance at nineteen newly completed construction projects of the Board of Education. Almost 13,000 pupils will answer the school bell at seven new buildings, while thousands of others will be in eight additions to present structures and four rehabilitated schools.

METUCHEN, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., campaigning in New Jersey today for the Republican candidates, lashed out at "Democratic prophets of doom." He made here the second of a series of campaign speeches that will take him to thirteen states.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Half of this country's hospital facilities lag behind technological and scientific advances, the president-elect of the American Hospital Association said today.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 15 -- Mary Lena Faulk, the defending titleholder, went two extra holes before she captured a fourth-round match in the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- Joint efforts by the world's scheduled airlines to iron out a wide range of problems in operations, engineering and development were reported here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Mounting complaints from politically important farm areas brought a relaxation today in one of the strictest provisions of the Federal crop-control program.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- British plans for bringing German arms into the West's defense encountered French objections today.

A decompression chamber to test and treat under-river workers who are vulnerable to the "bends," or compressed-air sickness, has been set up in Weehawken, N. J., at the construction site of the new third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

A way of producing cheap and plentiful supplies of a hitherto rare chemical that may provide clues to some types of insanity, including schizophrenia, was reported yesterday to the American Chemical Society.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- A few seconds separated Martin (Skip) Purcell of the Indian Harbor Y. C., Greenwich, from a clean sweep today as the sixth annual associate members' regatta of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound ended off the Stamford breakwater.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The Quaker Oats Company reported today that its net income in the fiscal year ended on June 30 rose to $8,902,470, or $2.38 a common share, from $8,380,297, or $2.23, in the preceding year. Sales were $266,133,116, compared with $265,264,488.

West Hartford, Conn., sold yesterday $4,455,000 of school and library bonds due from 1955 to 1974 to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.09 for obligations bearing 1.7 per cent interest. The bonds were reoffered at yields of 0.7 to 1.95 per cent.
SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Washington State's seven incumbent Congressmen, only two of whom faced opposition, swept through to the November finals in yesterday's quiet primary.
A shadow was allowed to remain on the escutcheon of two pedigreed Siamese cats yesterday when a New York judge ruled out a libel suit brought in their behalf.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The discovery that an enzyme turned loose by "strep" throat kills laboratory animals and may be the cause of rheumatic fever was announced here today at the second World Congress of cardiology.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 -- The president of the National Petroleum Association today urged the Eisenhower Administration to take a "new look" at the anti-trust laws in order to help the oil industry solve its No. 1 problem -- excessive refining capacity.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, who came to New Jersey to urge the election of Representative Charles R. Howell to the Senate, said tonight that President Eisenhower would "move more boldly" to counter Soviet aggression if the Democrats regained control of Congress.
Rain, which pursued a curious course through New York's metropolitan area yesterday, raised more than a little havoc with the National League pennant race.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, United States champion, was extended by Jack Frost before winning his third-round match in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Tom Poholsky was stingy with hits but had to work out of pinches tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-1 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Several telephone and cable manufacturers here are convinced that a new "guided" wireless wave form called HO1 will supplement, and may eventually supplant, almost all methods of telecommunication.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, a nationwide chain of department stores including Stern's in this city, showed slightly lower earnings in the three, six and twelve months ended July 31 than a year ago, despite improved sales volumes.

DENVER, Sept. 15 -- President Eisenhower announced today that he had accepted "very reluctantly" the resignation of Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission effective Sept. 30.

The world heavyweight championship fight between the titleholder, Rocky Marciano, and Ezzard Charles, a former champion, will take place tonight at the Yankee Stadium. Originally scheduled for last night, the fifteen-round bout was postponed because of inclement weather.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- A citizens' committee, eager to promote United Nations goodwill in the United States is seeking a new name.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Samuel Goldwyn announced today the signing of Vivian Blaine to repeat her stage role as Miss Adelaide in his film version of "Guys and Dolls."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 8:

Mrs. Grace Perpall, a former contract bridge champion and wife of a retired Wall Street business man and coin collector, was injured critically at 10:20 A. M. yesterday in a gas explosion in her apartment at 277 Park Avenue, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets. Mrs. Perpall, who is 55 years old, was taken to Bellevue Hospital.

In your Sept. 8 editorial entitled "Record in Construction" you say: "* * * the series of new records that have been set by the construction industry probably constitute the most bullish element in the economic picture." The context makes it clear that you refer to the Government estimates of construction that has already been put in place, as no other construction figures are quoted.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 15 -- A 21-inch color television tube offering picture quality probably a little better than any tube previously shown was demonstrated here today for the first time by the Radio Corporation of America.
The state Public Service Commission heard testimony yesterday on a dispute among bus operators that has denied bus service to 7,000 school children and college students in Brooklyn.
ALTHOUGH the play is sluggish, the performance is brisk. The play is "Dear Charles," which opened at the Morosco last evening. The performance is largely Tallulah Bankhead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- An attorney for Edward O. Lamb, a publisher and radio-television operator, called a Government witness a "hired character assassin" today and charged that the witness once offered a bribe for false testimony against Mr. Lamb.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 15 (UP) -- An Army court-martial ruled today that Cpl. Claude Batchelor's claim that he was brainwashed in a Communist prison camp in Korea was no defense against the charge that he had collaborated with his Red captors and informed on other American prisoners of war.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida refused today to appear before the Audit Committee of the Diet's Lower House to testify regarding alleged large gifts by shipping companies to members of his party and administration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Fight fans, many of them from Rocky Marciano's home town of Brockton, Mass., milled about on the railroad station platform here late today after receiving word of the twenty-four-hour postponement of the title fight between the heavyweight champion and Ezzard Charles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- A stabilized United States trade policy "would do more than anything else to establish economic security and a greater volume of trade in the free world," Russell Smith, director of foreign operations of the Bank of America, said today.

After nine days of successive advances that had brought the market near its 1954 high, stocks rebounded yesterday afternoon and closed with moderate losses. Nonferrous metals and oils were strong but aircrafts, steels and rails were lower.

By analyzing unsatisfied demand, stores can develop more sales opportunities, retail controllers were told yesterday. This can be done by studying the character of the market, Perry Meyers, president of Perry Meyers, Inc., said.
The $25,000,000 liner Independence has earned $29,000,000 in her brief life span of three and a half years and has plowed most of it right back into the national economy.

Chesapeake Industries, Inc., moved into the advertising field yesterday. The concern, which owns nine subsidiaries, each in a different industrial and business field, acquired National Transit-ads, Inc., said to be the largest car card advertising company in the country.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Jim Fridley's pinch single with the bases loaded in the ninth off Mel Parnell lifted the Baltimore Orioles to a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight for a sweep of the two-game series.

EAST PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 15 -- The Garden State Parkway's $1,750,000 bridge over the Passaic River between Clifton and this borough has reached a point where the concrete footings will be ready for a steel superstructure to be set in place in the next two weeks.

RUNNYMEDE, England, Sept. 15 -- The shaky handwriting on the cards attached to the bunches of flowers in the memorial cloister usually reads, "In proud and loving memory." This is the day when pride predominates.
Hundreds of boys who should be committed or investigated are being turned loose here because the state is failing to provide enough room in training schools, a city jurist charged yesterday.
The managers of small retail stores were told yesterday that the best way to assure good business this fall and at Christmas was to provide for adequate stocks and to promote hard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Army, whatever its detractors may say, is anything but derelict in the matter of preparedness.
A rise in cocoa futures was a major feature of trading on the commodity exchanges here yesterday. Most of the markets were slightly lower on light dealings.

This September, for the first time in a very long course of years, there will be no freshman student entering any school for the study of optometry within the State of New York. In the spring of this year and as reported by your newspaper, Columbia University formally announced that, commencing with the fall 1954 semester, the Department of Optometry will not register a freshman class.

The Port of New York Authority's plan to establish an 800-car parking area in New Jersey to encourage motorists not to drive through Lincoln Tunnel may at first glance seem to flout the laws of merchandising. Tunnel tolls are, of course, the mainstay of Port Authority revenues.
A rise in cocoa futures was a major feature of trading on the commodity exchanges here yesterday. Most of the markets were slightly lower on light dealings.

This September, for the first time in a very long course of years, there will be no freshman student entering any school for the study of optometry within the State of New York. In the spring of this year and as reported by your newspaper, Columbia University formally announced that, commencing with the fall 1954 semester, the Department of Optometry will not register a freshman class.

The Port of New York Authority's plan to establish an 800-car parking area in New Jersey to encourage motorists not to drive through Lincoln Tunnel may at first glance seem to flout the laws of merchandising. Tunnel tolls are, of course, the mainstay of Port Authority revenues.
Milgrim's showing of originals yesterday displayed the long torso line, achieved either with a high empire cut or a hip-low waistline.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 15 -- Jim Tatum has been quoted as rating his Maryland football team superior offensively to the Terrapins who were ranked as the top eleven of the nation in 1953.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 15 -- The West German Government was hopeful tonight that the impending visit of John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, to Bonn and London would precipitate a decision on the Federal Republic's right to rearm.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 15 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan reminded the radically republican Transvaal Nationalist party today that South Africa needed foreign allies. He delivered a speech calling a halt to what looked like the beginning of a runaway campaign for establishing a republic and possibly getting out of the British Commonwealth.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- A knack for neighborly fence mending between sessions appeared today to have paid off for Representative Norris Cotton of New Hampshire.

Today's new film is "Brigadoon," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical in CinemaScope, at the Radio City Music Hall. Based on the stage play, the film stars Gene Kelly, Van Johnson and Cyd Charisse. Elaine Stewart, Barry Jones and Hugh Laing head the supporting cast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) The Veterans Administration announced today the invention of an ultrasonic photographing device that detects such things as goiters, cysts and tumors, in the body's internal organs.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 3 -- Freestanding storage walls that look built into a room are among the unusual design ideas on view at the Tenth Triennale of Decorative Arts in progress here. That there is news in them is a credit to the ingenuity of the Italian designers who have created them.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Exuberant Democratic - Farmer - Labor leaders tonight hailed their apparent margin over Republicans in yesterday's Minnesota primary election as a sign of victory in November.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Stanley Mikell's Brush Burn and W. Arnold Hanger's Iceberg II captured the second runnings of the American Bred and Foreign Bred stakes today, qualifying for starting places in the United Nations Handicap on Sept. 29.
DENVER, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth's letter of resignation from the Atomic Energy Commission and of President Eisenhower's reply:
More than $62,000,000 of new public utility preferred and common stock is figuring in underwriting transactions effective today. The offerings are as follows:

" The Five Seasons," a novel by Karl Eska, the pseudonym of an Austrian writer now in America, will be published Monday by Viking Press. It is an account of the day-in-day-out existence of a provincial Communist community. The author, fleeing the Nazis in 1939, went to Poland.
A group of embalmers employed by funeral directors in the city went on strike for shorter hours yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Hogs declined again today despite the fact that receipts were less than expected. Butchers were marked down 25 to 35 cents while sows were steady to 50 cents lower.

VIENNA, Sept. 14 -- Hungary, which once led all East bloc satellites in the zeal with which she communized and mechanized according to the precepts of Stalin is now backtracking at an even greater speed. Every day brings an editorial in Szabad Nep, Budapest Communist newspaper that two years earlier would have been heresy.
DENVER, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A former adviser to former President Truman, John A. Carroll, 53 years old, will make his second bid for the United States Senate in November.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The stock markets were bright again today. Buying, though still selective, showed signs of widening and industrial share prices closed firm despite profit taking.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- A softening of business in several kinds of women's wear manufacturing in New York was reported today to the semi-annual meeting of the executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

Israel's chess players, matched in the third round of the finals with Russia's grand-masters, stood firmly yesterday against the Soviet team in the tournament for the Hamilton-Russell Trophy, according to a report from Amsterdam.

The Eisenhower Administration has issued the first revision of its budget figures for fiscal 1954-55 since the original estimates were announced in the President's Budget Message last Jan. 21. In terms of progress toward a balanced budget the new estimate is, superficially at least, less satisfactory than its predecessor of eight months ago.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- Methods of detecting cancer through a blood-test procedure, reported to aid diagnosis in nearly 90 per cent of cases, were outlined at the St. John's Hospital Postgraduate Assembly in Santa Monica today.

Summer, the meteorologists insist, will not end this year until 8:56 A. M. on Sept. 23. But men's calendars order things at a more frenetic pace than the deeper pulse of nature. The vacation season is already over and seashore cottages have been locked. Seasonal business booms and slumps alike have finished.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Ankonian 3263, a $50,000 Black Angus bull owned by the Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney Farms, may very well owe his life to an improvised oxygen tent. He was placed in the device yesterday when he was found to be suffering from pneumonia.
Charles A. Berns, chairman of the board of "21" Brands, importer and distributor of wine and spirits, spoke enthusiastically yesterday of British restaurants.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Paul Richards, new major-domo of the downtrodden Baltimore Orioles, said today the two men he was named to replace at Baltimore -- Jimmie Dykes, field manager, and Art Ehlers, general manager -- could remain in other Oriole positions.

James S. Elliott, the 29-year-old producer-director, is on his way to New Orleans to complete negotiations for the pre-Broadway premiere there on Jan. 17 of Tennessee Williams' two-play program, "27 Wagons Full of Cotton" and "Lord Byron's Love Letter."
OTTAWA, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Bureau of Statistics reduced today its estimate of Canada's 1954 wheat crop by 135,000,000 bushels, putting it at a five-year low of 377,851,000 bushels.

The first specific clues as to the magnitude of planned Soviet economic assistance to Communist China's economic development from 1953 to 1959 have been published by Planovoye Khozyaistvo, organ of the Soviet Union's State Planning Committee.
A 21-year-old secretary described yesterday in Kings County Court the fatal beating of Thomas A. Condon on a Brooklyn street on the morning of July 10.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Mao Tse-tung, leader of Communist China, called today for indivisible relations with the Soviet Union. He promised to build a "great Socialist state" drawing its lessons from "the advanced experience'' of Russia.
The transfer of the aircraft carrier Midway and sixteen destroyers from the Atlantic to the Pacific Fleet in the near future reflects, though indirectly, the crisis in East Asia.

A contract for a new type of marine propulsion plant known as a free-piston gas generator-turbine, which is to be installed in one of four Liberty ships slated for conversion, was awarded yesterday to the General Motors Corporation, Cleveland Diesel Engine Division.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Army today confirmed the reinstatement of another worker who was suspended for security investigation at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

The Expanded Metal Engineering Company has purchased an irregular plot 96 by 60 feet adjoining its property at 2-01 Fiftieth Avenue in Long Island City, Queens. The property was acquired from William Wyer as trustee of the Long Island Rail Road. The land, which has a railroad siding, will be used by the buyer for expansion purposes. The sale was negotiated by the C. Grant Keck Organization as broker.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 16 - Ed McGrath of Rockville fired a one-under-par 34, 37 -- 71 today to retain his Long Island Senior Golf Association championship with a 36-hole gross total of 148 at Seawane Harbor.
Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, predicted here last night that industry would have electrical power from atomic furnaces in five to fifteen years.
THREE one-man shows and two groups are among the metropolitan art exhibitions opening this week as the season gets under way.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 16 -- Former President Truman's health will not permit him to stump the country for the election of a Democratic House and Senate this fall.
It was a gray and gloomy day at Ebbets Field yesterday and the Dodgers' mood matched the weather as their seven-game winning streak was snapped by a 9 -- 3 Redleg victory.

A long-time controversial figure on this port's piers worked four hours yesterday morning, precipitating a form of chain reaction in which a hiring boss was discharged and 450 longshoremen were made idle all afternoon and again last night.
LINCOLN, R. I., Sept. 16 (UP) -- J. J. Nash's Dominave, the 9-to-5 choice of 11,367 Lincoln Downs' racegoers, defeated A. K. Anderson's Crown Derby in a photo-finish in the Jamestown Purse today.
Strong support for a plank in the Democratic state platform favoring the legalization of bingo was voiced yesterday by party leaders in New York City.
MONTREAL, Sept. 16 (UP)-- One of the largest collections of manuscripts dealing with Jewish history in North America had been discovered in a Montreal home, it was disclosed today.

" Adventure," the C. B. S. television educational series produced in cooperation with the American Museum of Natural History, will return for its third season on Sunday, Sept. 26, from 3:30 to 4:30 P. M. with an examination of life on the Navajo Indian Reservation.

Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" was performed for the first time this season by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, and one was impressed anew with what a subtle, rich and beautifully wrought ballet it is.
Shoppers will find a number of market basket items higher in price this week-end.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Samuel W. Anderson, Assistant United States Secretary of Commerce, said last night that high tariff forces in the United States had "taken a new lease on life."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission said yesterday that President Eisenhower had approved its conclusion that present tariffs on dried figs needed no formal review now.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The stock market wavered today under the combined influence of a warning of a possible winter fuel crisis, the decline in sterling and yesterday's setback on Wall Street. Prices fell slightly in late business after an indecisive opening.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Virginia officials appeared today to be planning a boycott of a law school celebration where Chief Justice Earl Warren will make the main address.
The role of the railroads in any war emergency must be thoroughly reappraised, in the opinion of E. G. Plowman, vice president and general traffic manager of the United States Steel Corporation.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 16 - Mary Lena Faulk moved to the semi-final round today in defense of her women's United States amateur golf championship.

According to official announcements from either Moscow or Washington, or both, Soviet scientists have exploded atomic devices on at least six separate occasions. One hydrogen device was detonated at the same time one of the atomic devices was tested.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- Newly discovered papers indicate that the defalcations of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman amounted to nearly $70,000 as early as 1931, Attorney General Grover C. Richman disclosed here today.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Anthony Eden returned to London tonight concerned over the serious differences still existing between France and Britain and the other partners in the Western alliance over the means of rearming West Germany.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The world's airlines must use a "more scientific approach" in determining seating densities on tourist class flights if the aviation industry is to profit through lower class fares, delegates to the tenth annual general meeting of the International Air Transport Association were told today.
A new English version of "The Barber of Seville" will have the first of six performances tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Malin Preview Theatre, West Forty-sixth Street.

The champion steeplechaser of the Saratoga meeting finished third, the horse that had an early twenty-length lead finished next to last, and the French-bred Carafar was the late-charging winner of the Bushwick hurdle handicap at damp, windy Aqueduct yesterday.

The two-story industrial building at 20-07 Borden Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Forty-ninth Avenue Corporation and will be used by the buyer for the manufacture of wood cabinets. The United Cooperage Corporation was the seller and the sale was negotiated by the Cross Brown Company and Richard J. Block, Inc., as co-brokers.
LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by Mr. Eden tonight:...
Wood and metal in rich color are emphasized in a new collection of lamps now on view at the Heifetz Design Gallery, 16 East Fifty-third Street.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Presidential Palace sources confirmed today reports that President Sukarno had taken a second wife, a divorcee with five children.

For visitors who like to carry home a memento with an anthropological flavor, the American Museum of Natural History is running a gift shop that sells originals and copies of native handicraft from all over the world.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Wide needless use of prepaid hospital care is pricing it out of the reach of low-income groups, the American Hospital Association was told today.

PARIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, commander of the French fortress at Dienbienphu, said today the armistice concluded in Geneva was "the only logical end to the Indochina war."

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Bob Grim went all the way for his nineteenth victory as the Yankees downed the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 2; Yogi Berra made it possible with a three-run homer in the first inning; Mickey Mantle was banished from a game for the first time, and Spike Briggs, the president of the Bengals, intimated that Fred Hutchinson would be rehired as manager.

The first performance in the Western Hemisphere of Dmitri Shostakovich's Tenth Symphony will take place at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Dmitri Mitropoulos on Thursday evening, Oct. 14, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Wheat futures firmed after a weak turn early today but other grains were generally easy on the absence of any substantial buying interest
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Devaluation of the cruzeiro, Brazil's monetary unit, appeared likely today following remarks made by Finance Minister Eugenio Gudin.

No one was making any rash statements. But, with fingers crossed, the Giants, for the first time, let off some real steam yesterday in their dressing room after their double victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
Cotton futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Changes ranged from 8 points higher to 18 points lower, with two near months showing firmness.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, praised the Eisenhower Administration today for making 1953 the "most prosperous year in the history of the United States."

Two influences now affecting furniture of contemporary design, the Italian and the Oriental, turn up against traditional backgrounds to lend spice to the recently refurbished House in Town at W. J. Sloane.

Mayor Wagner has named and assumed the chairmanship of a fourteen-member New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion. He thus sets up the machinery to substantiate a key policy plank and indicates his personal determination to see that the program moves along.

The sixth Interval Concert of the season last night in Carnegie Recital Hall presented a violin recital by Irving Becker. With Irving Owen at the piano, he played Handel's Sonata in D. Beethoven's C minor Sonata. Lehman Engel's Sonata in C and a group of short pieces. Prokofieff's Sonata for Unaccompanied Violin in D also was on the program.
The first sign of a substantial seasonal upturn in business lending by the New York banks was seen yesterday in a Federal Reserve Bank report of member bank operations for the week ended Wednesday.
Daylight, today, marks the anniversary of the Civil War's Battle of Antietam. On that memorable day a page of history waited while two great armies fought the bloody battle of Robert E.

Plans for a new apartment building in the Carnegie Hill section were disclosed yesterday with the announcement that Frederick Brown had purchased the plot 100.8 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street.
VALLEJO, Calif., Sept. 16 -The Navy announced tonight it was expanding its nuclear-powered ship program to include the West Coast.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 16 -- A spokesman for the United States State Department warned here tonight that unless the Republic of Korea cooperated whole-heartedly with the program for the long-range rehabilitation and security of Korea, American aid earmarked for the coming fiscal year would be cut.
PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- The twenty-member Exchange Club of this village protested to national officers today against a charter stipulation that only white persons might become members.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals dismissed today a move seeking release of a soldier jailed in France for having assaulted a taxi driver and stolen his cab.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The United States has 215 warships and thousands of planes standing guard in the Pacific to back up the new warning by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, against Red aggression, Administration officials said today.

Research on atomic bomb explosions at the Nevada Proving Grounds has indicated that nuclear radiation may replace surgery in the treatment of some eye conditions, the Seventh International Congress of Ophthalmology was told yesterday.

Last May Actors Equity stimulated a move to increase employment among its members by having them appear in concert readings a la "Don Juan in Hell," "John Brown's Body," etc. Appointed as supervisors of three divisions, to be assembled from a pool, were Helen Hayes, Peggy Wood and Maurice Evans.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept 16 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming said today that Army officers "many times" had offered to let him retire and avoid court-martial on charges of collaborating with the Communists in Korea.
Hope for a new way of attacking diabetes was offered here yesterday.
Cooler weather revives an interest in home baking and makes it twice as attractive as it was in hot summer.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Dean Margaret T. Corwin of the New Jersey College for Women announced today her retirement at the end of the scholastic year. She has been dean since 1934.
The B. T. Babbitt Company, which has been concentrating on radio and television to promote its household cleaning agents in the past year, will switch to newspapers in an intensive fall campaign.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16 -- A court-martial was established by royal decree today to try more than 400 officers arrested in the last month as members of a Communist espionage ring.
A commercial airliner that lumbers along at 280 miles an hour gave an emergency assist to a sound-swift jet fighter yesterday and led its lost pilot to a safe landing.

The Philip Murray Memorial Foundation, established to honor the former president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, presented $200,000 yesterday to the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

NEWARK, Sept. 16 -- The New Jersey Legalized Games of Chance Control Commission revoked today the raffles license of St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in this city. The church was declared ineligible for licenses for bingo games and raffles for one year.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 16 (UP) -- The State Senate completed action today on a proposal to let the Legislature abolish public schools, making Mississippi the fourth Southern state to take positive steps toward evasion of the ruling against segregated classrooms.
OTTAWA, Sept. 16 -- A bitter dispute between the Roman Catholic Church and the United Church of Canada, this country's two largest religious denominations, was considered to be in the making today.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan refused yesterday to dismiss the perjury indictment against Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States.

The 1954-55 maintenance campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will be headed by Gustave L. Levy, a partner in the investment banking firm of Goldman Sachs Co. The thirty-eighth annual federation appeal for the benefit of 116 hospitals and health and social services agencies will begin Oct. 14 at a special gifts dinner at the Plaza Hotel.
A long, uncertain afternoon on the baseball front wound up yesterday with the Giants fastening a virtual stranglehold on first place in the National League pennant race.

Directors of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company approved a plan yesterday to split the stock two for one, J. French Robinson, president, announced. A special meeting of stockholders on Dec. 2 has been called to vote on increasing the authorized capital stock to provide for the split.
The election of Henry M. Tiedemann as an assistant vice president of Grace Line Inc., by the board of directors was announced here yesterday by C. C. Mallory, president.
A veteran of thirty years in Customs Service, Anthony Simonetti, was sworn in yesterday as deputy appraiser of merchandise.
A luncheon meeting of the Twenty-third Street Association, Inc., will be held Wednesday at the Masonic Club, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

This year's Mayfair Assembly, a subscription dance for debutantes, post-debutantes and their escorts, will be held on Dec. 17 in the St. Regis Roof. The event, of which Mrs. James H. M. Ewart and Mrs. Duncan van Norden are co-chairmen, is under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 16 -- Two municipal officials denied today that they ever had issued orders for bills of patients at the Jersey City Medical Center to be written off or abated.

" THE Royal Family" was a big hit when it opened on Broadway in 1927, but the comedy play lost some of its original impact in a television version last Wednesday from 10 to 11 P. M. It served as the premiere of a monthly color series being presented by C. B. S.-TV under the general title, "The Best of Broadway."
A new state aid formula that would give New York City a substantially greater proportion of school funds was proposed yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- A group of New England electric companies has agreed to form a corporation for generating atomic energy. The companies represent about 90 per cent of the electric output of the region.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Senator Irving M. Ives hinted strongly today that he would support two Republicans from the metropolitan area for open positions on his party's 1954 state ticket. Following a luncheon with Republican leaders here, the Senator expressed high praise for Representative Jacob K. Javits of Manhattan and Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach as potential running-mates this fall.
ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Robert Shreve, Forsgate and Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol tied for the New Jersey Senior Golf Association championship today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Proudly coupling a collection of original boutique designs made in Europe exclusively for it, with its usual extensive presentation of import designs and line-for-line copies, Gimbels has re-captured the highlights of the couture openings in France, England and Italy.

Heavy cuts in Brooklyn bus service to save $3,500,000 yearly were approved yesterday by a 4-to-1 vote of the Transit Authority. Under the plan sent to the Board of Estimate which may order a public hearing because the curtailment of some lines is involved, two lines will be eliminated, four will be shortened and five will not operate at night or over week-ends.
New rugs, bedspreads and bed linens were displayed yesterday by Simon Manges Son, 575 Madison Avenue. All are available through decorators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Twelve persons already have been summoned before Federal grand juries in Washington and in Camden, N. J., in a drive to mop up Soviet spy networks, old and new.
PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Anthony Eden's rapid trip around Europe in the interests of West Germany's rearming came to an inconclusive end today.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 17 -- Another atomic weapon has been exploded in the Soviet Union and experiments apparently have been conducted in defense against atomic attack.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- The Millarden Farms' palomino gelding, Injun Joe, from Annville, Pa., ridden by Pat Dixon, took the first division of the William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy competition as the forty-ninth annual Piping Rock horse show opened today.

A collection of Albert Einstein's popular writings, assembled under the scientist's supervision, will be published next Friday by Crown. Its title will be "Ideas and Opinions." The volume contains articles, letters and statements on many subjects, including some pieces not heretofore published.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Prof. Henry D. Smyth said today that the United States must continue to stockpile atomic bombs and hydrogen bombs for some time, but that more and more atomic tools could eventually be put to peace-time use.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Fifty teams participated at Fenway today in the Nick Conte memorial pro-amateur tournament, arranged by the Westchester Professional Golfers Association as a tribute to Fenway's late assistant pro.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 16 -- The executive Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers, A. F. L., which has 438,000 members, today made three changes in the union's retirement fund system.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Federal farm price support operations in the last fiscal year lost a record $419,477,074, the Agriculture Department said today.
A sentence of forty years to life in prison was imposed yesterday on William Howell, accomplice in the slaying of Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader.
NORFOLK, Neb., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Ezra Taft Benson said today that Adlai E. Stevenson had "torpedoed" the Democratic campaign strategy to get the farm vote in this year's elections.
A group of investors headed by Morris Nussbaum has purchased three apartment buildings in the Bronx from Charles Afromawitz and Elmer Litvin.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 16 -- Like Biggie Munn. at Michigan State, George Munger has given up the football coaching portfolio at Pennsylvania for the security and relaxation of administrative work in physicial education. From Michigan State to take Munger's place has come Steve Sebo, former backfield assistant to Munn.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 16 -- A bitter debate in the Bundestag today brought the parties that support the Government of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to the point of severe strain over the case of Dr. Otto John, the West German intelligence chief who fled to East Germany two months ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -The State Department was told today that the recent increase in tariffs on watch movements had resulted in a 25 percent slump in the watch business in the United States and a "Don't Buy American" campaign in Switzerland.
WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Raytheon Manufacturing Company today reported net profit of $1,102,000 on sales of $44,698,000 for the quarter ended on Aug. 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $368,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The May Department Stores Company and its subsidiaries, which operate a chain of stores and branches, showed a drop in sales and earnings in the six and twelve months periods ended on last July 31. The company explained that the declines were "due primarily to the general decline in business activity throughout most of the country this year."
Securities authorities struck twice yesterday to enforce regulations governing trading in stocks.
Tweeds and two-piece ensembles were emphasized in the collection of American fashions shown yesterday by Martin's in Brooklyn.

ONE of the best familiarization courses for the shooter with a new big game rifle will be available for another few weeks on the outlying slopes and pastures, where the woodchucks will be feeding in preparation for their winter nap.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 16 -- Twelve trucking companies operating out of St. Paul, Des Moines, Kansas City and other Midwest points have organized a pooled trailer service which they believe will reduce costs and lead to important changes in the industry.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 -- Arthur G. McKee Co., Cleveland engineering and construction concern has received a contract to build a $19,000,000 taconite processing installation at the Reserve Mining Company's new E. W. Davis Works at Silver Bay, Minn., sixty-five miles northeast of Duluth.

A day of small volume and declining prices in stock trading ended with a minor rally in the closing hour yesterday. Aircrafts, chemicals, oils and steels all improved enough to place the day on the plus side of the ledger, despite a small loss for rails.
Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield predicted yesterday the election of Senator Irving M. Ives as Governor Of New York, and a Republican-controlled Congress at the November elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced today he would turn down virtually all requests for speaking engagements in behalf of Republican candidates and instead devote his time to a renewal of his investigative activities.

Cocoa rose the cent-a-pound limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The increase reflected general commission house buying, short covering and trade hedge-lifting. The September option, which has no limit, closed at 48.15 cents a pound, up 120 points.

SAIGON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Vietnam's three most powerful religious sects denounced both sides today in the squabble between Premier Ngo Ninh Diem and his Army Chief of Staff. They called for a new Government.
TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- A State Air Pollution Control Commission will be established in New Jersey as the result of a bill signed this morning by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

The European situation -- meaning the problem of defense, German rearmament and German sovereignty -- is singularly confused at the moment. There are a lot of actors talking on and off the stage. We will have to wait a few days until the atmosphere clears.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Paramount, casting about for an actor to portray the Governor of Texas in "Lucy Gallant," had the bright notion of offering the role to Allan Shivers, who last month was renominated to run for Governor by an overwhelming vote.

THE Post Office Department operates on the admirable theory that "neither snow nor rain nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds." Baseball never has functioned along those lines -- except maybe in Brooklyn. A fellow couldn't be sure but this may be further proof of the notion that Brooklyn is out of this world.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- An airborne mystery alarmed citizens of two Michigan cities tonight and then turned out apparently to have been caused by an Air Force bomber plane in momentary trouble.

Those who are still looking hopefully for the emergence of the Chinese Tito can have small comfort from the remarks of Mao Tse-tung at the opening session of the first "National Peoples' Congress" in Peiping. Chairman Mao made it plain that he regarded the tie of Red China to the Soviet Union as the cornerstone of all Chinese building.
The tax advantage of acquiring certain local government notes returning little or no interest was evidenced again yesterday in a $10,000,000 borrowing by the New York City Housing Authority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Joseph Harkavy of New York today told a session of the second World Congress of Cardiology that tobacco was the "most important" irritant causing allergic heart disease.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A State Department spokesman said today that Secretary of State Dulles did not intend to snub France when he decided not to stop in Paris on his current European trip.

CHICAGO. Sept. 16 (AP) -- Buyers bid aggressively for 6.500 salable hogs put on sale today and both butchers and sows gained 25 to 50 cents. Top was up 50 cents at $20.50. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The National Foreign Trade Council came out strongly yesterday against quotas as being worse than tariffs in the restriction of trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 601,525 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 86,967 cars or 12.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 109,029 cars or 15.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 279,766 cars or 31.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced in Houston, Tex., yesterday that it had completed acquisition of the properties of its former wholly owned subsidiary, the Northeastern Gas Transmission Company.

Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, made public yesterday the following letter to Max Greenberg, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O.:

PARIS, Sept. 16 (AP)-- Following is the text of the communique issued today at the conclusion of the meetings here between Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary and Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier.

Professor Gerald's letter of Sept. 4 describes, without exaggeration, an experience which many, only too regretfully, can recall. A sense of courtesy, in this my adopted country, kept me from writing a similar letter years ago, pointing out the unbelievably bad reception meted out to arrivals in the Port of New York.
Thomas Wysokowski denied yesterday that he had deliberately killed Thomas A. Condon, 40-year-old business man, on a Brooklyn street early on the morning of July 10.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 16 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer reached agreement tonight on the broad outlines for a solution to the problem of West German rearmament and membership in a Western alliance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -(AP) -- The Marine Corps showed off the newest thing in extra power for its helicopters today -- one pound rocket engines hidden in the tips of the rotor blades.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 16 -- The first effort to merge small European national economies into a larger and better-functioning unit is just ten years old this month.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls, Spartanburg, S. C., took a two-stroke lead at the end of the first round of play in the $5,000 Wichita women's open today with a three-over-par 74.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- The battered but rugged scallop dragger, Monte Carlo, converted into a floating research laboratory, reached Boston today with new information on the North Magnetic Pole.
Reflecting greater operating revenues, net income of the Connecticut Light and Power Company in the twelve months ended Aug. 31 increased to $8,899,048 from $7,321,393 earned in the preceding year.

Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., hopes to defend the heavyweight championship of the world tonight against Ezzard Charles, challenger from Cincinnati. Originally scheduled to fight on Wednesday night, and then last night, the warriors had to endure two postponements because of inclement weather.

The Validation Board for German Dollar Bonds has established the whereabouts of about $193,000,000 of an estimated total of $200,000,000 to $350,000,000 of pre-war German dollar bonds supposedly unredeemed.

Russia and Yugoslavia were still bracketed for first place in the tournament for the Hamilton-Russell chess trophy after both had triumphed by scores of 3 -- 1 in fourth-round matches, according to a report from Amsterdam yesterday.
Your editorial of Sept. 11 on "Guatemala Without Arbenz" contains some highly interesting comments on the situation in that country.

ROME, Sept. 16 -- The Vatican cancelled today the most onerous of Pope Pius' audiences during the next few days because his strength has been failing recently. The Pope's condition is attributed chiefly to overwork and his physicians therefore consider it imperative for him to spare himself as much as possible.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 16 (UP) -- A hitherto secret' document disclosed today that the Chinese Communists had planned to set up an underground organization of former American war prisoners in the United States and had picked Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor as its first leader.

On Sept. 2 The New York Times printed a report of a survey made by Jack Granofsky. The report covered two and a half years in time and 263 women in number. Mr. Granofsky wrote his thesis and the public was told his conclusion: that most able-bodied women shun the disabled.

YONKERS, Sept. 16 -- Adding 38, 36 -- 74 today at Hudson River to his opening-day 75, Tom Robbins of Winged Foot won the Westchester Senior Golf Association championship for the seventh consecutive year.
The licenses of six "wreck-chasing" tow-car owners have been permanently revoked, the police announced yesterday.

Still another Congressional investigation is now under way -- one which will bear careful watching, if for no other reason than that the public knows so little about it. Also, what is known thus far raises doubts about its usefulness and competence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A Government witness testified today that Edward Lamb, publisher and radio-television operator, had been introduced as "Comrade Lamb" at the dedication of a Communist party headquarters ten years ago.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 16 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon warned tonight of the danger of a return to "discredited Trumanism."
Line-for-line copies of European fashions, along with the originals, were shown by Macy's yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. These fashions will be available at the store on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Five million children will start learning to read this month, but for many the first "lessons" will involve no books. How trips, stories and classroom "fun" help prepare school beginners for reading is described in a pamphlet for parents just released by the National Education Association.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner told garage owners in the state today some of the requirements they would have to meet to take part in the compulsory automobile inspection program that takes effect next year.

Indications that the Watkins committee will have its report on Senator McCarthy ready by the end of the month fortify the impression already formed throughout the country that this is a Senatorial investigation conducted with seriousness of purpose, efficiency and dispatch.
TOKYO, Sept. 16. -- Japanese opposition parties criticized Premier Shigeru Yoshida today for his refusal to appear before the Diet's Audit Committee investigating charges of shipping scandals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Christian Churches, accused the World Council of Churches tonight of "deliberately" putting Iron Curtain clergymen on its governing committee.

AUGUST LIND is a mild little gentleman with a smoldering passion for New York. He stopped by the other day to explain what he'd been doing since the World's Fair closed in 1940. He recalled, in passing that he had gone to the fair a total of 366 days in 1939 and 1940.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 16 -- Property here of the Pequot Mills, whose sheeting operations were moved last year to South Carolina, is to be converted into a shopping and industrial center.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Experts of the United Nations Technical Assistance Program are penetrating the heights of South America's Andean chain. Their project is the rehabilitation of a race.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The home remodeling and repair racket in Chicago "stinks," Senator Homer E. Capehart asserted today.

In all their eight years of presenting imported designs along with considerably less expensive line-for-line copies, Ohrbach's has never equaled yesterday's collection for its superb taste in selection and the quality of workmanship in the copies.
Parade, Sunday Magazine supplement, floor in 285 Madison Ave through Cross Brown Co -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Gov. Dewey's Committee for Economic Progress said today it looked as if 1954 would be the "second biggest, year" in the state's history, in terms of employment and business volume.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16 -- Hopes for a settlement today of a strike that is paralyzing Chile's copper mining industry did not work out. Labor, on the one hand, and the Government and employers, on the other, were standing firm on their respective positions tonight.
Earl Bunting has resigned as managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers, effective Dec. 31.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- One of the season's biggest surprises took place at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Royal Pastime, a 43-to-1 shot, owned by William A. Rorech, whose home is only a hop, skip and jump from the track, roared down the middle of the stretch to capture the ninth edition of the $25,000 American Trotting Championship.
Arthur Peter Hansen went through an experience yesterday that should make him a supporter of formal celebrations.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said today he is "extremely optimistic" about business conditions for the rest of 1954 and beyond.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 16 -- President Eisenhower went trout fishing today but didn't catch anything much.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, First Department, raised the question yesterday whether the right to jury trials should be abolished or at least modified in personal injury cases.
A scandal-tainted Congress of industrial Organizations union complied swiftly yesterday with in order from Walter P. Reuther to clean house or be kicked out.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 16 -- An exchange of gunfire took place yesterday between Chinese Communist and Nationalist batteries on two small islands north of the Nationalist-held Tachen Islands off the Chekiang coast, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 5 per cent below those of the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The American designer Mainbocher has lowered the waistline. While this may sound as if he had been influenced by the trend that is sweeping over both sides of the Atlantic it is not the case. He has retained that stamp of individuality that is so strongly his.

Internal dissension has arisen in Vietnam at the worst possible time. The civilian government, embodied in the Premier, is in a head-on clash with the military group and an uneasy compromise has been reached. Several religious groups have said, "A plague on both your houses," and are demanding a completely new government.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- An American in Moscow need not feel lonely for lack of news from home. He can pick up Pravda or Izvestia any morning and find a generous selection of quotations from his favorite New York, Washington and Chicago newspaper or leading national magazines.

A sharp clash, tinged with bitterness, developed yesterday between Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Carmine G. DeSapio, one of Averell Harriman's principal supporters for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
BROOKHAVEN, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Robert P. Schur, County Attorney of Suffolk, was killed in an automobile accident at 11:30 o'clock, tonight in Mastic, L. I.
The following is a round-up of cleaning products that may be of help to the homemaker:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 17 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies pressed a button today and a bulldozer threw ore down a chute at the Atomic Energy Commission's A 2,000,000 plant at Rum Jungle in Northern Territory, thirty miles south of Darwin, and Australia's first crushing of uranium ore had begun.
American Cancer Society Inc, two floors for national headquarters in 521 W 57th St -- Cushman Wakefield Inc and James D. Landauer Associates Inc, brokers.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- A challenge to young chemists to match and surpass the achievements of the last twenty-five years in the fields of organic and inorganic chemistry was issued today by Hugh Stott Taylor, dean of the Princeton University Graduate College.

HILLSBORO, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Teaching in Hillsboro's three public elementary schools proceeded quietly today -- with eighteen Negro children mixed with 800 whites in two schools, and about fifty Negroes and no whites in the third school.

ATHENS, Sept. 17 -- Brigadier Evangelos Evart, Chief of Police for Athens and all metropolitan police forces in Greece, resigned today. He had been advised by Gen. Vasilis Vrachnos, Under Secretary of Interior, to resign for reasons connected with the Cyprus issue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Cowboy actors Gene Autry and Roy Rogers have laid aside their smoking six-shooters to protest to the law about what television is doing to their old movies.
New York and New Jersey trucking companies made contract proposals on all issues except wages during negotiations yesterday with twelve locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Communism, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the martial spirit of Southerners got tangled up today in a Congressional inquiry into military education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Willie Troy, with the hope of a middleweight title bout, technically knocked out Walter Cartier of New York tonight in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round television bout.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The American Memorial Library, a gleaming concrete and glass building believed to be the largest public library in Europe and the most modern in the world, was opened here today by the Mayor of West Berlin, Dr. Walther Schreiber.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The uncertain mood of the stock market during the past few days became one of weakness today. Selling increased and prices of industrial shares fell steadily, though some issues partly recovered toward the close.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- A wholly new Federal law regulating wages, hours and labor relations in the building industry was urged here today by the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor.

AT this stage of the art season, group shows outnumber one-man appearances but, none the less, at the Artists Gallery, George Griffin, a young New York artist who has studied at the Art Students League, is making a solo debut.
A detective who was photographed, while off duty, holding an umbrella over Rocky Marciano has been knocked out of one of the choicest detective assignments in the city.
Two key officials of the American Federation of Labor pier union resigned in anger yesterday and urged their followers to go back to the old International Longshoremen's Association.
A 50-year-old high school official was beaten on the face and head yesterday afternoon by five teen-age boys after he had broken up a fight in which they were assaulting another youth.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Three Milwaukee relief pitchers checked the St. Louis Cardinals with just three hits in the last six innings tonight as the Braves gained a 6-4 victory and cut the Dodgers' second-place edge to two games in the National League race.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Scows from Wisconsin proved a point in the "one-of-a-kind" race that the Riverside Yacht Club conducted today. They flew away from one-design classes better known in the East in a contest in which no two boats were alike among twenty-seven that took part.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 17 -- Partisans of Continental integration through a supranational authority stuck to their guns today at the opening debate by the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe on a substitute for the European Defense Community.

Ezzard Charles wasn't bothered by his weight -- the 192 1/2 pounds was the most he had ever carried into a ring. He was in superb shape, he was strong and felt fine. The whole trouble was with his eyes. He didn't see the punch that put him down in the second round; he didn't see any of the punches that finished him in the eighth.
In the obituary of Admiral Edward C. Kalbfus, United States Navy, Retired, appearing in your columns on Sept. 7, the following statement appears:
As one who for years has warned that E. D. C. was bound to fail I ask to be permitted to point out some of the overlooked but frightening aspects of this failure on the American domestic scene.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent to 110, based on a 1947-49 average of 100, in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices of processed foods were responsible for the advance. Average prices of farm products and industrial materials remained unchanged.
The earnings of the Universal Pictures Company and its subsidiaries for the thirty-nine weeks ended on July 31 exceeded those reported for all of the last fiscal year.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Mississippi Southern humbled the once-mighty Crimson Tide of Alabama again tonight with a 7-2 victory and the second opening-game upset in two years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- More than 250,000 refugees have moved from Communist - controlled North Vietnam to South Vietnam, Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, said today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Exchange was irregular yesterday on moderate activity. Price changes ranged from a rise of 6 points to a decline of the same extent.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 -- This city of more than a million, located below the Mason-Dixon line and hence in one-time slave territory, appears to have accepted desegregation in the public schools with no difficulties.

The $29,550 Discovery Handicap, postponed last Saturday because of the big blow, had its tenth running at Aqueduct yesterday. The winner was the Foxcatcher Farms' 13-to-1 Chevation, who scored after six straight reverses.
Those giant plumes of black smoke that issue almost daily from the Transit Authority's powerhouse on West Fifty-ninth Street will be part of New York's "scenery" for several years.

The 167th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution was marked yesterday at a ceremony arranged by the New York chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution on the steps of Federal Hall at Wall and Nassau Streets.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 17 -- The Chinese Nationalists have warned persons living along the southeast China coast to move from military targets. They did this in a broadcast declaring their reprisal attacks against the Communists would be continued, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The State Department announced today that a high-ranking United States delegation would attend the sixth conference of the Colombo Plan Governments opening Monday in Ottawa.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -- Chilean authorities informed the Braden Copper Company tonight that workers at its El Teniente mine had agreed to resume work Monday, pending arbitration of their demands.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Reports of frosts in northern parts of the Canadian prairie provinces, with a forecast of more tonight, gave wheat a stronger tone today, supported by considerable short profit-taking at the week's end.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 17 -- After its three most glorious years of success since Fritz Crisler's masterpiece of 1933-1935, Princeton's football fortunes took a sharp drop last fail

Mayor Wagner has followed a sensible course in converting the thirteen "hydrant inspector" jobs from political plums into Civil Service positions. The change will take place at the end of this year. During the summer New Yorkers learned, to their combined amusement and dismay, that the work of inspecting hydrants required very little effort, was doled out to a favored few friends of politicians and frequently yielded high income.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- The Piping Rock Horse Show ball, peak of the three-day sports classic on the club show grounds, took place this evening in the ballroom. About 500 members and their guests attended the dinner in advance of dancing.
DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 17 -- A National Labor Relations Board member today denounced charges that the present board "is prejudiced in favor of management."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- The Government is trying to collect $240,326 in 1947 corporate taxes from Louis E. Wolfson and two associates in the Tampa Shipbuilding Company, Inc., it was disclosed today.
Canada's Province of Quebec is rapidly becoming an industrial giant as well as a vacation delight.

The five-story apartment building containing thirty-seven suites at 1 Gruman Avenue in Newark. N. J., has been sold by the Gruman Realty Corporation to the One Gruman Corporatin, represented by Julius Feinerg, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Ic., was the broker and Irving Mandelbaum was attorney for th seller.

On my return this week from a visit to Europe I learned that a letter signed by Girolamo Valenti had appeared in your issue of Aug. 11 highly critical of my interview in London with a New York Times reporter (New York Times, Aug. 7). I had expressed concern regarding the growth of communism in Italy and its infiltration into the Italian armed forces.
Advances on several fronts of surgical and medical treatment of eye ailments were reported yesterday at the closing session of the Seventeenth International Congress of Ophthalmology.
Fifteen witnesses testified before the Temporary Commission on the Courts yesterday in favor of some form of central administrative office for the courts in New York State.

In the communiques issued in Bonn and London yesterday after Secretary Dulles' talks one phrase was repeated, and it is pregnant with meaning -- "full equality." If Germany is to get full equality, meaning full sovereignty and no discrimination in the process of rearmament and arms manufacture, we are, indeed, at the beginning of a new era.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period of Aug. 1-Aug. 28 averaged 33,372 bales for each working days.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Juan Terry Trippe, president and founder of Pan American World Airways, was named by acclamation today as president-elect of the International Air Transport Assocation.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 17 -- Dr. Ronald Richter, former chief of Argentina's atomic energy project, was arrested early today to serve a five-day term for contempt of Congress.

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Alfred A. Valdmanis, Latvian-born financial expert who pleaded guilty to having swindled the Newfoundland Government out of $200,000, was sentenced today to four years at hard labor.

Those interested in good food and cooking may have been wondering what will be served at that important dinner on Oct. 30 that will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in connection with the bicentennial celebration of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- The Labor Department reported today a further drop in the number of persons filing claims for state unemployment insurance.

Harry Belafonte, who won many followers on Broadway last season for his singing in "John Murray Anderson's Almanac," has been engaged for a starring part in Paul Gregory's first musical offering, "Three for Tonight."

ROME, Sept. 17 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano confirmed today that the Pope was not well. An article in the paper said "His Holiness has not yet completely recovered" from the illness he suffered early this year.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- Governor Dewey will put Senator Irving M. Ives' name in nomination as the Republican candidate to succeed him when the party's state convention meets in Syracuse next week.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17 -- Former President Truman exhorted fellow Democrats today to give President Eisenhower a Democratic Congress in the hope "we can save him from the misdeeds of his own party."
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Raymond Burr of Millbrook, N. Y. scored 13 points with his chestnut mare Reno Gold to win the green working hunter championship at the Piping Rock Horse show today.
Tenants of a Brooklyn housing development filed suit yesterday in Federal Court for reductions in rents and the return to the Federal Housing Administration of $4,000,000 in windfall profits.

NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Sixty veterans of the United States Eighty-second Airborne Division were honored guests here today as this Dutch city unveiled its Liberation Monument. Nijmegen paid homage to the American troops who dropped from the skies ten years ago to set it free.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Eight Arab states charged here today that Israel was endangering the peace of the Middle East and threatening to disrupt good relations between their countries and the West.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The association of West Germany in the Atlantic community on the basis of full military and political equality was agreed on today as a policy by the United States and Britain.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, a relentless tribe, clinched at least a tie for the American League pennant tonight by whipping the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 3, on Bobby Avila's grand slam homer in the seventh inning.

The Samstu Realty Corporation sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 782 West End Avenue, corner of Ninety-eighth Street, to Lawrence M. Lyons, operator, who immediately resold his contract to a syndicate of investors. The terms were cash over two mortgages amounting to $289,000. The Brener Lewis Company was the broker in the first sale and Louis L. Rogers in the resale.
VALDOSTA, Ga., Sept. 17 (AP) -- An Air Force B-25 bomber crashed near the Moody Base last night killing two officers assigned to that South Georgia training center.

NEWARK, Del., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Kenny No, the former Communist pilot who flew a MIG-15 jet fighter from behind Korea's Iron Curtain a year ago -- and collected a $100,000 reward -- enrolled this week as a freshman at the University of Delaware.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 17 (UP) -- Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor testified today that he once had heard an Army witness against him sing a song about how the Americans were sabotaging the Korean war peace talks at Panmunjom.
The Giants' dash to the National League pennant was reduced to half speed at the Polo Grounds last night

There descended upon New York yesterday, like a flock of bluebirds, the thirty girls and six boys of the Obernkirchen Children's Choir, here from Germany to make a series of appearances, including a debut at Town Hall Thursday evening.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 17 -- In his struggle with opposition power groups and personalities, Ngo Dinh Diem, 53-year-old bachelor Premier of Vietnam, appeared today to have strengthened his position.

A second thirteen-week series of lectures by world authorities, under the continuing title of "Man's Right to Knowledge," will begin over C. B. S. radio on Sunday, Oct. 3, from 1 to 1:30 P. M. The series will be subtitled "Present Knowledge and Future Directions," and, like the first, will be broadcast in observance of the Columbia University Bicentennial.

SAUGUS, Mass., Sept. 17 -- An authentic reproduction of the Saugus Iron Works, which flourished here 300 years ago, was formally dedicated today as a "shrine to private initiative and enterprise." Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of the executive committee of the Inland Steel Company, said that the industry had been fortunate to "rediscover and rebuild what was clearly its place of origin in this new country."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today directed truckers handling mixed freight in truckloads within the East or between the East and the Midwest to raise their hauling charges by 16 to 33 cents a hundred pounds, so as to match railroad rates.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 17 -- At the closing session of its sixth world congress today, the International Society for the Welfare of Cripples elected Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York its president for the next three years.
The new Robert P Patterson Army Reserve Training Center on the New York University campus in the Bronx was dedicated yesterday.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Two young Californians gained the final of the women's United States amateur golf championship in unusual fashion today.

Stock prices rose sharply yesterday in the liveliest trading this month. The market favorites were the industrials, and at one time during the day The New York Times price index of twenty-five such issues pushed ahead to its best level since Oct. 25, 1929.
The Board of Education is confronted with the problem of what to do with teachers who say they left the Communist party in good faith but who will not identify others who were in the party with them.

John Golden, the veteran showman, has contributed $1,000 for essays of not more than 250 words on "Why the United States Needs the United Nations." The producer has accepted for the fifth consecutive year the chairmanship of the New York City celebration of United Nations Day, Oct. 24.

Gross revenues of the El Paso Natural Gas Company (Delaware) and its subsidiaries rose to $130,885,061 in the twelve months ended July 31 from $94,312,399 in the prior year. Earnings, however, were under those of a year ago, according to the figures issued yesterday.

Driving a car requires the use of muscles, eyes and intelligence. It also requires, to a greater degree than many of us may realize, the use of the ears. It is obvious, of course, that we must listen for horns and other warning signals while driving. But there are softer, less insistent sounds that we hear absently, automatically, that make up a large part of good driving technique.

After four rounds of the chess tournament for the Hamilton-Russell Trophy in Amsterdam, the competitors took yesterday off, with Russia's champion team tied at 12 points with Yugoslavia, followed by Argentina with 10 points.

The securities underwriting community is bracing for some of the heaviest financing of the year. In the field of corporate securities, in the Investment Dealers Digest reports there is a backlog of $774,434,000 of new issues of bonds and preferred stock for which marketing dates have been set. Nearly $350,000,000 of the total is slated to reach the market next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Department of Justice is taking a very close look at the pending merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation with the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Corporation.

VALLEJO, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Soviet Russia, with "seven times as many" submarines as Germany had at the beginning of World War II, was pictured today as working hard at adapting nuclear energy to neutralize United States control of the seas.

The four-story apartment house accommodating eight families at 341 St. Johns Place in Brooklyn has been sold by John B. Johnson to John J.
