Here are some Richard Strauss scores, for example, that bear as liner descriptions the flaming banner: RICHARD STRAUSS IN HIGH FIDELITY, which sounds like the name of a musical comedy, or a title in the Bobbsey Twins series.
ORIENT, L. I., Sept. 18 -- To get into one of the country's most strictly guarded research centers a visitor must meet more mundane requirements than the signing of a non-Communist oath.

IN his recent fiction H. E. Bates, one of England's most prolific novelists, has been alternating between the sublime and the sordid, between magnificent evocations of nature and terrifying descriptions of murder. Some of his novels, like "The Cruise of the Breadwinner," have dealt with British courage under the stress of war.
HARTFORD, Sept. 18 -- Can the courts intervene in the decisions of a political convention? Can the courts overthrow the choice of a nominating convention and substitute a nominee?
Leaders of the dying American Federation of Labor pier union will have a hard time getting back into the old International Longshoremen's Association, it appeared yesterday.

THIS is the final week of the New York City Ballet's first four-week season at the City Center. It will return for another such season early in November, when it will devote itself exclusively to "The Nutcracker," and will settle down for a long session of repertory some time in January.

WITH the publication last year of Joseph Leeming's "Riddles, Riddles, Riddles" and Lillian Morrison's "Black Within and Red Without" it seemed as if American children wouldn't need another riddle book for a long, long time.

EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- More than sixty veterans of the United States 101st Airborne Division attended here today anniversary celebrations marking the liberation of Eindhoven ten years ago.
TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- A Diet committee voted today to bring contempt charges against Premier Shigeru Yoshida. He had refused to appear and testify in an investigation of alleged shipping scandals.

WHEN the Old Vic production billed as "A Midsummer Night's Dream" erupts on Broadway on Tuesday night, playgoers will be thoroughly drenched in the Arts. For this latest version of "The Dream," as the comedy is cozily known to the theatre's cognoscenti, combines the Shakespeare text with an hour-long Mendelssohn score and a full-fledged ballet to boot.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 18 -- At his vacation retreat near this Rocky Mountain village President Eisenhower has begun work on another series of speeches he will deliver next week.

DURING the past dozen years Phyllis McGinley has earned for herself an increasingly wide and popular reputation as a writer of light verse; but this designation isn't good enough. Ogden Nash, to name just one other, is that too. But Miss McOinley's work goes further, and far deeper.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- Congratulatory telegrams from Casey Stengel and the Yankees to Al Lopez and the Cleveland Indians had long since been dispatched when the New Yorkers did a bit of clinching of their own tonight at Connie Mack Stadium.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, warned today that creation of a West German national army could throw Germany entirely into the Soviet orbit.

A new record was set last month in shipments of rayon staple fiber, according to the Textile Economic Bureau, Inc., statistical reporting agency for the man-made fibers industry. Shipments in August totaled 29,800,000 pounds, a gain of 11 per cent over July and 4 per cent higher than the previous record in June of this year.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Belgium and Switzerland signed an atomic exchange agreement today, twelve days after President Eisenhower announced the United States would help Belgium build an atomic reactor.

CONCORD, N. H. -- The sight and sound of falling leaves is never taken lightly in New Hampshire. This year, as in the past eighteen years, forty - five "leaf watchers" throughout the state will make the whole thing official by reporting to the Development Commission when the leaves have begun to turn in their areas.

The driver of a city bus and the proprietor of a cleaning shop sat across the desk from a referee in New York's massive Criminal Courts Building a few nights ago. The bus driver was suing for $75 for the loss of a pair of trousers.

IT is my suspicion that when a writer finds himself misunderstood, when those who take issue with him hand back his ideas in distorted form, the chances are at least even that he has not made himself sufficiently clear.

DURING the last sun-bright days before frost, fragrance-conscious gardeners as well as uninitiates should make a point of visiting a friend who grows herbs. The chances are that any real devotee will be willing to share some of the perennial herbs and will gladly give generously of all the now expendable annuals which are soon to be killed by cold unless taken up and moved indoors.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner teamed with Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn, the East's top-ranking tennis player, to win a one-set exhibition doubles match during the twelfth annual Perth Amboy invitation tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Regardless of what happens in the November elections, there will be at least twenty-five new faces in Congress when it meets again next January.

SOMEONE has said of Casanova's Memoirs that it is a wonderful book about life with the accent on love and sex. M. F. K. Fisher's "The Art of Eating" is a wonderful book about life with the accent on food and cooking.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Corky Valentine, a rookie, helped the Cincinnati Redlegs solidify their hold on fourth place today when he pitched them to a 5-1 victory over the Cubs for his twelfth triumph of the campaign.

MR. KOALA BEAR who is elderly, comfortable, kind and fat and lires alone with an amiable cat is the victim of an honest mistake in this blithe picture book. Two hungry little koalas claiming the favored status of nephews come to visit in his gum tree penthouse for a week's stay.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The dispute over the rearmament of West Germany will overshadow the opening of the 1954 session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Congress is being urged by one of its staff committees to take a long and serious look at the growing importance of the General Assembly in the affairs of the United Nations.

IT has become a tribal custom to seize on round numbers as times for celebration. On Oct. 10 the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will begin its twenty-fifth season of broadcasting its Sunday afternoon concerts over the C. B. S. network, and some things will be done to make this anniversary a ceremonial occasion.

SEATTLE, Sept. 18 - Washington state's present alignment in Congress of six Republicans and one Democrat could remain unchanged after the November election, observers indicated today as they studied the returns of last Tuesday's primary.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The defeat of the European Defense Community treaty in the French National Assembly has left a vacuum in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Heavy season-end bookings on most trans-Atlantic steamship lines indicate that 1954 may be a banner post-war year.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 18 -- The Santa Monica City Counsel, by a vote of 5 to 2 yesterday, awarded to the General Petroleum Corporation a ten-year case allowing the concern to drill for oil offshore within city limits, but at least one mile out.

THE next two or three weeks are the time of decision for next year's lawn. In any lawn that has been seriously troubled with crabgrass, great progress can be made this month toward suppressing this marauding weed in 1955.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18--Mr. Murphy expressed satisfaction with his talks here before he flew to Rome this afternoon.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Phil Walters of Green Farms, Conn., a former stock car driver, won his second Watkins Glen Grand Prix today, flashing around the twisting, hilly Grand Prix course in a Cunningham Special at an average speed of 33.3 miles per hour.
AVON, Conn., Sept. 18 -- Maj. Gen. Oscar R. Cauldwell, USMC (ret.) has returned to the faculty of Avon Old Farms School here after a three-year leave of absence.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 -- The most significant aspect of last Tuesday's primary in Wisconsin was not who won but the size of the vote itself and the surprisingly strong showing of the Democrats.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The Rev. James F. McDonald of Elkton, Md., founder of the John McCormack Memorial Society, believes he has one of the largest and most representative collections of the Irish tenor's recordings.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The new sixteen-acre fair grounds of the Yorktown Grange were dedicated as Rochambeau Park this afternoon at a ceremony attended by Maj. John Taissier, military attache of the French Embassy.

Medals for "distinguished service" in 1954 will be awarded next month by the Theodore Roosevelt Association to Ralph J. Bunche, Under-Secretary of the United Nations, Robert Frost, poet, and Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, publishers of The Reader's Digest.

GARDENERS in the Deep South are tuning up for the fall planting season.[ It is starting nov, will be] well under way by early October and will reach its peak in No: vember. Planting in this area continues through the winter.

TAIPEI, Formosa Sept. 18 -- Still on guard for possible Communist moves against their offshore island positions, the Chinese Nationalists continued to use some of their planes and ships this week to patrol the southeast Chinese "invasion coast," to attack junks and to bomb Communist military installations on and around Amoy.

VIENNA, Sept. 18 -- Austria's coalition government has agreed on a budget for 1955 of $953,000,000 with a deficit of $100,000.000. Of the deficit $66,500,000 will result from the long-term budget for capital investment and will be covered by loans. It is hoped that the deficit in the ordinary budget of $33,500,000 eventually may be covered by higher receipts from taxation and a diminution of unemployment.
LOS ANGELES, which has had its musical vicissitudes in recent years, has just rounded out perhaps the most successful summer in its history.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The British Government's policy favoring German rearmament under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is arousing stronger opposition in the nation than did the now discarded program for a German military contribution through the European Defense Community.

Joseph Mayper, chairman of the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Conference, whose membership includes all steamship lines in regular passenger service between New York and Europe, last week issued this statement:

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored their first victory for Manager Marty Marion today and handed Don Larsen his twentieth defeat of the season as they whipped the Baltimore Orioles, 6 to 2.
UMATILLA, Ore., Sept. 18 -- McNary Dam, a massive multipurpose project, will be formally dedicated by President Eisenhower next Thursday.

When September rolls around, school bells ring for gardeners, too. Throughout the metropolitan area many courses are offered in subjects ranging from artistic flower arrangements to fruit culture. Listed in the schedule below home owners may find just the course they need to "brush up" on their horticulture or train an artistic bent. Each class meets weekly.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 -- The oldest and stormiest jurisdictional dispute in United States labor history was settled here today.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 18 (AP) -- With its first team stalled by the battling Kansas Jayhawkers, Texas Christian University's Horned Frogs used an all-sophomore second team for three touchdowns and a 27-6 victory in the football season opener here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The saying goes that the weather, no matter how bad, cannot stop the mail. But there are quite a few weather men who sometimes wish it could.

IRVING GITLIN, the lively, energetic newly appointed director of public affairs for the Columbia Broadcasting System, is losing no time in translating his ideas into action. His first major effort in public affairs presentations will be one of his pet projects: a series of major political debates in what he terms "the tradition of the Lincoln-Douglas joustings of almost a hundred years ago."

THE electronic color season broke out on two major fronts last week, running somewhat ahead of nature's fall array of colors. N. B. C.- TV fired first with "Satins and Spurs," an original musical comedy starring Betty Hutton, the first in a series to be seen every fourth Sunday from 7:30 to 9 P.M.

The city's Health Department has found that it can spare the needle without spoiling the child's development of immunity to three diseases that can be serious or even fatal. Since April 1, the department has cut in half the number of injections it gives to the 26 per cent of the city's infants who are brought to its child health stations for care and counsel.

A college scholarship service has been established by the College Entrance Examination Board. According to Dr. William C. Fells, associate director of the board, the scholarship problem is a relatively new one. Only recently has the administration of scholarships become an indispensable and inseparable part of the administration of admissions.

On Tuesday of this week the General Assembly of the United Nations will again come into regular session. Twice during its period of recess there were suggestions that it be called into extraordinary session. Each time it was felt that it would be possible to defer discussion and action on critical questions until the regular meeting time.

SOME fruit it just does not pay to grow, but every home owner should be able to harvest at least one kind in his own garden. No strawberries ever taste quite so delicious as those plucked on a warm June morning while the dew still clings to the fruit.

MUCH for little -- that's the reward even a beginner reaps from hardy bulbs. This is the time to get bulb fever, not next spring. Bulbs must be planted between now and November (I've set out tulips in December but not through choice) or there will be no way to have their spring flowers next year.

AN HOUR or so after emerging from Customs at Idlewild, last week's most impressive import to this country sat quietly in her hotel suite, sipping American coffee (briefly) and pondering the career of Gina Lollobrigida past, present (see photo at left) and future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The slump from 1952 of 12 per cent in the 1954 majorities given by the voters of Maine to the Republican candidates for Senator and the House of Representatives served as a reminder of one fact in particular: that citizens of the United States, in the last twenty years, have formed the habit of returning the Democrats to power after breaking it briefly in favor of the Republicans.

NOT long ago an Eighth Army colonel noticed a remarkable change in his jeep driver. The man was grinning from ear to ear and seemed eager to open a conversation. Both characteristics were completely foreign to the usually brooding private.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders today stepped up his charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The lengthy negotiations between Congress of Industrial Organizations shipbuilders and the Bethlehem Steel Company were settled early yesterday after a seventeen-hour session. The agreement is based on a 3-cent across-the-board hourly wage increase and some additional fringe benefits.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 18 -- The University of Texas staged a power-packed demonstration of its ground attack today to defeat Lousiana State, 20-6, before 36,000 fans in Memorial Stadium.

Some time ago it was pointed out in this space that under present rules of international law "each state has sovereignty and jurisdiction over the air space directly above its territory (including territorial water)." It was further indicated that "each state has complete discretion as to the admission * * * of any aircraft to the air space under its sovereignty."

THE life of Jesus by Daniel-Rops is the biggest bestseller of any book published in France since the end of World War II. It has gone into over 400 editions and has been translated into fifteen languages. The author is a meticulous scholar who has taught in French higher educational institutions for most of his life.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Gordon Jones set the Milwaukee Braves down with seven hits tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals posted a 3-to-0 victory.

LIFE in the Japanese island village where authors Taro and Mitsu Yashima grew up was a wonderland of things to watch. There were the barrel-maker slicing bamboo strips; the "pale skinned man from a far-away town" baking turtle-shaped cakes; the mattress-maker's knife going "zagut, zagut"; the lantern man turning out umbrellas and lanterns; and many others in the stores, factories and farms.

Yugoslavia's chess players, winning from Hungary by 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 in the fifth round, took a slight lead over Russia in the Hamilton-Russell Cup finals at the Apollo Hall yesterday, according to a report from Amsterdam.

In the wake of the recent revelations here about how some union officials have milked union welfare funds for their own benefit, a Times reporter interviewed members of some of the unions involved to get their reactions. As was to be expected, he found them disgusted by the news of what had been done with their money.
Good business has given retailers more confidence, resident buying offices report.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 18 -- A collection of Mark Twain material, including about 1,600 family letters, of which 134 were signed by the American humorist himself, passed into the hands of the University of California this week.

A YOUNG business man and father tells me: "When I was a kid I wasn't given anything in Sunday school but now they seem to understand my boys. They let them be human beings: I was scared to death of my Sunday school teacher but it's not like that any more."
At 3 P. M. yesterday there was an actual case of: "Don't raise the bridge, boys. Lower the barge."
DENVER, Sept. 18 -- Last Tuesday's primaries re-emphasized that Colorado's Democrats were going to be hard to beat in the November general election, observers indicated.

FRUIT trees, grapevines and small fruits may be planted successfully now. In fact, fall planting of fruits has several advantages over spring planting that make it worthwhile to add them to the autumn gardening schedule.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 -- The extreme left wing in California is fighting a critical rear guard action to maintain formal recognition in the form of a place on the ballot.
Two separate scientific sessions last week contributed to the growing medical conviction that excess fats in the diet play an important part in the development of heart disease.

Before we can start teaching students about communism, as Professor Hook advocates in "Should Our Schools Study Communism" (Aug. 29) we would have to educate our educators, maybe Professor Hook himself. He writes: "The study of communism should teach students the world of difference between democratic socialist regimes, which can be our stanchest allies against bolshevism, and Communist regimes, open or disguised in the form of a coalition.
ROME, Sept. 18--Attilio Piccioni, Italian Foreign Minister since last January, resigned today to help defend his son, who is involved in the Wilma Montesi affair.

STARLINGS, a tramp breed of birds, whose importation from Europe sixty-four years ago has done little since but unbalance the good nature of Americans and their continent, were the objects of another counter-attack by man recently.

IT was said of Stonewall Jackson by one of his officers that "no one could love the man for himself. He seems to be cut off from his fellow-men and to commune with his own spirit, or with spirits of which we know not." But if Old Jack was not readily explicable, the many sides of his strange and discordant nature have been ably held up to view in this life by Burke Davis.

Our Foreign Operations Administrator, Mr. Stassen, pointed out the magnitude of the Vietnamese refugee problem in a statement on Friday. It was originally supposed that by this time perhaps as many as 100,000 Vietnamese from the northern part of the country would have sought to escape.
NANTUCKET, Mass. -- The best way to fit a hurricane into a vacation is to follow it. On this point we feel we qualify as experts.

The focus of Western diplomacy last week was upon three capitals that form an irregular triangle at the heart of the West European coalition. All week long, at the Palais Schaumburg in Bonn, the Elysee Palace in Paris, and the Foreign Office in London, there were critical soundings among four leading statesmen of the Western world -- Dulles, Adenauer, Mendes-France, Eden.
Women prominent in society are working toward the success of the annual autumn benefit of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church on Oct. 19 in the parish house.

SOME years ago there appeared in California marked trends toward a new style in landscape design for residential properties. It arose from still other trends toward less formal living habits and smaller living spaces both indoors and outdoors.
Per capita industrial production in this country has dropped so sharply in the last year that it is only 1 per cent above the average rate for 1947.

Back in the blackest days of the depression it did not take much more than hope to buy a hotel. Those were the days when Ernest Henderson and Robert L. Moore, who had been college roommates at Harvard before World War I, formed the hotel-buying habit.

YONGDUNGPO, Korea, Sept. 16 -- The opening of a modern textbook printing plant here today marked the greatest single aid to Korean formal education since the turn of the century. The new plant, geared to turn out 30,000,000 schoolbooks each year, is the first modern printing plant in which only Korean language schoolbooks will be made.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The Eternal Light of the new $300,000 synagogue of Larchmont Temple will be lighted for the first time by an electrical impulse brought by telegraph lines from Beth Elohim of Charleston, S. C., one of the first Reform Temples in the nation.

COASTAL New Englanders and residents of the central and northern areas are preoccupied this fall with repairing their gardens and landscapes in the wake of hurricanes Carol and Edna. For them there is the question of whether to replant trees and shrubs now or wait until spring.
Two Korean war veterans who are determined to run their own business stepped briskly through the entrance to 342 Madison Avenue last week.

Political 1954 has been a year of sharp changes in the Republican mood. Early in the year the party was worried. The economy was in a slide. The President's program was running into trouble and the Administration was heading for a collision with the farm bloc.

AMERICAN-built jet aircraft will probably be available for commercial service in the United States late in this decade. But, according to present indications, there will be gradual changes in the country's fleets of commercial planes rather than an abrupt conversion from conventional piston-driven craft to the new types -- turboprops for short and medium-length flights and turbojets (propellerless craft like the de Havilland Comet and the Boeing Stratoliner) for transcontinental and transoceanic operations.

A GARDENER'S first visit to the nursery could be a bewildering but fascinating experience. For there the visitor would see rows and rows of plants of all sizes, descriptions and varieties and would hear a new language that may sound strange at first.

HE liked "an easy man," said Lord Melbourne, Queen Victoria's first Prime Minister. Despite public difficulties and private trials, he himself was such a man; for, although genuinely conscientious and intermittently industrious, he preferred to choose his own time and do his work in his own way, and was always careful to avoid giving any impression of undue effort.

MARKING dangerous highway grades with signs requiring specific driving procedures is one of the most important and realistic projects undertaken to reduce accidents, according to Motor Vehicle Commissioner James R. Macduff.
German wines are making a brave if modest effort to balance the Bonn Federal Republic's trade with the United States.

The press of developments in Europe overshadowed for the moment the situation in the Far East. But critical tensions persisted there, tensions generated by the expansionist pressure of the Chinese Communist regime and Western diplomatic efforts to counter that pressure. Last week there were developments affecting both aspects.

As the wife of a soldier who fought fascism in the last war, I was profoundly shocked by the statement in John Ridley's article: "As for culture -- which means Marxist books, pictures, plays and music -- it is talked of indefatigably.

ADDITIONAL sections of the Garden state Parkway will be opened next week to permit traffic to flow for 143 miles between Irvington and Cape May. At present the Parkway from Irvington stops at Somers Point, below Atlantic City, although an additional sixteen miles has been in use in Cape May County.

With a view toward picking a winning slate of state candidates, the Republican and Democratic parties will hold state conventions this week. The Republican promises to be the more harmonious gathering.

LATE September and October are a "second spring" planting season in the mild Southwest, while greenthumbers are busy in the East trying to beat the deadline of early frosts. In most parts of California daytime temperatures are warm and little frost is to be expected except in mountain spots.

LOS ANGELES -- One of the most conspicuous bottlenecks in the modernization of the national park system appeared to have been eliminated this week with the announcement of a developmental plan embodied in a new working agreement between the National Park Service and the concessionaire at Grand Canyon National Park.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 18--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has decided to avoid attending the meeting of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg Monday when French Premier Pierre Mendes-France explains his views on German rearmament.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Bergen County, long one of the most important Republican strongholds in New Jersey, is experiencing a political upheaval that has drawn the attention of Republican and Democratic leaders throughout the state.

BETTER taste at lower cost in home furnishings was the specifically stated theme of the Tenth Triennale which opened in Milan, Italy, late last month and which will continue through November. This comprehensive fair, held every three years, is dedicated to a review of goings-on in the fields of decorative, industrial and household arts and residential architecture.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement as he arrived here today from London:

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The Chicago Parent-Teacher Association, after an eighteen-month study, reported this week it had found nine deficiencies in the city public schools. Unless they were corrected, the P.-T. A. warned, the city would have a mediocre educational system.

THE Gibson Girl presided over a chafing dish; today's hostess (and host, too) uses an electric fryer and electric saucepan. There are many more improvements to keep the ex-galley slave away from the hot kitchen stove.

After a prolonged downward trend, resulting from the low birthrate of the depression years, high school enrollment has now started to go upward again. The increase can be expected to grow at an accelerated rate. The "baby boom" of the Forties will make itself felt at the high school level within another year or two.

The theme "Of Music and Art" is as many-faceted and as capable of as many different effects as a mirror-studded dancehall chandelier with colored lights playing on it. With extraordinary ambition, the Milwaukee Art Institute has attempted to present almost all sides of the prism in its large current loan exhibition.

TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- The Japanese political pot boiled briskly this week over Premier Shigeru Yoshida's scheduled visit to Britain, the United States and Western Europe and Opposition attempts here to prevent the trip.
New equipment and devices to make the telephone useful in more ways and more places went on display yesterday in the lobby of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at 195 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley said today he was opposed to calling the Senate back into session until some definite agreement had been worked out between France and Germany and other West European nations for anti-Communist defense forces.

SEPTEMBER is the month for planting the perennials which are the backbone of the garden. Iris, peonies, phlox, bleeding heart and all of the spring-flowering perennials can be safely planted any time now, and if the plants are of blooming size, they can be expected to flower successfully next year.

Rocky Marciano, looking like the beaten gladiator rather than the victor of the night before, left for Los Angeles from the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, yesterday. The Rock from Brockton, Mass., is scheduled for a television performance tonight, but he certainly won't be cast in the role of a matinee idol.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Land scarcity in Nassau County caused a 25 per cent drop in building construction in the first six months of this year compared with the first half of 1953, the Nassau County Planning Commission has announced.

THE title of this book is somewhat ambiguous. It treats not of the appeals of communism to those who sympathize with or vote for it but to those who join the Communist parties of the West and militantly work for communism.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight that the political tide was running toward the Democrats to end a twenty-month Republican record of failure.

An auction of autographed menus at the Lotos Club Monday night showed that the most valued signature was that of an ex-President of the United States -- even to an autograph-hunter of the opposite political persuasion.

THE ancient Roman province of Cilicia, dear to the hearts of Caesar and Pompey, across which ran the great highway linking Byzantium with the East, is as little known to most Americans and Europeans as the Arctic regions.
HARTFORD, Sept. 18 -- Connecticut is moving to tighten up its liquor control laws where they pertain to the selling of liquor to minors.

A new show place for photographers was opened last week at the James Gallery, 70 East Twelfth Street, a cooperative group of painters and photographers. The current show includes photographs by photographer members Phil Harrington of Look Magazine and Gene Lesser, a New York freelance.

WHEN the Puritan minister Hugh Peter mounted the scaffold at Charing Cross in 1660 to meet a traitor's death, a contemporary news sheet reported: "There never was a person suffered death so unpitied; when his head was cut off, there was such a shout, as if the people of England had acquired a victory."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 18 -- Enthusiasm ran high this week in the Democratic - Farmer - Labor party of Minnesota as it moves into the general election campaign after displaying its greatest primary strength in ten years.

A feature-length motion picture is being made at Randolph-Macon Women's College (Lynchburg, Va.) of "The Oresteia," a trilogy of plays in original Greek. The plays were given for the first time in this country by the college last spring. The students will take part in the plays, and the high school stage of Lynchburg will be used for the locale.

THOSE who had expected that Leo Kerz and Harry Horner would get caught up again in plans for a repertory company, following their split with Joseph Kramm over managerial policies in the formation of The Ensemble, were correct.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18 -- Five religious leaders will receive honorary degrees from Yale University on Sept. 28 at ceremonies marking the opening of the Yale Divinity School's 133d year. The recipients will be:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18--The inevitable happened today and this city's happy baseball fans took the clinching of the 1954 American League pennant by their Cleveland Indians with a minimum of shouting and backslapping.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has set up a plan for repairing in a minimum of time and for a nominal charge -- or no charge at all -- any of its appliances damaged by a disaster such as flood, storm or hurricane.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Only a small portion of the fleet participating today in the penultimate regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship schedule was able to finish before the deadline.

Ten days ago New York Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams busted Deputy Chief Inspector Louis Goldberg, who had been busting up bingo in Brooklyn's parish halls and fraternal lodges. The commissioner said he was not punishing the inspector for his zeal, but for refusing to tell headquarters where it would strike next.

FALL planting in the Rocky Mountain area is restricted by weather. The great number of warm, sunny days in winter and the generally low humidity throughout the plains and mountains are responsible for reducing the natural moisture available to woody plants; and those which have been recently transplanted suffer especially because of weak root systems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Justice Department sources said today that the new anti-Communist laws had failed to resolve the tangled case of Judith Coplon, former Government employe twice convicted of spying for Russia.

AN exhibit of "blindiana" never before assembled for public display is opening the eyes of the sighted this week to the history of the blind. Called "Seeing Fingers" and sponsored by the Associated Blind, Inc., the exhibit tells the story of progress of devices for the blind from the sketchy message conveyed by knotted strings of ancient times to the nuances of the latest talking book.
MONTREAL, Sept, 18 -- Canada will start construction on her section of the St. Lawrence Seaway project before the end of the year and will extend the work considerably by next spring.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 18 -- Ceylon's imports from the United States and other countries of the dollar area have sharply contracted this year, while exports have been maintained at only slightly reduced levels.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Vladimir K. Zworykin, one of the fathers of television, is unhappy over the direction that the commercial medium is taking.

In "China Revisited" by John Ridley (Aug. 29) the author says about Anshan and its iron production that he saw there an iron smelting mill consisting of six blast furnaces producing a million and a half tons of iron annually.

Although there seemed to be prevalent early last week an element of caution that restrained activity in security markets, stocks finished the period on a strong note and showed a gain for the second successive week.
WHEN Robert Anderson's latest play, "All Summer Long," was being cast, the playwright was worried because June Walker and her son, John Kerr, had been chosen to play the roles of mother and son.

IF you dug under the plum tree you might find a diamond ring. Aunt Flossy, a despairing spinster, claimed she had lost the sparkler over the porch banister. This was her sly way of trying to leave the impression that an engagement ring had adorned her finger. But her story, which no one took really seriously, wasn't as good as the one about the tree that spread its branches above the family yard.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 18--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said here today upon his arrival by plane from London that the United States would continue its association with European planning to achieve peace and security.

ADIMINUTIVE British actress with a voice that could out - Lorelei any Rhine-maiden in the business plummeted into the city recently on her way to the West Coast to make her first Hollywood film. The lady with the distinctive voice, Joan Greenwood, is known to Broadway theatre-goers for her role of the raffish ingenue in the recent production of T. S. Eliot's "The Confidential Clerk.

TOM EWELL, one of 6,500 members in good standing of Actors' Equity, is celebrating his twentieth year in show business this season -- by working. For Ewell the delights of employment are doubled by a new assignment: repeating his stage role in the movie version of "The Seven Year Itch," opposite (a sound of trumpets underneath the title cards) every red-blooded American's dream girl, Marilyn Monroe.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Trustful Hanover, a 4-year-old bay mare driven by John Simpson, won the Mississippi Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Four steak knives are offered by Lipton Tea in return for 75 cents and a boxtop. The knives are described in heavy newspaper advertising as retailing at $2.

More than a score of art exhibitions -- one-man shows and small groups -- come into the New York galleries this week. Quite a number of them represent work by newcomers and a number of the exhibitions are in new galleries and in show places well off the beaten track.

THAT Wieland Wagner's new "Tannhaeuser" would be unlike any other "Tannhaeuser" ever staged was a foregone conclusion. Not so foregone was the manner in which the new production would differ from the tradition.

Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, one of the largest engineering schools in the country, announced plans yesterday for its centennial celebration, which will bring together scientists, engineers and academic scholars from many parts of the world.

AS everybody knows who has taken the slightest interest in the United Nations. Trygve Lie was the first Secretary General of the organization, serving from February, 1946, until he was replaced in April last year by another Scandinavian, Dag Hammarskjold of Sweden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Taxes on gasoline and other petroleum products -- but primarily gasoline -- have jumped to almost $5,000,000,000 a year, according to the American Petroleum Institute's Tax Economic Bulletin.

The long-disputed markings on the surface of Mars are the outlines of swirls and furrows cut into the surface of the red planet by winds. This is the view Dr. Dean B. McLaughlin of the University of Michigan, expressed in the current issue of the British astronomical journal The Observatory.
Arthur W. Nelson has joined the bond department of E. F. Hutton Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Mrs. Annie Lee Moss, a Negro widow who twice had been suspended as an Army Signal Corps employe, begins her defense before a security hearing board on Monday, the Army disclosed today.

VENICE wound up its fifteenth annual filmic festivities with a nine-man international jury selecting a joint British-Italian entry, "Romeo and Juliet," as best of the show. For once, the decision was questioned by only a very few.

The subjects covered at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society here last week ranged over everything from cosmetics to cosmology. The society is the largest one-field scientific organization in the United States, excepting the American Medical Association, and about 13,000 of its 72,000 members were in New York City for the big meeting last week.

PEOPLE reminiscing about their colorful elder relatives are generally considered to be almost as boring as people talking about their operations; therefore a novelist who adopts this form of family reminiscence does so at his peril. It militates not only against intensity but against credibility as well.

AMONG the small handful of men and women who have set their names upon history there are few more fascinating or incredible than that inspired daughter of the mayor of a French village whom we know as Joan of Arc.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 18 -- Republican political leaders in the Missouri Basin breathed a little easier this week after Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced that he would relax the rigid controls he had imposed on use of diverted farm land.
Rocky Marciano started putting up a fight yesterday for the detective who was demoted and transferred for shielding the world heavyweight champion from the rain with an umbrella last Wednesday.

An appeal was made last night to candidates of both major parties to "departisanize" the issue of civil rights and pledge themselves to the enactment of a broad human rights program in the next session of Congress.

At New York City's squat, sprawling 165th Infantry Armory over the week-end carpenters and party workers were building platforms, putting up flags and bunting, and hanging pictures of Harry Truman, Adlai Stevenson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and other Democratic luminaries.

HERE'S a humdinger in the Dr. Seuss tradition of fantastic humor. The hero, a horse who wants to be a champion racer like his competent, conceited brother, is a bowlegged, knockkneed beast named So 'm I.
THE home greenhouse which has been empty during the hot summer days will soon take on a new look. There is a great deal to be done and no time to be lost in starting.

Army and Air Force post exchanges, along with Navy ships' stores, are attempting a trick that might well have stumped Houdini. The PX's each year do a retail business of $350,000,000 to $400,000,000 in the United States.

A FEW minutes after 11 o'clock on the night of July 22, 1952, a 34-year-old Egyptian lieutenant colonel of infantry returned to his home in the Cairo suburb of Heliopolis. He changed from civilian clothes to uniform, told his wife that he had work to do and would probably be late, and left the house.

THRIFTY is the word for gardeners who increased their stock of favorite perennials by sowing fresh seed earlier in the summer in pots or seed flats. Now, if luck smiled, they have a supply of good-sized, hardy young seedlings to move into the border.
Baseball's only sotto voce manager, Alfonso Ramon Lopez of the Cleveland Indians, has proved by winning the American League pennant, his theory that baseball players are people.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The United States has sent a new note to the Soviet Union asking whether the Soviet is holding three Americans in prison camps.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- In the midst of the usual summer crisis in the nation's international relations (worse this year than any other since the Korean war) the capital presents a strange picture.

Actors' Equity has granted a basic contract to closed circuit television. It is reported that actors in Broadway plays will receive an "additional" $342.50 for a broadcast to forty out-of-town theatres. Since this amounts to less than $10 per performance per theatre, any consideration of such a contract as a "victory" is surely a distortion of the word.

FOR a long time now the veteran Edison Marshall has been fabricating his historical romances with all the bravura of an expert horseman settling to the saddle for a canter on a nippy fall day. There's an infectious joy of living in the texture of the writing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 -- Two of California's top officials, both Republicans and both aspiring to retain their posts, are at odds over the use of this state's "pot of gold" accruing from offshore oil royalties.

PHILLIPBURG, N. J., Sept. 18--The Warren Hospital Building Fund announced this week that the Ingersoll-Rand Company would make $500,000 available to the fund toward construction of its new 200-bed hospital. The gift would be made on a matching basis of 50 cents for every dollar raised from all sources exclusive of Federal funds.
The Knights of Pythias has accepted State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman's appeal to run a community center in space provided in a low-rent housing project in the city.

READERS of Mika Waltari's popular historical novels may expect to be surprised by the five novelettes that compose "Moonscape." Where "The Egyptian" and "The Adventurer" were tapestries aglow with color and teeming with incident, the new book is a panel of chiaroscuros.

Books make good shipmates, and Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt reported last week that almost 10,500,000 such shipmates had been sent out by the American Merchant Marine Library Association in its thirty-three-year existence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Washington Senators defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8 -- 7, tonight in a fifteen-inning game which saw Boston's Ted Williams benched for weak hitting for the first time in his thirteen-year major league career.
ART when really understood is the province of every human being.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Tony Trabert defeated the defender, Ken Rosewall of Australia, and Vic Seixas scored over Luis Ayala of Chile to make it an all-United States final round in the Pacific Southwest tennis championships today.

Parity, crop cutbacks and other similar and familiar terms in farm economics are, by and large, esoteric issues to city dwellers. In rural areas, though, which still contain about 35 per cent of the population, they can mean the difference between a Republican and a Democrat.

FOR infinitely varied delight there is no Latin poet who surpasses Ovid, and the "Metamorphoses," is Ovid at his wisest and best. Here is a treasury of some of the world's most engaging stories, stories so deeply rooted in western civilization that we can hardly understand much of the great writing of our immediate past without some familiarity with them.
THE death of Joseph Stalin has given Russia a new regime with a new way of doing business that has already achieved notable successes at home and abroad.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 18 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgian Foreign Minister, warned the free nations of Europe today that if West Germany was not rearmed the United States would withdraw its troops from the Continent.

ATLANTA, Sept. 18 -- Georgia Tech ushered in a bid as one of the nation's foremost 1954 grid-iron powers today by beating Tulane, 28 to 0, before a shirt-sleeved crowd of 28,000. A pair of sophomore halfbacks -- Paul Rotenberry and Jimmy Thompson -- streaked through the Tulane secondary for runs of 48 and 58 yards.

IN their little dispute concerning the priority of discovering the parallels between the plot of Faulkner's "The Sound and the Fury" and the events of Holy Week, both correspondent Robert Adams, and Carvel Collins, who pointed out these parallels in his review of Faulkner's "A Fable," do not consider the possibility that perhaps many others noted these before they did.

Deciding the time had come to quit dawdling along the trail, the Giants put on the pressure again at the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith took another full stride toward the clinching of the National League pennant. They crushed the Phillies, 9 to 1, to the cheers of 10,003, and so moved to within three games of the flag.

The Dec. 22 performance of the musical "Fanny" has been taken over by the Smith College Club of New York for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund. "Fanny," starring Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak, opens Nov. 4 at the Majestic Theatre.

AMONG the millions of children who flocked back to public schools this month are some half-million "handicapped children" -- the mentally slow, the crippled ones, children with speech defects, boys and girls who are deaf, near-deaf, the blind and the partially seeing, children with heart conditions or other special health problems, like epilepsy.

THIS is Paul Darcy Boles' second novel and it is entirely unlike his first, "The Streak," which was an exploration into the soul of the automobile racing driver -- an effective tour de force, as such things go, but hardly outstanding in a publishing season featuring a whole string of novels dealing with the soul-searchings of racing drivers.

OUR knowledge of the Middle East has grown substantially since a House of Commons inquiry in 1832 found it necessary, for adequate data about the Euphrates, to dig all the way back to Herodotus and chronicles of Roman legionary marches toward the Persian Gulf.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- The auto industry's over-all program for the year ahead -- both in manufacturing and merchandising -- is arousing widespread speculation in trade quarters.
The Ford Foundation, the nation's richest public trust, asserted yesterday that "today, timidity characterizes too much of our current corporate and individual giving."

ROME, Sept. 18 -- Robert D. Murphy, United States Deputy Under Secretary of State, arrived in Rome by air from Belgrade this evening and expressed mild optimism for early solution of the Trieste problem.

LAST Sunday was the starting date of the celebration of the tercentenary of the arrival of the first group of Jewish settlers in the United States. It seems a fitting occasion therefore to review those gramophone recordings of the last few months which are devoted to musical and religious aspects of the Jewish heritage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Nuclear power as a force for peace rather than for war will come back onto the world's stage next week. The United Nations General Assembly will again be invited to consider some form of an international atomic power development for peaceful purposes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The 1954 session of the General Assembly, which will open on Tuesday, is starting out on a subdued note. Sensational developments may come later, but world attention is concentrated at present on the question of German rearmament, which will be debated in London, not here.

A SUBURBAN film studio has been converted into one of the world's most unusual television centers by High- Definition Films, Inc. It is a unique operation: a film studio without motion picture cameras, a television studio which produces only film.
BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Maine Democrats are not sure in full detail what Monday's election results mean for them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, despite the Mundt and Watkins committee investigations, acts like a man who is neither bloodied nor bowed.

In your very interesting article, "A Carrier's Watch Chain" (Aug. 15), by Edward A. Mossien, you mentioned that the aircraft carrier Forrestal was being built at Norfolk, Va. This was in error The Forrestal and its sistership, the Ranger, are both being constructed here at Newport News, Va., separated from Norfolk by a body of water requiring almost an hour to cross and proud of being the birthplace of many of our most famous ships.

THE problem of blemish by scratches, dust and oily fingerprints which the 35mm negative has been heir to since its introduction about twenty-five years ago, appears to have been solved at last by a corrective liquid in a special 35mm enlarging negative carrier.

THE balanced budget appears to be as elusive as ever. To the business community, the news of a rise in the Federal deficit was not so disturbing as the lower estimates for defense spending, which will mean a loss of sales that may be difficult to be offset in the civilian market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- While thousands along the seawall of Haines Point and thousands of others on anchored craft saw the speed-boat thrills, a lead-foot cockpit ace, Bill Cantrell, once of Louisville and now of Detroit, won the first fifteen-mile heat of the President's Cup competition on the Potomac late today.

IN almost thirty years of casual singing, Bing Crosby, has left his inimitable mark on more songs than any of his crooning colleagues, past or present. Summing up his recording career is, consequently, no simple matter.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 18 -- South Africa is starting to reorganize and re-equip her sea defense on the theoretical basis that in case of war the Suez Canal will be either entirely closed or little used.

A spreading of godlessness in America would aid communism in its aim to break up democracy, Rabbi Zev Zahavy said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Zichron Ephraim Synagogue, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street.

THIS eighth story about Jenny Linsky, the Greenwich Village cat, is a departure from the earlier ones. It's a picture book about twice the usual size, with twice as much color and a very simple story for a slightly younger audience.
FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Montpelier's Cap-a-Pie won the $3,000 Manly Steeplechase Handicap today as a crowd of 7,500 fans established a betting record for this course.
Common stock investing habits of the country's big insurance companies closely parallel those of the investment trusts, according to studies just completed in Wall Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 18 (UP) -- Clarence Budington Kelland, author and Republican National committeeman from Arizona, today said his party was "riding to a fall when we should and easily could have been galloping to sweeping victory."

The Cleveland Indians clinched the American League pennant yesterday by defeating the Tigers at Detroit, 3--2. The Indians were blanked by Steve Gromek until the seventh inning, when Dale Mitchell hit a two-run homer. At the Polo Grounds, the Giants routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 9--1, and now need any combination of three New York victories and Dodger defeats to clinch the National League flag.
PELHAM, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- This commuters' community is looking haughtily upon towns with mere centennials and sesquicentennials as it prepares for tercentennial fanfare Oct. 9 to 17.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The official newspaper of the Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded today that President Eisenhower dismiss a Commerce Department official for a recent complaint that Congress had not gone far enough in helping business.

THERE is no doubt that apparitions are experienced by some people. They are mostly visual hallucinations, usually of deceased persons closely attached to those who see them. In this book G. N. M. Tyrrell deals only with apparitions involving psi (or psychic) phenomena, such as the extra-sensory perception of a distant or a coming event.

A YOUNG man who had attended an exclusive preparatory school and an Ivy League college felt that his horizon had been restricted because, during the years of his education he had met only the sons of bankers, brokers, executives, lawyers and doctors.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Two innovations will greet the 2,976 undergraduates and 520 graduate students returning to Princeton University for the opening of classes Monday morning.

Students will not be able to charter regular commercial airliners at the low rates heretofore enjoyed, according to C. Edwin Lacks, director of the United States Student Association Educational Travel, Inc.
Democratic leaders of New York County agreed yesterday on the choice of three candidates for nomination to the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, which takes in Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A liberal housing law too liberally administered opened the door for the hundreds of millions of dollars in windfall profits that Congress and the Administration now are investigating. The opportunity for abuses, according to an investigative report by the Federal Housing Administration this week, was exploited in some cases by graft and corruption which the report attributed to a former official of the agency.

THIS sequel to "Mr. Wicker's Window" takes Christopher Mason backward in time again to the eighteenth century for adventures even more fabulous than those of the earlier story. After a reunion with old friends at Mr. Wicker's Georgetown antique shop, Chris rejoins the crew of the Mirabelle for a cruise to Mexico.
New trends in public education and finance are revamping the house plant and the fiscal foundation of New York State's public school system.

AT the end of a week made momentous for certain susceptible residents of New York by the simultaneous presence in our parish of Gins Lollobrigida, Ava Gardner and Marilyn Monroe -- all of them pushing for publicity in the most amiable and lady-like way -- it may seem a trifle inattentive for this observer to choose to devote this Sunday dissertation to the subject of film societies.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France, in speeches tomorrow and Monday, intends to outline proposals for an alternative to the method of arming West Germany envisaged in the rejected European Defense Community plan.
THE United Nations' most expert practitioner of the delicate art of staying alive while his colleagues at home are not doing quite as well is Andrei Yanuarevitch Vishinsky, a Russian lawyer.
With fourteen pilots finishing within 2 percentage points of perfect scores, the finale of the Eastern Cruisers Association predicted-log race was conducted yesterday on Long Island Sound.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and New York Democratic leaders joined last night in declaring that the Maine election results presaged Democratic victories at Albany and Washington in November and in 1956.

AS its tribute to the celebration of the Marian Year the Metropolitan Museum has arranged, in one of its smaller galleries, an exhibition of European works of art illustrating scenes from the life of the Virgin.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The belief that the period of readjustment may soon be over appears to have been strengthened by late summer economic development, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. In its district, the bank noted, productive activity and employment have continued stable, and although inventory reduction is still in progress the rate of liquidation has diminished.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Sept. 18 (UP) -- Wake Forest mounted one 81-yard scoring march and then sent a long-legged sophomore scampering on a 32-yard touchdown gallop today to defeat George Washington University, 14 to 0.

TAKE a mixture of politics and sex (straight and frustrated) afflicting a group of likely males. Center it round a woman, physically scarred by fire -- and you have the basic ingredients of Mary Fassett Hunt's rather heady novel.

RICHARD F. WALSH, on his first trip to Hollywood last week since being reelected president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, was greeted by a minor, short-lived palace revolution.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., which this year is seeking $1,000,000 for its program, will benefit from the second annual Velvet Ball on Oct. 15 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

MOSCOW, Idaho, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Oregon, led by the deadly passing of George Shaw, a quarterback, broke loose after a close first half today to crush outmanned Idaho, 41 -- 0, in the opening game of their Pacific Coast Conference season.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 18 -- The first school of library science in the Middle East will open this fall at the University of Ankara, under a grant from the Ford Foundation.

MANY Americans are convinced that the mood in Britain today is one of growing anti-Americanism. They point to Parliament, where many Labor members seem to go out of their way to put the worst interpretation on American actions, and Sir Winston Churchill recently had to rebuke the leader of the Opposition, Mr. Attlee, for a speech which, he protested, was one long anti-American "wail."
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis reported last week that in 1953 it paid its largest bill for patient care for any year in its history.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- An exhibition of art masterpieces lent from private collections will open Oct. 4 for a week's showing at the Country Art Gallery on Belmont Street, for the benefit of the North Shore Hospital development drive.
Re that "Vocal Monuments" proposal in Sylvan Gotshal's letter of Sept. 5:

This newspaper begins today a series of articles on the Soviet Union by Harrison E. Salisbury, who has just returned to this country after serving as our Moscow correspondent since early 1949. When he left the Soviet capital Mr. Salisbury was the dean of American correspondents there and had the added distinction of having traveled more extensively through the country than any other foreign writer in recent years.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 5 -- Installation of the first pure Boer Nationalist administration in South Africa's Cape Province has brought a series of measures to show both the nonwhite and British in the province who is master.

The do-it-yourself era almost reached a fantastic pinnacle when a Brooklyn cancer specialist designed, bought materials for and stopped just short of building his own three-ton cobalt-beam cancer therapy machine.

Last Friday, Australian Premier Menzies pressed a button that began operation of a large new uranium processing plant at Rum Jungle, the rich uranium field in Northern Australia. Only a few days ago President Eisenhower waved a wand that started work on the building of the first large-scale atomic power plant in the United States.

BACK of grandfather's house was the plum thicket, where the leaves were so dense it was like a dim cathedral within. Here Katie had her private tea parties every summer of her childhood, until the summer of the last Reunion.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Morton W. (Cappy) Smith of Beau Vale Farm, Cobham, Va., won the open jumper championship with his 7-year-old chestnut gelding, Clay Pigeon, as the forty-ninth annual Piping Rock horse show ended its three-day run today.

On Friday at Aqueduct, Chevation won $20,500 for William du Pont Jr.'s Foxcatcher Farms in the Discovery Handicap. Yesterday there was another job of cash collecting on an even handsomer scale, by a Foxcatcher horse.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Manchester United's team of youngsters scrambled to a 1-1 tie against hard-hitting Huddersfield Town today for a one-point lead in the first division of English soccer.

HURON, S. D., Sept. 18 -- Republicans will not compromise with socialism, Vice President Richard M. Nixon pledged today as he declared that the outcome of the fall election would "shape the course of American life for a generation."

Sylvan Gotshal's letter (Sept. 5) about creating an American Society for Living Monuments featuring the Lincoln Memorial, Mount Vernon, Monticello and various others through the media of radio, TV and the movies, was of considerable interest to me.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported today that twenty-eight of its recommendations to curb subversion had been written into law or administrative action.

WASHINGTON, Sept., 18 (AP) -- The Air Force, speeding up its jet fighter program, announced tonight an order of more than $100,000,000 for additional F-100 supersonic planes. They will be produced at a new, second-source plant at Columbus, Ohio.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The United States Army turned over to Washington today the case of two United States soldiers "abducted" by Czech border police on the Iron Curtain frontier. An Army spokesman disclosed that one of the two men wore civilian clothes.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The output per man in the building industry, the second largest industry in Britain, has increased about 10 per cent since 1948, the British Productivity Council said toady.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 17 -- With one race to go, a new British-built 5-0-5, an International 14 and a Class A scow were neck- and-neck today for the corrected time award in the one-of-a-kind series being conducted by the Riverside Yacht Club.

IN his article on the difference between American and British novels ("Britons Find It Jolly Good Reading") David Daiches classified me as a British writer. His general point was that the Americans have the power and the British the technique.

BACK in the days of auction bridge, there were quite rigid "rules" for the play of the cards and everything seemed quite simple. Players led the fourth-highest card of the longest and strongest suit against no-trump contracts.

Mrs. Edward Patterson, chairman of the committee for the annual Boys Club Ball, has made known the names of members of her committee who will assist with arrangements. The ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York, will be held on Oct. 21 in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.
ROME, Sept. 18 -- Yielding to the insistence of his physician and his household, Pope Plus XII spent the greater part of today in bed. The rest of the time he sat in an armchair.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 18 -- Coronado, a part of Norfolk county to be annexed to the City of Norfolk, Jan. 1, has been the scene of three mysterious explosions since Negroes started to buy houses in the formerly all-white neighborhood last October.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 18 -- High Government officials of Afghanistan and Pakistan, including Prime Minister Mohammed Ali of Pakistan, began today conferences that may "open a new era of goodwill and cooperation" between, these adjoining Moslem countries south of the Soviet Union.

This is the week of the autumn equinox, and just ahead lies the long slope into winter, first frost, color in the woodlands, the falling leaves, Indian Summer and, finally, ice and snow. The season turns on the equinoctial pivot, subtle as morning mist, bold as sumac-crimson.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Precedence in planting goes to making or renovating a lawn, setting out evergreens and early spring-flowering bulbs and perennials. Deciduous trees and shrubs, roses and tulips wait.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18 -- Maryland, opening the defense of its national championship, scored touchdowns after each of three Kentucky errors to defeat the Wildcats, 20 -- 0, today before 36,000 fans. The Terrapins sent into action the backfield that was a second-line unit behind last season's varsity foursome and the difference was scarcely noticeable.
LEE-ON-SOLENT, England, Sept. 18 -- Two hundred women of the Royal Navy won the right today to eat out. They had begun to mutter threats of a hunger strike against their fattening mess hall fare.

CHILDREN get lost in Coney Island, police gather them up and anxious mothers come to fetch them. In the meantime, the kids are sad, worried, frightened or simply puzzled. They stare blankly into space, perhaps wondering how they got into such a fix and when if ever they were going to get out of it.

Chain drug stores in shopping centers enjoy higher gross volume and lower costs than similar stores not located in such centers, a group of drug chain merchants and their suppliers were told last week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- Eight new operas and two ballets are being prepared for performances in Moscow Leningrad and the provinces this season. But there still are not enough new works, according to Soviet Music, organ of the Union of Soviet Composers.

SUMMER is fast fading into fall, and the drifts of phlox that have made the perennial border fragrant for weeks are being superseded by pungent chrysanthemums. Fall brings with it more than chrysanthemums and the threat of frost.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The New York Giants unveiled a powerful ground attack in the second half tonight to overcome a three-point half-time deficit and defeat the Green Bay Packers, 38 -- 27, in an exhibition game between the two National Football League teams.
SEATTLE, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Washington's Huskies edged the Utah Redskins, 7-6, before 25,600 fans today in a rough-and-ragged football game.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Vagabond King charged furiously in the stretch to defeat his Walmac Farm stablemate, Gala Fete, by three quarters of a length and capture the $27,950 Midwest Handicap before 21,594 at Hawthorne today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 18 -- Utah's two seats in the House of Representatves have been marked "doubtful" by both parties.

There is no question of the constitutionality or finality of the recent Greek Government legislative decree extending special guarantees to Greeks with ships registered under foreign flags, according to a statement issued here yesterday by George Voyadjis, Greece's Minister of Mercantile Marine.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 18 (AP) -- The placards were crude. They had been made in a hurry, obviously.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- An "extremely insecure" harvesting situation in several regions of the Soviet Union was reported today by the Ministry of Agriculture.

Faces of Democratic and Republican State Committee planners were a bit rueful yesterday -- but at least the ruddy hues were not being televised. Nor will there be live televising of the two parties' state conventions this week here and in Syracuse, respectively.
Despite strong opposition front both college presidents and students, most Greek letter fraternities and sororities continue to practice racial and religious discrimination in selecting members.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United States carried off five individual titles today, but finished second to Chapultepec in both the men and women's divisions of the Mexican swimming championships.
Cardinal Spellman has approved and agreed to support a study of juvenile delinquency to be made by a committee of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers of New York.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- A successful solution to the problem of peaceful co-existence of East and West is a prerequisite to this country's survival, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told 2,000 undergraduates and their families today.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Church services and military ceremonies were held in many parts of Britain today to mark the end of Battle of Britain Week.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- Hopeful of attracting new foreign capital, the Mexican Government has just given another indication of its good intentions toward private enterprise and foreign investments here.
David L. Cole, who is acting as referee in the dispute between American Airlines and its pilots, will meet with representatives of both sides at his temporary home at Ithaca, N. Y., later this month.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 19 -- Pope Pius XII seemed noticeably weaker when he appeared at a mass audience for several thousand pilgrims at his summer residence here this afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- The Dodgers suffered their crowning humiliation of the season at Forbes Field today when they bowed to the Pirates for the fourth straight time and fell to a practically hopeless five and a half games behind the league-leading Giants.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- Thousands of Muscovites patiently stood in line among the flower beds of the Gorki Park of Rest and Culture today to get their first glimpse of the products of a North Atlantic nation. On display were food products, consumer goods and machinery of eighty-eight Danish concerns.

THE new "Stork Club" show is an amazing attraction. Where else can a viewer see a whole museum of personalities? Or "eavesdrop" on a conversation between Faye Emerson and Dorothy Kilgallen? Or hear the fascinating description of a society woman's gown?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- A video tape-recording machine developed by Bing Crosby Enterprises, Inc., will be sold under contract to the Western Electric Corporation and tested.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- There was increased hope in the capital tonight that the Allies had made progress toward a formula for the controlled rearmament of Germany within the Atlantic alliance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra T. Benson, today announced he hoped to authorize "within the next few weeks" the first foreign purchases of American farm surpluses under a $1,000,000,000 surplus disposal program.

The Port of New York Authority will establish a new Eastern trade promotion office here to expedite and increase its port promotion services in the metropolitan area, eastern Pennsylvania and New England.

Executives, editors, reporters and correspondents of The New York Times will talk about their work with this newspaper in a series of interviews this week, beginning today on television and radio and continuing through Friday.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is planning to embark within six weeks on a program of buying Talgo trains. The program for the purchase of the low-slung, lightweight streamliners will cost from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000, Patrick B. McGinnis, president, said today.

George S. Kaufman isn't averse to having a distant project afoot. During his recent sojourn abroad, he conferred with Geoffrey Kerr about a dramatization of Mr. Kerr's novel, "Under the Influence." An outline of the proposed treatment was agreed upon.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Barbara Romack, a diminutive 21-year-old golfer from Sacramento, Calif., became the women's amateur champion of the United States today.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 19 -- The Netherlands budget, due on Tuesday, is being awaited with keen interest and the hope of an all-round reduction in taxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations issued a special statement today accusing Communist China of committing thirty-nine "warlike" acts against ships and planes of the West.

THERE probably isn't a more attractive place in town, for the sidewalk superintendent, than the easterly block on Fifth Avenue, between Eighth and Ninth Streets. Steel erectors are working like demons there, putting together the skeleton of a nineteen-story - and - penthouse apartment building.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Marcello Cardinal Mimmi, Archbishop of Naples, announced to thousands of rejoicing Neapolitans that the blood of their patron saint, St. Januarius, had liquefied today, the Saint's birthday.
In Germany, where fashions for children are practically unknown, Waltraud Gollong is an exception in the garment design field -- she "creates" for youngsters.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 19 -- President Eisenhower put off his return to Denver until tomorrow morning.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles spoiled the Chicago White Sox' home farewell today by whipping them, 5 to 1, at Comiskey Park.
HARTFORD, Sept. 19 -- Connecticut's election campaign has finally got off the ground, but it has not gained much altitude.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19 -- President Tito aligned Yugoslavia today in support of German sovereignty and rearmament.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 19 -- By a decision of the Bank Deutscher Laender, sperrmarks ceased to exist last Thursday after being in vogue for twenty-three years.
Diana Moncado, soprano, will give a recital tonight in Carnegie Recital Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- After twenty-nine years, fifteen as a manager in the majors, Casey Stengel finally became associated with a 100-game winner today. Gil McDougald's 3-run homer in the eighth brought the Yankees to a 4-2 come-from-behind victory over the Philadelphia Athletics at Connie Mack Stadium and made a bigger man of the pilot of the dethroned champions.

Contracts for the initial docking of thirteen naval cargo, transport and auxiliary vessels have been awarded to shipyards on the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific Coasts. This was announced over the week-end by E. C. Upton Jr., acting administrator of the Maritime Administration.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- An all-winning performance by Naute Mia, an 8-year-old brown gelding, owned by Mrs. Robert A. Schmid of New York, was the highlight of the Bedford horse show at the Shannon Stables today. Naute Mia was entered in five events, won five blue ribbons and earned 25 points for the hunter championship.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that he expected New York waterfront employers to grant a union-shop contract. This would require all of the port's 35,000 longshoremen to join the old International Longshoremen's Association.
A mixture of rain and the Dodgers themselves simplified matters considerably for the Giants yesterday as the National League pennant race moved into its final week.

Averell Harriman and Senator Irving M. Ives were top-heavy favorites last night to win the Democratic and Republican nominations for Governor as delegates began assembling for the state conventions of the two major parties.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Optimistic Democrats said today that they expected enough gains in twelve key states to give the party control of Congress.
Four new films, including imports from Italy and Germany, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight that "nothing could prevent" the United States from retaliating if any nation ever made a surprise atomic attack.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 -- Today's Israelis brought here seventy-two mother tongues and at least that many variations on how to cook.

British sterling was definitely on the offered side last week chiefly at the instance of lower markets in London where there persisted the accumulation of American dollars for grain and other seasonal commitments.
