The Dodgers still had a good chance to win the pennant when the Flatbush burghers were exhorted to rally behind them with a "Back the Brooks" movement. This was to be a month-long festival through September with gay, cheering crowds of the faithful yelling like crazy as their heroes swept inexorably past the hated Giants and into another championship.

In issues of The New York Times for Sept. 3 and Sept. 10 the impression was given that "only recently" in 1950 the Vatican had modified its position on the use of the "so-called safe period or rhythm system." This error appeared in reports from the World Population Conference meeting in Rome until Sept. 8.

MADRID, Sept. 19 -- Spanish commerce and industry are going through a "difficult" period, according to Spanish economists. However, the country's economic situation is expected to improve because of this year's generally satisfactory agricultural production.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The schedule of thirty-eight Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regattas ended today on a note of high winds, confused seas, rain and a noteworthy absence of contestants. Seventeen boats turned out for the event, which was conducted by the Frostbite Yacht Club, using Larchmont's facilities.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Japan's Finance Minister, Sankuro Ogasawara, left last night by plane for the United States, where he will help arrange for Premier Shigeru Yoshida's projected visit.

Six year-round recreation centers and thirty-seven neighborhood playrounds will be started in 1955 as "a powerful weapon in the war on so-called juvenile delinquency," Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

The Navy announced yesterday that the ninth annual competitive examination for high school seniors who desired to attend college and to train fer careers as naval officers would be held throughout the nation on Dec. 11.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Treasury's announcement over the week-end that it would disclose new borrowing plans tomorrow has alerted the money markets to a long-awaited fall borrowing. Earlier expectations that this would include a new long-term bond have evaporated.
Disunity among Christians is a "public denial of the heart of the Gospel," the Right Rev. Lesslie Newbigin, Bishop of Madura and the Church of South India, declared yesterday.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Phenix City citizens will vote for a new City Commissioner tomorrow under the eyes of armed National Guardsmen and in an atmosphere free for the first time in many years of political corruption.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 19 -- Turkey has allowed three representatives of the Committee to Liberate Arab Palestine prolong their visit here after receiving assurances they do not represent the Moslem Brotherhood, a fanatical religious organization.

One of the most inspiring stories in the history of rebuilding in the Philippines is that of the formation of the Liberty Wells Association. This is a private undertaking that seeks through donations, many of them memorials, to provide the funds for accelerating the driving of artesian wells in the villages of the archipelago so that every villager may be assured of pure drinking water.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Following are items proposed for inclusion on the regular and supplementary agenda of the ninth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene here Tuesday.

State, county municipal offerings scheduled for sale this week aggregate $74,897,417 of bonds and $11,232,000 of short-term notes, according to the weekly report of The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. Last week $191,589,177 of bonds and $10,700,000 of notes were offered.

In a final hurricane crescendo the summer of 1954 signaled its imminent passing. Now summer is dying, its lush splendor spent. Over the land and in the cities it is quietly saying good-by, fading into the realm of time and memory. Now also the soft September days are upon us, swiftly stealing, gently gliding on to fall.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- British participation is the key to European unity and West German rearmament, Premier Pierre Mendes-France said in a speech in the city of Nevers today. He added that French-German reconciliation was essential to stability in Europe. He said this even though the occasion of his speech was the dedication of a monument to those who died in the resistance to the German occupation of France.
Prices of cotton futures followed divergent trends last week. Near contracts gained ground while distant deliveries moved lower.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 19 -- A 15-to-25 mile so'easter, rain squalls, whitecaps and a heavy sea greeted skippers today as they reported for the concluding test of the three-day one-of-a- kind series conducted by the Riverside Yacht Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 19 -- Henry F. Holland, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, spent four hours today with President Juan D. Peron discussing United States-Argentine problems.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs took a two-game hold on fourth place in the National League today when Roy McMillan's sacrifice fly scored Nino Escalera from third base in the tenth inning for a 7-6 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The British Government will be faced at the projected nine-power conference here with French requests for guarantees of Britain's continued military and political support on the Continent, it was learned tonight.
TOBERMORY, Scotland, Sept. 19 -- A Scottish duke, an Irish admiral and a shipload of young British sailors have joined forces here in a romantic undersea treasure hunt.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Sept. 20 -- The Chinese Nationalists said last night that their Formosa-based F-47 Thunderbolts, had damaged four more gunboats and destroyed at least thirty-six junks yesterday in renewed rocket - firing attacks against Communist shipping off the Fukien coast.

Reversing a downward trend, American colleges and universities will show a substantial increase in student enrollment this fail. An estimated 2,533,000 men and women, or 89,000 more than last year, are scheduled to crowd the nation's campuses as the 1954-55 academic year gets under way in most institutions today.

SAIGON, Sept. 19 -- The breach between Ngo Dinh Diem, Premier of South Vietnam, and Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese armed forces, widened here today and a showdown of some sort appeared inevitable.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Capt. John R. Wheeler, riding Little Mac. a 17-year-old Army horse captured in Italy during World War II, today won the jumping trials and a berth in the 1954 United States equestrian squad.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Pentti Karvonen of Finland claimed a new world record today for the 3,000-meter steeple chase with a time of 8 minutes 41.4 seconds during a German Finish track and field meet.

Picking up four points, one in an adjourned fifth-round game with Bulgaria, and three in the sixth-round match with Iceland, Russia yesterday regained the lead in the team tournament for the Hamilton-Russell trophy at the Apollo Hall, according to a report from Amsterdam.
A Protestant clergyman declared yesterday that pressure was being put on educators to bring more Bible reading, prayers and references to God into the schools.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- "American stock is low abroad," according to Dr. Paul A. Limbert, general secretary of the World's Alliance of Young Men's Christian Associations.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 19 -- Chile celebrated Independence Day, her biggest holiday of the year, today in what might best be described as a state of shaky optimism over strike problems.

BUFFALO, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions swarmed over the Pittsburgh Steelers, 42 -- 14, in a National Football League exhibition today before a crowd of 20,000 in Civic Stadium.

STOCKHOLM, Monday, Sept. 20 -- From returns 80 per cent complete early today in Sweden's communal election yesterday, it was clear that the Socialists and their Government partners, the Agrarians, had won against their Center and Rightist opposition.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, the national champion, today won the men's singles title of the twenty-eighth annual Pacific Southwest tennis tournament with a straight set victory over his Davis Cup team-mate, Tony Trabert.

Hasrollah Fatemi, former member of the Iranian Parliament and delegate to the United Nations, has written an account of the events of the last half-century that led to the present oil controversy and settlement in Iran. It will be issued next Monday by Whittier Books under the title "Oil Diplomacy."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- 25-knot southerly produced a "rails down" finish as George E. Roosevelt's schooner, Mistress, took the final leg on corrected time in the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's three-day club cruise which ended today.
Sales and earnings of the Vick Chemical Company rose to record highs in the fiscal year ended June 30, according to the company's annual report released for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Administration will begin this week a study of a five-day collection of opinions on tariff and trade that may help decide what one official has called "the future of free-world trade policy."

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- In a plea for widespread support of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, Dr. Albert Einstein said today that Israel was "the only place on earth where Jews have the possibility to shape public life according to their traditional ideals."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 -- A move is under way to revive educational television in Los Angeles, which lapsed when station KTHE, one of the first transmitters in the field nationally, shut down ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Mel Parnell limited Washington to six hits today to post his third victory of the year for Boston, 6 -- 2. All of Parnell's victories this season have been at the expense of the Senators. He has a 24 -- 4 life-time record against the Nationals.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- In the face of reports from Detroit that steel ordering from auto makers would not be strong for at least another month, the increase in the national steel rate last week was evidence of a continuing uptrend.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A Radcliffe College student, missing since Wednesday, was reunited with her parents early today after being recognized last night by a policeman.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept, 19 (AP) -- France's Robert Cohen, despite a sprained right hand, punched his way to a fifteen-round split decision over Thailand's Chamrern Songkitrat for the world's bantamweight title tonight. There were no knockdowns.
Twelve retired professors from leading colleges and universities were appointed yesterday by the John Hay Whitney Foundation as visiting professors at liberal arts colleges over the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Gale IV, one of the two entries of the Detroit sportsman, Joseph Schoenith, and driven skillfully by the 46-year-old daredevil, Wild Bill Cantrell, became the winner for 1954 of the President's Cup this afternoon.

Three four-story apartment buildings at 891-95 East 172d Street and 1525 Minford Place in the Bronx have been purchased by Victor Feldman from the Retailers Realty Corporation. The property has a combined assessed valuation of $57,000. Achilles R. Scharsmith was the broker.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves' last flickering pennant hopes went out the window today as the St. Louis Cardinals won in the ninth, 7 -- 6.

Last week the Administration issued the first interim revision of its original budget estimates for the fiscal year that began July 1. As things look at the moment, expenditures will be $1.6 billions lower than seemed probable back in January, but receipts will fall short of that first prediction by $3.3 billions. In consequence, the prospect at the moment is for a deficit some $1.7 billions greater than the $2.9 billions foreseen eight months ago.
SEASIDE PARK, N. J., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Runyon Colie Jr. of the Mantoloking Yacht Club Downer fleet battled wind, rain and wild seas today to win the Atlantic Coast Penguin sailing championship.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Republicans are in a "mood of desperation" since "that cold north wind from Maine" and "the Democratic tide is rolling," Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, told a party rally here today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government is to revive plans for a royal commission on coastal shipping, shelved three months ago when Canadian-United States negotiations on the St. Lawrence seaway were pending.
Russeks unfolded its presentation of import designs and line-for-line copies yesterday in an informal but handsome showing of models on the store's third floor.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- The air in Moscow today had an autumn nip and there has already been snow on some of the grain fields in Western Siberia. In short, the harvest season in the Soviet Union is coming quickly to a close.
Promptly at 7:45 this evening, the signal for the curtain to go up on "A Midsummer Night's Dream" at the Metropolitan Opera House will be given by Sol Hurok, importer of entertainment novelties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Credentials of the Czechoslovak and Polish delegates to the 1954 General Assembly of the United Nations were challenged today by the newly organized Assembly of Captive European Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- James F. Brownlee, New York financier and food executive, today was named head of a task force to study the ailing soft coal industry and other problems of energy and fuel supply.

TOBERMORY, Scotland, Sept. 20 -- The idea of searching for sunken Spanish treasure off the Scottish isles calls up visions of gold doubloons, galleons and fierce Highlanders, but the work in reality is hard, slow and uncomfortable.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, who has won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship eight times, took the qualifying medal in the annual event with a 42, 36 -- 78 at the Ridgewood Country Club today.
The judges stood up for a lawyer yesterday when Miss Mollie Strum, United States Department of Justice trial attorney, became the first woman president of the Federal Bar Association.
Marble Collegiate Church, a famed New York landmark at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, will celebrate its 100th anniversary next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Increased Government support for exploration and development of new mineral resources was urged today by mining men who gathered for the 1954 convention of the American Mining Congress.
" Business failures are human failures," according to Dun Bradstreet.
Mayor Wagner accepted two checks totaling $96,000 yesterday for the expenses of an infantile paralysis center that will open soon at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island.
The City Council moved yesterday to seek a legislative exemption of charity bingo games from the criminal penalties now contained in state laws against gambling.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Sept. 20 -- Benny Howarth, head coach of St. Mark's School's football squad, was working over his alignments for the day's practice and his assistant, Jake McCandless, was taping up a player's ankle when encountered this afternoon in the school's gymnasium.
HARTFORD, Sept. 20 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democratic nominee for governor, proposed tonight the creation of a state department of commerce to stimulate the "economic growth" of Connecticut.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The $5,900 Walnut Hall Farm Stake for 3-year-old pacing fillies today produced a world record and two starters for Thursday's $70,000 Little Brown Jug as a week of Grand Circuit activity opened at the Delaware Fair.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The prosecution contended today there "were no excuses for the acts" attributed to Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming during his three years in a Communist prisoner-of-war camp.

Leon Hoffman, president of the New York Press Photographers Association, formally explained yesterday to a "very sympathetic" police deputy the umbrella incident that led to the demotion and transfer of Detective James J. P. McShane.
If the Yankees are to become the winningest also-rans in base-ball history, they will have to sweep their last five games of the season.
The West Haven, Conn., School District, plans to sell $3,500,000 of school bonds on Sept. 28, it was announced yesterday. Maturities will run from 1955 to 1974.

The 7,551-gross-ton freighter Chantala of the British India Steam Navigation Company loaded cargo in Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, yesterday under the watchful eyes of thirty-nine youthful aspirants to officer rank in the British merchant navy.
ROME, Sept, 20 -- Moderately favorable forecasts for solution of the Trieste problem were being made after top-level Italian- American talks in Rome today.

The New York State League for Nursing and the New York State Nurses Association announced yesterday that they had approved the Joint Commission in New York State for the Improvement of the Care of the Patient.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Treasury Department announced tonight that its short term borrowing costs had again fallen below 1 per cent.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 14 -- Begum Liaquat All Khan, as founder-president of the All-Pakistan Women's Association, has led Pakistan's women into the political life of this nation. In contrast with the years before they won their franchise, the women now command legislative consideration in government assemblies.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly irregular yesterday. Active months moved 3 points higher to 10 points lower from last Friday's close.

NEWARK, Sept. 20 -- Former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. tonight called upon Republican leaders in New Jersey to replace Clifford P. Case, party nominee for United States Senator, with a compromise candidate.

Luther Rawlings scored a technical knockout over Frankie Fernandez at 2:29 of the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Abe Simon, the referee, stopped the fight when Fernandez became helpless from a steady onslaught by Rawlings.

Two-way nonstop airline service across the Pacific has become "a distinct possibility for the near future," according to Col. Clarence M. Young, executive vice president of Pan American World Airways' Pacific-Alaska division.

At the outset I want to congratulate you on the position you have taken concerning the recent bingo controversy. Many years ago, when a member of the Legislature, I introduced a bill in an attempt to legalize bingo and gambling, but organizations of all faiths were against it and it never saw daylight.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Tom Brewer defeated the Philadelphia Athletics with four hits today and Ted Williams slammed his twenty-eighth homer of the season as the Boston Red Sox maintained their hold on fourth place with a 5-2 victory.

Averell Harriman's nomination for Governor by midnight tonight appeared certain as Democrats assembled here yesterday for their state convention and faced their first convention floor fight in twelve years.
A proposal to increase the capital funds of the National City Bank of New York by sale of 2,500,000 additional shares of its capital stock was approved by stockholders at a special meeting yesterday.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 20 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon taxed the Democrats tonight with attempting to play off the farmer against the consumer.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Leaders of the tea industry were cautioned today against "wild price swings" which were termed "disruptive" by Anthony Hyde, executive director of the Tea Council of the U. S. .A., Inc.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -- Three Mexican airlines have combined to form the largest air transport system in Mexico under the name Aeronaves de Mexico, it was announced today.

Joseph T. Sharkey was elected to a full two-year term as Brooklyn Democratic leader last night at a meeting of the party's executive committee in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. Mr. Sharkey, the majority leader of the City Council, became the county chieftain last April 8 after Kenneth F. Sutherland resigned.

While Premier Mendes-France's new plan for European defense is being studied it may help to clarify the singularly confused atmosphere if we take a look at the internal political situation in France. Each country is engaged on two fronts, ours included.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Mrs. Annie Lee Moss went before an Army Security Board in secret session today to defend herself against charges that twice have caused her suspension, as a Signal Corps employe.

Subscription rights to 800,000 shares of common stock are being offered to stockholders of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company. The shareholders may purchase the new shares at the rate of one for each four held on Sept. 14, at $13.75 a share.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Nine Vietnamese ministers were reported to have resigned today as a crisis threatening to oust Premier Ngo Dinh Diem gathered momentum.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Bob Watson, the Ardsley Country Club professional, and Lyman Russell of the Westchester C. C., won the best-ball phase of today's pro-amateur tournament staged by the Westchester Professional Golfers Association at Siwanoy.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The segregation issue was thrown back into the classroom tonight by a cautiously worded statement from the Board of Education of this Mason and Dixon border line community.

THE Cleveland Indians won their first pennant in 1920 and the way was eased because the simmering Black Sox scandal of the 1919 world series did not erupt into the open until September of 1920. The indignant Charlie Comiskey, owner of the White Sox, suspended eight guilty players just as the championship homestretch was reached.

ROME, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization notified Gordon McIntire of Kewanee, Ill., today that it would pay him $$11,000 for wrongful dismissal rather than reinstate him.
YONKERS, Sept. 20 -- So many dogs are running at large here that the Yonkers Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals asked the city today for more funds.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced yesterday the first private placement of its dollar obligations -- $50,000,000 worth of them -- outside the United States.

A thousand angry members of Local 932, United Culinary, Bar and Grill Employes, C. I. O., last night forced the suspension of the local's twelve-man executive board. Their action was a direct aftermath to public charges last week that the local's officers had misused the union's welfare funds.

A Federal investigation is being made into charges that some of the thirteen Puerto Rican Nationalists on trial for seditious conspiracy were beaten and mistreated at prisons where they are being held.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- United States trade with other countries picked up in the first six months of the year, but the gap between what this country sells and buys abroad increased.
SEOUL, Sept. 20 (UP) -- "The stage is set for Korean unification, but by the Communists," Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin charged today in commenting on the plan to withdraw the United States Third Division.

Among the most impressive of the specific welfare activities of the United Nations is its world-famous Children's Fund, which in the nearly eight years since its establishment has extended life-giving help to scores of millions of individuals in nearly a hundred countries throughout the world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Department of Labor today reported there had been some small declines in the midsummer in unemployment in the Nation's key labor centers.

The possibility of the first major trans-Atlantic yacht race since 1935 emerged yesterday when Commodore John Nicholas Brown of the New York Yacht Club said he had received a cable from Sweden suggesting such a contest for next summer.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Martin P. Durkin, who preceded James P. Mitchell as Secretary of Labor, described Mr. Mitchell's speech to the American Federation of Labor convention today as "a cover-up for what the Administration hasn't done."
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A fifteen-story office building will be erected in the City of London on the ruins of a Roman temple of the second century A. D.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, promised his union convention today a full discussion of the group's relations with the rest of the American labor movement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The House of Representatives' subcommittee on Military Operations was back today from a twenty-day, 14,000-mile inspection tour of United States military installations in Europe. It reported that further hearings would be held here before its formal findings and recommendations were presented to Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals tallied five runs in the tenth inning to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 2, today before 1,746 fans. The Cardinals took fifth place from the Phillies by less than a half of percentage point.

Motifs of antiquity and influences from the Orient, the two strongest trends for fall in home furnishings and decoration, are reiterated in a series of decorating vignettes, a fabric collection and a group of model rooms, all introduced here yesterday.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 20 -- A clash between Dr. Daniel F. Malan, the Prime Minister, and Johannes G. Strydom, second most powerful man in the Nationalist party, has come out into the open. Dr. Malan is rumored to be opposing Mr. Strydom's ambition to become Prime Minister.
Music of countries behind the Iron Curtain will be played in Battery Park from noon to 2 P. M. today, the day of the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The United States Army identified today the two United States soldiers arrested by the Czechoslovak Communists and said the State Department was negotiating for their release.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Sept. 20 (AP) -- physician, Dr. Clyde M. Knowles Jr., who reportedly had the support of anti-vice crusaders, was elected to the Phenix City Commission today. Armed National Guardsmen had patrolled voting places to prevent election frauds.

" In this business," snaps Leo (Lippy) Durocher, "you get one guess. You get it now * * * right quick * * * you have to do something about it now * * * not later. They don't give you two guesses * * * don't let you go out to dinner * * * while you think it over. You've got to decide what to do * * * within seconds."
Blood donations were made yesterday by nineteen sailors from the British cruiser Sheffield to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

Amid a setting that scarcely could have provided them greater pleasure, Leo Durocher and his Giants last night crowned themselves champions of the National League for 1954. They achieved their goal in Ebbets Field where, before a gathering of 26,982, they soundly thrashed their arch rivals, the Dodgers, 7 to 1, in the opener of a three-game series.

If the bobsled event in the next Olympic games is not won by an American team, it will not be for the lack of scientific research. The members of one two-man team are so anxious to qualify as United States representatives in the international competition that they are giving their bobsled aerodynamic tests in a windtunnel.

NEWHALL, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Fifteen Civil Air Patrol chaplains and three crew men of an Air Force C-46 transport plane narrowly escaped death today. They parachuted just before the big craft crashed in flames on the Los Angeles City Prison Farm.

The ninth session of the General Assembly of the United Nations will convene at 3 o'clock this afternoon. It is a pleasure to welcome the representatives of the countries that meet here. They face difficult and complex problems and they need goodwill and understanding on our part as they approach them.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 -- A murder, one among many that happen month after month, has become a test case of justice in Mexico.
Mme. Colette Hebert, French baker at 1031 Third Avenue (Sixty-first Street), has reopened her shop, which had been closed while she was in Europe during the summer.
A mover's helper was charged by the police last night with stealing a $30,000 ring belonging to Mrs. Barbara (Bobo) Rockefeller, divorced wife of Winthrop Rockefeller.

CODY, Wyo., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Interior Secretary Douglas McKay said tonight the Republicans must keep control of Congress next year to prevent a trend toward "a Socialist empire of government ownership and control."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20-- Senate Majority Leader William F. Knowland today was reported studying whether the Senate should be convened within the next two weeks to vote on censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
A preliminary medical examination yesterday showed that the escort of an 18-year-old girl found mysteriously dead in Queens Sunday had been drinking before the accident that took his life.

An offer of $3,200,000 cash for the stock or assets of Ferro Machine and Foundry, Inc., Cleveland gray iron and aluminum foundries company, has been made by a group of investors. E. M. Knapp, president of Ferro, said in Cleveland yesterday that the company was "not for sale."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Government of Brazil has ordered a 50 per cent increase in the minmium bonus rates (agios) Brazilian importers pay when they buy United States dollars.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 20 -- The Government placed Chile under a state of siege, the equivalent of martial law, today as a result of tension over labor disputes. A few areas were left under normal administration.
The Weather Bureau is considering a new form of hurricane warning to alert the publice to possible damage from approaching storms, according to D. M. Little, acting chief of the bureau.

Reflecting greater gross revenues, net income of the Virginia Electric and Power Company in the twelve months ended Aug. 31 increased to $15,128,610 from $12,454,505 earned in the preceding year, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Radioactive finger rings are a new atomic-age contribution to industrial safety, an Army specialist on atomic medicine said today.
A Brooklyn jury found Thomas Wysokowski, 17 years old, guilty of first-degree manslaughter yesterday in the "stomp" killing of a 40-year-old father of four.

Hundreds of children in the neighborhood of Tenth Avenue and West Twenty-eighth Street treated themselves to an early Christmas last night when a truck containing thousands of toys was turned over at the intersection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- One of the hopeful claims made by some Democrats with respect to last week's election in Maine was that the overall drop in 1954 of 12 per cent from the vote cast for Republican candidates for Congress in 1952 was attributable to a national surge against the Administration's farm bill that in November will substitute many Congressional Democrats for Republicans in the agrarian areas.
Ed Danowski is the exception among football coaches. He is more grateful for what he has in assets than he is mindful and complaining of his team's shortcomings.

Directors of North Western Pulp and Power, Ltd., elected a new slate of officers yesterday as a further corporate step in connection with the financing and construction of a 300-ton mill for the production of bleached kraft pulp at Edson, Alberta.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 -- L. Judson Morhouse, acting state chairman of the Republican party, released today a list of twenty-seven names as possible choices for the ticket to be headed by Senator Irving M. Ives.
Sweet Girl was exactly that to those in the crowd of 20,052 who liked her at Aqueduct yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Warren Spahn of the Braves won his twentieth verdict of the season today with a 6-2 triumph over the Cincinnati Redlegs. The Milwaukee star is the first left-handed pitcher in modern major league history to achieve six twenty-victory seasons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow an additional $4,000,000,000 to meet the Government's bills.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 20 -- A light primary vote was recorded today in twelve cities and towns in Rhode Island where Democrats chose local candidates to oppose Republicans in the Nov. 2 election.
The smile on the face of the famous Mona Lisa was attributed facetiously yesterday to a "lump in the throat."
The state obtained a court order yesterday against a group of Quebec oil promoters accused of a $5,000,000 stock swindle, the largest in the state in fifteen years.

Diana Moncado, soprano, presented her debut recital last evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. A native of the Philippines, she has sung extensively in concert, her most recent appearance having been with the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra.

DENVER, Sept. 20 -- President Eisenhower, his five-day stay at his mountain retreat ended, returned to his desk today with emphasis on politics. He resumed work on major speeches for his swing next week into the Pacific Northwest and California and awaited the arrival of Republican National Committee officials.
REPORTS from both north and south indicate excellent prospects for the coming upland game and big game seasons, and the waterfowl outlook seems quite bright, at least on the Atlantic flyway.
They call themselves the dedicated family.

Millions of people in this country -- including many students destined to be leaders in Southeast Asia -- have read with disgust of the demonstrations on Sept. 14 in Greenbrier County, West Virginia, in which white school children and their parents protested against the amalgamation of their classes with those of dark Americans.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- After spreading rapidly through France, the Netherlands, Germany and Scandinavia, the artificially propagated rabbit disease called myxomatosis has encountered the wet weather of Britain and dissolved.

Esther Dorothy plays with colors in furs as a painter does with the pigments on his palette. While her colored furs have been seen in New York collections in previous seasons, she showed them in even wider range yesterday when she presented a fall and winter collection at the Sherry Netherlands.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Calling on a pair of relief pitchers, Ray Herbert and Bob Miller, in the ninth to preserve their lead, the Detroit Tigers beat the Orioles tonight, 4 to 3, to stay within a half-game of the fourth-place Boston Red Sox in the American League.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Dr. Roger Bannister, first man to run a mile in less than four minutes, today was selected for the Silver Pears Trophy -- awarded annually for the outstanding British achievement in any field.

Frank B. Laughlin, assistant collector of customs here since 1945, yesterday became the first local Customs Service civil servant to receive the Treasury Department's Exceptional Civilian Service Gold Medal.

Large-scale design, a trend that has been noted in recent furniture, is the most distinguishing characteristic of the new additions at Peck Hills, 214 East Thirty-fourth Street.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 3,351,826 shares as of the close of business on Sept. 15, the Exchange reported yesterday. This compared with 3,079,590 shares on Aug. 13 and was the largest short interest position since March 28, 1932, when it was 3,427,664 shares.

The three-story store and office building at 2251-2259 Broadway, southwest corner of Eighty-first Street, has been purchased by Samuel Reznick in a transaction negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co. as brokers. Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon Kaplan were attorneys for the seller and Halperin, Natanson, Shivitz Scholer acted for the buyer.

Cocoa prices opened easier but ended strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot September position was off more than 70 points early in the day as liquidation, following Friday's sharp decline, lowered quotations.

" A Star Is Born," the musical drama filmed in Technicolor and CinemaScope for Warner Brothers release, will have a simultaneous local premiere at the Paramount and Victoria Theatres on Monday night, Oct. 11. The picture will start its regular run at both houses the next morning.

For the last five years New Yorkers have been accustomed to seeing one or two of the "home" teams involved in the World Series. That the Yankees will be missing from this year's program has been apparent for some time. And a few weeks ago, when Milwaukee was riding the crest of a winning streak, many wondered if New York would have a National League entry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- A former undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Communist party testified today that the names of prominent Toledo, Ohio, residents sometimes had been placed on party rolls in an effort to confuse authorities.
Stocks rubbed out early gains in yesterday's market and closed with fairly general losses. Volume dropped with prices and ended the day at 2,060,000 shares, against 2,250,000 on Friday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 -- The 1954 Republican state platform will contain an endorsement of some form of a compulsory liability insurance law for automobiles.

A novel type of moving diorama in which full-color advertisements are shown every ten seconds and reappear every three minutes has been tested with considerable success in a supermarket in this city. The unit, which is manufactured by the Cinema Diorama Corporation, carried eighteen advertisements from noncompetitive food and allied companies for products usually sold in such stores
Stocks rubbed out early gains in yesterday's market and closed with fairly general losses. Volume dropped with prices and ended the day at 2,060,000 shares, against 2,250,000 on Friday.

Democratic and Republican leaders were urged again yesterday to consult with organized lawyers before making final selections of candidates for Court of Appeals and Supreme Court judgeships in the fall.
A new statistic was entered yesterday in the city's annals: the 75,000th apartment built by the New York City Housing Authority since 1935 was occupied.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Witnesses at a Senate committee hearing today named Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama as the rumored source of "influence" in Washington for Federal Housing Administration approval of mortgages that gave nearly $2,500,000 in "windfall" profits to two Alabama promoters.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 20 (UP) -- A stunt driver who sped a car over a cliff to his death apparently made the plunge intentionally, the coroner said today.

The rush of retail business last week surprised department stores. An "amazing Saturday," as one department store executive described it, enabled stores to move far above the level of business in the same week of 1953, itself an excellent week for sales.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The United States accepted today a British invitation to take part in the nine-power conference on German rearmament opening Tuesday, Sept. 28, in London.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- A South Korean Army leader charged today that the United States has restricted his army's ammunition and fuel to a two-day supply to prevent any offensive against North Korea.

Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President, opened yesterday morning a $600,000 campaign for the New York Association for the Blind by changing the street sign at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street to "Lighthouse Street."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Brazil's powerful Federation of Commercial Associations has recommended to the Government that foreign capital be permitted to participate in the development of the nation's oil resources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, returned today from a four-state campaign speaking tour and predicted that the Administration's foreign policy would be the major issue in November's voting decisions.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Communist China opened its annual campaign for United Nations membership today with a warning that failure of the United Nations to seat Peiping "can very well mean the end of the United Nations." This demand was backed by Pravda, the Soviet Communist newspaper.

The Permanente Cement Company, in its consolidated report for the six months ended on last July 31, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,430,000, equal to 87 cents a share. In the corresponding period last year the net was $2,272,157, or 81 cents a share.
A twenty-two-year-old independent union of mechanics voted yesterday to affiliate with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Judy Holliday, actress-comedienne; Steve Allen, pianist-comedian, and Dick Shawn, comedian, will be the principal players in Max Liebman's second Sunday night color show scheduled for N. B. C. television, Oct. 10, at 7:30 P. M.

Presenting a diversified line of finished cotton goods for spring and summer of 1955, M Lowenstein Sons, Inc., has set its prices on about the same level as those prevailing in the comparable seasons this year.
POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., Sept. 20 -- The bones of Chief Cornstalk, uncovered after sixteen hours of excavation, were reburied today at this small Ohio River town.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The stock market here, unsettled in face of selling in anticipation of the end of the bookkeeping account, recorded widespread small losses today.

Directors of R. K. O. Pictures Corporation yesterday extended until the close of business of next Dec. 31 the period within which stockholders may exercise their privilege of tendering stock ot the corporation for redemption at $6 a share.
GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- Europe is not building enough houses to care for its normal population growth. In most European countries standards of housing are below those of 1937.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Interest centered largely in the expiring September contracts in grain and soybeans on the Board of Trade today. Price currents were irregular as trades were evened and spreads closed out.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- After the black years of 1951 and 1952, Army football last fall came back almost to the pinnacle it had attained in the days of Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis. In their closing performance against Navy, the West Point cadets were a superb organization of striking power and resistance, primed with confidence and coached to perfection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Lowell Watson, a former Communist, testified today that he had collected money from Edward O. Lamb, publisher-broadcaster, in the early Nineteen Thirties after telling Mr. Lamb that part of his contribution would go to the Communist party.

Consolidated net income of the companies comprising the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company and the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., rose to 69,193,290 ($193,741,212) in the first half from 62,541,837 ($175,005,143) in the initial six months of 1953.

New designs in clear, brilliant Steuben crystal are on view today at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue, and in the Steuben Glass Room at Lord Taylor. These hand-blown pieces, both decorative and functional, include flower vases, low serving bowls, candlesticks and a cruet.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, scoring three runs on a wild pick-off throw, a wild pitch and a passed ball, beat the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 7, tonight and snapped an eleven-game Tribe winning string for the second time this season.
Milk is the ingredient that most effectively improves the food value of bread, according to experts in the field of nutrition.

Charles S. Hallock, who retired last year as special assistant to the manager of ship repair sales in this area of the Bethlehem Steel Company, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and for fifty-five years had been associated with ship repair work in Brooklyn. He resided in Brightwaters, L. I.
A realistic attitude toward the possibility of aircraft accidents was advocated yesterday by J. Carlton Ward Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the Flight Safety Foundation.

DIAMOND LAKE, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP) -- More than a hundred Oregon State Game Commission agents dumped chemical death into Diamond Lake today in what was believed to have been the greatest single effort ever made to restore a faltering game fish lake to usefulness.
The increased use of eyeglasses made of plastic and of specially hardened glass to protect the eyes against injuries from broken lenses was recommended here yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 21 -- The Iranian Government presented its oil settlement to Parliament today for ratification as an issue of confidence. The Government said it would stand or fall with the production and marketing agreement it has signed with the consortium of eight foreign oil companies.

For the first time this season, the New York City Ballet last night presented George Balanchine's "Prodigal Son" at the City Center, and it has been many a season since the old piece has been so lively and so lusty.

I have to apologize to The Times and its readers for not having expressed myself clearly in my letter on East-West trade which you kindly published in your edition of Aug. 30. This has led to the misunderstanding voiced in the letter of Montgomery M. Green, published in your issue of Sept. 8.

During the past week Secretary Dulles has gone out of his way publicly to demonstrate the fact of French isolation within the Western Alliance. He refused to go to Paris on his recent trip to the Continent and on his return from meetings with Chancellor Adenauer and Mr. Eden he fulsomely praised the German Chancellor but made no reference to a role for France in future Western arrangements. These were obviously calculated omissions.

A Government witness at the seditious conspiracy trial of thirteen Puerto Rican Nationalists testified yesterday he had acted as a Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent after joining the party in 1953.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 21 -- The Constituent Assembly today stripped Governor General Ghulam Mohammed of broad independent powers and sharply curtailed the authority left to him as nominal head of state. The action took the form of four amendments to the Government of India Act of 1935 as adopted for Pakistan.
Only 4,467 of the Flatbush faithful turned out at Ebbets Field yesterday to see the Dodgers lose their fifth straight game on a first-inning grandslam drive by Bobby Hofman.
LONDON, Sept. 21--British exports last month amounted to 205,600,000 ($575,680,000)--41,000,000 ($114,800,000) below the July figure.
Public offering will be made today of the largest public utility bond issue ever brought to market under competitive bidding.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Two anti-Communist picket lines outside United Nations headquarters, and a shower of anti-Russian leaflets inside the General Assembly hall greeted delegates to the opening session of the Assembly here today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The police reported today the recovery here of two cabin cruisers stolen in Michigan. They said the boats might be part of the loot from what they called a $100,000 boat theft ring operating in Great Lakes ports.

PUBLIC benefits frequently accrue from competition, but on Monday the Robert Montgomery show (N. B. C.-TV) and "Studio One" (C. B. S-TV) clashed with unmerciful impact. Not only did each program open the new season on the same night, but both offered strong advance appeals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The General Assembly opened its 1954 session today by voting to postpone until next year a decision on which government should represent China in the United Nations.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 21 -- What do people expect when they come to Danbury? The answer: some reminder of the seventeenth century.
FOR most people, to have a little farm of one's own and to live in the city involve long train rides on week-ends or commuting. Not so for George Morrison.

Harrison Salisbury's illuminating series of articles on inside Russia tell us, among other tidbits, that every one of the current top leaders measures approximately 5 foot 4. This uniformity in height certainly points up the well-advertised notion that they constitute a body of peers, with Premier Malenkov the acknowledged head, but a head among equals with Messrs. Khrushchev, Molotov, Bulganin, Kaganovich and Mikoyan.

Magistrate Nicholas F. DeLagi dismissed yesterday for lack of evidence a charge of theft against a moving man accused of stealing a $30,000 ring belonging to Mrs. Barbara (Bobo) Rockefeller, divorced wife of Winthrop Rickefeller.

An American co-defendant charged with fraudulent promotion of Quebec oil stock proved a "willing and cooperative witness" yesterday against Paul Payette of Montreal, the chief defendant, according to the State Attorney General's office here.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Hurricanes Carol and Edna have about wrecked the 1954 scallop season in this area.
Bankers Trust Company moved yesterday into the ranks of big local banks effectively acknowledging that they are making money this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP)William Henry Taylor, an International l{onetary Fund official, has been questioned by a Federal grand jury investigating charges that he and other former United States Government officials were members of a wartime Communist espionage ring.
BOSTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Jackie Jensen, voted the most valuable Red Sox player this year, responded by driving in five runs to power Boston to two 4-3 victories today over the Philadelphia Athletics.
BURLINGAME, Calif., Sept. 21 -- J. Harding Jensen, vice president and general manager of Matson Terminals, Inc., died unexpectedly today at his home. He was 45 years old.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 21 -- Per A. Norlin, managing director of the Scandinavian Airlines System, has announced his resignation effective at the end of 1954.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- Thomas E. Murray, member of the Atomic Energy Commission, recommended today that the United States build a nuclear power reactor in Japan to generate electricity.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington lobbyist and "mystery man," was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on five counts of perjury. The charges arose from his testimony two years ago before a special grand jury investigating corrupt practices by Internal Revenue Bureau officials.

" Home Is the Hero," an Irish drama by Walter Macken, Dublin actor-playwright-novelist, opens this evening at 8 o'clock at the Booth Theatre under the auspices of the Theatre Guild and Worthington Miner.
The Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries lifted net income for the twelve months ended Aug. 31 to $21,147,546 from $20,522,465 a year earlier.

The annual appeal of the United Community Campaigns of America will open with a special telecast on Sunday that will include messages by Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Harvey S. Firestone Jr., national chairman of the campaigns.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 21 -- Charles Woodruff Yost arrived here by air today en route to Vientiane, where he will become the first resident Minister from the United States to Laos. Mr. Yost was until recently Deputy United States High Commissioner in Vienna.
TWO of the artists exhibiting work this week are from the Far West, though neither one could, in any sense, be considered a regional artist without extra-local appeal.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- Yesterday, in Moscow, Leningrad and other centers, technical training schools were opened for graduates of the ten-year urban public school. The object of the schools is to divert a number of students from the pursuit of intellectual careers and train a new class of skilled technicians for industry, agriculture, transport and trade.
Sweeping liberalization of currency regulations designed to attract American capital to Italy is in progress, Ezio Vanoni, Minister of the Budget, declared in an interview here yesterday.
The chairmanship of the 1954 drive in the metropolitan area for 1,000 new members of the Seeing Ey Inc., has been accepted by Mrs. Harry C. Mills of 888 Park Avenue and Rye, N. Y.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The Church of England, one of Britain's biggest landlords, is to sell by auction about 1,500 properties in the Paddington district of London. The sale, beginning next May, is expected to raise the equivalent of $5,600,000.

Conflicting and confluent currents of importance to the future of American labor are now building up. On the one hand an impressive surge has set in toward greater unity between the A. F. L. and the C. I. O., as well as within the federations themselves. But strong centrifugal forces are also at work -- as implied, if not openly expressed, by President McDonald in his speech to the United Steelworkers convention on Monday.
Bonds totaling $45,136,000 were sold in the public market by ten government entities yesterday. In addition, two cities announced plans to sell $29,900,000 of bonds next month.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 21 -- Gen. Lee Heung Keun, chairman of the South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff, appealed to the American people today for more weapons and equipment to ward off communism.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 -- Following are excerpts from addresses today at the United Nations General Assembly by Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, outgoing Assembly President, Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union, George K. C. Yeh of China and Richard G. Casey of Australia, and the text of the remarks by Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens of the Netherlands, newly elected President of the Assembly:

Nowhere is the fashion versatility of fur more evident than at Maximilian's. It is expressed in the lightweight pliability of mink, broadtail, nutria and Persian, which, because of the designing ability of Anne Maximilian, adapt themselves to the new silhouettes as they axe expressed in fabrics.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The American Motors Corporation announced plans today to slash millions in production costs of its 1955 Nash and Hudson automobiles by using the same basic body shell on both cars.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The Permanent Commission of the Brussels Treaty Organization began today to discuss changes in the pact that would permit the entry of West Germany and Italy.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Bob Turley, the American League strikeout leader, led Baltimore to a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight to clinch seventh place for the Orioles.
Retailers are optimistic about business in the remainder of the year but more cautiously so than economists. The latter have been predicting general gains, but the retailers are more selective.

AFTER appearing at the Edinburgh Festival during the summer the Old Vic has brought its "A Midsummer Night's Dream" to the Metropolitan Opera House, where it opened last evening. This is the colossal masque with the Mendelssohn music, sixty experienced musicians and Moira Shearer and Robert Helpmann in the leading roles.

Scattered general buying and short covering pushed coffee prices up the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Only the spot September option failed to rise the limit, closing 145 points higher. Volume was 94,250 bags. Offerings of coffee futures were light. The spot price of Santos 4's rose 1 1/4 cents a pound to 70 3/4 cents.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The Stanley Cup champions, the Detroit Red Wings, and the Montreal Canadiens will be the host teams Oct. 7 when the National Hockey League opens its coming season on the earliest date in its thirty-eight-year history.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 21 -- Refugees from North Vietnam demonstrating in favor of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem were fired on today by the police and Army security units. Five refugees were reported to have been killed and a number of policemen and refugees injured.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, will depart for Paris and London tomorrow morning. He will leave behind him considerably improved prospects for a solution of the Trieste problem.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 21 -- Vice Admiral Alfred M. Pride, commander of the Seventh Fleet which is charged with the defense of Formosa, is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow morning to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- Anti - Communist legislation passed at the recent session of Congress will eliminate Communists from mining unions, Senator Pat McCarran predicted before the American Mining Congress here today.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The British Government told the envoys of eight Arab states today that it was gravely concerned over the situation on the borders between Israel and her neighbors. It said it believed talks should be held to settle their differences.
DENVER, Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower approved today a program aimed at bolstering the economy and military strength of South Korea.
The International Longshoremen's Association lowered its retroactive demands on the New York Shipping Association yesterday but insisted there would be no further concessions.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 21 -- Yesterday's declaration of a state of siege was accepted quietly by Chile and today the labor situation in the copper mines that have been on strike was reported almost normal. No incidents were caused by yesterday's announcement.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and the Ohio Company is offering 200,000 common shares of the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company at $29.25 a share today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Transportation companies would be materially aided if Government agencies lost their privilege of shipping personnel and freight at reduced rates, Richard L. Bowditch, chairman of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today.

Rumors that Governor Dewey might succeed Eric A. Johnston as president of the Motion Picture Association of America were scotched yesterday by the announcement that Mr. Johnston had accepted a new contract that will keep him in office through Oct. 15, 1961.
Governor Dewey and the Republican state and national administrations were denounced repeatedly yesterday by Mayor Wagner and other speakers at opening sessions of the Democratic state convention.

A decorative motif simulating the gambling casinos of Monaco and Monte Carlo will form the background for the annual dinner dance of the Mobile Clinic of the Speyer Hospital for Animals on Nov. 9 in the St. Regis Roof.

Another obstacle in the struggle for the Hamilton-Russell chess trophy was overcome by the Soviet grand masters yesterday when they defeated Yugoslavia, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in the eighth round, according to a report from Amsterdam.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Piero Piccioni, son of Attilio Piccioni, former Foreign Minister, and a self-styled marquis, Ugo Montagna, were arrested tonight on charges of having been involved in the Wilma Montesi case. The body of Signorina Montesi, 21-year-old Roman girl, was found on a deserted beach twenty miles south of Rome April 11, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Flying Tiger Line and Slick Airways today asked permission to call off their proposed merger, saying that labor protective problems had proved insoluble.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21 -- The platform committee of the Republican state convention heard today with obvious relief some kind words on one of Governor Dewey's favorite proposals, public development of Niagara power.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today after hearing a New York builder testify about an unprofitable housing project in Indiana that he blamed the Federal Housing Administration for poor business judgment.
A code of standards for cigarette advertising, as suggested by the Federal Trade Commission, is favored by the American Tobacco Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization ordered today outlays totaling $145,000,000 in the present fiscal year for twenty-two critical materials needed to complete the minimum goals of the national security stockpile.

AN increasingly acute shortage of competent waterfowl guides in the area within a fifty-mile radius of the city, coupled with the high cost of a day's shooting, is leading a number of wildfowlers to assemble their own shooting rigs.

The Duchess of Kent and Sir Roger Makins, British Ambassador to the United States, were among a large number of notables who attended the opening of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Former Representative Hamilton Fish announced plans last night to organize a nonpartisan "states' rights" and "anti-internationalism" organization to be known as the American Political Action Committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Sinclair Refining Company jointly announced today plans to build one of the largest ammonia plants in the Middle West. The new facility will be erected in Hammond, Ind., near Standard's Whiting refinery and Sinclair's East Chicago refinery.
To keep any metropolis healthy today, its citizens must be persuaded to pay the price of living in a changing world, Dr. Leona Baumgartner warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Army is studying the possibility of moving supplies in ships carrying loaded freight cars from the continental United States to distant places such as Alaska.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Moroccan merchants and shopkeepers in Casablanca, commercial capital of the French North African protectorate, closed their places of business today in answer to a strike call by the anti-French nationalists.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21--Senator Irving M. Ives of Norwich, the prospective Republican candidate for Governor, gave the nod today to State Controller J. Raymond McGovern of New Rochelle as his running mate for Lieutenant Governor.
DENVER, Sept. 21 -- A program seeking to relieve unemployment in distressed coal fields in the United States while aiding underdeveloped foreign countries was approved today by President Eisenhower.
The exact role of the Soviet Army in the events attending the death of Stalin and the arrest and execution of Lavrenti P. Beria remains somewhat unclear.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Chamber of Commerce enthusiasts began preparations today for the all-Arizona (trained) world series opening in New York, Sept. 29.
The time is at hand for a large-scale medical research program to find the cause of, and a treatment for, the common cold, scientists agreed here yesterday.

An unusual step toward all-coast negotiations will be taken when representatives of East, West and Gulf Coast shipowners and the American Federation of Labor deck officers' union meet Friday in San Francisco to discuss the focal point of present contract talks -- a new, union-proposed pension plan.
Prices of cotton futures moved 10 points higher to 7 points lower yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21--West German officials indicated today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer probably would not accept the French proposals as a basis for negotiating the arming of West Germany at the forth-coming London conference.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Pope Pius XII was reported much improved in health today after two days without audiences. He was, indeed, so much better that the next mass audience, which was scheduled to take place on Thursday, has been put forward one day and will be held tomorrow.
BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Daylight Saving Time ends next Sunday -- unless you live in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Hampshire or a few communities in Vermont.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Producers cut hog marketings today and prices responded with gains of 25 to 50 cents on both butchers and sows. Salable receipts at 7,000 head were 3,000 below the advance estimate.
Shouting, singing, snake-dancing demonstrations, bearing all the earmarks of a Presidential convention, erupted here last night during nominations for Democratic candidates for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- One hundred and six oil and gas companies will move tomorrow against the Federal Power Commission's order blanketing the natural gas industry under Federal regulation. The companies range from the giants of the industry to the smallest independent operators.

Gifts from Jewish communities in Amsterdam and The Hague were presented last night to Congregation Shearith Israel of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, 2 West Seventieth Street, in honor of the congregation's 300th anniversary.

The stock market yesterday more than recovered its losses of Monday. After a hesitant start, the market worked gradually higher in slow trading. Final prices were at or near their best for the session, with selected oils, steels, rails and chemicals making the best gains.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- A top Communist official has outlined plans to whittle down Hungary's "bureaucratic" state apparatus and put white collar workers into overalls, turning out productive instead of paper work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Agriculture Secretary Ezra Taft Benson denied again today that political pressure had caused him to junk the toughest section of the Government's new crop-control program.

The American Broadcasting Company announced a series of executive promotions and departmental consolidations yesterday, affecting its radio and television networks. It also was learned that at least five executives, including two vice presidents, have resigned from the company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- At about 9:30 P. M. on May 9, 1940, the Foreign Minister of the Netherlands was handed a five-word message from a secret agent in Germany. It read: "Tomorrow at dawn; hold tight."

The hurricane effect which the election of a Democratic Governor of Maine has produced in this state and in the nation should not be taken as a signal for unbounded enthusiasm and optimism on the part of the Democratic party. Maine elections are notorious for their concentration on local issues and personalities. This year's Gubernatorial contest was no exception.

As 17-year-old Patricia Russell of Gilboa, N. Y., underwent surgery at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center yesterday, the organization that is financing her entire care announced a benefit theatre party. Miss Russell is paralyzed from the neck down, save for a limited ability to move her arms.
Democrats who had been envisioning a bright live television pick-up of their voting for a nominee for Governor found last night that the prospect at first blurred -- and then faded out completely.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The Federal grand jury began today its investigation into Federal Housing Administration loan scandals in the Chicago area.

The first decline in Latin-American draft indebtedness in five months was recorded in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the draft experience of fifteen commercial banks.

A method by which several noncompeting manufacturers could join in offering a premium of considerable value to a dealer was outlined yesterday at a conference of the Premium Advertising Association of America. The session was held at the Astor Hotel in conjunction with the New York Premium Show which opened on Monday and will continue through tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, today blasted Big Ten athletics officials and others as "isolationists and selfish men" intent on severing years of harmonious relations between college and professional football.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Marian Hall, the new $700,000 science and art building of Marymount College here, was opened today. Registration began for a record 550 students.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 21 -- This community's two public schools were closed again "until further notice" today in the face of mounting tension and threats of violence over efforts to abolish segregation.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Republican primaries and caucuses in Fairfield County last night ran counter to the wishes of several town committees, which spent today patching up party fights.

Today's new film is "Sabrina," Paramount's version of the Broadway romantic comedy "Sabrina Fair," co-starring Humphrey Bogart, Audrey Hepburn and William Holden, at the Criterion. Billy Wilder produced and directed, from an adaptation of the Samuel Taylor play, written by Ernest Lehman, Mr. Taylor and Mr. Wilder.

Few pitchers achieve twenty victories in a season. Fewer do it in their first year in the majors, but Bob Grim, the 24-year-old ex-Marine from the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn hit the jackpot yesterday with a 3-1 triumph over the Washington Senators at the Stadium. And last spring Grim's name was not even on the New York roster.
Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., disclosed last night that it plans to buy the Clearing Machine Corporation of Chicago for $9,000,000 to $10,000,000.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- Dave Beck, president of the country's biggest union, asserted today that employers should go to jail along with union leaders in cases of welfare fund fraud.

Ashley Trimble Cole, chairman of the State Racing Commission, yesterday was asked what his board would do in the event of locality or civic objection to a long meeting such as the one proposed in the revamping of the local scene. Cole honored the question, then asked his secretary, Harry Millar, to circulate the following typewritten response:
The text of the keynote speech by Mayor Wagner at the Democratic state convention at the 165th Infantry Regiment Armory yesterday follows:

OTTAWA, Sept. 21 -- The Liberal party, which governs Canada, has begun a campaign to destroy the dominant political party in the Province of Quebec. The Liberals maintain the Quebec party is a threat to national unity and an obstacle to progress.
Development of a new printing press for medium and small newspapers was announced yesterday by R. Hoe Co., Inc., the country's oldest maker of printing equipment.
The company that makes, the most cigarette-selling machines has absorbed the company that mixes soft drinks at the nudge of a coin.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Five drivers were unseated but all escaped serious injury in an accident which marred the featured $8,035 Breeders' Filly Stake for 3-year-old trotters on the Grand Circuit harness racing card today.

Two bands in Battery Park yesterday entertained hundreds of persons with music from Soviet satellite countries. The program, one of the weekly New York Festival concerts, included works by Chopin, Paderewski and Dvorak.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Jean Simmons, who just completed co-starring with Marion Brando in "Desiree" at Twentieth Century-Fox will team again with the actor in "Guys and Dolls."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee said today foreign countries probably would buy about 18 per cent more American cotton during the 1954-55 marketing year than they took last year.
Whirling full skirts, a wide, jutting bodice line and intricate back detail were typical of Carrie Munn's designs, which were presented yesterday in her showroom at 640 Madison Avenue.

Federal alcohol agents of the Treasury Department seized a still on Staten Island yesterday from a bootlegging gang whose two-month venture in lawless liquor had cost the Government $1,000,000 in lost taxes.
DENVER, Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower heard from his top political strategists today that the November Congressional elections presented "a good picture" from the Republican viewpoint.

Donations on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 440 pints of blood. Included were 187 obtained at Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street, and 112 at Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America, C. I. O., 113 University Place.

The Randolph Singers, David Randolph conducting, sang a program of madrigals at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening as one of the series of Interval Concerts currently being presented there by Norman J. Seaman.
DENVER, Sept. 21 -- President Eisenhower asked peoples behind the Iron Curtain today to join Americans in prayers for peace tomorrow.

Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday morning at a pontifical mass of thanksgiving, marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and the Infirm. The mass was celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Summer Tan beat Nashua in the $30,025 Cowdin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. There were eight other contestants in the six-and-a-half-furlong test for 2- year-olds, but the 18,779 fans calculated that the race would be virtually a match event between Mrs. Russell A. Firestone's Homebred and the Belair Stud's son of Nasrullah.
The Philharmonic-Symphony's 1953-54 season of concerts resulted in a deficit of $124,205.

EXETER, N. H., Sept. 21 -- This year's Phillips Exeter Academy's football squad may not be deep in experienced players, but it certainly is geographically representative of the United States. Boys from nineteen states, ranging from Colorado to Florida and Texas to Maine, make up the group that went through a two-hour practice today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, threw back at James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, today the "unfair" tag the Cabinet officer sought to pin on the federation yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Uhleen Fingo, a 4-year-old brown mare owned by C. T. Black of Berryville, Va., sloshed through the mud to a length victory over Titanic in 2:08 3/5 tonight to win the Louisiana Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Dissident New Jersey Republicans, all but convinced that they cannot force Clifford P. Case to withdraw as the party's candidate for United States Senator, now plan to work for his defeat in the November election.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Sept. 21--Adlai E. Stevenson tonight called the Senatorial contest in Illinois a political struggle between representatives of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson made a flying visit to the Republic Aviation Corporation plant here today in an effort to speed deliveries of hundreds of F-84F fighter-bombers lined up on the ramp awaiting final work.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The United States believes the Soviet Union may be preparing a full-scale propaganda campaign for unconditional prohibition of the use of nuclear weapons, a report issued today said.

GENEVA, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The New York State Department of Insurance has been asked to investigate the operation of a labor union Welfare fund here, according to Clare L. Touhey, attorney for the Geneva Builders Exchange, bargaining agency for local contractors.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Two women workers were stoned, seven persons were beaten and nine pickets were arrested today at the Square D. Company in this city's worst picket line violence since the labor battles of the Nineteen Thirties.

Recent experiments have shown that the intake of fluorine reduces tooth decay in children up to the age of 8 or 9. It does not benefit older individuals. Yet certain influential political and dental groups exert pressure to have fluorine added to the entire city water supply.

Averell Harriman won the Democratic nomination for Governor early this morning when a last-minute attempt to stampede the Democratic state convention in favor of Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. collapsed.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., Piping Rock, posted a 39, 36 -- 75, three over par, to take a three-stroke lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal-play championship at Piping Rock Club today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs used home runs today to beat the St. Louis Cardinals twice, 4 to 3 in ten innings, and 3 to 2 in seven innings, before 2,119 fans.
The discovery of a second vast canyon deep below the surface of the North Atlantic was announced here yesterday by Columbia University scientists.
The assignment of Capt. Gaines A. Tyler as chief of staff of the Third Coast Guard District was announced here yesterday by Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, district commander.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Milford situation developed over the week-end when more than 1,500 persons gathered at the American Legion Hall in the center of this primarily agricultural community to hear a discussion of the integration problem.

There will be thirteen singers new to the Metropolitan Opera during the coming season, which opens on Nov. 8. Rudolf Bing, general manager, also announced that there would be two conductors new to the Metropolitan, Dimitri Mitropoulos and Rudolf Kempe, and that six singers would return after an absence of a season or more.

For the first time since the depression of the Nineteen Thirties the annual book circulation of the Brooklyn Public Library has topped 8,000,000. This was noted yesterday in the annual report of the library for the fiscal year ended June 30.

" THE queerest fish among the eccentric worthies of the Middle Ages," according to George Bernard Shaw, was Joan of Arc. The warrior maiden from the Marches of Lorraine was a saint in Shaw's opinion; but Shaw's opinion of what constitutes a saint differed rather substantially from that of the Roman Catholic Church, which canonized Joan in 1920.

I MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Lefty Joe Nuxhall limited the Braves to six hits today for a 5-0 Cincinnati Redlegs' victory before the smallest Milwaukee crowd of the season, 10,001, in 56-degree temperature.

Senator Estes Kefauver called yesterday for a dramatic manifestation of this country's peaceful motives to counteract the mounting success of Soviet propaganda, which depicts us as warmongers building atomic weapons to destroy the cities of the world.
BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Bob Watson, Ardsley pro, led the field in the Metropolitan open golf championship with a record round today.

Three Brooklyn transportation companies received permission yesterday to operate school buses on eighteen routes in the borough on which service was suspended last spring for lack of franchises. The resumption of service will affect 6,000 students.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (UP) -- A Crowd estimated at 250,000 -- more than one-quarter of the population of Cleveland -- whooped for the Indians today as the 1954 American League pennant winners rode in a cross-city parade.
Bernard Newman, who creates ready-to-wear originals for Bergdorf Goodman, has a subtle, refined way with clothes.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21 -- The Fifth meeting of the Colombo Plan Consultative Committe got under way behind closed doors today to allow for frank discussions among delegates of achievements thus far and future needs.

THE New York Giants trailed the Brooklyn Dodgers by the trifling margin of thirty-five games at the end of last season. Less than a year later the Polo Grounds tenants have picked up the equivalent of more than forty games on their arch-rivals from across the bridge. How come?
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon challenged Adlai E. Stevenson tonight to "let the American people know what his party would do if it came to power."

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Chester Bowles, former Ambassador to India, said today that American aid to undeveloped nations is "timid and inadequate," and he offered a seven-point program of United States grants to strengthen it.
