The lack of sun this week, the drought early this summer and the recent hurricane could not prevent the American Dahlia Society from staging its fortieth annual show. The event, in which the Horticultural Society of New York is cooperating opened yesterday in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, 160 Central Park South, and may be seen again today from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Commerce Department today laid its finger on declining national security outlays as a "fundamental development" in the business downturn since last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to authorize the first of a series of mergers. Alleghany said it proposed to carry out the mergers now that it had control of the New York Central Railroad system.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- A slightly better tendency developed on the stock markets here today. Selling of industrials was lighter and most markets closed steady. British funds continued to improve with undated long and medium dated issues rising two shillings sixpence (35 cents) or half that much.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration, calling the case a major test, said today it would battle in a New Jersey court to unseat the directors of a Fort Lee apartment project. The administration has charged that the directors made windfall profits from F. H. A.-insured mortgages.

Bjorn Wiinblad, Danish artist and potter, celebrated his thirty- fifth birthday on Monday by setting up an exhibition of his ceramics, posters, paintings and printed fabrics at Georg Jensen, 667 Fifth Avenue. The showing, opened to the public yesterday, will continue through Dec. 2.

The city has reduced the height requirements for prospective policemen by half an inch in an effort to obtain more of them quickly, a Municipal Civil Service Commission spokesman said last night. The new minimum has been set at 5 feet 7 1/2 inches.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest transportation system, up to the end of last month was still in the red for this year.
Trading increased yesterday on many of the New York exchanges. Potatoes and hides experienced the fourth heaviest activity of the year and copper had the highest volume since April 12.
ROME, Sept. 22 -- Schoolboys were heartened and foreign diplomats expressed their gratification when Dr. Gaetano Martino was appointed Italy's new Foreign Minister last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Cardinal Spellman of New York today made a formal tour of a postage stamp exhibit he is sponsoring at the National Philatelic Museum to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the first postage stamp issued by Vatican City.
The state Democratic organization placed itself on record yesterday as favoring residential rent rollbacks, legalization of bingo and repeal of the Condon-Wadlin Law.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 -- The lead of Representative Jacob K. Javits in the race for the Republican nomination for Attorney General lengthened tonight as a result of the acceptance by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. of the similar nomination at the Democratic State Convention in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Acting Secretary of State, forecast today the eventual return of freedom to the "millions of oppressed peoples behind the Iron Curtain."

A new disinfectant product that will make completely inactive all three poliomyelitis viruses, and thus make safer rooms where they existed, has been developed in the German laboratories of Lehn Fink Products Corporation.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Thursday, Sept. 23 -- Desperate prisoners broke out of their solitary confinement cells at the Missouri State Penitentiary last night. In the ensuing riot at least three prisoners were killed and fourteen injured.

THE poem for today is from "Songs for Eve,"* a fine book of new lyrics by Archibald MacLeish, who is growing old as a serene scholar in wisdom and young as a bucking colt in the swinging liveliness of his verse:

While the twelve chess teams in the Hamilton-Russell Cup competition rested yesterday, with the Russians ahead, the fourteen countries in the consolation tournament contested ninth-round matches, according to a report from Amsterdam.

THE general angling picture is not bright, except for those who will settle for bottom fishing, although fair catches of bluefish are reported at Barnegat Ridge off New Jersey, and at the Race on Long Island Sound.
Leonard Hall made a strong plea here last night for the election of Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Louis F. Budenz, a member of the Fordham University faculty and a former high official of the Communist party, told a Senate investigating panel today that peaceful coexistence with the Soviet Union was impossible, now or at any time.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 -- Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck declared today that continuance of the Republican party in office at Albany would be assured by stressing to the voters the achievements of "the twelve golden years" under Governor Dewey.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Labor party leaders reaffirmed today their support of the arming of West Germany. But their resolution was in general terms, designed to hold every waverer when the issue is debated at the annual party conference in Scarborough a week from Friday.
DENVER, Sept. 22 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to state and territorial chief executives on a survey of educational needs:
That perennial favorite -- black -- appeared in both basic and elegant roles at yesterday's showing of designs by Oldric Royce of 16 East Fifty-second Street.

SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 22 -- Twelve huge United States atomic cannon were maneuvered through the narrow streets of German villages and across the many bridges of the Northwest German plain today, preparing to support opposing sides in the mock war that began at noon.

A $160,000,000 issue of Kansas Turnpike Authority's 3 3/8 per cent revenue bonds was sold at public offering yesterday. The offering was made by an underwriting group of more than 375 members under the co-management of Smith, Barney Co., The First Boston Corporation and Beecroft, Cole Co.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today that the Eisenhower farm program was designed to bring prosperity to the farmer by giving the American system "a chance to work."
Underwriters offering the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new issue of debentures yesterday were almost as busy placating disappointed customers as they were selling the security.

The annual E. H. Harriman Memorial Medals and Certificates have been awarded to fourteen railroads for fine achievement in the conservation of human life during the year 1953, an achievement happily not marred by yesterday's train wreck out West, in which there appear to be no fatalities.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 22 -- South Africa has proposed a system of bases with a reserve of military supplies in Africa south of the Equator as part of regional defense that she is promoting.
BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Bob Watson, Ardsley pro, maintained the lead today at the end of thirty-six holes in the Metropolitan open golf championship.
The Allstate Insurance Company plans to enter the residential fire insurance business in New York State on Oct. 11, with rates averaging 20 per cent below those now charged by other companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, said today the committee probably would hold its delayed hearings on the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract early next month.

In Moscow today the party is over when Premier Georgi M. Malenkov starts for the door. But, often enough, Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the party's Central Committee, lingers behind for one last word.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- British officials and diplomats of the continental powers concerned are emphasizing that definitive results should not be expected from next week's nine-power conference on West German armament and sovereignty.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Peggy Mackie of the Inwood Country Club turned in a 40, 37 -- 77 today for a total of 155 and a two-stroke lead over Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal-play championship tournament at Piping Rock.

Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society will present six new works chosen by Mr. Scherman in "open house" auditions during their eighth season of Town Hall subscription concerts, beginning Monday, Oct. 25.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Robin Roberts pitched Philadelphia to a 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh in the second game to give the Phillies a sweep of a double-header tonight after a seventeen-hit attack had humbled the Pirates, 12 -- 1, in the twilight opener.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- A tape recording of a forty-minute telephone conversation involving most of the obscenities in the English language punctuated the opening today of a Congressional inquiry into labor union welfare funds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was urged today to junk its recent order freezing natural gas prices and work out a new system of regulating independent producers.

ROCQUENCOURT,France,Sept. 22 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, urged France today to forego complicated safeguards against German aggression in her demands at the London conference next week.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 22 -- A reproduction of the "Black Maria," Thomas A. Edison's first motion picture studio, was dedicated here today. The ceremony was a tribute to the inventor, whose 107th birthday anniversary will be celebrated tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A. Philadelphia judge "reluctantly" ruled today that the law setting up Pennsylvania's censorship code for movies was invalid.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- Vauxhall Motors, the British branch of the General Motors Corporation, today announced plans to spend 36,000,000 ($100,800,000) on plant expansion in the next five years in a bid to double exports.

The first filter cigarette to carry the name of one of the big manufacturers was announced yesterday by P. Lorillard Company. It is an Old Gold filter king-size cigarette, and heavy advertising will break soon in New England on the theme, "A famous brand name with a true filter and true flavor, America's first family of cigarettes, regular, king, filter kings."

Today it's good-by to summer for another year. September, the door that stands between the season past and the autumn here, is swinging shut. For the good and the bad that comes and goes September alone is to blame. We recall the hurricanes and steady drizzles, the bleak and dreary days -- they were in September.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A suit asking $90,000,000 damages was filed against eighty-five major railroads today by Riss Co. of Kansas City, Mo., one of the nation's largest motor carriers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 -- Tjong Hoen-nji, often described by the Chinese community here as its number one anti-Communist leader, has been arrested by the newly formed Bureau for Surveillance of Foreigners. This is the first case handled by the bureau since its establishment last week.

MARTINSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 22 -- If President Eisenhower is "sick and tired" of hearing "prophets of gloom and doom," several million unemployed workers are "sick and tired" of hearing about boom economy, Representative Charles R. Howell, Democratic nominee for Senator, said here tonight.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The newspaper Asahi said today Japanese scientists had "almost conclusive evidence" that the Russians recently exploded a hydrogen bomb on an island 500 miles northwest of Nome, Alaska.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored four runs in the fourth and two in the ninth inning to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 3, today. Brooks Lawrence limited the losers to five hits to gain his fourteenth triumph. Stan Musial accounted for three of the winners' nine hits. The box score:
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Nationalist planes sank five Communist gunboats today in the twentieth straight day of raids on the Red China coast, the Defense Ministry reported.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT EISENHOWER, Sept. 22 -- President Eisenhower headed for three days of Western politicking today after picturing his role in the Republican fight to hold Congress as a delineator of the broad issues rather than as a slugging campaigner.

Casey Stengel will continue to manage the Yankees the next two seasons. Accepting the challenge of the rebuilding job that confronts the dethroned champions, the 64-year-old pilot yesterday signed for 1955 and 1956 a new contract at the old but still fancy figures, estimated at $80,000 annually.

MILFORD, Del., Sept. 22 -- The Milford Board of Education said tonight it intended to reopen this community's two public schools on Monday with Negro pupils in attendance at the previously all-white senior high school or resign in a body.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Roy Mack and his brother, Earle, emerged from a three-hour closed-door meeting today with no announcement on the future of the Philadelphia Athletics, reported on the brink of a shift to Kansas City.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter, who hopes to become the only lightweight in history to regain the title twice, hammered out a methodical ten-round decision over Freddie (Babe) Herman before a slim crowd at the Cow Palace tonight.

Niagara Falls, N. Y., sold $4,340,000 of public improvement bonds yesterday to Chase National Bank and associates. The bonds, which mature from 1956 to 1975, were awarded on a bid of 100.3209 for securities bearing interest at 1.6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- The Government tried to bring the problem of high coffee prices into focus today by reporting that world coffee production had exceeded consumption by 1,000,000 bags this season.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 -- The feeling grew here today that David J. McDonald's battle with the Congress of Industrial Organizations would be fought as a war of nerves.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 -- The Republican state convention adopted unanimously tonight as its 1954 campaign platform an 11,000-word document that described itself as "a proud record of contrast between our deeds of performance and the carping hypocrisies of political opponents."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 22 -- A talked-about alliance between the Brazilian Labor party of the late President Getulio Vargas and the Communists became clearer today. Imprensa Popular, leading Communist paper in Rio de Janeiro, announced that all Communists should vote for the Labor candidates in the election Oct. 3.

Twenty-three members of The Jockey Club met in the president's room at Belmont yesterday and gave formal approval to The Jockey Club plan, announced last Monday, for the rehabilitation of New York's race tracks.
WALTER MACKEN'S "Home Is The Hero," which opened at the Booth last evening, represents three acts of conscientious writing and acting. In Dublin it may mean something that escapes us here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The ten delegates who will speak for the United States in the committee rooms of the United Nations met today with their chief, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A Senator from the Philippines said today his country must gain trade concession to meet its international defense commitments.
The transfer of five police officials was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Secretary of State Dulles will address the United Nations General Assembly at 4 P. M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- J. Edgar Hoover reported today that crime was on the increase in the United States. If the current trend continues, he said, major crimes will reach an all-time high this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Senate leaders were expected to convene the Senate Tuesday or Wednesday to vote on whether Senator Joseph R. McCarthy should be censured.
The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, yesterday praised sales promotion campaigns by the food industry.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 -- Following are the conclusion and a summary of pledges in the Republican state platform as adopted by the party's state convention here tonight:

A former Red Army officer testified here yesterday that millions of dollars given by United States Jews for developing a Jewish autonomous area in Birobidzham, in the Soviet Far Eastern part of Siberia, had been diverted by the Communists to other uses.

A mysterious increase in blindness among premature infants in the last twelve years, which has terrified pediatricians, was declared here yesterday to be "intimately associated" with the routine use of oxygen in nurseries.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Colgate opens its football season against Cornell Saturday and it is going to Ithaca with high hopes of winning, even though the Red is a two-touchdown favorite.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians, newly crowned pennant winners, tied an American League record today by winning their 110th game when a rookie, Don Mossi, pitched a five-hitter to beat the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 1.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- British scientists have found out what caused three disastrous crashes of the British Overseas Airways Corporation's de Havilland Comet, pioneer jet airliner. All Comets were grounded after the crashes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Watkins committee received today from Mr. McCarthy's lawyer a motion to strike from its records testimony given by Charles L. Watkins, Senate Parliamentarian. Mr. Williams said he had handed the written motion to Senator Watkins.
Women bus passengers of the "one-arm-riding" variety were blamed yesterday for marring slightly what would have otherwise been an excellent safety record in the operation of the city transit system.

Mortimer Smith, author of "And Madly Teach," has a new work about education and educators on Henry Regnery's schedule for Oct. 19 publication. Entitled "The Diminishing Mind: A Study of Planned Mediocrity in Our Public Schools," the book "decries the collapse of disciplined learning" in the public schools and gives a "frightening" picture of the programs of "life adjustment" the educators are trying to substitute in its place.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Representative Usher L. Burdick complained today that he was "cleaned" on a recent trip to San Francisco and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, said today that officials from half a dozen responsible government agencies had granted that New England received "no adequate warning" of the approach of the hurricane Carol.

On Sept. 14 it was reported in the press that the city was planning to increase recreational facilities in twenty-five public housing developments. Since many of these developments are located near or adjacent to some of the areas in which recreational services have been notably lacking in the past, such action by the city will be widely applauded.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 13 to 25 points yesterday.

When the federal budget is of a magnitude where Government spending accounts for between one-sixth and one-fifth of the gross national product, and when the Government debt is within striking distance of the $300-billion mark, fiscal policy must be administered with proper regard for its effect on the economy as a whole.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The attempt of a handful of dissident Republicans in New Jersey to force Clifford P. Case to withdraw as his party's Senatorial nominee is a clear recurrence of the suicide drive from which the G. O. P. occasionally suffers. This small group of die-hards is apparently determined to rule the party or to wreck it.
Twenty-five thousand students will converge today on Columbia University's various schools as the institution opens its third century.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 -- An amnesty for all convicted under the anti-Communist law is awaiting the signature of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Bishop Janos Peter of the Reformed Calvanist Church charged today that "certain American political figures and official organs attempted to confuse the joy of our meeting with shrewd machinations" at the assembly of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Steve Gromek pitched a four-hitter for his eighteenth victory of the season and Harvey Kuenn became the first American Leaguer to collect 200 hits as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4 -- 1, today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP) -- A new plan to abolish Alabama's compulsory public school system and let the parents say whether they want segregated classrooms has been recommended by a legislative committee and group of lawyers.
The house of Revillon Freres, known for the classic elegance of its styles, has stressed this year a new approach to the handling of furs.
Velvet bows and print linings provided perky touches for classically draped furs in yesterday's showing of Bette Yokova designs for Jack Stein, 660 Fifth Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Robert Taylor will star in "The Trial," and Charles Schnee will produce the film adaption of the Don Mankiewicz novel, to which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday acquired screen rights in advance of publication.

Three girls, the golden, the lavender and the green, held the center of the stage yesterday afternoon at Lilly Dache's unusual showing in her penthouse at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. They typified her new theories on the appearance of women.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, said tonight Adlai E. Stevenson's choice of adjective "dreary" to describe the Eisenhower Administration was the proper one.
Arnold E. Linton has been named manager of the tube manufacturing plant of the Radio Corporation of America, at Woodbridge, N. J.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of the keynote speech at the Republican state convention by Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck of Schenectady, temporary chairman of the convention:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The steering committee recommended today that the United Nations General Assembly take up Indonesia's complaint that the Netherlands had refused to hand over Western New Guinea.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- The American Federation of Labor convention applauded today a demand that the free nations bomb the Soviet Union if Communist forces crossed a line to be fixed by the Western powers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Early rallies in wheat failed to hold today, and prices for grain futures went into a sharp slump before running into any good buying support.
FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 22 -- A court-martial here today found Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming guilty of collaborating with the Communists while a prisoner of war in Korea in 1951.

For those Americans who believe that the world-wide war against communism must be waged with more than guns, President Eisenhower's speech of April 16, 1953, to the American Society of Newspaper Editors was thrilling. After outlining a course of international action that could lead to general disarmament, he said:
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves defeated Cincinnati, 3 -- 1, today in a game ended on a weird note with the umpires calling out a Redleg base runner on an interference penalty play.
ONE of the larger current art exhibitions is that at the Serigraph Gallery. One hundred and thirty-seven works by Japanese printmakers, 1660-1858, are on view.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Army awarded to the General Motors Corporation today a $35,000,000 contract for M-42 self-propelled guns.
York Avenue's junior gardeners sang and danced for joy over a good harvest yesterday. But for officials of the New York Plant and Flower Guild the event was touched with sadness.

" Howdy Doody," the National Broadcasting Company's television puppet, will be commentator at a special children's concert to be played in Symphony Hall, Boston,. at 11 o'clock on Saturday morning, Oct. 23, by an orchestra of leading Boston musicians. A repeat performance will be given at 2 P. M.

Many members of society from the Long Island colonies, New York, Westchester and New Jersey attended the opening program of the twenty-five-day fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association yesterday afternoon at Belmont Park.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Britain won the largest number of votes in the election today of seven vice presidents to serve at the 1954 session of the General Assembly.
OTTAWA, Sept. 22 -- Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec has again defied Federal authority in response to an attack by Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent against his leadership and Administration.

Yesterday's showing of Bloomingdale's Green Room fashions presented many interpretations of fall's leading trends that were thoroughly wearable. The average woman probably will have no hesitancy in selecting them.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate to the United Nations, said here today that the agreements reached at the Geneva conference were "neither final nor complete."

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Terence Rattigan scored a great success with his double bill, "Separate Tables," which opened at St James' Theatre tonight. The London theatre critics were virtually unanimous in their enthusiastic reception of the two plays, both set in the same genteel, small, seaside hotel, and sharing the same cast.

French Canada is unique in the world, an island that retains its faith, language, ideas and habits of mind from centuries back. It is a state within a state, almost divorced from the dominant English-speaking, Protestant British element which holds most of the territory and 48 per cent of the population compared to 31 per cent of French origin.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. agreed last night to run for Attorney General on the Democratic state ticket, which Averell Harriman had previously been chosen to head.

Tomm Byrne, saved by a triple play in the sixth inning, hurled the Yankees to a 3-0 victory, their 102d of the season, over the Washington Senators yesterday at the Stadium. Byrne's five-hit shutout before 2,117 fans was fashioned a few hours after Casey Stengel had been rehired as manager of the Bombers for the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 15:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 -- Henry F. Holland, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, arrived here today and faced demands that the United States find some way to guarantee Chile a "fair" price for her products.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- Communists in the Senate called today for the resignation of Premier Mario Scelba. They accused him of "favoring" a person or persons responsible for the death of Wilma Montesi last year.
Following are excerpts from the platform adopted yesterday by the Democratic state convention:
Following are sketches of the candidates nominated yesterday at the Democratic State Convention here:
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Medley Hanover scored by a length over Nemma Hal in the Minnesota Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, covering the mile in 2:06 1-5. White Mountain Boy was third.

Stock Exchange prices broke out of a period of apparent uncertainty yesterday with broad gains on rising volume. The New York Times industrial average hit its highest mark since Oct. 24, 1929, and the combined average was at its best since May 15, 1930.

Donald Dixon, International News Service correspondent who was held prisoner by the Chinese Communists for eighteen months, returned yesterday to the home he left forty months ago to cover the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Supreme Court announced today that it would hear arguments beginning Dec. 6 on the decrees it should issue to enforce its ruling outlawing segregation in public schools.

The recurrent drive against New York City noise has received official recognition with the introduction into the City Council of legislation calling for a study of ways and means of eliminating unnecessary noise and increasing the penalties for violating anti-noise ordinances now on the books.
LAKE PLACID, Sept. 22 -- Conflicting traffic laws in this state were described today as likely to label as a criminal a motorist guilty of a traffic infraction.

" Living Blackboard," public service educational series televised by WPIX in cooperation with the New York City Board of Education, will return for its fourth year on Tuesday, Oct. 5. It will offer courses designed for all age groups, an expansion of the original format that was for high school students only.

VENICE, Sept. 22 -- "Porgy and Bess" scored a triumph in its Italian premiere here tonight. The eagerly awaited presentation of the folk opera at La Fenice Theatre ended Venice's seventeenth International Festival of Contemporaneous Music.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The United States Government is approaching the nine-power conference in London next week with a more hopeful and conciliatory attitude than existed here a few days ago.

Deposits in the 527 mutual savings banks of the nation rose $117,000,000 during August to reach a new high of $25,651,000,000, according to J. Hamilton Cheston, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to cancel the charges made by railroads for unloading fruit and vegetables at New York and Philadelphia.
Averell Harriman was on a political merry-go-round yesterday. It was his first day as the Democratic candidate for the Governorship of New York State.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Japan may sign a reparations agreement with Burma this week. It would be the first such agreement between Japan and one of the countries she attacked during World War II.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and Columbia University will offer evening and Saturday courses in the history of fine arts and in cultural history for the third consecutive year at the museum, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street. Five courses will be given in the winter session.

The post of President of the General Assembly is becoming more important as the years pass. The Assembly has greater powers than it had before the Korean war and each year sees the international situation take on new complexities and dangers.

Karl Spooner, a 23-year-old southpaw pitcher, yesterday hurled the Dodgers to a 3-0, three-hit triumph over the Giants at Ebbets Field to break the Brooks' five-game losing streak and leap headlong into the record books.

The Standard Oil Company (N. J.) announced last night that it wanted to acquire about 2,867,000 additional shares, or 8 per cent more of the capital stock of one of its principal subsidiaries, the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

A decline last week of 1,492,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the week-end were 151,787,000 barrels, compared with 153,279,000 a week earlier and 141,648,000 a year ago.

In a letter published in The Times on Sept. 21 P. E. Hockings of Sydney, Australia, claims that millions of Australians "read with disgust" reports of demonstrations by white parents against their children having to mix with "dark Americans" in their classes.

During the past week I have been reading the various accounts in The New York Times concerning the enforcement of existing regulations prohibiting bingo games in the city of New York. I would like to take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the numerous readers of your worthy newspaper the feelings of the Greek Orthodox Church concerning this matter.
A 7.9 per cent decline in sales was reflected in a sharp drop in earnings reported yesterday by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the nine months ended July 31.

Robert B. Smallwood will give a tea today at his apartment in the Ritz Tower for Lady Ravensdale of London, and members of the committee arranging a literary auction for the benefit of the Allied Circle of London. The American Friends of the Allied Circle is sponsoring the auction, which will be held on Oct. 31 in the galleries of French Co., 210 East Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, advocated today that courts of appeal be given power to increase or decrease sentences for crime imposed by the lower courts.
DENVER, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower smiled with tears in her eyes today when a tiny cerebral palsy victim tried valiantly to pronounce the name "Eisenhower."

W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, which has allocated $4,000,000 for airborne radar, yesterday termed the ellectronic equipment one of the greatest technological advances in commercial aviation in ten years.

The Brooklyn Public Library is facing an increasingly critical problem with the departure of many of its librarians for other jobs at higher pay and with the mounting difficulty of attracting new librarians to the borough at the pay rates in force here. The serious situation created by staff vacations in the summer compelled the Brooklyn Library several months ago to announce the closing of forty-two of its fifty branches and offices on Thursdays.

When Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully won $110,000 in the Washington Park Handicap early this month, the horse's trainer, T. J. Kelly, said he was going to use his 10 per cent of the purse to buy his family a house.

This morning at 8:56 (E. S. T. that is) summer ends and autumn begins. Confirmed city dwellers are likely to be more indifferent to such matters than those who live closer to the soil, although both recognize the changing season in one fashion or another.
The text of Averell Harriman's acceptance speech at the Democratic state convention last night follows:
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- For the first time in a week industrial shares, or some of them, rose on the Stock Exchange today.

A bank "showcase," newest and largest of the Manufacturers Trust Company's 111 metropolitan branches, was opened for inspection yesterday at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. The $3,000,000 building, its five floors enclosed in huge glass panes, will be opened for business on Monday, Oct. 4.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- A 225-car pilgrimage rode from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial today to commemorate the ninety-second anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation freeing the slaves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Charles P. Taft, president of the Committee for a National Trade Policy, told United States bicycle manufacturers today to get down to work instead of "asking for a monopoly wrapped up in the American flag."

SVOLVAER, Norway, Sept. 22 (UP) -- A Norwegian coastal liner ripped its hull on a reef and sank within twenty minutes today, but quick action saved all but two of the ship's 300 tourists and crew members.
Securities totaling $20,000,000 were sold in the public market yesterday by two public utilities.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Brooks School's first intra-squad football scrimmage today helped produce answers to some questions confronting Coach Nick Evangelos. The Green and Black, it seems, has a well-balanced squad and Evangelos is trying to decide on his starters.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 22 (UP) -- Charles F. Murphy, czar of the nation's comic-book industry, said today he had ordered an immediate stop to distribution of horror, terror and gory crime comic books. He told a joint meeting of the Bureau of Publishers and Independent Distributors and the Central States Distributors Association:

The Playwrights Company begins its seventeenth season on Broadway tonight with the premiere of "All Summer Long," a new play by Robert Anderson, at the Coronet Theatre. The curtain is scheduled to rise at 8 P. M.
Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, urged the United States and British Governments last night to reconsider their present arms policy in the Middle East.
The New York Shipping Association announced yesterday that it had offered a wage increase of 8 cents an hour, retroactive to Oct. 1, 1953, to the International Longshoremen's Association.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The village board tonight gave United Nations Secretariat employes the go-ahead sign to come into this community to establish a multi-national housing development.

A contract for the construction of two supertankers, the first vessels of the 45,000-deadweight-ton class to be built for American interests, has just been signed between the Tide Water Associated Oil Company and the Mitsubishi Shipbuilding and Engineering Company, Ltd., of Japan.

A 4 A. M. long-distance telephone call from Senator Herbert H. Lehman, vacationing at Sun Valley, Idaho, to Carmine G. DeSapio at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday started the chain of events that brought about Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s nomination for Attorney General.
Fifty thousand new citizens will be sworn in at mass ceremonies in the nation on Veterans Day, Nov. 11.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (UP) -- The raw materials director of the Atomic Energy Commission said today that there was "little chance" that Russian production of uranium was equal to that of the Belgian Congo -- "the free world's leading producer."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Defense Department, in a new manual for wartime field censors issued today, warned all three services against abuse of their power to suppress information.

Bars and taverns did better in 1953 than in 1952. This was revealed, somewhat to the surprise of the trade itself, in a survey of 226 establishments in all parts of the country by Dun Bradstreet, made public yesterday.

The appointment of John C. Crary Jr., as counsel to the State University of New York was announced yesterday after the monthly meeting of the university's board of trustees at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
CAIRO, Friday, Sept. 24 -Egypt's ruling military junta yesterday deprived of nationality six Egyptians accused of acts abroad considered to be treasonous.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -President Eisenhower called tonight for the election in November of a Republican-led Congress to avoid "stagnation and inaction."
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- Indonesia's Premier extended his Government's support to India today by denouncing the Southeast Asian defense treaty.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 23 -An authoritative Government source said tonight that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem had reached agreement with political groups outside the Government for a reorganization of his Cabinet.
Five thousand members of the American College of Physicians gathered in twenty-three cities yesterday to get a television report on the latest methods for the management of high blood pressure.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 23 -Israel said today that United Nations observers had violated the state's sovereignty by patrolling on the border without Israeli authorization.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The British Government disclosed today that the "Flying Bedstead," the vertical take-off jet aircraft developed here for experimental purposes, had been tethered during its initial tests to safeguard the machine and the pilot.

Refrigerator Cheese cake, an easy-to-make version of a classic dessert, suggests a fitting finish for many fall meals. For a family supper, such as soup and salad, the cake rounds out the menu by supplying the high quality protein of cottage cheese.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $263,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Government rested its case yesterday in the seditious conspiracy trial of thirteen Puerto Rican Nationalists after four witnesses testified about the March 1 shooting of five members of Congress in the House of Representatives.

Concurrently with a statement indicating that its six-month sales had dropped sharply to the lowest level in thirty years, the American Woolen Company announced yesterday that it would open a joint sales office with Textron, Inc., and Robbins Mills.

One of the biggest closed-circuit television presentations for industry was staged yesterday for 20,000 package store and tavern men in twenty-seven theatres from coast to coast by the Frankfort Distillers Company. In New York alone the company rented five theatres.

The moat that guarded one of this city's old localities from the nationalistic tenor of New York proper has been bridged once more, and it is to be feared that Greenpoint stands ready to lose its individuality.

The annual fund-raising campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York opened yesterday with a luncheon for volunteers and team captains at the Barbizon Hotel for Women, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- On the eve of President Eisenhower's talk here tomorrow the American Federation of Labor convention adopted today a slashing attack on the record of the President's Administration.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) at a meeting yesterday in Chicago declared a 100 per cent stock dividend in addition to the regular quarterly payment in cash of 62 1/2 cents a capital share. Both dividends will be paid on Dec. 1 to stock of record Oct. 25.
The Railway Express Agency, Inc., announced yesterday the purchase of 3,000 one and a half-ton pickup and delivery trucks at a cost of $9,500,000.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The first of the Government decrees introducing Premier Pierre MendesFrance's program for the reconversion of French industry appeared today. It creates a fund of 5,000,000,000 francs ($14,500,000) for aiding industrial reconversion and assisting French industry to compete in foreign markets.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- American League club owners will meet in New York Tuesday to discuss and perhaps act on the expected sale of the Philadelphia Athletics by the Mack family.

In the game of musical chairs the players march around a circle of chairs to musical accompaniment. Suddenly the music stops and each player dashes madly for a chair. There is always one chair too few; one player is left standing, and must go out.
Condemnation of the 10.63 acres required for the New York University-Bellevue slum clearance redevelopment project was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23 -- Republicans, facing their first state campaign since 1938 without Thomas E. Dewey as a standard bearer, nominated at their party convention today a slate headed by Senator Irving M. Ives of Norwich for Governor.

GENEVA, Sept. 23 -- A special study published today concluded that Europe will need all the fuel it can get during the next ten years. Indeed, by 1963, according to experts of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, there is likely to be a serious and chronic shortage unless coal output is vigorously encouraged.
Shouts of dismay greeted the action of the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday in approving a site for a new Junior High School 62 in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Victor Darnley, driven by Cecil Champion, rushed through the stretch to gain a head decision in 2:06 2/5 from Singing Sword in the Wisconsin Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 24 -Aikichi Kuboyama, one of twenty-three Japanese fishermen injured last March when the ash from a hydrogen-bomb explosion sprayed the sampan, Fukuryu Maru died last night in Tokyo Hospital.

The International Longshoremen's Association rejected yesterday the latest employer offer of a 10-cent wagewelfare package and retroactivity to Oct. 1, 1953. The action, which was reported by Patrick J. Connolly, executive vice president of the union, was voted at a meeting of its Atlantic Coast District Wage Scale Committee.
American industry puts entirely too much faith in price as a sales stimulant, the National Industrial Conference Board was told yesterday at its 351st meeting, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Secretary of State Dulles expressed hope today that a new international agency to "explore and develop the vast possibilities for the peaceful uses of atomic energy" would be in operation next year.

Borough President Edward G. Baker of Staten Island and former City Court Justice Jacob J. Schwartzwald were nominated last night as the Democratic candidates for the Supreme Court bench in the Second (Kings and Richmond counties) Judicial District.

Following are close-ups of the major candidates nominated yesterday at the Republican State Convention Syracuse as running mates for Senator Irving M. Ives. A biographical sketch of Mr. Ives was printed in The New York Times on Sept. 9.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -Simon D. Strauss, vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, urged the nation's miners today to reduce their reliance on Government assistance and to depend more on their own efforts to improve technology and broaden markets.

PARIS, Friday, Sept. 24 (AP) -The French Ministry of the Interior said early today that it had suspended a former Paris police inspector after he was found carrying secret national defense documents he was not authorized to have.

Following are the texts of addresses by President Eisenhower at the McNary Dam in Oregon yesterday afternoon and at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles last night, a transcribed by The New York Times and The Associated Press:

By defeating Czechoslovakia, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in the tenth round at Apollo Hall last night, Russia's chess team fulfilled expectations by clinching the international team tournament and retaining the Hamilton-Russell trophy, according to a report from Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Finance Minister Sankuro Osagawa of Japan predicted today that with the help of sound money policy his country could squeeze through the fiscal year with a $60,000,000 trade deficit, compared with more than $300,000,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Representatives of the nation's wool growers asked the Government today to raise price guarantees on domestically produced wool an average of about 11 cents a pound or around 20 per cent.

There are no major changes in college football's playing rules for 1954. However, two new officials' signals will be on display with the full-scale opening of the varsity gridiron campaign this week-end.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Lou Perini, owner of the Braves, tonight presented to the Milwaukee County Park Commission a check for $225,000 to increase the rent on County Stadium this year ten times. Perini's action was voluntary.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (UP) -- A former building company operator invoked the Fifth Amendment today when Congressional investigators asked him about his "business connections" with a salesman linked with Detroit's "model home" racket.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Although the Soviet Union has the largest submarine fleet in the world, the United States has the weapons to win a war underseas, Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- A former Communist admitted today he probably never had used the words "Communist party" when he collected contributions from Edward O. Lamb, publisherbroadcaster, in the early Nineteen Thirties.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 711,228 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The riot at the Missouri State Penitentiary here was brought under control today.

QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Simon Canarte Barbero, publisher of two anti-Government newspapers in Guayaquil and member of the Chamber of Deputies, was shot in the back and wounded today while entering the Chamber building.
Two new films will arrive at local theatres today.
Averell Harriman decried his Republican opponent for Governor, Senator Irving M. Ives, last night as a "gliberal," and criticized seven votes he said Mr. Ives had cast.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- If Syracuse had its huge line of a year ago with the fine array of backs now wearing the Orange there wouldn't be much question that it would rate with the better teams of the country.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The stock markets here were cheerful again today as a modest demand for the sounder industrial equities brought small but fairly widespread advances.

For many months it has been expected that if Governor Dewey did not run for re-election Irving M. Ives would be the Republican nominee for Governor. The party's state convention in Syracuse has now confirmed that expectation. From the Republican standpoint this is a wholly logical development, for Mr. Ives is in the state's liberal tradition, as is Mr. Dewey.

The mysterious eye affliction called congenital glaucoma, which is a major cause of blindness, is best handled when recognized promptly and treated by surgical means. This was the conclusion here yesterday of a special symposium on congenital glaucoma at the annual meeting of the America Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Indians and white children sat side by side in school today as New York ended more than 100 years of segregation.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A white marble statue of the head of Mithras, an Eastern deity, has been unearthed in a Roman temple in the heart of the City, or financial district, of London. The statue is believed to be about 1,800 years old.
BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 23--Otto Greiner, professional at the Knickerbocker Country Club, Tenafly, N. J., became the new Metropolitan open champion today.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Nathan I. White of Brookline, Mass., asserted today that there was no basis in fact to a charge that his brother, the late Harry Dexter White, had tried to withhold "a half-billion dollar loan" to Nationalist China after it had been approved by Congress.

A parade of wooden soldiers, portrayed by young women in society, will be a feature of the Toy Ball to be held on Oct. 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, and the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

The Metropolitan Opera ballet has engaged Mia Slavenska as guest ballerina for the coming season. She will make her first appearance on the opening night of the season, Nov. 8, in the triumphal ballet in "Aida," choreographed by Zachary Solov, choreographer in chief of the opera company.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The United States Seventh Fleet, reinforced by units of the Pacific Fleet, is winding up two weeks of airsea maneuvers in the Formosa straits, United States military sources disclosed here today.

The Federal Maritime Board reached its full strength yesterday as G. Joseph Minetti, Brooklyn lawyer and former Commissioner of Marine and Aviation in New York City, was sworn in as third member by Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UP) -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., scored his second upset in the Pacific Coast tennis championship by defeating the sixthseeded Bernard Bartzen today in the quarter-finals, 6--4, 6--3, 2-6, 3--6, 6--1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Arrangements for Jane Wyman to star in "Miracle in the Rain" and for Frank Rosenberg to produce the picture at Warner Brothers have been completed, a studio source confirmed today.
DOVER, Del., Friday, Sept. 24 -- The Delaware State Board of Education took over the two public schools in near-by Milford early today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -Recommendation that union welfare funds be federally-regulated and administered by "neutral" agencies, such as banks, was made today to a House of Representatives subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had authorized Middle South Utilities, Inc., of New York -- one of two power groups concerned with the controversial Dixon-Yates contract -- to issue and sell 475,000 additional shares of its $10 par common stock.

After showing her latest designs at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, Pauline Trigere took over as commentator. When the models lined up for the final number she said in husky French accents: "I think they look pretty cute myself."
BITBURG, Germany, Sept. 23 -- A tank filled with more than 1,000,000 gallons of United States jet fuel blew up during a firefighting demonstration at an Air Force tank farm today.

THE "twang" of a long bow is heard in many a backyard and apartment house basement these days, for the archery hunters are getting in practice for the opening of the big game season, usually two or three weeks in advance of the firearms season.

Motors, chemicals and a few of the rails charged ahead yesterday in what looked for a time like a runaway stock market. The New York Times combined average hit a new high since May 14, 1930, the industrial average a high since Oct. 24, 1929.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The Philippine delegation to the United Nations is to have two chief delegates at the current General Assembly session, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo and Ambassador Felixberto M. Serrano. This was announced today by the delegation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 -David J. McDonald disclaimed any intention today of pulling his United Steelworkers of America out of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were unchanged from those of the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WHY do New York apartment dwellers bother with dogs?

A restaged production of "Aida" will open the fall season of the New York City Opera Company next Wednesday evening at the City Center of Music and Drama. Frances Yeend will sing the title role, Giorgio Cocolios-Bardi will make his debut as Radames, Gloria Lane will sing Amneris and Lawrence Winters will be heard as Amonasro.
Events tonight: Felicia Vlodek, soprano, Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street; "Lucia dl Lammermoor," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, both at 8:30 o'clock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver charged today that a "sinister group" including the Senate Republican leader, Senator William F. Knowland of California, and Gen. Mark Clark, apparently was trying to get the United states into a full-scale war with Communist China.
Ties between London's famous Old Vic and Robert Helpmann, who scored in the triple capacity of actor, dancer and choreographer in "A Midsummer Night's Dream," have been strengthened.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Failure of many traffic safety programs in this country was attributed today to individual lawlessness behind the wheel of the "best citizens who profess to uphold highway protective projects."
The American Labor party, fighting the threat of extinction as a political group in this state, nominated last night its candidate for Governor and other offices in the November elections.

The five-story building containing forty-one apartments at 7612 Park Avenue in North Bergen, N. J., has been sold by the First Jersey Enterprises, Inc., to the Allison Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Eisenhower Administration asked all United States Attorneys today to help document, completely and quickly, "the nature and extent of corrupt practice in the Federal Housing Administration."

This year's state election campaign in New York now appears to present to voters a choice between a Democratic-Liberal coalition whose political philosophy might be described as left-of-center and a Republican ticket committed to a middle-of-the-road course.
This is the story of the lives of three Russians--Ivan and Dmitri and Maria-- of how they live and work, of what they dream and what they fear.

A public hearing on the Transit Authority's plan to curtail Brooklyn bus service was ordered yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The authority itself asserted that no final action had been taken on the cuts.
ONE of the oldest of press box aphorisms is this: A football writer is a baseball writer with a vest on.

UNION, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Senator Edward Martin, Republican of Pennsylvania, spoke here tonight in praise of the Congressional record of former Representative Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate for United States Senator from New Jersey.

Homemakers should not have to scout far for food values this week-end. Broiling and frying chickens are at their lowest price in four years. Meat, up last week, is down again this week, and markets are offering a wide variety of "specials."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 (AP) -- President Warren C. Giles of the National League today upheld Cincinnati's protest of yesterday's game with Milwaukee and ordered it resumed tomorrow at the point where the Redlegs had two men on bases with two out in the ninth inning.

PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A six-nation conference aimed at settlement of Greece's foreign debts has been interrupted to allow representatives of the creditor governments time to study the Greek proposals, delegates reported today.

THOMAS B. COSTAIN, one of the most successful of living historical novelists, is also one of the most industrious. During the last twelve years Mr. Costain has written seven historical novels and three works of history. The novels are sufficiently romantic and melodramatic to delight hordes of enthusiastic readers.
MAHE, Seychelles, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The "for rent" sign is up again on the Amirantes Islands [cross on map] south of here in the Indian Ocean.
A MEMBER of the Federal Communications Commission has issued a warning to the broadcasting industry about unrestricted commercial practices.
The Consumers Power Company in the twelve months ended Aug. 31 lifted its net income to $26,062,293 from $22,981,984 a year earlier, the company reported yesterday.

TAKEN on its own terms as character study, "All Summer Long" is a poignant and beautiful play. It is the work of Robert Anderson whose "Tea and Sympathy" was the first piece of art last season. Adapted from a novel by Donald Wetzel, it opened at the Coronet last evening -- the first piece of art this year.
The American Management Association sees "nothing but long-range growth for the economy ahead."
A thirty-seven-day career as a vice president of the American Oil Company ends today for James P. Patterson as he retires at the close of the business day.

Secretary of State Dulles touched on the raw nerve of the contemporary world in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday. They were essentially healing words coming in the first instance from President Eisenhower, who, in turn, is truly a spokesman for all Americans on this issue of the peaceful use of atomic energy.

Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker, a central figure in the ArmyMcCarthy hearings, left Camp Kilmer, N. J., yesterday on the first leg of a leisurely journey to a new post with the United States Far East Command in Japan.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor yesterday unveiled to the local maritime industry part of its blueprint for cleaning up the long-troubled port.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 23 (AP) - Following is the text o! the acceptance speech of Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican nominee for Governor of New York:
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- After stabbing the political officer and locking up the captain of their ship, seven Polish seamen sought asylum in England today.
Roy T. Hurley, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, expressed doubt yesterday that commercial airliners would carry passengers faster than the speed of sound in the near future.

German industry is the subject of two books to be published next month. On Oct. 5, Henry Regnery will issue "Tycoons and Tyrant: German Industry from Hitler to Adenauer," by Louis P. Lochner. It is an examination of the relationship between industry and the German Government and that country's political parties.

In a new field manual on the suppression of news in wartime the Defense Department has expressed some principles on the subject of censorship that might well be applied in peacetime and extended to all agencies of the Government.
Portsmouth, Va., sold in the public market yesterday $2,350,000 of school and improvement bonds at a net interest cost of 2.194 per cent.

For some time it has been apparent that the Soviet Government is uneasy about the mood of many of its young people who are graduating in increasing numbers from the country's tenyear schools. As repeated press complaints reveal, many of these young people want to be white collar workers and reject out of hand the notion that they should go into the factories and work alongside of their fellows with less education.
B. H. Wragge has covered the sports car theme -- from road signs to cylinders -- in his collection of fall fashions for Bonwit Teller, which was shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

Representative Charles A. Buckley was re-elected chairman of the executive committee of the Bronx Democratic county committee last night at a meeting in the Bronx High School of Science, 184th Street and Morris Avenue.
Following are excerpts from the platform adopted last night by the Liberal party convention:

Tape recordings of an actual Alcoholics Anonymous meeting will be heard during "The Hidden Disease," an hour-long documentary devoted to the problem of alcoholism and modern-day hopes and therapies for its control.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23 -- Governor Dewey passed the leadership of the Republican state organization to Senator Irving M. Ives today, with a blistering attack on "the Tammany party" and its 1954 state ticket.
The wide variety of room arrangements that may be obtained with sofa-beds is demonstrated in the new Pullman Gallery opening Monday on John Wanamaker's sixth floor.

New York City officially will roll out the welcome mat for Leo Durocher and his Giants on Monday, when the newly crowned National League champions will be honored with a parade and special ceremonies at City Hall.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Sept. 23 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming was sentenced today by a court-martial to "involuntary discharge" from the Army for collaborating with Communists while a prisoner of war in Korea.

Exposure to radiation from a hydrogen bomb test earlier this year has now brought about the death of a Japanese fisherman. This is an event deeply to be deplored. We earnestly hope that it will not add further complications and difficulties in the delicate field of JapaneseAmerican relations.

The Liberal party, avowedly hoping to poll 500,000 votes this fall, endorsed last night, with one exception, the Democratic state ticket headed by Averell Harriman for Governor. But it also adopted a campaign platform that went beyond the Democratic program in important respects.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- The left-wing Socialist party demanded today a Parliamentary inquiry into the "political responsibilities" involved in the Wilma Montesi case. The attack on the Government in the Senate centering on this case gathered speed and momentum.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A large area of agreement has been reached among Britain and France and other continental nations on the means of establishing West Germany's military and political integration in Europe, Anthony Eden said today.

In The Times of Sept. 14 is printed a letter by Roy Wilkins, administrator of the N. A. A. C. P., alleging widespread disfranchisement of the Negro race in Mississippi. Mr. Wilkins also hints, though he does not say, that "intimidation" and "special discriminatory applications of the registration laws" are responsible.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened active and strong yesterday, up 5 to 10 points, and then old-crop months moved to new highs for the season. The close was at gains of 9 to 19 points.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. sold $52,000,000 of 4 per cent collateral trust bonds of the Northern Pacific Railway Company within three hours after their award yesterday.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams amended yesterday the department's rules and regulations to "discourage from any source" intercession in behalf of departmental personnel.

SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 23 -- Two shells "fired" by giant United States atomic cannon failed today to stop the advance of Britain's Seventh Armored Division in a critical stage of the North Atlantic war games near here.

Many aspects of children's development from infant to teen-ager, some of which may confound the most perceptive parents, will be examined closely by a number of lecture and discussion groups scheduled to meet soon.

The Board of Education, in cooperation with the State Department of Education, is about to start eight pilot projects for teaching severely retarded children not now accepted in public school classes.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, who has won the title four times, and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair gained the final round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship today at the Ridgewood Country Club.
The Warren Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $8,930,412 after providing $1,675,000 for taxes in the fiscal year ended June 30.

The current investigation of union welfare funds and the disclosure of questionable practices should not be visualized as a correct picture of all union welfare funds. There are many unions with welfare funds being administered in an incorruptible manner. Not the least among these is New York Typographical Union No. 6.

The tug-of-war that went on behind the scenes at the state political conventions over some of the lesser offices on the tickets reminds us once again that an already shortened state ballot needs to be made shorter still. The Attorney General should be appointed by the Governor, as a member of his Cabinet, just as on the federal level.
Negotiations for a union agreement in the trucking industry for the metropolitan area were thrown into turmoil yesterday when the employers warned that a strike next Friday was "almost inevitable."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Following are the text of the speech by Secretary of State Dulles to the United Nations General Assembly today and extracts from a statement by Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs:
LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Sept. 23 -- There is bound to be a "green" stage in a football coach's career, and that is the situation confronting Larry Tiihonen, Lawrenceville School's head coach.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Federal Public Health Service said today that 2,678 new polio cases had been reported throughout the nation last week, the highest this year.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Besides the seven school districts that have assumed major responsibility for the education of Indian children, the Education Department said, there were a few other public schools that had contracted to take a small number of children from the reservations from time to time.

The $11,100 Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap served as the feature attraction at Belmont Park yesterday, but the race really wasn't much. There were only five starters and only four finishers, with Albert Foot guiding Shipboard to a twolength victory over Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- When a Republican (but less often when a Democrat) asks his party to nominate him for an important executive office, those who disbelieve in his qualifications pose a stock question, if they know the answer is in the negative: "Has he ever met a payroll?"
The Democratic state committee re-elected Richard H. Balch, Utica fishing tackle manufacturer, yesterday as its chairman.
The Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, Auxiliary Roman Catholic Bishop of Chicago, proposed yesterday that Government do more to help the family unit with its economic, housing and medical problems.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Four professionals and one amateur shot 67's today to share the lead in the first round of the $40,000 "world series" and celebrities golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- It appeared likely today that the special session of the Senate on the McCarthy issue might be postponed until after Election Day.

Commodity futures prices moved regularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was generally smaller. Potatoes, wool, lead and copper closed higher; cocoa, zinc, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil. rubber and burlap, lower, and coffee and sugar, mixed.

What is the reason the immense public affection which makes heroes of ballplayers rarely attaches to club managers -- even to winning club managers? After all, isn't the manager the person most responsible for a team's position? Isn't it the manager who makes the decisions that count in the final tally? We have searched our editorial conscience for the answer and have concluded that it is just these decisions that cut into popular sentiment.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 (AP) -Paul Payette, named by the New York State Attorney General as one of the principals in an alleged international oil swindle, denied the charges today. He declared that all the money raised by two oil companies he heads was spent on drilling operations in the Gaspe Peninsula in Canada.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly took to the tennis court today -the first time since she was injured when crushed against a cement truck while riding her horse last July 20.

A Queens builder, who has been in bankruptcy since last July, was arrested yesterday for grand larceny charges after a Navy veteran complained that he could not get back a deposit he had made on an unbuilt house.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Adios Harry, a DelawareState colt, came out to the Midwest today for the first time and won the world's richest pacing race, the $69,300 Little Brown Jug, at the County Fairgrounds.

HONG KONG, Sept. 23 -Premier Chou En-lai of Red China called again today for the "liberation" of Formosa. In a speech, he portrayed Nationalist control of that island as a threat to peace in the Far East and a menace to Communist China's security.
David Davis, presented by Interval Concerts in the ninth event of the series last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, upheld the impression he had made last season as a talented violinist.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- All grain and soybean futures declined here today. The outside demand was lethargic and there were no new bull features to stimulate buying.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Stan Lopata hit a three-run homer in the first inning to propel Philadelphia to a 4-2 victory over Pittsburgh today after the Phillies had edged the Pirates, 7 -- 6, in the completion of a suspended game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The International Monetary Fund said today that conditions were now ripe for "significant progress" toward the comparatively free interchange of currencies that is essential to healthy world trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Army will not drop below its current strength of nineteen divisions during this fiscal year, Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 23 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight the Eisenhower Administration "put the Reds on the run in America."

Luxurious fabrics, jet black and vivid colors, were blended by the hand of Pierre Balmain to create his fall and winter collection of suits, dresses and gowns. Shown at the Plaza Hotel yesterday, they are at De Pinna.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Bucky Harris' resignation as manager of the Washington Senators will be announced tomorrow, but a successor has not been signed yet, it was learned tonight.

The Obernkirchen Children's Choir of Obernkirchen, Germany, which sang a concert at Town Hall last evening to open its first tour of the United States, completely captivated its audience by the charm, freshness and spontaneity of its performance.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Greece won an important first test vote today in her fight to put the Cyprus dispute before the United Nations.
Demands for an investigation by the United Nations of the treatment of Jews in Communist countries were made before a Congressional committee here yesterday by spokesmen for Jewish organizations.

LONDON Sept. 23 (AP) -- A British Government expert on guided missiles has been shifted to nonsecret civilian projects because of past membership in the Communist party, an official source disclosed today.

The thirty-one-family apartment house at 42-6 Herriot Street in Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by the Goldlee Realty Company to Sadie Grodzitsky. Peter Fornaby and Walter M. Kar were the brokers and title insurance was furnished by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

Many dinner parties were given last night at the Blue Grass Ball in the Persian Room of the Plaza. The dinner dance, which also marked the formal opening of the room, was for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society.

Repayments by metal and metal products concerns and by sales finance companies were the principal influences in a reduction of $14,000,000 in business loans from New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Motorcycle Patrolman Timothy W. O'Neill, nemesis of speeding Russians here since 1946, started arming himself tonight with a new weapon -the Russian language.

LONDON Sept. 23 (AP) -- A British Government expert on guided missiles has been shifted to nonsecret civilian projects because of past membership in the Communist party, an official source disclosed today.

The thirty-one-family apartment house at 42-6 Herriot Street in Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by the Goldlee Realty Company to Sadie Grodzitsky. Peter Fornaby and Walter M. Kar were the brokers and title insurance was furnished by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

IThe three-story apartment ihouse accommodating six families at 1635 Fifty-sixth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Abe Pettigrossi to Alter Lipschutz, Henry Futterweit was the broker in the transaction and title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
