F. L., as transmitted by The Associated Press and The New York Times:

Let me remind Justice Donoghue, whose letter appeared in your issue of Sept. 21, that latter-day Townsend Harrisites were not as fortunate as earlier varieties. In my day the school occupied several floors in the skyscraper quarters of the Twenty-third Street Business Center.
EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson drew cheers tonight when he addressed a Democratic rally of 2,500 persons in this overwhelmingly Republican Chicago suburb.

The city and state organizations of the American for Democratic Action opened their seventh annual convention last night at the Diplomatic Hotel. Five hundred delegates began discussions concerning support of candidates in the forthcoming election.
A House maritime subcommittee toured five major shipyards in Brooklyn yesterday and reported the same lack of work and few or no future orders it had found last week at Staten Island yards.

A motion-picture series called "Through the Looking Glass," on the subject of films, film-makers and film-making, will be presented for nine weeks beginning on Monday, Oct. 4, at the Museum of Modern Art.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, the Republican candidate for Governor, blamed New York City Democrats today for creating a cleavage that, he said, was pitting New York City against the rest of the state.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The office of the United States High Commissioner rejected today as "unacceptable" a Soviet protest charging the United States with violating the rights of occupation by sending spies into the Soviet zone of Germany.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The Permanent Commission of the Brussels Treaty Organization virtually completed today the revision of the pact's original text to permit the admission of West Germany and Italy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Mixed Negro-white housing projects in New York City were singled out today in a United Nations publication as "perhaps the most outstanding success in nonsegregated public housing."
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 25 -- Twelve joint Soviet-Rumanian industrial companies, formed after the end of World War II, have been dissolved, it was announced here today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- White farmers called on the Kenya Government today to stop drafting them for full-time service in the security forces to fight Mau Mau terrorists.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Pier 15 at Fifteenth Street here has been leased from the Kerr Steamship Company of New York by the International Terminal Operating Company of 27 Whitehall Street for three years.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept. 24 -- What is believed to be the world's largest plastic vessel, a fifty - one - foot, self - propelled barge, using a new fibreglass sandwich-type construction, was demonstrated today by the Army at Fort Eustis, Va.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 -President Eisenhower got a friendly personal reception today from a politically hostile convention of the American Federation of Labor.
A $250,000 settlement by the Government was sanctioned yesterday for a technical engineer who was seriously injured in 1951 in the crash of an Air Transport Command plane.
PARIS, Sept. 24 -- A French police embroglio, involving security leaks and the activities of the Communist party, threatened today to force a shake-up of the Mendes-France Government.
CHATSWORTH, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Forest and brush fires in California took a toll of three lives in the northern part of the state today.

Nuclear energy could be the "most decisive" factor in the future of the world, offering boundless "hopes for human welfare'' or becoming the basis for elimination of life on earth, Prof. Niels Bohr, Danish physicist, said here yesterday. He arrived aboard the Norwegian America liner Oslofjord.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- Pope Pius XII had so thoroughly recovered today from the ailment accompanied by hiccuping that troubled him last week that his archiater, or chief physician, felt justified in going away for a brief vacation.
The Amato Opera Theatre, which last night unveiled its new production of "Lucia di Lammermoor," has been running for three years without, like many Italian opera companies, going bankrupt.

The Republican and Democratic platforms make an interesting study in contrasts this fall, and each contains enough on the credit side to make us wish that future state policy could be a selective combination of the two parties' views.

SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 24 -- A simulated atomic bomb dropped by a Tactical Air Force jet plane substantially "destroyed'' today a British corps headquarters. It thereby presented the big battle royal maneuver of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's armed forces with the first revolutionary problem.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Miguel Lanz Duret, president of the Inter-American Press Association and Mexican newspaper publisher, was denied admittance to Argentina today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - Roy B. White, chairman of the board of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, won a patent this week that represented a step toward the goal of the coal-carrying roads -- something to beat the Diesel.
Many eye inflammations caused by allergy are similar to inflammations caused by eye diseases and a physician sometimes has difficulty telling them apart, it was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Eisenhower Administration assured the free world today of its intention to press ahead with the progressive lowering of United States tariff barriers to world trade.
So nervous were two young hoodlums yesterday that after they committed a robbery, they stumbled, collided, knocked each other down and dropped $5,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Pakistani Embassy announced today the signing of an agreement with the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company to search a 20,000-square-mile area of Pakistan for oil.

Directors of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., yesterday voted to double the annual dividend rate on its stock with the declaration of a payment of 25 cents for the final three months of this year. Payable on Dec. 13 to holders of record of Nov. 16, the dividend compares with the previous yearly rate of 50 cents a share, distributed at the rate of 25 cents semi-annually.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 -- Loans and gifts of money and presents to union officials guiding the destinies of the welfare fund of the Sheet Metal Workers Union, A. F. L., were described today before the Congressional subcommittee investigating union welfare funds.

Walter A. Lynch, the 1950 Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, was nominated last night by the same two political parties for one of eight prospective vacancies on the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, consisting of Manhattan and the Bronx.
Daylight Saving Time will end here at 2 A. M. tomorrow. Clocks should be set back one hour.
Stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Aug. 31 had an average price of $46.33, the Exchange reported yesterday This compared with $47.61 at the close of July and $45.68 at the end of June.

VIENNA, Sept. 24 -- The Wiener Kurier, German language daily newspaper published since 1945 by United States authorities in Vienna, is to cease publication Oct. 16. One week later it will be succeeded by a United States-German language weekly.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 381 pints of blood on Thursday, including 102 at the New York Telephone Company, 68-06 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens. Today and tomorrow n bloodmobiles will be out and the blood centers at the New York Chapter House of the Red Cross.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has informed the Western powers that he is prepared to negotiate West Germany's armament on this basis: full sovereignty, membership in a Western alliance in the form of an enlarged Brussels pact and equal membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 24 -- General Motors Corporation is to double the capacity of its assembly plant in Belgium, which produces 42,000 cars and trucks a year, Harlow H. Curtice, the corporation's president, announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Twenty airlines sought the right today to take part in the Civil Aeronautics Board hearings to determine which ones might fly the profitable New York-to-Florida run.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 -- Tension between Egypt's ruling military junta and the fanatical Moslem Brotherhood threatened today to upset internal stability here and the implementation of the Anglo-Egyptian agreement on the Suez Canal Zone.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24 -- Hudson County Judge Paul J. Duffy tonight sentenced George W. Rogers, 53-year-old Bayonne radio expert, to two life sentences in the New Jersey State Prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Average primary market prices declined 0.1 percentage point to 109.9 over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Fractional decreases were reported in all major groupings.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- For the coach of a team that has been tapped for distinction and to lead the Ivy group again, Lefty James of Cornell has a surprisingly furrowed brow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- Two high-ranking Yugoslav delegations will embark next month on a journey that diplomats here relate to the new Yugoslav diplomacy.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 -- The American Federation of Labor set forth today its conviction that chances for unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations were brighter than at any time since the split in labor's ranks began nineteen years ago.
NEWTON, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Senator Douglas asserted tonight that "speculators are taking hundreds of millions away from farmers while the Republican Administration sits on its hands."

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The European Assembly suggested today that the nine-power conference in London next week let West Germany rearm and strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. However, it said nothing about putting Germany into the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Senator Albert M. Gore said today that the Justice Department had "political" motives in ordering coast-to-coast grand jury inquiries of housing irregularities.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of help to the homemaker:

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed slightly irregular yesterday, 12 points higher to 6 points lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON Sept 24 (AP) -- Gene Littler, who turned pro after winning last year's national amateur championship, and Marty Furgol, a seasoned pro, set the pace today with seven-under-par 135's at the halfway mark in the $40,000 "world series of golf" tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24--The Giants, embarking on their final four-game series of the regular season, had to settle for an even break with the Phillies in their double-header tonight before 12,165 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -A college professor told the Tariff Commission today the United States bicycle industry's claims of being financially injured by imports of foreign bikes are not borne out by production figures.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- D. N. Pritt, a lawyer and president of the British Society for Cultural Relations with the U. S. S. R., said today that the number of corrective labor camps in the Moscow Raion (administrative region) had been conspicuously reduced.
Five seminars on neighborhood problems for Protestant churches will be conducted at 11 A. M. Tuesday at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Unemployment compensation claims rose early this month, reversing an almost steady decline since midsummer, the Labor Department said today.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Two dogs from the open classes, one an importation, were the winners today in the 102d specialty of the American Fox Terrier Club.
Securities underwriters will be able to breathe more easily now that the heavy financing activity of the past week is behind them.
HAVANA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- President Fulgencio Batista appeared headed today for re-election by default in the Nov. 1 elections.

In the comparative privacy of Ebbets Field yesterday the Dodgers beat the Pirates for the first time in their most recent five meetings -- but not easily. The score was 6-5, and the Bucs had the tying run on base in the seventh inning, as well as the eighth and ninth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. told 700 lawyers here tonight that the chief responsibility for fair and impartial trials could not be shifted to the Nation's press.

Speaking at Duluth this week Vice President Nixon declared that President Eisenhower's farm program is designed to bring prosperity to the farmer "by giving the American system a chance to work." WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Army said today that about thirty-five former prisoners of war still faced court-martial charges for misconduct while in the hands of Chinese or North Korean Communists.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union has followed up its political offensive in Indonesia with the suggestion that both countries enter into their first trade pact. Informed sources said today that a Soviet proposal to this effect was now under consideration and that Indonesia was receptive to the idea.

Thwarted in its attempt to gain control of this port's longshoremen, the International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A. F. L., has directed its efforts toward winning over casual dockworkers known as "chenangoes."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., today barred Communists, Fascists and Ku Klux Klansmen from membership.
The Long Island Rail Road apologized to commuters yesterday because Thursday's unseasonable cold spell had caught it unprepared.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -The Washington Senators announced today that Bucky Harris was out as their manager. It was considered pretty certain that Chuck Dressen would become the new manager, but Senators' officials said Dressen had not yet signed.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Two men held up the Fulton Avenue drive-in branch of the County Trust Company here between 7:30 and 8 o'clock this morning, and escaped with $97,564.47 in cash. It was Westchester County's biggest bank robbery and Mount Vernon's first, according to police records.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Treasury reported success tonight in its latest attempt to borrow $4,000,000,000 in cash through the sale of new notes.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Washington Senators today swept a double-header with the Boston Red Sox, 1 -- 0, in eleven innings, iand 6 -- 4, to keep alive their hopes for fourth place and a share of the world series money.

Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern ruled yesterday in a test case that Edward C. Maguire would forfeit his $15,000 a year lifetime job as a Commissioner of the Board of Water Supply if he provided legal services to Yonkers Raceway.
Newspaper advertising linage is picking up, Media Records reported yesterday.

With Russia having clinched first place in the Hamilton-Russell Cup chess series, play continued in the tenth and semi-final round, at the end of which Yugoslavia, by defeating West Germany, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, retained the runner-up position, one point ahead of Argentina, according to a report from Amsterdam, the Netherlands, yesterday.

Martyr refused to give up under the pressure of setting the pace in the $25,250 Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. As a consequence the speedy gelding owned by Mrs. Jan Burke made a runaway of the mile test, winning by seven lengths. Stanley Small rode the son of By Jimminy to the triumph.
Prisoners at the House of Detention for Women in Greenwich Village staged a noisy two-hour demonstration last night over the disciplining of a narcotics addict for an obscene remark to a guard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The "market basket" of goods and services usually bought by moderate income city families cost 0.2 per cent less in August than in July.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday net income of $828,750 for August, compared with an income deficit of $318,482 in July and a net income of $3,332,184 in August last year. Operating revenues last month were $58,887,153, compared with $69,590,951 in the previous August.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- An anonymous envoy of Horrockses arrived in New York the other day, announced his business to a United States customs inspector and was flabbergasted to hear the American say: "Oh, sure, you belong to that British cotton firm. We've heard plenty about you but we still can't pronounce the name.

THOSE who have not yet mailed their application for the special anUerless li- cense to hunt the Adirondack wilderness area can save the price of a 3-cent stamp, for the quota of 7,000 licenses has been reached--with an ahnost equal number applying too late.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -The United States will begin another series of atomic tests at the Nevada proving ground early in 1955.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Eisenhower Administration has done a "wonderful" job of reducing Federal expenditures, according to Rowland R. Hughes, director of the Bureau of the Budget.

NEWARK, Sept. 24 -- Clifford P. Case pledged himself today to spur Federal efforts to reduce rents for tenants in projects in which windfall profits have been realized by builders. There are seventeen such housing developments in New Jersey.
For the first time since 1947 the nation's wheat crop has been harvested and shipped without serious transportation congestion or delays.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Confidence that his Government would maintain monetary and fiscal stabilization for "a long time" was expressed today by Dr. Antonio Garillo Flores, Mexican Minister of Finance.
DENVER, Sept. 24 -- President Eisenhower returned to the summer White House today as the finished politician and party leader, in the eyes of those who had watched him on his Western campaign trip.

Pledges to forego unethical practices in the current Congressional campaign have been signed by 227 candidates in the nine days since a fair campaign practices code was mailed to them. This was announced yesterday by the Fair Campaign Practice Committee, 55 West Fifty-third Street, which sent out the code.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- The pressing of a button in Charleston, S. C., tonight sent an electrical impulse that lighted an eternal light here and symbolized the dedication of the new $300,000 Larchmont Temple at Larchmont Avenue and Willow Street.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The pace of the recovery in industrial share values quickened today. Other markets were quieter though firm.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 23 -- The South Korean Government continued its "Hate Japan" campaign today with a bitter editorial in the Korean Republic's unofficial propaganda organ.
Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, appealed to Americans last night to support the Chinese Nationalists against Communist China.
Teamsters and truck operators in the metropolitan area settled their dispute over bargaining procedures yesterday and prepared to begin serious discussion of contract issues today.
We sit down to eat three times a day, a routine that may be deadly or delightful according to the skill and imagination of the cook.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- There is strong archaeological evidence that excavations in Turkey have revealed the long-lost Empire of Arzawa, which flourished about 1400 B. C. It disappeared from history 200 years later.
The police held an eastbound A train for fifteen minutes at the Nostrand Avenue station of the IND line yesterday while they checked a report that Elmer (Trigger) Burke had been sighted aboard.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24 (AP) Banner Direct won the Washington Pace in 2:03 3/5 in a three-horse photo finish tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The 5-year-old bay horse gained a neck victory over Red Dominion, with Tyler Hanover third. Banner Direct, owned and driven by William Burton of Cambridge, Md., returned $15.70 for $2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Government witness testified today that twenty years ago, when he was a high school student, he had a conversation with Edward Lamb, publisher, and Mr. Lamb then had recommended the setting up of secret study groups.

A Helfer and Jimmy Dudley have been selected to do the play-by-play description of the world series games on radio and Jack Brickhouse and Russ Hodges have been picked to handle the television commentary. The series starts Wednesday. Air time will be 12:45 and game time 1 P. M. WOR and WMCA will carry the radio description and Channels 4, 9 and 11 will televise the games

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (UP) -Virgil Trucks wild-pitched home the winning run tonight to ruin his chances for his twentieth victory of the season as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Chicago White Sox, 2 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of a rookie left-hander. Billy O'Dell.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 24 -- Only one regular is back from the 1953 Haverford eleven that carved a 6-1 record, but Frederick R. (Doe) Wallace, the school's head coach, has high hopes for his football team.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union agreed today that the United Nations General Assembly should consider the report by the United States on its efforts for international cooperation in the peaceful uses of atomic energy. The steering committee recommended such study by the Assembly.
A leading retail merchant yesterday suggested changes in fair trade laws which would permit any retailer to match the prices that discount houses charge for price-fixed merchandise.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Joey Giardello, the No. 1 middleweight contender from Philadelphia, was forced to the limit tonight before winning a unanimous ten-round decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones, a 12-5 short-ender from Yonkers, the bout was nationaly televised.
The reinstatement of the ninth of twenty-two Fort Monmouth, N. J., civilian employes suspended on charges under the Eisenhower security program was announced yesterday by his lawyer.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Hundreds of Chinese Nationalist fighter-bombers flew through the fringes of a typhoon today and sank or damaged thirty-four Communist boats along the China coast, Government sources reported.

October is for the man adjusted, who will wear tweeds and smoke a pipe while leaning against a tugging dog. November for the doubter; he finds comfort in the hard earth and safety in the bright dead leaves. December belongs to the anguished, sensing expression in the naked branch on the gray sky.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Japan plunged into almost hysterical mourning today over the death last night of a 40-year-old fisherman who had become the nation's symbol of hatred and fear of atomic weapons.

QUEBEC, Sept. 24 -- .he head of the Government of Quebec made it clear today he did not intend to be talked into a test of strength now with the Federal Administration on the issue of provincial autonomy and national unity.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The University of Southern California, led by a sophomore, Jon Arnett, defeated Pittsburgh 27 -- 7, before 50,253 fans in Memorial Coliseum tonight.
With oils and steels in the lead, the stock market moved forward yesterday to establish a number of new highs.

Nancy Mitford, the novelist who recently undertook her first excursion into the field of historical biography with "Madame de Pompadour," is working on the English stage adaptation of "The Dazzling Hour," the Anna Bonacci French play.

Wednesday, the day the Giants meet the Cleveland Indians in the first game of the World Series, will be publication day of "The Willie Mays Story," by Ken Smith. It traces the life and baseball achievements of the colorful sports figure from early childhood in Alabama to the present.

In a further move to strengthen his Government in Vietnam Premier Ngo Dinh Diem has reorganized his entire Cabinet. He has not solved the problems arising from his clash with the army and its chief of staff but he has brought into the Government two important religious groups and several independents.

The lucid letter by Dr. William Wolf gives in a nutshell the reasons why the city's public water supply should not be fluoridated. In support of his argument I wish to draw your attention to a comprehensive examination of many thousand young recruits, both male and female, serving in the British Army during the recent war.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Tony Trabert eliminated the I Chilean champion, Luis Ayala, inI straight sets today to move intol the semi-finals of the Pacific/ Coast tennis championships along/ with Tom Brown of San Francis-l co, who upset the fourth-ranked Eddie Moylam of Trenton in a four-set duel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission told the Interstate Commerce Commission today it was prepared to assume regulatory control of Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation as an investment company.
OTTAWA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Canada and the United States have agreed to ease customs and immigration regulations to facilitate construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway touching both countries.

It has been brought to my attention that in a footnote to one of my Princeton lectures of last spring, recently published under the title of "Realities of American Foreign Policy" (Princeton University Press), I committed an egregious error of fact and inadvertently did an injustice to The New York Times.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- "1984," the late George Orwell's fanciful frightening conception of a highly mechanistic world police state, will be made into a movie next year by Rathvon Overseas, Ltd., the producing company owned by N. Peter Rathvon.

SARANAC INN N. Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Buffalo attorney told New York State industrialists today that they might become liable for unnecessary taxes if they were not careful in soliciting business in other states.
HONG KONG, Sept. 24 -- The Chinese Communists' rationing of grain, edible oil and cotton cloth has been ascribed by an official to shortages that developed last year.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (UP) -The Detroit Tigers beat the Indians today, 6 -- 4, and prevented Cleveland from gaining a record 111th victory.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- George Mikan, the giant whose scoring exploits made the Minneapolis Lakers the greatest team in professional basketball, announced his retirement today.
MIAMI, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Miami dipped into its third and fourth stringers tonight, but still ran up a 51-13 victory over Furman University of Greenville, S. C.

In the comment of Topics of The Times in the Sept. 19 issue on the Soviet conduct toward foreign aircraft there appeared several passages from my article, "The Treatment of Aerial Intruders in Recent Practice and International Law" (American Journal of International Law, Vol. 47, p. 559, October, 1953), the meaning of one of which was unfortunately somewhat distorted by the apparently inadvertent omission of one word.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Senate will be convened in special session on Nov. 8, six days after Election Day, to consider the possible censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. From California, Senator William F. Knowland, the majority leader, directed that all Senators be notified to be on hand. The proceeding will weigh the findings of the special committee that heard the censure charges against the Republican Senator from Wisconsin.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- An unofficial estimate of the wheat crop in Canada's prairie provinces at 298,000,000 bushels, or 53,000,000 bushels less than the recent official forecast, caused active buying today. Wheat registered a good upturn before reacting somewhat from the top figures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- France will appeal next week for United States help in maintaining her forces in South Vietnam. Talks at which this plea will be made are scheduled to get under way at the State Department Monday.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The director of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory -heart of this country's nuclear research -- said today he believed that the United States was well ahead of Russia in the atomic weapons race.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 2 -- The Solar Cooker, developed by the National Physical Laboratory of India here, is expected to be on the consumer market in India soon. The Laboratory has given permission to The Jeevanlal Limited, Calcutta, to produce it on a mass scale.

Rosh ha-Shanah, ushering in the Jewish New Year of 5715, will begin at sundown Monday in synagogues and temples. Religious services for Jewish members of the armed forces will be held in military installations over the world.

BITBURG, Germany, Sept. 24 (UP) -- An investigation was begun today to determine if the disastrous explosion of a United States jet aviation fuel tank here called for new safety measures in the Allies' Europe-wide pipeline and fuel storage system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Postponement until after the November elections of the Senate's recall to vote on possible censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was viewed here tonight as feeding a new and explosive issue into many Congressional campaigns.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 24 -- A list of thousands of dollar commodities to be freed from import restrictions on Oct. 1 was announced tonight by the Swedish Ministry of Trade.

In your issue of Sept. 18 you published a statement by Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell refuting my challenge of the pessimistic picture he painted regarding the growth of communism in Italy as reported by The Times of Aug. 7. I have no desire to enter into a controversy of personal opinions, but Dr. Bonnell has chosen to produce statistics to validate his impressions, to which I should like to make several comments.
MILFORD, Del., Sept. 24 -Gov. J. Caleb Boggs called upon all persons to permit the Milford public schools to reopen on Monday without any incident or demonstration.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 24 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett indicated today Israel would return to the Jordanian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission after Comdr. Elmo H. Hutchison of the United States Navy had been replaced as chairman.
The Avco Manufacturing Corporation, which resumed the declaration of dividends on its common stock yesterday, reported its consolidated net income at $3,002,843 for the nine months ended on Aug. 31.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Two new colonial controversies -- centering on islands in the eastern Mediterranean and the Pacific -- were taken on today by the United Nations General Assembly.

Arnold Portocarrero fanned eleven Yankees and hurled the last-place Philadelphia Athletics to a 5-1 victory over the ex-champions yesterday at the Stadium. The setback wrecked the hopes of the Bombers, who had downed the Athletics fifteen straight times, to win more games than any other runner-up in baseball history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Dr. Max Beer of the Neue Zuercher Zeitung of Zurich, Switzerland, was elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association tonight. He succeeds Krishnamachari Balaraman of The Hindu of Madras, India.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A builder told the Senate Banking Committee today that income taxes had not yet been paid on "windfall" profits of a million dollars made in 1950-51 on housing projects built with loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., Sept. 24 -- Pakistan has a new delegate to the United Nations this year who is not only a diplomat but also an expert at swimming, polo, field hockey, cricket, squash and especially tiger shooting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Secretary of Commerce, Sinclair Weeks, told Senator Theodore Green, Democrat of Rhode Island, today that there had been no "false economies" in the Weather Bureau that would weaken the agency's hurricane warning system.
Two invitations were accepted yesterday by Mayor Wagner in brief ceremonies at City Hall.
NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- For at least one hour a week the basic curriculum at Nyack High School undergoes a slight revision.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Flemington High School canceled three football games, starting with tomorrow's game with Belvidere, because a player was hospitalized with what was described as polio.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 24 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem announced today a Cabinet reshuffle that brought into his Government representatives of the Hoa Hao and Cao Dai religious sects, and a number of new independents.
The Soviet Union's foreign policy, like that of the United States, must face both East and West -- East to China and the Pacific and West to Europe and beyond to the United States.
Averell Harriman will open his campaign as the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor today with a television appearance and a speech in Elmira.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Poland will demand the extradition of seven Polish mutineers who locked up the captain of their trawler, stabbed the political officer and sailed into Whitby Harbor to seek political asylum.

Futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Wool, rubber, burlap, silk, copper and lead rose; cocoa, potatoes, hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil declined, and coffee, sugar and zinc closed mixed.
POCONO MANOR, Pa., Sept. 24 -- Cyrus S. Ching, former head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, today called the guaranteed annual wage idea a "preposterous proposal."

Your issue of Sept. 19 carries word from Berlin that the people of the United States have erected there "a gleaming concrete and glass building," the largest library in Europe, at a cost of $1,285,000.

LEONARD JEROME, nineteenth - century American yachtsman, horseman and financier, brought up his three beautiful daughters to be princesses, musicians and patrons of art. His wife, who was much at home at the court of Louis Napoleon and the Empress Eugenie, hoped that they would make brilliantly patrician marriages in France. But England won the three -- one of them to the greater glory of history.

TRENTON, Sept. 24 -- Former Gov. Walter E. Edge began a bitter attack today on those elements within the Republican party who have opposed the candidacy of Clifford P. Case, Republican nominee for United States Senator.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Another sharp drop in passenger car production this week, due to model change-overs, was described by Ward's Automotive Reports today as the "most costly change-over in five years."
ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Sept. 24 -- In this small Windward Island anxiety is being felt over the sweeping election victory earlier in the week of E. M. Gairy's party.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept. 22 -- A year of tragedy and bitterness in Wyoming politics is being rounded out in an election campaign that formally got under way this week. A Senate race holds top interest.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 (AP) -Another first in Milwaukee's major league history -- two victories over two different teams on the same day -- went into the National League record books today.

DURING the next four or five weeks many towns and villages throughout the Northeast, taking advantage of the autumn color display, will stage festivals and celebrations of various kinds. These events, along with specially planned color tours, are an extra inducement to city dwellers to get out into the countryside during the fall.

THREE: Soviet scientists come to America with a strange brutish volunteer whom they call G. O. G. 666 -- for "General Order in Geneties 666." Their object: by using an American antitoxin on Gog, to cure the virulent strain of pneumonia which has been decimating Gog's people.

BLOOMSBURY is one of the university quarters of London. It is also the neighborhood of the British Museum and of many pleasant late Georgian squares. In one of these, a group of young intellectuals used to meet for conversation in the years before World War I.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower's selection of California for the scene of his exhortation this week to Republicans to get in there and pitch struck regional political observers as particularly appropriate.

HONOLULU, Sept. 19 -- A labor leader who has been convicted of Communist conspiracy and new strength ascribed, by most observers to the Democratic party are factors contributing to exceptional election year interest in Hawaii.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector). Sept. 25 -- The Israeli army has ordered its forces not to permit United Nations observers to patrol Jerusalem border areas unless accompanied by Israeli officers.

The Attorney General of the State of New York is the state's chief legal officer. That is a big job in any state. In the most populous state in the union it is especially important. It is the vital state office for which Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat, and Jacob K. Javits, Republican, will contest in the fall campaign.

Yogi Berra drove in one of his team's runs as the Yankees routed the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 -- 2, last night at the Stadium. This left the energetic catcher of the ex-champions one behind Cleveland's Larry Doby, who leads the American League with 126 runs driven in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The historian of the National Trust for Historic Preservatian is jubilant that the steeple of Old North Church in Boston will rise again, but can't help being a bit annoyed at the perversity of human nature.

THE Republicans in this state have sent in a boy to do a man's work in the Senatorial campaign that will be decided on Nov. 2, but on the basis of his performance to date no one is writing off his chances to make good.

WITHIN a few weeks, if present automotive manufacturing schedules hold good, some of the 1955 cars will be presented to the motoring public in glittering display, accompanied by the eulogistic descriptions that have become traditional for the introduction of new models during the last half century.

ADMIRERS of Patrick Quentin's witty theatrical-producer-detective Peter Duluth and of Q. Patrick's gentlemanly and sensitive homicide lieutenant Timothy Trant will find them both in the new Quentin novel MY SON, THE MURDERER (Simon Schuster, $2.50), but in unwontedly small roles.
COUNT on Tallulah Bank-head for a show. With the assistance of a good cast and with benefit of knowing direction, she is now putting on a good show in "Dear Charles" at the Morosco.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- Continued terrorism in Tunisia is creating an atmosphere of suspicion and strain in negotiations under way here on internal autonomy for the French protectorate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Aided by contributions of $54,500 from the Rockefellers and Mellons, Republican fund-raisers this summer collected almost three times as much money as the Democrats for the Congressional election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The United States Information Agency announced today world-wide distribution of a volume of 400 pages of statements by Soviet Communists, representing a "conclusive indictment of the Soviet conspiracy from the mouths of its own leaders."

It pained me to find in the Food Department article entitled "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table" (Aug. 22) a statement that yearly retail sales of coffee in this country totaled 40 billion dollars.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Government in its role of assisting American shipping has begun administering a program of shipbuilding and repair which will mean expenditure of $400,000,000 for the shipyards of the nation and keep shipyard employment close to 36,000.

DOUGLAS FAIRBANKS JR. wasn't just sightseeing on his tour of Turkey last month as a guest of the Government. The actor and owner of the Dougfair Corporation, motion picture and television film producing company of Beverly Hills, was stealing a march on his Hollywood competitors to acquire film rights to the life of Kemal Ataturk, father of the Turkish republic.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 25--Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight that the Republicans had brought the nation to its most "precarious" position since World War II.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Ohio State used superior depth and the explosive running of two halfbacks, Howard (Hopalong) Cassady and Bobby Watkins, to overcome Indiana, 28 -- 0, today in the Big Ten opener for both teams before 72,703 fans.

THE main trouble in trying to discuss Alphonso Ramon Lopez, the manager of the Cleveland Indians, and Leo Ernest Durocher, the manager of the New York Giants, is that it destroys a fellow's faith in simple arithmetic. In this instance, one and one don't add up to two.

DENVER, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Denver Post, in a copyrighted story from Washington, reported here tonight that the Special Senate Committee investigating Senator Joseph R. McCarthy would recommend censuring him "for his contempt and abuse of his colleagues."
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 24 -- President Eisenhower's McNary dam speech Thursday served to emphasize the issues involved in the Cordon-Neuberger race for the Senate in Oregon.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Andy Nelson, a fullback, passed and ran Memphis State to a 13-13 tie with Tulane today, scoring both Memphis touchdowns after setting them up with his accurate throwing.
The city is preparing to crack down hard--through revision of the law--on building owners and others responsible for building violations.

Further evidence of improvement in the nation's economy had a beneficial effect on sentiment in the securities markets last week. Stock prices displayed a stronger tone for the third successive week, with the list touching highs for the movement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- The record of the new regime now in command of the San Francisco Opera Company is spattered with many firsts, but none of these is more striking than its presentation of Cherubini's one-act comedy, "The Portoguese Inn," last night at the War Memorial Opera House.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Employment, total wages and working time in Pennsylvania factories were unchanged from mid-July to mid-August, according to a report of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank. This was the second consecutive month in which employment held steady, following declines for nine months.
CAIRO, Sept. 25 -- Forty Egyptian university professors have been dismissed by the military junta as part of a program to purge the nation's three principal universities of political dissidence.

EACH year at this time the spirit of Nessmuk becomes manifest in thousands of urban, suburban and rural sportsmen, who firmly resolve that they will peel off the veneer of comfort and "rough it" during the course of the hunting season.

OLD General Carbajal, who rode a red mule, had a tough decision. A warrior for forces that had rebelled against the King of Spain in Peru, he had set out to capture and kill a loyalist named Valentin. When the case ended in success, the general discovered that Valentin was his son, who, along with his unwed mother, had been abandoned in Spain.

ON the eighty-eighth day of the Japanese farmers' calendar, early in May, the young girls of a Japanese village dress in special clothes, a blue and white kimono tied high with a narrow obi, to show the scarlet underskirt, perform a ceremonial dance before the Shinto shrine and then enter the temple to pray.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Expedients that will be necessary because of Congressional parsimony will injure the service of the Federal courts this year, Henry P. Chandler asserted today.

Mrs. George Keppel, one of London's great hostesses and owner of the lovely Florentine Villa dell'Ombrellino of which Louis Jouvet once remarked: C'est comme si vous aviez une baignoire sur l'Acropole.

THE very same thinking which trimmed the lines of fall suits and threw out exaggerated shoulder padding has been applied to shirts and ties. Result, widespread collars and long, pointed collars on business shirts are out; neat trim collars are in.

MENTION was made in this column not long ago of the "unconventional" method of leading honors that Sydney Rusinow proposed some twenty years ago. A number of letters have asked for further details, proving that a new generation has grown up in contract bridge.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 -- A long simmering disagreement between leaders of the International United Brewery Workers Union, C. I. O., and its largest local -- Milwaukee Local 9 -- is reaching the crisis stage. The cleavage may prompt the local to consider the advisability of leaving the international union, according to union sources here.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The 1,800-year-old Roman Temple of Mithras unearthed in the City of London still has a chance of survival. But its preservation would be expensive.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Paced by the running and play-calling of Bobby Lance, Florida's Gators toppled Georgia Tech to its first home defeat in four years today with a 13-to-12 upset before 30,000 fans.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -Usually union leaders are among the most forthright, not to say bombastic, of our citizen setting forth the things they favor and the things they oppose. But in the case of politics, labor has learned that it can often put dynamite in the hands of its enemies by identifying itself too closely with a particular candidate or party.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 26 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida yesterday walked out of a press conference called to explain his trip to the Western countries. He leaves today for Canada and the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- A warning that there can be no peace with the Soviet Union or Communist China based on the weakness of the West was delivered tonight on the eve of a critical week for the British Labor party.

HARTFORD, Sept. 25 -- The Connecticut election campaign, which has been a pretty quiet affair all summer, began to warm up this week.

A limited number of fellowships for psychiatrists interested in emotional problems of the physically handicapped, particularly poliomyelitis patients with respiratory difficulties, were announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- Duke's fast, alert and experienced football squad ran roughshod over Pennsylvania today before 31,000 spectators at Franklin Field. Exploding for five touchdowns in the final quarter, the Blue Devils won by 52 -- 0.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 (AP)--Philip Scott, a 6-year-old bay horse owned by the Gray brothers of East Providence, R. I., and driven by Frank Safford, won the featured Long Island pace, a free-for-all event, in 2:02 4-5 by a length and one-half over Wilmington's Star at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Hillsota was third.

BURGENSTOCK, Switzerland, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Audrey Hepburn. Academy Award-winning film star, and Mel Ferrer, the actor, were married today at this resort area on Lake Lucerne.

The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany announced yesterday that $139,185 in fellowships and scholarships, derived from German reparation funds, had been awarded to 146 prominent refugee scholars and students.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 25 -- Dr. Frank N. D. Buchanan, 76-year-old founder, and leader of the Moral Re-Armament movement (M. R. A.), arrived here by plane late today for a ten-day world assembly of his followers.
NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Oklahoma summoned a desperate attack in the last period today to turn what appeared to be a defeat at the hands of Texas Christian University into a 21-to-16 victory.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- A United Nations commission reported today that the cost of maintaining the Republic of Korea's 750,000-man army was holding back reconstruction in the country.

By the end of next week almost every college and university in the United States will have begun its 1954-55 academic year. The institutions of higher learning are now experiencing an upward enrollment trend. With an estimated registration of 2,533,000, an increase of 89,000 over last year, the American colleges face the highest enrollment since the peak year of 1949-50, when the veterans flocked to the nation's campuses.

NECKTIE collectors will have a field day this season. Never has the choice been broader nor ties more interesting. The broad, bold tie that had the impact of a beacon light is about gone. Even low-priced ties have a look of luxury and elegance.

The rodeo arrived here yesterday. A fifteen-car special train from Fort Madison, Iowa, pulled in at the West Side railroad yards, Eleventh Avenue and Forty-first Street, shortly after noon. By 5 P. M., 210 "wild horses," eighty-five "untamed" Brahma bulls, seventy steers, eighty-five calves, sixty saddle horses and 226 riders were in their quarters at Madison Square Garden.

OVER the porch doorway of Richard Bissell's home in Connecticut there is the nameplate from the pilot house of the Mississippi sternwheeler Aquila. In his river days Mr. Bissell once piloted her. and when she sank beneath the waters off Dubuque he bought the name. the bell and other items as a sentimental gesture to memory.

A GREAT - GRANDDAUGHTER writing the story of her great-grandfather is not, generally speaking, cause for celebration. In Boston such books have always appeared in such profusion that they are dismissed as "grandfather biographies" and their authors are said to suffer from an acute Boston malady known as "grandfather on the brain."

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 25 (AP) -- George Byers Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, who saw his world record in the seven-liter speed-boat class broken earlier today, took it back with a speed of 114.6605 miles per hour.

THE ancient school once known as King's College, which left behind its old name and its cramped downtown quarters for the grandeur of Morningside Heights, this year is celebrating the two hundredth anniversary of its founding.
PARIS, Sept. 25 (UP) -- United States civilians living in France were warned today they may be drafted into the French Army.

IF Charles Dillon Stengel isn't careful, he's likely to be stuck with the job of managing the Yankees for the rest of his life. But is that bad? Hardly. Stengel signed another two-year contract the other day and it's a great relief to know that this amiable character will be spraying the near-by landscape with scrambled syntax for the next few seasons.

THE heart of Hollywood whose arteries are by this time perhaps slightly strictured to the movie premiere, is about to receive a shot of a different kind of dramatic adrenalin. The premiere of the Huntington Hartford Theatre as a new major legitimate house tomorrow night marks a twenty-five-year rarity in the United States.

University of California scientists find that air pollutants, called "smog," that cause eyes to water also upset the delicate feeding mechanism of plants. Smog decreases the permeability of plant tissue, which is exactly what happens in eyes.

In the forthcoming Gubernatorial election, the Democrats can count on pluralities in New York City, which they have held in every state election for more than a quarter of a century, and the Republicans can count on pluralities upstate which they have lost only twice (1930 and 1934) in twenty-five years.

IN the aftermath of Hurricanes Carol and Edna, many a feminine voice still complains that giving women's names to storms libles the ladies in general. "I resent the idea and think it's insulting," writes a New Orleans matron to a newspaper, adding that she'd rather have an unnamed hurricane hit her house than one which may recall one of her husband's old flames.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Colgate clearly outplayed favored Cornell for a 19-14 victory in the opening game of the season for both teams today. With Guy Martin, a sophomore quarterback, cleverly directing the split attack for the full sixty minutes in the place of the renowned Dick Lalla, the Red Raiders scored a touchdown in each of the first three periods for a 19-0 lead.
UNDER a resolution passed by the International Air Transport Association last year, and brought into effect now, low-cost charter flights across the North Atlantic for students have been ended.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Richard W. Adams, 19-year-old Yale sophomore, is contributing greatly to the gaiety of life in New Canaan by writing, directing and shooting his own motion picture.
PROVIDENCE, Sept. 25 -- Brown defeated Columbia, 18 to 7, today in the Ivy League's opening football contest of the season.
